most people today , even those who know very little about microbiology , be familiar with the concept of microbe , or “ germ , " and - pron - role in human health .
schoolchildren learn about bacteria , virus , and other microorganism , and many even view specimen under a microscope .
but a few hundred year ago , before the invention of the microscope , the existence of many type of microbe be impossible to prove .
by definition , microorganism , or microbe , be very small organism  many type of microbe be too small to see without a microscope , although some parasite and fungi be visible to the naked eye .
human have be live with - and use - microorganism for much long than - pron - have be able to see - pron - .
historical evidence suggest that human have have some notion of microbial life since prehistoric time and have use that knowledge to develop food as well as prevent and treat disease .
in this section , - pron - will explore some of the historical application of microbiology as well as the early beginning of microbiology as a science .
fermented foods and beverage people across the world have enjoy ferment food and beverage like beer , wine , bread , yogurt , cheese , and pickle vegetable for all of record history .
discovery from several archeological site suggest that even prehistoric people take advantage of fermentation to preserve and enhance the taste of food .
archaeologist study pottery jar from a neolithic village in china find that people be make a ferment beverage from rice , honey , and fruit as early as seven  zero  zero  zero bc . [ two ] production of these food and beverage require microbial fermentation , a process that use bacteria , mold , or yeast to convert sugar ( carbohydrate ) to alcohol , gas , and organic acid
( figure one  .  three ) .
while - pron - be likely that people first learn about fermentation by accident - perhaps by drink old milk that have curdle or old grape juice that have ferment - - pron - later learn to harness the power of fermentation to make product like bread , cheese , and wine .

meningitis have several potential cause .
- pron - can be bring on by bacteria , fungus , virus , or even a reaction to medication or exposure to heavy metal .
although people with viral meningitis usually heal on - pron - own , bacterial and fungal meningitis be quite serious and require treatment .
cora 's doctor order a lumbar puncture ( spinal tap ) to take three sample of cerebrospinal fluid ( csf ) from around the spinal cord ( figure one  .  two ) .
the sample will be send to laboratory in three different department for testing  clinical chemistry , microbiology , and hematology .
the sample will first be visually examine to determine whether the csf be abnormally colored or cloudy  then the csf will be examine under a microscope to see if - pron - contain a normal number of red and white blood cell and to check for any abnormal cell type .
in the microbiology lab , the speciman will be centrifuge to concentrate any cell in a sediment  this sediment will be smear on a slide and stain with a gram stain .
gram staining be a procedure use to differentiate between two different type of bacteria ( gram - positive and gram - negative ) .
about eight  zero % of patient with bacterial meningitis will show bacteria in - pron - csf with a gram stain . [ three ] cora 's gram stain do not show any bacteria , but - pron - doctor decide to prescribe - pron - antibiotic just in case .
part of the csf sample will be culture - put in special dish to see if bacteria or fungi will grow .
- pron - take some time for most microorganism to reproduce in sufficient quantity to be detect and analyze .

the iceman treateth prehistoric human have a very limited understanding of the cause of disease , and various culture develop different belief and explanation .
while many believe that illness be punishment for anger the god or be simply the result of fate , archaeological evidence suggest that prehistoric people attempt to treat illness and infection .
one example of this be ötzi the iceman , a five  three  zero  zero  - year - old mummy find freeze in the ice of the ötzal alps on the austrian - italian border in one  nine  nine  one .
because ötzi be so well preserve by the ice , researcher discover that - pron - be infect with the egg of the parasite trichuris trichiura , which may have cause - pron - to have abdominal pain and anemia .
researcher also find evidence of borrelia burgdorferi , a bacterium that cause lyme disease .
some researcher think ötzi may have be try to treat - pron - infection with the woody fruit of the piptoporus betulinus fungus , which be discover tie to - pron - belongings . [ five ]
this fungus have both laxative and antibiotic property .
ötzi be also cover in tattoo that be make by cut incision into - pron - skin , fill - pron - with herb , and then burn the herbs . [ six ]
there be speculation that this may have be another attempt to treat - pron - health ailment .
early notions of disease , contagion , and containment several ancient civilization appear to have have some understanding that disease could be transmit by thing - pron - could not see .
this be especially evident in historical attempt to contain the spread of disease .
for example , the bible refer to the practice of quarantine people with leprosy and other disease , suggest that people understand that disease could be communicable .
ironically , while leprosy be communicable , - pron - be also a disease that progress slowly .

the ancient greeks attribute disease to bad air , mal'aria , which - pron - call " miasmatic odor .
”
- pron - develop hygiene practice that build on this idea .
the romans also believe in the miasma hypothesis and create a complex sanitation infrastructure to deal with sewage .
in rome , - pron - build aqueduct , which bring fresh water into the city , and a giant sewer , the cloaca maxima , which carry waste away and into the river tiber ( figure one  .  four ) .
some researcher believe that this infrastructure help protect the romans from epidemic of waterborne illness .

two famous microbiologist , louis pasteur and robert koch , be especially active in advance - pron - understanding of the unseen world of microbe ( figure one  .  six ) .
pasteur , a french chemist , show that individual microbial strain have unique property and demonstrate that fermentation be cause by microorganism .
- pron - also invent pasteurization , a process use to kill microorganism responsible for spoilage , and develop vaccine for the treatment of disease , include rabie , in animal and human .
koch , a german physician , be the first to demonstrate the connection between a single , isolate microbe and a know human disease .
for example , - pron - discover the bacteria that cause anthrax ( bacillus anthracis ) , cholera ( vibrio cholera ) , and tuberculosis ( mycobacterium tuberculosis ) . [ one  zero ]
- pron - will discuss these famous microbiologist , and other , in later chapter .

chapter one  an invisible world two  one microbiology toolbox because individual microbe be generally too small to be see with the naked eye , the science of microbiology be dependent on technology that can artificially enhance the capacity of - pron - natural sens of perception .
early microbiologist like pasteur and koch have few tool at - pron - disposal than be find in modern laboratory , make - pron - discovery and innovation that much more impressive .
later chapter of this text will explore many application of technology in depth , but for now , here be a brief overview of some of the fundamental tool of the microbiology lab .

microscope produce magnify image of microorganism , human cell and tissue , and many other type of specimen too small to be observe with the naked eye .

stain and dye be use to add color to microbe so - pron - can be better observe under a microscope .
some dye can be use on live microbe , whereas other require that the specimen be fix with chemical or heat before staining .
some stain only work on certain type of microbe because of difference in - pron - cellular chemical composition .
 growth medium be use to grow microorganism in a lab setting .
some medium be liquid  other be more solid or gel - like .
a growth medium provide nutrient , include water , various salt , a source of carbon ( like glucose ) , and a source of nitrogen and amino acid ( like yeast extract ) so microorganism can grow and reproduce .
ingredient in a growth medium can be modify to grow unique type of microorganism .

a petri dish be a flat - lidded dish that be typically one  zero – one  one centimeter ( cm ) in diameter and one – one  .  five cm high .
petri dish make out of either plastic or glass be use to hold growth medium ( figure one  .  seven ) .

test tube be cylindrical plastic or glass tube with round bottom and open top .
- pron - can be use to grow microbe in broth , or semisolid or solid growth medium .

a bunsen burner be a metal apparatus that create a flame that can be use to sterilize piece of equipment .
a rubber tube carry gas ( fuel ) to the burner .
in many lab , bunsen burner be be phase out in favor of infrared microincinerator , which serve a similar purpose without the safety risk of an open flame .

an inoculation loop be a handheld tool that end in a small wire loop ( figure one  .  seven ) .
the loop can be use to streak microorganism on agar in a petri dish or to transfer - pron - from one test tube to another .
before each use , the inoculation loop must be sterilize so culture do not become contaminate .

a systematic approach learning objectives
 describe how microorganism be classify and distinguished as unique specie  compare historical and current system of taxonomy use to classify microorganism
once microbe become visible to human with the help of microscope , scientist begin to realize - pron - enormous diversity .
microorganism vary in all sort of way , include - pron - size , - pron - appearance , and - pron - rate of reproduction .
to study this incredibly diverse new array of organism , researcher need a way to systematically organize - pron - .
the science of taxonomy taxonomy be the classification , description , identification , and naming of live organism .
classification be the practice of organize organism into different group base on - pron - share characteristic .
the most famous early taxonomist be a swedish botanist , zoologist , and physician name carolus linnaeus ( one  seven  zero  one – one  seven  seven  eight ) .
in one  seven  three  five , linnaeus publish systema naturae , an one  one  - page booklet in which - pron - propose the linnaean taxonomy , a system of categorize and name organism use a standard format so scientist could discuss organism use consistent terminology .
- pron - continue to revise and add to the book , which grow into multiple volume
( figure one  .  eight ) .
chapter one  an invisible world two  three figure one  .  eight swedish botanist , zoologist , and physician carolus linnaeus develop a new system for categorize plant and animal .
in this one  eight  five  three portrait by hendrik hollander , linnaeus be hold a twinflower , name linnaea borealis in - pron - honor .
in - pron - taxonomy , linnaeus divide the natural world into three kingdom  animal , plant , and mineral ( the mineral kingdom be later abandon ) .
within the animal and plant kingdom , - pron - group organism use a hierarchy of increasingly specific level and sublevel base on - pron - similarity .
the name of the level in linnaeus 's original taxonomy be kingdom , class , order , family , genus ( plural  genera ) , and specie .
specie be , and continue to be , the most specific and basic taxonomic unit .
evolve trees of life ( phylogeny )
with advance in technology , other scientist gradually make refinement to the linnaean system and eventually create new system for classify organism .
in the one  eight  zero  zero , there be a grow interest in develop taxonomy that take into account the evolutionary relationship , or phylogeny , of all different specie of organism on earth .
one way to depict these relationship be via a diagram call a phylogenetic tree ( or tree of life ) .
in these diagram , group of organism be arrange by how closely related - pron - be think to be .
in early phylogenetic tree , the relatedness of organism be infer by - pron - visible similarity , such as the presence or absence of hair or the number of limb .
now , the analysis be more complicated .
today , phylogenic analysis include genetic , biochemical , and embryological comparison , as will be discuss later in this chapter .
linnaeus 's tree of life contain just two main branch for all live thing  the animal and plant kingdom .
in one  eight  six  six , ernst haeckel , a german biologist , philosopher , and physician , propose another kingdom , protista , for unicellular organism ( figure one  .  nine ) .
- pron - later propose a fourth kingdom , monera , for unicellular organism whose cell lack nucleus , like bacteria .

ernst haeckel 's rendering of the tree of life , from - pron - one  eight  six  six book general morphology of organisms , contain three kingdom  plantae , protista , and animalia .
- pron - later add a fourth kingdom , monera , for unicellular organism lack a nucleus .
nearly one  zero  zero year later , in one  nine  six  nine , american ecologist robert whittaker ( one  nine  two  zero – one  nine  eight  zero ) propose add another kingdom - fungi - in - pron - tree of life .
whittaker 's tree also contain a level of categorization above the kingdom level
- the empire or superkingdom level - to distinguish between organism that have membrane - bind nucleus in - pron - cell ( eukaryote ) and those that do not ( prokaryote ) .
empire prokaryota contain just the kingdom monera .
the empire eukaryota contain the other four kingdom  fungi , protista , plantae , and animalia .
whittaker 's fivekingdom tree be consider the standard phylogeny for many year .

note that virus be not find in any of these tree .
that be because - pron - be not make up of cell and thus - pron - be difficult to determine where - pron - would fit into a tree of life .

the role of genetics in modern taxonomy haeckel 's and whittaker 's tree present hypothesis about the phylogeny of different organism base on readily observable characteristic .
but the advent of molecular genetic in the late two  zero th century reveal other way to organize phylogenetic tree .
genetic method allow for a standardized way to compare all live organism without rely on observable characteristic that can often be subjective .
modern taxonomy rely heavily on compare the nucleic acid ( deoxyribonucleic acid [ dna ] or ribonucleic acid [ rna ] ) or protein from different organism .
the more similar the nucleic acid and protein be between two organism , the more closely related - pron - be consider to be .
in the one  nine  seven  zero , american microbiologist carl woese discover what appear to be a " living record " of the evolution of organism .
- pron - and - pron - collaborator george fox create a genetics - base tree of life base on similarity and difference - pron - observe in the gene sequence code for small subunit ribosomal rna ( rrna ) of different organism .
in the process , - pron - discover that a certain type of bacteria , call archaebacteria ( now know simply as archaea ) , be significantly different from other bacteria and eukaryote in term of - pron - small subunit rrna gene sequence .
to accommodate this difference , - pron - create a tree with three domains above the level of kingdom 
archaea , bacteria , and eukarya ( figure one  .  one  one ) .
analysis of small subunit rrna gene sequence suggest archaea , bacteria , and eukaryote all evolve from a common ancestral cell type .
the tree be skewed to show a closer evolutionary relationship between archaea and eukarya than - pron - have to bacteria .
figure one  .  one  one woese and fox 's phylogenetic tree contain three domain  bacteria , archaea , and eukarya .
domains archaea and bacteria contain all prokaryotic organism , and eukarya contain all eukaryotic organism .
( credit  modification of work by eric gaba )
scientist continue to use analysis of rna , dna , and protein to determine how organism be relate .
one interesting , and complicating , discovery be that of horizontal gene transfer - when a gene of one specie be absorb into another organism 's genome .
horizontal gene transfer be especially common in microorganism and can make - pron - difficult to determine how organism be evolutionarily relate .
consequently , some scientist now think in term of " webs of life " rather than “ tree of life .
"

name microbes
in develop - pron - taxonomy , linnaeus use a system of binomial nomenclature , a two - word naming system for identify organism by genus and specie .
for example , modern human be in the genus homo and have the specie name sapien , so - pron - scientific name in binomial nomenclature be homo sapien .
in binomial nomenclature , the genus part of the name be always capitalize  - pron - be follow by the specie name , which be not capitalize .
both name be italicize .
taxonomic name in the one  eight th through two  zero th century be typically derive from latin , since that be the common language use by scientist when taxonomic system be first create .
today , newly discover organism can be give name derive from latin , greek , or english .
sometimes these name reflect some distinctive trait of the organism  in other case , microorganism be name after the scientist who discover - pron - .
the archaeon haloquadratum walsbyi be an example of both of these naming scheme .
the genus , haloquadratum , describe the microorganism 's saltwater habitat ( halo be derive from the greek word for “ salt " ) as well as the arrangement of - pron - square cell , which be arrange in square cluster of four cell ( quadratum be latin for “ foursquare " ) .
the specie , walsbyi , be name after anthony edward walsby , the microbiologist who discover haloquadratum walsbyi in in one  nine  eight  zero .
while - pron - may seem easy to give an organism a common descriptive name - like a redheaded woodpecker - - pron - can imagine how that could become problematic .
what happen when another species of woodpecker with red head coloring be discover ?
the systematic nomenclature scientist use eliminate this potential problem by assign each organism a single , unique two - word name that be recognize by scientist all over the world .
in this text , - pron - will typically abbreviate an organism 's genus and specie after - pron - first mention .
the abbreviate form be simply the first initial of the genus , follow by a period and the full name of the specie .
for example , the bacterium escherichia coli be shorten to e . coli in - pron - abbreviate form .
- pron - will encounter this same convention in other scientific text as well .
bergey 's manuals
whether in a tree or a web , microbe can be difficult to identify and classify .
without easily observable macroscopic feature like feather , foot , or fur , scientist must capture , grow , and devise way to study - pron - biochemical property to differentiate and classify microbe .
despite these hurdle , a group of microbiologist create and update a set of manual for identify and classify microorganism .
first publish in one  nine  two  three and since update many time , bergey 's manual of determinative bacteriology and bergey 's manual of systematic bacteriology be the standard reference for identify and classify different prokaryote .
( appendix d of this textbook be partly base on bergey 's manual  - pron - show how the organism that appear in this textbook be classify . )
because so many bacteria look identical , method base on nonvisual characteristic must be use to identify - pron - .
for example , biochemical test can be use to identify chemical unique to certain specie .
likewise , serological test can be use to identify specific antibody that will react against the protein find in certain specie .
ultimately , dna and rrna sequencing can be use both for identify a particular bacterial specie and for classifying newly discover specie .

- pron - have a wide range of metabolic capability and can grow in a variety of environment , use different combination of nutrient .
some bacteria be photosynthetic , such as oxygenic cyanobacteria and anoxygenic green sulfur and green nonsulfur bacteria  these bacteria use energy derive from sunlight , and fix carbon dioxide for growth .
other type of bacteria be nonphotosynthetic , obtain - pron - energy from organic or inorganic compound in - pron - environment .
archaea be also unicellular prokaryotic organism .
archaea and bacteria have different evolutionary history , as well as significant difference in genetic , metabolic pathway , and the composition of - pron - cell wall and membrane .
unlike most bacteria , archaeal cell wall do not contain peptidoglycan , but - pron - cell wall be often compose of a similar substance call pseudopeptidoglycan .
like bacteria , archaea be find in nearly every habitat on earth , even extreme environment that be very cold , very hot , very basic , or very acidic ( figure one  .  one  four ) .
some archaea live in the human body , but none have be show to be human pathogen .

eukaryotic microorganisms
the domain eukarya contain all eukaryote , include uni - or multicellular eukaryote such as protist , fungus , plant , and animal .
the major defining characteristic of eukaryote be that - pron - cell contain a nucleus .
protist protists be an informal grouping of eukaryote that be not plant , animal , or fungi .
algae and protozoa be example of protist .
algae ( singular  alga ) be protist that can be either unicellular or multicellular and vary widely in size , appearance , and habitat ( figure one  .  one  five ) .
- pron - cell be surround by cell wall make of cellulose , a type of carbohydrate .
algae be photosynthetic organism that extract energy from the sun and release oxygen and carbohydrate into - pron - environment .
because other organism can use - pron - waste product for energy , algae be important part of many ecosystem .
many consumer product contain ingredient derive from algae , such as carrageenan or alginic acid , which be find in some brand of ice cream , salad dressing , beverage , lipstick , and toothpaste .
a derivative of algae also play a prominent role in the microbiology laboratory .
agar , a gel derive from algae , can be mix with various nutrient and use to grow microorganism in a petri dish .
algae be also be develop as a possible source for biofuel .

how be virus different from other microorganism ?
microbiology as a field of study microbiology be a broad term that encompass the study of all different type of microorganism .
but in practice , microbiologist tend to specialize in one of several subfield .
for example , bacteriology be the study of bacteria  mycology be the study of fungi  protozoology be the study of protozoa  parasitology be the study of helminth and other parasite  and virology be the study of virus ( figure one  .  two  one ) .
immunology , the study of the immune system , be often include in the study of microbiology because host – pathogen interaction be central to - pron - understanding of infectious disease process .
microbiologist can also specialize in certain area of microbiology , such as clinical microbiology , environmental microbiology , applied microbiology , or food microbiology .
in this textbook , - pron - be primarily concerned with clinical application of microbiology , but since the various subfield of microbiology be highly interrelated , - pron - will often discuss application that be not strictly clinical .

( credit  u . s . fish and wildlife service ) bioethics in microbiology
in the one  nine  four  zero , the u . s . government be look for a solution to a medical problem  the prevalence of sexually transmit disease ( std ) among soldier .
several now - infamous government - fund study use human subject to research common std and treatment .
in one such study , american researcher intentionally expose more than one  three  zero  zero human subject in guatemala to syphilis , gonorrhea , and chancroid to determine the ability of penicillin and other antibiotic to combat these disease .
subject of the study include guatemalan soldier , prisoner , prostitute , and psychiatric patient - none of whom be inform that - pron - be take part in the study .
researcher expose subject to std by various method , from facilitate intercourse with infect prostitute to inoculate subject with the bacteria know to cause the disease .
this latter method involve make a small wound on the subject 's genital or elsewhere on the body , and then put bacteria directly into the wound . [ one  three ]
in two  zero  one  one , a u . s . government commission task with investigate the experiment reveal that only some of the subject be treat with penicillin , and eight  three subject die by one  nine  five  three , likely as a result of the study . [ one  four ]
unfortunately , this be one of many horrific example of microbiology experiment that have violate basic ethical standard .
even if this study have lead to a life - save medical breakthrough ( - pron - do not ) , few would argue that - pron - method be ethically sound or morally justifiable .
but not every case be so clear cut .
professional work in clinical setting be frequently confront with ethical dilemma , such as work with patient who decline a vaccine or life - save blood transfusion .
these be just two example of life - and - death decision that eye on ethics chapter one  an invisible world three  seven may intersect with the religious and philosophical belief of both the patient and the health - care professional .
no matter how noble the goal , microbiology study and clinical practice must be guide by a certain set of ethical principle .
study must be do with integrity .
patient and research subject provide informed consent ( not only agree to be treat or study but demonstrate an understanding of the purpose of the study and any risk involve ) .
patient ' right must be respect .
procedure must be approve by an institutional review board .
when work with patient , accurate record - keeping , honest communication , and confidentiality be paramount .
animal use for research must be treat humanely , and all protocol must be approve by an institutional animal care and use committee .
these be just a few of the ethical principle explore in the eye on ethics box throughout this book .
resolution cora 's csf sample show no sign of inflammation or infection , as would be expect with a viral infection .
however , there be a high concentration of a particular protein , one  four - three - three protein , in - pron - csf .
an electroencephalogram ( eeg ) of - pron - brain function be also abnormal .
the eeg resemble that of a patient with a neurodegenerative disease like alzheimer 's or huntington 's , but cora 's rapid cognitive decline be not consistent with either of these .
instead , - pron - doctor conclude that cora have creutzfeldt - jakob disease ( cjd ) , a type of transmissible spongiform encephalopathy ( tse ) .
cjd be an extremely rare disease , with only about three  zero  zero case in the united states each year .
- pron - be not cause by a bacterium , fungus , or virus , but rather by prion - which do not fit neatly into any particular category of microbe .
like virus , prion be not find on the tree of life because - pron - be acellular .
prion be extremely small , about one - tenth the size of a typical virus .
- pron - contain no genetic material and be compose solely of a type of abnormal protein .
cjd can have several different cause .
- pron - can be acquire through exposure to the brain or nervoussystem tissue of an infected person or animal .
consume meat from an infected animal be one way such exposure can occur .
there have also be rare case of exposure to cjd through contact with contaminate surgical equipment[ one  five ] and from cornea and growth - hormone donor who unknowingly have cjd . [ one  six ][ one  seven ]
in rare case , the disease result from a specific genetic mutation that can sometimes be hereditary .
however , in approximately eight  five % of patient with cjd , the cause of the disease be spontaneous ( or sporadic ) and have no identifiable cause . [ one  eight ] base on - pron - symptom and - pron - rapid progression , cora be diagnose with sporadic cjd .
unfortunately for cora , cjd be a fatal disease for which there be no approve treatment .
approximately nine  zero % of patient die within one year of diagnosis . [ one  nine ]
- pron - doctor focus on limit - pron - pain and cognitive symptom as - pron - disease progress .
eight month later , cora die .
- pron - cjd diagnosis be confirm with a brain autopsy .

what - pron - ancestor knew  microorganisms ( or microbe ) be live organism that be generally too small to be see without a microscope .

throughout history , human have use microbe to make fermented food such as beer , bread , cheese , and wine .

long before the invention of the microscope , some people theorize that infection and disease be spread by live thing that be too small to be see .
- pron - also correctly intuit certain principle regard the spread of disease and immunity .
 antonie van leeuwenhoek , use a microscope , be the first to actually describe observation of bacteria , in one  six  seven  five .

during the golden age of microbiology ( one  eight  five  seven – one  nine  one  four ) , microbiologist , include louis pasteur and robert koch , discover many new connection between the field of microbiology and medicine .
one  .  two
a systematic approach

carolus linnaeus develop a taxonomic system for categorize organism into related group .

binomial nomenclature assign organism latinize scientific name with a genus and specie designation .

a phylogenetic tree be a way of show how different organism be think to be relate to one another from an evolutionary standpoint .

the first phylogenetic tree contain kingdom for plant and animal  ernst haeckel propose add kingdom for protist .

robert whittaker 's tree contain five kingdom  animalia , plantae , protista , fungi , and monera .

carl woese use small subunit ribosomal rna to create a phylogenetic tree that group organism into three domain base on - pron - genetic similarity .

bergey 's manual of determinative and systemic bacteriology be the standard reference for identify and classify bacteria , respectively .

bacteria can be identify through biochemical test , dna / rna analysis , and serological testing method .
one  .  three type of microorganisms 
microorganisms be very diverse and be find in all three domain of life 
archaea , bacteria , and eukarya .

archaea and bacteria be classify as prokaryote because - pron - lack a cellular nucleus .
archaea differ from bacteria in evolutionary history , genetic , metabolic pathway , and cell wall and membrane composition .

archaea inhabit nearly every environment on earth , but no archaea have be identify as human pathogen .

eukaryotes study in microbiology include algae , protozoa , fungus , and helminth .

algae be plant - like organism that can be either unicellular or multicellular , and derive energy via photosynthesis .

protozoa be unicellular organism with complex cell structure  most be motile .
 microscopic fungi include mold and yeast .

helminth be multicellular parasitic worm .
- pron - be include in the field of microbiology because - pron - egg and larvae be often microscopic .

virus be acellular microorganism that require a host to reproduce .

the field of microbiology be extremely broad .
microbiologist typically specialize in one of many subfield , but all health professional need a solid foundation in clinical microbiology .

the properties of light two  .  two peering into the invisible world two  .  three instruments of microscopy
two  .  four staining microscopic specimens introduction
when - pron - look at a rainbow , - pron - color span the full spectrum of light that the human eye can detect and differentiate .
each hue represent a different frequency of visible light , process by - pron - eye and brain and render as red , orange , yellow , green , or one of the many other familiar color that have always be a part of the human experience .
but only recently have human develop an understanding of the property of light that allow - pron - to see image in color .
over the past several century , - pron - have learn to manipulate light to peer into previously invisible world - those too small or too far away to be see by the naked eye .
through a microscope , - pron - can examine microbial cell and colony , use various technique to manipulate color , size , and contrast in way that help - pron - identify specie and diagnose disease .
figure two  .  one illustrate how - pron - can apply the property of light to visualize and magnify image  but these stunning micrograph be just two example of the numerous type of image - pron - be now able to produce with different microscopic technology .
this chapter explore how various type of microscope manipulate light in order to provide a window into the world of microorganism .
by understand how various kind of microscope work , - pron - can produce highly detailed image of microbe that can be useful for both research and clinical application .

light visible light consist of electromagnetic wave that behave like other wave .
hence , many of the property of light that be relevant to microscopy can be understand in term of light 's behavior as a wave .
an important property of light wave be the wavelength , or the distance between one peak of a wave and the next peak .
the height of each peak ( or depth of each trough ) be call the amplitude .
in contrast , the frequency of the wave be the rate of vibration of the wave , or the number of wavelength within a specified time period ( figure two  .  two ) .
figure two  .  two ( a )
the amplitude be the height of a wave , whereas the wavelength be the distance between one peak and the next .
( b )
these wave have different frequency , or rate of vibration .
the wave at the top have the low frequency , since - pron - have the few peak per unit time .
the wave at the bottom have the high frequency .
interaction of light light wave interact with material by be reflect , absorb , or transmit .
reflection occur when a wave bounce off of a material .
for example , a red piece of cloth may reflect red light to - pron - eye while absorb other color of light .
absorbance occur when a material capture the energy of a light wave .
in the case of glow - in - thedark plastic , the energy from light can be absorb and then later re - emitted as another form of phosphorescence .
transmission occur when a wave travel through a material , like light through glass ( the process of transmission be call transmittance ) .
when a material allow a large proportion of light to be transmit , - pron - may do so because - pron - be thin , or more transparent ( have more transparency and less opacity ) .

light wave can also interact with each other by interference , create complex pattern of motion .
drop two pebble into a puddle cause the wave on the puddle 's surface to interact , create complex interference pattern .
light wave can interact in the same way .
in addition to interfere with each other , light wave can also interact with small object or opening by bend or scattering .
this be call diffraction .
diffraction be large when the object be small relative to the wavelength of the light ( the distance between two consecutive peak of a light wave ) .
often , when wave diffract in different direction around an obstacle or opening , - pron - will interfere with each other .

lense and refraction
in the context of microscopy , refraction be perhaps the most important behavior exhibit by light wave .
refraction occur when light wave change direction as - pron - enter a new medium ( figure two  .  four ) .
different transparent material transmit light at different speed  thus , light can change speed when pass from one material to another .
this change in speed usually also cause a change in direction ( refraction ) , with the degree of change dependent on the angle of the incoming light .

( b )
as show in this diagram , light ray pass from one medium to another may be either refract or reflect .
the extent to which a material slow transmission speed relative to empty space be call the refractive index of that material .
large difference between the refractive index of two material will result in a large amount of refraction when light pass from one material to the other .
for example , light move much more slowly through water than through air , so light enter water from air can change direction greatly .
- pron - say that the water have a high refractive index than air ( figure two  .  five ) .
figure two  .  five
this straight pole appear to bend at an angle as - pron - enter the water .
this optical illusion be due to the large difference between the refractive index of air and water .
when light cross a boundary into a material with a high refractive index , - pron - direction turn to be close to perpendicular to the boundary ( i . e . , more toward a normal to that boundary  see figure two  .  five ) .
this be the principle behind lense .
- pron - can think of a lens as an object with a curved boundary ( or a collection of prism ) that collect all of the light that strike - pron - and refract - pron - so that - pron - all meet at a single point call the image point ( focus ) .
a convex lens can be use to magnify because - pron - can focus at close range than the human eye , produce a large image .
concave lense and mirror can also be use in microscope to redirect the light path .

electromagnetic spectrum and color visible light be just one form of electromagnetic radiation ( emr ) , a type of energy that be all around - pron - .
other form of emr include microwave , x - ray , and radio wave , among other .
the different type of emr fall on the electromagnetic spectrum , which be define in term of wavelength and frequency .
the spectrum of visible light occupy a relatively small range of frequency between infrared and ultraviolet light ( figure two  .  seven ) .

the electromagnetic spectrum range from high - frequency gamma ray to low - frequency radio wave .
visible light be the relatively small range of electromagnetic frequency that can be sense by the human eye .
on the electromagnetic spectrum , visible light fall between ultraviolet and infrared light .
( credit  modification of work by johannes ahlmann )
whereas wavelength represent the distance between adjacent peak of a light wave , frequency , in a simplified definition , represent the rate of oscillation .
wave with high frequency have short wavelength and , therefore , have more oscillation per unit time than low - frequency wave .
high - frequency wave also contain more energy than low - frequency wave .
this energy be deliver as elementary particle call photon .
high - frequency wave deliver more energetic photon than low - frequency wave .
photon with different energy interact differently with the retina .
in the spectrum of visible light , each color correspond to a particular frequency and wavelength ( figure two  .  seven  ) . the low frequency of visible light appear as the color red , whereas the high appear as the color violet .
when the retina receive visible light of many different frequency , - pron - perceive this as white light .
however , white light can be separate into - pron - component color use refraction .
if - pron - pass white light through a prism , different color will be refract in different direction , create a rainbow - like spectrum on a screen behind the prism .
this separation of color be call dispersion , and - pron - occur because , for a give material , the refractive index be different for different frequency of light .
certain material can refract nonvisible form of emr and , in effect , transform - pron - into visible light .
certain fluorescent dye , for instance , absorb ultraviolet or blue light and then use the energy to emit photon of a different color , give off light rather than simply vibrate .
this occur because the energy absorption cause electron to jump to high energy state , after which - pron - then almost immediately fall back down to - pron - ground state , emit specific amount of energy as photon .
not all of the energy be emit in a give photon , so the emitted photon will be of low energy and , thus , of low frequency than the absorb one .
thus , a dye such as texas red may be excite by blue light , but emit red light  or a dye such as fluorescein
isothiocyanate ( fitc ) may absorb ( invisible ) highenergy ultraviolet light and emit green light ( figure two  .  eight ) .
in some material , the photon may be emit follow a delay after absorption  in this case , the process be call phosphorescence .
glow - in - the - dark plastic work by use phosphorescent material .

magnification , resolution , and contrast microscopes magnify image and use the property of light to create useful image of small object .
magnification be define as the ability of a lens to enlarge the image of an object when compare to the real object .
for example , a magnification of one  zero ⨯ mean that the image appear one  zero time the size of the object as view with the naked eye .
great magnification typically improve - pron - ability to see detail of small object , but magnification alone be not sufficient to make the most useful image .
- pron - be often useful to enhance the resolution of object  the ability to tell that two separate point or object be separate .
a low - resolution image appear fuzzy , whereas a high - resolution image appear sharp .
two factor affect resolution .
the first be wavelength .
short wavelength be able to resolve small object  thus , an electron microscope have a much high resolution than a light microscope , since - pron - use an electron beam with a very short wavelength , as oppose to the long - wavelength visible light use by a light microscope .
the second factor that affect resolution be numerical aperture , which be a measure of a lens 's ability to gather light .
the high the numerical aperture , the well the resolution .
read this article ( https / / www . openstax . org / l /  two  two aperture ) to learn more about factor that can increase or decrease the numerical aperture of a lens .

who invent the microscope ?
while antonie van leeuwenhoek and robert hooke generally receive much of the credit for early advance in microscopy , neither can claim to be the inventor of the microscope .
some argue that this designation should belong to hans and zaccharias janssen , dutch spectacle - maker who may have invent the telescope , the simple microscope , and the compound microscope during the late one  five  zero  zero or early one  six  zero  zero
( figure two  .  one  one ) .
unfortunately , little be know for sure about the janssens , not even the exact date of - pron - birth and death .
the janssens be secretive about - pron - work and never publish .
- pron - be also possible that the janssens do not invent anything at all  - pron - neighbor , hans lippershey , also develop microscope and telescope during the same time frame , and - pron - be often credit with invent the telescope .
the historical record from the time be as fuzzy and imprecise as the image view through those early lense , and any archived record have be lose over the century .
by contrast , van leeuwenhoek and hooke can thank ample documentation of - pron - work for - pron - respective legacy .
like janssen , van leeuwenhoek begin - pron - work in obscurity , leave behind few record .
however , - pron - friend , the prominent physician reinier de graaf , write a letter to the editor of the philosophical transactions of the royal society of london call attention to van leeuwenhoek 's powerful microscope .
from one  six  seven  three onward , van leeuwenhoek begin regularly submit letter to the royal society detail - pron - observation .
in one  six  seven  four , - pron - report describe single - celle organism produce controversy in the scientific community , but - pron - observation be soon confirm when the society send a delegation to investigate - pron - finding .
- pron - subsequently enjoy considerable celebrity , at one point even entertain a visit by the czar of russia .
similarly , robert hooke have - pron - observation use microscope publish by the royal society in a book call micrographia in one  six  six  five .
the book become a bestseller and greatly increase interest in microscopy throughout much of europe .

the early pioneer of microscopy open a window into the invisible world of microorganism .
but microscopy continue to advance in the century that follow .
in one  eight  three  zero , joseph jackson lister create an essentially modern light microscope .
the two  zero th century see the development of microscope that leverage nonvisible light , such as fluorescence microscopy , which use an ultraviolet light source , and electron microscopy , which use shortwavelength electron beam .
these advance lead to major improvement in magnification , resolution , and contrast .
by comparison , the relatively rudimentary microscope of van leeuwenhoek and - pron - contemporary be far less powerful than even the most basic microscope in use today .
in this section , - pron - will survey the broad range of modern microscopic technology and common application for each type of microscope .
light microscopy
many type of microscope fall under the category of light microscope , which use light to visualize image .
example of light microscope include brightfield microscope , darkfield microscope , phase - contrast microscope , differential interference contrast microscope , fluorescence microscope , confocal scan laser microscope , and two - photon microscope .
these various type of light microscope can be use to complement each other in diagnostic and research .

the brightfield microscope , perhaps the most commonly use type of microscope , be a compound microscope with two or more lense that produce a dark image on a bright background .
some brightfield microscope be monocular ( have a single eyepiece ) , though most new brightfield microscope be binocular ( have two eyepiece ) , like the one show in figure two  .  one  two  in either case , each eyepiece contain a lens call an ocular lens .
the ocular lense typically magnify image one  zero time ( one  zero ⨯ ) .
at the other end of the body tube be a set of objective lense on a rotate nosepiece .
the magnification of these objective lense typically range from four ⨯ to one  zero  zero ⨯ , with the magnification for each lens designate on the metal case of the lens .
the ocular and objective lense work together to create a magnify image .
the total magnification be the product of the ocular magnification time the objective magnification  ocular magnificatio × objective magnificatio for example , if a four  zero ⨯ objective lens be select and the ocular lens be one  zero ⨯ , the total magnification would be ( four  zero × ) (  one  zero × ) = four  zero  zero × figure two  .  one  two component of a typical brightfield microscope .
the item be view be call a specimen .
the specimen be place on a glass slide , which be then clip into place on the stage ( a platform ) of the microscope .
once the slide be secure , the speciman on the slide be position over the light use the x - y mechanical stage knob .
these knob move the slide on the surface of the stage , but do not raise or lower the stage .
once the specimen be center over the light , the stage position can be raise or lower to focus the image .
the coarse focus knob be use for large - scale movement with four ⨯ and one  zero ⨯ objective lense  the fine focus knob be use for small - scale movement , especially with four  zero ⨯ or one  zero  zero ⨯ objective lense .
when image be magnify , - pron - become dimmer because there be less light per unit area of image .
highly magnified image produce by microscope , therefore , require intense lighting .
in a brightfield microscope , this light be provide by an illuminator , which be typically a high - intensity bulb below the stage .
light from the illuminator pass up through condens lens ( locate below the stage ) , which focus all of the light ray on the speciman to maximize illumination .
the position of the condenser can be optimize use the attach condenser focus knob  once the optimal distance be establish , the condenser should not be move to adjust the brightness .

a brightfield microscope create an image by direct light from the illuminator at the speciman  this light be differentially transmit , absorb , reflect , or refract by different structure .
different color can behave differently as - pron - interact with chromophore ( pigment that absorb and reflect particular wavelength of light ) in part of the speciman .
often , chromophore be artificially add to the speciman use stain , which serve to increase contrast and resolution .
in general , structure in the speciman will appear darker , to various extent , than the bright background , create maximally sharp image at magnification up to about one  zero  zero  zero ⨯ . further magnification would create a large image , but without increase resolution .
this allow - pron - to see object as small as bacteria , which be visible at about four  zero  zero ⨯ or so , but not small object such as virus .
at very high magnification , resolution may be compromise when light pass through the small amount of air between the speciman and the lens .
this be due to the large difference between the refractive index of air and glass  the air scatter the light ray before - pron - can be focus by the lens .
to solve this problem , a drop of oil can be use to fill the space between the speciman and an oil immersion lens , a special lens design to be use with immersion oil .
since the oil have a refractive index very similar to that of glass , - pron - increase the maximum angle at which light leave the speciman can strike the lens .
this increase the light collect and , thus , the resolution of the image ( figure two  .  one  three ) .
a variety of oil can be use for different type of light .
figure two  .  one  three ( a ) oil immersion lense like this one be use to improve resolution .
( b )
because immersion oil and glass have very similar refractive index , there be a minimal amount of refraction before the light reach the lens .
without immersion oil , light scatter as - pron - pass through the air above the slide , degrade the resolution of the image .
microscope maintenance  good practices
even a very powerful microscope can not deliver high - resolution image if - pron - be not properly clean and maintain .
since lense be carefully design and manufacture to refract light with a high degree of precision , even a slightly dirty or scratched lens will refract light in unintended way , degrade the image of the speciman .
in addition , microscope be rather delicate instrument , and great care must be take to avoid damage part and surface .

darkfield microscopy
a darkfield microscope be a brightfield microscope that have a small but significant modification to the condenser .
a small , opaque disk ( about one cm in diameter ) be place between the illuminator and the condenser lens .
this opaque light stop , as the disk be call , block most of the light from the illuminator as - pron - pass through the condenser on - pron - way to the objective lens , produce a hollow cone of light that be focus on the speciman .
the only light that reach the objective be light that have be refract or reflect by structure in the speciman .
the result image typically show bright object on a dark background ( figure two  .  one  four ) .

an opaque light stop insert into a brightfield microscope be use to produce a darkfield image .
the light stop block light travel directly from the illuminator to the objective lens , allow only light reflect or refract off the speciman to reach the eye .
darkfield microscopy can often create high - contrast , high - resolution image of specimen without the use of stain , which be particularly useful for view live specimen that may be kill or otherwise compromise by the stain .
for example , thin spirochete like treponema pallidum , the causative agent of syphilis , can be best view use a darkfield microscope ( figure two  .  one  five ) .

phase - contrast microscopes phase - contrast microscope use refraction and interference cause by structure in a specimen to create highcontrast , high - resolution image without stain .
- pron - be the old and simple type of microscope that create an image by alter the wavelength of light ray pass through the speciman .
to create altered wavelength path , an annular stop be use in the condenser .
the annular stop produce a hollow cone of light that be focus on the speciman before reach the objective lens .
the objective contain a phase plate contain a phase ring .
as a result , light travel directly from the illuminator pass through the phase ring while light refract or reflect by the speciman pass through the plate .
this cause wave travel through the ring to be about one - half of a wavelength out of phase with those pass through the plate .
because wave have peak and trough , - pron - can add together ( if in phase together ) or cancel each other out ( if out of phase ) .
when the wavelength be out of phase , wave trough will cancel out wave peak , which be call destructive interference .
structure that refract light then appear dark against a bright background of only unrefracted light .
more generally , structure that differ in feature such as refractive index will differ in level of darkness ( figure two  .  one  six ) .

fluorescence microscopes
a fluorescence microscope use fluorescent chromophore call fluorochrome , which be capable of absorb energy from a light source and then emit this energy as visible light .
fluorochrome include naturally fluorescent substance ( such as chlorophyll ) as well as fluorescent stain that be add to the speciman to create contrast .
dye such as texas red and fitc be example of fluorochrome .
other example include the nucleic acid dye four ' ,  six ' - diamidino -  two  - phenylindole ( dapi ) and acridine orange .
the microscope transmit an excitation light , generally a form of emr with a short wavelength , such as ultraviolet or blue light , toward the speciman  the chromophore absorb the excitation light and emit visible light with long wavelength .
the excitation light be then filter out ( in part because ultraviolet light be harmful to the eye ) so that only visible light pass through the ocular lens .
this produce an image of the speciman in bright color against a dark background .
fluorescence microscope be especially useful in clinical microbiology .
- pron - can be use to identify pathogen , to find particular specie within an environment , or to find the location of particular molecule and structure within a cell .
approach have also be develop to distinguish live from dead cell use fluorescence microscopy base upon whether - pron - take up particular fluorochrome .
sometimes , multiple fluorochrome be use on the same speciman to show different structure or feature .
one of the most important application of fluorescence microscopy be a technique call immunofluorescence , which be use to identify certain disease - cause microbe by observe whether antibody bind to - pron - .
( antibody be protein molecule produce by the immune system that attach to specific pathogen to kill or inhibit - pron - . )
there be two approach to this technique  direct immunofluorescence assay ( dfa ) and indirect immunofluorescence assay ( ifa ) .
in dfa , specific antibody ( e . g . , those that the target the rabie virus ) be stain with a fluorochrome .

confocal microscopes
whereas other form of light microscopy create an image that be maximally focus at a single distance from the observer ( the depth , or z - plane ) , a confocal microscope use a laser to scan multiple z - plane successively .
this produce numerous two - dimensional , high - resolution image at various depth , which can be construct into a threedimensional image by a computer .
as with fluorescence microscope , fluorescent stain be generally use to increase contrast and resolution .
image clarity be further enhance by a narrow aperture that eliminate any light that be not from the z - plane .
confocal microscope be thus very useful for examine thick specimen such as biofilm , which chapter two  how - pron - see the invisible world six  one can be examine alive and unfixed ( figure two  .  two  zero ) .

two - photon microscope
while the original fluorescent and confocal microscope allow well visualization of unique feature in specimen , there be still problem that prevent optimum visualization .
the effective sensitivity of fluorescence microscopy when view thick specimen be generally limit by out - of - focus flare , which result in poor resolution .
this limitation be greatly reduce in the confocal microscope through the use of a confocal pinhole to reject out - of - focus background fluorescence with thin ( < one μm ) , unblurred optical section .
however , even the confocal microscope lack the resolution need for view thick tissue sample .
these problem be resolve with the development of the two - photon microscope , which use a scanning technique , fluorochrome , and long - wavelength light ( such as infrared ) to visualize specimen .
the low energy associate with the long - wavelength light mean that two photon must strike a location at the same time to excite the fluorochrome .
the low energy of the excitation light be less damaging to cell , and the long wavelength of the excitation light more easily penetrate deep into thick specimen .
this make the two - photon microscope useful for examine living cell within intact tissue - brain slice , embryo , whole organ , and even entire animal .
currently , use of two - photon microscope be limit to advance clinical and research laboratory because of the high cost of the instrument .
a single two - photon microscope typically cost between $ three  zero  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero and $ five  zero  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero , and the laser use to excite the dye use on specimen be also very expensive .
however , as technology improve , twophoton microscope may become more readily available in clinical setting .

scanning
probe microscopy a scan probe microscope do not use light or electron , but rather very sharp probe that be pass over the surface of the speciman and interact with - pron - directly .
this produce information that can be assemble into image with magnification up to one  zero  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero ⨯ .
such large magnification can be use to observe individual atom on surface .
to date , these technique have be use primarily for research rather than for diagnostic .
there be two type of scan probe microscope  the scan tunneling microscope ( stm ) and the atomic force microscope ( afm ) .
an stm use a probe that be pass just above the speciman as a constant voltage bias create the potential for an electric current between the probe and the speciman .
this current occur via quantum tunneling of electron between the probe and the speciman , and the intensity of the current be dependent upon the distance between the probe and the speciman .
the probe be move horizontally above the surface and the intensity of the current be measure .
scan tunneling microscopy can effectively map the structure of surface at a resolution at which individual atom can be detect .
similar to an stm , afm have a thin probe that be pass just above the speciman .
however , rather than measure variation in the current at a constant height above the speciman , an afm establish a constant current and measure variation in the height of the probe tip as - pron - pass over the speciman .
as the probe tip be pass over the speciman , force between the atom ( van der waals force , capillary force , chemical bonding , electrostatic force , and other ) cause - pron - to move up and down .
deflection of the probe tip be determine and measure use hooke 's law of elasticity , and this information be use to construct image of the surface of the speciman with resolution at the atomic level ( figure two  .  two  seven ) .
figure two  .  two  eight , figure two  .  two  nine , and figure two  .  three  zero summarize the microscopy technique for light microscope , electron microscope , and scan probe microscope , respectively .

prepare specimens for light microscopy
in clinical setting , light microscope be the most commonly use microscope .
there be two basic type of preparation use to view specimen with a light microscope  wet mount and fix specimen .
the simple type of preparation be the wet mount , in which the specimen be place on the slide in a drop of liquid .
some specimen , such as a drop of urine , be already in a liquid form and can be deposit on the slide use a dropper .
solid specimen , such as a skin scraping , can be place on the slide before add a drop of liquid to prepare the wet mount .
sometimes the liquid use be simply water , but often stain be add to enhance contrast .
once the liquid have be add to the slide , a coverslip be place on top and the speciman be ready for examination under the microscope .
the second method of prepare specimen for light microscopy be fixation .
the “ fixing " of a sample refer to the process of attach cell to a slide .
fixation be often achieve either by heat ( heat fix ) or chemically treat the speciman .
in addition to attach the speciman to the slide , fixation also kill microorganism in the speciman , stop - pron - movement and metabolism while preserve the integrity of - pron - cellular component for observation .
to heat - fix a sample , a thin layer of the speciman be spread on the slide ( call a smear ) , and the slide be then briefly heat over a heat source ( figure two  .  three  one ) .
chemical fixative be often preferable to heat for tissue specimen .
chemical agent such as acetic acid , ethanol , methanol , formaldehyde ( formalin ) , and glutaraldehyde can denature protein , stop biochemical reaction , and stabilize cell structure in tissue sample ( figure two  .  three  one ) .

in addition to fixation , staining be almost always apply to color certain feature of a specimen before examine - pron - under a light microscope .
stain , or dye , contain salt make up of a positive ion and a negative ion .
depend on the type of dye , the positive or the negative ion may be the chromophore ( the colored ion )  the other , uncolored ion be call the counterion .
if the chromophore be the positively charge ion , the stain be classify as a basic dye  if the negative ion be the chromophore , the stain be consider an acidic dye .
dye be select for staining base on the chemical property of the dye and the speciman be observe , which determine how the dye will interact with the speciman .
in most case , - pron - be preferable to use a positive stain , a dye that will be absorb by the cell or organism be observe , add color to object of interest to make - pron - stand out against the background .
however , there be scenario in which - pron - be advantageous to use a negative stain , which be absorb by the background but not by the cell or organism in the speciman .
negative staining produce an outline or silhouette of the organism against a colorful background ( figure two  .  three  two ) .

gram staining
the gram stain procedure be a differential staining procedure that involve multiple step .
- pron - be develop by danish microbiologist hans christian gram in one  eight  eight  four as an effective method to distinguish between bacteria with different type of cell wall , and even today - pron - remain one of the most frequently use staining technique .
the step of the gram stain procedure be list below and illustrate in figure two  .  three  three .
one .
first , crystal violet , a primary stain , be apply to a heat - fix smear , give all of the cell a purple color .
two .
next , gram 's iodine , a mordant , be add .
a mordant be a substance use to set or stabilize stain or dye  in this case , gram 's iodine act like a trap agent that complexe with the crystal violet , make the crystal violet – iodine complex clump and stay contain in thick layer of peptidoglycan in the cell wall .
three .
next , a decolorize agent be add , usually ethanol or an acetone / ethanol solution .
cell that have thick peptidoglycan layer in - pron - cell wall be much less affect by the decolorizing agent  - pron - generally retain the crystal violet dye and remain purple .
however , the decolorize agent more easily wash the dye out of cell with thin peptidoglycan layer , make - pron - again colorless .
four .
finally , a secondary counterstain , usually safranin , be add .
this stain the decolorized cell pink and be less noticeable in the cell that still contain the crystal violet dye .

how - pron - see the invisible world seven  three figure two  .  three  three gram - staining be a differential staining technique that use a primary stain and a secondary counterstain to distinguish between gram - positive and gram - negative bacteria .
the purple , crystal - violet stain cell be refer to as gram - positive cell , while the red , safranin - dye cell be gram - negative ( figure two  .  three  four ) .
however , there be several important consideration in interpret the result of a gram stain .
first , old bacterial cell may have damage to - pron - cell wall that cause - pron - to appear gramnegative even if the species be gram - positive .
thus , - pron - be good to use fresh bacterial culture for gram staining .
second , error such as leave on decolorizer too long can affect the result .
in some case , most cell will appear grampositive while a few appear gram - negative ( as in figure two  .  three  four ) .
this suggest damage to the individual cell or that decolorizer be leave on for too long  the cell should still be classify as gram - positive if - pron - be all the same specie rather than a mixed culture .
besides - pron - differ interaction with dye and decolorizing agent , the chemical difference between grampositive and gram - negative cell have other implication with clinical relevance .
for example , gram staining can help clinician classify bacterial pathogen in a sample into category associate with specific property .
gram - negative bacteria tend to be more resistant to certain antibiotic than gram - positive bacteria .
- pron - will discuss this and other application of gram stain in more detail in later chapter .

acid - fast stain
acid - fast staining be another commonly use , differential staining technique that can be an important diagnostic tool .
an acid - fast stain be able to differentiate two type of gram - positive cell  those that have waxy mycolic acid in - pron - cell wall , and those that do not .
two different method for acid - fast staining be the ziehl - neelsen technique and the kinyoun technique .
both use carbolfuchsin as the primary stain .
the waxy , acid - fast cell retain the carbolfuchsin even after a decolorize agent ( an acid - alcohol solution ) be apply .
a secondary counterstain , methylene blue , be then apply , which render non – acid - fast cell blue .
the fundamental difference between the two carbolfuchsin - base method be whether heat be use during the primary staining process .
the ziehl - neelsen method use heat to infuse the carbolfuchsin into the acid - fast cell , whereas the kinyoun method do not use heat .
both technique be important diagnostic tool because a number of specific disease be cause by acid - fast bacteria ( afb ) .
if afb be present in a tissue sample , - pron - red or pink color can be see clearly against the blue background of the surround tissue cell ( figure two  .  three  six ) .

why be acid - fast stain useful ?
use microscopy to diagnose tuberculosis mycobacterium tuberculosis , the bacterium that cause tuberculosis , can be detect in specimen base on the presence of acid - fast bacilli .

endospore staining endospores be structure produce within certain bacterial cell that allow - pron - to survive harsh condition .

microscopy and antibiotic resistance
as the use of antibiotic have proliferate in medicine , as well as agriculture , microbe have evolve to become more resistant .
strain of bacteria such as methicillin - resistant s . aureus ( mrsa ) , which have develop a high level of resistance to many antibiotic , be an increasingly worrying problem , so much so that research be underway to develop new and more diversified antibiotic .
fluorescence microscopy can be useful in test the effectiveness of new antibiotic against resistant strain like mrsa .
in a test of one new antibiotic derive from a marine bacterium , mc two  one  - a ( bromophene ) , researcher use the fluorescent dye sytox green to stain sample of mrsa .

of course , some argue that develop new antibiotic will only lead to even more antibiotic - resistant microbe , so - call superbug that could spawn epidemic before new treatment can be develop .
for this reason , many health professional be begin to exercise more discretion in prescribe antibiotic .
whereas antibiotic be once routinely prescribe for common illness without a definite diagnosis , doctor and hospital be much more likely to conduct additional testing to determine whether an antibiotic be necessary and appropriate before prescribe .
a sick patient may reasonably object to this stingy approach to prescribing antibiotic .
to the patient who simply want to feel well as quickly as possible , the potential benefit of take an antibiotic may seem to outweigh any immediate health risk that may occur if the antibiotic be ineffective .
but at what point do the risk of widespread antibiotic use supersede the desire to use - pron - in individual case ?
summary two  .  one
the properties of light 
light wave interact with material may be reflect , absorb , or transmit , depend on the property of the material .

light wave can interact with each other ( interference ) or be distort by interaction with small object or opening ( diffraction ) .

refraction occur when light wave change speed and direction as - pron - pass from one medium to another .
difference in the refraction index of two material determine the magnitude of directional change when light pass from one to the other .

a lens be a medium with a curved surface that refract and focus light to produce an image .
 visible light be part of the electromagnetic spectrum  light wave of different frequency and wavelength be distinguish as color by the human eye .

a prism can separate the color of white light ( dispersion ) because different frequency of light have different refractive index for a give material .

fluorescent dye and phosphorescent material can effectively transform nonvisible electromagnetic radiation into visible light .

the power of a microscope can be describe in term of - pron - magnification and resolution .

resolution can be increase by shorten wavelength , increase the numerical aperture of the lens , or use stain that enhance contrast .
two  .  two peer into the invisible world  antonie van leeuwenhoek be credit with the first observation of microbe , include protist and bacteria , with simple microscope that - pron - make .

robert hooke be the first to describe what - pron - now call cell .

simple microscope have a single lens , while compound microscope have multiple lense .
two  .  three instrument of microscopy 
numerous type of microscope use various technology to generate micrograph .
most be useful for a particular type of specimen or application .

light microscopy use lense to focus light on a specimen to produce an image .
commonly use light microscope include brightfield , darkfield , phase - contrast , differential interference contrast , eight  four chapter two  how - pron - see the invisible world
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five fluorescence , confocal , and two - photon microscope .
 electron microscopy focus electron on the speciman use magnet , produce much great magnification than light microscopy .
the transmission electron microscope ( tem ) and scan electron microscope ( sem ) be two common form .

scanning probe microscopy produce image of even great magnification by measure feedback from sharp probe that interact with the specimen .
probe microscope include the scanning tunneling microscope ( stm ) and the atomic force microscope ( afm ) .
two  .  four staining microscopic specimens

samples must be properly prepare for microscopy .
this may involve staining , fixation , and / or cut thin section .

a variety of stain technique can be use with light microscopy , include gram staining , acid - fast staining , capsule staining , endospore staining , and flagella staining .

samples for tem require very thin section , whereas sample for sem require sputter - coating .

preparation for fluorescence microscopy be similar to that for light microscopy , except that fluorochrome be use .

chapter outline three  .  one spontaneous generation three  .  two foundations of modern cell theory three  .  three unique characteristics of prokaryotic cells three  .  four unique characteristics of eukaryotic cells
introduction life take many form , from giant redwood tree tower hundred of foot in the air to the tiny know microbe , which measure only a few billionth of a meter .
human have long ponder life 's origin and debate the defining characteristic of life , but - pron - understanding of these concept have change radically since the invention of the microscope .
in the one  seven th century , observation of microscopic life lead to the development of the cell theory  the idea that the fundamental unit of life be the cell , that all organism contain at least one cell , and that cell only come from other cell .
despite share certain characteristic , cell may vary significantly .
the two main type of cell be prokaryotic cell ( lack a nucleus ) and eukaryotic cell ( contain a well - organize , membrane - bind nucleus ) .
each type of cell exhibit remarkable variety in structure , function , and metabolic activity
( figure three  .  one ) .
this chapter will focus on the historical discovery that have shape - pron - current understanding of microbe , include - pron - origin and - pron - role in human disease .
- pron - will then explore the distinguish structure find in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell .

explain the theory of spontaneous generation and why people once accept - pron - as an explanation for the existence of certain type of organism 
explain how certain individual ( van helmont , redi , needham , spallanzani , and pasteur ) try to prove or disprove spontaneous generation human have be ask for millennia  where do new life come from ?
religion , philosophy , and science have all wrestle with this question .
one of the old explanation be the theory of spontaneous generation , which can be trace back to the ancient greeks and be widely accept through the middle ages .
the theory of spontaneous generation
the greek philosopher aristotle ( three  eight  four – three  two  two bc ) be one of the early record scholar to articulate the theory of spontaneous generation , the notion that life can arise from nonlive matter .
aristotle propose that life arise from nonlive material if the material contain pneuma ( " vital heat " ) .
as evidence , - pron - note several instance of the appearance of animal from environment previously devoid of such animal , such as the seemingly sudden appearance of fish in a new puddle of water . [ one ]
this theory persist into the one  seven th century , when scientist undertake additional experimentation to support or disprove - pron - .
by this time , the proponent of the theory cite how frog simply seem to appear along the muddy bank of the nile river in egypt during the annual flooding .
other observe that mouse simply appear among grain store in barn with thatched roof .
when the roof leak and the grain mold , mouse appear .
jan baptista van helmont , a one  seven th century flemish scientist , propose that mouse could arise from rag and wheat kernel leave in an open container for three week .
in reality , such habitat provide ideal food source and shelter for mouse population to flourish .
however , one of van helmont 's contemporary , italian physician francesco redi ( one  six  two  six – one  six  nine  seven ) , perform an experiment in one  six  six  eight that be one of the first to refute the idea that maggot ( the larvae of fly ) spontaneously generate on meat leave out in the open air .
- pron - predict that prevent fly from have direct contact with the meat would also prevent the appearance of maggot .
redi leave meat in each of six container ( figure three  .  two ) .
two be open to the air , two be cover with gauze , and two be tightly seal .
- pron - hypothesis be support when maggot develop in the uncovered jar , but no maggot appear in either the gauze - cover or the tightly seal jar .
- pron - conclude that maggot could only form when fly be allow to lay egg in the meat , and that the maggot be the offspring of fly , not the product of spontaneous generation .
