disprove spontaneous generation
the debate over spontaneous generation continue well into the one  nine th century , with scientist serve as proponent of both side .
to settle the debate , the paris academy of sciences offer a prize for resolution of the problem .
louis pasteur , a prominent french chemist who have be study microbial fermentation and the cause of wine spoilage , accept the challenge .
in one  eight  five  eight , pasteur filter air through a gun - cotton filter and , upon microscopic examination of the cotton , find - pron - full of microorganism , suggest that the exposure of a broth to air be not introduce a " life force " to the broth but rather airborne microorganism .
later , pasteur make a series of flask with long , twisted neck ( " swan - neck " flask ) , in which - pron - boil broth to sterilize - pron - ( figure three  .  four ) .
- pron - design allow air inside the flask to be exchange with air from the outside , but prevent the introduction of any airborne microorganism , which would get catch in the twist and bend of the flask ' neck .
if a life force besides the airborne microorganism be responsible for microbial growth within the sterilize flask , - pron - would have access to the broth , whereas the microorganism would not .
- pron - correctly predict that sterilize broth in - pron - swan - neck flask would remain sterile as long as the swan neck remain intact .
however , should the neck be break , microorganism would be introduce , contaminate the flask and allow microbial growth within the broth .
pasteur 's set of experiment irrefutably disprove the theory of spontaneous generation and earn - pron - the prestigious alhumbert prize from the paris academy of sciences in one  eight  six  two .
in a subsequent lecture in one  eight  six  four , pasteur articulate "
omne vivum ex vivo
" ( “ life only come from life " ) .
in this lecture , pasteur recount - pron - famous swanneck flask experiment , state that " … life be a germ and a germ be life .
never will the doctrine of spontaneous generation recover from the mortal blow of this simple experiment . ”[ four ]
to pasteur 's credit , - pron - never have .

modern cell theory have two basic tenet 
 all cell only come from other cell ( the principle of biogenesis ) .

cell be the fundamental unit of organism .
today , these tenet be fundamental to - pron - understanding of life on earth .
however , modern cell theory grow out of the collective work of many scientist .
the origins of cell theory
the english scientist robert hooke first use the term “ cell " in one  six  six  five to describe the small chamber within cork that - pron - observe under a microscope of - pron - own design .
to hooke , thin section of cork resemble “ honey - comb , " or “ small boxes or bladders of air .
"
- pron - note that each “ cavern , bubble , or cell " be distinct from the other ( figure three  .  five ) .
at the time , hooke be not aware that the cork cell be long dead and , therefore , lack the internal structure find within live cell .
figure three  .  five robert hooke ( one  six  three  five – one  seven  zero  three ) be the first to describe cell base upon - pron - microscopic observation of cork .
this illustration be publish in - pron - work micrographia .
despite hooke 's early description of cell , - pron - significance as the fundamental unit of life be not yet recognize .
nearly two  zero  zero year later , in one  eight  three  eight , matthias schleiden ( one  eight  zero  four – one  eight  eight  one ) , a german botanist who make extensive microscopic observation of plant tissue , describe - pron - as be compose of cell .
visualize plant cell be relatively easy because plant cell be clearly separate by - pron - thick cell wall .
schleiden believe that cell form through crystallization , rather than cell division .
theodor schwann ( one  eight  one  zero – one  eight  eight  two ) , a noted german physiologist , make similar microscopic observation of animal tissue .
in one  eight  three  nine , after a conversation with schleiden , schwann realize that similarity exist between plant and nine  four chapter three
 the cell
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five animal tissue .
this lay the foundation for the idea that cell be the fundamental component of plant and animal .
in the one  eight  five  zero s , two polish scientist live in germany push this idea further , culminate in what - pron - recognize today as the modern cell theory .
in one  eight  five  two , robert remak ( one  eight  one  five – one  eight  six  five ) , a prominent neurologist and embryologist , publish convincing evidence that cell be derive from other cell as a result of cell division .
however , this idea be question by many in the scientific community .
three year later , rudolf virchow ( one  eight  two  one – one  nine  zero  two ) , a wellrespected pathologist , publish an editorial essay entitle “ cellular pathology , " which popularize the concept of cell theory use the latin phrase omni cellula a cellula ( “ all cell arise from cell " ) , which be essentially the second tenet of modern cell theory . [ five ]
give the similarity of virchow 's work to remak 's , there be some controversy as to which scientist should receive credit for articulate cell theory .
see the follow eye on ethics feature for more about this controversy .
science and plagiarism rudolf virchow , a prominent , polish - bear , german scientist , be often remember as the “ father of pathology .
"
well known for innovative approach , - pron - be one of the first to determine the cause of various disease by examine - pron - effect on tissue and organ .
- pron - be also among the first to use animal in - pron - research and , as a result of - pron - work , - pron - be the first to name numerous disease and create many other medical term .
over the course of - pron - career , - pron - publish more than two  ,  zero  zero  zero paper and head various important medical facility , include the charité – universitätsmedizin berlin , a prominent berlin hospital and medical school .
but - pron - be , perhaps , best remember for - pron - one  eight  five  five editorial essay title “ cellular pathology , " publish in
archiv für pathologische anatomie und physiologie , a journal that virchow - pron - cofounde and still exist today .
despite - pron - significant scientific legacy , there be some controversy regard this essay , in which virchow propose the central tenet of modern cell theory - that all cell arise from other cell .
robert remak , a former colleague who work in the same laboratory as virchow at the university of berlin , have publish the same idea three year before .
though - pron - appear virchow be familiar with remak 's work , - pron - neglect to credit remak 's idea in - pron - essay .
when remak write a letter to virchow point out similarity between virchow 's idea and - pron - own , virchow be dismissive .
in one  eight  five  eight , in the preface to one of - pron - book , virchow write that - pron - one  eight  five  five publication be just an editorial piece , not a scientific paper , and thus there be no need to cite remak 's work .
by today 's standard , virchow 's editorial piece would certainly be consider an act of plagiarism , since - pron - present remak 's idea as - pron - own .
however , in the one  nine th century , standard for academic integrity be much less clear .
virchow 's strong reputation , couple with the fact that remak be a jew in a somewhat anti - semitic political climate , shield - pron - from any significant repercussion .
today , the process of peer review and the ease of access to the scientific literature help discourage plagiarism .
although scientist be still motivate to publish original idea that advance scientific knowledge , those who would consider plagiarize be well aware of the serious consequence .
in academia , plagiarism represent the theft of both individual thought and research - an offense that can destroy reputation and end careers . [ six ] [ seven ]

endosymbiotic theory
as scientist be make progress toward understand the role of cell in plant and animal tissue , other be examine the structure within the cell - pron - .
in one  eight  three  one , scottish botanist robert brown ( one  seven  seven  three – one  eight  five  eight ) be the first to describe observation of nucleus , which - pron - observe in plant cell .
then , in the early one  eight  eight  zero s , german botanist andreas schimper ( one  eight  five  six – one  nine  zero  one ) be the first to describe the chloroplast of plant cell , identify - pron - role in starch formation during photosynthesis and note that - pron - divide independent of the nucleus .
base upon the chloroplast ' ability to reproduce independently , russian botanist konstantin mereschkowski ( one  eight  five  five – one  nine  two  one ) suggest in one  nine  zero  five that chloroplast may have originate from ancestral photosynthetic bacteria live symbiotically inside a eukaryotic cell .
- pron - propose a similar origin for the nucleus of plant cell .
this be the first articulation of the endosymbiotic hypothesis , and would explain how eukaryotic cell evolve from ancestral bacteria .
mereschkowski 's endosymbiotic hypothesis be further by american anatomist ivan wallin ( one  eight  eight  three – one  nine  six  nine ) , who begin to experimentally examine the similarity between mitochondria , chloroplast , and bacteria - in other word , to put the endosymbiotic hypothesis to the test use objective investigation .
wallin publish a series of paper in the one  nine  two  zero support the endosymbiotic hypothesis , include a one  nine  two  six publication co - author with mereschkowski .
wallin claim - pron - could culture mitochondria outside of - pron - eukaryotic host cell .
many scientist dismiss - pron - culture of mitochondria as result from bacterial contamination .
modern genome sequence work support the dissent scientist by show that much of the genome of mitochondria have be transfer to the host cell 's nucleus , prevent the mitochondria from be able to live on - pron - own . [ one  zero ]

the germ theory of disease
prior to the discovery of microbe during the one  seven th century , other theory circulate about the origin of disease .
for example , the ancient greeks propose the miasma theory , which hold that disease originate from particle emanate from decompose matter , such as that in sewage or cesspit .
such particle infect human in close proximity to the rot material .
disease include the black death , which ravage europe 's population during the middle ages , be think to have originate in this way .
in one  five  four  six , italian physician girolamo fracastoro propose , in - pron - essay de contagione et contagiosis morbis , that seed - like spore may be transfer between individual through direct contact , exposure to contaminate clothing , or through the air .
- pron - now recognize fracastoro as an early proponent of the germ theory of disease , which state that disease may result from microbial infection .
however , in the one  six th century , fracastoro 's idea be not widely accept and would be largely forget until the one  nine th century .
in one  eight  four  seven , hungarian obstetrician ignaz semmelweis ( figure three  .  eight ) observe that mother who give birth in hospital ward staff by physician and medical student be more likely to suffer and die from puerperal fever after childbirth ( one  zero %– two  zero % mortality rate ) than be mother in ward staff by midwife ( one % mortality rate ) .
semmelwei observe medical student perform autopsy and then subsequently carry out vaginal examination on live patient without wash - pron - hand in between .
- pron - suspect that the student carry disease nine  eight chapter three  the cell
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five from the autopsy to the patient - pron - examine .
- pron - suspicion be support by the untimely death of a friend , a physician who contract a fatal wound infection after a postmortem examination of a woman who have die of a puerperal infection .
the dead physician 's wound have be cause by a scalpel use during the examination , and - pron - subsequent illness and death closely parallel that of the dead patient .
although semmelweis do not know the true cause of puerperal fever , - pron - propose that physician be somehow transfer the causative agent to - pron - patient .
- pron - suggest that the number of puerperal fever case could be reduce if physician and medical student simply wash - pron - hand with chlorinated lime water before and after examine every patient .
when this practice be implement , the maternal mortality rate in mother care for by physician drop to the same one % mortality rate observe among mother care for by midwife .
this demonstrate that handwash be a very effective method for prevent disease transmission .
despite this great success , many discount semmelweis 's work at the time , and physician be slow to adopt the simple procedure of handwash to prevent infection in - pron - patient because - pron - contradict established norm for that time period .
figure three  .  eight ignaz semmelweis ( one  eight  one  eight – one  eight  six  five ) be a proponent of the importance of handwash to prevent transfer of disease between patient by physician .
around the same time semmelweis be promote handwash , in one  eight  four  eight , british physician john snow conduct study to track the source of cholera outbreak in london .
by trace the outbreak to two specific water source , both of which be contaminate by sewage , snow ultimately demonstrate that cholera bacteria be transmit via drinking water .
snow 's work be influential in that - pron - represent the first know epidemiological study , and - pron - result in the first know public health response to an epidemic .
the work of both semmelweis and snow clearly refute the prevail miasma theory of the day , show that disease be not only transmit through the air but also through contaminate item .
although the work of semmelweis and snow successfully show the role of sanitation in prevent infectious disease , the cause of disease be not fully understand .
the subsequent work of louis pasteur , robert koch , and joseph lister would further substantiate the germ theory of disease .
while study the cause of beer and wine spoilage in one  eight  five  six , pasteur discover property of fermentation by microorganism .
- pron - have demonstrate with - pron - swan - neck flask experiment ( figure three  .  four ) that airborne microbe , not spontaneous generation , be the cause of food spoilage , and - pron - suggest that if microbe be responsible for food spoilage and fermentation , - pron - could also be responsible for cause infection .
this be the foundation for the germ theory of disease .
meanwhile , british surgeon joseph lister ( figure three  .  nine ) be try to determine the cause of postsurgical infection .
many physician do not give credence to the idea that microbe on - pron - hand , on - pron - clothe , or in the air could infect patient ' surgical wound , despite the fact that five  zero % of surgical patient , on average , be die of postsurgical infections . [ one  five ]
lister , however , be familiar with the work of semmelweis and pasteur  therefore , - pron - insist on one  five .

- pron - extremely successful effort to reduce postsurgical infection cause - pron - technique to become a standard medical practice .
a few year later , robert koch ( figure three  .  nine ) propose a series of postulate ( koch 's postulate ) base on the idea that the cause of a specific disease could be attribute to a specific microbe .
use these postulate , koch and - pron - colleague be able to definitively identify the causative pathogen of specific disease , include anthrax , tuberculosis , and cholera .

learning objectives

explain the distinguish characteristic of prokaryotic cell  describe common cell morphology and cellular arrangement typical of prokaryotic cell and explain how cell maintain - pron - morphology

describe internal and external structure of prokaryotic cell in term of - pron - physical structure , chemical structure , and function  compare the distinguish characteristic of bacterial and archaeal cell cell theory state that the cell be the fundamental unit of life .
however , cell vary significantly in size , shape , structure , and function .
at the simple level of construction , all cell possess a few fundamental component .
these include cytoplasm ( a gel - like substance compose of water and dissolve chemical need for growth ) , which be contain within a plasma membrane ( also call a cell membrane or cytoplasmic membrane )  one or more chromosome , which contain the genetic blueprint of the cell  and ribosome , organelle use for the production of protein .
beyond these basic component , cell can vary greatly between organism , and even within the same multicellular organism .
the two large category of cell - prokaryotic cell and eukaryotic cell - be define by major difference in several cell structure .
prokaryotic cell lack a nucleus surround by a complex nuclear membrane one  zero  two chapter three  the cell
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five and generally have a single , circular chromosome locate in a nucleoid .
eukaryotic cell have a nucleus surround by a complex nuclear membrane that contain multiple , rod - shape chromosomes . [ one  six ] all plant cell and animal cell be eukaryotic .
some microorganism be compose of prokaryotic cell , whereas other be compose of eukaryotic cell .
prokaryotic microorganism be classify within the domain archaea and bacteria , whereas eukaryotic organism be classify within the domain eukarya .
the structure inside a cell be analogous to the organ inside a human body , with unique structure suit to specific function .
some of the structure find in prokaryotic cell be similar to those find in some eukaryotic cell  other be unique to prokaryote .
although there be some exception , eukaryotic cell tend to be large than prokaryotic cell .
the comparatively large size of eukaryotic cell dictate the need to compartmentalize various chemical process within different area of the cell , use complex membrane - bind organelle .
in contrast , prokaryotic cell generally lack membrane - bind organelle  however , - pron - often contain inclusion that compartmentalize - pron - cytoplasm .

these structure be describe in more detail in the next section .

in most prokaryotic cell , morphology be maintain by the cell wall in combination with cytoskeletal element .
the cell wall be a structure find in most prokaryote and some eukaryote  - pron - envelop the cell membrane , protect the cell from change in osmotic pressure ( figure three  .  one  five ) .
osmotic pressure occur because of difference in the concentration of solute on oppose side of a semipermeable membrane .
water be able to pass through a semipermeable membrane , but solute ( dissolve molecule like salt , sugar , and other compound ) can not .
when the concentration of solute be great on one side of the membrane , water diffuse across the membrane from the side with the low concentration ( more water ) to the side with the high concentration ( less water ) until the concentration on both side become equal .
this diffusion of water be call osmosis , and - pron - can cause extreme osmotic pressure on a cell when - pron - external environment change .
the external environment of a cell can be describe as an isotonic , hypertonic , or hypotonic medium .
in an isotonic medium , the solute concentration inside and outside the cell be approximately equal , so there be no net movement of water across the cell membrane .
in a hypertonic medium , the solute concentration outside the cell exceed that inside the cell , so water diffuse out of the cell and into the external medium .
in a hypotonic medium , the solute concentration inside the cell exceed that outside of the cell , so water will move by osmosis into the cell .
this cause the cell to swell and potentially lyse , or burst .
the degree to which a particular cell be able to withstand change in osmotic pressure be call tonicity .
cell that have a cell wall be better able to withstand subtle change in osmotic pressure and maintain - pron - shape .
in hypertonic environment , cell that lack a cell wall can become dehydrated , cause crenation , or shrivel of the cell  the plasma membrane contract and appear scallop or notch ( figure three  .  one  five ) .
by contrast , cell that possess a cell wall undergo plasmolysis rather than crenation .
in plasmolysis , the plasma membrane contract and detache from the cell wall , and there be a decrease in interior volume , but the cell wall remain intact , thus allow the cell to maintain some shape and integrity for a period of time ( figure three  .  one  six ) .
likewise , cell that lack a cell wall be more prone to lysis in hypotonic environment .
the presence of a cell wall allow the cell to maintain - pron - shape and integrity chapter three  the cell one  zero  five for a long time before lyse ( figure three  .  one  six ) .
figure three  .  one  five
in cell that lack a cell wall , change in osmotic pressure can lead to crenation in hypertonic environment or cell lysis in hypotonic environment .
figure three  .  one  six
in prokaryotic cell , the cell wall provide some protection against change in osmotic pressure , allow - pron - to maintain - pron - shape longer .
the cell membrane be typically attach to the cell wall in an isotonic medium ( leave ) .
in a hypertonic medium , the cell membrane detache from the cell wall and contract ( plasmolysis ) as water leave the cell .
in a hypotonic medium ( right ) , the cell wall prevent the cell membrane from expand to the point of bursting , although lysis will eventually occur if too much water be absorb .

the nucleoid all cellular life have a dna genome organize into one or more chromosome .
prokaryotic chromosome be typically circular , haploid ( unpaired ) , and not bind by a complex nuclear membrane .
prokaryotic dna and dna - associate protein be concentrate within the nucleoid region of the cell ( figure three  .  one  seven ) .
in general , prokaryotic dna interact with nucleoid - associate protein ( naps ) that assist in the organization and packaging of the chromosome .
in bacteria , nap function similar to histone , which be the dna - organize protein find in eukaryotic cell .
in archaea , the nucleoid be organize by either nap or histone - like dna organizing protein .
figure three  .  one  seven
the nucleoid region ( the area enclose by the green dash line ) be a condensed area of dna find within prokaryotic cell .
because of the density of the area , - pron - do not readily stain and appear light in color when view with a transmission electron microscope .
plasmids prokaryotic cell may also contain extrachromosomal dna , or dna that be not part of the chromosome .
this extrachromosomal dna be find in plasmid , which be small , circular , double - strand dna molecule .
cell that have plasmid often have hundred of - pron - within a single cell .
plasmid be more commonly find in bacteria  however , plasmid have be find in archaea and eukaryotic organism .
plasmid often carry gene that confer advantageous trait such as antibiotic resistance  thus , - pron - be important to the survival of the organism .
- pron - will discuss plasmid in more detail in mechanisms of microbial genetics .
ribosomes
all cellular life synthesize protein , and organism in all three domain of life possess ribosome , structure responsible for protein synthesis .
however , ribosome in each of the three domain be structurally different .
ribosome , - pron - , be construct from protein , along with ribosomal rna ( rrna ) .
prokaryotic ribosome be find in the cytoplasm .
- pron - be call seven  zero s ribosome because - pron - have a size of seven  zero s ( figure three  .  one  eight ) , whereas eukaryotic cytoplasmic ribosome have a size of eight  zero s . ( the s stand for svedberg unit , a measure of sedimentation in an ultracentrifuge , which be base on size , shape , and surface quality of the structure be analyze ) .
although - pron - be the same size , bacterial and archaeal ribosome have different protein and rrna molecule , and the archaeal version be more similar to - pron - eukaryotic counterpart than to those find in bacteria .
chapter three  the cell one  zero  seven figure three  .  one  eight prokaryotic ribosome ( seven  zero s ) be compose of two subunit  the three  zero s ( small subunit ) and the five  zero s ( large subunit ) , each of which be compose of protein and rrna component .
inclusion
as single - celle organism live in unstable environment , some prokaryotic cell have the ability to store excess nutrient within cytoplasmic structure call inclusion .
store nutrient in a polymerize form be advantageous because - pron - reduce the buildup of osmotic pressure that occur as a cell accumulate solute .
various type of inclusion store glycogen and starch , which contain carbon that cell can access for energy .
volutin granule , also call metachromatic granule because of - pron - staining characteristic , be inclusion that store polymerize inorganic phosphate that can be use in metabolism and assist in the formation of biofilm .
microbe know to contain volutin granule include the archaea methanosarcina , the bacterium corynebacterium diphtheriae , and the unicellular eukaryotic alga chlamydomonas .
sulfur granule , another type of inclusion , be find in sulfur bacteria of the genus thiobacillus  these granule store elemental sulfur , which the bacteria use for metabolism .
occasionally , certain type of inclusion be surround by a phospholipid monolayer embed with protein .
polyhydroxybutyrate ( phb ) , which can be produce by specie of bacillus and pseudomonas , be an example of an inclusion that display this type of monolayer structure .
industrially , phb have also be use as a source of biodegradable polymer for bioplastic .
several different type of inclusion be show in figure three  .  one  nine .

for example , some prokaryotic cell produce gas vacuole , accumulation of small , protein - line vesicle of gas .
these gas vacuole allow the prokaryotic cell that synthesize - pron - to alter - pron - buoyancy so that - pron - can adjust - pron - location in the water column .
magnetotactic bacteria , such as magnetospirillum magnetotacticum , contain magnetosome , which be inclusion of magnetic iron oxide or iron sulfide surround by a lipid layer .
these allow cell to align along a magnetic field , aid - pron - movement ( figure three  .  one  nine ) .
cyanobacteria such as anabaena cylindrica and bacteria such as halothiobacillus neapolitanus produce carboxysome inclusion .
carboxysome be compose of outer shell of thousand of protein subunit .
- pron - interior be fill with ribulose -  one  ,  five  - bisphosphate carboxylase / oxygenase ( rubisco ) and carbonic anhydrase .
both of these compound be use for carbon metabolism .
some prokaryotic cell also possess carboxysome that sequester functionally related enzyme in one location .
these structure be consider proto - organelle because - pron - compartmentalize important compound or chemical reaction , much like many eukaryotic organelle .
endospore bacterial cell be generally observe as vegetative cell , but some genera of bacteria have the ability to form endospore , structure that essentially protect the bacterial genome in a dormant state when environmental condition be unfavorable .
endospore ( not to be confuse with the reproductive spore form by fungi ) allow some bacterial cell to survive long period without food or water , as well as exposure to chemical , extreme temperature , and even radiation .

the process by which vegetative cell transform into endospore be call sporulation , and - pron - generally begin when nutrient become depleted or environmental condition become otherwise unfavorable ( figure three  .  two  zero ) .
the process begin with the formation of a septum in the vegetative bacterial cell .
the septum divide the cell asymmetrically , separate a dna forespore from the mother cell .
the forespore , which will form the core of the endospore , be essentially a copy of the cell 's chromosome , and be separate from the mother cell by a second membrane .
a cortex gradually form around the forespore by lay down layer of calcium and dipicolinic acid between membrane .
a protein spore coat then form around the cortex while the dna of the mother cell disintegrate .
further maturation of the endospore occur with the formation of an outermost exosporium .
the endospore be release upon disintegration of the mother cell , complete sporulation .

 the cell one  one  one plasma membrane structures that enclose the cytoplasm and internal structure of the cell be know collectively as the cell envelope .
in prokaryotic cell , the structure of the cell envelope vary depend on the type of cell and organism .
most ( but not all ) prokaryotic cell have a cell wall , but the makeup of this cell wall vary .
all cell ( prokaryotic and eukaryotic ) have a plasma membrane ( also call cytoplasmic membrane or cell membrane ) that exhibit selective permeability , allow some molecule to enter or leave the cell while restrict the passage of other .
the structure of the plasma membrane be often describe in term of the fluid mosaic model , which refer to the ability of membrane component to move fluidly within the plane of the membrane , as well as the mosaic - like composition of the component , which include a diverse array of lipid and protein component ( figure three  .  two  one ) .
the plasma membrane structure of most bacterial and eukaryotic cell type be a bilayer compose mainly of phospholipid form with ester linkage and protein .
these phospholipid and protein have the ability to move laterally within the plane of the membrane as well as between the two phospholipid layer .
figure three  .  two  one
the bacterial plasma membrane be a phospholipid bilayer with a variety of embed protein that perform various function for the cell .
note the presence of glycoprotein and glycolipid , whose carbohydrate component extend out from the surface of the cell .
the abundance and arrangement of these protein and lipid can vary greatly between specie .
archaeal membrane be fundamentally different from bacterial and eukaryotic membrane in a few significant way .
first , archaeal membrane phospholipid be form with ether linkage , in contrast to the ester linkage find in bacterial or eukaryotic cell membrane .
second , archaeal phospholipid have branch chain , whereas those of bacterial and eukaryotic cell be straight chain .
finally , although some archaeal membrane can be form of bilayer like those find in bacteria and eukaryote , other archaeal plasma membrane be lipid monolayer .
protein on the cell 's surface be important for a variety of function , include cell - to - cell communication , and sense environmental condition and pathogenic virulence factor .
membrane protein and phospholipid may have carbohydrate ( sugar ) associate with - pron - and be call glycoprotein or glycolipid , respectively .
these glycoprotein and glycolipid complex extend out from the surface of the cell , allow the cell to interact with the external environment ( figure three  .  two  one ) .
glycoprotein and glycolipid in the plasma membrane can vary considerably in chemical composition among archaea , bacteria , and eukaryote , allow scientist to use - pron - to characterize unique specie .
one  one  two chapter three
 the cell
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five plasma membrane from different cell type also contain unique phospholipid , which contain fatty acid .
as describe in use biochemistry to identify microorganisms , phospholipid - derive fatty acid analysis ( plfa ) profile can be use to identify unique type of cell base on difference in fatty acid .
archaea , bacteria , and eukaryote each have a unique pfla profile .
membrane transport mechanisms one of the most important function of the plasma membrane be to control the transport of molecule into and out of the cell .
internal condition must be maintain within a certain range despite any change in the external environment .
the transport of substance across the plasma membrane allow cell to do so .
cell use various mode of transport across the plasma membrane .
for example , molecule move from a high concentration to a low concentration with the concentration gradient be transport by simple diffusion , also know as passive transport ( figure three  .  two  two ) .
some small molecule , like carbon dioxide , may cross the membrane bilayer directly by simple diffusion .
however , charge molecule , as well as large molecule , need the help of carrier or channel in the membrane .
these structure ferry molecule across the membrane , a process know as facilitated diffusion ( figure three  .  two  three ) .
active transport occur when cell move molecule across - pron - membrane against concentration gradient ( figure three  .  two  four ) .
a major difference between passive and active transport be that active transport require adenosine triphosphate ( atp ) or other form of energy to move molecule “ uphill .
"
therefore , active transport structure be often call " pump .
"
figure three  .  two  two simple diffusion down a concentration gradient directly across the phospholipid bilayer .

group translocation also transport substance into bacterial cell .
in this case , as a molecule move into a cell against - pron - concentration gradient , - pron - be chemically modify so that - pron - do not require transport against an unfavorable concentration gradient .
a common example of this be the bacterial phosphotransferase system , a series of carrier that phosphorylate ( i . e . , add phosphate ion to ) glucose or other sugar upon entry into cell .
since the phosphorylation of sugar be require during the early stage of sugar metabolism , the phosphotransferase system be consider to be an energy neutral system .
photosynthetic membrane structure
some prokaryotic cell , namely cyanobacteria and photosynthetic bacteria , have membrane structure that enable - pron - to perform photosynthesis .
these structure consist of an infolding of the plasma membrane that enclose photosynthetic pigment such as green chlorophyll and bacteriochlorophyll .
in cyanobacteria , these membrane structure be call thylakoid  in photosynthetic bacteria , - pron - be call chromatophore , lamellae , or chlorosome .
cell wall
the primary function of the cell wall be to protect the cell from harsh condition in the outside environment .
when one  one  four chapter three  the cell
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five present , there be notable similarity and difference among the cell wall of archaea , bacteria , and eukaryote .
the major component of bacterial cell wall be call peptidoglycan ( or murein )  - pron - be only find in bacteria .
structurally , peptidoglycan resemble a layer of meshwork or fabric ( figure three  .  two  five ) .
each layer be compose of long chain of alternate molecule of n - acetylglucosamine ( nag ) and n - acetylmuramic acid ( nam ) .
the structure of the long chain have significant two - dimensional tensile strength due to the formation of peptide bridge that connect nag and nam within each peptidoglycan layer .
in gram - negative bacteria , tetrapeptide chain extend from each nam unit be directly cross - link , whereas in gram - positive bacteria , these tetrapeptide chain be link by pentaglycine cross - bridge .
peptidoglycan subunit be make inside of the bacterial cell and then export and assemble in layer , give the cell - pron - shape .
since peptidoglycan be unique to bacteria , many antibiotic drug be design to interfere with peptidoglycan synthesis , weaken the cell wall and make bacterial cell more susceptible to the effect of osmotic pressure ( see mechanisms of antibacterial drugs ) .
in addition , certain cell of the human immune system be able
" recognize " bacterial pathogen by detect peptidoglycan on the surface of a bacterial cell  these cell then engulf and destroy the bacterial cell , use enzyme such as lysozyme , which break down and digest the peptidoglycan in - pron - cell wall
( see pathogen recognition and phagocytosis ) .
figure
three  .  two  five peptidoglycan be compose of polymer of alternate nam and nag subunit , which be cross - link by peptide bridge link nam subunit from various glycan chain .
this provide the cell wall with tensile strength in two dimension .
the gram staining protocol ( see staining microscopic specimens ) be use to differentiate two common type of cell wall structure ( figure three  .  two  six ) .
gram - positive cell have a cell wall consist of many layer of peptidoglycan total three  zero – one  zero  zero nm in thickness .
these peptidoglycan layer be commonly embed with teichoic acid ( ta ) , carbohydrate chain that extend through and beyond the peptidoglycan layer . [ one  nine ] ta be think to stabilize peptidoglycan by increase - pron - rigidity .
ta also play a role in the ability of pathogenic gram - positive bacteria such as streptococcus to bind to certain protein on the surface of host cell , enhance - pron - ability to cause infection .
in addition to peptidoglycan and ta , bacteria of the family mycobacteriaceae have an external layer of waxy mycolic acid in - pron - cell wall  as describe in staining microscopic specimens , these bacteria be refer to as acidfast , since acid - fast stain must be use to penetrate the mycolic acid layer for purpose of microscopy ( figure three  .  two  seven ) .

archaeal cell wall structure differ from that of bacteria in several significant way .
first , archaeal cell wall do not contain peptidoglycan  instead , - pron - contain a similar polymer call pseudopeptidoglycan ( pseudomurein ) in which nam be replace with a different subunit .

last , as be the case with some bacterial specie , there be a few archaea that appear to lack cell wall entirely .
glycocalyces and s - layers
although most prokaryotic cell have cell wall , some may have additional cell envelope structure exterior to the cell wall , such as glycocalyce and s - layer .
a glycocalyx be a sugar coat , of which there be two important type  capsule and slime layer .
a capsule be an organized layer locate outside of the cell wall and usually compose of polysaccharide or protein ( figure three  .  two  nine ) .
a slime layer be a less tightly organize layer that be only loosely attach to the cell wall and can be more easily wash off .
slime layer may be compose of polysaccharide , glycoprotein , or glycolipid .
glycocalyce allow cell to adhere to surface , aid in the formation of biofilm ( colony of microbe that form in layer on surface ) .
in nature , most microbe live in mixed community within biofilm , partly because the biofilm afford - pron - some level of protection .
biofilm generally hold water like a sponge , prevent desiccation .
- pron - also protect cell from predation and hinder the action of antibiotic and disinfectant .
all of these property be advantageous to the microbe live in a biofilm , but - pron - present challenge in a clinical setting , where the goal be chapter three  the cell one  one  seven often to eliminate microbe .

( credit b  modification of work by american society for microbiology )
the ability to produce a capsule can contribute to a microbe 's pathogenicity ( ability to cause disease ) because the capsule can make - pron - more difficult for phagocytic cell ( such as white blood cell ) to engulf and kill the microorganism .
streptococcus pneumoniae , for example , produce a capsule that be well known to aid in this bacterium 's pathogenicity .
as explain in staining microscopic specimen , capsule be difficult to stain for microscopy  negative staining technique be typically use .
an s - layer be another type of cell envelope structure  - pron - be compose of a mixture of structural protein and glycoprotein .
in bacteria , s - layer be find outside the cell wall , but in some archaea , the s - layer serve as the cell wall .
the exact function of s - layer be not entirely understand , and - pron - be difficult to study  but available evidence suggest that - pron - may play a variety of function in different prokaryotic cell , such as help the cell withstand osmotic pressure and , for certain pathogen , interact with the host immune system .
part three
after diagnose barbara with pneumonia , the pa write - pron - a prescription for amoxicillin , a commonlyprescribe type of penicillin derivative .
more than a week later , despite take the full course as direct , barbara still feel weak and be not fully recover , although - pron - be still able to get through - pron - daily activity .
- pron - return to the health center for a follow - up visit .
many type of bacteria , fungus , and virus can cause pneumonia .
amoxicillin target the peptidoglycan of bacterial cell wall .
since the amoxicillin have not resolve barbara 's symptom , the pa conclude that the causative agent probably lack peptidoglycan , mean that the pathogen could be a virus , a fungus , or a bacterium that lack peptidoglycan .
another possibility be that the pathogen be a bacterium contain peptidoglycan but have develop resistance to amoxicillin .

how can the pa definitively identify the cause of barbara 's pneumonia ?

many bacterial cell have protein appendage embed within - pron - cell envelope that extend outward , allow interaction with the environment .

the term fimbriae commonly refer to short bristle - like protein project from the cell surface by the hundred .

adherence to surface be also important in biofilm formation .

flagella flagella be structure use by cell to move in aqueous environment .
bacterial flagella act like propeller .
- pron - be stiff spiral filament compose of flagellin protein subunit that extend outward from the cell and spin in solution .
the basal body be the motor for the flagellum and be embed in the plasma membrane ( figure three  .  three  one ) .
a hook region connect the basal body to the filament .
gram - positive and gram - negative bacteria have different basal body configuration due to difference in cell wall structure .
different type of motile bacteria exhibit different arrangement of flagella ( figure three  .  three  two ) .
a bacterium with a singular flagellum , typically locate at one end of the cell ( polar ) , be say to have a monotrichous flagellum .
an example of a monotrichously flagellate bacterial pathogen be vibrio cholerae , the gram - negative bacterium that cause cholera .
cell with amphitrichous flagella have a flagellum or tuft of flagella at each end .
an example be spirillum minor , the cause of spirillary ( asian ) rat - bite fever or sodoku .
cell with lophotrichous flagella have a tuft at one end of the cell .
the gram - negative bacillus pseudomonas aeruginosa , an opportunistic pathogen know for cause many infection , include “ swimmer 's ear " and burn wound infection , have lophotrichous flagellum .
flagella that cover the entire surface of a bacterial cell be call peritrichous flagella .
the gram - negative bacterium e . coli show a peritrichous arrangement of flagella .

flagellate bacteria may exhibit multiple arrangement of - pron - flagella .
common arrangement include monotrichous , amphitrichous , lophotrichous , or peritrichous .
directional movement depend on the configuration of the flagella .
bacteria can move in response to a variety of environmental signal , include light ( phototaxis ) , magnetic field ( magnetotaxis ) use magnetosome , and , most commonly , chemical gradient ( chemotaxis ) .
purposeful movement toward a chemical attractant , like a food source , or away from a repellent , like a poisonous chemical , be achieve by increase the length of run and decrease the length of tumble .
when run , flagella rotate in a counterclockwise direction , allow the bacterial cell to move forward .
in a peritrichous bacterium , the flagella be all bundle together in a very streamlined way ( figure three  .  three  three ) , allow for efficient movement .
when tumble , flagella be splay out while rotate in a clockwise direction , create a looping motion and prevent meaningful forward movement but reorient the cell toward the direction of the attractant .
when an attractant exist , run and tumble still occur  however , the length of run be long , while the length of the tumble be reduce , allow overall movement toward the high concentration of the attractant .
when no chemical gradient exist , the length of run and tumble be more equal , and overall movement be more random ( figure three  .  three  four ) .
figure three  .  three  three bacteria achieve directional movement by change the rotation of - pron - flagella .
in a cell with peritrichous flagellum , the flagella bundle when - pron - rotate in a counterclockwise direction , result in a run .
however , when the flagella rotate in a clockwise direction , the flagella be no longer bundle , result in tumble .
chapter three  the cell one  two  one figure three  .  three  four
without a chemical gradient , flagellar rotation cycle between counterclockwise ( run ) and clockwise ( tumble ) with no overall directional movement .
however , when a chemical gradient of an attractant exist , the length of run be extend , while the length of tumble be decrease .
this lead to chemotaxis  an overall directional movement toward the high concentration of the attractant .

identify two difference between eukaryotic and prokaryotic cell .
nucleus unlike prokaryotic cell , in which dna be loosely contain in the nucleoid region , eukaryotic cell possess a nucleus , which be surround by a complex nuclear membrane that house the dna genome ( figure three  .  three  seven ) .
by contain the cell 's dna , the nucleus ultimately control all activity of the cell and also serve an essential role in reproduction and heredity .
eukaryotic cell typically have - pron - dna organize into multiple linear chromosome .
the dna within the nucleus be highly organized and condense to fit inside the nucleus , which be accomplish by wrap the dna around protein call histone .

although most eukaryotic cell have only one nucleus , exception exist .
for example , protozoan of the genus paramecium typically have two complete nucleus  a small nucleus that be use for reproduction ( micronucleus ) and a large nucleus that direct cellular metabolism ( macronucleus ) .
additionally , some fungi transiently form cell with two nucleus , call heterokaryotic cell , during sexual reproduction .
cell whose nucleus divide , but whose cytoplasm do not , be call coenocyte .
the nucleus be bind by a complex nuclear membrane , often call the nuclear envelope , that consist of two distinct lipid bilayer that be contiguous with each other ( figure three  .  three  eight ) .

the nuclear envelope contain nuclear pore , which be large , rosette - shape protein complex that control the movement of material into and out of the nucleus .
the overall shape of the nucleus be determine by the nuclear lamina , a meshwork of intermediate filament find just inside the nuclear envelope membrane .
outside the nucleus , additional intermediate filament form a loose mesh and serve to anchor the nucleus in position within the cell .

ribosomes ribosomes find in eukaryotic organelle such as mitochondria or chloroplast have seven  zero s ribosome - the same size as prokaryotic ribosome .

the difference between eukaryotic and prokaryotic ribosome be clinically relevant because certain antibiotic drug be design to target one or the other .

since human cell be eukaryotic , - pron - generally be not harm by antibiotic that destroy the prokaryotic ribosome in bacteria .
however , sometimes negative side effect may occur because mitochondria in human cell contain prokaryotic ribosome .

the endomembrane system comprise several organelle and connection between - pron - , include the endoplasmic reticulum , golgi apparatus , lysosome , and vesicle .

endoplasmic reticulum
the endoplasmic reticulum ( er ) be an interconnected array of tubule and cisterna ( flattened sac ) with a single lipid bilayer ( figure three  .  four  one ) .
the space inside of the cisterna be call luman of the er .
there be two type of er , rough endoplasmic reticulum ( rer ) and smooth endoplasmic reticulum ( ser ) .
these two different type of er be site for the synthesis of distinctly different type of molecule .
rer be stud with ribosome bind on the cytoplasmic side of the membrane .
these ribosome make protein destine for the plasma membrane ( figure three  .  four  one ) .
follow synthesis , these protein be insert into the membrane of the rer .
small sac of the rer contain these newly synthesize protein then bud off as transport vesicle and move either to the golgi apparatus for further processing , directly to the plasma membrane , to the membrane of another organelle , or out of the cell .
transport vesicle be single - lipid , bilayer , membranous sphere with hollow interior that carry molecule .

lysosome
in the one  nine  six  zero , belgian scientist christian de duve ( one  nine  one  seven – two  zero  one  three ) discover lysosome , membrane - bind organelle of the endomembrane system that contain digestive enzyme .
certain type of eukaryotic cell use lysosome to break down various particle , such as food , damage organelle or cellular debris , microorganism , or immune complex .
compartmentalization of the digestive enzyme within the lysosome allow the cell to efficiently digest matter without harm the cytoplasmic component of the cell .

peroxisomes christian de duve be also credit with the discovery of peroxisome , membrane - bind organelle that be not part of the endomembrane system ( figure three  .  four  three ) .

the cytoskeleton be a network of microfilament , intermediate filament , and microtubule find throughout the cytoplasm of a eukaryotic cell .
in these fluorescently label animal cell , the microtubule be green , the actin microfilament be red , the nucleus be blue , and keratin ( a type of intermediate filament ) be yellow .
microfilament be compose of two intertwined strand of actin , each compose of actin monomer form filamentous cable six nm in diameter[ two  five ]
( figure three  .  four  five ) .
the actin filament work together with motor protein , like myosin , to effect muscle contraction in animal or the amoeboid movement of some eukaryotic microbe .
in ameboid organism , actin can be find in two form  a stiffer , polymerized , gel form and a more fluid , unpolymerized soluble form .
actin in the gel form create stability in the ectoplasm , the gel - like area of cytoplasm just inside the plasma membrane of ameboid protozoan .
temporary extension of the cytoplasmic membrane call pseudopodia ( mean " false foot " ) be produce through the forward flow of soluble actin filament into the pseudopodia , follow by the gel - sol cycling of the actin filament , result in cell motility .
once the cytoplasm extend outward , form a pseudopodium , the remain cytoplasm flow up to join the leading edge , thereby create forward locomotion .
beyond amoeboid movement , microfilament be also involve in a variety of other process in eukaryotic cell , include cytoplasmic streaming ( the movement or circulation of cytoplasm within the cell ) , cleavage furrow formation during cell division , and muscle movement in animal ( figure three  .  four  five ) .
these function be the result of the dynamic nature of microfilament , which can polymerize and depolymerize relatively easily in response to cellular signal , and - pron - interaction with molecular motor in different type of eukaryotic cell .

mitochondria
the large , complex organelle in which aerobic cellular respiration occur in eukaryotic cell be call mitochondria ( figure three  .  four  nine ) .
the term " mitochondrion " be first coin by german microbiologist carl benda in one  eight  nine  eight and be later connect with the process of respiration by otto warburg in one  nine  one  three .
scientist during the one  nine  six  zero s discover that mitochondria have - pron - own genome and seven  zero s ribosome .
the mitochondrial genome be find to be bacterial , when - pron - be sequence in one  nine  seven  six .
these finding ultimately support the endosymbiotic theory propose by lynn margulis , which state that mitochondria originally arise through an endosymbiotic event in which a bacterium capable of aerobic cellular respiration be take up by phagocytosis into a host cell and remain as a viable intracellular component .
each mitochondrion have two lipid membrane .
the outer membrane be a remnant of the original host cell 's membrane structure .
the inner membrane be derive from the bacterial plasma membrane .
the electron transport chain for aerobic respiration use integral protein embed in the inner membrane .
the mitochondrial matrix , correspond to the location of the original bacterium 's cytoplasm , be the current location of many metabolic enzyme .
- pron - also contain mitochondrial dna and seven  zero s ribosome .
invagination of the inner membrane , call cristae , evolve to increase surface area for the location of biochemical reaction .
the fold pattern of the cristae differ among various type of eukaryotic cell and be use to distinguish different eukaryotic organism from each other .

membrane transport mechanisms
the process of simple diffusion , facilitated diffusion , and active transport be use in both eukaryotic and prokaryotic cell .
however , eukaryotic cell also have the unique ability to perform various type of endocytosis , the uptake of matter through plasma membrane invagination and vacuole / vesicle formation ( figure three  .  five  two ) .
a type of endocytosis involve the engulfment of large particle through membrane invagination be call phagocytosis , which mean “ cell eat .
"
in phagocytosis , particle ( or other cell ) be enclose in a pocket within the membrane , which then pinch off from the membrane to form a vacuole that completely surround the particle .
another type of endocytosis be call pinocytosis , which mean “ cell drinking .
"
in pinocytosis , small , dissolve material and liquid be take into the cell through small vesicle .
saprophytic fungi , for example , obtain - pron - nutrient from dead and decaying matter largely through pinocytosis .
receptor - mediate endocytosis be a type of endocytosis that be initiate by specific molecule call ligand when - pron - bind to cell surface receptor on the membrane .
receptor - mediate endocytosis be the mechanism that peptide and amine - derive hormone use to enter cell and be also use by various virus and bacteria for entry into host cell .

cell wall
in addition to a plasma membrane , some eukaryotic cell have a cell wall .
cell of fungi , algae , plant , and even some protist have cell wall .
depend upon the type of eukaryotic cell , cell wall can be make of a wide range of material , include cellulose ( fungus and plant )  biogenic silica , calcium carbonate , agar , and carrageenan ( protist and algae )  or chitin ( fungi ) .
in general , all cell wall provide structural stability for the cell and protection from environmental stress such as desiccation , change in osmotic pressure , and traumatic injury . [ two  nine ] extracellular matrix cell of animal and some protozoan do not have cell wall to help maintain shape and provide structural stability .
instead , these type of eukaryotic cell produce an extracellular matrix for this purpose .
- pron - secrete a sticky mass of carbohydrate and protein into the space between adjacent cell ( figure three  .  five  three ) .
some protein component assemble into a basement membrane to which the remain extracellular matrix component adhere .
proteoglycans typically form the bulky mass of the extracellular matrix while fibrous protein , like collagen , provide strength .
both proteoglycan and collagen be attach to fibronectin protein , which , in turn , be attach to integrin protein .
these integrin protein interact with transmembrane protein in the plasma membrane of eukaryotic cell that lack cell wall .
in animal cell , the extracellular matrix allow cell within tissue to withstand external stress and transmit signal from the outside of the cell to the inside .

flagella and cilia
some eukaryotic cell use flagella for locomotion  however , eukaryotic flagella be structurally distinct from those find in prokaryotic cell .
whereas the prokaryotic flagellum be a stiff , rotate structure , a eukaryotic flagellum be more like a flexible whip compose of nine parallel pair of microtubule surround a central pair of microtubule .
this arrangement be refer to as a nine + two array ( figure three  .  five  four ) .
the parallel microtubule use dynein motor protein to move relative to each other , cause the flagellum to bend .
cilia ( singular  cilium ) be a similar external structure find in some eukaryotic cell .
unique to eukaryote , cilium be short than flagella and often cover the entire surface of a cell  however , - pron - be structurally similar to flagella ( a nine + two array of microtubule ) and use the same mechanism for movement .
a structure call a basal body be find at the base of each cilium and flagellum .
the basal body , which attach the cilium or flagellum to the cell , be compose of an array of triplet microtubule similar to that of a centriole but embed in the plasma membrane .
because of - pron - short length , cilium use a rapid , flexible , wave motion .
in addition to motility , cilium may have other function such as sweeping particle past or into cell .
for example , ciliate protozoan use the sweeping of cilia to move food particle into - pron - mouthpart , and ciliate cell in the mammalian respiratory tract beat in synchrony to sweep mucus chapter three

summary three  .  one spontaneous generation

the theory of spontaneous generation state that life arise from nonlive matter .
- pron - be a long - hold belief date back to aristotle and the ancient greeks .

experimentation by francesco redi in the one  seven th century present the first significant evidence refute spontaneous generation by show that fly must have access to meat for maggot to develop on the meat .
prominent scientist design experiment and argue both in support of ( john needham ) and against ( lazzaro spallanzani ) spontaneous generation .

louis pasteur be credit with conclusively disprove the theory of spontaneous generation with - pron - famous swan - neck flask experiment .
- pron - subsequently propose that “ life only come from life .
"
three  .  two foundations of modern cell theory

although cell be first observe in the one  six  six  zero s by robert hooke , cell theory be not well accept for another two  zero  zero year .
the work of scientist such as schleiden , schwann , remak , and virchow contribute to - pron - acceptance .

endosymbiotic theory state that mitochondria and chloroplast , organelle find in many type of organism , have - pron - origin in bacteria .
significant structural and genetic information support this theory .

the miasma theory of disease be widely accept until the one  nine th century , when - pron - be replace by the germ theory of disease thank to the work of semmelweis , snow , pasteur , lister , and koch , and other .
three  .  three unique characteristics of prokaryotic cells  prokaryotic cell differ from eukaryotic cell in that - pron - genetic material be contain in a nucleoid rather than a membrane - bind nucleus .
in addition , prokaryotic cell generally lack membrane - bind organelle .
 prokaryotic cell of the same specie typically share a similar cell morphology and cellular arrangement .
 most prokaryotic cell have a cell wall that help the organism maintain cellular morphology and protect - pron - against change in osmotic pressure .

outside of the nucleoid , prokaryotic cell may contain extrachromosomal dna in plasmid .
 prokaryotic ribosome that be find in the cytoplasm have a size of seven  zero s . 
some prokaryotic cell have inclusion that store nutrient or chemical for other use .

some prokaryotic cell be able to form endospore through sporulation to survive in a dormant state when condition be unfavorable .
endospore can germinate , transform back into vegetative cell when condition improve .

in prokaryotic cell , the cell envelope include a plasma membrane and usually a cell wall .

bacterial membrane be compose of phospholipid with integral or peripheral protein .
the fatty acid clinical focus chapter three  the cell one  four  one component of these phospholipid be ester - link and be often use to identify specific type of bacteria .
the protein serve a variety of function , include transport , cell - to - cell communication , and sense environmental condition .
archaeal membrane be distinct in that - pron - be compose of fatty acid that be ether - link to phospholipid .

some molecule can move across the bacterial membrane by simple diffusion , but most large molecule must be actively transport through membrane structure use cellular energy .

prokaryotic cell wall may be compose of peptidoglycan ( bacteria ) or pseudopeptidoglycan ( archaea ) .
 gram - positive bacterial cell be characterize by a thick peptidoglycan layer , whereas gram - negative bacterial cell be characterize by a thin peptidoglycan layer surround by an outer membrane .

some prokaryotic cell produce glycocalyx coating , such as capsule and slime layer , that aid in attachment to surface and / or evasion of the host immune system .

some prokaryotic cell have fimbriae or pili , filamentous appendage that aid in attachment to surface .
pili be also use in the transfer of genetic material between cell .

some prokaryotic cell use one or more flagella to move through water .
peritrichous bacteria , which have numerous flagellum , use run and tumble to move purposefully in the direction of a chemical attractant .
three  .  four unique characteristics of eukaryotic cells  eukaryotic cell be define by the presence of a nucleus contain the dna genome and bind by a nuclear membrane ( or nuclear envelope ) compose of two lipid bilayer that regulate transport of material into and out of the nucleus through nuclear pore .
 eukaryotic cell morphology vary greatly and may be maintain by various structure , include the cytoskeleton , the cell membrane , and / or the cell wall

the nucleolus , locate in the nucleus of eukaryotic cell , be the site of ribosomal synthesis and the first stage of ribosome assembly .

eukaryotic cell contain eight  zero s ribosome in the rough endoplasmic reticulum ( membrane bind - ribosome ) and cytoplasm ( free ribosome ) .
- pron - contain seven  zero ribosome in mitochondria and chloroplast .
 eukaryotic cell have evolve an endomembrane system , contain membrane - bind organelle involve in transport .
these include vesicle , the endoplasmic reticulum , and the golgi apparatus .

the smooth endoplasmic reticulum play a role in lipid biosynthesis , carbohydrate metabolism , and detoxification of toxic compound .
the rough endoplasmic reticulum contain membrane - bind eight  zero s ribosome that synthesize protein destine for the cell membrane 
the golgi apparatus process protein and lipid , typically through the addition of sugar molecule , produce glycoprotein or glycolipid , component of the plasma membrane that be use in cell - to - cell communication .

lysosome contain digestive enzyme that break down small particle ingest by endocytosis , large particle or cell ingest by phagocytosis , and damage intracellular component .

the cytoskeleton , compose of microfilament , intermediate filament , and microtubule , provide structural support in eukaryotic cell and serve as a network for transport of intracellular material .

centrosomes be microtubule - organize center important in the formation of the mitotic spindle in mitosis .

mitochondria be the site of cellular respiration .
- pron - have two membrane  an outer membrane and an inner membrane with cristae .
the mitochondrial matrix , within the inner membrane , contain the mitochondrial dna , seven  zero s ribosome , and metabolic enzyme .

the plasma membrane of eukaryotic cell be structurally similar to that find in prokaryotic cell , and membrane component move accord to the fluid mosaic model .
however , eukaryotic membrane contain sterol , which alter membrane fluidity , as well as glycoprotein and glycolipid , which help the cell recognize other cell and infectious particle .

in addition to active transport and passive transport , eukaryotic cell membrane can take material into the cell via endocytosis , or expel matter from the cell via exocytosis .

prokaryote have an important role in change , shaping , and sustain the entire biosphere .

explain how prokaryote be classify
all live organism be classify into three domain of life  archaea , bacteria , and eukarya .
in this chapter , - pron - will focus on the domain archaea and bacteria .
archaea and bacteria be unicellular prokaryotic organism .
unlike eukaryote , - pron - have no nucleus or any other membrane - bind organelle .
prokaryote habitats and functions prokaryotes be ubiquitous .
- pron - can be find everywhere on - pron - planet , even in hot spring , in the antarctic ice shield , and under extreme pressure two mile under water .
one bacterium , paracoccus denitrifican , have even be show to survive when scientist remove - pron - from - pron - native environment ( soil ) and use a centrifuge to subject - pron - to force of gravity as strong as those find on the surface of jupiter .
prokaryote also be abundant on and within the human body .
accord to a report by national institutes of health , prokaryote , especially bacteria , outnumber human cell one  zero   one  . [ one ] more recent study suggest the ratio could be close to one   one , but even that ratio mean that there be a great number of bacteria within the human body . [ two ]
bacteria thrive in the human mouth , nasal cavity , throat , ear , gastrointestinal tract , and vagina .
large colony of bacteria can be find on healthy human skin , especially in moist area ( armpit , navel , and area behind ear ) .
however , even dry area of the skin be not free from bacteria .

the existence of prokaryote be very important for the stability and thriving of ecosystem .
for example , - pron - be a necessary part of soil formation and stabilization process through the breakdown of organic matter and development of biofilm .
one gram of soil contain up to one  zero billion microorganism ( most of - pron - prokaryotic ) belong to about one  ,  zero  zero  zero specie .
many specie of bacteria use substance release from plant root , such as acid and carbohydrate , as nutrient .
the bacteria metabolize these plant substance and release the product of bacterial metabolism back to the soil , form humus and thus increase the soil 's fertility .
in salty lake such as the dead sea ( figure four  .  two ) , salt - love halobacteria decompose dead brine shrimp and nourish young brine shrimp and fly with the product of bacterial metabolism .

in addition to live in the ground and the water , prokaryotic microorganism be abundant in the air , even high in the atmosphere .
there may be up to two  ,  zero  zero  zero different kind of bacteria in the air , similar to - pron - diversity in the soil .
prokaryote can be find everywhere on earth because - pron - be extremely resilient and adaptable .
- pron - be often metabolically flexible , which mean that - pron - may easily switch from one energy source to another , depend on the availability of the source , or from one metabolic pathway to another .
for example , certain prokaryotic cyanobacteria can switch from a conventional type of lipid metabolism , which include production of fatty aldehyde , to a different type of lipid metabolism that generate biofuel , such as fatty acid and wax ester .
groundwater bacteria store complex high - energy carbohydrate when grow in pure groundwater , but - pron - metabolize these molecule when the groundwater be enrich with phosphate .
some bacteria get - pron - energy by reduce sulfate into sulfide , but can switch to a different metabolic pathway when necessary , produce acid and free hydrogen ion .
prokaryote perform function vital to life on earth by capturing ( or " fix " ) and recycle element like carbon and nitrogen .
organism such as animal require organic carbon to grow , but , unlike prokaryote , - pron - be unable to use inorganic carbon source like carbon dioxide .
thus , animal rely on prokaryote to convert carbon dioxide into organic carbon product that - pron - can use .
this process of convert carbon dioxide to organic carbon product be call carbon fixation .
plant and animal also rely heavily on prokaryote for nitrogen fixation , the conversion of atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia , a compound that some plant can use to form many different biomolecule necessary to - pron - survival .
bacteria in the genus rhizobium , for example , be nitrogen - fix bacteria  - pron - live in the root of legume plant such as clover , alfalfa , and pea ( figure four  .  three ) .
ammonia produce by rhizobium help these plant to survive by enable - pron - to make building block of nucleic acid .
in turn , these plant may be eat by animal - sustain - pron - growth and survival - or - pron - may die , in which case the product of nitrogen fixation will enrich the soil and be use by other plant .

another positive function of prokaryote be in clean up the environment .
recently , some researcher focus on the diversity and function of prokaryote in manmade environment .
- pron - find that some bacteria play a unique role in degrade toxic chemical that pollute water and soil . [ three ]
despite all of the positive and helpful role prokaryote play , some be human pathogen that may cause illness or infection when - pron - enter the body .
in addition , some bacteria can contaminate food , cause spoilage or foodborne illness , which make - pron - subject of concern in food preparation and safety .
less than one % of prokaryote ( all of - pron - bacteria ) be think to be human pathogen , but collectively these specie be responsible for a large number of the disease that afflict human .
besides pathogen , which have a direct impact on human health , prokaryote also affect human in many indirect way .
for example , prokaryote be now think to be key player in the process of climate change .
in recent year , as temperature in the earth
's polar region have rise , soil that be formerly freeze year - round ( permafrost ) have begin to thaw .
carbon trap in the permafrost be gradually release and metabolize by prokaryote .
this produce massive amount of carbon dioxide and methane , greenhouse gas that escape into the atmosphere and contribute to the greenhouse effect .

symbiotic relationships
as - pron - have learn , prokaryotic microorganism can associate with plant and animal .
often , this association result in unique relationship between organism .
for example , bacteria live on the root or leaf of a plant get nutrient from the plant and , in return , produce substance that protect the plant from pathogen .
on the other hand , some bacteria be plant pathogen that use mechanism of infection similar to bacterial pathogen of animal and human .
prokaryote live in a community , or a group of interact population of organism .
a population be a group of individual organism belong to the same biological specie and limit to a certain geographic area .

the study of these interaction between microbial population and - pron - environment be call microbial ecology .
any interaction between different specie that be associate with each other within a community be call symbiosis .
such interaction fall along a continuum between opposition and cooperation .
interaction in a symbiotic relationship may be beneficial or harmful , or have no effect on one or both of the specie involve .
