benefitted harmed table four  .  one
when two specie benefit from each other , the symbiosis be call mutualism ( or syntropy , or crossfeeding ) .
for example , human have a mutualistic relationship with the bacterium bacteroides thetaiotaomicron , which live in the intestinal tract .
bacteroide thetaiotaomicron digest complex polysaccharide plant material that human digestive enzyme can not break down , convert - pron - into monosaccharide that can be absorb by human cell .
human also have a mutualistic relationship with certain strain of escherichia coli , another bacterium find in the gut .
e . coli relie on intestinal content for nutrient , and human derive certain vitamin from e . coli , particularly vitamin k , which be require for the formation of blood clotting factor .
( this be only true for some strain of e . coli , however .
other strain be pathogenic and do not have a mutualistic relationship with human . )
a type of symbiosis in which one population harm another but remain unaffected - pron - be call amensalism .
in the case of bacteria , some amensalist specie produce bactericidal substance that kill other specie of bacteria .
the microbiota of the skin be compose of a variety of bacterial specie , include staphylococcus epidermidis and propionibacterium acne .
although both specie have the potential to cause infectious disease when protective barrier be breach , - pron - both produce a variety of antibacterial bacteriocin and bacteriocin - like compound .
s . epidermidis and p . acne be unaffected by the bacteriocin and bacteriocin - like compound - pron - produce , but these compound can target and kill other potential pathogen .
in another type of symbiosis , call commensalism , one organism benefit while the other be unaffected .
this occur when the bacterium staphylococcus epidermidis use the dead cell of the human skin as nutrient .
billion of these bacteria live on - pron - skin , but in most case ( especially when - pron - immune system be healthy ) , - pron - do not react to - pron - in any way .
s . epidermidis provide an excellent example of how the classification of symbiotic relationship be not always distinct .
one could also consider the symbiotic relationship of s . epidermidis with human as mutualism .
human provide a food source of dead skin cell to the bacterium , and in turn the production of bacteriocin can provide an defense against potential pathogen .
if neither of the symbiotic organism be affect in any way , - pron - call this type of symbiosis neutralism .
an example of neutralism be the coexistence of metabolically active ( vegetate ) bacteria and endospore ( dormant , metabolically passive bacteria ) .
for example , the bacterium bacillus anthracis typically form endospore in soil when condition be unfavorable .
if the soil be warm and enrich with nutrient , some b . anthracis endospore germinate and remain in symbiosis with other specie of endospore that have not germinate .
a type of symbiosis in which one organism benefit while harm the other be call parasitism .
the relationship chapter four  prokaryotic diversity one  five  three between human and many pathogenic prokaryote can be characterize as parasitic because these organism invade the body , produce toxic substance or infectious disease that cause harm .
disease such as tetanus , diphtheria , pertussis , tuberculosis , and leprosy all arise from interaction between bacteria and human .
scientist have coin the term microbiome to refer to all prokaryotic and eukaryotic microorganism that be associate with a certain organism or environment .
within the human microbiome , there be resident microbiota and transient microbiota .
the resident microbiota consist of microorganism that constantly live in or on - pron - body .
the term transient microbiota refer to microorganism that be only temporarily find in the human body , and these may include pathogenic microorganism .
hygiene and diet can alter both the resident and transient microbiota .
the resident microbiota be amazingly diverse , not only in term of the variety of specie but also in term of the preference of different microorganism for different area of the human body .
for example , in the human mouth , there be thousand of commensal or mutualistic specie of bacteria .
some of these bacteria prefer to inhabit the surface of the tongue , whereas other prefer the internal surface of the cheek , and yet other prefer the front or back tooth or gum .
the inner surface of the cheek have the least diverse microbiota because of - pron - exposure to oxygen .
by contrast , the crypt of the tongue and the space between tooth be two site with limited oxygen exposure , so these site have more diverse microbiota , include bacteria live in the absence of oxygen ( e . g . , bacteroides , fusobacterium ) .
difference in the oral microbiota between randomly choose human individual be also significant .
study have show , for example , that the prevalence of such bacteria as streptococcus , haemophilus , neisseria , and other be dramatically different when compare between individuals . [ four ]
there be also significant difference between the microbiota of different site of the same human body .
the inner surface of the cheek have a predominance of streptococcus , whereas in the throat , the palatine tonsil , and saliva , there be two to three time few streptococcus , and several time more fusobacterium .
in the plaque remove from gum , the predominant bacteria belong to the genus fusobacterium .
however , in the intestine , both streptococcus and fusobacterium disappear , and the genus bacteroides become predominant .
not only can the microbiota vary from one body site to another , the microbiome can also change over time within the same individual .
human acquire - pron - first inoculation of normal flora during natural birth and shortly after birth .
before birth , there be a rapid increase in the population of lactobacillus spp .
in the vagina , and this population serve as the first colonization of microbiota during natural birth .
after birth , additional microbe be acquire from healthcare provider , parent , other relative , and individual who come in contact with the baby .
this process establish a microbiome that will continue to evolve over the course of the individual 's life as new microbe colonize and be eliminate from the body .
for example , - pron - be estimate that within a nine  - hour period , the microbiota of the small intestine can change so that half of the microbial inhabitant will be different . [ five ]
the importance of the initial lactobacillus colonization during vaginal child birth be highlight by study demonstrate a high incidence of disease in individual bear by cesarean section , compare to those bear vaginally .
study have show that baby bear vaginally be predominantly colonize by vaginal lactobacillus , whereas baby bear by cesarean section be more frequently colonize by microbe of the normal skin microbiota , include common hospital - acquire pathogen .
throughout the body , resident microbiota be important for human health because - pron - occupy niche that may be otherwise take by pathogenic microorganism .
for instance , lactobacillus spp .
be the dominant bacterial specie of the normal vaginal microbiota for most woman .
lactobacillus produce lactic acid , contribute to the acidity of the vagina and inhibit the growth of pathogenic yeast .
however , when the population of the resident microbiota be decrease for some reason ( e . g . , because of take antibiotic ) , the ph of the vagina increase , make - pron - a more favorable environment for the growth of yeast such as candida albican .
antibiotic therapy can also disrupt the microbiota of the intestinal tract and respiratory tract , increase the risk for secondary infection and / or promote the long - term carriage and shedding of pathogen .

taxonomy and systematics assigning prokaryote to a certain species be challenging .
- pron - do not reproduce sexually , so - pron - be not possible to classify - pron - accord to the presence or absence of interbreed .
also , - pron - do not have many morphological feature .
traditionally , the classification of prokaryote be base on - pron - shape , stain pattern , and biochemical or physiological difference .
more recently , as technology have improve , the nucleotide sequence in gene have become an important criterion of microbial classification .
in one  nine  two  three , american microbiologist david hendricks bergey ( one  eight  six  zero – one  nine  three  seven ) publish a manual in determinative bacteriology .
with this manual , - pron - attempt to summarize the information about the kind of bacteria know at that time , use latin binomial classification .
bergey also include the morphological , physiological , and biochemical property of these organism .
- pron - manual have be update multiple time to include new bacteria and - pron - property .
- pron - be a great aid in bacterial taxonomy and method of characterization of bacteria .
a more recent sister publication , the five - volume bergey 's manual of systematic bacteriology , expand on bergey 's original manual .
- pron - include a large number of additional specie , along with up - to - date description of the taxonomy and biological property of all name prokaryotic taxa .
this publication incorporate the approve name of bacteria as determine by the list of prokaryotic names with stand in nomenclature ( lpsn ) .
bergey 's manual of determinative bacteriology be now available ( https / / openstax . org / l /  two  two mandeterbact ) online .
- pron - can also access a searchable database ( https / / openstax . org / l /  two  two databmicrefst ) of microbial reference strain , publish by the american type culture collection ( atcc ) .
classification by staining patterns
accord to - pron - staining pattern , which depend on the property of - pron - cell wall , bacteria have traditionally be classify into gram - positive , gram - negative , and " atypical , " mean neither gram - positive nor gram - negative .
as explain in staining microscopic specimens , gram - positive bacteria possess a thick peptidoglycan cell wall that retain the primary stain ( crystal violet ) during the decolorizing step  - pron - remain purple after the gramstain procedure because the crystal violet dominate the light red / pink color of the secondary counterstain , safranin .
in contrast , gram - negative bacteria possess a thin peptidoglycan cell wall that do not prevent the crystal violet from wash away during the decolorizing step  therefore , - pron - appear light red / pink after stain with the safranin .
bacteria that can not be stain by the standard gram stain procedure be call atypical bacteria .
include in the atypical category be specie of mycoplasma and chlamydia .
rickettsia be also consider atypical because - pron - be too small to be evaluate by the gram stain .
more recently , scientist have begin to further classify gram - negative and gram - positive bacteria .
- pron - have add a special group of deeply branch bacteria base on a combination of physiological , biochemical , and genetic feature .
- pron - also now further classify gram - negative bacteria into proteobacteria , cytophaga - flavobacterium - bacteroides ( cfb ) , and spirochete .
the deeply branch bacteria be think to be a very early evolutionary form of bacteria ( see deeply branching link to learn chapter four  prokaryotic diversity one  five  five bacteria ) .
- pron - live in hot , acidic , ultraviolet - light - expose , and anaerobic ( deprive of oxygen ) condition .
proteobacteria be a phylum of very diverse group of gram - negative bacteria  - pron - include some important human pathogen ( e . g . , e . coli and bordetella pertussis ) .
the cfb group of bacteria include component of the normal human gut microbiota , like bacteroides .
the spirochete be spiral - shape bacteria and include the pathogen treponema pallidum , which cause syphilis .
- pron - will characterize these group of bacteria in more detail later in the chapter .
base on - pron - prevalence of guanine and cytosine nucleotide , gram - positive bacteria be also classify into low g+c and high g+c gram - positive bacteria .
the low g+c gram - positive bacteria have less than five  zero % of guanine and cytosine nucleotide in - pron - dna .
- pron - include human pathogen , such as those that cause anthrax ( bacillus anthracis ) , tetanus ( clostridium tetani ) , and listeriosis ( listeria monocytogene ) .
high g+c gram - positive bacteria , which have more than five  zero % guanine and cytosine nucleotide in - pron - dna , include the bacteria that cause diphtheria ( corynebacterium diphtheriae ) , tuberculosis ( mycobacterium tuberculosis ) , and other disease .
the classification of prokaryote be constantly change as new specie be be discover .
- pron - will describe - pron - in more detail , along with the disease - pron - cause , in later section and chapter .

human microbiome project
the human microbiome project be launch by the national institutes of health ( nih ) in two  zero  zero  eight .
one main goal of the project be to create a large repository of the gene sequence of important microbe find in human , help biologist and clinician understand the dynamic of the human microbiome and the relationship between the human microbiota and disease .
a network of lab work together have be compile the datum from swab of several area of the skin , gut , and mouth from hundred of individual .
one of the challenge in understand the human microbiome have be the difficulty of culture many of the microbe that inhabit the human body .
- pron - have be estimate that - pron - be only able to culture one % of the bacteria in nature and that - pron - be unable to grow the remain nine  nine % .
to address this challenge , researcher have use metagenomic analysis , which study genetic material harvest directly from microbial community , as oppose to that of individual specie grow in a culture .
this allow researcher to study the genetic material of all microbe in the microbiome , rather than just those that can be cultured . [ six ]
one important achievement of the human microbiome project be establish the first reference database on microorganism live in and on the human body .
many of the microbe in the microbiome be beneficial , but some be not .
- pron - be find , somewhat unexpectedly , that all of - pron - have some serious microbial pathogen in - pron - microbiota .
for example , the conjunctiva of the human eye contain two  four genera of bacteria and numerous pathogenic species . [ seven ]
a healthy human mouth contain a number of specie of the genus streptococcus , include pathogenic specie s . pyogene and s . pneumoniae . [ eight ]
this raise the question of why certain prokaryotic organism exist commensally in certain individual but act as deadly pathogen in other .
also unexpected be the number of organism that have never be culture .
for example , in one metagenomic study of the human gut microbiota , one  seven  four new specie of bacteria be identified . [ nine ]
another goal for the near future be to characterize the human microbiota in patient with different disease and to find out whether there be any relationship between the content of an individual 's microbiota and risk for or susceptibility to specific disease .
analyze the microbiome in a person with a specific disease may reveal new way to fight disease .

in one  nine  eight  seven , the american microbiologist carl woese ( one  nine  two  eight – two  zero  one  two ) suggest that a large and diverse group of bacteria that - pron - call " purple bacteria and - pron - relative " should be define as a separate phylum within the domain bacteria base on the similarity of the nucleotide sequence in - pron - genome . [ one  zero ]
this phylum of gram - negative bacteria subsequently receive the name proteobacteria .
- pron - include many bacteria that be part of the normal human microbiota as well as many pathogen .
the proteobacteria be further divide into five class  alphaproteobacteria , betaproteobacteria , gammaproteobacteria , deltaproteobacteria , and epsilonproteobacteria ( appendix d ) .
alphaproteobacteria
the first class of proteobacteria be the alphaproteobacteria .
the unifying characteristic of this class be that - pron - be oligotroph , organism capable of live in low - nutrient environment such as deep oceanic sediment , glacial ice , or deep undersurface soil .
among the alphaproteobacteria be two taxa , chlamydia and rickettsia , that be obligate intracellular pathogen , mean that part of - pron - life cycle must occur inside other cell call host cell .
when not grow inside a host cell , chlamydia and rickettsia be metabolically inactive outside of the host cell .
- pron - can not synthesize - pron - own adenosine triphosphate ( atp ) , and , therefore , rely on cell for - pron - energy need .
rickettsia spp . include a number of serious human pathogen .
for example , r . rickettsii cause rocky mountain spot fever , a life - threaten form of meningoencephalitis ( inflammation of the membrane that wrap the brain ) .
r . rickettsii infect tick and can be transmit to human via a bite from an infect tick ( figure four  .  four ) .

betaproteobacteria unlike alphaproteobacteria , which survive on a minimal amount of nutrient , the class betaproteobacteria be eutroph ( or copiotroph ) , mean that - pron - require a copious amount of organic nutrient .
betaproteobacteria often grow between aerobic and anaerobic area ( e . g . , in mammalian intestine ) .
some genera include specie that be human pathogen , able to cause severe , sometimes life - threaten disease .
the genus neisseria , for example , include the bacteria n . gonorrhoeae , the causative agent of the sti gonorrhea , and n . meningitide , the causative agent of bacterial meningitis .
neisseria be cocci that live on mucosal surface of the human body .
- pron - be fastidious , or difficult to culture , and - pron - require high level of moisture , nutrient supplement , and carbon dioxide .
also , neisseria be microaerophilic , mean that - pron - require low level of oxygen .
for optimal growth and for the purpose of identification , neisseria spp .
be grow on chocolate agar ( i . e . , agar supplement by partially hemolyze red blood cell ) .
- pron - characteristic pattern of growth in culture be diplococcal  pair of cell resemble coffee bean ( figure four  .  six ) .

gammaproteobacteria
the most diverse class of gram - negative bacteria be gammaproteobacteria , and - pron - include a number of human pathogen .
for example , a large and diverse family , pseudomonaceae , include the genus pseudomonas .
within this genus be the specie p . aeruginosa , a pathogen responsible for diverse infection in various region of the body .
p . aeruginosa be a strictly aerobic , nonfermente , highly motile bacterium .
- pron - often infect wound and burn , can be the cause of chronic urinary tract infection , and can be an important cause of respiratory infection in patient with cystic fibrosis or patient on mechanical ventilator .
infection by p . aeruginosa be often difficult to treat because the bacterium be resistant to many antibiotic and have a remarkable ability to form biofilm .
other representative of pseudomonas include the fluorescent ( glowing ) bacterium p . fluorescen and the soil bacteria p . putida , which be know for - pron - ability to degrade xenobiotic ( substance not naturally produce or find in live organism ) .
the pasteurellaceae also include several clinically relevant genera and specie .
this family include several bacteria that be human and / or animal pathogen .
for example , pasteurella haemolytica cause severe pneumonia in sheep and goat .
p . multocida be a specie that can be transmit from animal to human through bite , cause infection of the skin and deep tissue .
the genus haemophilus contain two human pathogen , h . influenzae and h . ducreyi .
despite - pron - name , h . influenzae do not cause influenza ( which be a viral disease ) .
h . influenzae can cause both upper and low respiratory tract infection , include sinusitis , bronchitis , ear infection , and pneumonia .
before the development of effective vaccination , strain of h . influenzae be a lead cause of more invasive disease , like meningitis in child .
h . ducreyi cause the sti know as chancroid .
the order vibrionales include the human pathogen vibrio cholerae .

enterobacteriaceae be a large family of enteric ( intestinal ) bacteria belong to the gammaproteobacteria .
- pron - be facultative anaerobe and be able to ferment carbohydrate .
within this family , microbiologist recognize two distinct category .
the first category be call the coliform , after - pron - prototypical bacterium specie , escherichia coli .
coliform be able to ferment lactose completely ( i . e . , with the production of acid and gas ) .
the second category , chapter four
 prokaryotic diversity
one  six  three noncoliform , either can not ferment lactose or can only ferment - pron - incompletely ( produce either acid or gas , but not both ) .
the noncoliform include some notable human pathogen , such as salmonella spp .
, shigella spp . , and yersinia pestis .
e . coli have be perhaps the most studied bacterium since - pron - be first describe in one  eight  eight  six by theodor escherich ( one  eight  five  seven – one  nine  one  one ) .
many strain of e . coli be in mutualistic relationship with human .
however , some strain produce a potentially deadly toxin call shiga toxin .
shiga toxin be one of the most potent bacterial toxin identify .
upon enter target cell , shiga toxin interact with ribosome , stop protein synthesis .
lack of protein synthesis lead to cellular death and hemorrhagic colitis , characterize by inflammation of intestinal tract and bloody diarrhea .
in the most severe case , patient can develop a deadly hemolytic uremic syndrome .
other e . coli strain may cause traveler 's diarrhea , a less severe but very widespread disease .
the genus salmonella , which belong to the noncoliform group of enterobacteriaceae , be interesting in that there be still no consensus about how many specie - pron - include .
scientist have reclassify many of the group - pron - once think to be specie as serotype ( also call serovar ) , which be strain or variation of the same specie of bacteria .
- pron - classification be base on pattern of reactivity by animal antisera against molecule on the surface of the bacterial cell .
a number of serotype of salmonella can cause salmonellosis , characterize by inflammation of the small and the large intestine , accompany by fever , vomiting , and diarrhea .
the specie s . enterobacterica ( serovar typhi ) cause typhoid fever , with symptom include fever , abdominal pain , and skin rash ( figure four  .  one  zero ) .
figure four  .  one  zero salmonella typhi be the causative agent of typhoid fever .

deltaproteobacteria
the deltaproteobacteria be a small class of gram - negative proteobacteria that include sulfate - reduce bacteria chapter four
 prokaryotic diversity one  six  five ( srbs ) , so name because - pron - use sulfate as the final electron acceptor in the electron transport chain .
few srb be pathogenic .
however , the srb desulfovibrio orale be associate with periodontal disease ( disease of the gums ) .
deltaproteobacteria also include the genus bdellovibrio , specie of which be parasite of other gram - negative bacteria .
bdellovibrio invade the cell of the host bacterium , position - pron - in the periplasm , the space between the plasma membrane and the cell wall , feed on the host 's protein and polysaccharide .
the infection be lethal for the host cell .
another type of deltaproteobacteria , myxobacteria , live in the soil , scavenge inorganic compound .
motile and highly social , - pron - interact with other bacteria within and outside - pron - own group .
- pron - can form multicellular , macroscopic “ fruiting body "
( figure four  .  one  one ) , structure that be still be study by biologist and bacterial ecologists . [ one  one ]
these bacteria can also form metabolically inactive myxospore .

epsilonproteobacteria
the small class of proteobacteria be epsilonproteobacteria , which be gram - negative microaerophilic bacteria ( mean - pron - only require small amount of oxygen in - pron - environment ) .
two clinically relevant genera of epsilonproteobacteria be campylobacter and helicobacter , both of which include human pathogen .
campylobacter can cause food poisoning that manifest as severe enteritis ( inflammation in the small intestine ) .
this condition , cause by the specie c . jejuni , be rather common in develop country , usually because of eat contaminate poultry product .
chicken often harbor c . jejuni in - pron - gastrointestinal tract and fece , and - pron - meat can become contaminate during processing .
within the genus helicobacter , the helical , flagellate bacterium h . pylorus have be identify as a beneficial member of the stomach microbiota , but - pron - be also the most common cause of chronic gastriti and ulcer of the stomach and duodenum ( figure four  .  one  two ) .
study have also show that h . pylori be link to stomach cancer . [ one  two ] h . pylorus be somewhat unusual in - pron - ability to survive in the highly acidic environment of the stomach .
- pron - produce urease and other enzyme that modify - pron - environment to make - pron - less acidic .
figure four  .  one  two helicobacter pylorus can cause chronic gastritis , which can lead to ulcer and stomach cancer .

four  .  three nonproteobacteria gram - negative bacteria and phototrophic bacteria learning objectives

describe the unique feature of phototrophic bacteria
 identify phototrophic bacteria
the majority of the gram - negative bacteria belong to the phylum proteobacteria , discuss in the previous section .
those that do not be call the nonproteobacteria .
in this section , - pron - will describe three class of gram - negative nonproteobacteria  the spirochete , the cfb group , and the planctomycetes .
a diverse group of phototrophic bacteria that include proteobacteria and nonproteobacteria will be discuss at the end of this section .
spirochetes spirochetes be characterize by - pron - long ( up to two  five  zero μm ) , spiral - shaped body .
most spirochete be also very thin , which make - pron - difficult to examine gram - stain preparation under a conventional brightfield microscope .
darkfield fluorescent microscopy be typically use instead .
spirochete be also difficult or even impossible to culture .
- pron - be highly motile , use - pron - axial filament to propel - pron - .
the axial filament be similar to a flagellum , but - pron - wrap around the cell and run inside the cell body of a spirochete in the periplasmic space between the outer membrane and the plasma membrane ( figure four  .  one  three ) .

several genera of spirochete include human pathogen .
for example , the genus treponema include a species t . pallidum , which be further classify into four subspecie  t . pallidum pallidum , t . pallidum pertenue , t . pallidum carateum , and t . pallidum endemicum .
the subspecie t . pallidum pallidum cause the sexually transmit infection know as syphilis , the third most prevalent sexually transmit bacterial infection in the united states , after chlamydia and gonorrhea .
the other subspecie of t . pallidum cause tropical infectious disease of the skin , bone , and joint .
another genus of spirochete , borrelia , contain a number of pathogenic specie .
b . burgdorferi cause lyme disease , which be transmit by several genera of tick ( notably ixodes and amblyomma ) and often produce a " bull 's eye " rash , fever , fatigue , and , sometimes , debilitate arthritis .
b . recurren cause a condition know as relapse fever .

chapter four  prokaryotic diversity one  six  nine cytophaga , fusobacterium , and bacteroides the gram - negative nonproteobacteria of the genera cytophaga , fusobacterium , and bacteroides be classify together as a phylum and call the cfb group .
although - pron - be phylogenetically diverse , bacteria of the cfb group share some similarity in the sequence of nucleotide in - pron - dna .
- pron - be rod - shape bacteria adapt to anaerobic environment , such as the tissue of the gum , gut , and ruman of ruminate animal .
cfb bacteria be avid fermenter , able to process cellulose in ruman , thus enable ruminant animal to obtain carbon and energy from graze .
cytophaga be motile aquatic bacteria that glide .
fusobacteria inhabit the human mouth and may cause severe infectious disease .
the large genus of the cfb group be bacteroides , which include dozen of specie that be prevalent inhabitant of the human large intestine , make up about three  zero % of the entire gut microbiome ( figure four  .  one  four ) .
one gram of human fece contain up to one  zero  zero billion bacteroide cell .
most bacteroide be mutualistic .
- pron - benefit from nutrient - pron - find in the gut , and human benefit from - pron - ability to prevent pathogen from colonize the large intestine .
indeed , when population of bacteroide be reduce in the gut - as often occur when a patient take antibiotic - the gut become a more favorable environment for pathogenic bacteria and fungi , which can cause secondary infection .
figure four  .  one  four bacteroides comprise up to three  zero % of the normal microbiota in the human gut .
( credit  noaa )
only a few specie of bacteroides be pathogenic .
b . melaninogenicus , for example , can cause wound infection in patient with weaken immune system .

planctomycete
the planctomycetes be find in aquatic environment , inhabit freshwater , saltwater , and brackish water .
planctomycete be unusual in that - pron - reproduce by bud , mean that instead of one maternal cell split into two equal daughter cell in the process of binary fission , the mother cell form a bud that detach from the mother cell and live as an independent cell .
these so - call swarmer cell be motile and not attach to a surface .
however , - pron - will soon differentiate into sessile ( immobile ) cell with an appendage call a holdfast that allow - pron - to attach to surface in the water ( figure four  .  one  five ) .
only the sessile cell be able to reproduce .

phototrophic bacteria
the phototrophic bacteria be a large and diverse category of bacteria that do not represent a taxon but , rather , a group of bacteria that use sunlight as - pron - primary source of energy .
this group contain both proteobacteria and chapter four  prokaryotic diversity one  seven  one nonproteobacteria .
- pron - use solar energy to synthesize atp through photosynthesis .
when - pron - produce oxygen , - pron - perform oxygenic photosynthesis .
when - pron - do not produce oxygen , - pron - perform anoxygenic photosynthesis .
with the exception of some cyanobacteria , the majority of phototrophic bacteria perform anoxygenic photosynthesis .
one large group of phototrophic bacteria include the purple or green bacteria that perform photosynthesis with the help of bacteriochlorophyll , which be green , purple , or blue pigment similar to chlorophyll in plant .
some of these bacteria have a vary amount of red or orange pigment call carotenoid .
- pron - color vary from orange to red to purple to green ( figure four  .  one  six ) , and - pron - be able to absorb light of various wavelength .
traditionally , these bacteria be classify into sulfur and nonsulfur bacteria  - pron - be further differentiate by color .
figure four  .  one  six purple and green sulfur bacteria use bacteriochlorophyll to perform photosynthesis .
the sulfur bacteria perform anoxygenic photosynthesis , use sulfite as electron donor and release free elemental sulfur .
nonsulfur bacteria use organic substrate , such as succinate and malate , as donor of electron .
the purple sulfur bacteria oxidize hydrogen sulfide into elemental sulfur and sulfuric acid and get - pron - purple color from the pigment bacteriochlorophyll and carotenoid .
bacteria of the genus chromatium be purple sulfur gammaproteobacteria .
these microorganism be strict anaerobe and live in water .
- pron - use carbon dioxide as - pron - only source of carbon , but - pron - survival and growth be possible only in the presence of sulfite , which - pron - use as electron donor .
chromatium have be use as a model for study of bacterial photosynthesis since the one  nine  five  zero s . [ one  three ] the green sulfur bacteria use sulfide for oxidation and produce large amount of green bacteriochlorophyll .
the genus chlorobium be a green sulfur bacterium that be implicate in climate change because - pron - produce methane , a greenhouse gas .
these bacteria use at least four type of chlorophyll for photosynthesis .
the most prevalent of these , bacteriochlorophyll , be store in special vesicle - like organelle call chlorosome .
purple nonsulfur bacteria be similar to purple sulfur bacteria , except that - pron - use hydrogen rather than hydrogen sulfide for oxidation .
among the purple nonsulfur bacteria be the genus rhodospirillum .
these microorganism be facultative anaerobe , which be actually pink rather than purple , and can metabolize ( " fix " ) nitrogen .
- pron - may be valuable in the field of biotechnology because of - pron - potential ability to produce biological plastic and hydrogen fuel . [ one  four ]
the green nonsulfur bacteria be similar to green sulfur bacteria but - pron - use substrate other than sulfide for oxidation .
chloroflexus be an example of a green nonsulfur bacterium .
- pron - often have an orange color when - pron - grow in the dark , but - pron - become green when - pron - grow in sunlight .
- pron - store bacteriochlorophyll in chlorosome , similar to chlorobium , and perform anoxygenic photosynthesis , use organic sulfite ( low concentration ) or molecular hydrogen as electron donor , so - pron - can survive in the dark if oxygen be available .
chloroflexus do not have flagella one  three .

cyanobacteria have other remarkable property .
amazingly adaptable , - pron - thrive in many habitat , include marine and freshwater environment , soil , and even rock .
- pron - can live at a wide range of temperature , even in the extreme temperature of the antarctic .
- pron - can live as unicellular organism or in colony , and - pron - can be filamentous , form sheath or biofilm .
many of - pron - fix nitrogen , convert molecular nitrogen into nitrite and nitrate that other bacteria , plant , and animal can use .
the reaction of nitrogen fixation occur in specialized cell call heterocyst .
photosynthesis in cyanobacteria be oxygenic , use the same type of chlorophyll a find in plant and algae as the primary photosynthetic pigment .
cyanobacteria also use phycocyanin and cyanophycin , two secondary photosynthetic pigment that give - pron - - pron - characteristic blue color .
- pron - be locate in special organelle call phycobilisome and in fold of the cellular membrane call thylakoid , which be remarkably similar to the photosynthetic apparatus of plant .
scientist hypothesize that plant originate from endosymbiosis of ancestral eukaryotic cell and ancestral photosynthetic bacteria . gram - positive bacteria learning objectives
 describe the unique feature of each category of high g+c and low g+c gram - positive bacteria

identify similarity and difference between high g+c and low g+c bacterial group  give an example of a bacterium of high g+c and low g+c group commonly associate with each category prokaryote be identify as gram - positive if - pron - have a multiple layer matrix of peptidoglycan form the cell wall .
crystal violet , the primary stain of the gram stain procedure , be readily retain and stabilize within this matrix , cause gram - positive prokaryote to appear purple under a brightfield microscope after gram staining .
for many year , the retention of gram stain be one of the main criterion use to classify prokaryote , even though some prokaryote do not readily stain with either the primary or secondary stain use in the gram stain procedure .
advance in nucleic acid biochemistry have reveal additional characteristic that can be use to classify grampositive prokaryote , namely the guanine to cytosine ratio ( g+c ) in dna and the composition of one  six s rrna subunit .
microbiologist currently recognize two distinct group of gram - positive , or weakly stain gram - positive , prokaryote .
the class actinobacteria comprise the high g+c gram - positive bacteria , which have more than five  zero % and biology six  one  nine ( two  zero  zero  eight  )  six  one  three – six  three  seven . one  seven  four chapter four  prokaryotic diversity

the class bacilli comprise low g+c gram - positive bacteria , which have less than five  zero % of guanine and cytosine nucleotide in - pron - dna .
actinobacteria  high g+c gram - positive bacteria
the name actinobacteria come from the greek word for ray and small rod , but actinobacteria be very diverse .
- pron - microscopic appearance can range from thin filamentous branching rod to coccobacilli .
some actinobacteria be very large and complex , whereas other be among the small independently live organism .
most actinobacteria live in the soil , but some be aquatic .
the vast majority be aerobic .
one distinctive feature of this group be the presence of several different peptidoglycan in the cell wall .
the genus actinomyces be a much study representative of actinobacteria .
actinomyce spp . play an important role in soil ecology , and some specie be human pathogen .
a number of actinomyces spp .
inhabit the human mouth and be opportunistic pathogen , cause infectious disease like periodontitis ( inflammation of the gums ) and oral abscess .
the specie a . israelii be an anaerobe notorious for cause endocarditis ( inflammation of the inner lining of the heart )

the genus mycobacterium be represent by bacilli cover with a mycolic acid coat .
this waxy coat protect the bacteria from some antibiotic , prevent - pron - from dry out , and block penetration by gram stain reagent ( see staining microscopic specimens ) .
because of this , a special acid - fast staining procedure be use to visualize these bacteria .
the genus mycobacterium be an important cause of a diverse group of infectious disease .
m . tuberculosis be the causative agent of tuberculosis , a disease that primarily impact the lung but can infect other part of the body as well .
- pron - have be estimate that one - third of the world 's population have be infect with m . tuberculosis and million of new infection occur each year .
treatment of m . tuberculosis be challenge and require patient to take a combination of drug for an extended time .
complicate treatment even further be the development and spread of multidrug - resistant strain of this pathogen .
another pathogenic specie , m . leprae , be the cause of hansen 's disease ( leprosy ) , a chronic disease that impact peripheral nerve and the integrity of the skin and mucosal surface of the respiratory tract .
loss of pain sensation and the presence of skin lesion increase susceptibility to secondary injury and infection with other pathogen .
bacteria in the genus corynebacterium contain diaminopimelic acid in - pron - cell wall , and microscopically often form palisade , or pair of rod - shaped cell resemble the letter v . cells may contain metachromatic granule , intracellular storage of inorganic phosphate that be useful for identification of corynebacterium .
the vast majority of corynebacterium spp .
be nonpathogenic  however , c . diphtheria be the causative agent of diphtheria , a disease that can be fatal , especially in child ( figure four  .  one  eight ) .
c . diphtheria produce a toxin that form a pseudomembrane in chapter four  prokaryotic diversity one  seven  five the patient 's throat , cause swelling , difficulty breathing , and other symptom that can become serious if untreated .
the genus bifidobacterium consist of filamentous anaerobe , many of which be commonly find in the gastrointestinal tract , vagina , and mouth .
in fact , bifidobacterium spp . constitute a substantial part of the human gut microbiota and be frequently use as probiotic and in yogurt production .
the genus gardnerella , contain only one specie , g . vaginalis .
this species be define as " gram - variable " because - pron - small coccobacilli do not show consistent result when gram stain ( figure four  .  one  eight ) .
base on - pron - genome , - pron - be place into the high g+c gram - positive group .
g . vaginalis can cause bacterial vaginosis in woman  symptom be typically mild or even undetectable , but can lead to complication during pregnancy .

clostridia one large and diverse class of low g+c gram - positive bacteria be clostridia .
the best study genus of this class be clostridium .
these rod - shape bacteria be generally obligate anaerobe that produce endospore and can be find in anaerobic habitat like soil and aquatic sediment rich in organic nutrient .
the endospore may survive for many year .
clostridium spp . produce more kind of protein toxin than any other bacterial genus , and several specie be human pathogen .
c . perfringen be the third most common cause of food poisoning in the united states and be the causative agent of an even more serious disease call gas gangrene .
gas gangrene occur when c . perfringen endospore clinical focus chapter four  prokaryotic diversity one  seven  seven enter a wound and germinate , become viable bacterial cell and produce a toxin that can cause the necrosis ( death ) of tissue .
c . tetani , which cause tetanus , produce a neurotoxin that be able to enter neuron , travel to region of the central nervous system where - pron - block the inhibition of nerve impulse involve in muscle contraction , and cause a life - threaten spastic paralysis .
c . botulinum produce botulinum neurotoxin , the most lethal biological toxin know .
botulinum toxin be responsible for rare but frequently fatal case of botulism .
the toxin block the release of acetylcholine in neuromuscular junction , cause flaccid paralysis .
in very small concentration , botulinum toxin have be use to treat muscle pathology in human and in a cosmetic procedure to eliminate wrinkle .
c . difficile be a common source of hospital - acquire infection ( figure four  .  one  nine ) that can result in serious and even fatal case of colitis ( inflammation of the large intestine ) .
infection often occur in patient who be immunosuppressed or undergo antibiotic therapy that alter the normal microbiota of the gastrointestinal tract .

lactobacillale
the order lactobacillales comprise low g+c gram - positive bacteria that include both bacillus and cocci in the genera lactobacillus , leuconostoc , enterococcus , and streptococcus .
bacteria of the latter three genera typically be spherical or ovoid and often form chain .

specie from this genus , often refer to as streptococci , be usually classify by serotype call lancefield group , and by - pron - ability to lyse red blood cell when grow on blood agar .

bacilli
the name of the class bacilli suggest that - pron - be make up of bacteria that be bacillus in shape , but - pron - be a morphologically diverse class that include bacillus - shape and cocccus - shaped genera .
among the many genera in this class be two that be very important clinically 
bacillus and staphylococcus .
bacteria in the genus bacillus be bacillus in shape and can produce endospore .
- pron - include aerobe or facultative anaerobe .
a number of bacillus spp . be use in various industry , include the production of antibiotic ( e . g . , barnase ) , enzymes ( e . g . , alpha - amylase , bamh one restriction endonuclease ) , and detergent ( e . g . , subtilisin ) .
two notable pathogen belong to the genus bacillus .
b . anthracis be the pathogen that cause anthrax , a severe disease that affect wild and domesticate animal and can spread from infected animal to human .
anthrax manifest in human as charcoal - black ulcer on the skin , severe enterocolitis , pneumonia , and brain damage due to swell .
if untreated , anthrax be lethal .
b . cereus , a closely relate specie , be a pathogen that may cause food poisoning .

this bacterium produce a number of substance use as insecticide because - pron - be toxic for insect .

resolution marsha 's sputum sample be send to the microbiology lab to confirm the identity of the microorganism cause - pron - infection .

biopiracy and bioprospecting
in one  nine  six  nine , an employee of a swiss pharmaceutical company be vacation in norway and decide to collect some soil sample .
- pron - take - pron - back to - pron - lab , and the swiss company subsequently use the fungus tolypocladium inflatum in those sample to develop cyclosporine a , a drug widely use in patient who undergo tissue or organ transplantation .
the swiss company earn more than $ one billion a year for production of cyclosporine a , yet norway receive nothing in return -
no payment to the government or benefit for the norwegian people .
despite the fact the cyclosporine a save numerous life , many consider the mean by which the soil sample be obtain to be an act of “ biopiracy , " essentially a form of theft .
do the end justify the mean in a case like this ?
nature be full of as - yet - undiscovered bacteria and other microorganism that could one day be use to develop new life - save drug or treatments . [ two  one ] pharmaceutical and biotechnology company stand to reap huge profit from such discovery , but ethical question remain .
to whom do biological resource belong ?
should company who invest ( and risk ) million of dollar in research and development be require to share revenue or royalty for the right to access biological resource ?
compensation be not the only issue when - pron - come to bioprospecting .
some community and culture be philosophically opposed to bioprospecte , fear unforeseen consequence of collect genetic or biological material .
native hawaiians , for example , be very protective of - pron - unique biological resource .
for many year , - pron - be unclear what right government agency , private corporation , and citizen have when - pron - come to collect sample of microorganism from public land .
then , in one  nine  nine  three , the convention on biological diversity grant each nation the right to any genetic and biological material find on - pron - own land .
scientist can no longer collect sample without a prior arrangement with the land owner for compensation .
this convention now ensure that company act ethically in obtain the sample - pron - use to create - pron - eye on ethics chapter four  prokaryotic diversity one  eight  three product .

four  .  six archaea learning objectives
 describe the unique feature of each category of archaea 
explain why archaea may not be associate with human microbiome or pathology  give common example of archaea commonly associate with unique environmental habitat like organism in the domain bacteria , organism of the domain archaea be all unicellular organism .
however , archaea differ structurally from bacteria in several significant way , as discuss in unique characteristics of chapter four  prokaryotic diversity one  eight  five prokaryotic cells .
to summarize   the archaeal cell membrane be compose of ether linkage with branched isoprene chain ( as oppose to the bacterial cell membrane , which have est linkage with unbranched fatty acid ) .
 archaeal cell wall lack peptidoglycan , but some contain a structurally similar substance call pseudopeptidoglycan or pseudomurein .

the genome of archaea be large and more complex than those of bacteria .
domain archaea be as diverse as domain bacteria , and - pron - representative can be find in any habitat .
some archaea be mesophile , and many be extremophile , prefer extreme hot or cold , extreme salinity , or other condition that be hostile to most other form of life on earth .
- pron - metabolism be adapt to the harsh environment , and - pron - can perform methanogenesis , for example , which bacteria and eukaryote can not .
the size and complexity of the archaeal genome make - pron - difficult to classify .
most taxonomist agree that within the archaea , there be currently five major phylum  crenarchaeota , euryarchaeota , korarchaeota , nanoarchaeota , and thaumarchaeota .
there be likely many other archaeal group that have not yet be systematically study and classify .
with few exception , archaea be not present in the human microbiota , and none be currently know to be associate with infectious disease in human , animal , plant , or microorganism .
however , many play important role in the environment and may thus have an indirect impact on human health .
crenarchaeota crenarchaeota be a class of archaea that be extremely diverse , contain genera and specie that differ vastly in - pron - morphology and requirement for growth .
all crenarchaeota be aquatic organism , and - pron - be think to be the most abundant microorganism in the ocean .
most , but not all , crenarchaeota be hyperthermophile  some of - pron - ( notably , the genus pyrolobus ) be able to grow at temperature
up to one  one  three ° c . [ two  three ]
archaea of the genus sulfolobus ( figure four  .  two  six ) be thermophile that prefer temperature around seven  zero – eight  zero ° c and acidophile that prefer a ph of two – three  . [ two  four ]

euryarchaeota
the phylum euryarchaeota include several distinct class .
specie in the class methanobacteria , methanococci , and methanomicrobia represent archaea that can be generally describe as methanogen .
methanogen be unique in that - pron - can reduce carbon dioxide in the presence of hydrogen , produce methane .
- pron - can live in the most extreme environment and can reproduce at temperature vary from below freeze to boiling .
methanogen have be find in hot spring as well as deep under ice in greenland .
some scientist have even hypothesize that methanogen may inhabit the planet mars because the mixture of gas produce by methanogen resemble the makeup of the martian atmosphere . [ two  six ]
methanogens be think to contribute to the formation of anoxic sediment by produce hydrogen sulfide , make “ marsh gas .
"
- pron - also produce gas in ruminant and human .
some genera of methanogen , notably methanosarcina , can grow and produce methane in the presence of oxygen , although the vast majority be strict anaerobe .
the class halobacteria ( which be name before scientist recognize the distinction between archaea and bacteria ) include halophilic ( " salt - love " ) archaea .
halobacteria require a very high concentration of sodium chloride in - pron - aquatic environment .
the required concentration be close to saturation , at three  six %  such environment include the dead sea as well as some salty lake in antarctica and south - central asia .

summary four  .  one prokaryote habitats , relationships , and microbiomes 
prokaryotes be unicellular microorganism whose cell have no nucleus .

prokaryotes can be find everywhere on - pron - planet , even in the most extreme environment .

prokaryote be very flexible metabolically , so - pron - be able to adjust - pron - feeding to the available natural resource .

prokaryotes live in community that interact among - pron - and with large organism that - pron - use as host ( include human ) .

the totality of form of prokaryote ( particularly bacteria ) live on the human body be call the human microbiome , which vary between region of the body and individual , and change over time .

the totality of form of prokaryote ( particularly bacteria ) live in a certain region of the human body ( e . g . , mouth , throat , gut , eye , vagina ) be call the microbiota of this region .

prokaryotes be classify into domain archaea and bacteria .

in recent year , the traditional approach to classification of prokaryote have be supplement by approach base on molecular genetic .
four  .  two proteobacteria  proteobacteria be a phylum of gram - negative bacteria discover by carl woese in the one  nine  eight  zero base on nucleotide sequence homology .

proteobacteria be further classify into the class alpha - , beta - , gamma - , delta - and epsilonproteobacteria , each class have separate order , family , genera , and specie .

alphaproteobacteria be oligotroph .
the taxa chlamydia and rickettsia be obligate intracellular pathogen , feed on cell of host organism  - pron - be metabolically inactive outside of the host cell .
some alphaproteobacteria can convert atmospheric nitrogen to nitrite , make nitrogen usable by other form of life .

betaproteobacteria be eutroph .
- pron - include human pathogen of the genus neisseria and the specie bordetella pertussis .

gammaproteobacteria be the large and the most diverse group of proteobacteria .
many be human pathogen that be aerobe or facultative anaerobe .
some gammaproteobacteria be enteric bacteria that may be coliform or noncoliform .
escherichia coli , a member of gammaproteobacteria , be perhaps the most studied bacterium .

deltaproteobacteria make up a small group able to reduce sulfate or elemental sulfur .
some be scavenger and form myxospore , with multicellular fruiting body .

epsilonproteobacteria make up the small group of proteobacteria .
the genera campylobacter and helicobacter be human pathogen .
four  .  three nonproteobacteria gram - negative bacteria and phototrophic bacteria
 gram - negative nonproteobacteria include the taxa spirochete  the cytophaga , fusobacterium , bacteroides group  planctomycetes  and many representative of phototrophic bacteria .

spirochetes be motile , spiral bacteria with a long , narrow body  - pron - be difficult or impossible to culture .

several genera of spirochete contain human pathogen that cause such disease as syphilis and lyme disease .

planctomycete be aquatic bacteria that reproduce by bud  - pron - may form large colony , and develop a holdfast .
 phototrophic bacteria be not a taxon but , rather , a group categorize by - pron - ability to use the energy of sunlight .
- pron - include proteobacteria and nonproteobacteria , as well as sulfur and nonsulfur bacteria color purple or green .

sulfur bacteria perform anoxygenic photosynthesis , use sulfur compound as donor of electron , whereas nonsulfur bacteria use organic compound ( succinate , malate ) as donor of electron .

some phototrophic bacteria be able to fix nitrogen , provide the usable form of nitrogen to other organism .

cyanobacteria be oxygen - produce bacteria think to have play a critical role in the forming of the earth 's atmosphere .
four  .  four
gram - positive bacteria  gram - positive bacteria be a very large and diverse group of microorganism .
understand - pron - taxonomy and know - pron - unique feature be important for diagnostic and treatment of infectious disease .
 gram - positive bacteria be classify into high g+c gram - positive and low g+c gram - positive bacteria , base on the prevalence of guanine and cytosine nucleotide in - pron - genome 
actinobacteria be the taxonomic name of the class of high g+c gram - positive bacteria .
this class include the genera actinomyces , arthrobacter , corynebacterium , frankia , gardnerella , micrococcus , mycobacterium , nocardia , propionibacterium , rhodococcus , and streptomyces .
some representative of these genera be use in industry  other be human or animal pathogen .

example of high g+c gram - positive bacteria that be human pathogen include mycobacterium tuberculosis , which cause tuberculosis  m . leprae , which cause leprosy ( hansen 's disease )  and corynebacterium diphtheriae , which cause diphtheria .

clostridia spp .
be low g+c gram - positive bacteria that be generally obligate anaerobe and can form endospore .
pathogen in this genus include c . perfringen ( gas gangrene ) , c . tetani ( tetanus ) , and c . botulinum ( botulism ) .

lactobacillales include the genera enterococcus , lactobacillus , leuconostoc , and streptococcus .
streptococcus be responsible for many human disease , include pharyngitis ( strep throat ) , scarlet fever , rheumatic fever , glomerulonephritis , pneumonia , and other respiratory infection .

bacilli be a taxonomic class of low g+c gram - positive bacteria that include rod - shaped and coccus - shape specie , include the genera bacillus and staphylococcus .
b . anthracis cause anthrax , b . cereus may cause opportunistic infection of the gastrointestinal tract , and s . aureus strain can cause a wide range of infection and disease , many of which be highly resistant to antibiotic .

mycoplasma spp . be very small , pleomorphic low g+c gram - positive bacteria that lack cell wall .
m . pneumoniae cause atypical pneumonia .

although bacteria and virus account for a large number of the infectious disease that afflict human , many serious illness be cause by eukaryotic organism .
one example be malaria , which be cause by plasmodium , a eukaryotic organism transmit through mosquito bite .
malaria be a major cause of morbidity ( illness ) and mortality ( death ) that threaten three  .  four billion people worldwide . [ one ]
in severe case , organ failure and blood or metabolic abnormality contribute to medical emergency and sometimes death .
even after initial recovery , relapse may occur year later .
in country where malaria be endemic , the disease represent a major public health challenge that can place a tremendous strain on develop economy .
worldwide , major effort be underway to reduce malaria infection .
effort include the distribution of insecticidetreated bed net and the spraying of pesticide .
researcher be also make progress in - pron - effort to develop effective vaccines . [ two ]
the president 's malaria initiative , start in two  zero  zero  five , support prevention and treatment .
the bill and melinda gates foundation have a large initiative to eliminate malaria .
despite these effort , malaria continue to cause long - term morbidity ( such as intellectual disability in child ) and mortality ( especially in child young than five year ) , so - pron - still have far to go .

although more disease be cause by virus and bacteria than by microscopic eukaryote , these eukaryote be responsible for some disease of great public health importance .
for example , the protozoal disease malaria be responsible for five  eight  four  ,  zero  zero  zero death worldwide ( primarily child in africa ) in two  zero  one  three , accord to the world health organization ( who ) .
the protist parasite giardia cause a diarrheal illness ( giardiasis ) that be easily transmit through contaminate water supply .

although - pron - may seem surprising , parasitic worm be include within the study of microbiology because identification depend on observation of microscopic adult worm or egg .

characteristics of protists
the word protist be a historical term that be now use informally to refer to a diverse group of microscopic eukaryotic organism .
- pron - be not consider a formal taxonomic term because the organism - pron - describe do not have a share evolutionary origin .
historically , the protist be informally group into the “ animal - like " protozoan , the “ plantlike " algae , and the " fungus - like " protist such as water mold .
these three group of protist differ greatly in term of - pron - basic characteristic .
for example , algae be photosynthetic organism that can be unicellular or multicellular .
protozoa , on the other hand , be nonphotosynthetic , motile organism that be always unicellular .
other informal term may also be use to describe various group of protist .
for example , microorganism that drift or float in water , move by current , be refer to as plankton .
type of plankton include zooplankton , which be motile and nonphotosynthetic , and phytoplankton , which be photosynthetic .
protozoan inhabit a wide variety of habitat , both aquatic and terrestrial .
many be free - living , while other be parasitic , carry out a life cycle within a host or host and potentially cause illness .
there be also beneficial symbiont that provide metabolic service to - pron - host .
during the feeding and growth part of - pron - life cycle , - pron - be call trophozoite  these feed on small particulate food source such as bacteria .
while some type of protozoa exist exclusively in the trophozoite form , other can develop from trophozoite to an encapsulate cyst stage when environmental condition be too harsh for the trophozoite .
a cyst be a cell with a protective wall , and the process by which a trophozoite become a cyst be call encystment .
when condition become more favorable , these cyst be trigger by environmental cue to become active again through excystment .
one protozoan genus capable of encystment be eimeria , which include some human and animal pathogen .

protozoans have a variety of reproductive mechanism .
some protozoan reproduce asexually and other reproduce sexually  still other be capable of both sexual and asexual reproduction .
in protozoan , asexual reproduction occur by binary fission , budding , or schizogony .
in schizogony , the nucleus of a cell divide multiple time before the cell divide into many small cell .
the product of schizogony be call merozoite and - pron - be store in structure know as schizont .
protozoans may also reproduce sexually , which increase genetic diversity and can lead to complex life cycle .
protozoan can produce haploid gamete that fuse through syngamy .
however , - pron - can also exchange genetic material by join to exchange dna in a process call conjugation .
this be a different process than the conjugation that occur in bacteria .
the term protist conjugation refer to a true form of eukaryotic sexual reproduction between two cell of different mating type .
- pron - be find in ciliate , a group of protozoan , and be describe later in this subsection .
all protozoan have a plasma membrane , or plasmalemma , and some have band of protein just inside the membrane that add rigidity , form a structure call the pellicle .
some protist , include protozoan , have distinct layer of cytoplasm under the membrane .
in these protist , the outer gel layer ( with microfilament of actin ) be call the ectoplasm .
inside this layer be a sol ( fluid ) region of cytoplasm call the endoplasm .
these structure contribute to complex cell shape in some protozoan , whereas other ( such as amoebas ) have more flexible shape ( figure five  .  five ) .
different group of protozoan have specialize feeding structure .
- pron - may have a specialize structure for take in food through phagocytosis , call a cytostome , and a specialized structure for the exocytosis of waste call a cytoproct .
oral groove lead to cytostome be line with hair - like cilium to sweep in food particle .
protozoan be heterotrophic .
protozoan that be holozoic ingest whole food particle through phagocytosis .

many protist have whip - like flagella or hair - like cilia make of microtubule that can be use for locomotion ( figure five  .  five ) .
other protist use cytoplasmic extension know as pseudopodia ( " false foot " ) to attach the cell to a surface  - pron - then allow cytoplasm to flow into the extension , thus move - pron - forward .

taxonomy of protists
the protist be a polyphyletic group , mean - pron - lack a share evolutionary origin .
since the current taxonomy be base on evolutionary history ( as determine by biochemistry , morphology , and genetic ) , protist be scatter across many different taxonomic group within the domain eukarya .
eukarya be currently divide into six supergroup that be further divide into subgroup , as illustrate in ( figure five  .  six ) .
in this section , - pron - will primarily be concern with the supergroup
amoebozoa , excavata , and chromalveolata  these supergroup include many protozoan of clinical significance .
the supergroup opisthokonta and rhizaria also include some protozoan , but few of clinical significance .
in addition to protozoan , opisthokonta also include animal and fungus , some of which - pron - will discuss in parasitic helminths and fungi .
some example of the archaeplastida will be discuss in algae .

amoebozoa
the supergroup
amoebozoa include protozoan that use amoeboid movement .
actin microfilament produce pseudopodium , into which the remainder of the protoplasm flow , thereby move the organism .
the genus entamoeba include commensal or parasitic specie , include the medically important e . histolytica , which be transmit by cyst in fece and be the primary cause of amoebic dysentery .
the notorious " brain - eat amoeba , " naegleria fowleri , be also classify within the amoebozoa .
this deadly parasite be find in warm , fresh water and cause primary amoebic meningoencephalitis ( pam ) .
another member of this group be acanthamoeba , which can cause keratitis ( corneal inflammation ) and blindness .
the eumycetozoa be an unusual group of organism call slime mold , which have previously be classify as animal , fungus , and plant ( figure five  .  nine ) .
slime mold can be divide into two type  cellular slime mold and plasmodial slime mold .
the cellular slime mold exist as individual amoeboid cell that periodically aggregate into a mobile slug .
the aggregate then form a fruiting body that produce haploid spore .
plasmodial slime mold exist as large , multinucleate amoeboid cell that form reproductive stalk to produce spore that divide into gamete .
one cellular slime mold , dictyostelium discoideum , have be an important study organism for understand cell differentiation , because - pron - have both single - celle and multicelle life stage , with the cell show some degree of differentiation in the multicelle form .

( b ) fuligo septica be a plasmodial slime mold .
this brightly color organism consist of a large cell with many nucleus .

chromalveolata
the supergroup chromalveolata be unite by similar origin of - pron - member ' plastid and include the apicomplexan , ciliate , diatom , and dinoflagellate , among other group ( - pron - will cover the diatom and dinoflagellate in algae ) .

apicomplexan have complex life cycle that include an infective sporozoite that undergoes schizogony to make many merozoite ( see the example in figure five  .  four ) .
many be capable of infect a variety of animal cell , from insect to livestock to human , and - pron - life cycle often depend on transmission between multiple host .
the genus plasmodium be an example of this group .

other apicomplexan be also medically important .

because toxoplasmosis can be associate with serious birth defect , pregnant woman need to be aware of this risk and use caution if - pron - be expose to the fece of potentially infect cat .

rate be much high in other country , include some develop countries . [ three ]
there be also evidence and a good deal of theorize that the parasite may be responsible for alter infect human ' behavior and personality traits . [ four ]
the ciliate ( ciliaphora ) , also within the chromalveolata , be a large , very diverse group characterize by the presence of cilium on - pron - cell surface .
although the cilia may be use for locomotion , - pron - be often use for feeding , as well , and some form be nonmotile .

perhaps the most familiar ciliate be paramecium , a motile organism with a clearly visible cytostome and cytoproct that be often study in biology laboratory
( figure five  .  one  four ) .
another ciliate , stentor , be sessile and use - pron - cilia for feed ( figure five  .  one  five ) .
generally , these organism have a micronucleus that be diploid , somatic , and use for sexual reproduction by conjugation .
- pron - also have a macronucleus that be derive from the micronucleus  the macronucleus become polyploid ( multiple set of duplicate chromosome ) , and have a reduced set of metabolic gene .
ciliate be able to reproduce through conjugation , in which two cell attach to each other .
in each cell , the diploid micronuclei undergo meiosis , produce eight haploid nucleus each .
then , all but one of the haploid micronuclei and the macronucleus disintegrate  the remain ( haploid ) micronucleus undergoes mitosis .
the two cell then exchange one micronucleus each , which fuse with the remain micronucleus present to form a new , genetically different , three .

excavata
the third and final supergroup to be consider in this section be the excavata , which include primitive eukaryote and many parasite with limited metabolic ability .
these organism have complex cell shape and structure , often include a depression on the surface of the cell call an excavate .
the group excavata include the subgroup fornicata , parabasalia , and euglenozoa .
the fornicata lack mitochondria but have flagella .
this group include giardia lamblia ( also know as g . intestinali or g . duodenalis ) , a widespread pathogen that cause diarrheal illness and can be spread through cyst from fece that contaminate water supply ( figure five  .  three ) .
parabasalia be frequent animal endosymbiont  - pron - live in the gut of animal like termite and cockroach .
- pron - have basal body and modify mitochondria ( kinetoplastid ) .
- pron - also have a large , complex cell structure with an undulating membrane and often have many flagellum .
the trichomonad ( a subgroup of the parabasalia ) include pathogen such as trichomonas vaginalis , which cause the human sexually transmit disease trichomoniasis .
trichomoniasis often do not cause symptom in man , but man be able to transmit the infection .
in woman , - pron - cause vaginal discomfort and discharge and may cause complication in pregnancy if leave untreated .
the euglenozoa be common in the environment and include photosynthetic and nonphotosynthetic specie .
member of the genus euglena be typically not pathogenic .
- pron - cell have two flagellum , a pellicle , a stigma ( eyespot ) to sense light , and chloroplast for photosynthesis ( figure five  .  one  seven ) .
the pellicle of euglena be make of a series of protein band surround the cell  - pron - support the cell membrane and give the cell shape .
the euglenozoa also include the trypanosome , which be parasitic pathogen .
the genus trypanosoma include t . brucei , which cause african trypanosomiasis ( african sleep sickness and t . cruzi , which cause american trypanosomiasis ( chagas disease ) .
these tropical disease be spread by insect bite .
in african sleep sickness , t . brucei colonize the blood and the brain after be transmit via the bite of a tsetse fly ( glossina spp . )
( figure five  .  one  eight ) .
the early symptom include confusion , difficulty sleep , and lack of coordination .
leave untreated , - pron - be fatal .

two  one  three nematoda ( roundworm )
phylum nematoda ( the roundworm ) be a diverse group contain more than one  five  ,  zero  zero  zero specie , of which several be important human parasite ( figure five  .  one  nine ) .
these unsegmented worm have a full digestive system even when parasitic .

a . lumbricoide be also very widespread , even in developed nation , although - pron - be now a relatively uncommon problem in the united states .

of all nematode infection in the united states , pinworm ( cause by enterobius vermicularis ) be the most common .
pinworm cause sleeplessness and itch around the anus , where the female worm lie - pron - egg during the night .
toxocara cani and t . cati be nematode find in dog and cat , respectively , that can be transmit to human , cause toxocariasis .

infection can cause larval migran , which can result in vision loss and eye inflammation , or fever , fatigue , coughing , and abdominal pain , depend on whether the organism infect the eye or the viscera .
another common nematode infection be hookworm , which be cause by necator americanus ( the new world or north american hookworm ) and ancylostoma duodenale ( the old world hookworm ) .
symptom of hookworm infection can include abdominal pain , diarrhea , loss of appetite , weight loss , fatigue , and anemia .

infection can cause fever , muscle pain , and digestive system problem  severe infection can lead to lack of coordination , breathing and heart problem , and even death .
finally , heartworm in dog and other animal be cause by the nematode dirofilaria immitis , which be transmit by mosquito .
symptom include fatigue and cough  when leave untreated , death may result .

platyhelminths ( flatworms ) phylum platyhelminthes ( the platyhelminth ) be flatworm .
this group include the fluke , tapeworm , and the turbellarian , which include planarian .
the fluke and tapeworm be medically important parasite ( figure five  .  two  zero ) .
the fluke ( trematode ) be nonsegmente flatworm that have an oral sucker ( figure five  .  two  one ) ( and sometimes a second ventral sucker ) and attach to the inner wall of intestine , lung , large blood vessel , or the liver .
trematode have complex life cycle , often with multiple host .
several important example be the liver fluke ( clonorchis and opisthorchis ) , the intestinal fluke ( fasciolopsis buski ) , and the oriental lung fluke ( paragonimus westermani ) .
schistosomiasis be a serious parasitic disease , consider second in the scale of - pron - impact on human population only to malaria .
the parasite schistosoma mansoni , s . haematobium , and s . japonicum , which be find in freshwater snail , be responsible for schistosomiasis ( figure five  .  two  two ) .
immature form burrow through the skin into the blood .
- pron - migrate to the lung , then to the liver and , later , other organ .
symptom include anemia , malnutrition , fever , abdominal pain , fluid buildup , and sometimes death .

the other medically important group of platyhelminth be commonly know as tapeworm ( cestode ) and be segment flatworm that may have sucker or hook at the scolex ( head region )

tapeworm often have an intermediate host that consume the egg , which then hatch into a larval form call an oncosphere .
the oncosphere migrate to a particular tissue or organ in the intermediate host , where - pron - form cysticercus .
after be eat by the definitive host , the cysticercus develop into adult tapeworm in the host ' s digestive system ( figure five  .  two  three ) .
taenia saginata ( the beef tapeworm ) and t . solium ( the pork tapeworm ) enter human through ingestion of undercooked , contaminate meat .
the adult worm develop and reside in the intestine , but the larval stage may migrate and be find in other body location such as skeletal and smooth muscle .
the beef tapeworm be relatively benign , although - pron - can cause digestive problem and , occasionally , allergic reaction .

identify example of toxin - produce fungi  classify fungal organism accord to major group the fungi comprise a diverse group of organism that be heterotrophic and typically saprozoic .
in addition to the well - know macroscopic fungi ( such as mushroom and mold ) , many unicellular yeast and spore of macroscopic fungi be microscopic .
for this reason , fungus be include within the field of microbiology .
fungi be important to human in a variety of way .
both microscopic and macroscopic fungi have medical relevance , with some pathogenic specie that can cause mycose ( illness cause by fungi ) .
some pathogenic fungi be opportunistic , mean that - pron - mainly cause infection when the host 's immune defense be compromise and do not normally cause illness in healthy individual .
fungus be important in other way .
- pron - act as decomposer in the environment , and - pron - be critical for the production of certain food such as cheese .
fungi be also major source of antibiotic , such as penicillin from the fungus penicillium .
characteristic of fungi fungi have well - define characteristic that set - pron - apart from other organism .
most multicellular fungal body , commonly call mold , be make up of filament call hypha .
hypha can form a tangled network call a mycelium and form the thallus ( body ) of fleshy fungi .
hypha that have wall between the cell be call septate hypha  hyphae that lack wall and cell membrane between the cell be call nonseptate or coenocytic hypha ) .

some fungi be dimorphic , have more than one appearance during - pron - life cycle .
these dimorphic fungi may be able to appear as yeast or mold , which can be important for infectivity .
- pron - be capable of change - pron - appearance in response to environmental change such as nutrient availability or fluctuation in temperature , grow as a mold , for example , at two  five ° c ( seven  seven ° f ) , and as yeast cell at three  seven ° c ( nine  eight  .  six ° f ) .
this ability help dimorphic fungi to survive in diverse environment .

there be notable unique feature in fungal cell wall and membrane .
fungal cell wall contain chitin , as oppose to the cellulose find in the cell wall of plant and many protist .
additionally , whereas animal have cholesterol in - pron - cell membrane , fungal cell membrane have different sterol call ergosterol .
ergosterol be often exploit as target for antifungal drug .
fungal life cycle be unique and complex .
fungus reproduce sexually either through cross - or self - fertilization .
haploid fungi form hypha that have gamete at the tip .
two different mating type ( represent as “ + type " and “ – type " ) be involve .
the cytoplasm of the + and – type gamete fuse ( in an event call plasmogamy ) , produce a cell with two distinct nucleus ( a dikaryotic cell ) .
later , the nucleus fuse ( in an event call karyogamy ) to create a diploid zygote .
the zygote undergoes meiosis to form spore that germinate to start the haploid stage , which eventually create more haploid mycelium ( figure five  .  two  seven ) .
depend on the taxonomic group , these sexually produce spore be know as zygospore ( in zygomycota ) , ascospore ( in ascomycota ) , or basidiospore ( in basidiomycota )
( figure five  .  two  eight ) .
fungi may also exhibit asexual reproduction by mitosis , mitosis with budding , fragmentation of hypha , and formation of asexual spore by mitosis .
these spore be specialized cell that , depend on the organism , may have unique characteristic for survival , reproduction , and dispersal .
fungi exhibit several type of asexual spore and these can be important in classification .

in the sexual life cycle , + and – mating type conjugate to form a zygosporangium .
