fungal diversity
the fungi be very diverse , comprise seven major group .
not all of the seven group contain pathogen .
some of these group be generally associate with plant and include plant pathogen .
for example , urediniomycetes and ustilagomycetes include the plant rust and smut , respectively .
these form reddish or dark mass , respectively , on plant as rust ( red ) or smut ( dark ) .
some specie have substantial economic impact because of - pron - ability to reduce crop yield .
glomeromycota include the mycorrhizal fungi , important symbiont with plant root that can promote plant growth by act like an extend root system .
the glomeromycota be obligate symbiont , mean that - pron - can only survive when associate with plant root  the fungi receive carbohydrate from the plant and the plant benefit from the increase ability to take up nutrient and mineral from the soil .
the chytridiomycetes ( chytrid ) be small fungi , but be extremely ecologically important .
chytrid be generally aquatic and have flagellate , motile gamete  specific type be implicate in amphibian decline around the world .
because of - pron - medical importance , - pron - will focus on zygomycota , ascomycota , basidiomycota , and microsporidia .
figure five  .  three  three summarize the characteristic of these medically important group of fungi .
the zygomycota ( zygomycete ) be mainly saprophyte with coenocytic hypha and haploid nucleus .
- pron - use sporangiospore for asexual reproduction .
the group name come from the zygospore that - pron - use for sexual reproduction ( figure five  .  two  seven ) , which have hard wall form from the fusion of reproductive cell from two individual .
zygomycete be important for food science and as crop pathogen .
one example be rhizopus stolonifer ( figure five  .  two  eight ) , an important bread mold that also cause rice seedling blight .
mucor be a genus of fungi that can potentially cause necrotize infection in human , although most specie be intolerant of temperature find in mammalian body ( figure five  .  two  eight ) .
the ascomycota include fungi that be use as food ( edible mushroom , morel , and truffle ) , other that be common cause of food spoilage ( bread mold and plant pathogen ) , and still other that be human pathogen .
ascomycota may have septate hypha and cup - shape fruiting body call ascocarps .
some genera of ascomycota use sexually produce ascospore as well as asexual spore call conidium , but sexual phase have not be discover or describe for other .
some produce an ascus contain ascospore within an ascocarp ( figure five  .  two  nine ) .
example of the ascomycota include several bread mold and minor pathogen , as well as specie capable of cause chapter five

specie in the genus aspergillus be important cause of allergy and infection , and be useful in research and in the production of certain ferment alcoholic beverage such as japanese sake .
the fungus aspergillus flavus , a contaminant of nuts and stored grain , produce an aflatoxin that be both a toxin and the most potent know natural carcinogen .
neurospora crassa be of particular use in genetic research because the spore produce by meiosis be keep inside the ascus in a row that reflect the cell division that produce - pron - , give a direct view of segregation and assortment of gene ( figure five  .  three  zero ) .
penicillium produce the antibiotic penicillin ( figure five  .  two  nine ) .
many specie of ascomycete be medically important .
a large number of specie in the genera trichophyton , microsporum , and epidermophyton be dermatophyte , pathogenic fungi capable of cause skin infection such as athlete 's foot , jock itch , and ringworm .
blastomyce dermatitidis be a dimorphic fungus that can cause blastomycosis , a respiratory infection that , if leave untreated , can become disseminated to other body site , sometimes lead to death .

eukaryotic pathogen in eukaryotic hosts
when - pron - think about antimicrobial medication , antibiotic such as penicillin often come to mind .
penicillin and related antibiotic interfere with the synthesis of peptidoglycan cell wall , which effectively target bacterial cell .
these antibiotic be useful because human ( like all eukaryote ) do not have peptidoglycan cell wall .
develop medication that be effective against eukaryotic cell but not harmful to human cell be more difficult .
despite huge morphological difference , the cell of human , fungus , and protist be similar in term of - pron - ribosome , cytoskeleton , and cell membrane .
as a result , - pron - be more challenging to develop medication that target protozoan and fungi in the same way that antibiotic target prokaryote .
fungicide have relatively limited mode of action .
because fungi have ergosterol ( instead of cholesterol ) in - pron - cell membrane , the different enzyme involve in sterol production can be a target of some medication .
the azole and morpholine fungicide interfere with the synthesis of membrane sterol .
these be use widely in agriculture ( fenpropimorph ) and clinically ( e . g . , miconazole ) .
some antifungal medication target the chitin cell wall of fungi .
despite the success of these compound in target fungi , antifungal medication for systemic infection still tend to have more toxic side effect than antibiotic for bacteria .

five  .  four algae learning objectives
 explain why algae be include within the discipline of microbiology
 describe the unique characteristic of algae

compare the major group of algae in this chapter , and give example of each  classify algal organism accord to major group
the algae be autotrophic protist that can be unicellular or multicellular .
these organism be find in the supergroup chromalveolata ( dinoflagellate , diatom , golden algae , and brown algae ) and archaeplastida ( red algae and green algae ) .
- pron - be important ecologically and environmentally because - pron - be responsible for the production of approximately seven  zero % of the oxygen and organic matter in aquatic environment .
some type of algae , even those that be microscopic , be regularly eat by human and other animal .
additionally , algae be the source for agar , agarose , and carrageenan , solidify agent use in laboratory and in food production .
although algae be typically not pathogenic , some produce toxin .
harmful algal bloom , which occur when algae grow quickly and produce dense population , can produce high concentration of toxin that impair liver and nervous - system function in aquatic animal and human .
like protozoan , algae often have complex cell structure .
for instance , algal cell can have one or more chloroplast that contain structure call pyrenoid to synthesize and store starch .
the chloroplast - pron - differ in - pron - number of membrane , indicative of secondary or rare tertiary endosymbiotic event .
primary chloroplast have two membrane - one from the original cyanobacteria that the ancestral eukaryotic cell engulf , and one from the plasma membrane of the engulf cell .
chloroplast in some lineage appear to have result from secondary endosymbiosis , in which another cell engulf a green or red algal cell that already have a primary chloroplast within - pron - .
the engulf cell destroy everything except the chloroplast and possibly the cell membrane of - pron - original cell , leave three or four membrane around the chloroplast .
different algal group have different pigment , which be chapter five

the eukaryotes of microbiology two  three  one reflect in common name such as red algae , brown algae , and green algae .
some algae , the seaweed , be macroscopic and may be confuse with plant .
seaweed can be red , brown , or green , depend on - pron - photosynthetic pigment .
green algae , in particular , share some important similarity with land plant  however , there be also important distinction .
for example , seaweed do not have true tissue or organ like plant do .
additionally , seaweed do not have a waxy cuticle to prevent desiccation .
algae can also be confuse with cyanobacteria , photosynthetic bacteria that bear a resemblance to algae  however , cyanobacteria be prokaryote ( see nonproteobacteria gram - negative bacteria and phototrophic bacteria ) .
algae have a variety of life cycle .
reproduction may be asexual by mitosis or sexual use gamete .
algal diversity
although the algae and protozoa be formerly separate taxonomically , - pron - be now mix into supergroup .
the algae be classify within the chromalveolata and the archaeplastida .
although the euglenozoa ( within the supergroup excavata ) include photosynthetic organism , these be not consider algae because - pron - feed and be motile .
the dinoflagellate and stramenopile fall within the chromalveolata .
the dinoflagellate be mostly marine organism and be an important component of plankton .
- pron - have a variety of nutritional type and may be phototrophic , heterotrophic , or mixotrophic .
those that be photosynthetic use chlorophyll a , chlorophyll c two , and other photosynthetic pigment ( figure five  .  three  five ) .
- pron - generally have two flagellum , cause - pron - to whirl ( in fact , the name dinoflagellate come from the greek word for " whirl "  dini ) .
some have cellulose plate form a hard outer covering , or theca , as armor .
additionally , some dinoflagellate produce neurotoxin that can cause paralysis in human or fish .
exposure can occur through contact with water contain the dinoflagellate toxin or by feed on organism that have eat dinoflagellate .
when a population of dinoflagellate become particularly dense , a red tide ( a type of harmful algal bloom ) can occur .
red tide cause harm to marine life and to human who consume contaminate marine life .
major toxin producer include gonyaulax and alexandrium , both of which cause paralytic shellfish poisoning .
another species , pfiesteria piscicida , be know as a fish killer because , at certain part of - pron - life cycle , - pron - can produce toxin harmful to fish and - pron - appear to be responsible for a suite of symptom , include memory loss and confusion , in human expose to water contain the specie .

lichens learning objectives

no one have to worry about get sick from a lichen infection , but lichen be interesting from a microbiological perspective and - pron - be an important component of most terrestrial ecosystem .
lichen provide opportunity for study of close relationship between unrelated microorganism .
lichens contribute to soil production by break down rock , and - pron - be early colonizer in soilless environment such as lava flow .
the cyanobacteria in some lichen can fix nitrogen and act as a nitrogen source in some environment .
lichen be also important soil stabilizer in some desert environment and - pron - be an important winter food source for caribou and reindeer .
finally , lichen produce compound that have antibacterial effect , and further research may discover compound that be medically useful to human .
characteristics a lichen be a combination of two organism , a green alga or cyanobacterium and an ascomycete fungus , live in a symbiotic relationship .
whereas algae normally grow only in aquatic or extremely moist environment , lichen can potentially be find on almost any surface ( especially rock ) or as epiphyte ( mean that - pron - grow on other plant ) .
in some way , the symbiotic relationship between lichen and algae seem like a mutualism ( a relationship in which both organism benefit ) .
the fungus can obtain photosynthate from the algae or cyanobacterium and the algae or chapter five

the eukaryotes of microbiology two  three  five cyanobacterium can grow in a dry environment than - pron - could otherwise tolerate .
however , most scientist consider this symbiotic relationship to be a control parasitism ( a relationship in which one organism benefit and the other be harm ) because the photosynthetic organism grow less well than - pron - would without the fungus .
- pron - be important to note that such symbiotic interaction fall along a continuum between conflict and cooperation .
lichens be slow growing and can live for century .
- pron - have be use in food and to extract chemical as dye or antimicrobial substance .
some be very sensitive to pollution and have be use as environmental indicator .
lichen have a body call a thallus , an outer , tightly pack fungal layer call a cortex , and an inner , loosely pack fungal layer call a medulla ( figure five  .  three  eight ) .
lichen use hyphal bundle call rhizine to attach to the substrate .

the rhizine anchor the thallus to the substrate .
lichen diversity lichens be classify as fungi and the fungal partner belong to the ascomycota and basidiomycota .
lichens can also be group into type base on - pron - morphology .
there be three major type of lichen , although other type exist as well .
lichen that be tightly attach to the substrate , give - pron - a crusty appearance , be call crustose lichen .
those that have leaf - like lobe be foliose lichen  - pron - may only be attach at one point in the growth form , and - pron - also have a second cortex below the medulla .
finally , fruticose lichen have round structure and an overall branched appearance .

[ two ]
at that time , dmitri ivanovski , a russian botanist , discover the source of tmd by use a porcelain filter device first invent by charles chamberland and louis pasteur in paris in one  eight  eight  four .
porcelain chamberland filter have a pore size of zero  .  one μm , which be small enough to remove all bacteria ≥ zero  .  two μm from any liquid pass through the device .
an extract obtain from tmd - infect tobacco plant be make to determine the cause of the disease .
initially , the source of the disease be think to be bacterial .
- pron - be surprising to everyone when ivanovski , use a chamberland filter , find that the cause of tmd be not remove after pass the extract through the porcelain filter .
so if a bacterium be not the cause of tmd , what could be cause the disease ?
ivanovski conclude the cause of tmd must be an extremely small bacterium or bacterial spore .
other scientist , include martinus beijerinck , continue investigate the cause of tmd .
- pron - be beijerinck , in one  eight  nine  nine , who eventually conclude the causative agent be not a bacterium but , instead , possibly a chemical , like a biological poison - pron - would describe today as a toxin .
as a result , the word virus , latin for poison , be use to describe the cause of tmd a few year after ivanovski 's initial discovery .
even though - pron - be not able to see the virus that cause tmd , and do not realize the cause be not a bacterium , ivanovski be credit as the original discoverer of virus and a founder of the field of virology .
today , - pron - can see virus use electron microscope ( figure six  .  two ) and - pron - know much more about - pron - .
virus be distinct biological entity  however , - pron - evolutionary origin be still a matter of speculation .
in term of taxonomy , - pron - be not include in the tree of life because - pron - be acellular ( not consist of cell ) .
in order to survive and reproduce , virus must infect a cellular host , make - pron - obligate intracellular parasite .

why be the first virus investigate mistaken for a toxin ?
hosts and viral transmission viruses can infect every type of host cell , include those of plant , animal , fungus , protist , bacteria , and archaea .
most virus will only be able to infect the cell of one or a few specie of organism .
this be call the host range .
however , have a wide host range be not common and virus will typically only infect specific host and only specific cell type within those host .
the virus that infect bacteria be call bacteriophage , or simply phage .
the word phage come from the greek word for devour .
other virus be just identify by - pron - host group , such as animal or plant virus .
once a cell be infect , the effect of the virus can vary depend on the type of virus .
chapter six

acellular pathogens two  four  five viruses may cause abnormal growth of the cell or cell death , alter the cell 's genome , or cause little noticeable effect in the cell .
virus can be transmit through direct contact , indirect contact with fomite , or through a vector  an animal that transmit a pathogen from one host to another .
arthropod such as mosquito , tick , and fly , be typical vector for viral disease , and - pron - may act as mechanical vector or biological vector .
mechanical transmission occur when the arthropod carry a viral pathogen on the outside of - pron - body and transmit - pron - to a new host by physical contact .
biological transmission occur when the arthropod carry the viral pathogen inside - pron - body and transmit - pron - to the new host through bite .
in human , a wide variety of virus be capable of cause various infection and disease .
some of the deadly emerge pathogen in human be virus , yet - pron - have few treatment or drug to deal with viral infection , make - pron - difficult to eradicate .
virus that can be transmit from an animal host to a human host can cause zoonosis .
for example , the avian influenza virus originate in bird , but can cause disease in human .
reverse zoonosis be cause by infection of an animal by a virus that originate in a human .
fight bacteria with viruses
the emergence of superbug , or multidrug resistant bacteria , have become a major challenge for pharmaceutical company and a serious health - care problem .
accord to a two  zero  one  three report by the us centers for disease control and prevention ( cdc ) , more than two million people be infect with drug - resistant bacteria in the us annually , result in at least two  three  ,  zero  zero  zero deaths . [ three ]
the continue use and overuse of antibiotic will likely lead to the evolution of even more drug - resistant strain .
one potential solution be the use of phage therapy , a procedure that use bacteria - kill virus ( bacteriophage ) to treat bacterial infection .
phage therapy be not a new idea .
the discovery of bacteriophage date back to the early two  zero th century , and phage therapy be first use in europe in one  nine  one  five by the english bacteriologist frederick twort . [ four ]
however , the subsequent discovery of penicillin and other antibiotic lead to the near abandonment of this form of therapy , except in the former soviet union and a few country in eastern europe .
interest in phage therapy outside of the country of the former soviet union be only recently re - emerge because of the rise in antibiotic - resistant bacteria . [ five ] phage therapy have some advantage over antibiotic in that phage kill only one specific bacterium , whereas antibiotic kill not only the pathogen but also beneficial bacteria of the normal microbiota .
development of new antibiotic be also expensive for drug company and for patient , especially for those who live in country with high poverty rate .
phage have also be use to prevent food spoilage .
in two  zero  zero  six , the us food and drug administration approve the use of a solution contain six bacteriophage that can be spray on lunch meat such as bologna , ham , and turkey to kill listeria monocytogene , a bacterium responsible for listeriosis , a form of food poisoning .
some consumer have concern about the use of phage on food , however , especially give the rise popularity of organic product .
food that have be treat with phage must declare " bacteriophage preparation " in the list of ingredient or include a label declare that the meat have be “ treat with antimicrobial solution to reduce microorganisms . ”[ six ] micro connections three .

the size of a virus be small relative to the size of most bacterial and eukaryotic cell and - pron - organelle .
in one  nine  three  five , after the development of the electron microscope , wendell stanley be the first scientist to crystallize the structure of the tobacco mosaic virus and discover that - pron - be compose of rna and protein .
in one  nine  four  three , - pron - isolate influenza b virus , which contribute to the development of an influenza ( flu ) vaccine .
stanley 's discovery unlock the mystery of the nature of virus that have be puzzle scientist for over four  zero year and - pron - contribution to the field of virology lead to - pron - be award the nobel prize in one  nine  four  six .
as a result of continue research into the nature of virus , - pron - now know - pron - consist of a nucleic acid ( either rna or dna , but never both ) surround by a protein coat call a capsid ( see figure six  .  five ) .
the interior of the capsid be not fill with cytosol , as in a cell , but instead - pron - contain the bare necessity in term of genome and enzyme need to direct the synthesis of new virion .
each capsid be compose of protein subunit call capsomere make of one or more different type of capsomere protein that interlock to form the closely packed capsid .
there be two category of virus base on general composition .
virus form from only a nucleic acid and capsid be call naked virus or nonenvelope virus .
virus form with a nucleic - acid pack capsid surround by a lipid layer be call envelop virus ( see figure six  .  five ) .
the viral envelope be a small portion of phospholipid membrane obtain as the virion bud from a host cell .
the viral envelope may either be intracellular or cytoplasmic in origin .
extend outward and away from the capsid on some naked virus and envelop virus be protein structure call spike .
at the tip of these spike be structure that allow the virus to attach and enter a cell , like the influenza virus hemagglutinin spike ( h ) or enzyme like the neuraminidase ( n ) influenza virus spike that allow the virus to detach from the cell surface during release of new virion .
influenza virus be often identify by - pron - h and n spike .
for example , h one n one influenza virus be responsible for the pandemic in one  nine  one  eight and two  zero  zero  nine  , [ eight ]
h two n two for the pandemic in one  nine  five  seven , and h three n two for the pandemic in one  nine  six  eight .

virus vary in the shape of - pron - capsid , which can be either helical , polyhedral , or complex .
a helical capsid form the shape of tobacco mosaic virus ( tmv ) , a naked helical virus , and ebola virus , an envelop helical virus .
the capsid be cylindrical or rod shape , with the genome fitting just inside the length of the capsid .
polyhedral capsid form the shape of poliovirus and rhinovirus , and consist of a nucleic acid surround by a polyhedral ( manysided ) capsid in the form of an icosahedron .
an icosahedral capsid be a three - dimensional , two  zero  - sided structure with one  two vertex .
these capsid somewhat resemble a soccer ball .
both helical and polyhedral virus can have envelope .
viral shape see in certain type of bacteriophage , such as t four phage , and poxvirus , like vaccinia virus , may have feature of both polyhedral and helical virus
so - pron - be describe as a complex viral shape ( see figure six  .  six ) .
in the bacteriophage complex form , the genome be locate within the polyhedral head and the sheath connect the head to the tail fiber and tail pin that help the virus attach to receptor on the host cell 's surface .
poxvirus that have complex shape be often brick shape , with intricate surface characteristic not see in the other category of capsid .

classification and taxonomy of viruses
although virus be not classify in the three domain of life , - pron - number be great enough to require classification .
since one  nine  seven  one , the international union of microbiological societies virology division have give the task of develop , refining , and maintain a universal virus taxonomy to the international committee on taxonomy of viruses ( ictv ) .
since virus can mutate so quickly , - pron - can be difficult to classify - pron - into a genus and a species epithet use the binomial nomenclature system .
thus , the ictv 's viral nomenclature system classify virus into family and genera base on viral genetic , chemistry , morphology , and mechanism of multiplication .
to date , the ictv have classify know virus in seven order , nine  six family , and three  five  zero genera .
viral family name end in - viridae
( e . g , parvoviridae ) and genus name end in −virus ( e . g . , parvovirus ) .
the name of viral order , family , and genera be all italicized .
when refer to a viral species , - pron - often use a genus and specie epithet such as pandoravirus dulcis or pandoravirus salinus .
the baltimore classification system be an alternative to ictv nomenclature .
the baltimore system classify virus two  five  zero chapter six

this system thus create seven group of virus that have common genetic and biology .
explore the late virus taxonomy ( https / / www . openstax . org / l /  two  two virustaxon ) at the ictv website .
aside from formal system of nomenclature , virus be often informally group into category base on chemistry , morphology , or other characteristic - pron - share in common .
category may include naked or envelop structure , single - stranded ( ss ) or double - stranded ( ds ) dna or ss or d rna genome , segment or nonsegmente genome , and positive - strand ( + ) or negative - strand ( − ) rna .
for example , herpe virus can be classify as a dsdna envelop virus  human immunodeficiency virus ( hiv ) be a + ssrna envelop virus , and tobacco mosaic virus be a + ssrna virus .
other characteristic such as host specificity , tissue specificity , capsid shape , and special gene or enzyme may also be use to describe group of similar virus .

classification of viral diseases
while the ictv have be task with the biological classification of virus , - pron - have also play an important role in the classification of disease cause by virus .
to facilitate the tracking of virus - relate human disease , the ictv have create classification that link to the international classification of diseases ( icd ) , the standard taxonomy of disease that be maintain and update by the world health organization ( who ) .
the icd assign an alphanumeric code of up to six character to every type of viral infection , as well as all other type of disease , medical condition , and cause of death .
this icd code be use in conjunction with two other code system ( the current procedural terminology , and the healthcare common procedure coding system ) to categorize patient condition for treatment and insurance reimbursement .
for example , when a patient seek treatment for a viral infection , icd code be routinely use by clinician to order laboratory test and prescribe treatment specific to the virus suspect of cause the illness .
this icd code be then use by medical laboratory to identify test that must be perform to confirm the diagnosis .
the icd code be use by the health - care management system to verify that all treatment and laboratory work perform be appropriate for the give virus .
medical coder use icd code to assign the proper code for procedure perform , and medical biller , in turn , use this information to process claim for reimbursement by insurance company .
vitalrecord keeper use icd code to record cause of death on death certificate , and epidemiologist use icd code to calculate morbidity and mortality statistic .

describe the replication process of plant virus
all virus depend on cell for reproduction and metabolic process .
by - pron - , virus do not encode for all of the enzyme necessary for viral replication .
but within a host cell , a virus can commandeer cellular machinery to produce more viral particle .
bacteriophage replicate only in the cytoplasm , since prokaryotic cell do not have a nucleus or organelle .
in eukaryotic cell , most dna virus can replicate inside the nucleus , with an exception observe in the large dna virus , such as the poxvirus , that can replicate in the cytoplasm .
rna virus that infect animal cell often replicate in the cytoplasm .
the life cycle of viruses with prokaryote hosts
the life cycle of bacteriophage have be a good model for understand how virus affect the cell - pron - infect , since similar process have be observe for eukaryotic virus , which can cause immediate death of the cell or establish a latent or chronic infection .
virulent phage typically lead to the death of the cell through cell lysis .
temperate phage , on the other hand , can become part of a host chromosome and be replicate with the cell genome until such time as - pron - be induce to make newly assemble virus , or progeny virus .
clinical focus chapter six  acellular pathogens two  five  three
the lytic cycle
during the lytic cycle of virulent phage , the bacteriophage take over the cell , reproduce new phage , and destroy the cell .
t - even phage be a good example of a well - characterize class of virulent phage .
there be five stage in the bacteriophage lytic cycle ( see figure six  .  seven ) .
attachment be the first stage in the infection process in which the phage interact with specific bacterial surface receptor ( e . g . , lipopolysaccharide and ompc protein on host surface ) .
most phage have a narrow host range and may infect one specie of bacteria or one strain within a species .
this unique recognition can be exploit for targeted treatment of bacterial infection by phage therapy or for phage typing to identify unique bacterial subspecie or strain .
the second stage of infection be entry or penetration .
this occur through contraction of the tail sheath , which act like a hypodermic needle to inject the viral genome through the cell wall and membrane .
the phage head and remain component remain outside the bacteria .
figure six  .  seven
a virulent phage show only the lytic cycle picture here .
in the lytic cycle , the phage replicate and lyse the host cell .
the third stage of infection be biosynthesis of new viral component .
after enter the host cell , the virus synthesize virus - encode endonuclease to degrade the bacterial chromosome .
- pron - then hijack the host cell to replicate , transcribe , and translate the necessary viral component ( capsomere , sheath , base plate , tail fiber , and viral enzyme ) for the assembly of new virus .
polymerase gene be usually express early in the cycle , while capsid and tail protein be express later .
during the maturation phase , new virion be create .
to liberate free phage , the bacterial cell wall be disrupt by phage protein such as holin or lysozyme .
the final stage be release .
mature virus burst out of the host cell in a process call lysis and the progeny virus be liberate into the environment to infect new cell .
the lysogenic cycle
in a lysogenic cycle , the phage genome also enter the cell through attachment and penetration .
a prime example of a phage with this type of life cycle be the lambda phage .
during the lysogenic cycle , instead of kill the host , the phage genome integrate into the bacterial chromosome and become part of the host .
the integrated phage genome be call a prophage .
a bacterial host with a prophage be call a lysogen .
the process in which a bacterium be infect by a temperate phage be call lysogeny .
- pron - be typical of temperate phage to be latent or inactive within the cell .
as the bacterium replicate - pron - chromosome , - pron - also replicate the phage 's dna and pass - pron - on to new daughter cell during reproduction .
the presence of the phage may alter the phenotype of the bacterium , since - pron - can bring in extra gene ( e . g . , toxin gene that can increase bacterial virulence ) .
this change in the host phenotype be call lysogenic conversion or phage conversion .
some bacteria , such as vibrio cholerae and clostridium botulinum , be less virulent in the absence of the prophage .
the phage infect these bacteria carry the toxin gene in - pron - genome and enhance the virulence of the host when the toxin gene be express .
in the case of v . cholera , phage encode toxin can cause severe diarrhea  in c . botulinum , the toxin can cause paralysis .
during lysogeny , the prophage will persist in the host chromosome until induction , which result in the excision of the viral genome from the host chromosome .

transduction transduction occur when a bacteriophage transfer bacterial dna from one bacterium to another during sequential infection .
there be two type of transduction  generalize and specialized transduction .
during the lytic cycle of viral replication , the virus hijack the host cell , degrade the host chromosome , and make more viral genome .
as - pron - assemble and package dna into the phage head , packaging occasionally make a mistake .
instead of package viral dna , - pron - take a random piece of host dna and insert - pron - into the capsid .
once release , this virion will then link to learning chapter six
 acellular pathogens two  five  five inject the former host 's dna into a newly infect host .
the asexual transfer of genetic information can allow for dna recombination to occur , thus provide the new host with new gene ( e . g . , an antibiotic - resistance gene , or a sugar - metabolize gene ) .
generalize transduction occur when a random piece of bacterial chromosomal dna be transfer by the phage during the lytic cycle .
specialized transduction occur at the end of the lysogenic cycle , when the prophage be excise and the bacteriophage enter the lytic cycle .
since the phage be integrate into the host genome , the prophage can replicate as part of the host .
however , some condition ( e . g . , ultraviolet light exposure or chemical exposure ) stimulate the prophage to undergo induction , cause the phage to excise from the genome , enter the lytic cycle , and produce new phage to leave host cell .
during the process of excision from the host chromosome , a phage may occasionally remove some bacterial dna near the site of viral integration .
the phage and host dna from one end or both end of the integration site be package within the capsid and be transfer to the new , infected host .
since the dna transfer by the phage be not randomly package but be instead a specific piece of dna near the site of integration , this mechanism of gene transfer be refer to as specialize transduction ( see figure six  .  nine ) .
the dna can then recombine with host chromosome , give the latter new characteristic .
transduction seem to play an important role in the evolutionary process of bacteria , give - pron - a mechanism for asexual exchange of genetic information .
figure six  .  nine
this flowchart illustrate the mechanism of specialized transduction .
an integrated phage excise , bring with - pron - a piece of the dna adjacent to - pron - insertion point .
on reinfection of a new bacterium , the phage dna integrate along with the genetic material acquire from the previous host .

attachment , penetration , biosynthesis , maturation , and release ( see figure six  .  one  zero ) .
however , the mechanism of penetration , nucleic - acid biosynthesis , and release differ between bacterial and animal virus .
after bind to host receptor , animal virus enter through endocytosis ( engulfment by the host cell ) or through membrane fusion ( viral envelope with the host cell membrane ) .
many virus be host specific , mean - pron - only infect a certain type of host  and most virus only infect certain type of cell within tissue .
this specificity be call a tissue tropism .
example of this be demonstrate by the poliovirus , which exhibit tropism for the tissue of the brain and spinal cord , or the influenza virus , which have a primary tropism for the respiratory tract .

in influenza virus infection , viral glycoprotein attach the virus to a host epithelial cell .
as a result , the virus be engulf .
viral rna and viral protein be make and assemble into new virion that be release by bud .
animal virus do not always express - pron - gene use the normal flow of genetic information - from dna to rna to protein .
some virus have a dsdna genome like cellular organism and can follow the normal flow .
however , other may have ssdna , dsrna , or ssrna genome .
the nature of the genome determine how the genome be replicate and express as viral protein .
if a genome be ssdna , host enzyme will be use to synthesize a second strand that be complementary to the genome strand , thus produce dsdna .
the dsdna can now be replicate , transcribe , and translate similar to host dna .
if the viral genome be rna , a different mechanism must be use .
there be three type of rna genome 
dsrna , positive ( + ) single - strand ( + ssrna ) or negative ( − ) single - strand rna ( −ssrna ) .
if a virus have a + ssrna genome , - pron - can be translate directly to make viral protein .
viral genomic + ssrna act like cellular mrna .
however , if a virus contain a −ssrna genome , the host ribosome can not translate - pron - until the −ssrna be replicate into + ssrna by viral rna - dependent rna polymerase ( rdrp )
( see figure six  .  one  one ) .
the rdrp be bring in by the virus and can be use to make + ssrna from the original −ssrna genome .
the rdrp be also an important enzyme for the replication of dsrna virus , because - pron - use the negative strand of the double - strand genome as a template to create + ssrna .
the newly synthesize + ssrna copy can then be translate by cellular ribosome .

the ssdna be then make into dsdna , which can integrate into the host chromosome and become a permanent part of the host .
the integrate viral genome be call a provirus .
the virus now can remain in the host for a long time to establish a chronic infection .
the provirus stage be similar to the prophage stage in a bacterial infection during the lysogenic cycle .
however , unlike prophage , the provirus do not undergo excision after splice into the genome .

persistent infections persistent infection occur when a virus be not completely clear from the system of the host but stay in certain tissue or organ of the infect person .
the virus may remain silent or undergo productive infection without seriously harm or kill the host .
mechanism of persistent infection may involve the regulation of the viral or host gene expression or the alteration of the host immune response .
the two primary category of persistent infection be latent infection and chronic infection .
example of virus that cause latent infection include herpe simplex virus ( oral and genital herpe ) , varicella - zoster virus ( chickenpox and shingle ) , and epstein - barr virus
( mononucleosis ) .
hepatitis c virus and hiv be two example of virus that cause long - term chronic infection .
latent infection
not all animal virus undergo replication by the lytic cycle .
there be virus that be capable of remain hide or dormant inside the cell in a process call latency .
these type of virus be know as latent virus and may cause latent infection .
virus capable of latency may initially cause an acute infection before become dormant .
for example , the varicella - zoster virus infect many cell throughout the body and cause chickenpox , characterize by a rash of blister cover the skin .
about one  zero to one  two day postinfection , the disease resolve and the virus go dormant , live within nerve - cell ganglia for year .
during this time , the virus do not kill the nerve cell or continue replicate .
- pron - be not clear why the virus stop replicate within the nerve cell and express few viral protein but , in some case , typically after many year of dormancy , the virus be reactivate and cause a new disease call shingle ( figure six  .  one  three ) .
whereas chickenpox affect many area throughout the body , shingle be a nerve cell - specific disease emerge from the ganglia in which the virus be dormant .

other become provirus by integrate into the host genome .
during dormancy , virus do not cause any symptom of disease and may be difficult to detect .
a patient may be unaware that - pron - or - pron - be carry the virus unless a viral diagnostic test have be perform .

a chronic infection be a disease with symptom that be recurrent or persistent over a long time .
some viral infection can be chronic if the body be unable to eliminate the virus .
hiv be an example of a virus that produce a chronic infection , often after a long period of latency .
once a person become infect with hiv , the virus can be detect in tissue continuously thereafter , but untreated patient often experience no symptom for year .
however , the virus maintain chronic persistence through several mechanism that interfere with immune function , include prevent expression of viral antigen on the surface of infected cell , alter immune cell - pron - , restrict expression of viral gene , and rapidly change viral antigen through mutation .
eventually , the damage to the immune system result in progression of the disease lead to acquire immunodeficiency syndrome ( aids ) .
the various mechanism that hiv use to avoid be clear by the immune system be also use by other chronically infect virus , include the hepatitis c virus .

life cycle of viruses with plant hosts plant virus be more similar to animal virus than - pron - be to bacteriophage .
plant virus may be envelop or non - enveloped .
like many animal virus , plant virus can have either a dna or rna genome and be single stranded or double strand .
however , most plant virus do not have a dna genome  the majority have a + ssrna genome , which act like messenger rna ( mrna ) .
only a minority of plant virus have other type of genome .
plant virus may have a narrow or broad host range .
for example , the citrus tristeza virus infect only a few plant of the citrus genus , whereas the cucumber mosaic virus infect thousand of plant of various plant family .
most plant virus be transmit by contact between plant , or by fungus , nematode , insect , or other arthropod that act as mechanical vector .
however , some virus can only be transfer by a specific type of insect vector  for example , a particular virus may be transmit by aphid but not whitefly .
in some case , virus may also enter healthy plant through wound , as may occur due to pruning or weather damage .
virus that infect plant be consider biotrophic parasite , which mean that - pron - can establish an infection without kill the host , similar to what be observe in the lysogenic life cycle of bacteriophage .
viral infection can be asymptomatic ( latent ) or can lead to cell death ( lytic infection ) .
the life cycle begin with the penetration of the virus into the host cell .
next , the virus be uncoate within the cytoplasm of the cell when the capsid be remove .
depend on the type of nucleic acid , cellular component be use to replicate the viral genome and synthesize viral protein for assembly of new virion .
to establish a systemic infection , the virus must enter a part of the vascular system of the plant , such as the phloem .
the time require for systemic infection may vary from a few day to a few week depend on the virus , the plant specie , and the environmental condition .
the virus life cycle be complete when - pron - be transmit from an infected plant to a healthy plant .

viral growth curve
unlike the growth curve for a bacterial population , the growth curve for a virus population over - pron - life cycle do not follow a sigmoidal curve .
during the initial stage , an inoculum of virus cause infection .
in the eclipse phase , virus bind and penetrate the cell with no virion detect in the medium .
the chief difference that next appear in the viral chapter six  acellular pathogens two  six  one growth curve compare to a bacterial growth curve occur when virion be release from the lysed host cell at the same time .
such an occurrence be call a burst , and the number of virion per bacterium release be describe as the burst size .
in a one - step multiplication curve for bacteriophage , the host cell lyse , release many viral particle to the medium , which lead to a very steep rise in viral titer ( the number of virion per unit volume ) .
if no viable host cell remain , the viral particle begin to degrade during the decline of the culture ( see figure six  .  one  four ) .
figure six  .  one  four
the one - step multiplication curve for a bacteriophage population follow three step  one ) inoculation , during which the virion attach to host cell  two ) eclipse , during which entry of the viral genome occur  and three ) burst , when sufficient number of new virion be produce and emerge from the host cell .
the burst size be the maximum number of virion produce per bacterium .

ebola in the us
on september two  four , two  zero  one  four , thomas eric duncan arrive at the texas health presbyterian hospital in dallas complain of a fever , headache , vomiting , and diarrhea - symptom commonly observe in patient with the cold or the flu .
after examination , an emergency department doctor diagnose - pron - with sinusitis , prescribe some antibiotic , and send - pron - home .
two day later , duncan return to the hospital by ambulance .
- pron - condition have deteriorate and additional blood test confirm that - pron - have be infect with the ebola virus .
further investigation reveal that duncan have just return from liberia , one of the country in the midst of a severe ebola epidemic .
on september one  five , nine day before - pron - show up at the hospital in dallas , duncan have help transport an ebola - stricken neighbor to a hospital in liberia .
the hospital continue to treat duncan , but - pron - die several day after be admit .
the timeline of the duncan case be indicative of the life cycle of the ebola virus .
the incubation time for ebola range from two day to two  one day .
nine day pass between duncan 's exposure to the virus infection and the appearance of - pron - symptom .
this correspond , in part , to the eclipse period in the growth of the virus population .
during the eclipse phase , duncan would have be unable to transmit the disease to other .
however , once an infected individual begin exhibit symptom , the disease become very contagious .
ebola virus be transmit through direct contact with droplet of bodily fluid such as saliva , blood , and vomit .
duncan could conceivably have transmit the disease to other at any time after - pron - begin have symptom , presumably some time before - pron - arrival at the hospital in dallas .
once a hospital realize a patient like duncan be infect with ebola virus , the patient be immediately quarantine , and public health official initiate a back trace to identify everyone with whom a patient like duncan may have interact during the period in which - pron - be show symptom .
public health official be able to track down one  zero high - risk individual ( family member of duncan ) and five  zero low - risk individual to monitor - pron - for sign of infection .
none contract the disease .
however , one of the nurse charge with duncan 's care do become infected .
this , along with duncan 's initial misdiagnosis , make - pron - clear that us hospital need to provide additional training to medical personnel to prevent a possible ebola outbreak in the us .

six  .  three isolation , culture , and identification of viruses learning objectives

isolation of viruses
unlike bacteria , many of which can be grow on an artificial nutrient medium , virus require a live host cell for replication .
infected host cell ( eukaryotic or prokaryotic ) can be culture and grow , and then the growth medium can be harvest as a source of virus .
virion in the liquid medium can be separate from the host cell by either centrifugation or filtration .
filter can physically remove anything present in the solution that be large than the virion  the virus can then be collect in the filtrate ( see figure six  .  one  six ) .

cultivation of viruses viruses can be grow in vivo ( within a whole live organism , plant , or animal ) or in vitro ( outside a live organism in cell in an artificial environment , such as a test tube , cell culture flask , or agar plate ) .
bacteriophage can be grow in the presence of a dense layer of bacteria ( also call a bacterial lawn ) grow in a zero  .  seven % soft agar in a petri dish or flat ( horizontal ) flask ( see figure six  .  one  seven ) .

animal virus require cell within a host animal or tissue - culture cell derive from an animal .
animal virus cultivation be important for one ) identification and diagnosis of pathogenic virus in clinical specimen , two ) production of vaccine , and three ) basic research study .
in vivo host source can be a develop embryo in an embryonate bird 's egg ( e . g . , chicken , turkey ) or a whole animal .
for example , most of the influenza vaccine manufacture for annual flu vaccination program be culture in hen ' egg .
the embryo or host animal serve as an incubator for viral replication ( see figure six  .  one  eight ) .
location within the embryo or host animal be important .
many virus have a tissue tropism , and must therefore be introduce into a specific site for growth .
within an embryo , target site include the amniotic cavity , the chorioallantoic membrane , or the yolk sac .
viral infection may damage tissue membrane , produce lesion call pox  disrupt embryonic development  or cause the death of the embryo .

for in vitro study , various type of cell can be use to support the growth of virus .
a primary cell culture be freshly prepare from animal organ or tissue .

because of anchorage - dependence requirement , primary cell culture require a liquid culture medium in a petri dish or tissue - culture flask so cell have a solid surface such as glass or plastic for attachment and growth .
primary culture usually have a limited life span .

the immortal cell line of henrietta lack
in january one  nine  five  one , henrietta lacks , a three  zero  - year - old african american woman from baltimore , be diagnose with cervical cancer at john hopkins hospital .
- pron - now know - pron - cancer be cause by the human papillomavirus ( hpv ) .
cytopathic effect of the virus alter the characteristic of - pron - cell in a process call transformation , which give the cell the ability to divide continuously .
this ability , of course , result in a cancerous tumor that eventually kill mrs . lacks in october at age three  one .
before - pron - death , sample of - pron - cancerous cell be take without - pron - knowledge or permission .
the sample eventually end up in the possession of dr . george gey , a biomedical researcher at johns hopkins university .
gey be able to grow some of the cell from lacks 's sample , create what be know today as the immortal hela cell line .
these cell have the ability to live and grow indefinitely and , even today , be still widely use in many area of research .
accord to lacks 's husband , neither henrietta nor the family give the hospital permission to collect - pron - tissue speciman .
indeed , the family be not aware until two  zero year after lacks 's death that - pron - cell be still alive and actively be use for commercial and research purpose .
yet hela cell have be pivotal in numerous research discovery relate to polio , cancer , and aids , among other disease .
the cell have also be commercialize , although - pron - have never - pron - be patent .
despite this , henrietta lack 's estate have never benefit from the use of the cell , although , in two  zero  one  three , the lacks family be give control over the publication of the genetic sequence of - pron - cell .
this case raise several bioethical issue surround patient ' informed consent and the right to know .
at the time lack 's tissue be take , there be no law or guideline about informed consent .
do that mean - pron - be treat fairly at the time ?
certainly by today 's standard , the answer would be no .
harvest tissue or organ from a die patient without consent be not only consider unethical but illegal , regardless of whether such an act could save other patient ' life .
be - pron - ethical , then , for scientist to continue to use lacks 's tissue for research , even though - pron - be obtain illegally by today 's standard ?
ethical or not , lacks 's cell be widely use today for so many application that - pron - be impossible to list - pron - all .
be this a case in which the end justify the mean ?
would lacks be pleased to know about - pron - contribution to science and the million of people who have benefit ?
would - pron - want - pron - family to be compensate for the commercial product that have be develop use - pron - cell ?
or would - pron - feel violate and exploit by the researcher who take part of - pron - body without - pron - consent ?
because - pron - be never ask , - pron - will never know .

cytopathic effect ( cpe ) be distinct observable cell abnormality due to viral infection .
cpe can include loss of adherence to the surface of the container , change in cell shape from flat to round , shrinkage of the nucleus , vacuole in the cytoplasm , fusion of cytoplasmic membrane and the formation of multinucleate syncytia , inclusion body in the nucleus or cytoplasm , and complete cell lysis ( see figure six  .  two  one ) .
further pathological change include viral disruption of the host genome and alter normal cell into transformed cell , which be the type of cell associate with carcinoma and sarcoma .
the type or severity of the cpe depend on the type of virus involve .

hemagglutination assay
a serological assay be use to detect the presence of certain type of virus in patient serum .
serum be the strawcolored liquid fraction of blood plasma from which clotting factor have be remove .
serum can be use in a direct assay call a hemagglutination assay to detect specific type of virus in the patient 's sample .
hemagglutination be the agglutination ( clump ) together of erythrocyte ( red blood cell ) .
many virus produce surface protein or spike call hemagglutinin that can bind to receptor on the membrane of erythrocyte and cause the cell to agglutinate .
hemagglutination be observable without use the microscope , but this method do not always differentiate between infectious and noninfectious viral particle , since both can agglutinate erythrocyte .
to identify a specific pathogenic virus use hemagglutination , - pron - must use an indirect approach .
protein call antibody , generate by the patient 's immune system to fight a specific virus , can be use to bind to component such as hemagglutinin that be uniquely associate with specific type of virus .
the binding of the antibody with the hemagglutinin find on the virus subsequently prevent erythrocyte from directly interact with the virus .
so when erythrocyte be add to the antibody - coat virus , there be no appearance of agglutination  agglutination have be inhibit .
- pron - call these type of indirect assay for virus - specific antibody hemagglutination inhibition ( hai ) assay .
hai can be use to detect the presence of antibody specific to many type of virus that may be cause or have cause an infection in a patient even month or year after infection ( see figure six  .  two  two ) .
this assay be describe in great detail in agglutination assays .

what be the outcome of a positive hia test ?
nucleic acid amplification test nucleic acid amplification test ( naat ) be use in molecular biology to detect unique nucleic acid sequence of virus in patient sample .
polymerase chain reaction ( pcr ) be an naat use to detect the presence of viral dna in a patient 's tissue or body fluid sample .
pcr be a technique that amplifie ( i . e . , synthesize many copy ) of a viral dna segment of interest .
use pcr , short nucleotide sequence call primer bind to specific sequence of viral dna , enable identification of the virus .
reverse transcriptase - pcr ( rt - pcr ) be an naat use to detect the presence of rna virus .
rt - pcr differ from pcr in that the enzyme reverse transcriptase ( rt ) be use to make a cdna from the small amount of viral rna in the speciman .
the cdna can then be amplify by pcr .
both pcr and rt - pcr be use to detect and confirm the presence of the viral nucleic acid in patient specimen .

why do michelle 's physician order two different test instead of rely on one or the other ?
enzyme immunoassay enzyme immunoassay ( eia ) rely on the ability of antibody to detect and attach to specific biomolecule call antigen .
the detect antibody attache to the target antigen with a high degree of specificity in what may be a complex mixture of biomolecule .
also include in this type of assay be a colorless enzyme attach to the detect antibody .
the enzyme act as a tag on the detect antibody and can interact with a colorless substrate , lead to the production of a colored end product .
eia often rely on layer of antibody to capture and react with antigen , all of which be attach to a membrane filter ( see figure six  .  two  three ) .
eia for viral antigen be often use as preliminary screening test .
if the result be positive , further confirmation will require test with even great sensitivity , such as a western blot or an naat .
eia be discuss in more detail in eia and elisas .

describe prion and - pron - unique characteristic
research attempt to discover the causative agent of previously uninvestigated disease have lead to the discovery of nonlive disease agent quite different from virus .
these include particle consist only of rna or only of protein that , nonetheless , be able to self - propagate at the expense of a host - a key similarity to virus that allow - pron - to cause disease condition .
to date , these discovery include viroid , virusoid , and the proteinaceous prion .
viroids
in one  nine  seven  one , theodor diener , a pathologist work at the agriculture research service , discover an acellular particle that - pron - name a viroid , mean " virus - like .
”
viroid consist only of a short strand of circular rna capable of selfreplication .
the first viroid discover be find to cause potato tuber spindle disease , which cause slow sprouting and various deformity in potato plant ( see figure six  .  two  four ) .
like virus , potato spindle tuber viroid ( pstvs ) take control of the host machinery to replicate - pron - rna genome .
unlike virus , viroid do not have a protein coat to protect - pron - genetic information .

( credit  pamela roberts , university of florida institute of food and agricultural sciences , usda ars )
viroid can result in devastating loss of commercially important agricultural food crop grow in field and orchard .
since the discovery of pstv , other viroid have be discover that cause disease in plant .
tomato planta macho viroid ( tpmvd ) infect tomato plant , which cause loss of chlorophyll , disfigured and brittle leaf , and very small tomato , result in loss of productivity in this field crop .
avocado sunblotch viroid ( asbvd ) result in low yield and poor - quality fruit .
asbvd be the small viroid discover thus far that infect plant .
peach latent mosaic viroid ( plmvd ) can cause necrosis of flower bud and branch , and wound of ripen fruit , which lead to fungal and bacterial growth in the fruit .
plmvd can also cause similar pathological change in plum , nectarine , apricot , and cherry , result in decreased productivity in these orchard , as well .
viroid , in general , can be disperse mechanically during crop maintenance or harvesting , vegetative reproduction , and possibly via seed and insect , result in a severe drop in food availability and devastating economic consequence .

what be the genome of a viroid make of ?
virusoid a second type of pathogenic rna that can infect commercially important agricultural crop be the virusoid , which be subviral particle best describe as non – self - replicate ssrnas .
rna replication of virusoid be similar to that of viroid but , unlike viroid , virusoid require that the cell also be infect with a specific " helper ” virus .
there be currently only five describe type of virusoid and - pron - associate helper virus .
the helper virus be all from the family of sobemoviruses .
an example of a helper virus be the subterranean clover mottle virus , which have an associate virusoid package inside the viral capsid .
once the helper virus enter the host cell , the virusoid be release and can be find free in plant cell cytoplasm , where - pron - possess ribozyme activity .
the helper virus undergo typical viral replication independent of the activity of the virusoid .
the virusoid genome be small , only two  two  zero to three  eight  eight nucleotide long .
a virusoid genome do not code for any protein , but instead serve only to replicate virusoid rna .
virusoid belong to a large group of infectious agent call satellite rnas , which be similar pathogenic rna find in animal .
unlike the plant virusoid , satellite rna may encode for protein  however , like plant virusoid , satellite rna must coinfect with a helper virus to replicate .
one satellite rna that infect human and that have be describe by some scientist as a virusoid be the hepatitis delta virus ( hdv ) , which , by some report , be also call hepatitis delta virusoid .
much large than a plant virusoid , hdv have a circular , ssrna genome of one  ,  seven  zero  zero nucleotide and can direct the biosynthesis of hdv - associate protein .
the hdv helper virus be the hepatitis b virus ( hbv ) .
coinfection with hbv and hdv result in more severe pathological change in the liver during infection , which be two  seven  six chapter six

prion
at one time , scientist believe that any infectious particle must contain dna or rna .
then , in one  nine  eight  two , stanley prusiner , a medical doctor study scrapie ( a fatal , degenerative disease in sheep ) discover that the disease be cause by proteinaceous infectious particle , or prion .
because protein be acellular and do not contain dna or rna , prusiner 's finding be originally meet with resistance and skepticism  however , - pron - research be eventually validate , and - pron - receive the nobel prize in physiology or medicine in one  nine  nine  seven .
a prion be a misfolde rogue form of a normal protein ( prpc ) find in the cell .
this rogue prion protein ( prpsc ) , which may be cause by a genetic mutation or occur spontaneously , can be infectious , stimulate other endogenous normal protein to become misfolded , form plaque ( see figure six  .  two  five ) .
today , prion be know to cause various form of transmissible spongiform encephalopathy ( tse ) in human and animal .
tse be a rare degenerative disorder that affect the brain and nervous system .
the accumulation of rogue protein cause the brain tissue to become spongelike , kill brain cell and form hole in the tissue , lead to brain damage , loss of motor coordination , and dementia ( see figure six  .  two  six ) .
infect individual be mentally impair and become unable to move or speak .
there be no cure , and the disease progress rapidly , eventually lead to death within a few month or year .
figure six  .  two  five
endogenous normal prion protein ( prpc ) be convert into the disease - cause form ( prpsc ) when - pron - encounter this variant form of the protein .
prpsc may arise spontaneously in brain tissue , especially if a mutant form of the protein be present , or - pron - may originate from misfolded prion consume in food that eventually find - pron - way into brain tissue .

link to learn clinical focus chapter six
 acellular pathogens two  seven  nine summary six  .  one viruses

virus be generally ultramicroscopic , typically from two  zero nm to nine  zero  zero nm in length .
some large virus have be find .

virion be acellular and consist of a nucleic acid , dna or rna , but not both , surround by a protein capsid .
there may also be a phospholipid membrane surround the capsid .

virus be obligate intracellular parasite .

virus be know to infect various type of cell find in plant , animal , fungus , protist , bacteria , and archaea .
virus typically have limit host range and infect specific cell type .

viruses may have helical , polyhedral , or complex shape .

classification of virus be base on morphology , type of nucleic acid , host range , cell specificity , and enzyme carry within the virion .

like other disease , viral disease be classify use icd code .
six  .  two
the viral life cycle 
many virus target specific host or tissue .
some may have more than one host .

many virus follow several stage to infect host cell .
these stage include attachment , penetration , uncoating , biosynthesis , maturation , and release .

bacteriophage have a lytic or lysogenic cycle .
the lytic cycle lead to the death of the host , whereas the lysogenic cycle lead to integration of phage into the host genome .

bacteriophages inject dna into the host cell , whereas animal virus enter by endocytosis or membrane fusion .

animal virus can undergo latency , similar to lysogeny for a bacteriophage .

the majority of plant virus be positive - strand ssrna and can undergo latency , chronic , or lytic infection , as observe for animal virus .

the growth curve of bacteriophage population be a one - step multiplication curve and not a sigmoidal curve , as compare to the bacterial growth curve .

bacteriophage transfer genetic information between host use either generalize or specialized transduction .
six  .  three isolation , culture , and identification of viruses  viral cultivation require the presence of some form of host cell ( whole organism , embryo , or cell culture ) .

virus can be isolate from sample by filtration .

viral filtrate be a rich source of release virion .

bacteriophage be detect by presence of clear plaque on bacterial lawn .
 animal and plant virus be detect by cytopathic effect , molecular technique ( pcr , rt - pcr ) , enzyme immunoassay , and serological assay ( hemagglutination assay , hemagglutination inhibition assay ) .
six  .  four viroids , virusoid , and prion

one hypothesis about how life emerge on earth involve the concept of a " primordial soup .
"
this idea propose that life begin in a body of water when metal and gas from the atmosphere combine with a source of energy , such as lightning or ultraviolet light , to form the carbon compound that be the chemical building block of life .
in one  nine  five  two , stanley miller ( one  nine  three  zero – two  zero  zero  seven ) , a graduate student at the university of chicago , and - pron - professor harold urey
( one  eight  nine  three – one  nine  eight  one ) , set out to confirm this hypothesis in a nowfamous experiment .

nh three  ) -and seal - pron - in a sterile flask .

biochemistry be the discipline that study the chemistry of life , and - pron - objective be to explain form and function base on chemical principle .
organic chemistry be the discipline devote to the study of carbon - base chemistry , which be the foundation for the study of biomolecule and the discipline of biochemistry .
both biochemistry and organic chemistry be base on the concept of general chemistry , some of which be present in appendix a . elements in live cells
the most abundant element in cell be hydrogen ( h ) , follow by carbon ( c ) , oxygen ( o ) , nitrogen ( n ) , phosphorous ( p ) , and sulfur ( s ) .
- pron - call these element macronutrient , and - pron - account for about nine  nine % of the dry weight of cell .
some element , such as sodium ( na ) , potassium ( k ) , magnesium ( mg ) , zinc ( zn ) , iron ( fe ) , calcium ( ca ) , molybdenum ( mo ) , copper ( cu ) , cobalt ( co ) , manganese ( mn ) , or vanadium ( va ) , be require by some cell in very small amount and be call micronutrient or trace element .
all of these element be essential to the function of many biochemical reaction , and , therefore , be essential to life .
the four most abundant element in live matter ( c , n , o , and h ) have low atomic number and be thus light element capable of form strong bond with other atom to produce molecule ( figure seven  .  two ) .
carbon form four chemical bond , whereas nitrogen form three , oxygen form two , and hydrogen form one .
when bond together within molecule , oxygen , sulfur , and nitrogen often have one or more “ lone pair " of electron that play important role in determine many of the molecule ' physical and chemical property ( see appendix a ) .
these trait in combination permit the formation of a vast number of diverse molecular specie necessary to form the structure and enable the function of live organism .

organic molecules and isomerism organic molecule in organism be generally large and more complex than inorganic molecule .
- pron - carbon skeleton be hold together by covalent bond .
- pron - form the cell of an organism and perform the chemical reaction that facilitate life .
all of these molecule , call biomolecule because - pron - be part of live matter , contain carbon , which be the building block of life .
carbon be a very unique element in that - pron - have four valence electron in - pron - outer orbital and can form four single covalent bond with up to four other atom at the same time ( see appendix a ) .
these atom be usually oxygen , hydrogen , nitrogen , sulfur , phosphorous , and carbon - pron -  the simple organic compound be methane , in which carbon bind only to hydrogen ( figure seven  .  three ) .
as a result of carbon 's unique combination of size and bonding property , carbon atom can bind together in large number , thus produce a chain or carbon skeleton .
the carbon skeleton of organic molecule can be straight , branch , or ring shape ( cyclic ) .
organic molecule be build on chain of carbon atom of vary length  most be typically very long , which allow for a huge number and variety of compound .
no other element have the ability to form so many different molecule of so many different size and shape .

molecule with the same atomic makeup but different structural arrangement of atom be call isomer .
the concept of isomerism be very important in chemistry because the structure of a molecule be always directly relate to - pron - function .
slight change in the structural arrangement of atom in a molecule may lead to very different property .
chemist represent molecule by - pron - structural formula , which be a graphic representation of the molecular structure , show how the atom be arrange .
compound that have identical molecular formula but differ in the bonding sequence of the atom be call structural isomer .
the monosaccharide glucose , galactose , and fructose all have the same molecular formula , c six h one  two o six , but - pron - can see from figure seven  .  four that the atom be bond together differently .
figure seven  .  four glucose , galactose , and fructose have the same chemical formula ( c six h one  two o six ) , but these structural isomer differ in - pron - physical and chemical property .
isomer that differ in the spatial arrangement of atom be call stereoisomer  one unique type be enantiomer .
the property of enantiomer be originally discover by louis pasteur in one  eight  four  eight while use a microscope to analyze crystallize fermentation product of wine .
enantiomer be molecule that have the characteristic of chirality , in which - pron - structure be nonsuperimposable mirror image of each other .
chirality be an important characteristic in many biologically important molecule , as illustrate by the example of structural difference in the enantiomeric form of the monosaccharide glucose or the amino acid alanine ( figure seven  .  five ) .
many organism be only able to use one enantiomeric form of certain type of molecule as nutrient and as building block to make structure within a cell .
some enantiomeric form of amino acid have distinctly different taste and smell when consume as food .
for example , l - aspartame , commonly call aspartame , taste sweet , whereas daspartame be tasteless .
drug enantiomer can have very different pharmacologic affect .
for example , the compound two  eight  eight chapter seven  microbial biochemistry

some of the crystal pasteur observe from wine fermentation rotate light clockwise whereas other rotate the light counterclockwise .
today , - pron - denote enantiomer that rotate polarize light clockwise ( + ) as d form , and the mirror image of the same molecule that rotate polarize light counterclockwise ( − ) as the l form .
the d and l label be derive from the latin word dexter ( on the right ) and laevus ( on the left ) , respectively .
these two different optical isomer often have very different biological property and activity .

another important reason to be aware of optical isomer be the therapeutic use of these type of chemical for drug treatment , because some microorganism can only be affect by one specific optical isomer .

although - pron - be compose primarily of carbon and hydrogen , lipid molecule may also contain oxygen , nitrogen , sulfur , and phosphorous .
lipid serve numerous and diverse purpose in the structure and function of organism .
- pron - can be a source of nutrient , a storage form for carbon , energy - storage molecule , or structural component of membrane and hormone .
lipid comprise a broad class of many chemically distinct compound , the most common of which be discuss in this section .
fatty acids and triacylglycerides
the fatty acid be lipid that contain long - chain hydrocarbon terminate with a carboxylic acid functional group .
because the long hydrocarbon chain , fatty acid be hydrophobic (
“ water fear " ) or nonpolar .
fatty acid with hydrocarbon chain that contain only single bond be call saturate fatty acid because - pron - have the great number of hydrogen atom possible and be , therefore , “ saturate " with hydrogen .
fatty acid with hydrocarbon chain contain at least one double bond be call unsaturated fatty acid because - pron - have few hydrogen atom .
saturate fatty acid have a straight , flexible carbon backbone , whereas unsaturated fatty acid have " kink " in - pron - carbon skeleton because each double bond cause a rigid bend of the carbon skeleton .
these difference in saturate versus unsaturated fatty acid structure result in different property for the corresponding lipid in which the fatty acid be incorporate .
for example , lipid contain saturate fatty acid be solid at room temperature , whereas lipid contain unsaturated fatty acid be liquid .
a triacylglycerol , or triglyceride , be form when three fatty acid be chemically link to a glycerol molecule ( figure seven  .  one  two ) .
triglyceride be the primary component of adipose tissue ( body fat ) , and be major constituent of sebum ( skin oil ) .
- pron - play an important metabolic role , serve as efficient energy - storage molecule that can provide more than double the caloric content of both carbohydrate and protein .
figure seven  .  one  two triglyceride be compose of a glycerol molecule attach to three fatty acid by a dehydration synthesis reaction .

- - pron - be hydrophobic .

"

the amphipathic nature of phospholipid enable - pron - to form uniquely functional structure in aqueous environment .
as mention , the polar head of these molecule be strongly attract to water molecule , and the nonpolar tail be not .
because of - pron - considerable length , these tail be , in fact , strongly attract to one another .
as a result , energetically stable , large - scale assembly of phospholipid molecule be form in which the hydrophobic tail congregate within enclosed region , shield from contact with water by the polar head ( figure seven  .  one  four ) .
the simple of these structure be micelle , spherical assembly contain a hydrophobic interior of phospholipid tail and an outer surface of polar head group .
large and more complex structure be create from lipid - bilayer sheet , or unit membrane , which be large , two - dimensional assembly of phospholipid congregate tail to tail .
the cell membrane of nearly all organism be make from lipid - bilayer sheet , as be the membrane of many intracellular component .
these sheet may also form lipid - bilayer sphere that be the structural basis of vesicle and liposome , subcellular component that play a role in numerous physiological function .
figure seven  .  one  four
phospholipids tend to arrange - pron - in aqueous solution form liposome , micelle , or lipid bilayer sheet .

isoprenoids and sterols
the isoprenoid be branch lipid , also refer to as terpenoid , that be form by chemical modification of the isoprene molecule ( figure seven  .  one  five ) .
these lipid play a wide variety of physiological role in plant and animal , with many technological use as pharmaceutical ( capsaicin ) , pigment ( e . g . , orange beta carotene , xanthophyll ) , and fragrance ( e . g . , menthol , camphor , limonene [ lemon fragrance ] , and pinene [ pine fragrance ] ) .
long - chain isoprenoid be also find in hydrophobic oil and wax .
wax be typically water resistant and hard at room temperature , but - pron - soften when heated and liquefy if warm adequately .
in human , the main wax production occur within the sebaceous gland of hair follicle in the skin , result in a secreted material call sebum , which consist mainly of triacylglycerol , wax ester , and the hydrocarbon squalene .
there be many bacteria in the microbiota on the skin that feed on these lipid .
one of the most prominent bacteria that feed on lipid be propionibacterium acne , which use the skin 's lipid to generate short - chain fatty acid and be involve in the production of acne .

an amino acid be an organic molecule in which a hydrogen atom , a carboxyl group ( –cooh ) , and an amino group ( –nh two ) be all bond to the same carbon atom , the so - call α carbon .
the fourth group bond to the α carbon vary among the different amino acid and be call a residue or a side chain , represent in structural formula by the letter
r . a residue be a monomer that result when two or more amino acid combine and remove water molecule .
the primary structure of a protein , a peptide chain , be make of amino acid residue .
the unique characteristic of the functional group and r group allow these component of the amino acid to form hydrogen , ionic , and disulfide bond , along with polar / nonpolar interaction need to form secondary , tertiary , and quaternary protein structure .
these group be compose primarily of carbon , hydrogen , oxygen , nitrogen , and sulfur , in the form of hydrocarbon , acid , amide , alcohol , and amine .
a few example illustrate these possibility be provide in figure seven  .  one  seven .
figure seven  .  one  seven amino acid may chemically bond together by reaction of the carboxylic acid group of one molecule with the amine group of another .
this reaction form a peptide bond and a water molecule and be another example of dehydration synthesis ( figure seven  .  one  eight ) .
molecule form by chemically link relatively modest number of amino acid ( approximately five  zero or few ) be call peptide , and prefix be often use to specify these number  dipeptide ( two amino acid ) , tripeptide ( three amino acid ) , and so forth .
more generally , the approximate number of amino acid be designate  oligopeptide be form by join up to approximately two  zero amino acid , whereas polypeptide be synthesize from up to approximately five  zero amino acid .
when the number of amino acid link together become very large , or when multiple polypeptide be use as building subunit , the macromolecule that result be call protein .
