protein structure
the size ( length ) and specific amino acid sequence of a protein be major determinant of - pron - shape , and the shape of a protein be critical to - pron - function .
for example , in the process of biological nitrogen fixation ( see biogeochemical cycles ) , soil microorganism collectively know as rhizobia symbiotically interact with root of legume plant such as soybean , peanut , or bean to form a novel structure call a nodule on the plant root .
the plant then produce a carrier protein call leghemoglobin , a protein that carry nitrogen or oxygen .
leghemoglobin bind with a very high affinity to - pron - substrate oxygen at a specific region of the protein where the shape and amino acid sequence be appropriate ( the active site ) .
if the shape or chemical environment of the active site be alter , even slightly , the substrate may not be able to bind as strongly , or - pron - may not bind at all .
thus , for the protein to be fully active , - pron - must have the appropriate shape for - pron - function .
protein structure be categorize in term of four level  primary , secondary , tertiary , and quaternary .
the primary structure be simply the sequence of amino acid that make up the polypeptide chain .
figure seven  .  one  nine depict the primary structure of a protein .
the chain of amino acid that define a protein
's primary structure be not rigid , but instead be flexible because of the nature of the bond that hold the amino acid together .
when the chain be sufficiently long , hydrogen bonding may occur between amine and carbonyl functional group within the peptide backbone ( exclude the r side group ) , result in localized folding of the polypeptide chain into helix and sheet .
these shape constitute a protein 's secondary structure .
the most common secondary structure be the α - helix and β - pleated sheet .
in the α - helix structure , the helix be hold by hydrogen bond between the oxygen atom in a carbonyl group of one amino acid and the hydrogen atom of the amino group that be just four amino acid unit farther along the chain .
in the β - pleat sheet , the pleat be form by similar hydrogen bond between continuous sequence of carbonyl and amino group that be further separate on the backbone of the polypeptide chain ( figure seven  .  two  zero ) .
the next level of protein organization be the tertiary structure , which be the large - scale three - dimensional shape of a single polypeptide chain .
tertiary structure be determine by interaction between amino acid residue that be far apart in the chain .
a variety of interaction give rise to protein tertiary structure , such as disulfide bridge , which be bond between the sulfhydryl ( –sh ) functional group on amino acid side group  hydrogen bond  ionic bond  and hydrophobic interaction between nonpolar side chain .
all these interaction , weak and strong , combine to determine the final three - dimensional shape of the protein and - pron - function ( figure seven  .  two  one ) .
the process by which a polypeptide chain assume
a large - scale , three - dimensional shape be call protein folding .
folded protein that be fully functional in - pron - normal biological role be say to possess a native structure .

some protein be assembly of several separate polypeptide , also know as protein subunit .
these protein function adequately only when all subunit be present and appropriately configure .
the interaction that hold these subunit together constitute the quaternary structure of the protein .
the overall quaternary structure be stabilize by relatively weak interaction .
hemoglobin , for example , have a quaternary structure of four globular protein subunit  two α and two β polypeptide , each one contain an iron - base heme ( figure seven  .  two  two ) .
another important class of protein be the conjugated protein that have a nonprotein portion .
if the conjugate protein have a carbohydrate attach , - pron - be call a glycoprotein .
if - pron - have a lipid attach , - pron - be call a lipoprotein .
these protein be important component of membrane .

summary seven  .  one organic molecules

the most abundant element in cell be hydrogen , carbon , oxygen , nitrogen , phosphorus , and sulfur .

life be carbon base .
each carbon atom can bind to another one produce a carbon skeleton that can be straight , branch , or ring shape .

the same number and type of atom may bond together in different way to yield different molecule call isomer .
isomer may differ in the bonding sequence of - pron - atom ( structural isomer ) or in the spatial arrangement of atom whose bonding sequence be the same ( stereoisomer ) , and - pron - physical and chemical property may vary slightly or drastically .

functional group confer specific chemical property to molecule bear - pron - .
common functional group in biomolecule be hydroxyl , methyl , carbonyl , carboxyl , amino , phosphate , and sulfhydryl .

macromolecule be polymer assemble from individual unit , the monomer , which bind together like building block .
many biologically significant macromolecule be form by dehydration synthesis , a process in which monomer bind together by combine - pron - functional group and generate water molecule as byproduct .
seven  .  two carbohydrates  carbohydrates , the most abundant biomolecule on earth , be widely use by organism for structural and energy - storage purpose .
 carbohydrate include individual sugar molecule ( monosaccharide ) as well as two or more molecule chemically link by glycosidic bond .
monosaccharide be classify base on the number of carbon the three  one  zero chapter seven  microbial biochemistry
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five molecule as triose ( three c ) , tetrose ( four c ) , pentose ( five c ) , and hexose ( six c ) .
- pron - be the building block for the synthesis of polymer or complex carbohydrate .

disaccharides such as sucrose , lactose , and maltose be molecule compose of two monosaccharide link together by a glycosidic bond .
 polysaccharides , or glycan , be polymer compose of hundred of monosaccharide monomer link together by glycosidic bond .
the energy - storage polymer starch and glycogen be example of polysaccharide and be all compose of branched chain of glucose molecule .

the polysaccharide cellulose be a common structural component of the cell wall of organism .
other structural polysaccharide , such as n - acetyl glucosamine ( nag ) and n - acetyl muramic acid ( nam ) , incorporate modified glucose molecule and be use in the construction of peptidoglycan or chitin .
seven  .  three lipids 
lipid be compose mainly of carbon and hydrogen , but - pron - can also contain oxygen , nitrogen , sulfur , and phosphorous .
- pron - provide nutrient for organism , store carbon and energy , play structural role in membrane , and function as hormone , pharmaceutical , fragrance , and pigment .

fatty acid be long - chain hydrocarbon with a carboxylic acid functional group .
- pron - relatively long nonpolar hydrocarbon chain make - pron - hydrophobic .
fatty acid with no double bond be saturate  those with double bond be unsaturated .

fatty acid chemically bond to glycerol to form structurally essential lipid such as triglyceride and phospholipid .
triglyceride comprise three fatty acid bond to glycerol , yield a hydrophobic molecule .
phospholipid contain both hydrophobic hydrocarbon chain and polar head group , make - pron - amphipathic and capable of form uniquely functional large scale structure .

biological membrane be large - scale structure base on phospholipid bilayer that provide hydrophilic exterior and interior surface suitable for aqueous environment , separate by an intervene hydrophobic layer .
these bilayer be the structural basis for cell membrane in most organism , as well as subcellular component such as vesicle .

isoprenoid be lipid derive from isoprene molecule that have many physiological role and a variety of commercial application .

a wax be a long - chain isoprenoid that be typically water resistant  an example of a wax - contain substance be sebum , produce by sebaceous gland in the skin .
steroid be lipid with complex , ringed structure that function as structural component of cell membrane and as hormone .
sterol be a subclass of steroid contain a hydroxyl group at a specific location on one of the molecule 's ring  one example be cholesterol .
 bacteria produce hopanoid , structurally similar to cholesterol , to strengthen bacterial membrane .
fungi and protozoa produce a strengthen agent call ergosterol .
seven  .  four proteins 
amino acid be small molecule essential to all life .
each have an α carbon to which a hydrogen atom , carboxyl group , and amine group be bond .
the fourth bond group , represent by r , vary in chemical composition , size , polarity , and charge among different amino acid , provide variation in property .

peptide be polymer form by the linkage of amino acid via dehydration synthesis .
the bond between the link amino acid be call peptide bond .
the number of amino acid link together may vary from a few to many .

protein be polymer form by the linkage of a very large number of amino acid .
- pron - perform many important function in a cell , serve as nutrient and enzyme  storage molecule for carbon , nitrogen , and energy  and structural component .

the structure of a protein be a critical determinant of - pron - function and be describe by a graduate classification  primary , secondary , tertiary , and quaternary .
the native structure of a protein may be disrupt by denaturation , result in loss of - pron - high - order structure and - pron - biological function .

some protein be form by several separate protein subunit , the interaction of these subunit compose the quaternary structure of the protein complex .

the term use to describe all of the chemical reaction inside a cell be metabolism ( figure eight  .  two ) .
cellular process such as the building or break down of complex molecule occur through series of stepwise , interconnect chemical reaction call metabolic pathway .
reaction that be spontaneous and release energy be exergonic reaction , whereas endergonic reaction require energy to proceed .
the term anabolism refer to those endergonic metabolic pathway involve in biosynthesis , convert simple molecular building block into more complex molecule , and fuel by the use of cellular energy .
conversely , the term catabolism refer to exergonic pathway that break down complex molecule into simple one .
molecular energy store in the bond of complex molecule be release in catabolic pathway and harvest in such a way that - pron - can be use to produce high - energy molecule , which be use to drive anabolic pathway .
thus , in term of energy and molecule , cell be continually balance catabolism with anabolism .

classification by carbon and energy source organisms can be identify accord to the source of carbon - pron - use for metabolism as well as - pron - energy source .

oxidation and reduction in metabolism
the transfer of electron between molecule be important because most of the energy store in atom and use to fuel cell function be in the form of high - energy electron .
the transfer of energy in the form of electron allow the cell to transfer and use energy incrementally  that is , in small package rather than a single , destructive burst .
reaction that remove electron from donor molecule , leave - pron - oxidize , be oxidation reaction  those that add electron to acceptor molecule , leave - pron - reduce , be reduction reaction .
because electron can move from one molecule to another , oxidation and reduction occur in tandem .
these pair of reaction be call oxidation - reduction reaction , or redox reaction .
energy carrier  nad+ , nadp+ , fad , and atp
the energy release from the breakdown of the chemical bond within nutrient can be store either through the reduction of electron carrier or in the bond of adenosine triphosphate ( atp ) .
in living system , a small class of compound function as mobile electron carrier , molecule that bind to and shuttle high - energy electron between compound in pathway .
the principal electron carrier - pron - will consider originate from the b vitamin group and be derivative of nucleotide  - pron - be nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide , nicotine adenine dinucleotide phosphate , and flavin adenine dinucleotide .
these compound can be easily reduce or oxidize .
nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide ( nad+ / nadh ) be the most common mobile electron carrier use in catabolism .
nad+ be the oxidize form of the molecule  nadh be the reduce form of the molecule .
nicotine adenine dinucleotide phosphate ( nadp+ ) , the oxidize form of an nad+ variant that contain an extra phosphate group , be another important electron carrier  - pron - form nadph when reduce .
the oxidize form of flavin adenine dinucleotide be fad , and - pron - reduce form be fadh two .
both nad+ / nadh and fad / fadh two be extensively use in energy extraction from sugar during catabolism in chemoheterotroph , whereas nadp+ / nadph play an important role in anabolic reaction and photosynthesis .
collectively , fadh two , nadh , and nadph be often refer to as have reduce power due to - pron - ability to donate electron to various chemical reaction .
a live cell must be able to handle the energy release during catabolism in a way that enable the cell to store energy safely and release - pron - for use only as need .
living cell accomplish this by use the compound adenosine triphosphate ( atp ) .
atp be often call the " energy currency " of the cell , and , like currency , this versatile compound can be use to fill any energy need of the cell .
at the heart of atp be a molecule of adenosine monophosphate ( amp ) , which be compose of an adenine molecule bond to a ribose molecule and a single phosphate group .
ribose be a five - carbon sugar find in rna , and amp be one of the nucleotide in rna .
the addition of a second phosphate group to this core molecule result in the formation of adenosine diphosphate ( adp )  the addition of a third phosphate group form atp ( figure eight  .  three ) .
add a phosphate group to a molecule , a process call phosphorylation , require energy .
phosphate group be negatively charge and thus repel one another when - pron - be arrange in series , as - pron - be in adp and atp .
this repulsion make the adp and atp molecule inherently unstable .
thus , the bond between phosphate group ( one in adp and two in atp ) be call high - energy phosphate bond .
when these highenergy bond be break to release one phosphate ( call inorganic phosphate
[ pi ] ) or two connected phosphate group ( call pyrophosphate [ ppi ] ) from atp through a process call dephosphorylation , energy be release to drive endergonic reaction ( figure eight  .  four ) .

what be the function of an electron carrier ?
enzyme structure and function a substance that help speed up a chemical reaction be a catalyst .
catalyst be not use or change during chemical reaction and , therefore , be reusable .
whereas inorganic molecule may serve as catalyst for a wide range of chemical reaction , protein call enzyme serve as catalyst for biochemical reaction inside cell .
enzyme thus play an important role in control cellular metabolism .
an enzyme function by lower the activation energy of a chemical reaction inside the cell .
activation energy be the energy need to form or break chemical bond and convert reactant to product ( figure eight  .  five ) .
enzyme lower the activation energy by bind to the reactant molecule and hold - pron - in such a way as to speed up the reaction .

the chemical reactant to which an enzyme bind be call substrate , and the location within the enzyme where the substrate bind be call the enzyme 's active site .
the characteristic of the amino acid near the active site create a very specific chemical environment within the active site that induce suitability to bind , albeit briefly , to a specific substrate ( or substrate ) .

this active - site modification in the presence of substrate , along with the simultaneous formation of the transition state , be call induced fit ( figure eight  .  six ) .
overall , there be a specifically match enzyme for each substrate and , thus , for each chemical reaction  however , there be some flexibility as well .
some enzyme have the ability to act on several different structurally relate substrate .

enzyme inhibitors enzymes can be regulate in way that either promote or reduce - pron - activity .
there be many different kind of molecule that inhibit or promote enzyme function , and various mechanism exist for do so ( figure eight  .  eight ) .
a competitive inhibitor be a molecule similar enough to a substrate that - pron - can compete with the substrate for bind to chapter eight  microbial metabolism three  two  three the active site by simply block the substrate from bind .
for a competitive inhibitor to be effective , the inhibitor concentration need to be approximately equal to the substrate concentration .
sulfa drug provide a good example of competitive competition .
- pron - be use to treat bacterial infection because - pron - bind to the active site of an enzyme within the bacterial folic acid synthesis pathway .
when present in a sufficient dose , a sulfa drug prevent folic acid synthesis , and bacteria be unable to grow because - pron - can not synthesize dna , rna , and protein .
human be unaffected because - pron - obtain folic acid from - pron - diet .
on the other hand , a noncompetitive ( allosteric ) inhibitor bind to the enzyme at an allosteric site , a location other than the active site , and still manage to block substrate bind to the active site by induce a conformational change that reduce the affinity of the enzyme for - pron - substrate ( figure eight  .  nine ) .
because only one inhibitor molecule be need per enzyme for effective inhibition , the concentration of inhibitor need for noncompetitive inhibition be typically much low than the substrate concentration .
in addition to allosteric inhibitor , there be allosteric activator that bind to location on an enzyme away from the active site , induce a conformational change that increase the affinity of the enzyme 's active site ( s ) for - pron - substrate ( s ) .
allosteric control be an important mechanism of regulation of metabolic pathway involve in both catabolism and anabolism .
in a most efficient and elegant way , cell have evolve also to use the product of - pron - own metabolic reaction for feedback inhibition of enzyme activity .
feedback inhibition involve the use of a pathway product to regulate - pron - own further production .
the cell respond to the abundance of specific product by slow production during anabolic or catabolic reaction ( figure eight  .  nine ) .
figure eight  .  eight enzyme activity can be regulate by either competitive inhibitor , which bind to the active site , or noncompetitive inhibitor , which bind to an allosteric site .

glycolysis
for bacteria , eukaryote , and most archaea , glycolysis be the most common pathway for the catabolism of glucose  - pron - produce energy , reduce electron carrier , and precursor molecule for cellular metabolism .
every live organism carry out some form of glycolysis , suggest this mechanism be an ancient universal metabolic process .
the process - pron - do not use oxygen  however , glycolysis can be couple with additional metabolic process that be either aerobic or anaerobic .
glycolysis take place in the cytoplasm of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell .
- pron - begin with a single six - carbon glucose molecule and end with two molecule of a three - carbon sugar call pyruvate .
pyruvate may be break down further after glycolysis to harness more energy through aerobic or anaerobic respiration , but many organism , include many microbe , may be unable to respire  for these organism , glycolysis may be - pron - only source of generate atp .
the type of glycolysis find in animal and that be most common in microbe be the embden - meyerhof - parnas ( emp ) pathway , name after gustav embden ( one  eight  seven  four – one  nine  three  three ) , otto meyerhof ( one  eight  eight  four – one  nine  five  one ) , and jakub parnas ( one  eight  eight  four – one  nine  four  nine ) .
glycolysis use the emp pathway consist of two distinct phase ( figure eight  .  one  zero ) .
the first part of the pathway , call the energy investment phase , use energy from two atp molecule to modify a glucose molecule so that the six - carbon sugar molecule can be split evenly into two phosphorylated three - carbon molecule call glyceraldehyde three  - phosphate ( g three p ) .
the second part of the pathway , call the energy payoff phase , extract energy by oxidize g three p to pyruvate , produce four atp molecule and reduce two molecule of nad+ to two molecule of nadh , use electron that originate from glucose .
( a discussion and illustration of the full emp pathway with chemical structure and enzyme name appear in appendix c . )

respiration
- pron - have just discuss two pathway in glucose catabolism
- glycolysis and the krebs cycle - that generate atp by substrate - level phosphorylation .
most atp , however , be generate during a separate process call oxidative phosphorylation , which occur during cellular respiration .
cellular respiration begin when electron be transfer from nadh and fadh two -made in glycolysis , the transition reaction , and the krebs cycle - through a series of chemical reaction to a final inorganic electron acceptor ( either oxygen in aerobic respiration or non - oxygen inorganic molecule in anaerobic respiration ) .
these electron transfer take place on the inner part of the cell membrane of prokaryotic cell or in specialize protein complex in the inner membrane of the mitochondria of eukaryotic cell .
the energy of the electron be harvest to generate an electrochemical gradient across the membrane , which be use to make atp by oxidative phosphorylation .
electron transport system
the electron transport system ( ets ) be the last component involve in the process of cellular respiration  - pron - comprise a series of membrane - associate protein complex and associate mobile accessory electron carrier ( figure eight  .  one  five ) .
electron transport be a series of chemical reaction that resemble a bucket brigade in that electron from nadh and fadh two be pass rapidly from one ets electron carrier to the next .
these carrier can pass electron along in the ets because of - pron - redox potential .
for a protein or chemical to accept electron , - pron - must have a more positive redox potential than the electron donor .
therefore , electron move from electron carrier with more negative redox potential to those with more positive redox potential .
the four major class of electron carrier involve in both eukaryotic and prokaryotic electron transport system be the cytochrome , flavoprotein , iron - sulfur protein , and the quinone .
in aerobic respiration , the final electron acceptor ( i . e . , the one have the most positive redox potential ) at the end of the ets be an oxygen molecule ( o two ) that become reduce to water ( h two o ) by the final ets carrier .
this electron carrier , cytochrome oxidase , differ between bacterial type and can be use to differentiate closely related bacteria for diagnosis .
for example , the gram - negative opportunist pseudomonas aeruginosa and the gram - negative choleracause vibrio cholerae use cytochrome c oxidase , which can be detect by the oxidase test , whereas other gramnegative enterobacteriaceae , like e . coli , be negative for this test because - pron - produce different cytochrome oxidase type .
there be many circumstance under which aerobic respiration be not possible , include any one or more of the following  
the cell lack gene encode an appropriate cytochrome oxidase for transfer electron to oxygen at the end of the electron transport system .

the cell lack gene encode enzyme to minimize the severely damaging effect of dangerous oxygen radical produce during aerobic respiration , such as hydrogen peroxide ( h two o two ) or superoxide

one possible alternative to aerobic respiration be anaerobic respiration , use an inorganic molecule other than oxygen as a final electron acceptor .
there be many type of anaerobic respiration find in bacteria and archaea .

chemiosmosis , proton motive force , and oxidative phosphorylation
in each transfer of an electron through the ets , the electron lose energy , but with some transfer , the energy be store as potential energy by use - pron - to pump hydrogen ion ( h+ ) across a membrane .
in prokaryotic cell , h+ be pump to the outside of the cytoplasmic membrane ( call the periplasmic space in gram - negative and gram - positive bacteria ) , and in eukaryotic cell , - pron - be pump from the mitochondrial matrix across the inner mitochondrial membrane into the intermembrane space .
there be an uneven distribution of h+ across the membrane that establish an electrochemical gradient because h+ ion be positively charge ( electrical ) and there be a high concentration ( chemical ) on one side of the membrane .
this electrochemical gradient form by the accumulation of h+ ( also know as a proton ) on one side of the membrane compare with the other be refer to as the proton motive force ( pmf ) .
because the ion involve be h+ , a ph gradient be also establish , with the side of the membrane have the high concentration of h+ be more acidic .
beyond the use of the pmf to make atp , as discuss in this chapter , the pmf can also be use to drive other energetically unfavorable process , include nutrient transport and flagella rotation for motility .
the potential energy of this electrochemical gradient generate by the ets cause the h+ to diffuse across a membrane ( the plasma membrane in prokaryotic cell and the inner membrane in mitochondria in eukaryotic cell ) .
this flow of hydrogen ion across the membrane , call chemiosmosis , must occur through a channel in the membrane via a membrane - bind enzyme complex call atp synthase ( figure eight  .  one  five ) .
the tendency for movement in this way be much like water accumulate on one side of a dam , move through the dam when open .
atp synthase ( like a combination of the intake and generator of a hydroelectric dam ) be a complex protein that act as a tiny generator , turn by the force of the h+ diffuse through the enzyme , down - pron - electrochemical gradient from where there be many mutually repel h+ to where there be few h+ .
in prokaryotic cell , h+ flow from the outside of the cytoplasmic membrane into the cytoplasm , whereas in eukaryotic mitochondria , h+ flow from the intermembrane space to the mitochondrial matrix .
the turning of the part of this molecular machine regenerate atp from adp and inorganic phosphate
( pi ) by oxidative phosphorylation , a second mechanism for make atp that harvest the potential energy store within an electrochemical gradient .

lipid catabolism triglycerides be a form of long - term energy storage in animal .
- pron - be make of glycerol and three fatty acid ( see figure seven  .  one  two ) .
phospholipid compose the cell and organelle membrane of all organism except the archaea .
phospholipid structure be similar to triglyceride except that one of the fatty acid be replace by a phosphorylate head group ( see figure seven  .  one  three ) .
triglyceride and phospholipid be break down first by release fatty acid chain ( and / or the phosphorylate head group , in the case of phospholipid ) from the three - carbon glycerol backbone .
the reaction break down triglyceride be catalyze by lipase and those involve phospholipid be catalyze by phospholipase .
these enzyme contribute to the virulence of certain microbe , such as the bacterium staphylococcus aureus and the fungus cryptococcus neoforman .
these microbe use phospholipase to destroy lipid and phospholipid in host cell and then use the catabolic product for energy ( see virulence factors of bacterial and viral pathogens ) .
the result product of lipid catabolism , glycerol and fatty acid , can be further degrade .
glycerol can be phosphorylate to glycerol -  three  - phosphate and easily convert to glyceraldehyde three  - phosphate , which continue through glycolysis .
the release fatty acid be catabolize in a process call β - oxidation , which sequentially remove two - carbon acetyl group from the end of fatty acid chain , reduce nad+ and fad to produce nadh and fadh two , respectively , whose electron can be use to make atp by oxidative phosphorylation .
the acetyl group produce during β - oxidation be carry by coenzyme a to the krebs cycle , and - pron - movement through this cycle result in - pron - degradation to co two , produce atp by substrate - level phosphorylation and additional nadh and fadh two molecule ( see appendix c for a detailed illustration of β - oxidation ) .
other type of lipid can also be degrade by certain microbe .
for example , the ability of certain pathogen , like mycobacterium tuberculosis , to degrade cholesterol contribute to - pron - virulence .
the side chain of cholesterol can be easily remove enzymatically , but degradation of the remain fused ring be more problematic .
the four fuse ring be sequentially break in a multistep process facilitate by specific enzyme , and the result product , include pyruvate , can be further catabolize in the krebs cycle .

the remain molecule can then enter the transition reaction or the krebs cycle .

many of these carbohydrate be produce by photosynthesis , the biochemical process by which phototrophic organism convert solar energy ( sunlight ) into chemical energy .
although photosynthesis be most commonly associate with plant , microbial photosynthesis be also a significant supplier of chemical energy , fuel many diverse ecosystem .
in this section , - pron - will focus on microbial photosynthesis .
photosynthesis take place in two sequential stage  the light - dependent reaction and the light - independent reaction ( figure eight  .  one  nine ) .
in the light - dependent reaction , energy from sunlight be absorb by pigment molecule in photosynthetic membrane and convert into stored chemical energy .
in the light - independent reaction , the chemical energy produce by the light - dependent reaction be use to drive the assembly of sugar molecule use co two  however , these reaction be still light dependent because the product of the light - dependent reaction necessary for drive - pron - be short - lived .
the light - dependent reaction produce atp and either nadph or nadh to temporarily store energy .
these energy carrier be use in the light - independent reaction to drive the energetically unfavorable process of " fix " inorganic co two in an organic form , sugar .
figure eight  .  one  nine
the light - dependent reaction of photosynthesis ( leave ) convert light energy into chemical energy , form atp and nadph .
these product be use by the light - independent reaction to fix co two , produce organic carbon molecule .
photosynthetic structures in eukaryotes and prokaryotes
in all phototrophic eukaryote , photosynthesis take place inside a chloroplast , an organelle that arise in eukaryote by endosymbiosis of a photosynthetic bacterium ( see unique characteristics of eukaryotic cells ) .
these chloroplast be enclose by a double membrane with inner and outer layer .
within the chloroplast be a third membrane that form stack , disc - shape photosynthetic structure call thylakoid ( figure eight  .  two  zero ) .
a stack of thylakoids be call a granum , and the space surround the granum within the chloroplast be call stroma .
photosynthetic membrane in prokaryote , by contrast , be not organize into distinct membrane - enclose organelle  rather , - pron - be infolded region of the plasma membrane .
in cyanobacteria , for example , these infolded region be also refer to as thylakoid .
in either case , embed within the thylakoid membrane or other photosynthetic bacterial membrane be photosynthetic pigment molecule organize into one or more photosystem , where light energy be actually convert into chemical energy .
photosynthetic pigment within the photosynthetic membrane be organize into photosystem , each of which be compose of a light - harvesting ( antennae ) complex and a reaction center .
the light - harvesting complex consist of chapter eight  microbial metabolism three  four  one multiple protein and associate pigment that each may absorb light energy and , thus , become excited .
this energy be transfer from one pigment molecule to another until eventually ( after about a millionth of a second ) - pron - be deliver to the reaction center .
up to this point , only energy - not electron - have be transfer between molecule .
the reaction center contain a pigment molecule that can undergo oxidation upon excitation , actually give up an electron .
- pron - be at this step in photosynthesis that light energy be convert into an excited electron .
different kind of light - harvest pigment absorb unique pattern of wavelength ( color ) of visible light .
pigment reflect or transmit the wavelength - pron - can not absorb , make - pron - appear the corresponding color .
example of photosynthetic pigment ( molecule use to absorb solar energy ) be bacteriochlorophyll ( green , purple , or red ) , carotenoid ( orange , red , or yellow ) , chlorophyll ( green ) , phycocyanin ( blue ) , and phycoerythrin ( red ) .
by have mixture of pigment , an organism can absorb energy from more wavelength .
because photosynthetic bacteria commonly grow in competition for sunlight , each type of photosynthetic bacteria be optimize for harvest the wavelength of light to which - pron - be commonly expose , lead to stratification of microbial community in aquatic and soil ecosystem by light quality and penetration .
once the light harvest complex transfer the energy to the reaction center , the reaction center deliver - pron - high - energy electron , one by one , to an electron carrier in an electron transport system , and electron transfer through the ets be initiate .
the ets be similar to that use in cellular respiration and be embed within the photosynthetic membrane .
ultimately , the electron be use to produce nadh or nadph .
the electrochemical gradient that form across the photosynthetic membrane be use to generate atp by chemiosmosis through the process of photophosphorylation , another example of oxidative phosphorylation ( figure eight  .  two  one ) .

oxygenic and anoxygenic photosynthesis
for photosynthesis to continue , the electron lose from the reaction center pigment must be replace .
the source of this electron ( h two a ) differentiate the oxygenic photosynthesis of plant and cyanobacteria from anoxygenic photosynthesis carry out by other type of bacterial phototroph ( figure eight  .  two  two ) .
in oxygenic photosynthesis , h two o be split and supply the electron to the reaction center .
because oxygen be generate as a byproduct and be release , this type of photosynthesis be refer to as oxygenic photosynthesis .
however , when other reduce compound serve as the electron donor , oxygen be not generate  these type of photosynthesis be call anoxygenic photosynthesis .
hydrogen sulfide ( h two s ) or thiosulfate ⎛⎝ s two o three two −⎞⎠ can serve as the electron donor , generate elemental sulfur and sulfate ⎛⎝ so four two −⎞⎠ ion , respectively , as a result .
photosystem have be classify into two type 
photosystem i ( psi ) and photosystem ii ( psii )
( figure eight  .  two  three ) .
cyanobacteria and plant chloroplast have both photosystem , whereas anoxygenic photosynthetic bacteria use only one of the photosystem .
both photosystem be excite by light energy simultaneously .
if the cell require both atp and nadph for biosynthesis , then - pron - will carry out noncyclic photophosphorylation .
upon pass of the psii reaction center electron to the ets that connect psii and psi , the lose electron from the psii reaction center be replace by the splitting of water .
the excited psi reaction center electron be use to reduce nadp+ to nadph and be replace by the electron exit the ets .
the flow of electron in this way be call the z - scheme .

only psi be use during cyclic photophosphorylation  the high - energy electron of the psi reaction center be pass to an ets carrier and then ultimately return to the oxidized psi reaction center pigment , thereby reduce - pron - .

light - independent reactions
after the energy from the sun be convert into chemical energy and temporarily store in atp and nadph molecule ( have lifespan of millionth of a second ) , photoautotroph have the fuel need to build multicarbon carbohydrate molecule , which can survive for hundred of million of year , for long - term energy storage .
the carbon come from co two , the gas that be a waste product of cellular respiration .
the calvin - benson cycle ( name for melvin calvin [ one  nine  one  one – one  nine  nine  seven ] and andrew benson [ one  nine  one  seven – two  zero  one  five ] ) , the biochemical pathway use for fixation of co two , be locate within the cytoplasm of photosynthetic bacteria and in the stroma of eukaryotic chloroplast .
the light - independent reaction of the calvin cycle can be organize into three basic stage  fixation , reduction , and regeneration ( see appendix c for a detailed illustration of the calvin cycle ) .

fixation 
the enzyme ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase ( rubisco ) catalyze the addition of a co two to ribulose bisphosphate ( rubp ) .
this result in the production of three  - phosphoglycerate ( three  - pga ) .
 reduction  six molecule of both atp and nadph ( from the light - dependent reaction ) be use to convert three  - pga into glyceraldehyde three  - phosphate ( g three p ) .
some g three p be then use to build glucose .

regeneration  the remain g three p not use to synthesize glucose be use to regenerate rubp , enable the system to continue co two fixation .
three more molecule of atp be use in these regeneration reaction .
the calvin cycle be use extensively by plant and photoautotrophic bacteria , and the enzyme rubisco be say to be the most plentiful enzyme on earth , compose three  zero %– five  zero % of the total soluble protein in plant chloroplasts . [ one ]
however , besides - pron - prevalent use in photoautotroph , the calvin cycle be also use by many nonphotosynthetic chemoautotroph to fix co two .
additionally , other bacteria and archaea use alternative system for co two fixation .
although most bacteria use calvin cycle alternative be chemoautotrophic , certain green sulfur photoautotrophic bacteria have be also show to use an alternative co two fixation pathway .

carbon cycle carbon be one of the most important element to live organism , as show by - pron - abundance and presence in all organic molecule .
the carbon cycle exemplify the connection between organism in various ecosystem .
carbon be exchange between heterotroph and autotroph within and between ecosystem primarily by way of atmospheric co two , a fully oxidize version of carbon that serve as the basic building block that autotroph use to build multicarbon , high - energy organic molecule such as glucose .
photoautotroph and chemoautotroph harness energy from the sun and from inorganic chemical compound , respectively , to covalently bond carbon atom together into reduce organic compound whose energy can be later access through the process of respiration and fermentation ( figure eight  .  two  four ) .
overall , there be a constant exchange of co two between the heterotroph ( which produce co two as a result of respiration or fermentation ) and the autotroph ( which use the co two for fixation ) .

environmental methane accumulation due to methanogenesis be of consequence because - pron - be a strong greenhouse gas , and methanotroph help to reduce atmospheric methane level .

nitrogen cycle
many biological macromolecule , include protein and nucleic acid , contain nitrogen  however , get nitrogen into live organism be difficult .
prokaryote play essential role in the nitrogen cycle ( figure eight  .  two  five ) , transform nitrogen between various form for - pron - own need , benefit other organism indirectly .
plant and phytoplankton can not incorporate nitrogen from the atmosphere ( where - pron - exist as tightly bond , triple covalent n two ) , even though this molecule compose approximately seven  eight % of the atmosphere .
nitrogen enter the live world through freeliving and symbiotic bacteria , which incorporate nitrogen into - pron - macromolecule through specialized biochemical pathway call nitrogen fixation .
cyanobacteria in aquatic ecosystem fix inorganic nitrogen ( from nitrogen gas ) into ammonia ( nh three ) that can be easily incorporate into biological macromolecule .
rhizobium bacteria ( figure eight  .  one ) also fix nitrogen and live symbiotically in the root nodule of legume ( such as bean , peanut , and pea ) , provide - pron - with need organic nitrogen while receive fix carbon as sugar in exchange .
free - living bacteria , such as member of the genus azotobacter , be also able to fix nitrogen .
the nitrogen that enter living system by nitrogen fixation be eventually convert from organic nitrogen back into nitrogen gas by microbe through three step  ammonification , nitrification , and denitrification .
in terrestrial system , three  four  eight chapter eight  microbial metabolism
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five the first step be the ammonification process , in which certain bacteria and fungi convert nitrogenous waste from living animal or from the remain of dead organism into ammonia ( nh three ) .
this ammonia be then oxidize to nitrite ⎛ ⎝ no two − ⎞ ⎠ , then to nitrate ⎛ ⎝ no three − ⎞ ⎠ , by nitrify soil bacteria such as member of the genus nitrosomonas , through the process of nitrification .
last , the process of denitrification occur , whereby soil bacteria , such as member of the genera pseudomonas and clostridium , use nitrate as a terminal electron acceptor in anaerobic respiration , convert - pron - into nitrogen gas that reenter the atmosphere .
a similar process occur in the marine nitrogen cycle , where these three process be perform by marine bacteria and archaea .
human activity release nitrogen into the environment by the use of artificial fertilizer that contain nitrogen and phosphorus compound , which be then wash into lake , river , and stream by surface runoff .
a major effect from fertilizer runoff be saltwater and freshwater eutrophication , in which nutrient runoff cause the overgrowth and subsequent death of aquatic algae , make water source anaerobic and inhospitable for the survival of aquatic organism .

anoxygenic photosynthetic bacteria as well as chemoautotrophic archaea and bacteria use hydrogen sulfide as an electron donor , oxidize - pron - first to elemental sulfur ( s zero ) , then to sulfate ⎛⎝ so four two −⎞⎠ .
this lead to stratification of hydrogen sulfide in soil , with level increase at deep , more anaerobic depth .
many bacteria and plant can use sulfate as a sulfur source .

other biogeochemical cycles
beyond - pron - involvement in the carbon , nitrogen , and sulfur cycle , prokaryote be involve in other biogeochemical cycle as well .
like the carbon , nitrogen , and sulfur cycle , several of these additional biogeochemical cycle , such as the iron ( fe ) , manganese ( mn ) , and chromium ( cr ) cycle , also involve redox chemistry , with prokaryote play role in both oxidation and reduction .
several other element undergo chemical cycle that do not involve redox chemistry .
example of these be phosphorus ( p ) , calcium ( ca ) , and silica ( si ) cycle .
the cycling of these element be particularly important in ocean because large quantity of these element be incorporate into the exoskeleton of marine organism .
these biogeochemical cycle do not involve redox chemistry but instead involve fluctuation in the solubility of compound contain calcium , phosphorous , and silica .
the overgrowth of naturally occur microbial community be typically limit by the availability of nitrogen ( as previously mention ) , phosphorus , and iron .
human activity introduce excessive amount of iron , nitrogen , or phosphorus ( typically from detergent ) may lead to eutrophication .
bioremediation microbial bioremediation leverage microbial metabolism to remove xenobiotic or other pollutant .
xenobiotic be compound synthesize by human and introduce into the environment in much high concentration than would naturally occur .
such environmental contamination may involve adhesive , dye , flame retardant , lubricant , oil and petroleum product , organic solvent , pesticide , and product of the combustion of gasoline and oil .
many xenobiotic resist breakdown , and some accumulate in the food chain after be consume or absorb by fish and wildlife , which , in turn , may be eat by human .
of particular concern be contaminant like polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon ( pah ) , a carcinogenic xenobiotic find in crude oil , and trichloroethylene ( tce ) , a common groundwater contaminant .
bioremediation process can be categorize as in situ or ex situ .
bioremediation conduct at the site of contamination be call in situ bioremediation and do not involve movement of contaminated material .
in contrast , ex situ bioremediation involve the removal of contaminate material from the original site so that - pron - can be treat elsewhere , typically in a large , line pit where condition be optimize for degradation of the contaminant .
some bioremediation process rely on microorganism that be indigenous to the contaminate site or material .
enhance bioremediation technique , which may be apply to either in situ or ex situ processing , involve the addition of nutrient and / or air to encourage the growth of pollution - degrade microbe  - pron - may also involve the addition of non - native microbe know for - pron - ability to degrade contaminant .
for example , certain bacteria of the genera rhodococcus and pseudomonas be know for - pron - ability to degrade many environmental contaminant , include aromatic compound like those find in oil , down to co two .
the gene encode - pron - degradatory enzyme be commonly find on plasmid .
other , like alcanivorax borkumensis , produce surfactant that be useful in the solubilization of the hydrophobic molecule find in oil , make - pron - more accessible to other microbe for degradation .

compare and contrast the benefit of in situ and ex situ bioremediation .

metabolism include chemical reaction that break down complex molecule ( catabolism ) and those that build complex molecule ( anabolism ) .

organisms may be classify accord to - pron - source of carbon .
autotroph convert inorganic carbon dioxide into organic carbon  heterotroph use fix organic carbon compound .
 organisms may also be classify accord to - pron - energy source .
phototroph obtain - pron - energy from light .
chemotroph get - pron - energy from chemical compound .
organotroph use organic molecule , and lithotroph use inorganic chemical .

cellular electron carrier accept high - energy electron from food and later serve as electron donor in subsequent redox reaction .
fad / fadh two , nad+ / nadh , and nadp+ / nadph be important electron carrier .

adenosine triphosphate ( atp ) serve as the energy currency of the cell , safely store chemical energy in - pron - two high - energy phosphate bond for late use to drive process require energy .

enzymes be biological catalyst that increase the rate of chemical reaction inside cell by lower the activation energy require for the reaction to proceed .

in nature , exergonic reaction do not require energy beyond activation energy to proceed , and - pron - release energy .
- pron - may proceed without enzyme , but at a slow rate .
conversely , endergonic reaction require energy beyond activation energy to occur .
in cell , endergonic reaction be couple to exergonic reaction , make the combination energetically favorable .

substrates bind to the enzyme 's active site .
this process typically alter the structure of both the active site and the substrate , favor transition - state formation  this be know as induce fit .

cofactor be inorganic ion that stabilize enzyme conformation and function .
coenzyme be organic molecule require for proper enzyme function and be often derive from vitamin .
an enzyme lack a cofactor or coenzyme be an apoenzyme  an enzyme with a bind cofactor or coenzyme be a holoenzyme .

competitive inhibitor regulate enzyme by bind to an enzyme 's active site , prevent substrate binding .
noncompetitive ( allosteric ) inhibitor bind to allosteric site , induce a conformational change in the enzyme that prevent - pron - from function .
feedback inhibition occur when the product of a metabolic pathway noncompetitively bind to an enzyme early on in the pathway , ultimately prevent the synthesis of the product .
eight  .  two catabolism of carbohydrates

glycolysis be the first step in the breakdown of glucose , result in the formation of atp , which be produce by substrate - level phosphorylation  nadh  and two pyruvate molecule .
glycolysis do not use oxygen and be not oxygen dependent .

after glycolysis , a three - carbon pyruvate be decarboxylate to form a two - carbon acetyl group , couple with the formation of nadh .
the acetyl group be attach to a large carrier compound call coenzyme a . 
after the transition step , coenzyme a transport the two - carbon acetyl to the krebs cycle , where the two carbon enter the cycle .
per turn of the cycle , one acetyl group derive from glycolysis be further oxidize , produce three nadh molecule , one fadh two , and one atp by substrate - level phosphorylation , and release two co two molecule .

the krebs cycle may be use for other purpose .
many of the intermediate be use to synthesize important about / causes - transmission . html .

chapter eight  microbial metabolism three  five  three cellular molecule , include amino acid , chlorophyll , fatty acid , and nucleotide .
eight  .  three
cellular respiration

most atp generate during the cellular respiration of glucose be make by oxidative phosphorylation .

an electron transport system ( ets ) be compose of a series of membrane - associate protein complex and associate mobile accessory electron carrier .
the ets be embed in the cytoplasmic membrane of prokaryote and the inner mitochondrial membrane of eukaryote .

each ets complex have a different redox potential , and electron move from electron carrier with more negative redox potential to those with more positive redox potential .

to carry out aerobic respiration , a cell require oxygen as the final electron acceptor .
a cell also need a complete krebs cycle , an appropriate cytochrome oxidase , and oxygen detoxification enzyme to prevent the harmful effect of oxygen radical produce during aerobic respiration .

organisms perform anaerobic respiration use alternative electron transport system carrier for the ultimate transfer of electron to the final non - oxygen electron acceptor .

microbes show great variation in the composition of - pron - electron transport system , which can be use for diagnostic purpose to help identify certain pathogen .

as electron be pass from nadh and fadh two through an ets , the electron lose energy .
this energy be store through the pumping of h+ across the membrane , generate a proton motive force .

the energy of this proton motive force can be harness by allow hydrogen ion to diffuse back through the membrane by chemiosmosis use atp synthase .
as hydrogen ion diffuse through down - pron - electrochemical gradient , component of atp synthase spin , make atp from adp and pi by oxidative phosphorylation .

aerobic respiration form more atp ( a maximum of three  four atp molecule ) during oxidative phosphorylation than do anaerobic respiration ( between one and three  two atp molecule ) .
eight  .  four fermentation  fermentation use an organic molecule as a final electron acceptor to regenerate nad+ from nadh so that glycolysis can continue .

fermentation do not involve an electron transport system , and no atp be make by the fermentation process directly .
fermenter make very little atp - only two atp molecule per glucose molecule during glycolysis .
 microbial fermentation process have be use for the production of food and pharmaceutical , and for the identification of microbe .

during lactic acid fermentation , pyruvate accepts electron from nadh and be reduce to lactic acid .
microbe perform homolactic fermentation produce only lactic acid as the fermentation product  microbe perform heterolactic fermentation produce a mixture of lactic acid , ethanol and / or acetic acid , and co two .

lactic acid production by the normal microbiota prevent growth of pathogen in certain body region and be important for the health of the gastrointestinal tract .

during ethanol fermentation , pyruvate be first decarboxylated ( release co two ) to acetaldehyde , which then accept electron from nadh , reduce acetaldehyde to ethanol .
ethanol fermentation be use for the production of alcoholic beverage , for make bread product rise , and for biofuel production .
 fermentation product of pathway ( e . g . , propionic acid fermentation ) provide distinctive flavor to food product .
fermentation be use to produce chemical solvent ( acetone - butanol - ethanol fermentation ) and pharmaceutical ( mixed acid fermentation ) .

specific type of microbe may be distinguish by - pron - fermentation pathway and product .
microbes may also be differentiate accord to the substrate - pron - be able to ferment .
eight  .  five catabolism of lipids and proteins

collectively , microbe have the ability to degrade a wide variety of carbon source besides carbohydrate , include lipid and protein .
the catabolic pathway for all of these molecule eventually connect into three  five  four chapter eight 
microbial metabolism
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five glycolysis and the krebs cycle .
 several type of lipid can be microbially degrade .
triglyceride be degrade by extracellular lipase , release fatty acid from the glycerol backbone .
phospholipid be degrade by phospholipase , release fatty acid and the phosphorylate head group from the glycerol backbone .
lipase and phospholipase act as virulence factor for certain pathogenic microbe .

fatty acid can be further degrade inside the cell through β - oxidation , which sequentially remove twocarbon acetyl group from the end of fatty acid chain .

protein degradation involve extracellular protease that degrade large protein into small peptide .
detection of the extracellular protease gelatinase and caseinase can be use to differentiate clinically relevant bacteria .
eight  .  six
photosynthesis  heterotrophs depend on the carbohydrate produce by autotroph , many of which be photosynthetic , convert solar energy into chemical energy .

different photosynthetic organism use different mixture of photosynthetic pigment , which increase the range of the wavelength of light an organism can absorb .

photosystems ( psi and psii )
each contain a light - harvesting complex , compose of multiple protein and associate pigment that absorb light energy .
the light - dependent reaction of photosynthesis convert solar energy into chemical energy , produce atp and nadph or nadh to temporarily store this energy .

in oxygenic photosynthesis , h two o serve as the electron donor to replace the reaction center electron , and oxygen be form as a byproduct .
in anoxygenic photosynthesis , other reduced molecule like h two s or thiosulfate may be use as the electron donor  as such , oxygen be not form as a byproduct .

noncyclic photophosphorylation be use in oxygenic photosynthesis when there be a need for both atp and nadph production .
if a cell 's need for atp outweigh - pron - need for nadph , then - pron - may carry out cyclic photophosphorylation instead , produce only atp .

the light - independent reaction of photosynthesis use the atp and nadph from the light - dependent reaction to fix co two into organic sugar molecule .
eight  .  seven biogeochemical cycles

the recycling of inorganic matter between live organism and - pron - nonlive environment be call a biogeochemical cycle .
microbe play significant role in these cycle .

in the carbon cycle , heterotroph degrade reduce organic molecule to produce carbon dioxide , whereas autotroph fix carbon dioxide to produce organic .
methanogens typically form methane by use co two as a final electron acceptor during anaerobic respiration  methanotroph oxidize the methane , use - pron - as - pron - carbon source .

in the nitrogen cycle , nitrogen - fix bacteria convert atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia ( ammonification ) .
the ammonia can then be oxidize to nitrite and nitrate ( nitrification ) .
nitrate can then be assimilate by plant .
soil bacteria convert nitrate back to nitrogen gas ( denitrification ) .

in sulfur cycling , many anoxygenic photosynthesizer and chemoautotroph use hydrogen sulfide as an electron donor , produce elemental sulfur and then sulfate  sulfate - reduce bacteria and archaea then use sulfate as a final electron acceptor in anaerobic respiration , convert - pron - back to hydrogen sulfide .

human activity that introduce excessive amount of naturally limited nutrient ( like iron , nitrogen , or phosphorus ) to aquatic system may lead to eutrophication .

microbial bioremediation be the use of microbial metabolism to remove or degrade xenobiotic and other environmental contaminant and pollutant .
enhance bioremediation technique may involve the introduction of non - native microbe specifically choose or engineer for - pron - ability to degrade contaminant .

- pron - be all familiar with the slimy layer on a pond surface or that make rock slippery .
these be example of biofilm - microorganism embed in thin layer of matrix material ( figure nine  .  one ) .
biofilm be long consider random assemblage of cell and have little attention from researcher .
recently , progress in visualization and biochemical method have reveal that biofilm be an organized ecosystem within which many cell , usually of different specie of bacteria , fungus , and algae , interact through cell signal and coordinated response .
the biofilm provide a protect environment in harsh condition and aid colonization by microorganism .
biofilm also have clinical importance .
- pron - form on medical device , resist routine cleaning and sterilization , and cause health - acquire infection .
within the body , biofilm form on the tooth as plaque , in the lung of patient with cystic fibrosis , and on the cardiac tissue of patient with endocarditis .
the slime layer help protect the cell from host immune defense and antibiotic treatment .
study biofilm require new approach .
because of the cell ' adhesion property , many of the method for culture and count cell that be explore in this chapter be not easily apply to biofilm .
this be the beginning of a new era of challenge and reward insight into the way that microorganism grow and thrive in nature .

the bacterial cell cycle involve the formation of new cell through the replication of dna and partitioning of cellular component into two daughter cell .
in prokaryote , reproduction be always asexual , although extensive genetic recombination in the form of horizontal gene transfer take place , as will be explore in a different chapter .
most bacteria have a single circular chromosome  however , some exception exist .
for example , borrelia burgdorferi , the causative agent of lyme disease , have a linear chromosome .
binary fission
the most common mechanism of cell replication in bacteria be a process call binary fission , which be depict in figure nine  .  two .
before divide , the cell grow and increase - pron - number of cellular component .
next , the replication of dna start at a location on the circular chromosome call the origin of replication , where the chromosome be attach to the inner cell membrane .
replication continue in opposite direction along the chromosome until the terminus be reach .
the center of the enlarged cell constrict until two daughter cell be form , each offspring receive a complete copy of the parental genome and a division of the cytoplasm ( cytokinesis ) .
this process of cytokinesis and cell division be direct by a protein call ftsz . ftsz assemble into a z ring on the cytoplasmic membrane ( figure nine  .  three ) .
the z ring be anchor by ftsz - bind protein and define the division plane between the two daughter cell .
additional protein require for cell division be add to the z ring to form a structure call the divisome .
the divisome activate to produce a peptidoglycan cell wall and build a septum that divide the two daughter cell .
the daughter cell be separate by the division septum , where all of the cell ' outer layer ( the cell wall and outer membrane , if part one jeni , a two  four  - year - old pregnant woman in - pron - second trimester , visit a clinic with complaint of high fever , three  eight  .  nine ° c ( one  zero  two ° f ) , fatigue , and muscle ache - typical flu - like sign and symptom .
jeni exercise regularly and follow a nutritious diet with emphasis on organic food , include raw milk that - pron - purchase from a local farmer 's market .
all of - pron - immunization be up to date .
however , the health - care provider who see jeni be concern and order a blood sample to be send for testing by the microbiology laboratory .

generation time
in eukaryotic organism , the generation time be the time between the same point of the life cycle in two successive generation .
for example , the typical generation time for the human population be two  five year .
this definition be not practical for bacteria , which may reproduce rapidly or remain dormant for thousand of year .
in prokaryote ( bacteria and archaea ) , the generation time be also call the doubling time and be define as the time - pron - take for the population to double through one round of binary fission .
bacterial double time vary enormously .
whereas escherichia coli can double in as little as two  zero minute under optimal growth condition in the laboratory , bacteria of the same specie may need several day to double in especially harsh environment .
most pathogen grow rapidly , like e . coli , but there be exception .
for example , mycobacterium tuberculosis , the causative agent of tuberculosis , have a generation time of between one  five and two  zero hour .
on the other hand , m . leprae , which cause hansen 's disease ( leprosy ) , grow much more slowly , with a double time of one  four day .
calculate number of cells - pron - be possible to predict the number of cell in a population when - pron - divide by binary fission at a constant rate .
as an example , consider what happen if a single cell divide every three  zero minute for two  four hour .
the diagram in figure nine  .  four show the increase in cell number for the first three generation .
the number of cell increase exponentially and can be express as two n , where n be the number of generation .
if cell divide every three  zero minute , after two  four hour , four  eight division would have take place .
if - pron - apply the formula two n , where n be equal to four  eight , the single cell would give rise to two  four  eight or two  eight  one  ,  four  seven  four  ,  nine  seven  six  ,  seven  one  zero  ,  six  five  six cell at four  eight generation ( two  four hour ) .
when deal with such huge number , - pron - be more practical to use scientific notation .
therefore , - pron - express the number of cell as two  .  eight × one  zero  one  four cell .
in - pron - example , - pron - use one cell as the initial number of cell .
for any number of start cell , the formula be adapt as follow

n zero two n
nn be the number of cell at any generation n , n zero be the initial number of cell , and n be the number of generation .

the parental cell divide and give rise to two daughter cell .
each of the daughter cell , in turn , divide , give a total of four cell in the second generation and eight cell in the third generation .

with a double time of three  zero minute and a start population size of one × one  zero  five cell , how many cell will be present after two hour , assume no cell death ?
the growth curve microorganisms grow in closed culture ( also know as a batch culture ) , in which no nutrient be add and most waste be not remove , follow a reproducible growth pattern refer to as the growth curve .
an example of a batch culture in nature be a pond in which a small number of cell grow in a closed environment .
the culture density be define as the number of cell per unit volume .
in a closed environment , the culture density be also a measure of the number of cell in the population .
infection of the body do not always follow the growth curve , but correlation can exist depend upon the site and type of infection .
when the number of live cell be plot against time , distinct phase can be observe in the curve ( figure nine  .  five ) .
chapter nine
 microbial growth
three  six  five figure nine  .  five
the growth curve of a bacterial culture be represent by the logarithm of the number of live cell plot as a function of time .
the graph can be divide into four phase accord to the slope , each of which match event in the cell .
the four phase be lag , log , stationary , and death .
the lag phase
the beginning of the growth curve represent a small number of cell , refer to as an inoculum , that be add to a fresh culture medium , a nutritional broth that support growth .
the initial phase of the growth curve be call the lag phase , during which cell be gear up for the next phase of growth .
the number of cell do not change during the lag phase  however , cell grow large and be metabolically active , synthesize protein need to grow within the medium .
if any cell be damage or shock during the transfer to the new medium , repair take place during the lag phase .
the duration of the lag phase be determine by many factor , include the specie and genetic make - up of the cell , the composition of the medium , and the size of the original inoculum .
the log phase
in the logarithmic ( log ) growth phase , sometimes call exponential growth phase , the cell be actively divide by binary fission and - pron - number increase exponentially .
for any give bacterial specie , the generation time under specific growth condition ( nutrient , temperature , ph , and so forth ) be genetically determine , and this generation time be call the intrinsic growth rate .
during the log phase , the relationship between time and number of cell be not linear but exponential  however , the growth curve be often plot on a semilogarithmic graph , as show in figure nine  .  six , which give the appearance of a linear relationship .
three  six  six chapter nine  microbial growth
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five figure nine  .  six
both graph illustrate population growth during the log phase for a bacterial sample with an initial population of one cell and a double time of one hour .
( a ) when plot on an arithmetic scale , the growth rate resemble a curve .
( b ) when plot on a semilogarithmic scale ( mean the value on the y - axis be logarithmic ) , the growth rate appear linear .
cell in the log phase show constant growth rate and uniform metabolic activity .
for this reason , cell in the log phase be preferentially use for industrial application and research work .
the log phase be also the stage where bacteria be the most susceptible to the action of disinfectant and common antibiotic that affect protein , dna , and cell - wall synthesis .
stationary phase
as the number of cell increase through the log phase , several factor contribute to a slowing of the growth rate .
waste product accumulate and nutrient be gradually use up .
in addition , gradual depletion of oxygen begin to limit aerobic cell growth .
this combination of unfavorable condition slow and finally stall population growth .
the total number of live cell reach a plateau refer to as the stationary phase ( figure nine  .  five ) .
in this phase , the number of new cell create by cell division be now equivalent to the number of cell die  thus , the total population of living cell be relatively stagnant .
the culture density in a stationary culture be constant .
the culture 's carrying capacity , or maximum culture density , depend on the type of microorganism in the culture and the specific condition of the culture  however , carry capacity be constant for a give organism grow under the same condition .
during the stationary phase , cell switch to a survival mode of metabolism .
as growth slow , so too do the synthesis of peptidoglycan , protein , and nucleic - acid  thus , stationary culture be less susceptible to antibiotic that disrupt these process .
in bacteria capable of produce endospore , many cell undergo sporulation during the stationary phase .
secondary metabolite , include antibiotic , be synthesize in the stationary phase .
in certain pathogenic bacteria , the stationary phase be also associate with the expression of virulence factor , product that contribute to a microbe 's ability to survive , reproduce , and cause disease in a host organism .
for example , quorum sense in staphylococcus aureus initiate the production of enzyme that can break down human tissue and cellular debris , clear the way for bacteria to spread to new tissue where nutrient be more plentiful .
the death phase
as a culture medium accumulate toxic waste and nutrient be exhaust , cell die in great and great number .
soon , the number of die cell exceed the number of divide cell , lead to an exponential decrease in the number of cell ( figure nine  .  five ) .
this be the aptly name death phase , sometimes call the decline phase .
many cell lyse and release nutrient into the medium , allow survive cell to maintain viability and form endospore .
a chapter nine
 microbial growth three  six  seven few cell , the so - call persister , be characterize by a slow metabolic rate .
persister cell be medically important because - pron - be associate with certain chronic infection , such as tuberculosis , that do not respond to antibiotic treatment .
sustain microbial growth
the growth pattern show in figure nine  .  five take place in a closed environment  nutrient be not add and waste and dead cell be not remove .
in many case , though , - pron - be advantageous to maintain cell in the logarithmic phase of growth .
one example be in industry that harvest microbial product .

measurement of bacterial growth estimate the number of bacterial cell in a sample , know as a bacterial count , be a common task perform by microbiologist .

two major approach be use to measure cell number .
the direct method involve count cell , whereas the indirect method depend on the measurement of cell presence or activity without actually count individual cell .
both direct and indirect method have advantage and disadvantage for specific application .

plate count
the viable plate count , or simply plate count , be a count of viable or live cell .
- pron - be base on the principle that viable cell replicate and give rise to visible colony when incubate under suitable condition for the speciman .
the result be usually express as colony - form unit per milliliter ( cfu / ml ) rather than cell per milliliter because more than one cell may have land on the same spot to give rise to a single colony .
furthermore , sample of bacteria that grow in cluster or chain be difficult to disperse and a single colony may represent several cell .
some cell be describe as viable but nonculturable and will not form colony on solid medium .
for all these reason , the viable plate count be consider a low estimate of the actual number of live cell .
these limitation do not detract from the usefulness of the method , which provide estimate of live bacterial number .
microbiologist typically count plate with three  zero – three  zero  zero colony .
sample with too few colony ( < three  zero ) do not give statistically reliable number , and overcrowded plate ( > three  zero  zero colony ) make - pron - difficult to accurately count individual colony .
also , count in this range minimize occurrence of more than one bacterial cell form a single colony .
thus , the calculated cfu be close to the true number of live bacteria in the population .
there be two common approach to inoculate plate for viable count  the pour plate and the spread plate method .
although the final inoculation procedure differ between these two method , - pron - both start with a serial dilution of the culture .
serial dilution
the serial dilution of a culture be an important first step before proceed to either the pour plate or spread plate method .
the goal of the serial dilution process be to obtain plate with cfu in the range of three  zero – three  zero  zero , and the process usually involve several dilution in multiple of one  zero to simplify calculation .
the number of serial dilution be choose accord to a preliminary estimate of the culture density .
figure nine  .  one  one illustrate the serial dilution method .
a fix volume of the original culture , one  .  zero ml , be add to and thoroughly mixed with the first dilution tube solution , which contain nine  .  zero ml of sterile broth .
this step represent a dilution factor of one  zero , or one   one  zero , compare with the original culture .
from this first dilution , the same volume , one  .  zero ml , be withdraw and mix with a fresh tube of nine  .  zero ml of dilution solution .
the dilution factor be now one   one  zero  zero compare with the original culture .
this process continue until a series of dilution be produce that will bracket the desire cell concentration for accurate counting .
from each tube , a sample be plate on solid medium use either the pour plate method ( figure nine  .  one  two ) or the spread plate method ( figure nine  .  one  three ) .
the plate be incubate until colony appear .
two to three plate be usually prepare from each dilution and the number of colony count on each plate be average .
in all case , thorough mixing of sample with the dilution medium ( to ensure the cell distribution in the tube be random ) be paramount to obtain reliable result .

the most probable number
the number of microorganism in dilute sample be usually too low to be detect by the plate count method describe thus far .
for these specimen , microbiologist routinely use the most probable number ( mpn ) method , a statistical procedure for estimating of the number of viable microorganism in a sample .

a typical application of mpn method be the estimation of the number of coliform in a sample of pond water .

indirect cell count
besides direct method of count cell , other method , base on an indirect detection of cell density , be commonly use to estimate and compare cell density in a culture .
the foremost approach be to measure the turbidity ( cloudiness ) of a sample of bacteria in a liquid suspension .
the laboratory instrument use to measure turbidity be call a spectrophotometer ( figure nine  .  one  five ) .
in a spectrophotometer , a light beam be transmit through a bacterial suspension , the light pass through the suspension be measure by a detector , and the amount of light pass through the sample and reach the detector be convert to either percent transmission or a logarithmic value call absorbance ( optical density ) .
as the number of bacteria in a suspension increase , the turbidity also increase and cause less light to reach the detector .
the decrease in light pass through the sample and reach the detector be associate with a decrease in percent transmission and increase in absorbance measure by the spectrophotometer .
measure turbidity be a fast method to estimate cell density as long as there be enough cell in a sample to produce turbidity .
- pron - be possible to correlate turbidity reading to the actual number of cell by perform a viable plate count of sample take from culture have a range of absorbance value .
use these value , a calibration curve be generate by plot turbidity as a function of cell density .
once the calibration curve have be produce , - pron - can be three  seven  four chapter nine

alternative patterns of cell division binary fission be the most common pattern of cell division in prokaryote , but - pron - be not the only one .
other mechanism usually involve asymmetrical division ( as in bud ) or production of spore in aerial filament .
in some cyanobacteria , many nucleoid may accumulate in an enlarged round cell or along a filament , lead to the generation of many new cell at once .
the new cell often split from the parent filament and float away in a chapter nine  microbial growth three  seven  five process call fragmentation ( figure nine  .  one  six ) .
fragmentation be commonly observe in the actinomycetes , a group of gram - positive , anaerobic bacteria commonly find in soil .
another curious example of cell division in prokaryote , reminiscent of live birth in animal , be exhibit by the giant bacterium epulopiscium .
several daughter cell grow fully in the parent cell , which eventually disintegrate , release the new cell to the environment .
other specie may form a long narrow extension at one pole in a process call budding .
the tip of the extension swell and form a small cell , the bud that eventually detach from the parent cell .
budding be most common in yeast ( figure nine  .  one  six ) , but - pron - be also observe in prosthecate bacteria and some cyanobacteria .

biofilm
in nature , microorganism grow mainly in biofilm , complex and dynamic ecosystem that form on a variety of environmental surface , from industrial conduit and water treatment pipeline to rock in river bed .
biofilm be not restrict to solid surface substrate , however .
almost any surface in a liquid environment contain some minimal nutrient will eventually develop a biofilm .
microbial mat that float on water , for example , be biofilm that contain large population of photosynthetic microorganism .
biofilm find in the human mouth may contain hundred of bacterial specie .
regardless of the environment where - pron - occur , biofilm be not random collection of microorganism  rather , - pron - be highly structure community that provide a selective advantage to - pron - constituent microorganism .
biofilm structure observation use confocal microscopy have show that environmental condition influence the overall structure of biofilm .
filamentous biofilm call streamer form in rapidly flow water , such as freshwater stream , eddy , and specially design laboratory flow cell that replicate growth condition in fast - move fluid .
the streamer be three  seven  six chapter nine
