this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five anchor to the substrate by a “ head " and the “ tail
" float downstream in the current .
in still or slow - move water , biofilm mainly assume a mushroom - like shape .
the structure of biofilm may also change with other environmental condition such as nutrient availability .
detailed observation of biofilm under confocal laser and scan electron microscope reveal cluster of microorganism embed in a matrix intersperse with open water channel .
the extracellular matrix consist of extracellular polymeric substance ( eps ) secrete by the organism in the biofilm .
the extracellular matrix represent a large fraction of the biofilm , account for five  zero %– nine  zero % of the total dry mass .
the property of the eps vary accord to the resident organism and environmental condition .
eps be a hydrated gel compose primarily of polysaccharide and contain other macromolecule such as protein , nucleic acid , and lipid .
- pron - play a key role in maintain the integrity and function of the biofilm .
channel in the eps allow movement of nutrient , waste , and gas throughout the biofilm .
this keep the cell hydrate , prevent desiccation .
eps also shelter organism in the biofilm from predation by other microbe or cell ( e . g . , protozoan , white blood cell in the human body ) .
biofilm formation free - float microbial cell that live in an aquatic environment be call planktonic cell .
the formation of a biofilm essentially involve the attachment of planktonic cell to a substrate , where - pron - become sessile ( attach to a surface ) .
this occur in stage , as depict in figure nine  .  one  seven .
the first stage involve the attachment of planktonic cell to a surface coat with a conditioning film of organic material .
at this point , attachment to the substrate be reversible , but as cell express new phenotype that facilitate the formation of eps , - pron - transition from a planktonic to a sessile lifestyle .
the biofilm develop characteristic structure , include an extensive matrix and water channel .
appendage such as fimbriae , pili , and flagella interact with the eps , and microscopy and genetic analysis suggest that such structure be require for the establishment of a mature biofilm .
in the last stage of the biofilm life cycle , cell on the periphery of the biofilm revert to a planktonic lifestyle , slough off the mature biofilm to colonize new site .
this stage be refer to as dispersal .
figure nine  .  one  seven stage in the formation and life cycle of a biofilm .
( credit  modification of work by public library of science and american society for microbiology )
within a biofilm , different specie of microorganism establish metabolic collaboration in which the waste product of one organism become the nutrient for another .
for example , aerobic microorganism consume oxygen , create chapter nine
 microbial growth three  seven  seven anaerobic region that promote the growth of anaerobe .
this occur in many polymicrobial infection that involve both aerobic and anaerobic pathogen .
the mechanism by which cell in a biofilm coordinate - pron - activity in response to environmental stimuli be call quorum sense .
quorum sense - which can occur between cell of different specie within a biofilm - enable microorganism to detect - pron - cell density through the release and binding of small , diffusible molecule call autoinducer .
when the cell population reach a critical threshold ( a quorum ) , these autoinducer initiate a cascade of reaction that activate gene associate with cellular function that be beneficial only when the population reach a critical density .
for example , in some pathogen , synthesis of virulence factor only begin when enough cell be present to overwhelm the immune defense of the host .
although mostly study in bacterial population , quorum sense take place between bacteria and eukaryote and between eukaryotic cell such as the fungus candida albican , a common member of the human microbiota that can cause infection in immunocompromised individual .
the signal molecule in quorum sense belong to two major class .
gram - negative bacteria communicate mainly use n - acylate homoserine lactone , whereas gram - positive bacteria mostly use small peptide ( figure nine  .  one  eight ) .
in all case , the first step in quorum sense consist of the binding of the autoinducer to - pron - specific receptor only when a threshold concentration of signal molecule be reach .
once bind to the receptor take place , a cascade of signal event lead to change in gene expression .
the result be the activation of biological response link to quorum sense , notably an increase in the production of signal molecule - pron - , hence the term autoinducer .
figure nine  .  one  eight short peptide in gram - positive bacteria and n - acetylate homoserine lactone in gram - negative bacteria act as autoinducer in quorum sense and mediate the coordinate response of bacterial cell .
the r side chain of the n - acetylate homoserine lactone be specific for the specie of gram - negative bacteria .
some secreted homoserine lactone be recognize by more than one specie .
biofilms and human health
the human body harbor many type of biofilm , some beneficial and some harmful .
for example , the layer of normal microbiota line the intestinal and respiratory mucosa play a role in ward off infection by pathogen .
however , other biofilm in the body can have a detrimental effect on health .
for example , the plaque that form on tooth be a biofilm that can contribute to dental and periodontal disease .
biofilm can also form in wound , sometimes cause serious infection that can spread .
the bacterium pseudomonas aeruginosa often colonize biofilm in the airway of patient with cystic fibrosis , cause chronic and sometimes fatal infection of the lung .
biofilm can also form on medical device use in or on the body , cause infection in patient with in - dwell catheter , artificial joint , or contact lense .
pathogens embed within biofilm exhibit a high resistance to antibiotic than - pron - free - float counterpart .
several hypothesis have be propose to explain why .
cell in the deep layer of a biofilm be metabolically inactive and may be less susceptible to the action of antibiotic that disrupt metabolic activity .
the eps may also slow the diffusion of antibiotic and antiseptic , prevent - pron - from reach cell in the deep layer of the biofilm .
phenotypic change may also contribute to the increase resistance exhibit by bacterial cell in biofilm .
for example , the increase production of efflux pump , membrane - embed protein that actively extrude antibiotic out of bacterial cell , have be show to be an important mechanism of antibiotic resistance among biofilm - associate bacteria .
finally , biofilm provide an ideal environment for the exchange of extrachromosomal dna , which often three  seven  eight chapter nine  microbial growth

ask most people "
what be the major requirement for life ?
" and the answer be likely to include water and oxygen .
few would argue about the need for water , but what about oxygen ?
can there be life without oxygen ?
the answer be that molecular oxygen ( o two ) be not always need .
the early sign of life be date to a period when condition on earth be highly reduce and free oxygen gas be essentially nonexistent .
only after cyanobacteria start release oxygen as a byproduct of photosynthesis and the capacity of iron in the ocean for take up oxygen be exhaust do oxygen level increase in the atmosphere .
this event , often refer to as the great oxygenation event or the oxygen revolution , cause a massive extinction .
most organism could not survive the powerful oxidative property of reactive oxygen specie ( ros ) , highly unstable ion and molecule derive from partial reduction of oxygen that can damage virtually any macromolecule or structure with which - pron - come in contact .
singlet oxygen ( o two ) ,
superoxide
⎛ ⎝o two −⎞ ⎠ , peroxide ( h two o two ) , hydroxyl radical ( oh ) , and hypochlorite ion ( ocl− ) , the active ingredient of household bleach , be all example of ros .
the organism that be able to detoxify reactive oxygen specie harness the high electronegativity of oxygen to produce free energy for - pron - metabolism and thrive in the new environment .
oxygen requirements of microorganisms many ecosystem be still free of molecular oxygen .
some be find in extreme location , such as deep in the ocean or in earth 's crust  other be part of - pron - everyday landscape , such as marsh , bog , and sewer .
within the body of human and other animal , region with little or no oxygen provide an anaerobic environment for microorganism .

the effect of ph on microbial growth learning objectives

illustrate and briefly describe minimum , optimum , and maximum ph requirement for growth 
identify and describe the different category of microbe with ph requirement for growth 
acidophile , neutrophile , and alkaliphile  give example of microorganism for each category of ph requirement yogurt , pickle , sauerkraut , and lime - season dish all owe - pron - tangy taste to a high acid content ( figure nine  .  two  five ) .
recall that acidity be a function of the concentration of hydrogen ion [ h+ ] and be measure as ph .
environment with ph value below seven  .  zero be consider acidic , whereas those with ph value above seven  .  zero be consider basic .
extreme ph affect the structure of all macromolecule .
the hydrogen bond hold together strand of dna break up at high ph .
lipid be hydrolyze by an extremely basic ph .
the proton motive force responsible for production of atp in cellular respiration depend on the concentration gradient of h+ across the plasma membrane ( see cellular respiration ) .
if h+ ion be neutralize by hydroxide ion , the concentration gradient collapse and impair energy production .
but the component most sensitive to ph in the cell be - pron - workhorse , the protein .
moderate change in ph modify the ionization of amino - acid functional group and disrupt hydrogen bonding , which , in turn , promote change in the folding of the molecule , promote denaturation and destroy activity .

the optimum growth ph be the most favorable ph for the growth of an organism .
the low ph value that anph .
organism can tolerate be call the minimum growth ph and the high ph be the maximum growth ph .
these value can cover a wide range , which be important for the preservation of food and to microorganism ' survival in the stomach .
for example , the optimum growth ph of salmonella spp . be seven  .  zero – seven  .  five , but the minimum growth ph be close to four  .  two .
most bacteria be neutrophile , mean - pron - grow optimally at a ph within one or two ph unit of the neutral ph of seven ( see figure nine  .  two  six ) .
most familiar bacteria , like escherichia coli , staphylococci , and salmonella spp .
be neutrophile and do not fare well in the acidic ph of the stomach .
however , there be pathogenic strain of e . coli , s . typhi , and other specie of intestinal pathogen that be much more resistant to stomach acid .
in comparison , fungi thrive at slightly acidic ph value of five  .  zero – six  .  zero .
microorganism that grow optimally at ph less than five  .  five  five be call acidophile .
for example , the sulfur - oxidize sulfolobus spp .
isolate from sulfur mud field and hot spring in yellowstone national park be extreme acidophile .
these archaea survive at ph value of two  .  five – three  .  five .
specie of the archaean genus ferroplasma live in acid mine drainage at ph value of zero – two  .  nine .
lactobacillus bacteria , which be an important part of the normal microbiota of the vagina , can tolerate acidic environment at ph value three  .  five – six  .  eight and also contribute to the acidity of the vagina ( ph of four , except at the onset of menstruation ) through - pron - metabolic production of lactic acid .
the vagina 's acidity play an important role in inhibit other microbe that be less tolerant of acidity .
acidophilic microorganism display a number of adaptation to survive in strong acidic environment .
for example , protein show increase negative surface charge that stabilize - pron - at low ph .
pump actively eject h+ ion out of the cell .
the change in the composition of membrane phospholipid probably reflect the need to maintain membrane fluidity at low ph .

life in extreme environment raise fascinating question about the adaptation of macromolecule and metabolic process .
very low temperature affect cell in many way .
membrane lose - pron - fluidity and be damage by ice crystal formation .
chemical reaction and diffusion slow considerably .
protein become too rigid to catalyze reaction and may undergo denaturation .
at the opposite end of the temperature spectrum , heat denature protein and nucleic acid .
increase fluidity impair metabolic process in membrane .
some of the practical application of the destructive effect of heat on microbe be sterilization by steam , pasteurization , and incineration of inoculate loop .
protein in psychrophile be , in general , rich in hydrophobic residue , display an increase in flexibility , and have a low number of secondary stabilize bond when compare with homologous protein from mesophile .
antifreeze protein and solute that decrease the freezing temperature of the cytoplasm be common .
the lipid in the membrane tend to be unsaturated to increase fluidity .
growth rate be much slow than those encounter at moderate temperature .
under appropriate condition , mesophile and even thermophile can survive freeze .

feed the world … and the world 's algae artificial fertilizer have become an important tool in food production around the world .
- pron - be responsible for many of the gain of the so - call green revolution of the two  zero th century , which have allow the planet to feed many of - pron - more than seven billion people .
artificial fertilizer provide nitrogen and phosphorus , key limit nutrient , to crop plant , remove the normal barrier that would otherwise limit the rate of growth .
thus , fertilize crop grow much faster , and farm that use fertilizer produce high crop yield .
however , careless use and overuse of artificial fertilizer have be demonstrate to have significant negative impact on aquatic ecosystem , both freshwater and marine .
fertilizer that be apply at inappropriate time or in too - large quantity allow nitrogen and phosphorus compound to escape use by crop plant and enter drainage system .
inappropriate use of fertilizer in residential setting can also contribute to nutrient load , which find - pron - way to lake and coastal marine ecosystem .
as water warm and nutrient be plentiful , microscopic algae bloom , often change the color of the water because of the high cell density .
most algal bloom be not directly harmful to human or wildlife  however , - pron - can cause harm indirectly .
as the algal population expand and then die , - pron - provide a large increase in organic matter to the bacteria that live in deep water .
with this large supply of nutrient , the population of nonphotosynthetic microorganism explode , consume available oxygen and create " dead zone " where animal life have virtually disappear .
depletion of oxygen in the water be not the only damaging consequence of some algal bloom .
the algae that produce red tide in the gulf of mexico , karenia brevi , secrete potent toxin that can kill fish and other organism and also accumulate in shellfish .
consumption of contaminate shellfish can cause severe neurological and gastrointestinal symptom in human .
shellfish bed must be regularly monitor for the presence of the toxin , and harvest be often shut down when - pron - be present , incur economic cost to the fishery .
cyanobacteria , which can form bloom in marine and freshwater ecosystem , produce toxin call eye on ethics chapter nine

recur cyanobacterial algal bloom in lake erie ( figure nine  .  three  zero ) have force municipality to issue drink water ban for day at a time because of unacceptable toxin level .
this be just a small sampling of the negative consequence of algal bloom , red tide , and dead zone .
yet the benefit of crop fertilizer - the main cause of such bloom - be difficult to dispute .
there be no easy solution to this dilemma , as a ban on fertilizer be not politically or economically feasible .
in lieu of this , - pron - must advocate for responsible use and regulation in agricultural and residential contexts , as well as the restoration of wetland , which can absorb excess fertilizer before - pron - reach lake and ocean .

osmotic and barometric pressure
most natural environment tend to have low solute concentration than the cytoplasm of most microorganism .
rigid cell wall protect the cell from burst in a dilute environment .
not much protection be available against high osmotic pressure .
in this case , water , follow - pron - concentration gradient , flow out of the cell .
this result in plasmolysis ( the shrinking of the protoplasm away from the intact cell wall ) and cell death .
this fact explain why brine and layer meat and fish in salt be time - honor method of preserve food .
microorganisms call halophile ( " salt loving " ) actually require high salt concentration for growth .
these organism be find in marine environment where salt concentration hover at three  .  five % .
extreme halophilic microorganism , such as the red alga dunaliella salina and the archaeal specie halobacterium in figure nine  .  three  one , grow in hypersaline lake such as the great salt lake , which be three  .  five – eight time salty than the ocean , and the dead sea , which be one  zero time salty than the ocean .

microorganism depend on available water to grow .

bacteria require high aw ( zero  .  nine  seven – zero  .  nine  nine ) , whereas fungi can tolerate dry environment  for example , the range of aw for growth of aspergillus spp .
be zero  .  eight – zero  .  seven  five .

light photoautotrophs , such as cyanobacteria or green sulfur bacteria , and photoheterotroph , such as purple nonsulfur bacteria , depend on sufficient light intensity at the wavelength absorb by - pron - pigment to grow and multiply .

how microbes grow 
most bacterial cell divide by binary fission .
generation time in bacterial growth be define as the double time of the population .

cell in a closed system follow a pattern of growth with four phase  lag , logarithmic ( exponential ) , stationary , and death .

cell can be count by direct viable cell count .
the pour plate and spread plate method be use to plate serial dilution into or onto , respectively , agar to allow counting of viable cell that give rise to colonyforme unit .
membrane filtration be use to count live cell in dilute solution .
the most probable cell number ( mpn ) method allow estimation of cell number in culture without use solid medium .

indirect method can be use to estimate culture density by measure turbidity of a culture or live cell density by measure metabolic activity .

other pattern of cell division include multiple nucleoid formation in cell  asymmetric division , as in budding  and the formation of hypha and terminal spore .

biofilms be community of microorganism enmesh in a matrix of extracellular polymeric substance .
the formation of a biofilm occur when planktonic cell attach to a substrate and become sessile .
cell in biofilm coordinate - pron - activity by communicate through quorum sense .

biofilms be commonly find on surface in nature and in the human body , where - pron - may be beneficial or cause severe infection .
pathogen associate with biofilm be often more resistant to antibiotic and disinfectant .
nine  .  two oxygen requirements for microbial growth

aerobic and anaerobic environment can be find in diverse niche throughout nature , include different site within and on the human body .

microorganism vary in - pron - requirement for molecular oxygen .
obligate aerobe depend on aerobic respiration and use oxygen as a terminal electron acceptor .
- pron - can not grow without oxygen .
 obligate anaerobe can not grow in the presence of oxygen .
- pron - depend on fermentation and anaerobic respiration use a final electron acceptor other than oxygen .

facultative anaerobe show well growth in the presence of oxygen but will also grow without - pron - .
chapter nine
 microbial growth three  nine  seven

although aerotolerant anaerobe do not perform aerobic respiration , - pron - can grow in the presence of oxygen .
most aerotolerant anaerobe test negative for the enzyme catalase .

microaerophiles need oxygen to grow , albeit at a low concentration than two  one % oxygen in air .

optimum oxygen concentration for an organism be the oxygen level that promote the fast growth rate .
the minimum permissive oxygen concentration and the maximum permissive oxygen concentration be , respectively , the low and the high oxygen level that the organism will tolerate .

peroxidase , superoxide dismutase , and catalase be the main enzyme involve in the detoxification of the reactive oxygen specie .
superoxide dismutase be usually present in a cell that can tolerate oxygen .
all three enzyme be usually detectable in cell that perform aerobic respiration and produce more ros .

a capnophile be an organism that require a high than atmospheric concentration of co two to grow .
nine  .  three
the effect of ph on microbial growth 
bacteria be generally neutrophile .
- pron - grow good at neutral ph close to seven  .  zero .

acidophile grow optimally at a ph near three  .  zero .
alkaliphile be organism that grow optimally between a ph of eight and one  zero  .  five .
extreme acidophile and alkaliphile grow slowly or not at all near neutral ph .

microorganism grow good at - pron - optimum growth ph .
growth occur slowly or not at all below the minimum growth ph and above the maximum growth ph .
nine  .  four temperature and microbial growth  microorganisms thrive at a wide range of temperature  - pron - have colonize different natural environment and have adapt to extreme temperature .
both extreme cold and hot temperature require evolutionary adjustment to macromolecule and biological process .

psychrophile grow good in the temperature range of zero – one  five ° c whereas psychrotroph thrive between four ° c and two  five ° c .

mesophile grow good at moderate temperature in the range of two  zero ° c to about four  five ° c .
pathogen be usually mesophile .

thermophiles and hyperthemophile be adapt to life at temperature above five  zero ° c .

adaptation to cold and hot temperature require change in the composition of membrane lipid and protein .
nine  .  five other environmental conditions that affect growth  halophiles require high salt concentration in the medium , whereas halotolerant organism can grow and multiply in the presence of high salt but do not require - pron - for growth .

halotolerant pathogen be an important source of foodborne illness because - pron - contaminate food preserve in salt .
 photosynthetic bacteria depend on visible light for energy .

most bacteria , with few exception , require high moisture to grow .

chemically define medium contain only chemically know component .
 selective medium favor the growth of some microorganism while inhibit other .

enrich medium contain add essential nutrient a specific organism need to grow  differential medium help distinguish bacteria by the color of the colony or the change in the medium .

use microbiology to discover the secrets of life one  zero  .  two structure and function of dna one  zero  .  three structure and function of rna one  zero  .  four structure and function of cellular genomes introduction children inherit some characteristic from each parent .
sibling typically look similar to each other , but not exactly the same - except in the case of identical twin .
how can - pron - explain these phenomenon ?
the answer lie in heredity ( the transmission of trait from one generation to the next ) and genetic ( the science of heredity ) .
because human reproduce sexually , five  zero % of a child 's gene come from the mother 's egg cell and the remain five  zero % from the father 's sperm cell .
sperm and egg be form through the process of meiosis , where dna recombination occur .
thus , there be no predictable pattern as to which five  zero % come from which parent .
thus , sibling have only some gene , and - pron - associate characteristic , in common .
identical twin be the exception , because - pron - be genetically identical .
genetic difference among related microbe also dictate many observed biochemical and virulence difference .
for example , some strain of the bacterium escherichia coli be harmless member of the normal microbiota in the human gastrointestinal tract .
other strain of the same specie have gene that give - pron - the ability to cause disease .
in bacteria , such gene be not inherit via sexual reproduction , as in human .
often , - pron - be transfer via plasmid , small circular piece of double - strand dna that can be exchange between prokaryote .

the chromosomal theory of inheritance mendel carry out - pron - experiment long before chromosome be visualize under a microscope .
however , with the improvement of microscopic technique during the late one  eight  zero  zero , cell biologist could stain and visualize subcellular structure with dye and observe - pron - action during meiosis .
- pron - be able to observe chromosome replicate , condense from an amorphous nuclear mass into distinct x - shaped body and migrate to separate cellular pole .
the speculation that chromosome may be the key to understand heredity lead several scientist to examine mendel 's publication and re - evaluate - pron - model in term of the behavior of chromosome during mitosis and meiosis .
in one  nine  zero  two , theodor boveri ( one  eight  six  two – one  nine  one  five ) observe that in sea urchin , nuclear component ( chromosome ) determine proper embryonic development .
that same year , walter sutton ( one  eight  seven  seven – one  nine  one  six ) observe the separation of chromosome into daughter cell during meiosis .
together , these observation lead to the development of the chromosomal theory of inheritance , which identify chromosome as the genetic material responsible for mendelian inheritance .
despite compelling correlation between the behavior of chromosome during meiosis and mendel 's observation , the chromosomal theory of inheritance be propose long before there be any direct evidence that trait be carry on chromosome .
thomas hunt morgan ( one  eight  six  six – one  nine  four  five ) and - pron - colleague spend several year carry out cross with the fruit fly , drosophila melanogaster .
- pron - perform meticulous microscopic observation of fly chromosome and correlate these observation with result fly characteristic .
- pron - work provide the first experimental evidence to support the chromosomal theory of inheritance in the early one  nine  zero  zero .
in one  nine  one  five , morgan and - pron - “
fly room
" colleague publish the mechanism of mendelian heredity , which identify chromosome as the cellular structure responsible for heredity .
for - pron - many significant contribution to genetic , morgan receive the nobel prize in physiology or medicine in one  nine  three  three .
in the late one  nine  two  zero , barbara mcclintock ( one  nine  zero  two – one  nine  nine  two ) develop chromosomal staining technique to visualize and differentiate between the different chromosome of maize ( corn ) .
in the one  nine  four  zero and one  nine  five  zero , - pron - identify a breakage event on chromosome nine , which - pron - name the dissociation locus ( ds ) .
ds could change position within the chromosome .
- pron - also identify an activator locus ( ac ) .

at first , mcclintock 's finding of these jump gene , which - pron - now call transposon , be not accept by the scientific community .

today , - pron - know that transposon be mobile segment of dna that can move within the genome of an organism .
- pron - can regulate gene expression , protein expression , and virulence ( ability to cause disease ) .
microbes and viruses in genetic research microbiologists have also play a crucial part in - pron - understanding of genetic .
experimental organism such as mendel 's garden pea , morgan 's fruit fly , and mcclintock 's corn have already be use successfully to pave the way for an understanding of genetic .
however , microbe and virus be ( and still be ) excellent model system for the study of genetic because , unlike pea , fruit fly , and corn , - pron - be propagate more easily in the laboratory , grow to high population density in a small amount of space and in a short time .
in addition , because of - pron - structural simplicity , microbe and virus be more readily manipulate genetically .
fortunately , despite significant difference in size , structure , reproduction strategy , and other biological characteristic , there be biochemical unity among all organism  - pron - have in common the same underlie molecule responsible for heredity and the use of genetic material to give cell - pron - vary characteristic .
in the word of french scientist jacques monod , “ what be true for e . coli be also true for the elephant , " mean that the biochemistry of life have be maintain throughout evolution and be share in all form of life , from simple unicellular organism to large , complex organism .
this biochemical continuity make microbe excellent model to use for genetic study .
in a clever set of experiment in the one  nine  three  zero and one  nine  four  zero , german scientist joachim hämmerling ( one  nine  zero  one – one  nine  eight  zero ) , use the single - celle alga acetabularia as a microbial model , establish that the genetic information in a eukaryotic cell be house within the nucleus .

beadle and tatum 's experiment involve the mating of irradiated and nonirradiated mold spore .

this lead to the so - call one gene – one enzyme hypothesis , which suggest that each gene encode one enzyme .
subsequent knowledge about the process of transcription and translation lead scientist to revise this to the " one gene – one polypeptide " hypothesis .
although there be some gene that do not encode polypeptide ( but rather encode for transfer rna [ trnas ] or ribosomal rnas [ rrnas ] , which - pron - will discuss later ) , the one gene – one enzyme hypothesis be true in many case , especially in microbe .
beadle and tatum 's discovery of the link between gene and correspond characteristic earn - pron - the one  nine  five  eight nobel prize in physiology and medicine and have since become the basis for modern molecular genetic .

griffith 's transformation experiment british bacteriologist frederick griffith ( one  eight  seven  nine – one  nine  four  one ) be perhaps the first person to show that hereditary information could be transfer from one cell to another “ horizontally
" ( between member of the same generation ) , rather than “ vertically " ( from parent to offspring ) .
in one  nine  two  eight , - pron - report the first demonstration of bacterial transformation , a process in which external dna be take up by a cell , thereby change - pron - characteristics . [ three ]
- pron - be work with two strain of streptococcus pneumoniae , a bacterium that cause pneumonia  a rough ( r ) strain and a smooth ( s ) strain .
the r strain be nonpathogenic and lack a capsule on - pron - outer surface  as a result , colony from the r strain appear rough when grow on plate .
the s strain be pathogenic and have a capsule outside - pron - cell wall , allow - pron - to escape phagocytosis by the host immune system .
the capsule cause colony from the s strain to appear smooth when grow on plate .
in a series of experiment , griffith analyze the effect of live r , live s , and heat - kill s strain of s . pneumoniae on live mouse ( figure one  zero  .  seven ) .
when mouse be inject with the live s strain , the mouse die .
when - pron - inject the mouse with the live r strain or the heat - kill s strain , the mouse survive .
but when - pron - inject the mouse with a mixture of live r strain and heat - kill s strain , the mouse die .
upon isolate the live bacteria from the dead mouse , - pron - only recover the s strain of bacteria .
when - pron - then inject this isolate s strain into fresh mouse , the mouse die .
griffith conclude that something have pass from the heat - kill s strain into the live r strain and “ transform " - pron - into the pathogenic s strain  - pron - call this the “ transform principle .
"
these experiment be now famously know as griffith 's transformation experiment .

hershey and chase 's proof of dna as genetic material alfred hershey and martha chase perform - pron - own experiment in one  nine  five  two and be able to provide confirmatory evidence that dna , not protein , be the genetic material ( figure one  zero  .  nine  ) . [ four ]
hershey and chase be study a bacteriophage , a virus that infect bacteria .
virus typically have a simple structure  a protein coat , call the capsid , and a nucleic acid core that contain the genetic material , either dna or rna ( see viruses ) .
the particular bacteriophage - pron - be study be the t two bacteriophage , which infect e . coli cell .
as - pron - now know today , t two attache to the surface of the bacterial cell
and then - pron - inject - pron - nucleic acid inside the cell .
the phage dna make multiple copy of - pron - use the host machinery , and eventually the host cell burst , release a large number of bacteriophage .
hershey and chase label the protein coat in one batch of phage use radioactive sulfur , three  five s , because sulfur be find in the amino acid methionine and cysteine but not in nucleic acid .
- pron - label the dna in another batch use radioactive phosphorus , three  two p , because phosphorus be find in dna and rna but not typically in protein .
each batch of phage be allow to infect the cell separately .
after infection , hershey and chase put each phage bacterial suspension in a blender , which detach the phage coat from the host cell , and spin down the result suspension in a centrifuge .
the heavy bacterial cell settle down and form a pellet , whereas the light phage particle stay in the supernatant .
in the tube with the protein label , the radioactivity remain only in the supernatant .
in the tube with the dna label , the radioactivity be detect only in the bacterial cell .
hershey and chase conclude that - pron - be the phage dna that be inject into the cell that carry the information to produce more phage particle , thus prove that dna , not protein , be the source of the genetic material .
as a result of - pron - work , the scientific community more broadly accept dna as the molecule responsible for heredity .

in microbial metabolism , - pron - discuss three class of macromolecule  protein , lipid , and carbohydrate .
in this chapter , - pron - will discuss a fourth class of macromolecule  nucleic acid .
like other macromolecule , nucleic acid be compose of monomer , call nucleotide , which be polymerize to form large strand .
each nucleic acid strand contain certain nucleotide that appear in a certain order within the strand , call - pron - base sequence .
the base sequence of deoxyribonucleic acid ( dna ) be responsible for carry and retain the hereditary information in a cell .
in mechanisms of microbial genetics , - pron - will discuss in detail the way in which dna use - pron - own base sequence to direct - pron - own synthesis , as well as the synthesis of rna and protein , which , in turn , give rise to product with diverse structure and function .
in this section , - pron - will discuss the basic structure and function of dna .
dna nucleotides
the building block of nucleic acid be nucleotide .
nucleotide that compose dna be call deoxyribonucleotide .
the three component of a deoxyribonucleotide be a five - carbon sugar call deoxyribose , a phosphate group , and a nitrogenous base , a nitrogen - contain ring structure that be responsible for complementary base pair between nucleic acid strand ( figure one  zero  .  one  one ) .
the carbon atom of the five - carbon deoxyribose be number one ʹ , two ʹ , three ʹ , four ʹ , and five ʹ ( one ʹ be read as “ one prime " ) .

individual nucleoside triphosphate combine with each other by covalent bond know as five ʹ -  three ʹ phosphodiest bond , or linkage
whereby the phosphate group attach to the five ʹ carbon of the sugar of one nucleotide bond to the hydroxyl group of the three ʹ carbon of the sugar of the next nucleotide .
phosphodiester bonding between nucleotide form the sugar - phosphate backbone , the alternate sugar - phosphate structure compose the framework of a nucleic acid strand ( figure one  zero  .  one  three ) .
during the polymerization process , deoxynucleotide triphosphate ( dntp ) be use .
to construct the sugar - phosphate backbone , the two terminal phosphate be release from the dntp as a pyrophosphate .
the result strand of nucleic acid have a free phosphate group at the five ʹ carbon end and a free hydroxyl group at the three ʹ carbon end .
the two unused phosphate group from the nucleotide triphosphate be release as pyrophosphate during phosphodiest bond formation .
pyrophosphate be subsequently hydrolyze , release the energy use to drive nucleotide polymerization .

which scientist be give most of the credit for describe the molecular structure of dna ?
dna structure watson and crick propose that dna be make up of two strand that be twist around each other to form a righthande helix .
the two dna strand be antiparallel , such that the three ʹ end of one strand face the five ʹ end of the other ( figure one  zero  .  one  six ) .
the three ʹ end of each strand have a free hydroxyl group , while the five ʹ end of each strand have a free phosphate group .
the sugar and phosphate of the polymerized nucleotide form the backbone of the structure , whereas the nitrogenous basis be stack inside .
these nitrogenous basis on the interior of the molecule interact with each other , base pairing .
analysis of the diffraction pattern of dna have determine that there be approximately one  zero basis per turn in dna .
the asymmetrical spacing of the sugar - phosphate backbone generate major groove ( where the backbone be far apart ) and minor groove ( where the backbone be close together )
( figure one  zero  .  one  six ) .
these groove be location where protein can bind to dna .
the binding of these protein can alter the structure of dna , regulate replication , or regulate transcription of dna into rna .

one  zero  .  one  six watson and crick propose the double helix model for dna .
( a )
the sugar - phosphate backbone be on the outside of the double helix and purine and pyrimidine form the “ rung " of the dna helix ladder .
( b )
the two dna strand be antiparallel to each other .
( c )
the direction of each strand be identify by number the carbon ( one through five ) in each sugar molecule .
the five ʹ end be the one where carbon # five be not bind to another nucleotide  the three ʹ end be the one where carbon # three be not bind to another nucleotide .
base pairing take place between a purine and pyrimidine .
in dna , adenine ( a ) and thymine ( t ) be complementary base pair , and cytosine ( c ) and guanine ( g ) be also complementary base pair , explain chargaff 's rule ( figure one  zero  .  one  seven ) .
the base pair be stabilize by hydrogen bond  adenine and thymine form two hydrogen bond between - pron - , whereas cytosine and guanine form three hydrogen bond between - pron - .
figure one  zero  .  one  seven hydrogen bond form between complementary nitrogenous basis on the interior of dna .
in the laboratory , expose the two dna strand of the double helix to high temperature or to certain chemical can break the hydrogen bond between complementary basis , thus separate the strand into two separate single strand of dna ( single - strand dna [ ssdna ] ) .
this process be call dna denaturation and be analogous to protein denaturation , as describe in proteins .
the ssdna strand can also be put back together as double - strand dna ( dsdna ) , through reannealing or renature by cool or remove the chemical denaturant , allow these chapter one  zero  biochemistry of the genome four  two  three hydrogen bond to reform .
the ability to artificially manipulate dna in this way be the basis for several important technique in biotechnology ( figure one  zero  .  one  eight ) .
because of the additional hydrogen bonding between the c = g base pair , dna with a high gc content be more difficult to denature than dna with a low gc content .

in the laboratory , the double helix can be denature to single - strand dna through exposure to heat or chemical , and then renature through cooling or removal of chemical denaturant to allow the dna strand to reanneal .

dna function dna store the information need to build and control the cell .
the transmission of this information from mother to daughter cell be call vertical gene transfer and - pron - occur through the process of dna replication .
dna be replicate when a cell make a duplicate copy of - pron - dna , then the cell divide , result in the correct distribution of one dna copy to each result cell .
dna can also be enzymatically degrade and use as a source of nucleoside and nucleotide for the cell .
unlike other macromolecule , dna do not serve a structural role in cell .

historically , woman have be underrepresented in the science and in medicine , and often - pron - pioneering contribution have go relatively unnoticed .
for example , although rosalind franklin perform the x - ray diffraction study demonstrate the double helical structure of dna , - pron - be watson and crick who become famous for this discovery , build on - pron - datum .
there still remain great controversy over whether - pron - acquisition of - pron - datum be appropriate and whether personality conflict and gender bias contribute to the delayed recognition of - pron - significant contribution .
similarly , barbara mcclintock do pioneer work in maize ( corn ) genetic from the one  nine  three  zero s through one  nine  five  zero , discover transposon ( jump gene ) , but - pron - be not recognize until much later , receive a nobel prize in physiology or medicine in one  nine  eight  three ( figure one  zero  .  one  nine ) .
today , woman still remain underrepresented in many field of science and medicine .
while more than half of the undergraduate degree in science be award to woman , only four  six % of doctoral degree in science be award to woman .
in academia , the number of woman at each level of career advancement continue to decrease , with woman hold less than one - third of the position of ph . d . - level scientist in tenure - track position , and less than one - quarter of the full professorship at four  - year college and universities . [ one  one ]
even in the health profession , like nearly all other field , woman be often underrepresented in many medical career and earn significantly less than - pron - male counterpart , as show in a two  zero  one  three study publish by the journal of the american medical association . [ one  two ]
why do such disparity continue to exist and how do - pron - break these cycle ?
the situation be complex and likely result from the combination of various factor , include how society condition the behavior of girl from a young age and support - pron - interest , both professionally and personally .
some have suggest that woman do not belong in the laboratory , include nobel prize winner tim hunt , whose two  zero  one  five public comment suggest that woman be too emotional for science[ one  three ] be meet with widespread condemnation .
perhaps girl should be support more from a young age in the area of science and math ( figure one  zero  .  one  nine ) .
science , technology , engineering , and mathematic ( stem ) program sponsor by the american association of university women ( aauw ) [ one  four ] and national aeronautics and space administration ( nasa ) [ one  five ] be excellent example of program that offer such support .
contribution by woman in science should be make known more widely to the public , and marketing target to young girl should include more image of historically and professionally successful female scientist and medical professional , encourage all bright young mind , include girl and woman , to pursue career in science and medicine .

explain how rna can serve as hereditary information structurally speak , ribonucleic acid ( rna ) , be quite similar to dna .
however , whereas dna molecule be typically long and double strand , rna molecule be much short and be typically single strand .
rna molecule perform a variety of role in the cell but be mainly involve in the process of protein synthesis ( translation ) and - pron - regulation .
rna structure rna be typically single strand and be make of ribonucleotide that be link by phosphodiest bond .
a ribonucleotide in the rna chain contain ribose ( the pentose sugar ) , one of the four nitrogenous basis ( a , u , g , and c ) , and a phosphate group .
the subtle structural difference between the sugar give dna add stability , make dna more suitable for storage of genetic information , whereas the relative instability of rna make - pron - more suitable for - pron - more short - term function .
the rna - specific pyrimidine uracil form a complementary base pair with adenine and be use instead of the thymine use in dna .
even though rna be single strand , most type of rna molecule show extensive intramolecular base pair between complementary sequence within the rna strand , create a predictable three - dimensional structure essential for - pron - function ( figure one  zero  .  two  zero and figure one  zero  .  two  one ) .

thus far , - pron - have discuss the structure and function of individual piece of dna and rna .
in this section , - pron - will discuss how all of an organism 's genetic material - collectively refer to as - pron - genome - be organize inside of the cell .
since an organism 's genetic to a large extent dictate - pron - characteristic , - pron - should not be surprising that organism differ in the arrangement of - pron - dna and rna .
genotype versus phenotype
all cellular activity be encode within a cell 's dna .
the sequence of basis within a dna molecule represent the genetic information of the cell .
segment of dna molecule be call gene , and individual gene contain the instructional code necessary for synthesize various protein , enzyme , or stable rna molecule .
the full collection of gene that a cell contain within - pron - genome be call - pron - genotype .
however , a cell do not express all of - pron - gene simultaneously .
instead , - pron - turn on ( express ) or turn off certain gene when necessary .
the set of gene be express at any give point in time determine the cell 's activity and - pron - observable characteristic , refer to as - pron - phenotype .
gene that be always express be know as constitutive gene  some constitutive gene be know as housekeep gene because - pron - be necessary for the basic function of the cell .
while the genotype of a cell remain constant , the phenotype may change in response to environmental signal ( e . g . , change in temperature or nutrient availability ) that affect which nonconstitutive gene be express .
for example , the oral bacterium streptococcus mutan produce a sticky slime layer that allow - pron - to adhere to tooth , form dental plaque  however , the gene that control the production of the slime layer be only express in the presence of sucrose ( table sugar ) .
thus , while the genotype of s . mutan be constant , - pron - phenotype change depend on the presence and absence of sugar in - pron - environment .
temperature can also regulate gene expression .
for example , the gram - negative bacterium serratia marcescen , a pathogen frequently associate with hospital - acquire infection , produce a red pigment at two  eight ° c but not at three  seven ° c , the normal internal temperature of the human body ( figure one  zero  .  two  four ) .

( credit  modification of work by ann auman ) organization of genetic material
the vast majority of an organism 's genome be organize into the cell 's chromosome , which be discrete dna structure within cell that control cellular activity .
recall that while eukaryotic chromosome be house in the membrane - bind nucleus , most prokaryote contain a single , circular chromosome that be find in an area of the cytoplasm call the nucleoid ( see unique characteristics of prokaryotic cells ) .
a chromosome may contain several thousand gene .
organization of eukaryotic chromosome chromosome structure differ somewhat between eukaryotic and prokaryotic cell .
eukaryotic chromosome be typically linear , and eukaryotic cell contain multiple distinct chromosome .
many eukaryotic cell contain two copy of each chromosome and , therefore , be diploid .
the length of a chromosome greatly exceed the length of the cell , so a chromosome need to be package into a very small space to fit within the cell .
for example , the combined length of all of the three billion base pairs[ one  eight ] of dna of the human genome would measure approximately two meter if completely stretch out , and some eukaryotic genome be many time large than the human genome .
dna supercoiling refer to the process by which dna be twist to fit inside the cell .
supercoiling may result in dna that be either underwound ( less than one turn of the helix per one  zero base pair ) or overwound ( more than one turn per one  zero base pair ) from - pron - normal relaxed state .
protein know to be involve in supercoile include topoisomerase  these enzyme help maintain the structure of supercoiled chromosome , prevent overwinding of dna during certain cellular process like dna replication .
during dna packaging , dna - bind protein call histone perform various level of dna wrapping and attachment to scaffold protein .
the combination of dna with these attach protein be refer to as chromatin .
in eukaryote , the packaging of dna by histone may be influence by environmental factor that affect the presence of methyl group on certain cytosine nucleotide of dna .
the influence of environmental factor on dna packaging be call epigenetic .
epigenetic be another mechanism for regulate gene expression without alter the sequence of nucleotide .
epigenetic change can be maintain through multiple round of cell division and , therefore , can be heritable .

extrachromosomal dna

lethal plasmids maria , a two  zero  - year - old anthropology student from texas , recently become ill in the african nation of botswana , where - pron - be conduct research as part of a study - abroad program .

viral genomes viral genome exhibit significant diversity in structure .

why do viral genome vary widely among virus ?
genome size matters
there be great variation in size of genome among different organism .
most eukaryote maintain multiple chromosome  human , for example have two  three pair , give - pron - four  six chromosome .
despite be large at three billion base pair , the human genome be far from the large genome .
plant often maintain very large genome , up to one  five  zero billion base pair , and commonly be polyploid , have multiple copy of each chromosome .
the size of bacterial genome also vary considerably , although - pron - tend to be small than eukaryotic genome ( figure one  zero  .  two  eight ) .
some bacterial genome may be as small as only one  one  two  ,  zero  zero  zero base pair .
often , the size of a bacterium 's genome directly relate to how much the bacterium depend on - pron - host for survival .
when a bacterium rely on the host cell to carry out certain function , - pron - lose the gene encode the ability to carry out those function - pron - .
these type of bacterial endosymbiont be reminiscent of the prokaryotic origin of mitochondria and chloroplast .
from a clinical perspective , obligate intracellular pathogen also tend to have small genome ( some around micro connections chapter one  zero  biochemistry of the genome four  three  seven one million base pair ) .
because host cell supply most of - pron - nutrient , - pron - tend to have a reduced number of gene encode metabolic function .
due to - pron - small size , the genome of organism like mycoplasma genitalium ( five  eight  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero base pair ) , chlamydia trachomatis ( one  .  zero million ) , rickettsia prowazekii ( one  .  one million ) , and treponema pallidum ( one  .  one million ) be some of the early bacterial genome sequence .
respectively , these pathogen cause urethritis and pelvic inflammation , chlamydia , typhus , and syphilis .
whereas obligate intracellular pathogen have unusually small genome , other bacteria with a great variety of metabolic and enzymatic capability have unusually large bacterial genome .
pseudomonas aeruginosa , for example , be a bacterium commonly find in the environment and be able to grow on a wide range of substrate .
- pron - genome contain six  .  three million base pair , give - pron - a high metabolic ability and the ability to produce virulence factor that cause several type of opportunistic infection .
interestingly , there have be significant variability in genome size in virus as well , range from three  ,  five  zero  zero base pair to two  .  five million base pair , significantly exceed the size of many bacterial genome .
the great variation observe in viral genome size further contribute to the great diversity of viral genome characteristic already discuss .

one  zero  .  two structure and function of dna

nucleic acid be compose of nucleotide , each of which contain a pentose sugar , a phosphate group , and a nitrogenous base .
deoxyribonucleotide within dna contain deoxyribose as the pentose sugar .

dna contain the pyrimidine cytosine and thymine , and the purine adenine and guanine .

nucleotide be link together by phosphodiest bond between the five ʹ phosphate group of one nucleotide and the three ʹ hydroxyl group of another .
a nucleic acid strand have a free phosphate group at the five ʹ end and a free hydroxyl group at the three ʹ end .

chargaff discover that the amount of adenine be approximately equal to the amount of thymine in dna , and that the amount of the guanine be approximately equal to cytosine .
these relationship be later determined to be due to complementary base pair .

watson and crick , build on the work of chargaff , franklin and gosling , and wilkins , propose the double helix model and base pairing for dna structure .

dna be compose of two complementary strand orient antiparallel to each other with the phosphodiest backbone on the exterior of the molecule .
the nitrogenous basis of each strand face each other and link to learn chapter one  zero  biochemistry of the genome four  three  nine complementary basis hydrogen bond to each other , stabilize the double helix .

heat or chemical can break the hydrogen bond between complementary basis , denature dna .
cooling or remove chemical can lead to renaturation or reannealing of dna by allow hydrogen bond to reform between complementary basis .

dna store the instruction need to build and control the cell .
this information be transmit from parent to offspring through vertical gene transfer .
one  zero  .  three structure and function of rna  ribonucleic acid ( rna ) be typically single strand and contain ribose as - pron - pentose sugar and the pyrimidine uracil instead of thymine .
an rna strand can undergo significant intramolecular base pair to take on a three - dimensional structure .

there be three main type of rna , all involve in protein synthesis .

messenger rna ( mrna ) serve as the intermediary between dna and the synthesis of protein product during translation .

ribosomal rna ( rrna ) be a type of stable rna that be a major constituent of ribosome .
- pron - ensure the proper alignment of the mrna and the ribosome during protein synthesis and catalyze the formation of the peptide bond between two align amino acid during protein synthesis .

transfer rna ( trna ) be a small type of stable rna that carry an amino acid to the corresponding site of protein synthesis in the ribosome .
- pron - be the base pair between the trna and mrna that allow for the correct amino acid to be insert in the polypeptide chain be synthesize .

although rna be not use for long - term genetic information in cell , many virus do use rna as - pron - genetic material .
one  zero  .  four structure and function of cellular genomes

the entire genetic content of a cell be - pron - genome .

genes code for protein , or stable rna molecule , each of which carry out a specific function in the cell .

although the genotype that a cell possess remain constant , expression of gene be dependent on environmental condition .

a phenotype be the observable characteristic of a cell ( or organism ) at a give point in time and result from the complement of gene currently be use .

the majority of genetic material be organize into chromosome that contain the dna that control cellular activity .

prokaryotes be typically haploid , usually have a single circular chromosome find in the nucleoid .
eukaryote be diploid  dna be organize into multiple linear chromosome find in the nucleus .
 supercoiling and dna packaging use dna bind protein allow lengthy molecule to fit inside a cell .
eukaryote and archaea use histone protein , and bacteria use different protein with similar function .

prokaryotic and eukaryotic genome both contain noncode dna , the function of which be not well understand .
some noncode dna appear to participate in the formation of small noncoding rna molecule that influence gene expression  some appear to play a role in maintain chromosomal structure and in dna packaging .

extrachromosomal dna in eukaryote include the chromosome find within organelle of prokaryotic origin ( mitochondria and chloroplast ) that evolve by endosymbiosis .
some virus may also maintain - pron - extrachromosomally .

extrachromosomal dna in prokaryote be commonly maintain as plasmid that encode a few nonessential gene that may be helpful under specific condition .
plasmid can be spread through a bacterial community by horizontal gene transfer .
 viral genome show extensive variation and may be compose of either rna or dna , and may be either double or single strand .

differentiate between genotype and phenotype and explain how environmental factor influence phenotype dna serve two essential function that deal with cellular information .
first , dna be the genetic material responsible for inheritance and be pass from parent to offspring for all life on earth .
to preserve the integrity of this genetic information , dna must be replicate with great accuracy , with minimal error that introduce change to the dna sequence .
a genome contain the full complement of dna within a cell and be organize into small , discrete unit call gene that be arrange on chromosome and plasmid .
the second function of dna be to direct and regulate the construction of the protein necessary to a cell for growth and reproduction in a particular cellular environment .
a gene be compose of dna that be " read " or transcribe to produce an rna molecule during the process of transcription .
one major type of rna molecule , call messenger rna ( mrna ) , provide the information for the ribosome to catalyze protein synthesis in a process call translation .
the process of transcription and translation be collectively refer to as gene expression .
gene expression be the synthesis of a specific protein with a sequence of amino acid that be encode in the gene .
the flow of genetic information from dna to rna to protein be describe by the central dogma ( figure one  one  .  two ) .
this central dogma of molecular biology further elucidate the mechanism behind beadle and tatum 's “ one gene - one enzyme ” hypothesis ( see use microorganism to discover the secrets of life ) .
each of the process of replication , transcription , and translation include the stage of one ) initiation , two ) elongation ( polymerization ) , and three ) termination .
these stage will be describe in more detail in this chapter .

use and abuse of genome data
why can some human harbor opportunistic pathogen like haemophilus influenzae , staphylococcus aureus , or streptococcus pyogene , in - pron - upper respiratory tract but remain asymptomatic carrier , while other individual become seriously ill when infect ?
there be evidence suggest that difference in susceptibility to infection between patient may be a result , at least in part , of genetic difference between human host .
for example , genetic difference in human leukocyte antigen ( hlas ) and red blood cell antigen among host have be implicate in different immune response and result disease progression from infection with h . influenzae .
because the genetic interplay between pathogen and host may contribute to disease outcome , understand difference in genetic makeup between individual may be an important clinical tool .
ecological genomic be a relatively new field that seek to understand how the genotype of different organism interact with each other in nature .
the field answer question about how gene expression of one organism affect gene expression of another .
medical application of ecological genomic will focus on how pathogen interact with specific individual , as oppose to human in general .
such analysis would allow medical professional to use knowledge of an individual 's genotype to apply more individualized plan for treatment and prevention of eye on ethics chapter one  one  mechanisms of microbial genetics four  four  seven disease .
with the advent of next - generation sequencing , - pron - be relatively easy to obtain the entire genomic sequence of pathogen  a bacterial genome can be sequence in as little as a day . [ one ]
the speed and cost of sequence the human genome have also be greatly reduce and , already , individual can submit sample to receive extensive report on - pron - personal genetic trait , include ancestry and carrier status for various genetic disease .
as sequence technology progress further , such service will continue to become less expensive , more extensive , and quicker .
however , as this day quickly approach , there be many ethical concern with which society must grapple .
for example , should genome sequencing be a standard practice for everybody ?
should - pron - be require by law or by employer if - pron - will lower health - care cost ?
if one refuse genome sequencing , do - pron - or - pron - forfeit - pron - or - pron - right to health insurance coverage ?
for what purpose should the datum be use ?
who should oversee proper use of these datum ?
if genome sequencing reveal predisposition to a particular disease , do insurance company have the right to increase rate ?
will employer treat an employee differently ?
know that environmental influence also affect disease development , how should the datum on the presence of a particular disease - cause allele in an individual be use ethically ?
the genetic information nondiscrimination act of two  zero  zero  eight ( gina ) currently prohibit discriminatory practice base on genetic information by both health insurance company and employer .
however , gina do not cover life , disability , or long - term care insurance policy .
clearly , all member of society must continue to engage in conversation about these issue so that such genomic datum can be use to improve health care while simultaneously protect an individual 's right .

there be three model suggest for dna replication .
in the conservative model , parental dna strand ( blue ) remain associate in one dna molecule while new daughter strand ( red ) remain associate in newly form dna molecule .
in the semiconservative model , parental strand separate and direct the synthesis of a daughter strand , with each result dna molecule be a hybrid of a parental strand and a daughter strand .
in the dispersive model , all result dna strand have region of double - strand parental dna and region of doublestrande daughter dna .
matthew meselson ( one  nine  three  zero – ) and franklin stahl ( one  nine  two  nine – ) devise an experiment in one  nine  five  eight to test which of these model correctly represent dna replication ( figure one  one  .  five ) .
- pron - grow e . coli for several generation in a medium contain a " heavy " isotope of nitrogen ( one  five n ) that be incorporate into nitrogenous basis and , eventually , into the dna .
this label the parental dna .
the e . coli culture be then shift into a medium contain one  four n and allow to grow for one generation .
the cell be harvest and the dna be isolate .
the dna be separate by ultracentrifugation , during which the dna form band accord to - pron - density .
dna grow in one  five n would be expect to form a band at a high density position than that grow in one  four n . meselson and stahl note that after one generation of growth in one  four n , the single band observe be intermediate in position in between dna of cell grow exclusively in one  five n or one  four n .
this suggest either a semiconservative or dispersive mode of replication .
some cell be allow to grow for one more generation in one  four n and spin again .
the dna harvest from cell grow for two generation in one  four n form two band  one dna band be at the intermediate position between one  five n and one  four n , and the other correspond to the band of one  four n dna .
these result could only be explain if dna replicate in a semiconservative manner .
therefore , the other two model be rule out .
as a result of this experiment , - pron - now know that during dna replication , each of the two strand that make up the double helix serve as a template from which new strand be copy .
the new strand will be complementary to the parental or " old " strand .
the result dna molecule have the same sequence and be divide equally into the two daughter cell .

dna replication in bacteria dna replication have be well study in bacteria primarily because of the small size of the genome and the mutant that be available .
e . coli have four  .  six million base pair ( mbp ) in a single circular chromosome and all of - pron - be replicate in approximately four  two minute , start from a single origin of replication and proceed around the circle bidirectionally ( i . e . , in both direction ) .
this mean that approximately one  zero  zero  zero nucleotide be add per second .
the process be quite rapid and occur with few error .
dna replication use a large number of protein and enzyme ( table one  one  .  one ) .
one of the key player be the enzyme dna polymerase , also know as dna pol .
in bacteria , three main type of dna polymerase be know  dna pol i , dna pol ii , and dna pol iii .
- pron - be now know that dna pol iii be the enzyme require for dna synthesis  dna pol i and dna pol ii be primarily require for repair .
dna pol iii add deoxyribonucleotide each complementary to a nucleotide on the template strand , one by one to the three ' - oh group of the grow dna chain .

initiation
the initiation of replication occur at specific nucleotide sequence call the origin of replication , where various protein bind to begin the replication process .
e . coli have a single origin of replication ( as do most prokaryote ) , call oric , on - pron - one chromosome .
the origin of replication be approximately two  four  five base pair long and be rich in adeninethymine ( at ) sequence .
some of the protein that bind to the origin of replication be important in make single - strand region of dna accessible for replication .
chromosomal dna be typically wrap around histone ( in eukaryote and archaea ) or histone - like protein ( in bacteria ) , and be supercoiled , or extensively wrap and twist on - pron - .
this packaging make the information in the dna molecule inaccessible .
however , enzyme call topoisomerase change the shape and supercoiling of the chromosome .
for bacterial dna replication to begin , the supercoiled chromosome be relax by topoisomerase ii , also call dna gyrase .
an enzyme call helicase then separate the dna strand by break the hydrogen bond between the nitrogenous base pair .
recall that at sequence have few hydrogen bond and , hence , have weak interaction than guanine - cytosine ( gc ) sequence .
these enzyme require atp hydrolysis .
as the dna open up , y - shape structure call replication fork be form .
two replication fork be form at the origin of replication , allow for bidirectional replication and formation of a structure that look like a bubble when view with a transmission electron microscope  as a result , this structure be call a replication bubble .
the dna near each replication fork be coat with single - strand bind protein to prevent the singlestrande dna from rewinde into a double helix .
once single - strand dna be accessible at the origin of replication , dna replication can begin .
however , dna pol iii be able to add nucleotide only in the five ' to three ' direction ( a new dna strand can be only extend in this direction ) .
this be because dna polymerase require a free three ' - oh group to which - pron - can add nucleotide by form a covalent phosphodiest bond between the three ' - oh end and the five ' phosphate of the next nucleotide .
this also mean that - pron - can not add nucleotide if a free three ' - oh group be not available , which be the case for a single strand of dna .
the problem be solve with the help of an rna sequence that provide the free three ' - oh end .
because this sequence allow the start of dna synthesis , - pron - be appropriately call the primer .
the primer be five to one  zero nucleotide long and complementary to the parental or template dna .
- pron - be synthesize by rna primase , which be an rna polymerase .
unlike dna polymerase , rna polymerase do not need a free three ' - oh group to synthesize an rna molecule .
now that the primer provide the free three ' - oh group , dna polymerase iii can now extend this rna primer , add dna nucleotide one by one that be complementary to the template strand ( figure one  one  .  four ) .
elongation
during elongation in dna replication , the addition of nucleotide occur at - pron - maximal rate of about one  zero  zero  zero nucleotide per second .
dna polymerase iii can only extend in the five ' to three ' direction , which pose a problem at chapter one  one
 mechanisms of microbial genetics four  five  one the replication fork .
the dna double helix be antiparallel  that is , one strand be orient in the five ' to three ' direction and the other be orient in the three ' to five ' direction ( see structure and function of dna ) .
during replication , one strand , which be complementary to the three ' to five ' parental dna strand , be synthesize continuously toward the replication fork because polymerase can add nucleotide in this direction .
this continuously synthesize strand be know as the lead strand .
the other strand , complementary to the five ' to three ' parental dna , grow away from the replication fork , so the polymerase must move back toward the replication fork to begin add basis to a new primer , again in the direction away from the replication fork .
- pron - do so until - pron - bump into the previously synthesize strand and then - pron - move back again ( figure one  one  .  seven ) .
these step produce small dna sequence fragment know as okazaki fragment , each separate by rna primer .
okazaki fragment be name after the japanese research team and married couple reiji and tsuneko okazaki , who first discover - pron - in one  nine  six  six .
the strand with the okazaki fragment be know as the lag strand , and - pron - synthesis be say to be discontinuous .
the lead strand can be extend from one primer alone , whereas the lag strand need a new primer for each of the short okazaki fragment .
the overall direction of the lag strand will be three ' to five ' , and that of the lead strand five ' to three ' .
a protein call the sliding clamp hold the dna polymerase in place as - pron - continue to add nucleotide .
the slide clamp be a ring - shape protein that bind to the dna and hold the polymerase in place .
beyond - pron - role in initiation , topoisomerase also prevent the overwinding of the dna double helix ahead of the replication fork as the dna be open up  - pron - do so by cause temporary nick in the dna helix and then reseal - pron - .
as synthesis proceed , the rna primer be replace by dna .
the primer be remove by the exonuclease activity of dna polymerase i , and the gap be fill in .
the nick that remain between the newly synthesize dna ( that replace the rna primer ) and the previously synthesize dna be seal by the enzyme dna ligase that catalyze the formation of covalent phosphodiest linkage between the three ' - oh end of one dna fragment and the five ' phosphate end of the other fragment , stabilize the sugar - phosphate backbone of the dna molecule .

dna replication occur in both direction .

termination
once the complete chromosome have be replicate , termination of dna replication must occur .
although much be know about initiation of replication , less be know about the termination process .
follow replication , the result complete circular genome of prokaryote be concatenate , mean that the circular dna chromosome be interlock and must be separate from each other .
this be accomplish through the activity of bacterial topoisomerase iv , which introduce double - strand break into dna molecule , allow - pron - to separate from each other  the enzyme then reseal the circular chromosome .

dna replication in eukaryotes eukaryotic genome be much more complex and large than prokaryotic genome and be typically compose of multiple linear chromosome ( table one  one  .  two ) .

the essential step of replication in eukaryote be the same as in prokaryote .

the gap that remain be seal by dna ligase .
because eukaryotic chromosome be linear , one may expect that - pron - replication would be more straightforward .
as in prokaryote , the eukaryotic dna polymerase can add nucleotide only in the five ' to three ' direction .
in the lead strand , synthesis continue until - pron - reach either the end of the chromosome or another replication fork progress in the opposite direction .
on the lag strand , dna be synthesize in short stretch , each of which be initiate by a separate primer .
when the replication fork reach the end of the linear chromosome , there be no place to make a primer for the dna fragment to be copy at the end of the chromosome .
these end thus remain unpaired and , over time , - pron - may get progressively short as cell continue to divide .
the end of the linear chromosome be know as telomere and consist of noncode repetitive sequence .
the telomere protect coding sequence from be lose as cell continue to divide .
in human , a six base - pair sequence , ttaggg , be repeat one  zero  zero to one  zero  zero  zero time to form the telomere .
the discovery of the enzyme telomerase ( figure one  one  .  nine ) clarify - pron - understanding of how chromosome end be maintain .
telomerase contain a catalytic part and a build - in rna template .
- pron - attach to the end of the chromosome , and complementary basis to the rna template be add on the three ' end of the dna strand .
once the three ' end of the lag strand template be sufficiently elongate , dna polymerase can add the nucleotide complementary to the end of the chromosome .
in this way , the end of the chromosome be replicate .
in human , telomerase be typically active in germ cell and adult stem cell  - pron - be not active in adult somatic cell and may be associate with the aging of these cell .
eukaryotic microbe include fungus and protozoan also produce telomerase to maintain chromosomal integrity .
for - pron - discovery of telomerase and - pron - action , elizabeth blackburn ( one  nine  four  eight – ) receive the nobel prize for medicine or physiology in two  zero  zero  nine .

roll circle replication
whereas many bacterial plasmid ( see unique characteristics of prokaryotic cells ) replicate by a process similar to that use to copy the bacterial chromosome , other plasmid , several bacteriophage , and some virus of eukaryote use roll circle replication ( figure one  one  .  one  zero ) .
the circular nature of plasmid and the circularization of some viral genome on infection make this possible .
roll circle replication begin with the enzymatic nicking of one strand of the double - strand circular molecule at the double - strand origin ( dso ) site .
in bacteria , dna polymerase iii bind to the three ' - oh group of the nicked strand and begin to unidirectionally replicate the dna use the un - nicked strand as a template , displace the nick strand as - pron - do so .
completion of dna replication at the site of the original nick result in full displacement of the nicked strand , which may then recircularize into a singlestrande dna molecule .
rna primase then synthesize a primer to initiate dna replication at the single - strand origin ( sso ) site of the single - strand dna ( ssdna ) molecule , result in a double - strand dna ( dsdna ) molecule identical to the other circular dna molecule .

transcription learning objectives

during the process of transcription , the information encode within the dna sequence of one or more gene be transcribe into a strand of rna , also call an rna transcript .
the result single - strand rna molecule , compose of ribonucleotide contain the basis adenine ( a ) , cytosine ( c ) , guanine ( g ) , and uracil ( u ) , act as a mobile molecular copy of the original dna sequence .
transcription in prokaryote and in eukaryote require the dna double helix to partially unwind in the region of rna synthesis .
the unwound region be call a transcription bubble .
transcription of a particular gene always proceed from one of the two dna strand that act as a template , the so - call antisense strand .
the rna product be complementary to the template strand of dna and be almost identical to the nontemplate dna strand , or the sense strand .
the only difference be that in rna , all of the t nucleotide be replace with u nucleotide  during rna synthesis , u be incorporate when there be an a in the complementary antisense strand .
transcription in bacteria bacteria use the same rna polymerase to transcribe all of - pron - gene .
like dna polymerase , rna polymerase add nucleotides one by one to the three ' - oh group of the grow nucleotide chain .
one critical difference in activity between dna polymerase and rna polymerase be the requirement for a three ' - oh onto which to add nucleotide  dna polymerase require such a three ' - oh group , thus necessitate a primer , whereas rna polymerase do not .
