molecular cloning use transformation
the most commonly use mechanism for introduce engineer plasmid into a bacterial cell be transformation , a process in which bacteria take up free dna from - pron - surrounding .
in nature , free dna typically come from other lysed bacterial cell  in the laboratory , free dna in the form of recombinant plasmid be introduce to the cell 's surrounding .
some bacteria , such as bacillus spp . , be naturally competent , mean - pron - be able to take up foreign dna .
however , not all bacteria be naturally competent .
in most case , bacteria must be make artificially competent in the laboratory by increase the permeability of the cell membrane .
this can be achieve through chemical treatment that neutralize charge on the cell membrane or by expose the bacteria to an electric field that create microscopic pore in the cell membrane .
these method yield chemically competent or electrocompetent bacteria , respectively .
follow the transformation protocol , bacterial cell be plate onto an antibiotic - contain medium to inhibit the growth of the many host cell that be not transform by the plasmid conferring antibiotic resistance .
a technique call blue - white screening be then use for lacz - encode plasmid vector such as puc one  nine .
blue colony have a functional beta - galactosidase enzyme because the lacz gene be uninterrupted , with no foreign dna insert into the polylinker site .
these colony typically result from the digested , linearize plasmid religating to - pron - .
however , chapter one  two  modern applications of microbial genetics five  one  three white colony lack a functional beta - galactosidase enzyme , indicate the insertion of foreign dna within the polylinker site of the plasmid vector , thus disrupt the lacz gene .
thus , white colony result from this bluewhite screen contain plasmid with an insert and can be further screen to characterize the foreign dna .
to be sure the correct dna be incorporate into the plasmid , the dna insert can then be sequence .

molecular cloning use conjugation or transduction
the bacterial process of conjugation ( see how asexual prokaryotes achieve genetic diversity ) can also be manipulate for molecular cloning .
f plasmid , or fertility plasmid , be transfer between bacterial cell through the process of conjugation .
recombinant dna can be transfer by conjugation when bacterial cell contain a recombinant f plasmid be mix with compatible bacterial cell lack the plasmid .
f plasmid encode a surface structure call an f pilus that facilitate contact between a cell contain an f plasmid and one without an f plasmid .
on contact , a cytoplasmic bridge form between the two cell and the f - plasmid - contain cell replicate - pron - plasmid , transfer a copy of the recombinant f plasmid to the recipient cell .
once - pron - have receive the recombinant f plasmid , the recipient cell can produce - pron - own f pilus and facilitate transfer of the recombinant f plasmid to an additional cell .
the use of conjugation to transfer recombinant f plasmid to recipient cell be another effective way to introduce recombinant dna molecule into host cell .
alternatively , bacteriophage can be use to introduce recombinant dna into host bacterial cell through a manipulation of the transduction process ( see how asexual prokaryotes achieve genetic diversity ) .
in the laboratory , dna fragment of interest can be engineer into phagemid , which be plasmid that have phage sequence that allow - pron - to be package into bacteriophage .
bacterial cell can then be infect with these bacteriophage so that the recombinant phagemid can be introduce into the bacterial cell .
depend on the type of phage , the recombinant dna may be integrate into the host bacterial genome ( lysogeny ) , or - pron - may exist as a plasmid in the host 's cytoplasm .

create a genomic library molecular cloning may also be use to generate a genomic library .
the library be a complete ( or nearly complete ) copy of an organism 's genome contain as recombinant dna plasmid engineer into unique clone of bacteria .
have such a library allow a researcher to create large quantity of each fragment by grow the bacterial host for that fragment .
these fragment can be use to determine the sequence of the dna and the function of any gene present .
one method for generate a genomic library be to ligate individual restriction enzyme - digest genomic fragment into plasmid vector cut with the same restriction enzyme ( figure one  two  .  six ) .
after transformation into a bacterial host , each transform bacterial cell take up a single recombinant plasmid and grow into a colony of cell .
all of the cell in this colony be identical clone and carry the same recombinant plasmid .
the result library be a collection of colony , each of which contain a fragment of the original organism 's genome , that be each separate and distinct and can each be use for further study .
this make - pron - possible for researcher to screen these different clone to discover the one contain a gene of interest from the original organism 's genome .

to construct a genomic library use large fragment of genomic dna , an e . coli bacteriophage , such as lambda , can be use as a host ( figure one  two  .  seven ) .
genomic dna can be shear or enzymatically digest and ligate into a predigested bacteriophage lambda dna vector .
then , these recombinant phage dna molecule can be package into phage particle and use to infect e . coli host cell on a plate .
during infection within each cell , each recombinant phage will make many copy of - pron - and lyse the e . coli lawn , form a plaque .
thus , each plaque from a phage library represent a unique recombinant phage contain a distinct genomic dna fragment .
plaque can then be screen further to look for gene of interest .
one advantage to produce a library use phage instead of plasmid be that a phage particle hold a much large insert of foreign dna compare with a plasmid vector , thus require a much small number of culture to fully represent the entire genome of the original organism .

to focus on the express gene in an organism or even a tissue , researcher construct library use the organism 's messenger rna ( mrna ) rather than - pron - genomic dna .
whereas all cell in a single organism will have the same genomic dna , different tissue express different gene , produce different complement of mrna .

a cell 's full complement of mrna can be reverse - transcribe into cdna molecule , which can be use as a template for dna polymerase to make double - strand dna copy  these fragment can subsequently be ligate into either plasmid vector or bacteriophage to produce a cdna library .
the benefit of a cdna library be that - pron - contain dna from only the express gene in the cell .
this mean that the intron , control sequence such as promoter , and dna not destine to be translate into protein be not represent in the library .
the focus on translate sequence mean that the library can not be use to study the sequence and structure of the genome in - pron - entirety .

introducing recombinant molecules into eukaryotic hosts
the use of bacterial host for genetic engineering lay the foundation for recombinant dna technology  however , researcher have also have great interest in genetically engineer eukaryotic cell , particularly those of plant and animal .
the introduction of recombinant dna molecule into eukaryotic host be call transfection .
genetically engineer plant , call transgenic plant , be of significant interest for agricultural and pharmaceutical purpose .
the first transgenic plant sell commercially be the flavr savr delay - ripen tomato , which come to market in one  nine  nine  four .
genetically engineer livestock have also be successfully produce , result , for example , in pig with increase nutritional value[ one ] and goat that secrete pharmaceutical product in - pron - milk . [ two ]
electroporation compare to bacterial cell , eukaryotic cell tend to be less amenable as host for recombinant dna molecule .
because eukaryote be typically neither competent to take up foreign dna nor able to maintain plasmid , transfection of eukaryotic host be far more challenging and require more intrusive technique for success .
one method use for transfecte cell in cell culture be call electroporation .
a brief electric pulse induce the formation of transient pore in the phospholipid bilayer of cell through which the gene can be introduce .
at the same time , the electric pulse generate a short - live positive charge on one side of the cell 's interior and a negative charge on the opposite side  the charge difference draw negatively charge dna molecule into the cell ( figure one  two  .  nine ) .
figure one  two  .  nine electroporation be one laboratory technique use to introduce dna into eukaryotic cell .
microinjection an alternative method of transfection be call microinjection .
because eukaryotic cell be typically large than those of prokaryote , dna fragment can sometimes be directly inject into the cytoplasm use a glass one .

molecular analysis of dna
in this subsection , - pron - will outline some of the basic method use for separate and visualize specific fragment of dna that be of interest to a scientist .
some of these method do not require knowledge of the complete sequence of the dna molecule .
before the advent of rapid dna sequencing , these method be the only one available to work with dna , but - pron - still form the basic arsenal of tool use by molecular geneticist to study the body 's response to microbial and other disease .
nucleic acid probing dna molecule be small , and the information contain in - pron - sequence be invisible .
how do a researcher isolate a particular stretch of dna , or have isolate - pron - , determine what organism - pron - be from , what - pron - sequence be , or what chapter one  two  modern applications of microbial genetics five  two  one - pron - function be ?
one method to identify the presence of a certain dna sequence use artificially construct piece of dna call probe .
probes can be use to identify different bacterial specie in the environment and many dna probe be now available to detect pathogen clinically .
for example , dna probe be use to detect the vaginal pathogen candida albican , gardnerella vaginalis , and trichomonas vaginalis .
to screen a genomic library for a particular gene or sequence of interest , researcher must know something about that gene .
if researcher have a portion of the sequence of dna for the gene of interest , - pron - can design a dna probe , a single - strand dna fragment that be complementary to part of the gene of interest and different from other dna sequence in the sample .
the dna probe may be synthesize chemically by commercial laboratory , or - pron - may be create by cloning , isolating , and denature a dna fragment from a live organism .
in either case , the dna probe must be label with a molecular tag or beacon , such as a radioactive phosphorus atom ( as be use for autoradiography ) or a fluorescent dye ( as be use in fluorescent in situ hybridization , or fish ) , so that the probe and the dna - pron - bind to can be see ( figure one  two  .  one  three ) .
the dna sample be probe must also be denature to make - pron - single - strand so that the single - strand dna probe can anneal to the single - strand dna sample at location where - pron - sequence be complementary .
while these technique be valuable for diagnosis , - pron - direct use on sputum and other bodily sample may be problematic due to the complex nature of these sample .
dna often must first be isolate from bodily sample through chemical extraction method before a dna probe can be use to identify pathogen .

agarose gel electrophoresis
there be a number of situation in which a researcher may want to physically separate a collection of dna fragment of different size .
a researcher may also digest a dna sample with a restriction enzyme to form fragment .
the result size and fragment distribution pattern can often yield useful information about the sequence of dna basis that can be use , much like a bar - code scan , to identify the individual or specie to which the dna belong .
gel electrophoresis be a technique commonly use to separate biological molecule base on size and biochemical characteristic , such as charge and polarity .
agarose gel electrophoresis be widely use to separate dna ( or rna ) of vary size that may be generate by restriction enzyme digestion or by other mean , such as the pcr ( figure one  two  .  one  four ) .
due to - pron - negatively charge backbone , dna be strongly attract to a positive electrode .
in agarose gel electrophoresis , the gel be orient horizontally in a buffer solution .
sample be load into sample well on the side of the gel close to the negative electrode , then draw through the molecular sieve of the agarose matrix toward the positive electrode .
the agarose matrix impede the movement of large molecule through the gel , whereas small molecule pass through more readily .
thus , the distance of migration be inversely correlate to the size of the dna fragment , with small fragment travel a long distance through the gel .
size of dna fragment within a sample can be estimate by comparison to fragment of know size in a dna ladder also run on the same gel .
to separate very large dna fragment , such as chromosome or viral genome , agarose gel electrophoresis can be modify by periodically alternate the orientation of the electric field during pulse - field gel electrophoresis ( pfge ) .
in pfge , small fragment can reorient - pron - and migrate slightly faster than large fragment and this technique can thus serve to separate very large fragment that would otherwise travel together during standard agarose gel electrophoresis .
in any of these electrophoresis technique , the location of the dna or rna fragment in the gel can be detect by various method .
one common method be add ethidium bromide , a stain that insert into the nucleic acid at non - specific location and can be visualize when expose to ultraviolet light .
other stain that be safe than ethidium bromide , a potential carcinogen , be now available .

analysis restriction enzyme recognition site be short ( only a few nucleotide long ) , sequence - specific palindrome , and may be find throughout the genome .
thus , difference in dna sequence in the genome of individual will lead to difference in distribution of restriction - enzyme recognition site that can be visualize as distinct banding pattern on a gel after agarose gel electrophoresis .
restriction fragment length polymorphism ( rflp ) analysis compare dna banding pattern of different dna sample after restriction digestion ( figure one  two  .  one  five ) .
rflp analysis have many practical application in both medicine and forensic science .
for example , epidemiologist use rflp analysis to track and identify the source of specific microorganism implicate in outbreak of food poisoning or certain infectious disease .
rflp analysis can also be use on human dna to determine inheritance pattern of chromosome with variant gene , include those associate with heritable disease or to establish paternity .
forensic scientist use rflp analysis as a form of dna fingerprinting , which be useful for analyze dna obtain from crime scene , suspect , and victim .
dna sample be collect , the number of copy of the sample dna molecule be increase use pcr , and then subject to restriction enzyme digestion and agarose gel electrophoresis to generate specific banding pattern .
by compare the band pattern of sample collect from the crime scene against those collect from suspect or victim , investigator can definitively determine whether dna evidence collect at the scene be leave behind by suspect or victim .
figure one  two  .  one  five rflp analysis can be use to differentiate dna sequence .
in this example , a normal chromosome be digest into two fragment , whereas digestion of a mutated chromosome produce only one fragment .
the small red arrow point to the two different chromosome segment show the location of the restriction enzyme recognition site .
after digestion and agarose gel electrophoresis , the band pattern reflect the change by show the loss of two short band and the gain of a long band .

southern blots and modifications several molecular technique capitalize on sequence complementarity and hybridization between nucleic acid of a sample and dna probe .
typically , probe nucleic - acid sample within a gel be unsuccessful because as the dna probe soak into a gel , the sample nucleic acid within the gel diffuse out .
thus , blot technique be commonly use to transfer nucleic acid to a thin , positively charge membrane make of nitrocellulose or nylon .
in the southern blot technique , develop by sir edwin southern in one  nine  seven  five , dna fragment within a sample be first separate by agarose gel electrophoresis and then transfer to a membrane through capillary action ( figure one  two  .  one  six ) .
the dna fragment that bind to the surface of the membrane be then expose to a specific single - strand dna probe label chapter one  two  modern applications of microbial genetics five  two  five with a radioactive or fluorescent molecular beacon to aid in detection .
southern blot may be use to detect the presence of certain dna sequence in a give dna sample .
once the target dna within the membrane be visualized , researcher can cut out the portion of the membrane contain the fragment to recover the dna fragment of interest .
figure one  two  .  one  six
in the southern blot technique , dna fragment be first separate by agarose gel electrophoresis , then transfer by capillary action to a nylon membrane , which be then soak with a dna probe tag with a molecular beacon for easy visualization .
variation of the southern blot - the dot blot , slot blot , and the spot blot - do not involve electrophoresis , but instead concentrate dna from a sample into a small location on a membrane .
after hybridization with a dna probe , the signal intensity detect be measure , allow the researcher to estimate the amount of target dna present within the sample .
a colony blot be another variation of the southern blot in which colony represent different clone in a genomic library be transfer to a membrane by press the membrane onto the culture plate .
the cell on the membrane be lysed and the membrane can then be probe to determine which colony within a genomic library harbor the target gene .
because the colony on the plate be still grow , the cell of interest can be isolate from the plate .
in the northern blot , another variation of the southern blot , rna ( not dna ) be immobilize on the membrane and probe .
northern blot be typically use to detect the amount of mrna make through gene expression within a tissue or organism sample .
microarray analysis
another technique that capitalize on the hybridization between complementary nucleic acid sequence be call microarray analysis .
microarray analysis be useful for the comparison of gene - expression pattern between different cell type - for example , cell infect with a virus versus uninfected cell , or cancerous cell versus healthy cell ( figure one  two  .  one  seven ) .
typically , dna or cdna from an experimental sample be deposit on a glass slide alongside know dna sequence .
each slide can hold more than three  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero different dna fragment type .
distinct dna fragment ( encompass an organism 's entire genomic library ) or cdna fragment ( correspond to an organism 's full five  two  six chapter one  two  modern applications of microbial genetics
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five complement of express gene ) can be individually spot on a glass slide .
once deposit on the slide , genomic dna or mrna can be isolate from the two sample for comparison .
if mrna be isolate , - pron - be reverse - transcribe to cdna use reverse transcriptase .
then the two sample of genomic dna or cdna be label with different fluorescent dye ( typically red and green ) .
the label genomic dna sample be then combine in equal amount , add to the microarray chip , and allow to hybridize to complementary spot on the microarray .
hybridization of sample genomic dna molecule can be monitor by measure the intensity of fluorescence at particular spot on the microarray .
difference in the amount of hybridization between the sample can be readily observe .
if only one sample 's nucleic acid hybridize to a particular spot on the microarray , then that spot will appear either green or red .
however , if both sample ' nucleic acid hybridize , then the spot will appear yellow due to the combination of the red and green dye .
although microarray technology allow for a holistic comparison between two sample in a short time , - pron - require sophisticated ( and expensive ) detection equipment and analysis software .
because of the expense , this technology be typically limit to research setting .
researcher have use microarray analysis to study how gene expression be affect in organism that be infect by bacteria or virus or subject to certain chemical treatment .

molecular analysis of proteins

polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis
a variation of gel electrophoresis , call polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis ( page ) , be commonly use for separate protein .
in page , the gel matrix be finer and compose of polyacrylamide instead of agarose .
additionally , page be typically perform use a vertical gel apparatus ( figure one  two  .  one  eight ) .
because of the vary charge associate with amino acid side chain , page can be use to separate intact protein base on - pron - net charge .
alternatively , protein can be denature and coat with a negatively charge detergent call sodium dodecyl sulfate ( sds ) , mask the native charge and allow separation base on size only .
page can be further modify to separate protein base on two characteristic , such as - pron - charge at various ph as well as - pron - size , through the use of two - dimensional page .
in any of these case , follow electrophoresis , protein be visualize through staining , commonly with either coomassie blue or a silver stain .

amplification - base dna analysis methods
various method can be use for obtain sequence of dna , which be useful for study disease - cause organism .
with the advent of rapid sequencing technology , - pron - knowledge base of the entire genome of pathogenic organism have grow phenomenally .
- pron - start with a description of the polymerase chain reaction , which be not a sequencing method but have allow researcher and clinician to obtain the large quantity of dna need for sequencing and other study .
the polymerase chain reaction eliminate the dependence - pron - once have on cell to make multiple copy of dna , achieve the same result through relatively simple reaction outside the cell .

this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five polymerase chain reaction ( pcr )
most method of dna analysis , such as restriction enzyme digestion and agarose gel electrophoresis , or dna sequencing require large amount of a specific dna fragment .
in the past , large amount of dna be produce by grow the host cell of a genomic library .
however , library take time and effort to prepare and dna sample of interest often come in minute quantity .
the polymerase chain reaction ( pcr ) permit rapid amplification in the number of copy of specific dna sequence for further analysis ( figure one  two  .  two  zero ) .
one of the most powerful technique in molecular biology , pcr be develop in one  nine  eight  three by kary mullis while at cetus corporation .
pcr have specific application in research , forensic , and clinical laboratory , include   determine the sequence of nucleotide in a specific region of dna  amplify a target region of dna for clone into a plasmid vector  identify the source of a dna sample leave at a crime scene  analyze sample to determine paternity  compare sample of ancient dna with modern organism  determine the presence of difficult to culture , or unculturable , microorganism in human or environmental sample pcr be an in vitro laboratory technique that take advantage of the natural process of dna replication .
the heat - stable dna polymerase enzyme use in pcr be derive from hyperthermophilic prokaryote .
taq dna polymerase , commonly use in pcr , be derive from the thermus aquaticus bacterium isolate from a hot spring in yellowstone national park .
dna replication require the use of primer for the initiation of replication to have free three ʹ - hydroxyl group available for the addition of nucleotide by dna polymerase .
however , while primer compose of rna be normally use in cell , dna primer be use for pcr .
dna primer be preferable due to - pron - stability , and dna primer with know sequence target a specific dna region can be chemically synthesize commercially .
these dna primer be functionally similar to the dna probe use for the various hybridization technique describe earlier , bind to specific target due to complementarity between the target dna sequence and the primer .
pcr occur over multiple cycle , each contain three step  denaturation , annealing , and extension .
machine call thermal cycler be use for pcr  these machine can be program to automatically cycle through the temperature require at each step ( figure one  two  .  one ) .
first , double - stranded template dna contain the target sequence be denature at approximately nine  five ° c .
the high temperature require to physically ( rather than enzymatically ) separate the dna strand be the reason the heat - stable dna polymerase be require .
next , the temperature be lower to approximately five  zero ° c .
this allow the dna primer complementary to the end of the target sequence to anneal ( stick ) to the template strand , with one primer anneal to each strand .
finally , the temperature be raise to seven  two ° c , the optimal temperature for the activity of the heat - stable dna polymerase , allow for the addition of nucleotide to the primer use the single - stranded target as a template .
each cycle double the number of double - stranded target dna copy .
typically , pcr protocol include two  five – four  zero cycle , allow for the amplification of a single target sequence by ten of million to over a trillion .
natural dna replication be design to copy the entire genome , and initiate at one or more origin site .
primer be construct during replication , not before , and do not consist of a few specific sequence .
pcr target specific region of a dna sample use sequence - specific primer .
in recent year , a variety of isothermal pcr amplification method that circumvent the need for thermal cycling have be develop , take advantage of accessory protein that aid in the dna replication process .
as the development of these method continue and - pron - use become more widespread in research , forensic , and clinical lab , thermal cycler may become obsolete .

pcr variations several later modification to pcr further increase the utility of this technique .
reverse transcriptase pcr ( rtpcr ) be use for obtain dna copy of a specific mrna molecule .
rt - pcr begin with the use of the reverse transcriptase enzyme to convert mrna molecule into cdna .
that cdna be then use as a template for traditional pcr amplification .
rt - pcr can detect whether a specific gene have be express in a sample .
another recent application of pcr be real - time pcr , also know as quantitative pcr ( qpcr ) .

because - pron - be not possible to determine when in the pcr or rt - pcr protocol a give reagent have become limit , - pron - be not possible to know how many cycle be complete prior to this point , and thus - pron - be not possible to determine how many original template molecule be present in the sample at the start of pcr .
in qpcr , however , the use of fluorescence allow one to monitor the increase in a double - strand template during a pcr reaction as - pron - occur .
these kinetic datum can then be use to quantify the amount of the original target sequence .
the use of qpcr in recent year have further expand the capability of pcr , allow researcher to determine the number of dna copy , and sometimes organism , present in a sample .
in clinical setting , qrt - pcr be use to determine viral load in hiv - positive patient to evaluate the effectiveness of - pron - therapy .
dna sequence a basic sequencing technique be the chain termination method , also know as the dideoxy method or the sanger dna sequencing method , develop by frederick sanger in one  nine  seven  two .
the chain termination method involve dna replication of a single - strand template with the use of a dna primer to initiate synthesis of a complementary strand , dna polymerase , a mix of the four regular deoxynucleotide ( dntp ) monomer , and a small proportion of dideoxynucleotide ( ddntps ) , each label with a molecular beacon .
the ddntps be monomer miss a hydroxyl group ( –oh ) at the site at which another nucleotide usually attach to form a chain ( figure one  two  .  two  one ) .
every time a ddntp be randomly incorporate into the grow complementary strand , - pron - terminate the process of dna replication for that particular strand .
this result in multiple short strand of replicated dna that be each terminate at a different point during replication .
when the reaction mixture be subject to gel electrophoresis , the multiple newly replicate dna strand form a ladder of differ size .
because the ddntps be label , each band on the gel reflect the size of the dna strand when the ddntp terminate the reaction .
in sanger 's day , four reaction be set up for each dna molecule be sequence , each reaction contain only one of the four possible ddntps .
each ddntp be label with a radioactive phosphorus molecule .
the product of the four reaction be then run in separate lane side by side on long , narrow page gel , and the band of vary length be detect by autoradiography .
today , this process have be simplify with the use of ddntps , each label with a different color fluorescent dye or fluorochrome ( figure one  two  .  two  two ) , in one sequence reaction contain all four possible ddntps for each dna molecule be sequence ( figure one  two  .  two  three ) .
these fluorochrome be detect by fluorescence spectroscopy .
determine the fluorescence color of each band as - pron - pass by the detector produce the nucleotide sequence of the template strand .
figure one  two  .  two  one
a dideoxynucleotide be similar in structure to a deoxynucleotide , but be miss the three ʹ hydroxyl group ( indicate by the shade box ) .
when a dideoxynucleotide be incorporate into a dna strand , dna synthesis stop .

use ddntps , a mixture of dna fragment of every possible size , vary in length by only one nucleotide , can be generate .
the dna be separate on the basis of size and each band can be detect with a fluorescence detector .

these method have revolutionize the field of molecular genetic because the low - cost sequencer can generate sequence of hundred of thousand or million of short fragment ( two  five to six  zero  zero base pair ) just in one day .
although several variant of next generation sequencing technology be make by different company ( for example , four  five  four life sciences ' pyrosequencing and illumina 's solexa technology ) , - pron - all allow million of basis to be sequence quickly , make the sequencing of entire genome relatively easy , inexpensive , and commonplace .
in four  five  four sequencing ( pyrosequence ) , for example , a dna sample be fragment into four  zero  zero – six  zero  zero  - bp single - strand fragment , modify with the addition of dna adapter to both end of each fragment .
each dna fragment be then immobilize on a bead and amplify by pcr , use primer design to anneal to the adapter , create a bead contain many copy of that dna fragment .
each bead be then put into a separate well contain sequence enzyme .
to the well , each of the four nucleotide be add one after the other  when each one be incorporate , pyrophosphate be release as a byproduct of polymerization , emit a small flash of light that be record by a detector .
this provide the order of nucleotide incorporate as a new strand of dna be make and be an example of synthesis sequencing .
next chapter one  two  modern applications of microbial genetics five  three  five generation sequencer use sophisticated software to get through the cumbersome process of put all the fragment in order .
overall , these technology continue to advance rapidly , decrease the cost of sequence and increase the availability of sequence datum from a wide variety of organism quickly .
the national center for biotechnology information house a widely use genetic sequence database call genbank where researcher deposit genetic information for public use .
upon publication of sequence datum , researcher upload - pron - to genbank , give other researcher access to the information .
the collaboration allow researcher to compare newly discover or unknown sample sequence information with the vast array of sequence datum that already exist .

use a naat to diagnose a c . difficile infection javier , an eight  zero  - year - old patient with a history of heart disease , recently return home from the hospital after undergo an angioplasty procedure to insert a stent into a cardiac artery .

javier 's symptom suggest a possible infection with clostridium difficile , a bacterium that be resistant to many antibiotic .
the hospital collect and culture a stool sample to look for the production of toxin a and b by c . difficile , but the result come back negative .

currently naats be the clinical diagnostician 's gold standard for detect the genetic material of a pathogen .

follow restriction digestion , agarose gel electrophoresis be perform in both type of analysis to examine the band pattern that result from each procedure ( figure one  two  .  two  five ) .
rep - pcr can be use to further subtype various ribotype , increase resolution for detect difference between strain .

one  two  .  three whole genome methods and pharmaceutical applications of genetic engineering learning objectives

advances in molecular biology have lead to the creation of entirely new field of science .
among these be field that study aspect of whole genome , collectively refer to as whole - genome method .
in this section , - pron - will provide a brief overview of the whole - genome field of genomic , transcriptomic , and proteomic .
genomics , transcriptomics , and proteomics
the study and comparison of entire genome , include the complete set of gene and - pron - nucleotide sequence and organization , be call genomic .
this field have great potential for future medical advance through the study of the human genome as well as the genome of infectious organism .
analysis of microbial genome have contribute to the development of new antibiotic , diagnostic tool , vaccine , medical treatment , and environmental cleanup technique .
the field of transcriptomic be the science of the entire collection of mrna molecule produce by cell .
scientist compare gene expression pattern between infected and uninfected host cell , gain important information about the cellular response to infectious disease .
additionally , transcriptomic can be use to monitor the gene expression of virulence factor in microorganism , aid scientist in well understand pathogenic process from this viewpoint .
when genomic and transcriptomic be apply to entire microbial community , - pron - use the term metagenomic and metatranscriptomic , respectively .
metagenomic and metatranscriptomic allow researcher to study gene and gene expression from a collection of multiple specie , many of which may not be easily culture or culture at all in the laboratory .
a dna microarray ( discuss in the previous section ) can be use in metagenomic study .
another up - and - come clinical application of genomic and transcriptomic be pharmacogenomic , also call toxicogenomic , which involve evaluate the effectiveness and safety of drug on the basis of information from an individual 's genomic sequence .
genomic response to drug can be study use experimental animal ( such as laboratory rat or mouse ) or live cell in the laboratory before embark on study with human .
change in gene expression in the presence of a drug can sometimes be an early indicator of the potential for toxic effect .
personal genome sequence information may someday be use to prescribe medication that will be most effective and least toxic on the basis of the individual patient 's genotype .
the study of proteomic be an extension of genomic that allow scientist to study the entire complement of protein in an organism , call the proteome .
even though all cell of a multicellular organism have the same set of gene , cell in various tissue produce different set of protein .
thus , the genome be constant , but the proteome vary and be four .

this emerge field of bioinformatic can be use , among many other application , for clue to treat disease and understand the working of cell .

five  four  one rna interference technology
in structure and function of rna , - pron - describe the function of mrna , rrna , and trna .
in addition to these type of rna , cell also produce several type of small noncoding rna molecule that be involve in the regulation of gene expression .
these include antisense rna molecule , which be complementary to region of specific mrna molecule find in both prokaryote and eukaryotic cell .
non - coding rna molecule play a major role in rna interference ( rnai ) , a natural regulatory mechanism by which mrna molecule be prevent from guide the synthesis of protein .
rna interference of specific gene result from the base pairing of short , single - strand antisense rna molecule to region within complementary mrna molecule , prevent protein synthesis .
cell use rna interference to protect - pron - from viral invasion , which may introduce double - strand rna molecule as part of the viral replication process ( figure one  two  .  two  seven ) .
figure one  two  .  two  seven cell like the eukaryotic cell show in this diagram commonly make small antisense rna molecule with sequence complementary to specific mrna molecule .
when an antisense rna molecule be bind to an mrna molecule , the mrna can no longer be use to direct protein synthesis .
( credit  modification of work by robinson r )
researcher be currently develop technique to mimic the natural process of rna interference as a way to treat viral infection in eukaryotic cell .
rna interference technology involve use small interfering rna ( sirnas ) or microrna ( mirnas )
( figure one  two  .  two  eight ) .
sirnas be completely complementary to the mrna transcript of a specific gene of interest while mirna be mostly complementary .
these double - strand rna be bind to dicer , an endonuclease that cleave the rna into short molecule ( approximately two  zero nucleotide long ) .
the rnas be then bind to rna - induce silence complex ( risc ) , a ribonucleoprotein .
the sirna - risc complex bind to mrna and cleave - pron - .
for mirna , only one of the two strand bind to risc .
the mirna - risc complex then bind to mrna , inhibit translation .
if the mirna be completely complementary to the target gene , then the mrna can be cleave .
take together , these mechanism be know as gene silencing .

summarize the mechanism , risk , and potential benefit of gene therapy 
identify ethical issue involve gene therapy and the regulatory agency that provide oversight for clinical trial  compare
somatic - cell and germ - line gene therapy
many type of genetic engineering have yield clear benefit with few apparent risk .
few would question , for example , the value of - pron - now abundant supply of human insulin produce by genetically engineer bacteria .
however , many emerging application of genetic engineering be much more controversial , often because - pron - potential benefit be pit against significant risk , real or perceive .
this be certainly the case for gene therapy , a clinical application of genetic engineering that may one day provide a cure for many disease but be still largely an experimental approach to treatment .
mechanisms and risks of gene therapy human disease that result from genetic mutation be often difficult to treat with drug or other traditional form of therapy because the sign and symptom of disease result from abnormality in a patient 's genome .
for example , a patient may have a genetic mutation that prevent the expression of a specific protein require for the normal function of a particular cell type .
this be the case in patient with severe combined immunodeficiency ( scid ) , a genetic disease that impair the function of certain white blood cell essential to the immune system .
gene therapy attempt to correct genetic abnormality by introduce a nonmutated , functional gene into the patient 's genome .
the nonmutated gene encode a functional protein that the patient would otherwise be unable to produce .
viral vector such as adenovirus be sometimes use to introduce the functional gene  part of the viral genome be chapter one  two  modern applications of microbial genetics five  four  three remove and replace with the desire gene ( figure one  two  .  two  nine ) .
more advanced form of gene therapy attempt to correct the mutation at the original site in the genome , such as be the case with treatment of scid .
figure one  two  .  two  nine gene therapy use an adenovirus vector can be use to treat or cure certain genetic disease in which a patient have a defective gene .
( credit  modification of work by national institutes of health )
so far , gene therapy have prove relatively ineffective , with the possible exception of treatment for cystic fibrosis and adenosine deaminase deficiency , a type of scid .
other trial have show the clear hazard of attempt genetic manipulation in complex multicellular organism like human .
in some patient , the use of an adenovirus vector can trigger an unanticipated inflammatory response from the immune system , which may lead to organ failure .
moreover , because virus can often target multiple cell type , the virus vector may infect cell not target for the therapy , damage these other cell and possibly lead to illness such as cancer .
another potential risk be that the modified virus could revert to be infectious and cause disease in the patient .
lastly , there be a risk that the insert gene could unintentionally inactivate another important gene in the patient 's genome , disrupt normal cell cycling and possibly lead to tumor formation and cancer .
because gene therapy involve so many risk , candidate for gene therapy need to be fully inform of these risk before provide informed consent to undergo the therapy .
gene therapy go wrong
the risk of gene therapy be realize in the one  nine  nine  nine case of jesse gelsinger , an one  eight  - year - old patient who receive gene therapy as part of a clinical trial at the university of pennsylvania .
jesse receive gene therapy for a condition call ornithine transcarbamylase ( otc ) deficiency , which lead to ammonia accumulation in the blood due to deficient ammonia processing .
four day after the treatment , jesse die after a massive immune response to the adenovirus vector . [ one  zero ] until that point , researcher have not really consider an immune response to the vector to be a legitimate risk , but on investigation , - pron - appear that the researcher have some evidence suggest that this be a possible outcome .
prior to jesse 's treatment , several other human patient have suffer side effect of the treatment , and three monkey use in a trial have die as a result of inflammation and clot disorder .
despite this information , - pron - appear that neither jesse nor - pron - family be make aware of these outcome when - pron - consent to the therapy .
jesse 's death be the first patient death due to a gene therapy treatment and result in the immediate halting of the clinical trial in which - pron - be involve , the subsequent halting of all other case in point five  four  four chapter one  two  modern applications of microbial genetics
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five gene therapy trial at the university of pennsylvania , and the investigation of all other gene therapy trial in the united states .
as a result , the regulation and oversight of gene therapy overall be reexamine , result in new regulatory protocol that be still in place today .

oversight of gene therapy
presently , there be significant oversight of gene therapy clinical trial .
at the federal level , three agency regulate gene therapy in parallel  the food and drug administration ( fda ) , the office of human research protection ( ohrp ) , and the recombinant dna advisory committee ( rac ) at the national institutes of health ( nih ) .
along with several local agency , these federal agency interact with the institutional review board to ensure that protocol be in place to protect patient safety during clinical trial .
compliance with these protocol be enforce mostly on the local level in cooperation with the federal agency .
gene therapy be currently under the most extensive federal and local review compare to other type of therapy , which be more typically only under the review of the fda .
some researcher believe that these extensive regulation actually inhibit progress in gene therapy research .
in two  zero  one  three , the institute of medicine ( now the national academy of medicine ) call upon the nih to relax - pron - review of gene therapy trial in most cases . [ one  one ]
however , ensure patient safety continue to be of utmost concern .
ethical concerns beyond the health risk of gene therapy , the ability to genetically modify human pose a number of ethical issue relate to the limit of such “ therapy .
"
while current research be focus on gene therapy for genetic disease , scientist may one day apply these method to manipulate other genetic trait not perceive as desirable .
this raise question such as   which genetic trait be worthy of be " correct " ?

should gene therapy be use for cosmetic reason or to enhance human ability ?

should genetic manipulation be use to impart desirable trait to the unborn ?

be everyone entitle to gene therapy , or could the cost of gene therapy create new form of social inequality ?

who should be responsible for regulate and police inappropriate use of gene therapy ?
the ability to alter reproductive cell use gene therapy could also generate new ethical dilemma .
to date , the various type of gene therapy have be target to somatic cell , the non - reproductive cell within the body .
because somatic cell trait be not inherit , any genetic change accomplish by somatic - cell gene therapy would not be pass on to offspring .
however , should scientist successfully introduce new gene to germ cell ( egg or sperm ) , the result trait could be pass on to offspring .
this approach , call germ - line gene therapy , could potentially be use to combat heritable disease , but - pron - could also lead to unintended consequence for future generation .
moreover , there be the question of informed consent , because those impact by germ - line gene therapy one  zero .

for these reason , the u . s . government do not currently fund research project investigate germ - line gene therapy in human .
risky gene therapies
while there be currently no gene therapy on the market in the united states , many be in the pipeline and - pron - be likely that some will eventually be approve .
with recent advance in gene therapy target p five  three , a gene whose somatic cell mutation have be implicate in over five  zero % of human cancers , [ one  two ] cancer treatment through gene therapy could become much more widespread once - pron - reach the commercial market .
bring any new therapy to market pose ethical question that pit the expect benefit against the risk .
how quickly should new therapy be bring to the market ?
how can - pron - ensure that new therapy have be sufficiently test for safety and effectiveness before - pron - be market to the public ?
the process by which new therapy be develop and approve complicate such question , as those involve in the approval process be often under significant pressure to get a new therapy approve even in the face of significant risk .
to receive fda approval for a new therapy , researcher must collect significant laboratory datum from animal trial and submit an investigational new drug ( ind ) application to the fda 's center for drug evaluation and research ( cder ) .
follow a three  zero  - day wait period during which the fda review the ind , clinical trial involve human subject may begin .
if the fda perceive a problem prior to or during the clinical trial , the fda can order a “ clinical hold " until any problem be address .
during clinical trial , researcher collect and analyze datum on the therapy 's effectiveness and safety , include any side effect observe .
once the therapy meet fda standard for effectiveness and safety , the developer can submit a new drug application ( nda ) that detail how the therapy will be manufacture , package , monitor , and administer .
because new gene therapy be frequently the result of many year ( even decade ) of laboratory and clinical research , - pron - require a significant financial investment .
by the time a therapy have reach the clinical trial stage , the financial stake be high for pharmaceutical company and - pron - shareholder .
this create potential conflict of interest that can sometimes affect the objective judgment of researcher , - pron - funder , and even trial participant .
the jesse gelsinger case ( see case in point  gene therapy go wrong ) be a classic example .
face with a life - threaten disease and no reasonable treatment available , - pron - be easy to see why a patient may be eager to participate in a clinical trial no matter the risk .
- pron - be also easy to see how a researcher may view the short - term risk for a small group of study participant as a small price to pay for the potential benefit of a game - change new treatment .
gelsinger 's death lead to increase scrutiny of gene therapy , and subsequent negative outcome of gene therapy have result in the temporary halting of clinical trial pende further investigation .
for example , when child in france treat with gene therapy for scid begin to develop leukemia several year after treatment , the fda temporarily stop clinical trial of similar type of gene therapy occur in the united states . [ one  three ] case like these highlight the need for researcher and health professional not only to value human wellbeing and patient ' right over profitability , but also to maintain scientific objectivity when evaluate the risk and benefit of new therapy .

summary one  two  .  one microbes and the tool of genetic engineering  biotechology be the science of utilize living system to benefit humankind .
in recent year , the ability to directly alter an organism 's genome through genetic engineering have be make possible due to advance in recombinant dna technology , which allow researcher to create recombinant dna molecule with new combination of genetic material .

molecular cloning involve method use to construct recombinant dna and facilitate - pron - replication in host organism .
these method include the use of restriction enzyme ( to cut both foreign dna and plasmid vector ) , ligation ( to paste fragment of dna together ) , and the introduction of recombinant dna into a host organism ( often bacteria ) .

blue - white screening allow selection of bacterial transformant that contain recombinant plasmid use the phenotype of a reporter gene that be disable by insertion of the dna fragment .

genomic library can be make by clone genomic fragment from one organism into plasmid vector or into bacteriophage .
 cdna library can be generate to represent the mrna molecule express in a cell at a give point .

transfection of eukaryotic host can be achieve through various method use electroporation , gene gun , microinjection , shuttle vector , and viral vector .
one  two  .  two visualizing and characterizing dna , rna , and protein

find a gene of interest within a sample require the use of a single - strand dna probe label with a molecular beacon ( typically radioactivity or fluorescence ) that can hybridize with a complementary singlestranded nucleic acid in the sample .

agarose gel electrophoresis allow for the separation of dna molecule base on size .

restriction fragment length polymorphism ( rflp ) analysis allow for the visualization by agarose gel electrophoresis of distinct variant of a dna sequence cause by difference in restriction site .

southern blot analysis allow researcher to find a particular dna sequence within a sample whereas northern blot analysis allow researcher to detect a particular mrna sequence express in a sample .

microarray technology be a nucleic acid hybridization technique that allow for the examination of many thousand of gene at once to find difference in gene or gene expression pattern between two sample of genomic dna or cdna ,  polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis ( page ) allow for the separation of protein by size , especially if native protein charge be mask through pretreatment with sds .

polymerase chain reaction allow for the rapid amplification of a specific dna sequence .
variation of pcr can be use to detect mrna expression ( reverse transcriptase pcr ) or to quantify a particular sequence in the original sample ( real - time pcr ) .

although the development of sanger dna sequencing be revolutionary , advance in next generation sequence allow for the rapid and inexpensive sequencing of the genome of many organism , accelerate the volume of new sequence datum .

the science of genomic allow researcher to study organism on a holistic level and have many application of medical relevance .

the various –omic technology complement each other and together provide a more complete picture of an organism 's or microbial community 's ( metagenomic ) state .

the analysis require for large datum set produce through genomic , transcriptomic , and proteomic have lead to the emergence of bioinformatic .

how clean be clean ?
people wash - pron - car and vacuum the carpet , but most would not want to eat from these surface .
similarly , - pron - may eat with silverware clean in a dishwasher , but - pron - could not use the same dishwasher to clean surgical instrument .

car washing , vacuum , and dishwashe all reduce the microbial load on the item treat , thus make - pron - “ clean .

but whether - pron - be " clean enough ” depend on - pron - intend use .

likewise , because silverware be not use for invasive surgery , these utensil do not require the same level of cleanliness as surgical equipment , which require sterilization to prevent infection .
why not play - pron - safe and sterilize everything ?
sterilize everything - pron - come in contact with be impractical , as well as potentially dangerous .

therefore , the user must consider the item 's intend application when choose a cleaning method to ensure that - pron - be " clean enough .

inanimate item , such as doorknob , toy , or towel , which may harbor microbe and aid in disease transmission , be call fomite .
two factor heavily influence the level of cleanliness require for a particular fomite and , hence , the protocol choose to achieve this level .
the first factor be the application for which the item will be use .
for example , invasive application that require insertion into the human body require a much high level of cleanliness than application that do not .
the second factor be the level of resistance to antimicrobial treatment by potential pathogen .
for example , food preserve by can often become contaminate with the bacterium clostridium botulinum , which produce the neurotoxin that cause botulism .
because c . botulinum can produce endospore that can survive harsh condition , extreme temperature and pressure must be use to eliminate the endospore .
other organism may not require such extreme measure and can be control by a procedure such as wash clothe in a laundry machine .
laboratory biological safety levels
for researcher or laboratory personnel work with pathogen , the risk associate with specific pathogen determine the level of cleanliness and control require .
the centers for disease control and prevention ( cdc ) and the national institutes of health ( nih ) have establish four classification level , call " biological safety level " ( bsl ) .
various organization around the world , include the world health organization ( who ) and the european union ( eu ) , use a similar classification scheme .
accord to the cdc , the bsl be determine by the agent 's infectivity , ease of transmission , and potential disease severity , as well as the type of work be do with the agent . [ two ]
each bsl require a different level of biocontainment to prevent contamination and spread of infectious agent to laboratory personnel and , ultimately , the community .
for example , the low bsl , bsl -  one , require the few part one roberta be a four  six  - year - old real estate agent who recently undergo a cholecystectomy ( surgery to remove painful gallstone ) .
the surgery be perform laparoscopically with the aid of a duodenoscope , a specialized endoscope that allow surgeon to see inside the body with the aid of a tiny camera .
on return home from the hospital , roberta develop abdominal pain and a high fever .
- pron - also experience a burning sensation during urination and noticed blood in - pron - urine .
- pron - notify - pron - surgeon of these symptom , per - pron - postoperative instruction .

agent classify as bsl -  two include those that pose moderate risk to laboratory worker and the community , and be typically “ indigenous , " mean that - pron - be commonly find in that geographical area .

bsl -  one laboratory may also have an autoclave .
bsl -  three agent have the potential to cause lethal infection by inhalation .
these may be either indigenous or “ exotic , " mean that - pron - be derive from a foreign location , and include pathogen such as mycobacterium tuberculosis , bacillus anthracis , west nile virus , and human immunodeficiency virus ( hiv ) .

laboratory worker be under medical surveillance , possibly receive vaccination for the microbe with which - pron - work .
in addition to the standard ppe already mention , laboratory personnel in bsl -  three laboratory must also wear a respirator and work with microbe and infectious agent in a biological safety cabinet at all time .
bsl -  three laboratory require a handsfree sink , an eyewash station near the exit , and two set of self - close and lock door at the entrance .
these laboratory be equip with directional airflow , mean that clean air be pull through the laboratory from clean area to potentially contaminate area .
this air can not be recirculate , so a constant supply of clean air be require .
bsl -  four agent be the most dangerous and often fatal .
these microbe be typically exotic , be easily transmit by inhalation , and cause infection for which there be no treatment or vaccination .
example include ebola virus and marburg virus , both of which cause hemorrhagic fever , and smallpox virus .
there be only a small number of laboratory in the united states and around the world appropriately equip to work with these agent .
in addition to bsl -  three precaution , laboratory worker in bsl -  four facility must also change - pron - clothing on enter the laboratory , shower on exit , and decontaminate all material on exit .
while work in the laboratory , - pron - must either wear a full - body protective suit with a designate air supply or conduct all work within a biological safety cabinet with a high - efficiency particulate air ( hepa ) - filtered air supply and a doubly hepa - filter exhaust .
if wear a suit , the air pressure within the suit must be high than that outside the suit , so that if a leak in the suit occur , laboratory air that may be contaminate can not be draw into the suit ( figure one  three  .  two ) .
the laboratory - pron - must be locate either in a separate building or in an isolated portion of a building and have - pron - own air supply and exhaust system , as well as - pron - own decontamination system .

sterilization
the most extreme protocol for microbial control aim to achieve sterilization  the complete removal or killing of all vegetative cell , endospore , and virus from the target item or environment .
sterilization protocol be generally reserve for laboratory , medical , manufacturing , and food industry setting , where - pron - may be imperative for certain item to be completely free of potentially infectious agent .
sterilization can be accomplish through either physical link to learn chapter one  three  control of microbial growth five  five  seven mean , such as exposure to high heat , pressure , or filtration through an appropriate filter , or by chemical mean .
chemical that can be use to achieve sterilization be call sterilant .
sterilant effectively kill all microbe and virus , and , with appropriate exposure time , can also kill endospore .
for many clinical purpose , aseptic technique be necessary to prevent contamination of sterile surface .
aseptic technique involve a combination of protocol that collectively maintain sterility , or asepsis , thus prevent contamination of the patient with microbe and infectious agent .
failure to practice aseptic technique during many type of clinical procedure may introduce microbe to the patient 's body and put the patient at risk for sepsis , a systemic inflammatory response to an infection that result in high fever , increase heart and respiratory rate , shock , and , possibly , death .
medical procedure that carry risk of contamination must be perform in a sterile field , a designate area that be keep free of all vegetative microbe , endospore , and virus .
sterile field be create accord to protocol require the use of sterilize material , such as packaging and draping , and strict procedure for washing and application of sterilant .
other protocol be follow to maintain the sterile field while the medical procedure be be perform .
one food sterilization protocol , commercial sterilization , use heat at a temperature low enough to preserve food quality but high enough to destroy common pathogen responsible for food poisoning , such as c . botulinum .
because c . botulinum and - pron - endospore be commonly find in soil , - pron - may easily contaminate crop during harvesting , and these endospore can later germinate within the anaerobic environment once food be can .
metal can of food contaminate with c . botulinum will bulge due to the microbe 's production of gas  contaminated jar of food typically bulge at the metal lid .
to eliminate the risk for c . botulinum contamination , commercial food - can protocol be design with a large margin of error .
- pron - assume an impossibly large population of endospore ( one  zero  one  two per can ) and aim to reduce this population to one endospore per can to ensure the safety of canned food .
for example , low - and medium - acid food be heat to one  two  one ° c for a minimum of two  .  five  two minute , which be the time - pron - would take to reduce a population of one  zero  one  two endospore per can down to one endospore at this temperature .
even so , commercial sterilization do not eliminate the presence of all microbe  rather , - pron - target those pathogen that cause spoilage and foodborne disease , while allow many nonpathogenic organism to survive .
therefore , “ sterilization " be somewhat of a misnomer in this context , and commercial sterilization may be more accurately describe as " quasi - sterilization .
"

what be the difference between sterilization and aseptic technique ?
the association of surgical technologists publish standard ( https / / openstax . org / l /  two  two aststanasepte ) for aseptic technique , include create and maintain a sterile field .
other methods of control sterilization protocol require procedure that be not practical , or necessary , in many setting .
various other method be use in clinical and nonclinical setting to reduce the microbial load on item .
although the term for these method be often use interchangeably , there be important distinction ( figure one  three  .  four ) .
the process of disinfection inactivate most microbe on the surface of a fomite by use antimicrobial chemical or heat .
because some microbe remain , the disinfected item be not consider sterile .
ideally , disinfectant should be fast act , stable , easy to prepare , inexpensive , and easy to use .
an example of a natural disinfectant be vinegar  - pron - link to learning five  five  eight chapter one  three

chemical disinfectant , such as chlorine bleach or product contain chlorine , be use to clean nonliving surface such as laboratory bench , clinical surface , and bathroom sink .
typical disinfection do not lead to sterilization because endospore tend to survive even when all vegetative cell have be kill .
unlike disinfectant , antiseptic be antimicrobial chemical safe for use on live skin or tissue .
example of antiseptic include hydrogen peroxide and isopropyl alcohol .
the process of apply an antiseptic be call antisepsis .
in addition to the characteristic of a good disinfectant , antiseptic must also be selectively effective against microorganism and able to penetrate tissue deeply without cause tissue damage .
the type of protocol require to achieve the desire level of cleanliness depend on the particular item to be clean .
for example , those use clinically be categorize as critical , semicritical , and noncritical .
critical item must be sterile because - pron - will be use inside the body , often penetrate sterile tissue or the bloodstream  example of critical item include surgical instrument , catheter , and intravenous fluid .
gastrointestinal endoscope and various type of equipment for respiratory therapy be example of semicritical item  - pron - may contact mucous membrane or nonintact skin but do not penetrate tissue .
semicritical item do not typically need to be sterilize but do require a high level of disinfection .
item that may contact but not penetrate intact skin be noncritical item  example be bed linen , furniture , crutch , stethoscope , and blood pressure cuff .
these article need to be clean but not highly disinfected .
the act of handwash be an example of degerme , in which microbial number be significantly reduce by gently scrub living tissue , most commonly skin , with a mild chemical ( e . g . , soap ) to avoid the transmission of pathogenic microbe .
wipe the skin with an alcohol swab at an injection site be another example of degerme .
these degerming method remove most ( but not all ) microbe from the skin 's surface .
the term sanitization refer to the cleansing of fomite to remove enough microbe to achieve level deem safe for public health .
for example , commercial dishwasher use in the food service industry typically use very hot water and air for washing and drying  the high temperature kill most microbe , sanitize the dish .
surface in hospital room be commonly sanitize use a chemical disinfectant to prevent disease transmission between patient .

measure microbial control physical and chemical method of microbial control that kill the target microorganism be identify by the suffix - cide ( or - cidal ) .
the prefix indicate the type of microbe or infectious agent kill by the treatment method  bactericide kill bacteria , viricide kill or inactivate virus , and fungicide kill fungi .
other method do not kill organism but , instead , stop - pron - growth , make - pron - population static  such method be identify by the suffix - stat ( or - static ) .
for example , bacteriostatic treatment inhibit the growth of bacteria , whereas fungistatic treatment inhibit the growth of fungi .
factor that determine whether a particular treatment be - cidal or - static include the type of microorganism target , the concentration of the chemical use , and the nature of the treatment apply .
although - static treatment do not actually kill infectious agent , - pron - be often less toxic to human and other animal , and may also better preserve the integrity of the item treat .
such treatment be typically sufficient to keep the microbial population of an item in check .
the reduced toxicity of some of these - static chemical also allow - pron - to be impregnate safely into plastic to prevent the growth of microbe on these surface .
such plastic be use in product such as toy for child and cut board for food preparation .
when use to treat an infection , - static treatment be typically sufficient in an otherwise healthy individual , prevent the pathogen from multiply , thus allow the individual 's immune system to clear the infection .
the degree of microbial control can be evaluate use a microbial death curve to describe the progress and effectiveness of a particular protocol .
when expose to a particular microbial control protocol , a fix percentage of the microbe within the population will die .
because the rate of killing remain constant even when the population size vary , the percentage kill be more useful information than the absolute number of microbe kill .
death curve be often plot as semilog plot just like microbial growth curve because the reduction in microorganism be typically logarithmic ( figure one  three  .  five ) .
the amount of time - pron - take for a specific protocol to produce a one orderof - magnitude decrease in the number of organism , or the death of nine  zero % of the population , be call the decimal reduction time ( drt ) or d - value .

five  six  one figure one  three  .  five microbial death be logarithmic and easily observe use a semilog plot instead of an arithmetic one .
the decimal reduction time ( d - value ) be the time - pron - take to kill nine  zero % of the population ( a one  - log decrease in the total population ) when expose to a specific microbial control protocol , as indicate by the purple bracket .
several factor contribute to the effectiveness of a disinfect agent or microbial control protocol .
first , as demonstrate in figure one  three  .  five , the length of time of exposure be important .
long exposure time kill more microbe .
because microbial death of a population expose to a specific protocol be logarithmic , - pron - take longer to kill a high - population load than a low - population load expose to the same protocol .
a short treatment time ( measure in multiple of the d - value ) be need when start with a small number of organism .
effectiveness also depend on the susceptibility of the agent to that disinfect agent or protocol .
the concentration of disinfect agent or intensity of exposure be also important .
for example , high temperature and high concentration of disinfectant kill microbe more quickly and effectively .
condition that limit contact between the agent and the targeted cell cell - for example , the presence of bodily fluid , tissue , organic debris ( e . g . , mud or fece ) , or biofilm on surface - increase the cleaning time or intensity of the microbial control protocol require to reach the desire level of cleanliness .
all these factor must be consider when choose the appropriate protocol to control microbial growth in a give situation .

many of these method nonspecifically kill cell by disrupt membrane , change membrane permeability , or damage protein and nucleic acid by denaturation , degradation , or chemical modification .
various physical method use for microbial control be describe in this section .
heat heating be one of the most common - and old - form of microbial control .
- pron - be use in simple technique like cooking and canning .
heat can kill microbe by alter - pron - membrane and denature protein .
the thermal death point ( tdp ) of a microorganism be the low temperature at which all microbe be kill in a one  zero  - minute exposure .
different microorganism will respond differently to high temperature , with some ( e . g . , endospore - former such as c . botulinum ) be more heat tolerant .
a similar parameter , the thermal death time ( tdt ) , be the length of time need to kill all microorganism in a sample at a give temperature .
these parameter be often use to describe sterilization procedure that use high heat , such as autoclave .
boiling be one of the old method of moist - heat control of microbe , and - pron - be typically quite effective at kill vegetative cell and some virus .
however , boiling be less effective at kill endospore  some endospore be able to survive up to two  zero hour of boiling .
additionally , boiling may be less effective at high altitude , where the boiling point of water be low and the boiling time need to kill microbe be therefore long .
for these reason , boil be not consider a useful sterilization technique in the laboratory or clinical setting .
many different heating protocol can be use for sterilization in the laboratory or clinic , and these protocol can be break down into two main category  dry - heat sterilization and moist - heat sterilization .
aseptic technique in the laboratory typically involve some dry - heat sterilization protocol use direct application of high heat , such as sterilize inoculate loop ( figure one  three  .  six ) .
incineration at very high temperature destroy all microorganism .
dry heat can also be apply for relatively long period of time ( at least two hour ) at temperature up to one  seven  zero ° c by use a dry - heat sterilizer , such as an oven .
however , moist - heat sterilization be typically the more effective protocol because - pron - penetrate cell well than dry heat do .

( b )

five  six  three autoclave autoclaves rely on moist - heat sterilization .
- pron - be use to raise temperature above the boiling point of water to sterilize item such as surgical equipment from vegetative cell , virus , and especially endospore , which be know to survive boiling temperature , without damage the item .
charles chamberland ( one  eight  five  one – one  nine  zero  eight ) design the modern autoclave in one  eight  seven  nine while work in the laboratory of louis pasteur .
the autoclave be still consider the most effective method of sterilization ( figure one  three  .  seven ) .
outside laboratory and clinical setting , large industrial autoclave call retort allow for moist - heat sterilization on a large scale .
in general , the air in the chamber of an autoclave be remove and replace with increase amount of steam trap within the enclosed chamber , result in increase interior pressure and temperature above the boiling point of water .
the two main type of autoclave differ in the way that air be remove from the chamber .
in gravity displacement autoclave , steam be introduce into the chamber from the top or side .
air , which be heavy than steam , sink to the bottom of the chamber , where - pron - be force out through a vent .
complete displacement of air be difficult , especially in large load , so long cycle may be require for such load .
in prevacuum sterilizer , air be remove completely use a high - speed vacuum before introduce steam into the chamber .
because air be more completely eliminate , the steam can more easily penetrate wrap item .
many autoclave be capable of both gravity and prevacuum cycle , use the former for the decontamination of waste and sterilization of medium and unwrapped glassware , and the latter for sterilization of package instrument .

standard operating temperature for autoclave be one  two  one ° c or , in some case , one  three  two ° c , typically at a pressure of one  five to two  zero pound per square inch ( psi ) .
the length of exposure depend on the volume and nature of material be sterilize , but - pron - be typically two  zero minute or more , with large volume require longer exposure time to ensure sufficient heat transfer to the material be sterilize .
the steam must directly contact the liquid or dry material be sterilize , so container be leave loosely closed and instrument be loosely wrap in paper or foil .
the key to autoclave be that the temperature must be high enough to kill endospore to achieve complete sterilization .
because sterilization be so important to safe medical and laboratory protocol , quality control be essential .
autoclave may be equip with recorder to document the pressure and temperature achieve during each run .
additionally , internal indicator of various type should be autoclave along with the material to be sterilize to ensure that the proper sterilization temperature have be reach ( figure one  three  .  eight ) .
one common type of indicator be the use of heat - sensitive autoclave tape , which have white stripe that turn black when the appropriate temperature be achieve five  six  four chapter one  three  control of microbial growth
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five during a successful autoclave run .
this type of indicator be relatively inexpensive and can be use during every run .
however , autoclave tape provide no indication of length of exposure , so - pron - can not be use as an indicator of sterility .
another type of indicator , a biological indicator spore test , use either a strip of paper or a liquid suspension of the endospore of geobacillus stearothermophilus to determine whether the endospore be kill by the process .
the endospore of the obligate thermophilic bacterium g . stearothermophilus be the gold standard use for this purpose because of - pron - extreme heat resistance .
biological spore indicator can also be use to test the effectiveness of other sterilization protocol , include ethylene oxide , dry heat , formaldehyde , gamma radiation , and hydrogen peroxide plasma sterilization use either g . stearothermophilus , bacillus atrophaeus , b . subtili , or b . pumilus spore .
in the case of validate autoclave function , the endospore be incubate after autoclave to ensure no viable endospore remain .
bacterial growth subsequent to endospore germination can be monitor by biological indicator spore test that detect acid metabolite or fluorescence produce by enzyme derive from viable g . stearothermophilus .
a third type of autoclave indicator be the diack tube , a glass ampule contain a temperature - sensitive pellet that melt at the proper sterilization temperature .
spore strip or diack tube be use periodically to ensure the autoclave be function properly .
