pasteurization
although complete sterilization be ideal for many medical application , - pron - be not always practical for other application and may also alter the quality of the product .
boiling and autoclaving be not ideal way to control microbial growth in many food because these method may ruin the consistency and other organoleptic ( sensory ) quality of the food .
pasteurization be a form of microbial control for food that use heat but do not render the food sterile .
traditional pasteurization kill pathogen and reduce the number of spoilage - cause microbe while maintain food quality .
the process of pasteurization be first develop by louis pasteur in the one  eight  six  zero s as a method for prevent the spoilage of beer and wine .
today , pasteurization be most commonly use to kill heat - sensitive pathogen in milk and other food product ( e . g . , apple juice and honey )
( figure one  three  .  nine ) .
however , because pasteurized food product be not sterile , - pron - will eventually spoil .
chapter one  three  control of microbial growth five  six  five
the method use for milk pasteurization balance the temperature and the length of time of treatment .
one method , high - temperature short - time ( htst ) pasteurization , expose milk to a temperature of seven  two ° c for one  five second , which lower bacterial number while preserve the quality of the milk .
an alternative be ultra - high - temperature ( uht ) pasteurization , in which the milk be expose to a temperature of one  three  eight ° c for two or more second .
uht pasteurized milk can be store for a long time in seal container without be refrigerate  however , the very high temperature alter the protein in the milk , cause slight change in the taste and smell .
still , this method of pasteurization be advantageous in region where access to refrigeration be limit .

refrigeration and freezing just as high temperature be effective for control microbial growth , expose microbe to low temperature can also be an easy and effective method of microbial control , with the exception of psychrophile , which prefer cold temperature ( see temperature and microbial growth ) .
refrigerator use in home kitchen or in the laboratory maintain temperature between zero ° c and seven ° c .
this temperature range inhibit microbial metabolism , slow the growth of microorganism significantly and help preserve refrigerated product such as food or medical supply .
certain type of laboratory culture can be preserve by refrigeration for later use .
freeze below − two ° c may stop microbial growth and even kill susceptible organism .
accord to the us department of agriculture ( usda ) , the only safe way that frozen food can be thaw be in the refrigerator , immerse in cold water change every three  zero minute , or in the microwave , keep the food at temperature not five  six  six chapter one  three  control of microbial growth

in clinical setting , hyperbaric oxygen therapy be sometimes use to treat infection .
in this form of therapy , a patient breathe pure oxygen at a pressure high than normal atmospheric pressure , typically between one and three atmosphere ( atm ) .
this be achieve by place the patient in a hyperbaric chamber or by supply the pressurize oxygen through a breathing tube .
hyperbaric oxygen therapy help increase oxygen saturation in tissue that become hypoxic due to infection and inflammation .
this increase oxygen concentration enhance the body 's immune response by increase the activity of neutrophil and macrophage , white blood cell that fight infection .
increase oxygen level also contribute to the formation of toxic free radical that inhibit the growth of oxygen - sensitive or anaerobic bacteria like as clostridium perfringen , a common cause of gas gangrene .
in c . perfringen infection , hyperbaric oxygen therapy can also reduce secretion of a bacterial toxin that cause tissue destruction .
hyperbaric oxygen therapy also seem to enhance the effectiveness of antibiotic treatment .
unfortunately , some rare risk include oxygen toxicity and effect on delicate tissue , such as the eye , middle ear , and lung , which may be damage by the increase air pressure .
high pressure processing be not commonly use for disinfection or sterilization of fomite .
although the application of pressure and steam in an autoclave be effective for kill endospore , - pron - be the high temperature achieve , and not the pressure directly , that result in endospore death .
a streak of bad potluck one monday in spring two  zero  one  five , an ohio woman begin to experience blur , double vision  difficulty swallowing  and droop eyelid .
- pron - be rush to the emergency department of - pron - local hospital .
during the examination , - pron - begin to experience abdominal cramping , nausea , paralysis , dry mouth , weakness of facial muscle , and difficulty speak and breathing .
base on these symptom , the hospital 's incident command center be activate , and ohio public health official be notify of a possible case of botulism .
meanwhile , other patient with similar symptom begin show up at other local hospital .
because of the suspicion of botulism , antitoxin be ship overnight from the cdc to these medical facility , to be administer to the affect patient .
the first patient die of respiratory failure as a result of paralysis , and about half of the remain victim require additional hospitalization follow antitoxin administration , with at least two require ventilator for breathing .
public health official investigate each of the case and determine that all of the patient have attend the same church potluck the day before .
moreover , - pron - trace the source of the outbreak to a potato salad make with home - can potato .
more than likely , the potato be can use boiling water , a method that allow endospore of clostridium botulinum to survive .
c . botulinum produce botulinum toxin , a neurotoxin that be often deadly once ingest .
accord to the cdc , the ohio case be the large botulism outbreak in the united states in nearly four  zero years . [ six ] killing c . botulinum endospore require a minimum temperature of one  one  six ° c ( two  four  zero ° f ) , well above the boiling point of water .
this temperature can only be reach in a pressure canner , which be recommend for home canning of low - acid food such as meat , fish , poultry , and vegetable ( figure one  three  .  one  one ) .
additionally , the cdc recommend boil home - can food for about one  zero minute before consumption .
since the botulinum toxin be heat labile ( mean that - pron - be denature by heat ) , one  zero minute of boiling will render nonfunctional any botulinum toxin that the food may contain .

desiccation drying , also know as desiccation or dehydration , be a method that have be use for millennium to preserve food such as raisin , prune , and jerky .
- pron - work because all cell , include microbe , require water for - pron - metabolism and survival .
although dry control microbial growth , - pron - may not kill all microbe or - pron - endospore , which may start to regrow when condition be more favorable and water content be restore .
in some case , food be dry in the sun , rely on evaporation to achieve desiccation .
freeze - dry , or lyophilization , be another method of dessication in which an item be rapidly frozen ( “ snap - frozen " ) and place under vacuum so that water be lose by sublimation .
lyophilization combine both exposure to cold temperature and desiccation , make - pron - quite effective for control microbial growth .
in addition , lyophilization cause less damage to an item than conventional desiccation and well preserve the item 's original quality .
lyophilize item may be store at room temperature if package appropriately to prevent moisture acquisition .
lyophilization be use for preservation in the food industry and be also use in the laboratory for the long - term storage and transportation of microbial culture .
the water content of food and material , call the water activity , can be lower without physical drying by the link to learning chapter one  three  control of microbial growth five  six  nine addition of solute such as salt or sugar .
at very high concentration of salt or sugar , the amount of available water in microbial cell be reduce dramatically because water will be draw from an area of low solute concentration ( inside the cell ) to an area of high solute concentration ( outside the cell )
( figure one  three  .  one  two ) .
many microorganism do not survive these condition of high osmotic pressure .
honey , for example , be eight  zero % sucrose , an environment in which very few microorganism be capable of grow , thereby eliminate the need for refrigeration .
salt meat and fish , like ham and cod , respectively , be critically important food before the age of refrigeration .
fruit be preserve by add sugar , make jam and jelly .
however , certain microbe , such as mold and yeast , tend to be more tolerant of desiccation and high osmotic pressure , and , thus , may still contaminate these type of food .

radiation radiation in various form , from high - energy radiation to sunlight , can be use to kill microbe or inhibit - pron - growth .
ionize radiation include x - ray , gamma ray , and high - energy electron beam .
ionize radiation be strong enough to pass into the cell , where - pron - alter molecular structure and damage cell component .
for example , ionize radiation introduce double - strand break in dna molecule .
this may directly cause dna mutation to occur , or mutation may be introduce when the cell attempt to repair the dna damage .
as these mutation accumulate , - pron - eventually lead to cell death .
both x - ray and gamma ray easily penetrate paper and plastic and can therefore be use to sterilize many package material .
in the laboratory , ionize radiation be commonly use to sterilize material that can not be autoclave , such as plastic petri dish and disposable plastic inoculating loop .
for clinical use , ionize radiation be use to sterilize glove , intravenous tubing , and other latex and plastic item use for patient care .
ionize radiation be also use for the sterilization of other type of delicate , heat - sensitive material use clinically , include tissue for transplantation , pharmaceutical drug , and medical equipment .
in europe , gamma irradiation for food preservation be widely use , although - pron - have be slow to catch on in the united states ( see the micro connections box on this topic ) .
package dry spice be also often gamma - irradiate .

these type of ionize irradiation can not penetrate thick layer of iron or lead , so these metal be commonly use to protect human who may be potentially expose .
another type of radiation , nonionize radiation , be commonly use for disinfection and use less energy than ionize radiation .
- pron - do not penetrate cell or packaging .
ultraviolet ( uv ) light be one example  - pron - cause thymine dimer to form between adjacent thymine within a single strand of dna ( figure one  three  .  one  three ) .
when dna polymerase encounter the thymine dimer , - pron - do not always incorporate the appropriate complementary nucleotide ( two adenine ) , and this lead to formation of mutation that can ultimately kill microorganism .
uv light can be use effectively by both consumer and laboratory personnel to control microbial growth .
uv lamp be now commonly incorporate into water purification system for use in home .
in addition , small portable uv light be commonly use by camper to purify water from natural environment before drink .
germicidal lamp be also use in surgical suite , biological safety cabinet , and transfer hood , typically emit uv light at a wavelength of two  six  zero nm .
because uv light do not penetrate surface and will not pass through plastic or glass , cell must be expose directly to the light source .
sunlight have a very broad spectrum that include uv and visible light .
in some case , sunlight can be effective against certain bacteria because of both the formation of thymine dimer by uv light and by the production of reactive oxygen product induce in low amount by exposure to visible light .

sonication
the use of high - frequency ultrasound wave to disrupt cell structure be call sonication .
application of ultrasound wave cause rapid change in pressure within the intracellular liquid  this lead to cavitation , the formation of bubble inside the cell , which can disrupt cell structure and eventually cause the cell to lyse or collapse .
sonication be useful in the laboratory for efficiently lyse cell to release - pron - content for further research  outside the laboratory , sonication be use for clean surgical instrument , lense , and a variety of other object such as coin , tool , and musical instrument .

biological safety cabinets biological safety cabinet be a good example of the use of hepa filter .
hepa filter in biological safety cabinet ( bsc ) be use to remove particulate in the air either enter the cabinet ( air intake ) , leave the cabinet ( air exhaust ) , or treat both the intake and exhaust .
use of an air - intake hepa filter prevent environmental contaminant from enter the bsc , create a clean area for handle biological material .
use of an air - exhaust hepa filter prevent laboratory pathogen from contaminate the laboratory , thus maintain a safe work area for laboratory personnel .
there be three class of bsc  i , ii , and iii .
each class be design to provide a different level of protection for laboratory personnel and the environment  bsc ii and iii be also design to protect the material or device in the cabinet .

in addition to physical method of microbial control , chemical be also use to control microbial growth .
a wide variety of chemical can be use as disinfectant or antiseptic .
when choose which to use , - pron - be important to consider the type of microbe target  how clean the item need to be  the disinfectant 's effect on the item 's integrity  - pron - safety to animal , human , and the environment  - pron - expense  and - pron - ease of use .

phenolic
in the one  eight  zero  zero , scientist begin experiment with a variety of chemical for disinfection .
in the one  eight  six  zero , british surgeon joseph lister ( one  eight  two  seven – one  nine  one  two ) begin use carbolic acid , know as phenol , as a disinfectant for the treatment of surgical wound ( see foundations of modern cell theory ) .
in one  eight  seven  nine , lister 's work inspire the american chemist joseph lawrence ( one  eight  three  six – one  nine  zero  nine ) to develop listerine , an alcohol - base mixture of several related compound that be still use today as an oral antiseptic .
today , carbolic acid be no longer use as a surgical disinfectant because - pron - be a skin irritant , but the chemical compound find in antiseptic mouthwash and throat lozenge be call phenolic .
chemically , phenol consist of a benzene ring with an –oh group , and phenolic be compound that have this group as part of - pron - chemical structure ( figure one  three  .  one  nine ) .
phenolic such as thymol and eucalyptol occur naturally in plant .
other phenolic can be derive from creosote , a component of coal tar .
phenolic tend to be stable , persistent on surface , and less toxic than phenol .
- pron - inhibit microbial growth by denature protein and disrupt membrane .

phisohex be particularly effective against gram - positive bacteria , include those cause staphylococcal and streptococcal skin infection .
phisohex be formerly use for bathe infant , but this practice have be discontinue because - pron - have be show that exposure to hexachlorophene can lead to neurological problem .
triclosan be another bisphenol compound that have see widespread application in antibacterial product over the last several decade .
initially use in toothpaste , triclosan be now commonly use in hand soap and be frequently impregnate into a wide variety of other product , include cutting board , knife , shower curtain , clothing , and concrete , to make - pron - antimicrobial .
- pron - be particularly effective against gram - positive bacteria on the skin , as well as certain gram - negative bacteria and yeasts . [ eight ]
triclosan  antibacterial overkill ?
hand soap and other cleaning product be often market as “ antibacterial , " suggest that - pron - provide a level of cleanliness superior to that of conventional soap and cleanser .
but be the antibacterial ingredient in these product really safe and effective ?
about seven  five % of antibacterial liquid hand soap and three  zero % of bar soap contain the chemical triclosan , a phenolic , ( figure one  three  .  two  zero  ) . [ nine ]
triclosan block an enzyme in the bacterial fatty acid - biosynthesis pathway that be not find in the comparable human pathway .
although the use of triclosan in the home increase dramatically during the one  nine  nine  zero , more than four  zero year of research by the fda have turn up no conclusive evidence that wash with triclosan - contain product provide increase health benefit compare with washing with traditional soap .
although some study indicate that few bacteria may remain on a person 's hand after wash with triclosan - base soap , compare with traditional soap , no evidence point to any reduction in the transmission of bacteria that cause respiratory and gastrointestinal illness .
in short , soap with triclosan may remove or kill a few more germ but not enough to reduce the spread of disease .
perhaps more disturbing , some clear risk associate with triclosan - base soap have come to light .
the widespread use of triclosan have lead to an increase in triclosan - resistant bacterial strain , include those of clinical importance , such as salmonella enterica  this resistance may render triclosan useless as an antibacterial in the long run . [ one  zero ][ one  one ] bacteria can easily gain resistance to triclosan through a change to a single micro connections eight .

use of triclosan over the last several decade have also lead to a buildup of the chemical in the environment .
triclosan in hand soap be directly introduce into wastewater and sewage system as a result of the handwashing process .
there , - pron - antibacterial property can inhibit or kill bacteria responsible for the decomposition of sewage , cause septic system to clog and back up .
eventually , triclosan in wastewater find - pron - way into surface water , stream , lake , sediment , and soil , disrupt natural population of bacteria that carry out important environmental function , such as inhibit algae .
triclosan also find - pron - way into the body of amphibian and fish , where - pron - can act as an endocrine disruptor .
detectable level of triclosan have also be find in various human bodily fluid , include breast milk , plasma , and urine . [ one  two ]
in fact , a study conduct by the cdc find detectable level of triclosan in the urine of seven  five % of two  ,  five  one  seven people test in two  zero  zero  three – two  zero  zero  four  . [ one  three ]
this finding be even more troubling give the evidence that triclosan may affect immune function in humans . [ one  four ]

heavy metal
some of the first chemical disinfectant and antiseptic to be use be heavy metal .
heavy metal kill microbe by bind to protein , thus inhibit enzymatic activity ( figure one  three  .  two  one ) .
heavy metal be oligodynamic , mean that very small concentration show significant antimicrobial activity .
ion of heavy metal bind to sulfur - contain amino acid strongly and bioaccumulate within cell , allow these metal to reach high localize concentration .
this cause protein to denature .
heavy metal be not selectively toxic to microbial cell .
- pron - may bioaccumulate in human or animal cell , as well , and excessive concentration can have toxic effect on human .
if too much silver accumulate in the body , for example , - pron - can result in a condition call argyria , in which the skin turn irreversibly blue - gray .
one way to reduce the potential toxicity of heavy metal be by carefully control the duration of exposure and concentration of the heavy metal .

mercury mercury be an example of a heavy metal that have be use for many year to control microbial growth .

- pron - be toxic to the central nervous , digestive , and renal system at high concentration , and have negative environmental effect , include bioaccumulation in fish .

however , because of concern about use mercury compound , these antiseptic be no longer sell in the united states .

chlorine be another halogen commonly use for disinfection .
when chlorine gas be mixed with water , - pron - produce a strong oxidant call hypochlorous acid , which be uncharged and enter cell easily .
chlorine gas be commonly use in municipal drinking water and wastewater treatment plant , with the result hypochlorous acid produce the actual antimicrobial effect .
those work at water treatment facility need to take great care to minimize personal exposure to chlorine gas .
sodium hypochlorite be the chemical component of common household bleach , and - pron - be also use for a wide variety of disinfect purpose .
hypochlorite salt , include sodium and calcium hypochlorite , be use to disinfect swimming pool .
chlorine gas , sodium hypochlorite , and calcium hypochlorite be also commonly use disinfectant in the food processing and restaurant industry to reduce the spread of foodborne disease .
worker in these industry also need to take care to use these product correctly to ensure - pron - own safety as well as the safety of consumer .
a recent joint statement publish by the food and agriculture organization ( fao ) of the united nations and who indicate that none of the many beneficial use of chlorine product in food processing to reduce the spread of foodborne illness pose risk to consumers . [ one  eight ]
another class of chlorinated compound call chloramine be widely use as disinfectant .
chloramine be relatively stable , release chlorine over long period time .
chloramine be derivative of ammonia by substitution of one , two , or all three hydrogen atom with chlorine atom ( figure one  three  .  two  three ) .
figure one  three  .  two  three monochloroamine , one of the chloramine , be derive from ammonia by the replacement of one hydrogen atom with a chlorine atom .
chloramine and other cholorine compound may be use for disinfection of drinking water , and chloramine tablet be frequently use by the military for this purpose .
after a natural disaster or other event that compromise the public water supply , the cdc recommend disinfect tap water by add small amount of regular household bleach .
recent research suggest that sodium dichloroisocyanurate ( nadcc ) may also be a good alternative for drinking water disinfection .
currently , nadcc tablet be available for general use and for use by the military , camper , or those with emergency need  for these use , nadcc be preferable to chloramine tablet .
chlorine dioxide , a gaseous agent use for fumigation and sterilization of enclose area , be also commonly use for the disinfection of water .

some may irritate the skin , nose , or eye of some individual , and - pron - may not completely eliminate certain hardy organism one  eight .

what be a benefit of a chloramine over hypochlorite for disinfecting ?
alcohols alcohol make up another group of chemical commonly use as disinfectant and antiseptic .
- pron - work by rapidly denature protein , which inhibit cell metabolism , and by disrupt membrane , which lead to cell lysis .
once denature , the protein may potentially refold if enough water be present in the solution .
alcohol be typically use at concentration of about seven  zero % aqueous solution and , in fact , work better in aqueous solution than one  zero  zero % alcohol solution .
this be because alcohol coagulate protein .
in high alcohol concentration , rapid coagulation of surface protein prevent effective penetration of cell .
the most commonly use alcohol for disinfection be ethyl alcohol ( ethanol ) and isopropyl alcohol ( isopropanol , rub alcohol )
( figure one  three  .  two  four ) .
alcohol tend to be bactericidal and fungicidal , but may also be viricidal for envelop virus only .
although alcohol be not sporicidal , - pron - do inhibit the process of sporulation and germination .
alcohol be volatile and dry quickly , but - pron - may also cause skin irritation because - pron - dehydrate the skin at the site of application .
one common clinical use of alcohol be swab the skin for degerme before needle injection .
alcohols also be the active ingredient in instant hand sanitizer , which have gain popularity in recent year .
the alcohol in these hand sanitizer work both by denature protein and by disrupt the microbial cell membrane , but will not work effectively in the presence of visible dirt .
last , alcohol be use to make tincture with other antiseptic , such as the iodine tincture discuss previously in this chapter .
all in all , alcohol be inexpensive and quite effective for the disinfection of a broad range of vegetative microbe .
however , one disadvantage of alcohol be - pron - high volatility , limit - pron - effectiveness to immediately after application .

surfactants surface - active agent , or surfactant , be a group of chemical compound that low the surface tension of water .
surfactant be the major ingredient in soap and detergent .
soap be salt of long - chain fatty acid and have both polar and nonpolar region , allow - pron - to interact with polar and nonpolar region in other molecule ( figure one  three  .  two  five ) .
- pron - can interact with nonpolar oil and grease to create emulsion in water , loosening and lift away dirt and microbe from surface and skin .
soap do not kill or inhibit microbial growth and so be not consider antiseptic or disinfectant .
however , proper use of soap mechanically carry away microorganism , effectively degerme a surface .
some soap contain add bacteriostatic agent such as triclocarban or cloflucarban , compound structurally relate to triclosan , that introduce antiseptic or disinfectant property to the soap .
figure one  three  .  two  five
soap be the salt ( sodium salt in the illustration ) of fatty acid and have the ability to emulsify lipid , fat , and oil by interact with water through - pron - hydrophilic head and with the lipid at - pron - hydrophobic tail .
soap , however , often form film that be difficult to rinse away , especially in hard water , which contain high concentration of calcium and magnesium mineral salt .
detergent contain synthetic surfactant molecule with both polar and nonpolar region that have strong cleansing activity but be more soluble , even in hard water , and , therefore , leave behind no soapy deposit .
anionic detergent , such as those use for laundry , have a negatively charge anion at one end attach to a long hydrophobic chain , whereas cationic detergent have a positively charge cation instead .

handwash the right way handwashing be critical for public health and should be emphasize in a clinical setting .

diehard prions prions , the acellular , misfolde protein responsible for incurable and fatal disease such as kuru and creutzfeldt - jakob disease ( see viroids , virusoid , and prions ) , be notoriously difficult to destroy .
prion be extremely resistant to heat , chemical , and radiation .
- pron - be also extremely infectious and deadly  thus , handling and dispose of prion - infect item require extensive training and extreme caution .
typical method of disinfection can reduce but not eliminate the infectivity of prion .
autoclaving be not completely effective , nor be chemical such as phenol , alcohol , formalin , and β - propiolactone .
even when fix in formalin , affect brain and spinal cord tissue remain infectious .

supercritical fluids
within the last one  five year , the use of supercritical fluid , especially supercritical carbon dioxide ( scco two ) , have gain popularity for certain sterilizing application .
when carbon dioxide be bring to approximately one  zero time atmospheric pressure , - pron - reach a supercritical state that have physical property between those of liquid and gas .
material put into a chamber in which carbon dioxide be pressurize in this way can be sterilize because of the ability of scco two to penetrate surface .
supercritical carbon dioxide work by penetrate cell and form carbonic acid , thereby lower the cell ph considerably .
this technique be effective against vegetative cell and be also use in combination with peracetic acid to kill endospore .
- pron - efficacy can also be augment with increase temperature or by rapid cycle of pressurization and depressurization , which more likely produce cell lysis .
benefit of scco two include the nonreactive , nontoxic , and nonflammable property of carbon dioxide , and this protocol be effective at low temperature .
unlike other method , such as heat and irradiation , that can degrade the object be sterilize , the use of scco two preserve the object 's integrity and be commonly use for treat food ( include spice and juice ) and medical device such as endoscope .
- pron - be also gain popularity for disinfect tissue such as skin , bone , tendon , and ligament prior to transplantation .
scco two can also be use for p control because - pron - can kill insect egg and larvae within product .

learning objectives
 describe why the phenol coefficient be use  compare and contrast the disk - diffusion , use - dilution , and in - use method for test the effectiveness of antiseptic , disinfectant , and sterilant the effectiveness of various chemical disinfectant be reflect in the term use to describe - pron - .
chemical disinfectant be group by the power of - pron - activity , with each category reflect the type of microbe and viruse - pron - component disinfectant be effective against .
high - level germicide have the ability to kill vegetative cell , fungus , virus , and endospore , lead to sterilization , with extended use .
intermediate - level germicide , as - pron - name suggest , be less effective against endospore and certain virus , and low - level germicide kill only vegetative cell and certain envelop virus , and be ineffective against endospore .
however , several environmental condition influence the potency of an antimicrobial agent and - pron - effectiveness .
for example , length of exposure be particularly important , with long exposure increase efficacy .
similarly , the concentration of the chemical agent be also important , with high concentration be more effective than low one .
temperature , ph , and other factor can also affect the potency of a disinfect agent .
one method to determine the effectiveness of a chemical agent include swab surface before and after use to confirm whether a sterile field be maintain during use .
additional test be describe in the section that follow .
these test allow for the maintenance of appropriate disinfection protocol in clinical setting , control microbial growth to protect patient , health - care worker , and the community .
phenol coefficient
the effectiveness of a disinfectant or antiseptic can be determine in a number of way .
historically , a chemical agent 's effectiveness be often compare with that of phenol , the first chemical agent use by joseph lister .
in one  nine  zero  three , british chemist samuel rideal ( one  eight  six  three – one  nine  two  nine ) and j . t . ainslie walker ( one  eight  six  eight – one  nine  three  zero ) establish a protocol to compare the effectiveness of a variety of chemical with that of phenol , use as - pron - test organism staphylococcus aureus ( a gram - positive bacterium ) and salmonella enterica serovar typhi ( a gram - negative bacterium ) .
- pron - expose the test bacteria to the antimicrobial chemical solution dilute in water for seven  .  five minute .
- pron - then calculate a phenol coefficient for each chemical for each of the two bacteria test .
a phenol coefficient of one  .  zero mean that the chemical agent have about the same level of effectiveness as phenol .
a chemical agent with a phenol coefficient of less than one  .  zero be less effective than phenol .
an example be formalin , with phenol coefficient of zero  .  three ( s . aureus ) and zero  .  seven ( s . enterica serovar typhi ) .
a chemical agent with a phenol coefficient great than one  .  zero be more effective than phenol , such as chloramine , with phenol coefficient of one  three  three and one  zero  zero , respectively .
although the phenol coefficient be once a useful measure of effectiveness , - pron - be no longer commonly use because the condition and organism use be arbitrarily choose .

disk - diffusion method
the disk - diffusion method involve apply different chemical to separate , sterile filter paper disk ( figure one  three  .  three  one ) .
the disk be then place on an agar plate that have be inoculate with the targeted bacterium and the chemical diffuse out of the disk into the agar where the bacteria have be inoculate .
as the “ lawn " of bacteria chapter one  three  control of microbial growth five  nine  five grow , zone of inhibition of microbial growth be observe as clear area around the disk .
although there be other factor that contribute to the size of zone of inhibition ( e . g . , whether the agent be water soluble and able to diffuse in the agar ) , large zone typically correlate to increase inhibition effectiveness of the chemical agent .
the diameter across each zone be measure in millimeter .

a disk - diffusion assay be use to determine the effectiveness of chemical agent against a particular microbe .

the zone of inhibition around each disc indicate how effective that antimicrobial be against the particular specie be test .
( b )

these antimicrobial be much more effective at kill s . aureus , as indicate by the size of the zone of inhibition .

when compare the activity of two disinfectant against the same microbe , use the disk - diffusion assay , and assume both be water soluble and can easily diffuse in the agar , would a more effective disinfectant have a large zone of inhibition or a small one ?
use - dilution test
other method be also use for measure the effectiveness of a chemical agent in clinical setting .
the use - dilution test be commonly use to determine a chemical 's disinfection effectiveness on an inanimate surface .
for this test , a cylinder of stainless steel be dip in a culture of the target microorganism and then dry .
the cylinder be then dip in solution of disinfectant at various concentration for a specify amount of time .
finally , the cylinder be transfer to a new test tube contain fresh sterile medium that do not contain disinfectant , and this test tube be incubate .
bacterial survival be demonstrate by the presence of turbidity in the medium , whereas kill of the target organism on the cylinder by the disinfectant will produce no turbidity .
the association of official agricultural chemists international ( aoac ) , a nonprofit group that establish many protocol standard , have determine that a minimum of five  nine of six  zero replicate must show no growth in such a test to achieve a pass result , and the result must be repeatable from different batch of disinfectant and when perform on different day .
disinfectant manufacturer perform use - dilution test to validate the efficacy claim for - pron - product , as designate by the epa .

in - use
test an in - use test can determine whether an actively use solution of disinfectant in a clinical setting be microbially contaminate ( figure one  three  .  three  two ) .
a one  - ml sample of the use disinfectant be dilute into nine ml of sterile broth medium that also contain a compound to inactivate the disinfectant .
ten drop , total approximately zero  .  two ml of this mixture , be then inoculate onto each of two agar plate .
one plate be incubate at three  seven ° c for three day and the other be incubate at room temperature for seven day .
the plate be monitor for growth of microbial colony .
growth of five or more colony on either plate suggest that viable microbial cell exist in the disinfectant solution and that - pron - be contaminate .
such in - use test monitor the effectiveness of disinfectant in the clinical setting .

resolution
despite antibiotic treatment , roberta 's symptom worsen .
- pron - develop pyelonephritis , a severe kidney clinical focus chapter one  three  control of microbial growth five  nine  seven infection , and be rehospitalize in the intensive care unit ( icu ) .
- pron - condition continue to deteriorate , and - pron - develop symptom of septic shock .
at this point , - pron - physician order a culture from - pron - urine to determine the exact cause of - pron - infection , as well as a drug sensitivity test to determine what antibiotic would be effective against the causative bacterium .
the result of this test indicate resistance to a wide range of antibiotic , include the carbapenem , a class of antibiotic that be use as the last resort for many type of bacterial infection .
this be an alarming outcome , suggest that roberta 's infection be cause by a so - call superbug  a bacterial strain that have develop resistance to the majority of commonly use antibiotic .
in this case , the causative agent belong to the carbapenem - resistant enterobacteriaceae ( cre ) , a drug - resistant family of bacteria normally find in the digestive system ( figure one  three  .  three  three ) .
when cre be introduce to other body system , as may occur through improperly clean surgical instrument , catheter , or endoscope , aggressive infection can occur .
cre infection be notoriously difficult to treat , with a four  zero %– five  zero % fatality rate .
to treat - pron - kidney infection and septic shock , roberta be treat with dialysis , intravenous fluid , and medication to maintain blood pressure and prevent blood clotting .
- pron - be also start on aggressive treatment with intravenous administration of a new drug call tigecycline , which have be successful in treat infection cause by drug - resistant bacteria .
after several week in the icu , roberta recover from - pron - cre infection .
however , public health official soon notice that roberta 's case be not isolate .
several patient who undergo similar procedure at the same hospital also develop cre infection , some die as a result .
ultimately , the source of the infection be trace to the duodenoscope use in the procedure .
despite the hospital staff meticulously follow manufacturer protocol for disinfection , bacteria , include cre , remain within the instrument and be introduce to patient during procedure .

who be responsible ?
carbapenem - resistant enterobacteriaceae infection due to contaminate endoscope have become a highprofile problem in recent year .
several cre outbreak have be trace to endoscope , include a case at ronald reagan ucla medical center in early two  zero  one  five in which one  seven  nine patient may have be expose to a contaminated endoscope .
seven of the patient develop infection , and two later die .
several lawsuit have be file against olympus , the manufacturer of the endoscope .
some claim that olympus do not obtain fda approval for design change that may have lead to contamination , and other claim that the manufacturer knowingly withhold information from hospital concern defect in the endoscope .
lawsuit like these raise difficult - to - answer question about liability .
invasive procedure be inherently risky , but negative outcome can be minimize by strict adherence to establish protocol .
who be responsible , however , when negative outcome occur due to flawed protocol or faulty equipment ?
can hospital or healthcare worker be hold liable if - pron - have strictly follow a flawed procedure ?
should manufacturer be hold liable - and perhaps be drive out of business - if - pron - lifesave equipment fail or be find defective ?
what be the government 's role in ensure that use and maintenance of medical equipment and protocol be fail - safe ?
protocol for clean or sterilize medical equipment be often develop by government agency like the fda , and other group , like the aoac , a nonprofit scientific organization that establish many protocol for standard use globally .
these procedure and protocol be then adopt by medical device and equipment manufacturer .
ultimately , the end - user ( hospital and - pron - staff ) be responsible for follow these procedure and can be hold liable if a breach occur and patient become ill from improperly clean equipment .
unfortunately , protocol be not infallible , and sometimes - pron - take negative outcome to reveal - pron - flaw .
in two  zero  zero  eight , the fda have approve a disinfection protocol for endoscope , use glutaraldehyde ( at a low concentration when mix with phenol ) , o - phthalaldehyde , hydrogen peroxide , peracetic acid , and a mix of hydrogen peroxide with peracetic acid .
however , subsequent cre outbreak from endoscope use show that this protocol alone be inadequate .
as a result of cre outbreak , hospital , manufacturer , and the fda be investigate solution .
many hospital be institute more rigorous cleaning procedure than those mandate by the fda .
manufacturer be look for way to redesign duodenoscope to minimize hard - to - reach crevice where bacteria can escape disinfectant , and the fda be update - pron - protocol .
in february two  zero  one  five , the fda add new recommendation for careful hand cleaning of the duodenoscope elevator mechanism ( the location where microbe be most likely to escape disinfection ) , and issue more careful documentation about quality control of disinfection protocol ( figure one  three  .  three  four ) .
there be no guarantee that new procedure , protocol , or equipment will completely eliminate the risk for infection associate with endoscope .
yet these device be use successfully in five  zero  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero – six  five  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero procedure annually in the united states , many of - pron - lifesave .
at what point do the risk outweigh the benefit of these device , and who should be hold responsible when negative outcome occur ?

summary one  three  .  one control microbial growth
 inanimate item that may harbor microbe and aid in - pron - transmission be call fomite .
the level of cleanliness require for a fomite depend both on the item 's use and the infectious agent with which the item may be contaminate .

the cdc and the nih have establish four biological safety level ( bsl ) for laboratory perform research on infectious agent .
each level be design to protect laboratory personnel and the community .
these bsl be determine by the agent 's infectivity , ease of transmission , and potential disease severity , as well as the type of work be perform with the agent .

disinfection remove potential pathogen from a fomite , whereas antisepsis use antimicrobial chemical safe enough for tissue  in both case , microbial load be reduce , but microbe may remain unless the chemical use be strong enough to be a sterilant .

the amount of cleanliness ( sterilization versus high - level disinfection versus general cleanliness ) require for item use clinically depend on whether the item will come into contact with sterile tissue ( critical item ) , mucous membrane ( semicritical item ) , or intact skin ( noncritical item ) .
 medical procedure with a risk for contamination should be carry out in a sterile field maintain by proper aseptic technique to prevent sepsis .

sterilization be necessary for some medical application as well as in the food industry , where endospore of six  zero  zero chapter one  three  control of microbial growth
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five clostridium botulinum be kill through commercial sterilization protocol .
 physical or chemical method to control microbial growth that result in death of the microbe be indicate by the suffix - cide or - cidal
( e . g . , as with bactericide , viricide , and fungicide ) , whereas those that inhibit microbial growth be indicate by the suffix - stat or - static ( e . g . , bacteriostatic , fungistatic ) .
 microbial death curve display the logarithmic decline of living microbe expose to a method of microbial control .
the time - pron - take for a protocol to yield a one  - log ( nine  zero % ) reduction in the microbial population be the decimal reduction time , or d - value .

when choose a microbial control protocol , factor to consider include the length of exposure time , the type of microbe target , - pron - susceptibility to the protocol , the intensity of the treatment , the presence of organic that may interfere with the protocol , and the environmental condition that may alter the effectiveness of the protocol .
one  three  .  two use physical methods to control microorganisms

heat be a widely used and highly effective method for control microbial growth .
 dry - heat sterilization protocol be use commonly in aseptic technique in the laboratory .
however , moistheat sterilization be typically the more effective protocol because - pron - penetrate cell well than dry heat do .

pasteurization be use to kill pathogen and reduce the number of microbe that cause food spoilage .
hightemperature , short - time pasteurization be commonly use to pasteurize milk that will be refrigerate  ultrahigh temperature pasteurization can be use to pasteurize milk for long - term storage without refrigeration .

refrigeration slow microbial growth  freezing stop growth , kill some organism .
laboratory and medical specimen may be freeze on dry ice or at ultra - low temperature for storage and transport .
 high - pressure processing can be use to kill microbe in food .
hyperbaric oxygen therapy to increase oxygen saturation have also be use to treat certain infection .
 desiccation have long be use to preserve food and be accelerate through the addition of salt or sugar , which decrease water activity in food .
 lyophilization combine cold exposure and desiccation for the long - term storage of food and laboratory material , but microbe remain and can be rehydrate .

ionizing radiation , include gamma irradiation , be an effective way to sterilize heat - sensitive and package material .
nonionize radiation , like ultraviolet light , be unable to penetrate surface but be useful for surface sterilization .
 hepa filtration be commonly use in hospital ventilation system and biological safety cabinet in laboratory to prevent transmission of airborne microbe .
membrane filtration be commonly use to remove bacteria from heat - sensitive solution .

use chemical to control microorganisms

heavy metal , include mercury , silver , copper , and zinc , have long be use for disinfection and preservation , although some have toxicity and environmental risk associate with - pron - .

halogens , include chlorine , fluorine , and iodine , be also commonly use for disinfection .
chlorine compound , include sodium hypochlorite , chloramine , and chlorine dioxide , be commonly use for water disinfection .
iodine , in both tincture and iodophor form , be an effective antiseptic .

alcohols , include ethyl alcohol and isopropyl alcohol , be commonly use antiseptic that act by denature protein and disrupt membrane .

phenolics be stable , long - act disinfectant that denature protein and disrupt membrane .
- pron - be commonly find in household cleaner , mouthwash , and hospital disinfectant , and be also use to preserve harvest crop .

the phenolic compound triclosan , find in antibacterial soap , plastic , and textiles be technically an antibiotic because of - pron - specific mode of action of inhibit bacterial fatty - acid synthesis . .
 surfactants , include soap and detergent , lower the surface tension of water to create emulsion that mechanically carry away microbe .
soap be long - chain fatty acid , whereas detergent be synthetic chapter one  three  control of microbial growth six  zero  one surfactant .

quaternary ammonium compound ( quat ) be cationic detergent that disrupt membrane .
- pron - be use in household cleaner , skin disinfectant , oral rinse , and mouthwash .

bisbiguanides disrupt cell membrane , cause cell content to gel .
chlorhexidine and alexidine be commonly use for surgical scrub , for handwash in clinical setting , and in prescription oral rinse .

alkylate agent effectively sterilize material at low temperature but be carcinogenic and may also irritate tissue .
glutaraldehyde and o - phthalaldehyde be use as hospital disinfectant but not as antiseptic .
formaldehyde be use for the storage of tissue specimen , as an embalm fluid , and in vaccine preparation to inactivate infectious agent .
ethylene oxide be a gas sterilant that can permeate heat - sensitive package material , but - pron - be also explosive and carcinogenic .

peroxygens , include hydrogen peroxide , peracetic acid , benzoyl peroxide , and ozone gas , be strong oxidize agent that produce free radical in cell , damage - pron - macromolecule .
- pron - be environmentally safe and be highly effective disinfectant and antiseptic .
 pressurize carbon dioxide in the form of a supercritical fluid easily permeate package material and cell , form carbonic acid and lower intracellular ph . supercritical carbon dioxide be nonreactive , nontoxic , nonflammable , and effective at low temperature for sterilization of medical device , implant , and transplant tissue .

chemical preservative be add to a variety of food .
sorbic acid , benzoic acid , propionic acid , and - pron - more soluble salt inhibit enzyme or reduce intracellular ph .

sulfites be use in winemaking and food processing to prevent browning of food .

nitrites be use to preserve meat and maintain color , but cook nitrite - preserve meat may produce carcinogenic nitrosamine .

nisin and natamycin be naturally produce preservative use in cheese and meat .
nisin be effective against gram - positive bacteria and natamycin against fungi .
one  three  .  four test the effectiveness of antiseptics and disinfectants 
chemical disinfectant be group by the type of microbe and infectious agent - pron - be effective against .
high - level germicide kill vegetative cell , fungus , virus , and endospore , and can ultimately lead to sterilization .
intermediate - level germicide can not kill all virus and be less effective against endospore .
low - level germicide kill vegetative cell and some envelop virus , but be ineffective against endospore .

the effectiveness of a disinfectant be influence by several factor , include length of exposure , concentration of disinfectant , temperature , and ph .

historically , the effectiveness of a chemical disinfectant be compare with that of phenol at kill staphylococcus aureus and salmonella enterica serovar typhi , and a phenol coefficient be calculate .

the disk - diffusion method be use to test the effectiveness of a chemical disinfectant against a particular microbe .

the use - dilution test determine the effectiveness of a disinfectant on a surface .
in - use test can determine whether disinfectant solution be be use correctly in clinical setting .

human have successfully exploit these ability , use microbe to mass - produce substance that can be use as antimicrobial drug .

most people associate the term chemotherapy with treatment for cancer .
however , chemotherapy be actually a broad term that refer to any use of chemical or drug to treat disease .
chemotherapy may involve drug that target cancerous cell or tissue , or - pron - may involve antimicrobial drug that target infectious microorganism .
antimicrobial drug typically work by destroy or interfere with microbial structure and enzyme , either kill microbial cell or inhibit of - pron - growth .
but before - pron - examine how these drug work , - pron - will briefly explore the history of human ' use of antimicrobial for the purpose of chemotherapy .
use of antimicrobials in ancient societies

the result beer , which be thick and gruel - like , be use to treat a variety of ailment in both adult and child , include gum disease and wound .

healer of many culture understand the antimicrobial property of fungi and - pron - use of moldy bread or other mold - contain product to treat wound have be well document for centuries . [ three ]

fleming , therefore , be credit with the discovery of penicillin , the first natural antibiotic , ( figure one  four  .  four ) .

one  four  .  two fundamentals of
antimicrobial chemotherapy learning objectives

 contrast broad - spectrum drug versus narrow - spectrum drug

several factor be important in choose the most appropriate antimicrobial drug therapy , include bacteriostatic versus bactericidal mechanism , spectrum of activity , dosage and route of administration , the potential for side effect , and the potential interaction between drug .
the follow discussion will focus primarily on antibacterial drug , but the concept translate to other antimicrobial class .
bacteriostatic versus bactericidal antibacterial drug can be either bacteriostatic or bactericidal in - pron - interaction with target bacteria .
bacteriostatic drug cause a reversible inhibition of growth , with bacterial growth restart after elimination of the drug .
by contrast , bactericidal drug kill - pron - target bacteria .
the decision of whether to use a bacteriostatic or bactericidal six  one  two chapter one  four  antimicrobial drug
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five drug depend on the type of infection and the immune status of the patient .
in a patient with strong immune defense , bacteriostatic and bactericidal drug can be effective in achieve clinical cure .
however , when a patient be immunocompromise , a bactericidal drug be essential for the successful treatment of infection .
regardless of the immune status of the patient , life - threaten infection such as acute endocarditis require the use of a bactericidal drug .
spectrum of activity
the spectrum of activity of an antibacterial drug relate to diversity of target bacteria .
a narrow - spectrum antimicrobial target only specific subset of bacterial pathogen .
for example , some narrow - spectrum drug only target gram - positive bacteria , whereas other target only gram - negative bacteria .
if the pathogen cause an infection have be identify , - pron - be good to use a narrow - spectrum antimicrobial and minimize collateral damage to the normal microbiota .
a broad - spectrum antimicrobial target a wide variety of bacterial pathogen , include both grampositive and gram - negative specie , and be frequently use as empiric therapy to cover a wide range of potential pathogen while wait on the laboratory identification of the infect pathogen .
broad - spectrum antimicrobial be also use for polymicrobic infection ( mixed infection with multiple bacterial specie ) , or as prophylactic prevention of infection with surgery / invasive procedure .
finally , broad - spectrum antimicrobial may be select to treat an infection when a narrow - spectrum drug fail because of development of drug resistance by the target pathogen .
the risk associate with use broad - spectrum antimicrobial be that - pron - will also target a broad spectrum of the normal microbiota , increase the risk of a superinfection , a secondary infection in a patient have a preexist infection .
a superinfection develop when the antibacterial intend for the preexist infection kill the protective microbiota , allow another pathogen resistant to the antibacterial to proliferate and cause a secondary infection ( figure one  four  .  six ) .
common example of superinfection that develop as a result of antimicrobial usage include yeast infection ( candidiasis ) and pseudomembranous colitis cause by clostridium difficile , which can be fatal .
figure one  four  .  six broad - spectrum antimicrobial use may lead to the development of a superinfection .
( credit  modification of work by centers for disease control and prevention )

what be a superinfection and how do one arise ?
dosage and route of administration
the amount of medication give during a certain time interval be the dosage , and - pron - must be determine carefully to ensure that optimum therapeutic drug level be achieve at the site of infection without cause significant toxicity ( side effect ) to the patient .
each drug class be associate with a variety of potential side effect , and some of these be describe for specific drug later in this chapter .
despite good effort to optimize dosing , allergic reaction and other potentially serious side effect do occur .
therefore , the goal be to select the optimum dosage that will minimize chapter one  four  antimicrobial drug six  one  three the risk of side effect while still achieve clinical cure , and there be important factor to consider when select the good dose and dosage interval .
for example , in child , dose be base upon the patient 's mass .
however , the same be not true for adult and child one  two year of age and old , for which there be typically a single standard dose regardless of the patient 's mass .
with the great variability in adult body mass , some expert have argue that mass should be consider for all patient when determine appropriate dosage . [ seven ]
an additional consideration be how drug be metabolize and eliminate from the body .
in general , patient with a history of liver or kidney dysfunction may experience reduce drug metabolism or clearance from the body , result in increase drug level that may lead to toxicity and make - pron - more prone to side effect .
there be also some factor specific to the drug - pron - that influence appropriate dose and time interval between dos .
for example , the half - life , or rate at which five  zero % of a drug be eliminate from the plasma , can vary significantly between drug .
some drug have a short half - life of only one hour and must be give multiple time a day , whereas other drug have half - life exceed one  two hour and can be give as a single dose every two  four hour .
although a long half - life can be consider an advantage for an antibacterial when - pron - come to convenient dosing interval , the long half - life can also be a concern for a drug that have serious side effect because drug level may remain toxic for a long time .
last , some drug be dose dependent , mean - pron - be more effective when administer in large dos to provide high level for a short time at the site of infection .
other be time dependent , mean - pron - be more effective when low optimum level be maintain over a long period of time .
the route of administration , the method use to introduce a drug into the body , be also an important consideration for drug therapy .
drug that can be administer orally be generally prefer because patient can more conveniently take these drug at home .
however , some drug be not absorb easily from the gastrointestinal ( gi ) tract into the bloodstream .
these drug be often useful for treat disease of the intestinal tract , such as tapeworm treat with niclosamide , or for decontaminate the bowel , as with colistin .
some drug that be not absorb easily , such as bacitracin , polymyxin , and several antifungal , be available as topical preparation for treatment of superficial skin infection .
sometimes , patient may not initially be able to take oral medication because of - pron - illness ( e . g . , vomiting , intubation for respirator ) .
when this occur , and when a choose drug be not absorb in the gi tract , administration of the drug by a parenteral route ( intravenous or intramuscular injection ) be prefer and typically be perform in health - care setting .
for most drug , the plasma level achieve by intravenous administration be substantially high than level achieve by oral or intramuscular administration , and this can also be an important consideration when choose the route of administration for treat an infection ( figure one  four  .  seven ) .

drug interactions
for the optimum treatment of some infection , two antibacterial drug may be administer together to provide a synergistic interaction that be well than the efficacy of either drug alone .
a classic example of synergistic combination be trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole ( bactrim ) .
individually , these two drug provide only bacteriostatic inhibition of bacterial growth , but combine , the drug be bactericidal .
whereas synergistic drug interaction provide a benefit to the patient , antagonistic interaction produce harmful effect .
antagonism can occur between two antimicrobial or between antimicrobial and nonantimicrobial be use to treat other condition .
the effect vary depend on the drug involve , but antagonistic interaction may cause loss of drug activity , decrease therapeutic level due to increase metabolism and elimination , or increase potential for toxicity due to decrease metabolism and elimination .
as an example , some antibacterial be absorb most effectively from the acidic environment of the stomach .
if a patient take antacid , however , this increase the ph of the stomach and negatively impact the absorption of these antimicrobial , decrease - pron - effectiveness in treat an infection .
study have also show an association between use of some antimicrobial and failure of oral contraceptives . [ eight ] eight .

resistance police
in the united states and many other country , most antimicrobial drug be self - administer by patient at home .
unfortunately , many patient stop take antimicrobial once - pron - symptom dissipate and - pron - feel well .
if a one  zero  - day course of treatment be prescribe , many patient only take the drug for five or six day , unaware of the negative consequence of not complete the full course of treatment .
a short course of treatment not only fail to kill the target organism to expect level , - pron - also select for drug - resistant variant within the target population and within the patient 's microbiota .
patient ' nonadherence especially amplify drug resistance when the recommend course of treatment be long .
treatment for tuberculosis ( tb ) be a case in point , with the recommend treatment last from six month to a year .
the cdc estimate that about one - third of the world 's population be infect with tb , most live in underdeveloped or underserved region where antimicrobial drug be available over the counter .
in such country , there may be even low rate of adherence than in develop area .
nonadherence lead to antibiotic resistance and more difficulty in control pathogen .
as a direct result , the emergence of multidrugresistant and extensively drug - resistant strain of tb be become a huge problem .
overprescription of antimicrobial also contribute to antibiotic resistance .
patient often demand antibiotic for disease that do not require - pron - , like viral cold and ear infection .
pharmaceutical company aggressively market drug to physician and clinic , make - pron - easy for - pron - to give free sample to patient , and some pharmacy even offer certain antibiotic free to low - income patient with a prescription .
in recent year , various initiative have aim to educate parent and clinician about the judicious use of antibiotic .
however , a recent study show that , between two  zero  zero  zero and two  zero  one  three , the parental expectation for antimicrobial prescription for child actually increase ( figure one  four  .  eight ) .
one possible solution be a regimen call directly observe therapy ( dot ) , which involve the supervised administration of medication to patient .
patient be either require to visit a health - care facility to receive - pron - medication , or health - care provider must administer medication in patient ' home or another designate location .
dot have be implement in many case for the treatment of tb and have be show to be effective  indeed , dot be an integral part of who 's global strategy for eradicate tb . [ nine ] , [ one  zero ]
but be this a practical strategy for all antibiotic ?
would patient take penicillin , for example , be more or less likely to adhere to the full course of treatment if - pron - have to travel to a health - care facility for each dose ?
and who would pay for the increase cost associate with dot ?
when - pron - come to overprescription , should someone be police physician or drug company to enforce good practice ?
what group should assume this responsibility , and what penalty would be effective in discourage overprescription ?

an important quality for an antimicrobial drug be selective toxicity , mean that - pron - selectively kill or inhibit the growth of microbial target while cause minimal or no harm to the host .
most antimicrobial drug currently in clinical use be antibacterial because the prokaryotic cell provide a great variety of unique target for selective toxicity , in comparison to fungi , parasite , and virus .
each class of antibacterial drug have a unique mode of action ( the way in which a drug affect microbe at the cellular level ) , and these be summarize in figure one  four  .  nine and table one  four  .  one .

wall biosynthesis several different class of antibacterial block step in the biosynthesis of peptidoglycan , make cell more susceptible to osmotic lysis ( table one  four  .  two ) .
therefore , antibacterial that target cell wall biosynthesis be bactericidal in - pron - action .
because human cell do not make peptidoglycan , this mode of action be an excellent example of selective toxicity .
penicillin , the first antibiotic discover , be one of several antibacterial within a class call β - lactam .
this group of compound include the penicillin , cephalosporin , monobactam , and carbapenem , and be characterize by the presence of a β - lactam ring find within the central structure of the drug molecule ( figure one  four  .  one  zero ) .
the β - lactam antibacterial block the crosslinking of peptide chain during the biosynthesis of new peptidoglycan in the bacterial cell wall .
- pron - be able to block this process because the β - lactam structure be similar to the structure of the peptidoglycan subunit component that be recognize by the crosslinking transpeptidase enzyme , also know as a penicillin - bind protein ( pbp ) .
although the β - lactam ring must remain unchanged for these drug to retain - pron - antibacterial activity , strategic chemical change to the r group have allow for development of a wide variety of semisynthetic β - lactam drug with increase potency , expand spectrum of activity , and longer half - life for well dosing , among other characteristic .
penicillin g and penicillin v be natural antibiotic from fungi and be primarily active against gram - positive bacterial pathogen , and a few gram - negative bacterial pathogen such as pasteurella multocida .
figure one  four  .  one  zero summarize the semisynthetic development of some of the penicillin .
add an amino group ( - nh two ) to penicillin g create the aminopenicillin ( i . e . , ampicillin and amoxicillin ) that have increase spectrum of activity against more gramnegative pathogen .
furthermore , the addition of a hydroxyl group ( - oh ) to amoxicillin increase acid stability , which allow for improve oral absorption .
methicillin be a semisynthetic penicillin that be develop to address the spread of enzyme ( penicillinase ) that be inactivate the other penicillin .
change the r group of penicillin g to the more bulky dimethoxyphenyl group provide protection of the β - lactam ring from enzymatic destruction by penicillinase , give - pron - the first penicillinase - resistant penicillin .
similar to the penicillin , cephalosporin contain a β - lactam ring ( figure one  four  .  one  zero ) and block the transpeptidase activity of penicillin - bind protein .
however , the β - lactam ring of cephalosporin be fuse to a six - member ring , rather than the five - member ring find in penicillin .
this chemical difference provide cephalosporin with an increase resistance to enzymatic inactivation by β - lactamase .
the drug cephalosporin c be originally isolate from the fungus cephalosporium acremonium in the one  nine  five  zero and have a similar spectrum of activity to that of penicillin against gram - positive bacteria but be active against more gram - negative bacteria than penicillin .
another important structural difference be that cephalosporin c possess two r group , compare with just one r group for penicillin , and this provide for great diversity in chemical alteration and development of semisynthetic cephalosporin .
the family of semisynthetic cephalosporin be much large than the penicillin , and these drug have be classify into generation base primarily on - pron - spectrum of activity , increase in spectrum from the narrow - spectrum , first - generation cephalosporin to the broad - spectrum , fourth - generation cephalosporin .
a new fifth - generation cephalosporin have be develop that be active against methicillin - resistant staphylococcus aureus ( mrsa ) .
the carbapenem and monobactam also have a β - lactam ring as part of - pron - core structure , and - pron - inhibit the transpeptidase activity of penicillin - bind protein .
the only monobactam use clinically be aztreonam .
- pron - be a narrow - spectrum antibacterial with activity only against gram - negative bacteria .
in contrast , the carbapenem family include a variety of semisynthetic drug ( imipenem , meropenem , and doripenem ) that provide very broad - spectrum activity against gram - positive and gram - negative bacterial pathogen .
the drug vancomycin , a member of a class of compound call the glycopeptide , be discover in the one  nine  five  zero s as a natural antibiotic from the actinomycete amycolatopsis orientalis .
similar to the β - lactam , vancomycin inhibit cell wall biosynthesis and be bactericidal .
however , in contrast to the β - lactam , the structure of vancomycin be not similar to that of cell - wall peptidoglycan subunit and do not directly inactivate penicillin - bind protein .
rather , vancomycin be a very large , complex molecule that bind to the end of the peptide chain of cell wall precursor , create a structural blockage that prevent the cell wall subunit from be incorporate into the grow n - acetylglucosamine and n - acetylmuramic acid ( nam - nag ) backbone of the peptidoglycan structure ( transglycosylation ) .
vancomycin also structurally block transpeptidation .
vancomycin be bactericidal against gram - chapter one  four
 antimicrobial drug six  one  nine positive bacterial pathogen , but - pron - be not active against gram - negative bacteria because of - pron - inability to penetrate the protective outer membrane .
the drug bacitracin consist of a group of structurally similar peptide antibiotic originally isolate from bacillus subtili .
bacitracin block the activity of a specific cell - membrane molecule that be responsible for the movement of peptidoglycan precursor from the cytoplasm to the exterior of the cell , ultimately prevent - pron - incorporation into the cell wall .
bacitracin be effective against a wide range of bacteria , include gram - positive organism find on the skin , such as staphylococcus and streptococcus .
although - pron - may be administer orally or intramuscularly in some circumstance , bacitracin have be show to be nephrotoxic ( damage to the kidney ) .
therefore , - pron - be more commonly combine with neomycin and polymyxin in topical ointment such as neosporin .

inhibitor of protein biosynthesis
the cytoplasmic ribosome find in animal cell ( eight  zero s ) be structurally distinct from those find in bacterial cell ( seven  zero s ) , make protein biosynthesis a good selective target for antibacterial drug .

protein synthesis inhibitors
that bind the three  zero s subunit aminoglycosides be large , highly polar antibacterial drug that bind to the three  zero s subunit of bacterial ribosome , impair the proofread ability of the ribosomal complex .
this impairment cause mismatch between codon and anticodon , result in the production of protein with incorrect amino acid and shorten protein that insert into the cytoplasmic membrane .
disruption of the cytoplasmic membrane by the faulty protein kill the bacterial cell .
the aminoglycoside , which include drug such as streptomycin , gentamicin , neomycin , and kanamycin , be potent broad - spectrum antibacterial .
however , aminoglycoside have be show to be nephrotoxic ( damage to kidney ) , neurotoxic ( damage to the nervous system ) , and ototoxic ( damage to the ear ) .
another class of antibacterial compound that bind to the three  zero s subunit be the tetracycline .
in contrast to aminoglycoside , these drug be bacteriostatic and inhibit protein synthesis by block the association of trnas with the ribosome during translation .
naturally occur tetracycline produce by various strain of streptomyce be first discover in the one  nine  four  zero , and several semisynthetic tetracycline , include doxycycline and tigecycline have also be produce .
although the tetracycline be broad spectrum in - pron - coverage of bacterial pathogen , side effect that can limit - pron - use include phototoxicity , permanent discoloration of develop tooth , and liver toxicity with high dos or in patient with kidney impairment .
protein synthesis inhibitors
that bind the five  zero s subunit
there be several class of antibacterial drug that work through bind to the five  zero s subunit of bacterial ribosome .
the macrolide antibacterial drug have a large , complex ring structure and be part of a large class of naturally produce secondary metabolite call polyketide , complex compound produce in a stepwise fashion through the repeat addition of two - carbon unit by a mechanism similar to that use for fatty acid synthesis .
macrolide be broad - spectrum , bacteriostatic drug that block elongation of protein by inhibit peptide bond formation between specific combination of amino acid .
the first macrolide be erythromycin .
- pron - be isolate in one  nine  five  two from streptomyces erythreus and prevent translocation .
semisynthetic macrolide include azithromycin and telithromycin .
compare with erythromycin , azithromycin have a broad spectrum of activity , few side effect , and a significantly long half - life ( one  .  five hour for erythromycin versus six  eight hour for azithromycin ) that allow for once - daily dosing and a short three  - day course of therapy ( i . e . , zpac formulation ) for most infection .

the drug chloramphenicol represent yet another structurally distinct class of antibacterial that also bind to the five  zero s ribosome , inhibit peptide bond formation .
chloramphenicol , produce by streptomyces venezuelae , be discover in one  nine  four  seven  in one  nine  four  nine , - pron - become the first broad - spectrum antibiotic that be approve by the fda .
although - pron - be a natural antibiotic , - pron - be also easily synthesize and be the first antibacterial drug synthetically mass produce .

chloramphenicol also cause anemia in two different way .
one mechanism involve the targeting of mitochondrial ribosome within hematopoietic stem cell , cause a reversible , dose - dependent suppression of blood cell production .
once chloramphenicol dosing be discontinue , blood cell production return to normal .
this mechanism highlight the similarity between seven  zero s ribosome of bacteria and the seven  zero s ribosome within - pron - mitochondria .
the second mechanism of anemia be idiosyncratic ( i . e . , the mechanism be not understand ) , and involve an irreversible lethal loss of blood cell production know as aplastic anemia .
this mechanism of aplastic anemia be not dose dependent and can develop after therapy have stop .
because of toxicity concern , chloramphenicol usage in human be now rare in the united states and be limit to severe infection unable to be treat by less toxic antibiotic .
because - pron - side effect be much less severe in animal , - pron - be use in veterinary medicine .
the oxazolidinone , include linezolid , be a new broad - spectrum class of synthetic protein synthesis inhibitor that bind to the five  zero s ribosomal subunit of both gram - positive and gram - negative bacteria .
however , - pron - mechanism of action seem somewhat different from that of the other five  zero s subunit - bind protein synthesis inhibitor already discuss .
instead , - pron - seem to interfere with formation of the initiation complex ( association of the five  zero s subunit , three  zero s subunit , and other factor ) for translation , and - pron - prevent translocation of the grow protein from the ribosomal a site to the p site .
