inhibitors of metabolic pathways
some synthetic drug control bacterial infection by function as antimetabolite , competitive inhibitor for bacterial metabolic enzyme ( table one  four  .  six ) .
the sulfonamide ( sulfa drug ) be the old synthetic antibacterial agent and be structural analogue of para - aminobenzoic acid ( paba ) , an early intermediate in folic acid synthesis ( figure one  four  .  one  two ) .
by inhibit the enzyme involve in the production of dihydrofolic acid , sulfonamide block bacterial biosynthesis of folic acid and , subsequently , pyrimidine and purine require for nucleic acid synthesis .
this mechanism of action provide bacteriostatic inhibition of growth against a wide spectrum of gram - positive and gram - negative pathogen .
because human obtain folic acid from food instead of synthesize - pron - intracellularly , sulfonamide be selectively toxic for bacteria .
however , allergic reaction to sulfa drug be common .
the sulfone be structurally similar to sulfonamide but be not commonly use today except for the treatment of hansen 's disease ( leprosy ) .
trimethoprim be a synthetic antimicrobial compound that serve as an antimetabolite within the same folic acid synthesis pathway as sulfonamide .
however , trimethoprim be a structural analogue of dihydrofolic acid and inhibit a later step in the metabolic pathway
( figure one  four  .  one  two ) .
trimethoprim be use in combination with the sulfa drug sulfamethoxazole to treat urinary tract infection , ear infection , and bronchitis .
as discuss , the combination of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole be an example of antibacterial synergy .
when use alone , each antimetabolite only decrease production of folic acid to a level where bacteriostatic inhibition of growth occur .
however , when use in combination , inhibition of both step in the metabolic pathway decrease folic acid synthesis to a level that be lethal to the bacterial cell .
because of the importance of folic acid during fetal development , sulfa drug and trimethoprim use should be carefully consider during early pregnancy .
the drug isoniazid be an antimetabolite with specific toxicity for mycobacteria and have long be use in combination with rifampin or streptomycin in the treatment of tuberculosis .
- pron - be administer as a prodrug , require activation through the action of an intracellular bacterial peroxidase enzyme , form isoniazid - nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide ( nad ) and isoniazid - nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate ( nadp ) , ultimately prevent the synthesis of mycolic acid , which be essential for mycobacterial cell wall .
possible side effect of isoniazid use include hepatotoxicity , neurotoxicity , and hematologic toxicity ( anemia ) .

one  four  .  four mechanisms of other antimicrobial drug learning objective

explain the difference between mode of action of drug that target fungus , protozoa , helminth , and virus because fungi , protozoa , and helminth be eukaryotic , - pron - cell be very similar to human cell , make - pron - more difficult to develop drug with selective toxicity .
additionally , virus replicate within human host cell , make - pron - difficult to develop drug that be selectively toxic to virus or virus - infect cell .

antifungal drug
the most common mode of action for antifungal drug be the disruption of the cell membrane .
antifungal take advantage of small difference between fungi and human in the biochemical pathway that synthesize sterol .
the sterol be important in maintain proper membrane fluidity and , hence , proper function of the cell membrane .
for most fungi , the predominant membrane sterol be ergosterol .
because human cell membrane use cholesterol , instead of ergosterol , antifungal drug that target ergosterol synthesis be selectively toxic ( figure one  four  .  one  three ) .
figure one  four  .  one  three
the predominant sterol find in human cell be cholesterol , whereas the predominant sterol find in fungi be ergosterol , make ergosterol a good target for antifungal drug development .
the imidazole be synthetic fungicide that disrupt ergosterol biosynthesis  - pron - be commonly use in medical application and also in agriculture to keep seed and harvest crop from mold .
example include miconazole , ketoconazole , and clotrimazole , which be use to treat fungal skin infection such as ringworm , specifically tinea pedis ( athlete 's foot ) , tinea cruris ( jock itch ) , and tinea corporis .
these infection be commonly cause by dermatophyte of the genera trichophyton , epidermophyton , and microsporum .
miconazole be also use predominantly for the treatment of vaginal yeast infection cause by the fungus candida , and ketoconazole be use for the treatment of tinea versicolor and dandruff , which both can be cause by the fungus malassezia .
the triazole drug , include fluconazole , also inhibit ergosterol biosynthesis .
however , - pron - can be administer orally or intravenously for the treatment of several type of systemic yeast infection , include oral thrush and cryptococcal meningitis , both of which be prevalent in patient with aids .

the allylamine , a structurally different class of synthetic antifungal drug , inhibit an early step in ergosterol biosynthesis .
the most commonly use allylamine be terbinafine ( market under the brand name lamisil ) , which be use topically for the treatment of dermatophytic skin infection like athlete 's foot , ringworm , and jock itch .

common example include nystatin and amphotericin b . nystatin be typically use as a topical treatment for yeast infection of the skin , mouth , and vagina , but may also be use for intestinal fungal infection .

polyoxin be use to control fungi for agricultural purpose , and nikkomycin z be currently under development for use in human to treat yeast infection and valley fever ( coccidioidomycosis ) , a fungal disease prevalent in the southwestern us . [ one  two ]

treat a fungal infection of the lungs jack , a four  eight  - year - old engineer , be hiv positive but generally healthy thank to antiretroviral therapy ( art ) .
however , after a particularly intense week at work , - pron - develop a fever and a dry cough .
- pron - assume that - pron - just have a cold or mild flu due to overexertion and do not think much of - pron - .
however , after about a week , - pron - begin to experience fatigue , weight loss , and shortness of breath .
- pron - decide to visit - pron - physician , who find that jack have a low level of blood oxygenation .
the physician order blood testing , a chest xray , and the collection of an induce sputum sample for analysis .
- pron - x - ray show a fine cloudiness and several pneumatocele ( thin - walled pocket of air ) , which indicate pneumocystis pneumonia ( pcp ) , a type of pneumonia cause by the fungus pneumocystis jirovecii .
jack 's physician admit - pron - to the hospital and prescribe bactrim , a combination of sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim , to be administer intravenously .
p . jirovecii be a yeast - like fungus with a life cycle similar to that of protozoan .
as such , - pron - be classify as a protozoan until the one  nine  eight  zero s .
- pron - live only in the lung tissue of infected person and be transmit from person to person , with many people expose as child .
typically , p . jirovecii only cause pneumonia in immunocompromised individual .
healthy people may carry the fungus in - pron - lung with no symptom of disease .
pcp be particularly problematic among hiv patient with compromise immune system .
pcp be usually treat with oral or intravenous bactrim , but atovaquone or pentamidine ( another antiparasitic drug ) be alternative .
if not treat , pcp can progress , lead to a collapse lung and nearly one  zero  zero % mortality .
even with antimicrobial drug therapy , pcp still be responsible for one  zero % of hiv - relate death .
the cytological examination , use direct immunofluorescence assay ( dfa ) , of a smear from jack 's sputum sample confirm the presence of p . jirovecii ( figure one  four  .  one  five ) .
additionally , the result of jack 's blood test reveal that - pron - white blood cell count have dip , make - pron - more susceptible to the fungus .
- pron - physician review - pron - art regiman and make adjustment .
after a few day of hospitalization , jack be release to continue - pron - antimicrobial therapy at home .

six  three  three antiprotozoan drug
there be a few mechanism by which antiprotozoan drug target infectious protozoan ( table one  four  .  nine ) .
some be antimetabolite , such as atovaquone , proguanil , and artemisinin .
atovaquone , in addition to be antifungal , block electron transport in protozoan and be use for the treatment of protozoan infection include malaria , babesiosis , and toxoplasmosis .
proguanil be another synthetic antimetabolite that be process in parasitic cell into - pron - active form , which inhibit protozoan folic acid synthesis .
- pron - be often use in combination with atovaquone , and the combination be market as malarone for both malaria treatment and prevention .
artemisinin , a plant - derive antifungal first discover by chinese scientist in the one  nine  seven  zero , be quite effective against malaria .
semisynthetic derivative of artemisinin be more water soluble than the natural version , which make - pron - more bioavailable .
although the exact mechanism of action be unclear , artemisinin appear to act as prodrug that be metabolize by target cell to produce reactive oxygen specie ( ros ) that damage target cell .
due to the rise in resistance to antimalarial drug , artemisinin be also commonly use in combination with other antimalarial compound in artemisinin - base combination therapy ( act ) .
several antimetabolite be use for the treatment of toxoplasmosis cause by the parasite toxoplasma gondii .
the synthetic sulfa drug sulfadiazine competitively inhibit an enzyme in folic acid production in parasite and can be use to treat malaria and toxoplasmosis .
pyrimethamine be a synthetic drug that inhibit a different enzyme in the folic acid production pathway and be often use in combination with sulfadoxine ( another sulfa drug ) for the treatment of malaria or in combination with sulfadiazine for the treatment of toxoplasmosis .
side effect of pyrimethamine include decrease bone marrow activity that may cause increase bruise and low red blood cell count .
when toxicity be a concern , spiramycin , a macrolide protein synthesis inhibitor , be typically administer for the treatment of toxoplasmosis .
two class of antiprotozoan drug interfere with nucleic acid synthesis 
nitroimidazole and quinoline .
nitroimidazole , include semisynthetic metronidazole , which be discuss previously as an antibacterial drug , and synthetic tinidazole , be useful in combat a wide variety of protozoan pathogen , such as giardia lamblia , entamoeba histolytica , and trichomonas vaginalis .
upon introduction into these cell in low - oxygen environment , nitroimidazole become activate and introduce dna strand breakage , interfere with dna replication in target cell .
unfortunately , metronidazole be associate with carcinogenesis ( the development of cancer ) in human .
another type of synthetic antiprotozoan drug that have long be think to specifically interfere with dna replication in certain pathogen be pentamidine .
- pron - have historically be use for the treatment of african sleep sickness ( cause by the protozoan trypanosoma brucei ) and leishmaniasis ( cause by protozoa of the genus leishmania ) , but - pron - be also an alternative treatment for the fungus pneumocystis .
some study indicate that - pron - specifically bind to the dna find within kinetoplast ( kdna  long mitochondrion - like structure unique to trypanosomes ) , lead to the cleavage of kdna .
however , nuclear dna of both the parasite and host remain unaffected .
- pron - also appear to bind to trna , inhibit the addition of amino acid to trna , thus prevent protein synthesis .
possible side effect of pentamidine use include pancreatic dysfunction and liver damage .
the quinoline be a class of synthetic compound relate to quinine , which have a long history of use against malaria .
quinoline be think to interfere with heme detoxification , which be necessary for the parasite 's effective breakdown of hemoglobin into amino acid inside red blood cell .
the synthetic derivative chloroquine , quinacrine ( also call mepacrine ) , and mefloquine be commonly use as antimalarial , and chloroquine be also use to treat amebiasis typically cause by entamoeba histolytica .
long - term prophylactic use of chloroquine or mefloquine may result in serious side effect , include hallucination or cardiac issue .
patient with glucose -  six  - phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency experience severe anemia when treat with chloroquine .

unlike the complex structure of fungi , protozoa , and helminth , viral structure be simple , consist of nucleic acid , a protein coat , viral enzyme , and , sometimes , a lipid envelope .
furthermore , virus be obligate intracellular pathogen that use the host 's cellular machinery to replicate .
these characteristic make - pron - difficult to develop drug with selective toxicity against virus .
many antiviral drug be nucleoside analog and function by inhibit nucleic acid biosynthesis .
for example , acyclovir ( market as zovirax ) be a synthetic analog of the nucleoside guanosine
( figure one  four  .  one  six ) .
- pron - be activate by the herpe simplex viral enzyme thymidine kinase and , when add to a grow dna strand during replication , cause chain termination .
- pron - specificity for virus - infect cell come from both the need for a viral enzyme to activate - pron - and the increased affinity of the activate form for viral dna polymerase compare to host cell dna polymerase .
acyclovir and - pron - derivative be frequently use for the treatment of herpe virus infection , include genital herpe , chickenpox , shingle , epstein - barr virus infection , and cytomegalovirus infection .
acyclovir can be administer either topically or systemically , depend on the infection .
one possible side effect of - pron - use include nephrotoxicity .
the drug adenine - arabinoside , market as vidarabine , be a synthetic analog to deoxyadenosine that have a mechanism of action similar to that of acyclovir .
- pron - be also effective for the treatment of various human herpe virus .
however , because of possible side effect involve low white blood cell count and neurotoxicity , treatment with acyclovir be now prefer .
ribavirin , another synthetic guanosine analog , work by a mechanism of action that be not entirely clear .
- pron - appear to interfere with both dna and rna synthesis , perhaps by reduce intracellular pool of guanosine triphosphate ( gtp ) .
ribavarin also appear to inhibit the rna polymerase of hepatitis c virus .
- pron - be primarily use for the treatment of the rna virus like hepatitis c ( in combination therapy with interferon ) and respiratory syncytial virus .
possible side effect of ribavirin use include anemia and developmental effect on unborn child in pregnant patient .
in recent year , another nucleotide analog , sofosbuvir ( solvaldi ) , have also be develop for the treatment of hepatitis c . sofosbuvir be a uridine analog that interfere with viral polymerase activity .
- pron - be commonly coadministere with ribavirin , with and without interferon .
inhibition of nucleic acid synthesis be not the only target of synthetic antiviral .
although the mode of action of amantadine and - pron - relative rimantadine be not entirely clear , these drug appear to bind to a transmembrane protein that be involve in the escape of the influenza virus from endosome .
block escape of the virus also prevent viral rna release into host cell and subsequent viral replication .
increase resistance have limit the use of amantadine and rimantadine in the treatment of influenza a . use of amantadine can result in neurological side effect , but the side effect of rimantadine seem less severe .
interestingly , because of - pron - effect on brain chemical such as dopamine and nmda ( n - methyl d - aspartate ) , amantadine and rimantadine be also use for the treatment of parkinson 's disease .
neuraminidase inhibitor , include olsetamivir ( tamiflu ) , zanamivir ( relenza ) , and peramivir ( rapivab ) , specifically target influenza virus by block the activity of influenza virus neuraminidase , prevent the release of the virus from infected cell .
these three antiviral can decrease flu symptom and shorten the duration of illness , but - pron - differ in - pron - mode of administration  olsetamivir be administer orally , zanamivir be inhale , and peramivir be administer intravenously .
resistance to these neuraminidase inhibitor still seem to be minimal .
pleconaril be a synthetic antiviral under development that show promise for the treatment of picornavirus .
use of pleconaril for the treatment of the common cold cause by rhinovirus be not approve by the fda in two  zero  zero  two because of lack of prove effectiveness , lack of stability , and association with irregular menstruation .
- pron - further development for this purpose be halt in two  zero  zero  seven .
however , pleconaril be still be investigate for use in the treatment of life - threaten complication of enterovirus , such as meningitis and sepsis .
- pron - be also be investigate for use in the global eradication of a specific enterovirus ,
polio . [ one  seven ] pleconaril seem to work by bind to the viral capsid and prevent the uncoating of viral particle inside host cell during viral infection .
virus with complex life cycle , such as hiv , can be more difficult to treat .
first , hiv target cd four  - positive white blood cell , which be necessary for a normal immune response to infection .
second , hiv be a retrovirus , mean one  seven .

one  four  .  five drug resistance learning objectives

explain the concept of drug resistance 
describe how microorganism develop or acquire drug resistance 
describe the different mechanism of antimicrobial drug resistance antimicrobial resistance be not a new phenomenon .
in nature , microbe be constantly evolve in order to overcome the antimicrobial compound produce by other microorganism .
human development of antimicrobial drug and - pron - widespread clinical use have simply provide another selective pressure that promote further evolution .
several important factor can accelerate the evolution of drug resistance .
these include the overuse and misuse of antimicrobial , inappropriate use of antimicrobial , subtherapeutic dosing , and patient noncompliance with the recommend course of treatment .
exposure of a pathogen to an antimicrobial compound can select for chromosomal mutation confer resistance , which can be transfer vertically to subsequent microbial generation and eventually become predominant in a microbial population that be repeatedly expose to the antimicrobial .
alternatively , many gene responsible for drug resistance be find on plasmid or in transposon that can be transfer easily between microbe through horizontal gene transfer ( see how asexual prokaryotes achieve genetic diversity ) .
transposon also have the ability to move resistance gene between plasmid and chromosome to further promote the spread of resistance .
link to learn chapter one  four
 antimicrobial drug six  four  one mechanisms for drug resistance there be several common mechanism for drug resistance , which be summarize in figure one  four  .  one  eight .
these mechanism include enzymatic modification of the drug , modification of the antimicrobial target , and prevention of drug penetration or accumulation .
figure one  four  .  one  eight
there be multiple strategy that microbe use to develop resistance to antimicrobial drug .
( not show  target overproduction , target mimicry , and enzymatic bypass ) .
( credit  modification of work by gerard d wright )
drug modification or inactivation resistance gene may code for enzyme that chemically modify an antimicrobial , thereby inactivate - pron - , or destroy an antimicrobial through hydrolysis .
resistance to many type of antimicrobial occur through this mechanism .
for example , aminoglycoside resistance can occur through enzymatic transfer of chemical group to the drug molecule , impair the binding of the drug to - pron - bacterial target .
for β - lactam , bacterial resistance can involve the enzymatic hydrolysis of the β - lactam bond within the β - lactam ring of the drug molecule .
once the β - lactam bond be break , the drug lose - pron - antibacterial activity .
this mechanism of resistance be mediate by β - lactamase , which be the most common mechanism of β - lactam resistance .
inactivation of rifampin commonly occur through glycosylation , phosphorylation , or adenosine diphosphate ( adp ) ribosylation , and resistance to macrolide and lincosamide can also occur due to enzymatic inactivation of the drug or modification .
prevention of cellular uptake or efflux microbes may develop resistance mechanism that involve inhibit the accumulation of an antimicrobial drug , which then prevent the drug from reach - pron - cellular target .
this strategy be common among gram - negative six  four  two chapter one  four  antimicrobial drug
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five pathogen and can involve change in outer membrane lipid composition , porin channel selectivity , and / or porin channel concentration .
for example , a common mechanism of carbapenem resistance among pseudomonas aeruginosa be to decrease the amount of - pron - oprd porin , which be the primary portal of entry for carbapenem through the outer membrane of this pathogen .
additionally , many gram - positive and gram - negative pathogenic bacteria produce efflux pump that actively transport an antimicrobial drug out of the cell and prevent the accumulation of drug to a level that would be antibacterial .
for example , resistance to β - lactam , tetracycline , and fluoroquinolone commonly occur through active efflux out of the cell , and - pron - be rather common for a single efflux pump to have the ability to translocate multiple type of antimicrobial .
target modification
because antimicrobial drug have very specific target , structural change to those target can prevent drug binding , render the drug ineffective .
through spontaneous mutation in the gene encode antibacterial drug target , bacteria have an evolutionary advantage that allow - pron - to develop resistance to drug .
this mechanism of resistance development be quite common .
genetic change impact the active site of penicillin - bind protein ( pbps ) can inhibit the binding of β - lactam drug and provide resistance to multiple drug within this class .
this mechanism be very common among strain of streptococcus pneumoniae , which alter - pron - own pbp through genetic mechanism .
in contrast , strain of staphylococcus aureus develop resistance to methicillin ( mrsa ) through the acquisition of a new low - affinity pbp , rather than structurally alter - pron - exist pbp .
not only do this new low - affinity pbp provide resistance to methicillin but - pron - provide resistance to virtually all β - lactam drug , with the exception of the new fifth - generation cephalosporin design specifically to kill mrsa .
other example of this resistance strategy include alteration in  ribosome subunit , provide resistance to macrolide , tetracycline , and aminoglycosides   lipopolysaccharide ( lps ) structure , provide resistance to polymyxin   rna polymerase , provide resistance to rifampin   dna gyrase , provide resistance to fluoroquinolone   metabolic enzyme , provide resistance to sulfa drug , sulfone , and trimethoprim  and  peptidoglycan subunit peptide chain , provide resistance to glycopeptide .
target overproduction or enzymatic bypass
when an antimicrobial drug function as an antimetabolite , target a specific enzyme to inhibit - pron - activity , there be additional way that microbial resistance may occur .
first , the microbe may overproduce the target enzyme such that there be a sufficient amount of antimicrobial - free enzyme to carry out the proper enzymatic reaction .
second , the bacterial cell may develop a bypass that circumvent the need for the functional target enzyme .
both of these strategy have be find as mechanism of sulfonamide resistance .
vancomycin resistance among s . aureus have be show to involve the decrease cross - linkage of peptide chain in the bacterial cell wall , which provide an increase in target for vancomycin to bind to in the outer cell wall .
increase bind of vancomycin in the outer cell wall provide a blockage that prevent free drug molecule from penetrate to where - pron - can block new cell wall synthesis .
target mimicry
a recently discover mechanism of resistance call target mimicry involve the production of protein that bind and sequester drug , prevent the drug from bind to - pron - target .
for example , mycobacterium tuberculosis produce a protein with regular pentapeptide repeat that appear to mimic the structure of dna .
this protein bind fluoroquinolone , sequester - pron - and keep - pron - from bind to dna , provide m . tuberculosis resistance to fluoroquinolone .
protein that mimic the a - site of the bacterial ribosome have be find to contribute to aminoglycoside resistance as well . [ one  nine
] one  nine .

multidrug - resistant microbes and cross resistance
from a clinical perspective , - pron - great concern be multidrug - resistant microbe ( mdr ) and cross resistance .
mdr be colloquially know as " superbug " and carry one or more resistance mechanism ( s ) , make - pron - resistant to multiple antimicrobial .
in cross - resistance , a single resistance mechanism confer resistance to multiple antimicrobial drug .
for example , have an efflux pump that can export multiple antimicrobial drug be a common way for microbe to be resistant to multiple drug by use a single resistance mechanism .
in recent year , several clinically important superbug have emerge , and the cdc report that superbug be responsible for more than two million infection in the us annually , result in at least two  three  ,  zero  zero  zero fatalities . [ two  zero ]
several of the superbug discuss in the following section have be dub the eskape pathogen .
this acronym refer to the name of the pathogen ( enterococcus faecium , staphylococcus aureus , klebsiella pneumoniae , acinetobacter baumannii , pseudomonas aeruginosa and enterobacter spp . )
but - pron - be also fitting in that these pathogen be able to " escape " many conventional form of antimicrobial therapy .
as such , infection by eskape pathogen can be difficult to treat and - pron - cause a large number of nosocomial infection .
methicillin - resistant staphylococcus aureus ( mrsa ) methicillin , a semisynthetic penicillin , be design to resist inactivation by β - lactamase .
unfortunately , soon after the introduction of methicillin to clinical practice , methicillin - resistant strain of s . aureus appear and start to spread .
the mechanism of resistance , acquisition of a new low - affinity pbp , provide s . aureus with resistance to all available β - lactam .
strain of methicillin - resistant s . aureus ( mrsa ) be widespread opportunistic pathogen and a particular concern for skin and other wound infection , but may also cause pneumonia and septicemia .
although originally a problem in health - care setting ( hospital - acquire mrsa [ ha - mrsa ] ) , mrsa infection be now also acquire through contact with contaminated member of the general public , call community - associate mrsa ( ca - mrsa ) .
approximately one - third of the population carry s . aureus as a member of - pron - normal nasal microbiota without illness , and about six % of these strain be methicillin resistant . [ two  one ][ two  two ]

with the introduction of penicillin in the early one  nine  four  zero , and - pron - subsequent mass production , society begin to think of antibiotic as miracle cure for a wide range of infectious disease .
unfortunately , as early as one  nine  four  five , penicillin resistance be first document and start to spread .
great than nine  zero % of current s . aureus clinical isolate be resistant to penicillin . [ two  three ]

the development of clavulanic acid represent an early example of this strategy .
clavulanic acid be a molecule produce by the bacterium streptococcus clavuligerus .
- pron - contain a β - lactam ring , make - pron - structurally similar to penicillin and other β - lactam , but show no clinical effectiveness when administer on - pron - own .
instead , clavulanic acid bind irreversibly within the active site of β - lactamase and prevent - pron - from inactivate a coadministered penicillin .
clavulanic acid be first develop in the one  nine  seven  zero and be mass market in combination with amoxicillin begin in the one  nine  eight  zero under the brand name augmentin .
as be typically the case , resistance to the amoxicillinclavulanic acid combination soon appear .
resistance most commonly result from bacteria increase production of - pron - β - lactamase and overwhelm the inhibitory effect of clavulanic acid , mutate - pron - β - lactamase
so - pron - be no longer inhibit by clavulanic acid , or from acquire a new β - lactamase that be not inhibit by clavulanic acid .
despite increase resistance concern , clavulanic acid and relate β - lactamase inhibitor ( sulbactam and tazobactam ) represent an important new strategy  the development of compound that directly inhibit antimicrobial resistance - confer enzyme .
vancomycin - resistant enterococci and staphylococcus aureus vancomycin be only effective against gram - positive organism , and - pron - be use to treat wound infection , septic infection , endocarditis , and meningitis that be cause by pathogen resistant to other antibiotic .
- pron - be consider one of the last line of defense against such resistant infection , include mrsa .
with the rise of antibiotic resistance in the one  nine  seven  zero and one  nine  eight  zero , vancomycin use increase , and - pron - be not surprising that - pron - see the emergence and spread of vancomycin - resistant enterococci ( vre ) , vancomycin - resistant s . aureus ( vrsa ) , and vancomycin - intermediate s . aureus ( visa ) .
the mechanism of vancomycin resistance among enterococci be target modification involve a structural change to the peptide component of the peptidoglycan subunit , prevent vancomycin from bind .
these strain be typically spread among patient in clinical setting by contact with health - care worker and contaminate surface and medical equipment .
visa and vrsa strain differ from each other in the mechanism of resistance and the degree of resistance each mechanism confer .
visa strain exhibit intermediate resistance , with a minimum inhibitory concentration ( mic ) of four – eight μg / ml , and the mechanism involve an increase in vancomycin target .
visa strain decrease the crosslinking of peptide chain in the cell wall , provide an increase in vancomycin target that trap vancomycin in the outer cell wall .
in contrast , vrsa strain acquire vancomycin resistance through horizontal transfer of resistance gene from vre , an opportunity provide in individual coinfecte with both vre and mrsa .
vrsa exhibit a high level of resistance , with mic of one  six μg / ml or higher . [ two  four ]
in the case of all three type of vancomycin - resistant bacteria , rapid clinical identification be necessary so proper procedure to limit spread can be implement .
the oxazolidinone like linezolid be useful for the treatment of these vancomycin - resistant , opportunistic pathogen , as well as mrsa .
extend - spectrum β - lactamase – produce gram - negative pathogens gram - negative pathogen that produce extend - spectrum β - lactamase ( esbls ) show resistance well beyond just penicillin .
the spectrum of β - lactam inactivate by esbl provide for resistance to all penicillin , cephalosporin , monobactam , and the β - lactamase - inhibitor combination , but not the carbapenem .
an even great concern be that the gene encode for esbl be usually find on mobile plasmid that also contain gene for resistance to other drug class ( e . g . , fluoroquinolone , aminoglycoside , tetracycline ) , and may be readily spread to other bacteria by horizontal gene transfer .
these multidrug - resistant bacteria be member of the intestinal microbiota of some individual , but - pron - be also important cause of opportunistic infection in hospitalize patient , from whom - pron - two  three .

carbapenem - resistant gram - negative bacteria
the occurrence of carbapenem - resistant enterobacteriaceae ( cre ) and carbapenem resistance among other gramnegative bacteria ( e . g . , p . aeruginosa , acinetobacter baumannii , stenotrophomonas maltophila ) be a grow healthcare concern .
these pathogen develop resistance to carbapenem through a variety of mechanism , include production of carbapenemase ( broad - spectrum β - lactamase that inactivate all β - lactam , include carbapenem ) , active efflux of carbapenem out of the cell , and / or prevention of carbapenem entry through porin channel .
similar to concern with esbl , carbapenem - resistant , gram - negative pathogen be usually resistant to multiple class of antibacterial , and some have even develop pan - resistance ( resistance to all available antibacterial ) .
infection with carbapenem - resistant , gram - negative pathogen commonly occur in health - care setting through interaction with contaminated individual or medical device , or as a result of surgery .
multidrug - resistant mycobacterium tuberculosis
the emergence of multidrug - resistant mycobacterium tuberculosis ( mdr - tb ) and extensively drug - resistant mycobacterium tuberculosis ( xdr - tb ) be also of significant global concern .
mdr - tb strain be resistant to both rifampin and isoniazid , the drug combination typically prescribe for treatment of tuberculosis .
xdr - tb strain be additionally resistant to any fluoroquinolone and at least one of three other drug ( amikacin , kanamycin , or capreomycin ) use as a second line of treatment , leave these patient very few treatment option .
both type of pathogen be particularly problematic in immunocompromised person , include those suffer from hiv infection .
the development of resistance in these strain often result from the incorrect use of antimicrobial for tuberculosis treatment , select for resistance .

these antibiotic may not necessarily be the same as those use clinically for human , but - pron - be structurally relate to drug use for human .

one  four  .  six test the effectiveness of antimicrobials learning objectives
 describe how the kirby - bauer disk diffusion test determine the susceptibility of a microbe to an antibacterial drug .

explain the significance of the minimal inhibitory concentration and the minimal bactericidal concentration relative to the effectiveness of an antimicrobial drug .

this type of test , generally describe as antimicrobial susceptibility testing ( ast ) , be commonly perform in a clinical laboratory .
in this section , - pron - will discuss common method of test clinical focus chapter one  four  antimicrobial drug six  four  seven the effectiveness of antimicrobial .
the kirby - bauer disk diffusion test
the kirby - bauer disk diffusion test have long be use as a starting point for determine the susceptibility of specific microbe to various antimicrobial drug .
the kirby - bauer assay start with a mueller - hinton agar plate on which a confluent lawn be inoculate with a patient 's isolated bacterial pathogen .
filter paper disk impregnate with known amount of antibacterial drug to be test be then place on the agar plate .
as the bacterial inoculum grow , antibiotic diffuse from the circular disk into the agar and interact with the grow bacteria .
antibacterial activity be observe as a clear circular zone of inhibition around the drug - impregnate disk , similar to the disk - diffusion assay depict in figure one  three  .  three  one .
the diameter of the zone of inhibition , measure in millimeter and compare to a standardized chart , determine the susceptibility or resistance of the bacterial pathogen to the drug .
there be multiple factor that determine the size of a zone of inhibition in this assay , include drug solubility , rate of drug diffusion through agar , the thickness of the agar medium , and the drug concentration impregnate into the disk .
due to a lack of standardization of these factor , interpretation of the kirby - bauer disk diffusion assay provide only limited information on susceptibility and resistance to the drug test .
the assay can not distinguish between bacteriostatic and bactericidal activity , and difference in zone size can not be use to compare drug potency or efficacy .
comparison of zone size to a standardized chart will only provide information on the antibacterial to which a bacterial pathogen be susceptible or resistant .

how do one use the information from a kirby - bauer assay to predict the therapeutic effectiveness of an antimicrobial drug in a patient ?
antibiogram 
take some of the guesswork
out of prescriptions
unfortunately , infectious disease do not take a time - out for lab work .
as a result , physician rarely have the luxury of conduct susceptibility testing before - pron - write a prescription .
instead , - pron - rely primarily on the empirical evidence ( i . e . , the sign and symptom of disease ) and - pron - professional experience to make an educated guess as to the diagnosis , causative agent ( s ) , and drug most likely to be effective .
this approach allow treatment to begin sooner so the patient do not have to wait for lab test result .
in many case , the prescription be effective  however , in an age of increase antimicrobial resistance , - pron - be become increasingly more difficult to select the most appropriate empiric therapy .
select an inappropriate empiric therapy not only put the patient at risk but may promote great resistance to the drug prescribe .
recently , study have show that antibiogram be useful tool in the decision - making process of select appropriate empiric therapy .
an antibiogram be a compilation of local antibiotic susceptibility datum break down by bacterial pathogen .
in a november two  zero  one  four study publish in the journal infection control and hospital epidemiology , researcher determine that eight  five % of the prescription order in skilled nursing facility be decide upon empirically , but only three  five % of those prescription be deem appropriate when compare with the eventual pathogen identification and susceptibility profile obtain from the clinical laboratory .
however , in one nursing facility where use of antibiogram be implement to direct selection of empiric therapy , appropriateness of empiric therapy increase from three  two % before antibiogram implementation to four  five % after implementation of antibiograms . [ two  five ]
although these datum be preliminary , - pron - do suggest that health - care facility can reduce the number of inappropriate prescription by use antibiogram to select empiric therapy , thus benefit patient and minimize opportunity for antimicrobial resistance to develop .

dilution test
as discuss , the limitation of the kirby - bauer disk diffusion test do not allow for a direct comparison of antibacterial potency to guide selection of the good therapeutic choice .
however , antibacterial dilution test can be use to determine a particular drug 's minimal inhibitory concentration ( mic ) , the low concentration of drug that inhibit visible bacterial growth , and minimal bactericidal concentration ( mbc ) , the low drug concentration that kill ≥ nine  nine  .  nine % of the starting inoculum .
determine these concentration help identify the correct drug for a particular pathogen .
for the macrobroth dilution assay , a dilution series of the drug in broth be make in test tube and the same number of cell of a test bacterial strain be add to each tube ( figure one  four  .  one  nine ) .
the mic be determine by examine the tube to find the low drug concentration that inhibit visible growth  this be observe as turbidity ( cloudiness ) in the broth .
tube with no visible growth be then inoculate onto agar medium without antibiotic to determine the mbc .
generally , serum level of an antibacterial should be at least three to five time above the mic for treatment of an infection .
the mic assay can also be perform use nine  six  - well microdilution tray , which allow for the use of small volume and automate dispense device , as well as the testing of multiple antimicrobial and / or microorganism in one tray ( figure one  four  .  two  zero ) .
mic be interpret as the low concentration that inhibit visible growth , the same as for the macrobroth dilution in test tube .
growth may also be interpret visually or by use a spectrophotometer or similar device to detect turbidity or a color change if an appropriate biochemical substrate that change color in the presence of bacterial growth be also include in each well .
the etest be an alternative method use to determine mic , and be a combination of the kirby - bauer disk diffusion test and dilution method .
similar to the kirby - bauer assay , a confluent lawn of a bacterial isolate be inoculate onto the surface of an agar plate .
rather than use circular disk impregnate with one concentration of drug , however , commercially available plastic strip that contain a gradient of an antibacterial be place on the surface of the inoculated agar plate ( figure one  four  .  two  one ) .
as the bacterial inoculum grow , antibiotic diffuse from the plastic strip into the agar and interact with the bacterial cell .
because the rate of drug diffusion be directly relate to concentration , an elliptical zone of inhibition be observe with the etest drug gradient , rather than a circular zone of inhibition observe with the kirby - bauer assay .
to interpret the result , the intersection of the elliptical zone with the gradient on the drug - contain strip indicate the mic .
because multiple strip contain different antimicrobial can be place on the same plate , the mic of multiple antimicrobial can be determine concurrently and directly compare .
however , unlike the macrobroth and microbroth dilution method , the mbc can not be determine with the etest .

 describe the method and strategy use for discovery of new antimicrobial agent .
with the continue evolution and spread of antimicrobial resistance , and now the identification of pan - resistant bacterial pathogen , the search for new antimicrobial be essential for prevent the postantibiotic era .
although development of more effective semisynthetic derivative be one strategy , resistance to - pron - develop rapidly because bacterial pathogen be already resistant to early - generation drug in the family and can easily mutate and develop resistance to the new semisynthetic drug .
today , scientist continue to hunt for new antimicrobial compound and explore new avenue of antimicrobial discovery and synthesis .
- pron - check large number of soil and microbial product for antimicrobial activity by use high - throughput screening method , which use automation to test large number of sample simultaneously .
the recent development of the ichip[ two  six ] allow researcher to investigate the antimicrobial - produce capability of soil microbe that be difficult to grow by standard cultivation technique in the laboratory .
rather than grow the microbe in the laboratory , - pron - be grow in situ - right in the soil .
use of the ichip have result in the discovery of teixobactin , a novel antimicrobial from mount ararat , turkey .
teixobactin target two distinct step in gram - positive cell wall synthesis and for which antimicrobial resistance appear not yet to have evolve .
although soil have be widely examine , other environmental niche have not be test as fully .
since seven  zero % of the earth be cover with water , marine environment could be mine more fully for the presence of antimicrobialproduce microbe .
in addition , researcher be use combinatorial chemistry , a method for make a very large number of related compound from simple precursor , and test - pron - for antimicrobial activity .
an additional strategy that need to be explore further be the development of compound that inhibit resistance mechanism and restore the activity of old drug , such as the strategy describe earlier for β - lactamase inhibitor like clavulanic acid .
finally , develop inhibitor of virulence factor production and function could be a very important avenue .
although this strategy would not be directly antibacterial , drug that slow the progression of an infection could provide an advantage for the immune system and could be use successfully in combination with antimicrobial drug .

summary one  four  .  one history of chemotherapy and antimicrobial discovery 
antimicrobial drug produce by purposeful fermentation and / or contain in plant have be use as traditional medicine in many culture for millennium .

the purposeful and systematic search for a chemical “ magic bullet " that specifically target infectious microbe be initiate by paul ehrlich in the early two  zero th century .

the discovery of the natural antibiotic , penicillin , by alexander fleming in one  nine  two  eight start the modern age of antimicrobial discovery and research .

sulfanilamide , the first synthetic antimicrobial , be discover by gerhard domagk and colleague and be a breakdown product of the synthetic dye , prontosil .
one  four  .  two fundamentals of antimicrobial chemotherapy

antimicrobial drug can be bacteriostatic or bactericidal , and these characteristic be important consideration when select the most appropriate drug .

the use of narrow - spectrum antimicrobial drug be prefer in many case to avoid superinfection and the development of antimicrobial resistance .
 broad - spectrum antimicrobial use be warrant for serious systemic infection when there be no time to determine the causative agent , when narrow - spectrum antimicrobial fail , or for the treatment or prevention of infection with multiple type of microbe .

the dosage and route of administration be important consideration when select an antimicrobial to treat and infection .
other consideration include the patient 's age , mass , ability to take oral medication , liver and kidney function , and possible interaction with other drug the patient may be take .
one  four  .  three mechanisms of antibacterial drugs 
antibacterial compound exhibit selective toxicity , largely due to difference between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell structure .
 cell wall synthesis inhibitor , include the β - lactam , the glycopeptide , and bacitracin , interfere with peptidoglycan synthesis , make bacterial cell more prone to osmotic lysis .

there be a variety of broad - spectrum , bacterial protein synthesis inhibitor that selectively target the prokaryotic seven  zero s ribosome , include those that bind to the three  zero s subunit ( aminoglycoside and tetracycline ) and other that bind to the five  zero s subunit ( macrolide , lincosamide , chloramphenicol , and oxazolidinone ) .

polymyxins be lipophilic polypeptide antibiotic that target the lipopolysaccharide component of gramnegative bacteria and ultimately disrupt the integrity of the outer and inner membrane of these bacteria .

the nucleic acid synthesis inhibitor rifamycin and fluoroquinolone target bacterial rna transcription and dna replication , respectively .

some antibacterial drug be antimetabolite , act as competitive inhibitor for bacterial metabolic enzyme .
sulfonamide and trimethoprim be antimetabolite that interfere with bacterial folic acid synthesis .
isoniazid be an antimetabolite that interfere with mycolic acid synthesis in mycobacteria .
one  four  .  four mechanisms of other antimicrobial drug  because fungi , protozoan , and helminth be eukaryotic organism like human cell , - pron - be more challenging to develop antimicrobial drug that specifically target - pron - .
similarly , - pron - be hard to target virus because human virus replicate inside of human cell .
 antifungal drug interfere with ergosterol synthesis , bind to ergosterol to disrupt fungal cell membrane integrity , or target cell wall - specific component or other cellular protein .

antiprotozoan drug increase cellular level of reactive oxygen specie , interfere with protozoal dna replication ( nuclear versus kdna , respectively ) , and disrupt heme detoxification .

antihelminthic drug disrupt helminthic and protozoan microtubule formation  block neuronal transmission  inhibit anaerobic atp formation and / or oxidative phosphorylation  induce a calcium influx in tapeworm , lead to spasm and paralysis  and interfere with rna synthesis in schistosome .

antiviral drug inhibit viral entry , inhibit viral uncoating , inhibit nucleic acid biosynthesis , prevent viral escape from endosome in host cell , and prevent viral release from infected cell .

because - pron - can easily mutate to become drug resistant , hiv be typically treat with a combination of several antiretroviral drug , which may include reverse transcriptase inhibitor , protease inhibitor , integrase inhibitor , and drug that interfere with viral binding and fusion to initiate infection .
one  four  .  five drug resistance 
antimicrobial resistance be on the rise and be the result of selection of drug - resistant strain in clinical environment , the overuse and misuse of antibacterial , the use of subtherapeutic dos of antibacterial drug , and poor patient compliance with antibacterial drug therapy .
 drug resistance gene be often carry on plasmid or in transposon that can undergo vertical transfer easily and between microbe through horizontal gene transfer .
 common mode of antimicrobial drug resistance include drug modification or inactivation , prevention of cellular uptake or efflux , target modification , target overproduction or enzymatic bypass , and target mimicry .
 problematic microbial strain show extensive antimicrobial resistance be emerge  many of these strain can reside as member of the normal microbiota in individual but also can cause opportunistic infection .
the transmission of many of these highly resistant microbial strain often occur in clinical setting , but can also be community - acquire .
one  four  .  six test the effectiveness of antimicrobials

the kirby - bauer disk diffusion test help determine the susceptibility of a microorganism to various antimicrobial drug .
however , the zone of inhibition measure must be correlate to know standard to determine susceptibility and resistance , and do not provide information on bactericidal versus bacteriostatic activity , or allow for direct comparison of drug potency .
 antibiograms be useful for monitor local trend in antimicrobial resistance / susceptibility and for direct appropriate selection of empiric antibacterial therapy .

there be several laboratory method available for determine the minimum inhibitory concentration ( mic ) of an antimicrobial drug against a specific microbe .
the minimal bactericidal concentration ( mbc ) can also be determine , typically as a follow - up experiment to mic determination use the tube dilution method .
one  four  .  seven current strategies for antimicrobial discovery 
current research into the development of antimicrobial drug involve the use of high - throughput screening and combinatorial chemistry technology .
chapter one  four
 antimicrobial drug six  five  five
 new technology be be develop to discover novel antibiotic from soil microorganism that can not be culture by standard laboratory method .
 additional strategy include search for antibiotic from source other than soil , identify new antibacterial target , use combinatorial chemistry to develop novel drug , develop drug that inhibit resistance mechanism , and develop drug that target virulence factor and hold infection in check .

a disease be any condition in which the normal structure or function of the body be damage or impair .
physical injury or disability be not classify as disease , but there can be several cause for disease , include infection by a pathogen , genetic ( as in many cancer or deficiency ) , noninfectious environmental cause , or inappropriate immune response .
- pron - focus in this chapter will be on infectious disease , although when diagnose infectious disease , - pron - be always important to consider possible noninfectious cause .
sign and symptoms of disease
an infection be the successful colonization of a host by a microorganism .
infection can lead to disease , which cause sign and symptom result in a deviation from the normal structure or functioning of the host .
microorganism that can cause disease be know as pathogen .
the sign of disease be objective and measurable , and can be directly observe by a clinician .
vital sign , which be use to measure the body 's basic function , include body temperature ( normally three  seven ° c [ nine  eight  .  six ° f ] ) , heart rate ( normally six  zero – one  zero  zero beat per minute ) , breathing rate ( normally one  two – one  eight breath per minute ) , and blood pressure ( normally between nine  zero  /  six  zero and one  two  zero  /  eight  zero mm hg ) .
change in any of the body 's vital sign may be indicative of disease .
for example , have a fever ( a body temperature significantly high than three  seven ° c or nine  eight  .  six ° f ) be a sign of disease because - pron - can be measure .
in addition to change in vital sign , other observable condition may be consider sign of disease .
for example , the presence of antibody in a patient 's serum ( the liquid portion of blood that lack clotting factor ) can be observe and measure through blood test and , therefore , can be consider a sign .
however , - pron - be important to note that the presence of antibody be not always a sign of an active disease .
antibody can remain in the body long after an infection have resolve  also , - pron - may develop in response to a pathogen that be in the body but not currently cause disease .

 microbial mechanisms of pathogenicity six  six  three classifications of disease
the world health organization 's ( who )
international classification of diseases ( icd ) be use in clinical field to classify disease and monitor morbidity ( the number of case of a disease ) and mortality ( the number of death due to a disease ) .
in this section , - pron - will introduce terminology use by the icd ( and in health - care profession in general ) to describe and categorize various type of disease .
an infectious disease be any disease cause by the direct effect of a pathogen .
a pathogen may be cellular ( bacteria , parasite , and fungi ) or acellular ( virus , viroid , and prion ) .
some infectious disease be also communicable , mean - pron - be capable of be spread from person to person through either direct or indirect mechanism .
some infectious communicable disease be also consider contagious disease , mean - pron - be easily spread from person to person .
not all contagious disease be equally so  the degree to which a disease be contagious usually depend on how the pathogen be transmit .
for example , measle be a highly contagious viral disease that can be transmit when an infect person cough or sneeze and an uninfected person breathe in droplet contain the virus .
gonorrhea be not as contagious as measle because transmission of the pathogen ( neisseria gonorrhoeae ) require close intimate contact ( usually sexual ) between an infected person and an uninfected person .
disease that be contract as the result of a medical procedure be know as iatrogenic disease .
iatrogenic disease can occur after procedure involve wound treatment , catheterization , or surgery if the wound or surgical site become contaminate .
for example , an individual treat for a skin wound may acquire necrotize fasciitis ( an aggressive , " flesh - eat " disease ) if bandage or other dressing become contaminate by clostridium perfringen or one of several other bacteria that can cause this condition .
disease acquire in hospital setting be know as nosocomial disease .
several factor contribute to the prevalence and severity of nosocomial disease .
first , sick patient bring numerous pathogen into hospital , and some of these pathogen can be transmit easily via improperly sterilize medical equipment , bed sheet , call button , door handle , or by clinician , nurse , or therapist who do not wash - pron - hand before touch a patient .
second , many hospital patient have weaken immune system , make - pron - more susceptible to infection .
compound this , the prevalence of antibiotic in hospital setting can select for drug - resistant bacteria that can cause very serious infection that be difficult to treat .
certain infectious disease be not transmit between human directly but can be transmit from animal to human .
such a disease be call zoonotic disease ( or zoonosis ) .
accord to who , a zoonosis be a disease that occur when a pathogen be transfer from a vertebrate animal to a human  however , sometimes the term be define more broadly to include disease transmit by all animal ( include invertebrate ) .
for example , rabie be a viral zoonotic disease spread from animal to human through bite and contact with infected saliva .
many other zoonotic disease rely on insect or other arthropod for transmission .
example include yellow fever ( transmit through the bite of mosquito infect with yellow fever virus ) and rocky mountain spot fever ( transmit through the bite of tick infect with rickettsia rickettsii ) .
in contrast to communicable infectious disease , a noncommunicable infectious disease be not spread from one person to another .
one example be tetanus , cause by clostridium tetani , a bacterium that produce endospore that can survive in the soil for many year .
this disease be typically only transmit through contact with a skin wound  - pron - can not be pass from an infect person to another person .
similarly , legionnaires disease be cause by legionella pneumophila , a bacterium that live within amoebae in moist location like water - cool tower .
an individual may contract legionnaires disease via contact with the contaminated water , but once infect , the individual can not pass the pathogen to other individual .
in addition to the wide variety of noncommunicable infectious disease , noninfectious disease ( those not cause by pathogen ) be an important cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide .
noninfectious disease can be cause by a wide variety factor , include genetic , the environment , or immune system dysfunction , to name a few .
for example , sickle cell anemia be an inherited disease cause by a genetic mutation that can be pass from parent to offspring ( figure one  five  .  two ) .
other type of noninfectious disease be list in table one  five  .  two .

period of disease
the five period of disease ( sometimes refer to as stage or phase ) include the incubation , prodromal , illness , decline , and convalescence period ( figure one  five  .  three ) .
the incubation period occur in an acute disease after the initial entry of the pathogen into the host ( patient ) .
- pron - be during this time the pathogen begin multiply in the host .
however , there be insufficient number of pathogen particle ( cell or virus ) present to cause sign and symptom of disease .
incubation period can vary from a day or two in acute disease to month or year in chronic disease , depend upon the pathogen .
factor involve in determine the length of the incubation period be diverse , and can include strength of the pathogen , strength of the host immune defense , site of infection , type of infection , and the size infectious dose receive .
during this incubation period , the patient be unaware that a disease be begin to develop .
link to learn six  six  six chapter one  five
 microbial mechanisms of pathogenicity this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five figure one  five  .  three
the progression of an infectious disease can be divide into five period , which be relate to the number of pathogen particle ( red ) and the severity of sign and symptom ( blue ) .
the prodromal period occur after the incubation period .
during this phase , the pathogen continue to multiply and the host begin to experience general sign and symptom of illness , which typically result from activation of the immune system , such as fever , pain , soreness , swelling , or inflammation .
usually , such sign and symptom be too general to indicate a particular disease .
follow the prodromal period be the period of illness , during which the sign and symptom of disease be most obvious and severe .
the period of illness be follow by the period of decline , during which the number of pathogen particle begin to decrease , and the sign and symptom of illness begin to decline .
however , during the decline period , patient may become susceptible to develop secondary infection because - pron - immune system have be weaken by the primary infection .
the final period be know as the period of convalescence .
during this stage , the patient generally return to normal function , although some disease may inflict permanent damage that the body can not fully repair .
infectious disease can be contagious during all five of the period of disease .
which period of disease be more likely to associate with transmissibility of an infection depend upon the disease , the pathogen , and the mechanism by which the disease develop and progress .
for example , with meningitis ( infection of the lining of brain ) , the period of infectivity depend on the type of pathogen cause the infection .
patient with bacterial meningitis be contagious during the incubation period for up to a week before the onset of the prodromal period , whereas patient with viral meningitis become contagious when the first sign and symptom of the prodromal period appear .
with many viral disease associate with rash ( e . g . , chickenpox , measle , rubella , roseola ) , patient be contagious during the incubation period up to a week before the rash develop .
in contrast , with many respiratory infection ( e . g . , cold , influenza , diphtheria , strep throat , and pertussis ) the patient become contagious with the onset of the prodromal period .
depend upon the pathogen , the disease , and the individual infect , transmission can still occur during the period of decline , convalescence , and even long after sign and symptom of the disease disappear .
for example , an individual recover from a diarrheal disease may continue to carry and shed the pathogen in fece for some time , pose a risk of transmission to other through direct contact or indirect contact ( e . g . , through contaminated object or food ) .

acute and chronic diseases
the duration of the period of illness can vary greatly , depend on the pathogen , effectiveness of the immune response in the host , and any medical treatment receive .
for an acute disease , pathologic change occur over a relatively short time ( e . g . , hour , day , or a few week ) and involve a rapid onset of disease condition .
for example , influenza ( cause by influenzavirus ) be consider an acute disease because the incubation period be approximately one – two day .
infect individual can spread influenza to other for approximately five day after become ill .
after approximately one week , individual enter the period of decline .
for a chronic disease , pathologic change can occur over long time span ( e . g . , month , year , or a lifetime ) .
for example , chronic gastritis ( inflammation of the lining of the stomach ) be cause by the gram - negative bacterium helicobacter pylorus .
h . pylorus be able to colonize the stomach and persist in - pron - highly acidic environment by produce the enzyme urease , which modify the local acidity , allow the bacteria to survive indefinitely . [ two ]
consequently , h . pylorus infection can recur indefinitely unless the infection be clear use antibiotics . [ three ] hepatitis b virus can cause a chronic infection in some patient who do not eliminate the virus after the acute illness .
a chronic infection with hepatitis b virus be characterize by the continue production of infectious virus for six month or long after the acute infection , as measure by the presence of viral antigen in blood sample .
in latent disease , as oppose to chronic infection , the causal pathogen go dormant for extended period of time with no active replication .
example of disease that go into a latent state after the acute infection include herpe ( herpe simplex virus [ hsv -  one and hsv -  two ] ) , chickenpox ( varicella - zoster virus [ vzv ] ) , and mononucleosis ( epstein - barr virus [ ebv ] ) .
hsv -  one , hsv -  two , and vzv evade the host immune system by reside in a latent form within cell of the nervous system for long period of time , but - pron - can reactivate to become active infection during time of stress and immunosuppression .
for example , an initial infection by vzv may result in a case of childhood chickenpox , follow by a long period of latency .
the virus may reactivate decade later , cause episode of shingle in adulthood .
ebv go into latency in b cell of the immune system and possibly epithelial cell  - pron - can reactivate year later to produce b - cell lymphoma .

today 's physician , patient , and researcher owe a sizable debt to the physician robert koch ( one  eight  four  three – one  nine  one  zero ) , who devise a systematic approach for confirm causative relationship between disease and specific pathogen .
koch 's postulates
in one  eight  eight  four , koch publish four postulate ( table one  five  .  three ) that summarize - pron - method for determine whether a particular microorganism be the cause of a particular disease .
each of koch 's postulate represent a criterion that must be meet before a disease can be positively link with a pathogen .
in order to determine whether the criterion be meet , test be perform on laboratory animal and culture from healthy and diseased animal be compare ( figure one  five  .  four ) .
koch 's postulates ( one )
the suspect pathogen must be find in every case of disease and not be find in healthy individual .
( two )
the suspect pathogen can be isolate and grow in pure culture .
( three )
a healthy test subject infect with the suspect pathogen must develop the same sign and symptom of disease as see in postulate one .
( four )
the pathogen must be re - isolate from the new host and must be identical to the pathogen from postulate two .
table one  five  .  three chapter one  five
 microbial mechanisms of pathogenicity six  six  nine figure one  five  .  four
the step for confirm that a pathogen be the cause of a particular disease use koch 's postulate .
in many way , koch 's postulate be still central to - pron - current understanding of the cause of disease .
however , advance in microbiology have reveal some important limitation in koch 's criterion .
koch make several assumption that - pron - now know be untrue in many case .
the first relate to postulate one , which assume that pathogen be only find in disease , not healthy , individual .
this be not true for many pathogen .
for example , h . pylorus , describe earlier in this chapter as a pathogen cause chronic gastritis , be also part of the normal microbiota of the stomach in many healthy human who never develop gastritis .
- pron - be estimate that upwards of five  zero % of the human population acquire h . pylorus early in life , with most maintain - pron - as part of the normal microbiota for the rest of - pron - life without ever develop disease .
koch 's second faulty assumption be that all healthy test subject be equally susceptible to disease .
- pron - now know that individual be not equally susceptible to disease .
individual be unique in term of - pron - microbiota and the state of - pron - immune system at any give time .
the makeup of the resident microbiota can influence an individual 's susceptibility to an infection .
member of the normal microbiota play an important role in immunity by inhibit the growth of transient pathogen .
in some case , the microbiota may prevent a pathogen from establish an infection  in other , - pron - may not prevent an infection altogether but may influence the severity or type of sign and symptom .
as a result , two individual with the same disease may not always present with the same sign and symptom .
in addition , some individual have strong immune system than other .
individual with immune system weaken by age or an unrelated illness be much more susceptible to certain infection than individual with strong immune system .
koch also assume that all pathogen be microorganism that can be grow in pure culture ( postulate two ) and that animal could serve as reliable model for human disease .
however , - pron - now know that not all pathogen can be grow in pure culture , and many human disease can not be reliably replicate in animal host .

if a microbe can not be culture , a researcher can not move past postulate two .
likewise , without a suitable nonhuman host , a researcher can not evaluate postulate two without deliberately infect human , which present obvious ethical concern .
aids be an example of such a disease because the human immunodeficiency virus ( hiv ) only cause disease in human .

briefly summarize the limitation of koch 's postulate .
molecular koch 's postulates
in one  nine  eight  eight , stanley falkow ( one  nine  three  four – ) propose a revise form of koch 's postulate know as molecular koch 's postulate .
these be list in the left column of table one  five  .  four .
the premise for molecular koch 's postulate be not in the ability to isolate a particular pathogen but rather to identify a gene that may cause the organism to be pathogenic .
falkow 's modification to koch 's original postulate explain not only infection cause by intracellular pathogen but also the existence of pathogenic strain of organism that be usually nonpathogenic .
for example , the predominant form of the bacterium escherichia coli be a member of the normal microbiota of the human intestine and be generally consider harmless .
however , there be pathogenic strain of e . coli such as enterotoxigenic e . coli ( etec ) and enterohemorrhagic e . coli ( o one  five  seven  h seven ) ( ehec ) .
- pron - now know etec and ehec exist because of the acquisition of new gene by the once - harmless e . coli , which , in the form of these pathogenic strain , be now capable of produce toxin and cause illness .
the pathogenic form result from minor genetic change .
the right - side column of table one  five  .  four illustrate how molecular koch 's postulate can be apply to identify ehec as a pathogenic bacterium .
molecular koch 's postulates apply to ehec molecular koch 's postulates application to ehec ( one )
the phenotype ( sign or symptom of disease ) should be associate only with pathogenic strain of a species .
ehec cause intestinal inflammation and diarrhea , whereas nonpathogenic strain of e . coli do not .
( two ) inactivation of the suspect gene ( s ) associate with pathogenicity should result in a measurable loss of pathogenicity .
one of the gene in ehec encode for shiga toxin , a bacterial toxin ( poison ) that inhibit protein synthesis .
inactivate this gene reduce the bacteria 's ability to cause disease .
( three )
reversion of the inactive gene should restore the disease phenotype .
by add the gene that encode the toxin back into the genome ( e . g . , with a phage or plasmid ) , ehec 's ability to cause disease be restore .

as with koch 's original postulate , the molecular koch 's postulate have limitation .
for example , genetic manipulation of some pathogen be not possible use current method of molecular genetic .
in a similar vein , some disease do not have suitable animal model , which limit the utility of both the original and molecular postulate .

chapter one  five  microbial mechanisms of pathogenicity six  seven  one pathogenicity and virulence
the ability of a microbial agent to cause disease be call pathogenicity , and the degree to which an organism be pathogenic be call virulence .
virulence be a continuum .
on one end of the spectrum be organism that be avirulent ( not harmful ) and on the other be organism that be highly virulent .
highly virulent pathogen will almost always lead to a disease state when introduce to the body , and some may even cause multi - organ and body system failure in healthy individual .
less virulent pathogen may cause an initial infection , but may not always cause severe illness .
pathogen with low virulence would more likely result in mild sign and symptom of disease , such as low - grade fever , headache , or muscle ache .
some individual may even be asymptomatic .
an example of a highly virulent microorganism be bacillus anthracis , the pathogen responsible for anthrax .
b . anthracis can produce different form of disease , depend on the route of transmission ( e . g . , cutaneous injection , inhalation , ingestion ) .
the most serious form of anthrax be inhalation anthrax .
after b . anthracis spore be inhale , - pron - germinate .
an active infection develop and the bacteria release potent toxin that cause edema ( fluid buildup in tissue ) , hypoxia ( a condition prevent oxygen from reach tissue ) , and necrosis ( cell death and inflammation ) .
sign and symptom of inhalation anthrax include high fever , difficulty breathing , vomit and cough up blood , and severe chest pain suggestive of a heart attack .
with inhalation anthrax , the toxin and bacteria enter the bloodstream , which can lead to multi - organ failure and death of the patient .
if a gene ( or gene ) involve in pathogenesis be inactivate , the bacteria become less virulent or nonpathogenic .
virulence of a pathogen can be quantify use control experiment with laboratory animal .
two important indicator of virulence be the median infectious dose ( id five  zero ) and the median lethal dose ( ld five  zero ) , both of which be typically determine experimentally use animal model .
the id five  zero be the number of pathogen cell or virion require to cause active infection in five  zero % of inoculated animal .
the ld five  zero be the number of pathogenic cell , virion , or amount of toxin require to kill five  zero % of infected animal .
to calculate these value , each group of animal be inoculate with one of a range of know number of pathogen cell or virion .
in graph like the one show in figure one  five  .  five , the percentage of animal that have be infect ( for id five  zero ) or kill ( for ld five  zero ) be plot against the concentration of pathogen inoculate .
figure one  five  .  five represent datum graph from a hypothetical experiment measure the ld five  zero of a pathogen .
interpretation of the datum from this graph indicate that the ld five  zero of the pathogen for the test animal be one  zero  four pathogen cell or virion ( depend upon the pathogen study ) .
figure one  five  .  five
a graph like this be use to determine ld five  zero by plot pathogen concentration against the percent of infect test animal that have die .
in this example , the ld five  zero = one  zero  four pathogenic particle .

keep in mind that these be median value .
the actual infective dose for an individual can vary widely , depend on factor such as route of entry  the age , health , and immune status of the host  and environmental and pathogen - specific factor such as susceptibility to the acidic ph of the stomach .
- pron - be also important to note that a pathogen 's infective dose do not necessarily correlate with disease severity .
for example , just a single cell of salmonella enterica serotype typhimurium can result in an active infection .
the resultant disease , salmonella gastroenteritis or salmonellosis , can cause nausea , vomiting , and diarrhea , but have a mortality rate of less than one % in healthy adult .
in contrast , s . enterica serotype typhi have a much high id five  zero , typically require as many as one  ,  zero  zero  zero cell to produce infection .
however , this serotype cause typhoid fever , a much more systemic and severe disease that have a mortality rate as high as one  zero % in untreated individual .
