chapter one  five  microbial mechanisms of pathogenicity
six  seven  three primary pathogens versus opportunistic pathogens pathogens can be classify as either primary pathogen or opportunistic pathogen .
a primary pathogen can cause disease in a host regardless of the host 's resident microbiota or immune system .
an opportunistic pathogen , by contrast , can only cause disease in situation that compromise the host 's defense , such as the body 's protective barrier , immune system , or normal microbiota .
individual susceptible to opportunistic infection include the very young , the elderly , woman who be pregnant , patient undergo chemotherapy , people with immunodeficiency ( such as acquire immunodeficiency syndrome [ aids ] ) , patient who be recover from surgery , and those who have have a breach of protective barrier ( such as a severe wound or burn ) .
an example of a primary pathogen be enterohemorrhagic e . coli ( ehec ) , which produce a virulence factor know as shiga toxin .
this toxin inhibit protein synthesis , lead to severe and bloody diarrhea , inflammation , and renal failure , even in patient with healthy immune system .
staphylococcus epidermidis , on the other hand , be an opportunistic pathogen that be among the most frequent cause of nosocomial disease . [ five ] s . epidermidis be a member of the normal microbiota of the skin , where - pron - be generally avirulent .
however , in hospital , - pron - can also grow in biofilm that form on catheter , implant , or other device that be insert into the body during surgical procedure .
once inside the body , s . epidermidis can cause serious infection such as endocarditis , and - pron - produce virulence factor that promote the persistence of such infection .
other member of the normal microbiota can also cause opportunistic infection under certain condition .
this often occur when microbe that reside harmlessly in one body location end up in a different body system , where - pron - cause disease .
for example , e . coli normally find in the large intestine can cause a urinary tract infection if - pron - enter the bladder .
this be the lead cause of urinary tract infection among woman .
member of the normal microbiota may also cause disease when a shift in the environment of the body lead to overgrowth of a particular microorganism .
for example , the yeast candida be part of the normal microbiota of the skin , mouth , intestine , and vagina , but - pron - population be keep in check by other organism of the microbiota .
if an individual be take antibacterial medication , however , bacteria that would normally inhibit the growth of candida can be kill off , lead to a sudden growth in the population of candida , which be not affect by antibacterial medication because - pron - be a fungus .
an overgrowth of candida can manifest as oral thrush ( growth on mouth , throat , and tongue ) , a vaginal yeast infection , or cutaneous candidiasis .
other scenario can also provide opportunity for candida infection .
untreated diabete can result in a high concentration of glucose in the saliva , which provide an optimal environment for the growth of candida , result in thrush .
immunodeficiency such as those see in patient with hiv , aids , and cancer also lead to high incidence of thrush .
vaginal yeast infection can result from decrease in estrogen level during the menstruation or menopause .
the amount of glycogen available to lactobacilli in the vagina be control by level of estrogen  when estrogen level be low , lactobacilli produce less lactic acid .
the resultant increase in vaginal ph allow overgrowth of candida in the vagina .

stage of pathogenesis to cause disease , a pathogen must successfully achieve four step or stage of pathogenesis  exposure ( contact ) , adhesion ( colonization ) , invasion , and infection .
the pathogen must be able to gain entry to the host , travel to the location where - pron - can establish an infection , evade or overcome the host 's immune response , and cause damage ( i . e . , disease ) to the host .
in many case , the cycle be complete when the pathogen exit the host and be transmit to a new host .

an encounter with a potential pathogen be know as exposure or contact .
the food - pron - eat and the object - pron - handle be all way that - pron - can come into contact with potential pathogen .
yet , not all contact result in infection and disease .
for a pathogen to cause disease , - pron - need to be able to gain access into host tissue .
an anatomic site through which pathogen can pass into host tissue be call a portal of entry .
these be location where the host cell be in direct contact with the external environment .
major portal of entry be identify in figure one  five  .  six and include the skin , mucous membrane , and parenteral route .
figure one  five  .  six show be different portal of entry where pathogen can gain access into the body .
with the exception of the placenta , many of these location be directly expose to the external environment .
mucosal surface be the most important portal of entry for microbe  these include the mucous membrane of the respiratory tract , the gastrointestinal tract , and the genitourinary tract .
although most mucosal surface be in the interior of the body , some be contiguous with the external skin at various body opening , include the eye , nose , mouth , urethra , and anus .
most pathogen be suit to a particular portal of entry .
a pathogen 's portal specificity be determine by the organism 's environmental adaption and by the enzyme and toxin - pron - secrete .
the respiratory and gastrointestinal tract be particularly vulnerable portal of entry because particle that include microorganism be constantly inhale or ingest , respectively .
pathogen can also enter through a breach in the protective barrier of the skin and mucous membrane .
pathogen that enter the body in this way be say to enter by the parenteral route .
for example , the skin be a good natural barrier chapter one  five  microbial mechanisms of pathogenicity six  seven  five to pathogen , but break in the skin ( e . g . , wound , insect bite , animal bite , needle prick ) can provide a parenteral portal of entry for microorganism .
in pregnant woman , the placenta normally prevent microorganism from pass from the mother to the fetus .
however , a few pathogen be capable of cross the blood - placental barrier .
the gram - positive bacterium listeria monocytogene , which cause the foodborne disease listeriosis , be one example that pose a serious risk to the fetus and can sometimes lead to spontaneous abortion .
other pathogen that can pass the placental barrier to infect the fetus be know collectively by the acronym torch ( table one  five  .  six ) .
transmission of infectious disease from mother to baby be also a concern at the time of birth when the baby pass through the birth canal .
baby whose mother have active chlamydia or gonorrhea infection may be expose to the causative pathogen in the vagina , which can result in eye infection that lead to blindness .
to prevent this , - pron - be standard practice to administer antibiotic drop to infant ' eye shortly after birth .

adhesion
follow the initial exposure , the pathogen adhere at the portal of entry .
the term adhesion refer to the capability of pathogenic microbe to attach to the cell of the body use adhesion factor , and different pathogen use various mechanism to adhere to the cell of host tissue .
molecules ( either protein or carbohydrate ) call adhesin be find on the surface of certain pathogen and bind to clinical focus six .
the o in torch stand for “ other .
” six  seven  six
chapter one  five  microbial mechanisms of pathogenicity this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five specific receptor ( glycoprotein ) on host cell .
adhesin be present on the fimbriae and flagella of bacteria , the cilia of protozoa , and the capsid or membrane of virus .
protozoans can also use hook and barb for adhesion  spike protein on virus also enhance viral adhesion .
the production of glycocalyce ( slime layer and capsule ) ( figure one  five  .  seven ) , with - pron - high sugar and protein content , can also allow certain bacterial pathogen to attach to cell .
biofilm growth can also act as an adhesion factor .
a biofilm be a community of bacteria that produce a glycocalyx , know as extrapolymeric substance ( eps ) , that allow the biofilm to attach to a surface .
persistent pseudomonas aeruginosa infection be common in patient suffer from cystic fibrosis , burn wound , and middle - ear infection ( otitis medium ) because p . aeruginosa produce a biofilm .
the eps allow the bacteria to adhere to the host cell and make - pron - hard for the host to physically remove the pathogen .
the eps not only allow for attachment but provide protection against the immune system and antibiotic treatment , prevent antibiotic from reach the bacterial cell within the biofilm .
in addition , not all bacteria in a biofilm be rapidly grow  some be in stationary phase .
since antibiotic be most effective against rapidly grow bacteria , portion of bacteria in a biofilm be protect against antibiotics . invasion
once adhesion be successful , invasion can proceed .
invasion involve the dissemination of a pathogen throughout local tissue or the body .
pathogen may produce exoenzyme or toxin , which serve as virulence factor that allow - pron - to colonize and damage host tissue as - pron - spread deeper into the body .
pathogen may also produce virulence factor that protect - pron - against immune system defense .
a pathogen 's specific virulence factor determine the degree of tissue damage that occur .
figure one  five  .  eight show the invasion of h . pylorus into the tissue of the stomach , cause damage as - pron - progress .

intracellular pathogen achieve invasion by enter the host 's cell and reproducing .
some be obligate intracellular pathogen ( mean - pron - can only reproduce inside of host cell ) and other be facultative intracellular pathogen ( mean - pron - can reproduce either inside or outside of host cell ) .
by enter the host cell , intracellular pathogen be able to evade some mechanism of the immune system while also exploit the nutrient in the host cell .
entry to a cell can occur by endocytosis .
for most kind of host cell , pathogen use one of two different mechanism for endocytosis and entry .
one mechanism rely on effector protein secrete by the pathogen  these effector protein trigger entry into the host cell .
this be the method that salmonella and shigella use when invade intestinal epithelial cell .
when these pathogen come in contact with epithelial cell in the intestine , - pron - secrete effector molecule that cause protrusion of membrane ruffle that bring the bacterial cell in .
this process be call membrane ruffling .
the second mechanism rely on surface protein express on the pathogen that bind to receptor on the host cell , result in entry .
for example , yersinia pseudotuberculosis produce a surface protein know as invasin that bind to beta -  one integrin express on the surface of host cell .
some host cell , such as white blood cell and other phagocyte of the immune system , actively endocytose pathogen in a process call phagocytosis .
although phagocytosis allow the pathogen to gain entry to the host cell , in most case , the host cell kill and degrade the pathogen by use digestive enzyme .
normally , when a pathogen be ingest by a phagocyte , - pron - be enclose within a phagosome in the cytoplasm  the phagosome fuse with a lysosome to form a phagolysosome , where digestive enzyme kill the pathogen ( see pathogen recognition and phagocytosis ) .
however , some intracellular pathogen have the ability to survive and multiply within phagocyte .
example include listeria monocytogene and shigella  these bacteria produce protein that lyse the phagosome before - pron - fuse with the lysosome , allow the bacteria to escape into the phagocyte 's cytoplasm where - pron - can multiply .
bacteria such as mycobacterium tuberculosis , legionella pneumophila , and salmonella specie use a slightly different mechanism to evade be digest by the phagocyte .
these bacteria prevent the fusion of the phagosome with the lysosome , thus remain alive and divide within the phagosome .
infection
follow invasion , successful multiplication of the pathogen lead to infection .
infection can be describe as local , focal , or systemic , depend on the extent of the infection .
a local infection be confine to a small area of the body , typically near the portal of entry .
for example , a hair follicle infect by staphylococcus aureus infection may result in a boil around the site of infection , but the bacterium be largely contain to this small location .
other example of local infection that involve more extensive tissue involvement include urinary tract infection confine to the bladder six  seven  eight chapter one  five  microbial mechanisms of pathogenicity this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five or pneumonia confine to the lung .
in a focal infection , a localized pathogen , or the toxin - pron - produce , can spread to a secondary location .
for example , a dental hygienist nick the gum with a sharp tool can lead to a local infection in the gum by streptococcus bacteria of the normal oral microbiota .
these streptococcus spp . may then gain access to the bloodstream and make - pron - way to other location in the body , result in a secondary infection .
when an infection become disseminate throughout the body , - pron - call - pron - a systemic infection .
for example , infection by the varicella - zoster virus typically gain entry through a mucous membrane of the upper respiratory system .
- pron - then spread throughout the body , result in the classic red skin lesion associate with chickenpox .
since these lesion be not site of initial infection , - pron - be sign of a systemic infection .
sometimes a primary infection , the initial infection cause by one pathogen , can lead to a secondary infection by another pathogen .
for example , the immune system of a patient with a primary infection by hiv become compromise , make the patient more susceptible to secondary disease like oral thrush and other cause by opportunistic pathogen .
similarly , a primary infection by influenzavirus damage and decrease the defense mechanism of the lung , make patient more susceptible to a secondary pneumonia by a bacterial pathogen like haemophilus influenzae or streptococcus pneumoniae .
some secondary infection can even develop as a result of treatment for a primary infection .
antibiotic therapy target the primary pathogen can cause collateral damage to the normal microbiota , create an opening for opportunistic pathogen ( see case in point  a secondary yeast infection ) .
a secondary yeast infection anita , a three  six  - year - old mother of three , go to an urgent care center complaining of pelvic pressure , frequent and painful urination , abdominal cramp , and occasional blood - tinge urine .
suspect a urinary tract infection ( uti ) , the physician request a urine sample and send - pron - to the lab for a urinalysis .
since - pron - will take approximately two  four hour to get the result of the culturing , the physician immediately start anita on the antibiotic ciprofloxacin .
the next day , the microbiology lab confirm the presence of e . coli in anita 's urine , which be consistent with the presumptive diagnosis .
however , the antimicrobial susceptibility test indicate that ciprofloxacin would not effectively treat anita 's uti , so the physician prescribe a different antibiotic .
after take - pron - antibiotic for one week , anita return to the clinic complain that the prescription be not work .
although the painful urination have subside , - pron - be now experience vaginal itching , burning , and discharge .
after a brief examination , the physician explain to anita that the antibiotic be likely successful in kill the e . coli responsible for - pron - uti  however , in the process , - pron - also wipe out many of the " good " bacteria in anita 's normal microbiota .
the new symptom that anita have report be consistent with a secondary yeast infection by candida albican , an opportunistic fungus that normally reside in the vagina but be inhibit by the bacteria that normally reside in the same environment .
to confirm this diagnosis , a microscope slide of a direct vaginal smear be prepare from the discharge to check for the presence of yeast .
a sample of the discharge accompany this slide to the microbiology lab to determine if there have be an increase in the population of yeast cause vaginitis .
after the microbiology lab confirm the diagnosis , the physician prescribe an antifungal drug for anita to use to eliminate - pron - secondary yeast infection .

for a pathogen to persist , - pron - must put - pron - in a position to be transmit to a new host , leave the infected host through a portal of exit ( figure one  five  .  nine ) .
as with portal of entry , many pathogen be adapt to use a particular portal of exit .
similar to portal of entry , the most common portal of exit include the skin and the respiratory , urogenital , and gastrointestinal tract .
cough and sneezing can expel pathogen from the respiratory tract .
a single sneeze can send thousand of virus particle into the air .
secretion and excretion can transport pathogen out of other portal of exit .
fece , urine , seman , vaginal secretion , tear , sweat , and shed skin cell can all serve as vehicle for a pathogen to leave the body .
pathogen that rely on insect vector for transmission exit the body in the blood extract by a bite insect .
similarly , some pathogen exit the body in blood extract by needle .

bacterial exoenzymes and toxins as virulence factors
after exposure and adhesion , the next step in pathogenesis be invasion , which can involve enzyme and toxin .
many pathogen achieve invasion by enter the bloodstream , an effective mean of dissemination because blood vessel pass close to every cell in the body .
the downside of this mechanism of dispersal be that the blood also include numerous element of the immune system .
various term end in –emia be use to describe the presence of pathogen in the bloodstream .
the presence of bacteria in blood be call bacteremia .
bacteremia involve pyogen ( pus - form bacteria ) be call pyemia .
when virus be find in the blood , - pron - be call viremia .
the term toxemia describe the condition when toxin be find in the blood .
if bacteria be both present and multiply in the blood , this condition be call septicemia .
patient with septicemia be describe as septic , which can lead to shock , a life - threaten decrease in blood pressure ( systolic pressure < nine  zero mm hg ) that prevent cell and organ from receive enough oxygen and nutrient .
some bacteria can cause shock through the release of toxin ( virulence factor that can cause tissue damage ) and lead to low blood pressure .
gram - negative bacteria be engulf by immune system phagocyte , which then release tumor necrosis factor , a molecule involve in inflammation and fever .
tumor necrosis factor bind to blood capillary to increase - pron - permeability , allow fluid to pass out of blood vessel and into tissue , cause swelling , or edema ( figure one  five  .  one  zero ) .
with high concentration of tumor necrosis factor , the inflammatory reaction be severe and enough fluid be lose from the circulatory system that blood pressure decrease to dangerously low level .
this can have dire consequence because the heart , lung , and kidney rely on normal blood pressure for proper function  thus , multiorgan failure , shock , and death can occur .

exoenzyme
some pathogen produce extracellular enzyme , or exoenzyme , that enable - pron - to invade host cell and deep tissue .
exoenzyme have a wide variety of target .
some general class of exoenzyme and associate pathogen be list in table one  five  .  eight .
each of these exoenzymes function in the context of a particular tissue structure to facilitate invasion or support - pron - own growth and defend against the immune system .
for example , hyaluronidase s , an enzyme produce by pathogen like staphylococcus aureus , streptococcus pyogene , and clostridium perfringen , degrade the glycoside hyaluronan ( hyaluronic acid ) , which act as an intercellular cement between adjacent cell in connective tissue ( figure one  five  .  one  one ) .
this allow the pathogen to pass through the tissue layer at the portal of entry and disseminate elsewhere in the body ( figure one  five  .  one  one ) .
some classes of exoenzymes and - pron - targets class example function glycohydrolase hyaluronidase s in staphylococcus aureus degrade hyaluronic acid that cement cell together to promote spread through tissue nucleases dnase produce by s . aureus degrades dna release by die cell ( bacteria and host cell ) that can trap the bacteria , thus promote spread phospholipases phospholipase c of bacillus anthracis degrade phospholipid bilayer of host cell , cause cellular lysis , and degrade membrane of phagosome to enable escape into the cytoplasm proteases collagenase in clostridium perfringen degrade collagen in connective tissue to promote spread

( a ) hyaluronan be a polymer find in the layer of epidermis that connect adjacent cell .
( b )
hyaluronidase produce by bacteria degrade this adhesive polymer in the extracellular matrix , allow passage between cell that would otherwise be block .
pathogen - produce nuclease , such as dnase produce by s . aureus , degrade extracellular dna as a means of escape and spread through tissue .
as bacterial and host cell die at the site of infection , - pron - lyse and release - pron - intracellular content .
the dna chromosome be the large of the intracellular molecule , and mass of extracellular dna can trap bacteria and prevent - pron - spread .
s . aureus produce a dnase to degrade the mesh of extracellular dna so - pron - can escape and spread to adjacent tissue .
this strategy be also use by s . aureus and other pathogen to degrade and escape webs of extracellular dna produce by immune system phagocyte to trap the bacteria .
enzyme that degrade the phospholipid of cell membrane be call phospholipase .
- pron - action be specific in regard to the type of phospholipid - pron - act upon and where - pron - enzymatically cleave the molecule .
the pathogen responsible for anthrax , b . anthracis , produce phospholipase c . when b . anthracis be ingest by phagocytic cell of the immune system , phospholipase c degrade the membrane of the phagosome before - pron - can fuse with the lysosome , allow the pathogen to escape into the cytoplasm and multiply .
phospholipase can also target the membrane that enclose the phagosome within phagocytic cell .
as describe earlier in this chapter , this be the mechanism use by intracellular pathogen such as l . monocytogene and rickettsia to escape the phagosome and multiply within the cytoplasm of phagocytic cell .
the role of phospholipase in bacterial virulence be not restrict to phagosomal escape .
many pathogen produce phospholipase that act to degrade cell membrane and cause lysis of target cell .
these phospholipase be involve in lysis of red blood cell , white blood cell , and tissue cell .
bacterial pathogen also produce various protein - digest enzyme , or protease .
protease can be classify accord to - pron - substrate target ( e . g . , serine protease target protein with the amino acid serine ) or if - pron - contain metal in - pron - active site ( e . g . , zinc metalloprotease contain a zinc ion , which be necessary for enzymatic activity ) .
one example of a protease that contain a metal ion be the exoenzyme collagenase .
collagenase digest collagen , the dominant protein in connective tissue .
collagen can be find in the extracellular matrix , especially near mucosal membrane , blood vessel , nerve , and in the layer of the skin .
similar to hyaluronidase , collagenase allow the pathogen to penetrate and spread through the host tissue by digest this connective tissue protein .
the collagenase produce by the gram - positive bacterium clostridium perfringen , for example , allow the bacterium to make - pron - way through the tissue layer and subsequently enter and multiply in the blood ( septicemia ) .
c . perfringen then use toxin and a phospholipase to cause cellular lysis and necrosis .
once the host cell have die , the bacterium produce gas by ferment the muscle carbohydrate .
the widespread necrosis of tissue and accompany gas be characteristic of the condition know as gas gangrene ( figure one  five  .  one  two ) .

toxin
in addition to exoenzyme , certain pathogen be able to produce toxin , biological poison that assist in - pron - ability to invade and cause damage to tissue .
the ability of a pathogen to produce toxin to cause damage to host cell be call toxigenicity .
toxin can be categorize as endotoxin or exotoxin .
the lipopolysaccharide ( lps ) find on the outer membrane of gram - negative bacteria be call endotoxin ( figure one  five  .  one  three ) .
during infection and disease , gram - negative bacterial pathogen release endotoxin either when the cell die , result in the disintegration of the membrane , or when the bacterium undergo binary fission .
the lipid component of endotoxin , lipid a , be responsible for the toxic property of the lps molecule .
lipid a be relatively conserve across different genera of gram - negative bacteria  therefore , the toxic property of lipid a be similar regardless of the gram - negative pathogen .
in a manner similar to that of tumor necrosis factor , lipid a trigger the immune system 's inflammatory response ( see inflammation and fever ) .
if the concentration of endotoxin in the body be low , the inflammatory response may provide the host an effective defense against infection  on the other hand , high concentration of endotoxin in the blood can cause an excessive inflammatory response , lead to a severe drop in blood pressure , multi - organ failure , and death .

a classic method of detect endotoxin be by use the limulus amebocyte lysate ( lal ) test .
in this procedure , the blood cell ( amebocyte ) of the horseshoe crab ( limulus polyphemus ) be mixed with a patient 's serum .
the amebocyte will react to the presence of any endotoxin .
this reaction can be observe either chromogenically ( color ) or by look for coagulation ( clot reaction ) to occur within the serum .
an alternative method that have be use be an enzyme - link immunosorbent assay ( elisa ) that use antibody to detect the presence of endotoxin .
unlike the toxic lipid a of endotoxin , exotoxin be protein molecule that be produce by a wide variety of live pathogenic bacteria .
although some gram - negative pathogen produce exotoxin , the majority be produce by grampositive pathogen .
exotoxin differ from endotoxin in several other key characteristic , summarize in table one  five  .  nine .
in contrast to endotoxin , which stimulate a general systemic inflammatory response when release , exotoxin be much more specific in - pron - action and the cell - pron - interact with .
each exotoxin target specific receptor on specific cell and damage those cell through unique molecular mechanism .
endotoxin remain stable at high temperature , and require heating at one  two  one ° c ( two  five  zero ° f ) for four  five minute to inactivate .
by contrast , most exotoxin be heat labile because of - pron - protein structure , and many be denature ( inactivate ) at temperature above four  one ° c ( one  zero  six ° f ) .
as discuss earlier , endotoxin can stimulate a lethal inflammatory response at very high concentration and have a measure ld five  zero of zero  .  two  four mg / kg .
by contrast , very small concentration of exotoxin can be lethal .
for example , botulinum toxin , which cause botulism , have an ld five  zero of zero  .  zero  zero  zero  zero  zero  one mg / kg ( two  four  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero time more lethal than endotoxin ) .

four unique example of a - b toxin be the diphtheria , cholera , botulinum , and tetanus toxin .
the diphtheria toxin be produce by the gram - positive bacterium corynebacterium diphtheriae , the causative agent of nasopharyngeal and cutaneous diphtheria .
after the a subunit of the diphtheria toxin separate and gain access to the cytoplasm , - pron - facilitate the transfer of adenosine diphosphate ( adp ) - ribose onto an elongation - factor protein ( ef -  two ) that be need for protein synthesis .
hence , diphtheria toxin inhibit protein synthesis in the host cell , ultimately kill the cell ( figure one  five  .  one  five ) .
figure one  five  .  one  five
the mechanism of the diphtheria toxin inhibit protein synthesis .
the a subunit inactivate elongation factor two by transfer an adp - ribose .
this stop protein elongation , inhibit protein synthesis and kill the cell .
cholera toxin be an enterotoxin produce by the gram - negative bacterium vibrio cholerae and be compose of one a subunit and five b subunit .
the mechanism of action of the cholera toxin be complex .
the b subunit bind to receptor on the intestinal epithelial cell of the small intestine .
after gain entry into the cytoplasm of the epithelial cell , the a subunit activate an intracellular g protein .
the activated g protein , in turn , lead to the activation of the enzyme adenyl cyclase , which begin to produce an increase in the concentration of cyclic amp ( a secondary messenger molecule ) .
the increased camp disrupt the normal physiology of the intestinal epithelial cell and cause six  eight  eight chapter one  five  microbial mechanisms of pathogenicity this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five - pron - to secrete excessive amount of fluid and electrolyte into the luman of the intestinal tract , result in
severe “ rice - water stool " diarrhea characteristic of cholera .
botulinum toxin ( also know as botox ) be a neurotoxin produce by the gram - positive bacterium clostridium botulinum .
- pron - be the most acutely toxic substance know to date .
the toxin be compose of a light a subunit and heavy protein chain b subunit .
the b subunit bind to neuron to allow botulinum toxin to enter the neuron at the neuromuscular junction .
the a subunit act as a protease , cleave protein involve in the neuron 's release of acetylcholine , a neurotransmitter molecule .
normally , neuron release acetylcholine to induce muscle fiber contraction .
the toxin 's ability to block acetylcholine release result in the inhibition of muscle contraction , lead to muscle relaxation .
this have the potential to stop breathe and cause death .
because of - pron - action , low concentration of botox be use for cosmetic and medical procedure , include the removal of wrinkle and treatment of overactive bladder .

another neurotoxin be tetanus toxin , which be produce by the gram - positive bacterium clostridium tetani .
this toxin also have a light a subunit and heavy protein chain b subunit .
unlike botulinum toxin , tetanus toxin bind to inhibitory interneuron , which be responsible for release of the inhibitory neurotransmitter glycine and gamma - aminobutyric acid ( gaba ) .
normally , these neurotransmitter bind to neuron at the neuromuscular junction , result in the inhibition of acetylcholine release .
tetanus toxin inhibit the release of glycine and gaba from the interneuron , result in permanent muscle contraction .
the first symptom be typically stiffness of the jaw ( lockjaw ) .
violent muscle spasm in other part of the body follow , typically culminate with respiratory failure and death .

membrane - disrupt toxin affect cell membrane function either by form pore or by disrupt the phospholipid bilayer in host cell membrane .
two type of membrane - disrupt exotoxin be hemolysin and leukocidin , which form pore in cell membrane , cause leakage of the cytoplasmic content and cell lysis .
these toxin be originally think to target red blood cell ( erythrocyte ) and white blood cell ( leukocyte ) , respectively , but - pron - now know - pron - can affect other cell as well .
the gram - positive bacterium streptococcus pyogene produce streptolysin , watersoluble hemolysin that bind to the cholesterol moiety in the host cell membrane to form a pore .
the two type of streptolysin , o and s , be categorize by - pron - ability to cause hemolysis in erythrocyte in the absence or presence of oxygen .
streptolysin o be not active in the presence of oxygen , whereas streptolysin s be active in the presence of oxygen .
other important pore - form membrane - disrupt toxin include alpha toxin of staphylococcus aureus and pneumolysin of streptococcus pneumoniae .
bacterial phospholipase be membrane - disrupt toxin that degrade the phospholipid bilayer of cell membrane rather than form pore .
- pron - have already discuss the phospholipase associate with b . anthracis , l . pneumophila , and rickettsia specie that enable these bacteria to effect the lysis of phagosome .
these same phospholipase be also hemolysin .
other phospholipase that function as hemolysin include the alpha toxin of clostridium perfringen , phospholipase c of p . aeruginosa , and beta toxin of staphylococcus aureus .
some strain of s . aureus also produce a leukocidin call panton - valentine leukocidin ( pvl ) .
pvl consist of two subunit , s and f .
the s component act like the b subunit of an a - b exotoxin in that - pron - bind to glycolipid on the outer plasma membrane of animal cell .
the f - component act like the a subunit of an a - b exotoxin and carry the enzymatic activity .
the toxin insert and assemble into a pore in the membrane .
gene that encode
pvl be more frequently present in s . aureus strain that cause skin infection and
pneumonia . this result in the release of enzyme from the leukocyte , which , in turn , cause damage to lung tissue .
the third class of exotoxin be the superantigen .
these be exotoxin that trigger an excessive , nonspecific stimulation of immune cell to secrete cytokine ( chemical messenger ) .
the excessive production of cytokine , often call a cytokine storm , elicit a strong immune and inflammatory response that can cause life - threaten high fever , low blood pressure , multi - organ failure , shock , and death .
the prototype superantigen be the toxic shock syndrome toxin of s . aureus .
most toxic shock syndrome case be associate with vaginal colonization by toxinproduce s . aureus in menstruate woman  however , colonization of other body site can also occur .
some strain of streptococcus pyogene also produce superantigen  - pron - be refer to as the streptococcal mitogenic exotoxin and the streptococcal pyrogenic toxin .

virulence factors for survival in the host and immune evasion
evading the immune system be also important to invasiveness .
bacteria use a variety of virulence factor to evade phagocytosis by cell of the immune system .
for example , many bacteria produce capsule , which be use in adhesion but also aid in immune evasion by prevent ingestion by phagocyte .
the composition of the capsule prevent immune cell from be able to adhere and then phagocytose the cell .
in addition , the capsule make the bacterial cell much large , make - pron - harder for immune cell to engulf the pathogen ( figure one  five  .  one  seven ) .
a notable capsule - produce bacterium be the gram - positive pathogen streptococcus pneumoniae , which cause pneumococcal pneumonia , meningitis , septicemia , and other respiratory tract infection .
encapsulated strain of s . pneumoniae be more virulent than nonencapsulated strain and be more likely to invade the bloodstream and cause septicemia and meningitis .
some pathogen can also produce protease to protect - pron - against phagocytosis .
as describe in adaptive specific host defenses , the human immune system produce antibody that bind to surface molecule find on specific bacteria ( e . g . , capsule , fimbriae , flagella , lps ) .
this bind initiate phagocytosis and other mechanism of antibacterial killing and clearance .
protease combat antibody - mediate killing and clearance by attack and digest the antibody molecule ( figure one  five  .  one  seven ) .
in addition to capsule and protease , some bacterial pathogen produce other virulence factor that allow - pron - to evade the immune system .
the fimbriae of certain specie of streptococcus contain m protein , which alter the surface of streptococcus and inhibit phagocytosis by block the binding of the complement molecule that assist phagocyte in ingest bacterial pathogen .
the acid - fast bacterium mycobacterium tuberculosis ( the causative agent of tuberculosis ) produce a waxy substance know as mycolic acid in - pron - cell envelope .
when - pron - be engulf by phagocyte in the lung , the protective mycolic acid coat enable the bacterium to resist some of the killing mechanism within the phagolysosome .

some bacteria produce virulence factor that promote infection by exploit molecule naturally produce by the host .
for example , most strain of staphylococcus aureus produce the exoenzyme coagulase , which exploit the natural mechanism of blood clot to evade the immune system .
normally , blood clotting be trigger in response to blood vessel damage  platelet begin to plug the clot , and a cascade of reaction occur in which fibrinogen , a soluble protein make by the liver , be cleave into fibrin .
fibrin be an insoluble , thread - like protein that bind to blood platelet , cross - link , and contract to form a mesh of clumped platelet and red blood cell .
the result clot prevent further loss of blood from the damage blood vessel .
however , if bacteria release coagulase into the bloodstream , the fibrinogen - to - fibrin cascade be trigger in the absence of blood vessel damage .
the result clot coat the bacteria in fibrin , protect the bacteria from exposure to phagocytic immune cell circulate in the bloodstream .
whereas coagulase cause blood to clot , kinase have the opposite effect by trigger the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin , which be involve in the digestion of fibrin clot .
by digest a clot , kinase allow pathogen trap in the clot to escape and spread , similar to the way that collagenase , hyaluronidase , and dnase facilitate the spread of infection .
example of kinase include staphylokinase and streptokinase , produce by staphylococcus aureus and streptococcus pyogene , respectively .
- pron - be intriguing that s . aureus can produce both coagulase to promote clotting and staphylokinase to stimulate the digestion of clot .
the action of the coagulase provide an important protective barrier from the immune system , but when nutrient supply be diminished or other condition signal a need for the pathogen to escape and spread , the production of staphylokinase can initiate this process .
a final mechanism that pathogen can use to protect - pron - against the immune system be call antigenic variation , which be the alteration of surface protein so that a pathogen be no longer recognize by the host 's immune system .
for example , the bacterium borrelia burgdorferi , the causative agent of lyme disease , contain a surface lipoprotein know as vlse . because of genetic recombination during dna replication and repair , this bacterial protein undergoes antigenic variation .
each time fever occur , the vlse protein in b . burgdorferi can differ so much that antibody against previous vlse sequence be not effective .
- pron - be believe that this variation in the vlse contribute to the ability b . burgdorferi to cause chronic disease .
another important human bacterial pathogen that use antigenic variation to avoid the immune system be neisseria gonorrhoeae , which cause the sexually transmit disease gonorrhea .
this bacterium be well known for - pron - ability to undergo antigenic variation of - pron - type iv pili to avoid immune defense .

viral virulence
although viral pathogen be not similar to bacterial pathogen in term of structure , some of the property that contribute to - pron - virulence be similar .
virus use adhesin to facilitate adhesion to host cell , and certain envelop virus rely on antigenic variation to avoid the host immune defense .
these virulence factor be discuss in more detail in the following section .
viral adhesins
one of the first step in any viral infection be adhesion of the virus to specific receptor on the surface of cell .
this process be mediate by adhesin that be part of the viral capsid or membrane envelope .
the interaction of viral adhesin with specific cell receptor define the tropism ( preferential targeting ) of virus for specific cell , tissue , and organ in the body .
the spike protein hemagglutinin find on influenzavirus be an example of a viral adhesin  - pron - allow the virus to bind to the sialic acid on the membrane of host respiratory and intestinal cell .
another viral adhesin be the glycoprotein gp two  zero , find on hiv .
for hiv to infect cell of the immune system , - pron - must interact with two receptor on the surface of cell .
the first interaction involve bind between gp one  two  zero and the cd four cellular marker that be find on some essential immune system cell .
however , before viral entry into the cell can occur , a second interaction between gp one  two  zero and one of two chemokine receptor ( ccr five and cxcr four ) must occur .

antigenic drift be the result of point mutation cause slight change in the spike protein hemagglutinin ( h ) and neuraminidase ( n ) .
on the other hand , antigenic shift be a major change in spike protein due to gene reassortment .
this reassortment for antigenic shift occur typically when two different influenza virus infect the same host .
the rate of antigenic variation in influenza virus be very high , make - pron - difficult for the immune system to recognize the many different strain of influenzavirus .
although the body may develop immunity to one strain through natural exposure or vaccination , antigenic variation result in the continual emergence of new strain that the immune system will not recognize .
this be the main reason that vaccine against influenzavirus must be give annually .
each year 's influenza vaccine provide protection against the most prevalent strain for that year , but new or different strain may be more prevalent the following year .

although fungi and parasite be important pathogen cause infectious disease , - pron - pathogenic mechanism and virulence factor be not as well characterize as those of bacteria .
despite the relative lack of detailed mechanism , the stage of pathogenesis and general mechanism of virulence involve in disease production by these pathogen be similar to those of bacteria .
fungal virulence pathogenic fungi can produce virulence factor that be similar to the bacterial virulence factor that have be discuss earlier in this chapter .
in this section , - pron - will look at the virulence factor associate with specie of candida , cryptococcus , claviceps , and aspergillus .
candida albican be an opportunistic fungal pathogen and causative agent of oral thrush , vaginal yeast infection , and cutaneous candidiasis .
candida produce adhesin ( surface glycoprotein ) that bind to the phospholipid of epithelial and endothelial cell .
to assist in spread and tissue invasion , candida produce protease and phospholipase ( i . e . , exoenzyme ) .
one of these protease degrade keratin , a structural protein find on epithelial cell , enhance the ability of the fungus to invade host tissue .
in animal study , - pron - have be show that the addition of a protease inhibitor lead to attenuation of
candida infection . [ nine ]
similarly , the phospholipase can affect the integrity of host cell membrane to facilitate invasion .
the main virulence factor for cryptococcus , a fungus that cause pneumonia and meningitis , be capsule production .
the polysaccharide glucuronoxylomannan be the principal constituent of the cryptococcus capsule .
similar to encapsulated bacterial cell , encapsulate cryptococcus cell be more resistant to phagocytosis than nonencapsulated cryptococcus , which be effectively phagocytose and , therefore , less virulent .
like some bacteria , many fungi produce exotoxin .
fungal toxin be call mycotoxin .
clavicep purpurea , a fungus that grow on rye and related grain , produce a mycotoxin call ergot toxin , an alkaloid responsible for the disease know as ergotism .
there be two form of ergotism  gangrenous and convulsive .
in gangrenous ergotism , the ergot toxin cause vasoconstriction , result in improper blood flow to the extremity , eventually lead to gangrene .
a famous outbreak of gangrenous ergotism occur in eastern europe during the five th century ad due to the consumption of rye contaminate with c . purpurea .
in convulsive ergotism , the toxin target the central nervous system , cause mania and hallucination .
the mycotoxin aflatoxin be a virulence factor produce by the fungus aspergillus , an opportunistic pathogen that can enter the body via contaminate food or by inhalation .
inhalation of the fungus can lead to the chronic pulmonary disease aspergillosis , characterize by fever , bloody sputum , and / or asthma .
aflatoxin act in the host as both a mutagen ( a substance that cause mutation in dna ) and a carcinogen ( a substance involve in cause cancer ) , and have be associate with the development of liver cancer .
aflatoxin have also be show to cross the blood - placental barrier . [ one  zero ]
a second mycotoxin produce by aspergillus be gliotoxin .
this toxin promote virulence by induce host cell to self - destruct and by evade the host 's immune response by inhibit the function of phagocytic cell as well as the pro - inflammatory response .
like candida , aspergillus also produce several protease .
one be elastase , which break down the protein elastin find in the connective tissue of the lung , lead to the development of lung disease .

protozoan virulence protozoan pathogen be unicellular eukaryotic parasite that have virulence factor and pathogenic mechanism analogous to prokaryotic and viral pathogen , include adhesin , toxin , antigenic variation , and the ability to survive inside phagocytic vesicle .
protozoan often have unique feature for attach to host cell .
the protozoan giardia lamblia , which cause the intestinal disease giardiasis , use a large adhesive disc compose of microtubule to attach to the intestinal mucosa .
during adhesion , the flagella of g . lamblia move in a manner that draw fluid out from under the disc , result in an area of low pressure that facilitate adhesion to epithelial cell .
giardia do not invade the intestinal cell but rather cause inflammation ( possibly through the release of cytopathic substance that cause damage to the cell ) and shorten the intestinal villi , inhibit absorption of nutrient .
some protozoan be capable of antigenic variation .
the obligate intracellular pathogen plasmodium falciparum ( one of the causative agent of malaria ) reside inside red blood cell , where - pron - produce an adhesin membrane protein know as pfemp one .
this protein be express on the surface of the infected erythrocyte , cause blood cell to stick to each other and to the wall of blood vessel .
this process impede blood flow , sometimes lead to organ failure , anemia , jaundice ( yellowing of skin and sclera of the eye due to buildup of bilirubin from lysed red blood cell ) , and , subsequently , death .
although pfemp one can be recognize by the host 's immune system , antigenic variation in the structure of the protein over time prevent - pron - from be easily recognize and eliminate .
this allow malaria to persist as a chronic infection in many individual .
the virulence factor of trypanosoma brucei , the causative agent of african sleep sickness , include the ability to form capsule and undergo antigenic variation .
t . brucei evade phagocytosis by produce a dense glycoprotein coat that resemble a bacterial capsule .
over time , host antibody be produce that recognize this coat , but t . brucei be able to alter the structure of the glycoprotein to evade recognition .

explain how antigenic variation by protozoan pathogen help - pron - survive in the host .
helminth virulence helminths , or parasitic worm , be multicellular eukaryotic parasite that depend heavily on virulence factor that allow - pron - to gain entry to host tissue .
for example , the aquatic larval form of schistosoma mansoni , which cause schistosomiasis , penetrate intact skin with the aid of protease that degrade skin protein , include elastin .
to survive within the host long enough to perpetuate - pron - often - complex life cycle , helminth need to evade the immune system .
some helminth be so large that the immune system be ineffective against - pron - .
other , such as adult roundworm ( which cause trichinosis , ascariasis , and other disease ) , be protect by a tough outer cuticle .
over the course of - pron - life cycle , the surface characteristic of the parasite vary , which may help prevent an effective immune response .
some helminth express polysaccharide call glycan on - pron - external surface  because chapter one  five  microbial mechanisms of pathogenicity six  nine  seven
these glycan resemble molecule produce by host cell , the immune system fail to recognize and attack the helminth as a foreign body .
this “ glycan gimmickry , " as - pron - have be call , serve as a protective cloak that allow the helminth to escape detection by the immune system . [ one  one ]
in addition to evading host defense , helminth can actively suppress the immune system .
s . mansoni , for example , degrade host antibody with protease .
helminth produce many other substance that suppress element of both innate nonspecific and adaptive specific host defense .
- pron - also release large amount of material into the host that may locally overwhelm the immune system or cause - pron - to respond inappropriately .

describe how helminth avoid be destroy by the host immune system .
summary one  five  .  one characteristics of infectious disease 
in an infection , a microorganism enter a host and begin to multiply .
some infection cause disease , which be any deviation from the normal function or structure of the host .

sign of a disease be objective and be measure .
symptom of a disease be subjective and be report by the patient .

diseases can either be noninfectious ( due to genetic and environment ) or infectious ( due to pathogen ) .
some infectious disease be communicable ( transmissible between individual ) or contagious ( easily transmissible between individual )  other be noncommunicable , but may be contract via contact with environmental reservoir or animal ( zoonosis )

nosocomial disease be contract in hospital setting , whereas iatrogenic disease be the direct result of a medical procedure 
an acute disease be short in duration , whereas a chronic disease last for month or year .
latent disease last for year , but be distinguish from chronic disease by the lack of active replication during extended dormant period .

the period of disease include the incubation period , the prodromal period , the period of illness , the period of decline , and the period of convalescence .
these period be mark by change in the number of infectious agent and the severity of sign and symptom .

how pathogens cause disease 
koch 's postulate be use to determine whether a particular microorganism be a pathogen .
molecular koch
's postulate be use to determine what gene contribute to a pathogen 's ability to cause disease .

virulence , the degree to which a pathogen can cause disease , can be quantify by calculate either the id five  zero or ld five  zero of a pathogen on a give population .
 primary pathogen be capable of cause pathological change associate with disease in a healthy individual , whereas opportunistic pathogen can only cause disease when the individual be compromise by a break in protective barrier or immunosuppression .

infections and disease can be cause by pathogen in the environment or microbe in an individual 's resident microbiota .

infection can be classify as local , focal , or systemic depending on the extent to which the pathogen spread in the body .

a secondary infection can sometimes occur after the host 's defense or normal microbiota be compromise one  one .

one  five  .  three virulence factors of bacterial and viral pathogens

virulence factor contribute to a pathogen 's ability to cause disease .

exoenzymes and toxin allow pathogen to invade host tissue and cause tissue damage .
exoenzyme be classify accord to the macromolecule - pron - target and exotoxin be classify base on - pron - mechanism of action .

bacterial toxin include endotoxin and exotoxin .
endotoxin be the lipid
a component of the lps of the gramnegative cell envelope .
exotoxin be protein secrete mainly by gram - positive bacteria , but also be secrete by gram - negative bacteria .

bacterial pathogen may evade the host immune response by produce capsule to avoid phagocytosis , survive the intracellular environment of phagocyte , degrade antibody , or through antigenic variation .
 viral pathogen use adhesin for initiate infection and antigenic variation to avoid immune defense .

influenza virus use both antigenic drift and antigenic shift to avoid be recognize by the immune system .
one  five  .  four virulence factors of eukaryotic pathogens 
fungal and parasitic pathogen use pathogenic mechanism and virulence factor that be similar to those of bacterial pathogen  fungi initiate infection through the interaction of adhesin with receptor on host cell .
some fungi produce toxin and exoenzyme involve in disease production and capsule that provide protection of phagocytosis .

protozoa adhere to target cell through complex mechanism and can cause cellular damage through release of cytopathic substance .
some protozoa avoid the immune system through antigenic variation and production of capsule .

helminthic worm be able to avoid the immune system by coat - pron - exterior with glycan molecule that make - pron - look like host cell or by suppress the immune system .

global public health introduction
in the united states and other develop nation , public health be a key function of government .
a healthy citizenry be more productive , content , and prosperous  high rate of death and disease , on the other hand , can severely hamper economic productivity and foster social and political instability .
the burden of disease make - pron - difficult for citizen to work consistently , maintain employment , and accumulate wealth to better - pron - life and support a grow economy .
in this chapter , - pron - will explore the intersection between microbiology and epidemiology , the science that underlie public health .
epidemiology study how disease originate and spread throughout a population , with the goal of prevent outbreak and contain - pron - when - pron - do occur .
over the past two century , discovery in epidemiology have lead to public health policy that have transform life in develop nation , lead to the eradication ( or near eradication ) of many disease that be once cause of great human suffering and premature death .
however , the work of epidemiologist be far from finish .
numerous disease continue to plague humanity , and new disease be always emerge .
moreover , in the develop world , lack of infrastructure continue to pose many challenge to effort to contain disease .

explain the relationship between epidemiology and public health
the field of epidemiology concern the geographical distribution and timing of infectious disease occurrence and how - pron - be transmit and maintain in nature , with the goal of recognize and control outbreak .
the science of epidemiology include etiology ( the study of the cause of disease ) and investigation of disease transmission ( mechanism by which a disease be spread ) .
analyze disease in a population epidemiological analysis be always carry out with reference to a population , which be the group of individual that be at risk for the disease or condition .
the population can be define geographically , but if only a portion of the individual in that area be susceptible , additional criterion may be require .
susceptible individual may be define by particular behavior , such as intravenous drug use , own particular pet , or membership in an institution , such as a college .
be able to define the population be important because most measure of interest in epidemiology be make with reference to the size of the population .
the state of be disease be call morbidity .
morbidity in a population can be express in a few different way .
morbidity or total morbidity be express in number of individual without reference to the size of the population .
the morbidity rate can be express as the number of disease individual out of a standard number of individual in the population , such as one  zero  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero , or as a percent of the population .
there be two aspect of morbidity that be relevant to an epidemiologist  a disease 's prevalence and - pron - incidence .
prevalence be the number , or proportion , of individual with a particular illness in a give population at a point in time .
for example , the centers for disease control and prevention ( cdc ) estimate that in two  zero  one  two , there be about one  .  two million people one  three year and old with an active human immunodeficiency virus ( hiv ) infection .
express as a proportion , or rate , this be a prevalence of four  six  seven infect person per one  zero  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero in the population . [ one ]

- pron - also complain of abdominal pain and cramping , and most be severely dehydrate .
alarm by the number of case , hospital staff make some call and learn that other regional hospital be also see one  zero to two  zero similar case per day .

chapter one  six  disease and epidemiology seven  zero  five disease that be constantly present ( often at a low level ) in a population within a particular geographic region be call endemic disease .
for example , malaria be endemic to some region of brazil , but be not endemic to the united states .
disease for which a large than expected number of case occur in a short time within a geographic region be call epidemic disease .
influenza be a good example of a commonly epidemic disease .
incidence pattern of influenza tend to rise each winter in the northern hemisphere .
these seasonal increase be expect , so - pron - would not be accurate to say that influenza be epidemic every winter  however , some winter have an usually large number of seasonal influenza case in particular region , and such situation would qualify as epidemic ( figure one  six  .  three and figure one  six  .  four ) .
an epidemic disease signal the breakdown of an equilibrium in disease frequency , often result from some change in environmental condition or in the population .
in the case of influenza , the disruption can be due to antigenic shift or drift ( see virulence factors of bacterial and viral pathogens ) , which allow influenza virus strain to circumvent the acquire immunity of - pron - human host .
an epidemic that occur on a worldwide scale be call a pandemic disease .
for example , hiv / aids be a pandemic disease and novel influenza virus strain often become pandemic .

etiology
when study an epidemic , an epidemiologist 's first task be to determinate the cause of the disease , call the etiologic agent or causative agent .
connect a disease to a specific pathogen can be challenge because of the extra effort typically require to demonstrate direct causation as oppose to a simple association .
- pron - be not enough to observe an association between a disease and a suspect pathogen  control experiment be need to eliminate other possible cause .
in addition , pathogen be typically difficult to detect when there be no immediate clue as to what be cause the outbreak .
sign and symptom of disease be also commonly nonspecific , mean that many different agent can give rise to the same set of sign and symptom .
this complicate diagnosis even when a causative agent be familiar to scientist .
robert koch be the first scientist to specifically demonstrate the causative agent of a disease ( anthrax ) in the late one  eight  zero  zero .
koch develop four criterion , now know as koch 's postulate , which have to be meet in order to positively link a disease with a pathogenic microbe .
without koch 's postulate , the golden age of microbiology would not have occur .
between one  eight  seven  six and one  nine  zero  five , many common disease be link with - pron - etiologic agent , include cholera , diphtheria , gonorrhea , meningitis , plague , syphilis , tetanu , and tuberculosis .
today , - pron - use the molecular koch 's postulate , a variation of koch 's original postulate that can be use to establish a link between the disease state and virulence trait unique to a pathogenic strain of a microbe .
koch 's original postulate and molecular koch 's postulate be describe in more detail in how pathogens cause disease .

list some challenge to determine the causative agent of a disease outbreak .
the role of public health organizations
the main national public health agency in the united states be the centers for disease control and prevention ( cdc ) , an agency of the department of health and human services .
the cdc be charge with protect the public from disease and injury .
one way that the cdc carry out this mission be by oversee the national notifiable disease surveillance system ( nndss ) in cooperation with regional , state , and territorial public health department .
the nndss monitor disease consider to be of public health importance on a national scale .
such disease be call notifiable disease or reportable disease because all case must be report to the cdc .
a physician treat a patient with a notifiable disease be legally require to submit a report on the case .
notifiable disease include hiv infection , measle , west nile virus infection , and many other .
some state have - pron - own list of notifiable disease that include disease beyond those on the cdc 's list .
notifiable disease be track by epidemiological study and the data be use to inform health - care provider and the public about possible risk .
the cdc publish the morbidity and mortality weekly report ( mmwr ) , which provide physician and health - care worker with update on public health issue and the late datum pertain to notifiable disease .
table one  six  .  one be an example of the kind of datum contain in the mmwr .

learning objectives

explain the research approach use by the pioneer of epidemiology

explain how descriptive , analytical , and experimental epidemiological study go about determine the cause of morbidity and mortality
epidemiology have - pron - root in the work of physician who look for pattern in disease occurrence as a way to understand how to prevent - pron - .
the idea that disease could be transmit be an important precursor to make sense of some of the pattern .
in one  five  four  six , girolamo fracastoro first propose the germ theory of disease in - pron - essay de contagione et contagiosis morbis , but this theory remain in competition with other theory , such as the miasma hypothesis , for many year ( see what - pron - ancestors knew ) .
uncertainty about the cause of disease be not an absolute barrier to obtain useful knowledge from pattern of disease .
some important researcher , such as florence nightingale , subscribe to the miasma hypothesis .
the transition to acceptance of the germ theory during the one  nine th century provide a solid mechanistic grounding to the study of disease pattern .
the study of one  nine th century physician and researcher such as john snow , florence nightingale , ignaz semmelweis , joseph lister , robert koch , louis pasteur , and other sow the seed of modern epidemiology .
link to learning chapter one  six  disease and epidemiology
seven  zero  nine pioneers of epidemiology john snow ( figure one  six  .  five ) be a british physician know as the father of epidemiology for determine the source of the one  eight  five  four broad street cholera epidemic in london .
base on observation - pron - have make during an early cholera outbreak ( one  eight  four  eight – one  eight  four  nine ) , snow propose that cholera be spread through a fecal - oral route of transmission and that a microbe be the infectious agent .
- pron - investigate the one  eight  five  four cholera epidemic in two way .
first , suspect that contaminate water be the source of the epidemic , snow identify the source of water for those infect .
- pron - find a high frequency of cholera case among individual who obtain - pron - water from the river thames downstream from london .
this water contain the refuse and sewage from london and settlement upstream .
- pron - also note that brewery worker do not contract cholera and on investigation find the owner provide the worker with beer to drink and state that - pron - likely do not drink water . [ five ]
second , - pron - also painstakingly map the incidence of cholera and find a high frequency among those individual use a particular water pump locate on broad street .
in response to snow 's advice , local official remove the pump 's handle , [ six ] result in the containment of the broad street cholera epidemic .
snow 's work represent an early epidemiological study and - pron - result in the first know public health response to an epidemic .
snow 's meticulous case - tracking method be now common practice in study disease outbreak and in associate new disease with - pron - cause .
- pron - work further shed light on unsanitary sewage practice and the effect of waste dumping in the thames .
additionally , - pron - work support the germ theory of disease , which argue disease could be transmit through contaminate item , include water contaminate with fecal matter .
snow 's work illustrate what be refer to today as a common source spread of infectious disease , in which there be a single source for all of the individual infect .
in this case , the single source be the contaminate well below the broad street pump .
type of common source spread include point source spread , continuous common source spread , and intermittent common source spread .
in point source spread of infectious disease , the common source operate for a short time period - less than the incubation period of the pathogen .
an example of point source spread be a single contaminate potato salad at a group picnic .
in continuous common source spread , the infection occur for an extended period of time , longer than the incubation period .
an example of continuous common source spread would be the source of london water take downstream of the city , which be continuously contaminate with sewage from upstream .
finally , with intermittent common source spread , infection occur for a period , stop , and then begin again .
this may be see in infection from a well that be contaminate only after large rainfall and that clear - pron - of contamination after a short period .
in contrast to common source spread , propagate spread occur through direct or indirect person - to - person contact .
with propagated spread , there be no single source for infection  each infect individual become a source for one or more subsequent infection .
with propagated spread , unless the spread be stop immediately , infection occur for long than the incubation period .
although point source often lead to large - scale but localized outbreak of short duration , propagate spread typically result in long duration outbreak that can vary from small to large , depend on the population and the disease ( figure one  six  .  six ) .
in addition , because of person - to - person transmission , propagate spread can not be easily stop at a single source like point source spread .

florence nightingale 's work be another example of an early epidemiological study .
in one  eight  five  four , nightingale be part of a contingent of nurse dispatch by the british military to care for wounded soldier during the crimean war .
nightingale keep meticulous record regard the cause of illness and death during the war .
- pron - recordkeeping be a fundamental task of what would later become the science of epidemiology .
- pron - analysis of the datum - pron - collect be publish in one  eight  five  eight .
in this book , - pron - present monthly frequency datum on cause of death in a wedge chart histogram ( figure one  six  .  seven ) .
this graphical presentation of datum , unusual at the time , powerfully illustrate that the vast majority of chapter one  six  disease and epidemiology seven  one  one casualty during the war occur not due to wound sustain in action but to what nightingale deem preventable infectious disease .
often these disease occur because of poor sanitation and lack of access to hospital facility .
nightingale 's finding lead to many reform in the british military 's system of medical care .
joseph lister provide early epidemiological evidence lead to good public health practice in clinic and hospital .
these setting be notorious in the mid -  one  eight  zero  zero for fatal infection of surgical wound at a time when the germ theory of disease be not yet widely accept ( see foundations of modern cell theory ) .
most physician do not wash - pron - hand between patient visit or clean and sterilize - pron - surgical tool .
lister , however , discover the disinfect property of carbolic acid , also know as phenol ( see use chemical to control microorganisms ) .
- pron - introduce several disinfection protocol that dramatically lower post - surgical infection rates . [ seven ]
- pron - demand that surgeon who work for - pron - use a five % carbolic acid solution to clean - pron - surgical tool between patient , and even go so far as to spray the solution onto bandage and over the surgical site during operation ( figure one  six  .  eight ) .
- pron - also take precaution not to introduce source of infection from - pron - skin or clothing by remove - pron - coat , roll up - pron - sleeve , and wash - pron - hand in a dilute solution of carbolic acid before and during the surgery .

the colored section of the wedge represent different cause of death  wound ( pink ) , preventable infectious disease ( gray ) , and all other cause ( brown ) .

type of epidemiological studies today , epidemiologist make use of study design , the manner in which datum be gather to test a hypothesis , similar to those of researcher study other phenomenon that occur in population .
these approach can be divide into observational study ( in which subject be not manipulate ) and experimental study ( in which subject be manipulate ) .
collectively , these study give modern - day epidemiologist multiple tool for explore the connection between infectious disease and the population of susceptible individual - pron - may infect .
observational studies
in an observational study , datum be gather from study participant through measurement ( such as physiological variable like white blood cell count ) , or answer to question in interview ( such as recent travel or exercise link to learn chapter one  six  disease and epidemiology seven  one  three frequency ) .
the subject in an observational study be typically choose at random from a population of affected or unaffected individual .
however , the subject in an observational study be in no way manipulate by the researcher .
observational study be typically easy to carry out than experimental study , and in certain situation - pron - may be the only study possible for ethical reason .
observational study be only able to measure association between disease occurrence and possible causative agent  - pron - do not necessarily prove a causal relationship .
for example , suppose a study find an association between heavy coffee drinking and low incidence of skin cancer .
this may suggest that coffee prevent skin cancer , but there may be another unmeasured factor involve , such as the amount of sun exposure the participant receive .
if - pron - turn out that coffee drinker work more in office and spend less time outside in the sun than those who drink less coffee , then - pron - may be possible that the low rate of skin cancer be due to less sun exposure , not to coffee consumption .
the observational study can not distinguish between these two potential cause .
there be several useful approach in observational study .
these include method classify as descriptive epidemiology and analytical epidemiology .
descriptive epidemiology gather information about a disease outbreak , the affect individual , and how the disease have spread over time in an exploratory stage of study .
this type of study will involve interview with patient , - pron - contact , and - pron - family member  examination of sample and medical record  and even history of food and beverage consume .
such a study may be conduct while the outbreak be still occur .
descriptive study may form the basis for develop a hypothesis of causation that could be test by more rigorous observational and experimental study .
analytical epidemiology employ carefully select group of individual in an attempt to more convincingly evaluate hypothesis about potential cause for a disease outbreak .
the selection of case be generally make at random , so the result be not biased because of some common characteristic of the study participant .
analytical study may gather - pron - datum by go back in time ( retrospective study ) , or as event unfold forward in time ( prospective study ) .
retrospective study gather datum from the past on present - day case .
datum can include thing like the medical history , age , gender , or occupational history of the affect individual .
this type of study examine association between factor choose or available to the researcher and disease occurrence .
prospective study follow individual and monitor - pron - disease state during the course of the study .
datum on the characteristic of the study subject and - pron - environment be gather at the beginning and during the study so that subject who become ill may be compare with those who do not .
again , the researcher can look for association between the disease state and variable that be measure during the study to shed light on possible cause .
analytical study incorporate group into - pron - design to assist in tease out association with disease .
approach to group - base analytical study include cohort study , case - control study , and cross - sectional study .
the cohort method examine group of individual ( call cohort ) who share a particular characteristic .
for example , a cohort may consist of individual bear in the same year and the same place  or - pron - may consist of people who practice or avoid a particular behavior , e . g . , smoker or nonsmoker .
in a cohort study , cohort can be follow prospectively or study retrospectively .
if only a single cohort be follow , then the affect individual be compare with the unaffected individual in the same group .
disease outcome be record and analyze to try to identify correlation between characteristic of individual in the cohort and disease incidence .
cohort study be a useful way to determine the cause of a condition without violate the ethical prohibition of expose subject to a risk factor .
cohort be typically identify and define base on suspect risk factor to which individual have already be expose through - pron - own choice or circumstance .
case - control study be typically retrospective and compare a group of individual with a disease to a similar group of individual without the disease .
case - control study be far more efficient than cohort study because researcher can deliberately select subject who be already affect with the disease as oppose to wait to see which subject from a random sample will develop a disease .
a cross - sectional study analyze randomly select individual in a population and compare individual affect by a disease or condition to those unaffected at a single point in time .
subject be compare to look for association between certain measurable variable and the disease or condition .
cross - sectional study be also use to determine seven  one  four chapter one  six  disease and epidemiology
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five the prevalence of a condition .
experimental studies experimental epidemiology use laboratory or clinical study in which the investigator manipulate the study subject to study the connection between disease and potential causative agent or to assess treatment .
example of treatment may be the administration of a drug , the inclusion or exclusion of different dietary item , physical exercise , or a particular surgical procedure .
animal or human be use as test subject .
because experimental study involve manipulation of subject , - pron - be typically more difficult and sometimes impossible for ethical reason .
koch 's postulate require experimental intervention to determine the causative agent for a disease .
unlike observational study , experimental study can provide strong evidence support cause because other factor be typically hold constant when the researcher manipulate the subject .
the outcome for one group receive the treatment be compare to outcome for a group that do not receive the treatment but be treat the same in every other way .
for example , one group may receive a regimen of a drug administer as a pill , while the untreated group receive a placebo ( a pill that look the same but have no active ingredient ) .
both group be treat as similarly as possible except for the administration of the drug .
because other variable be hold constant in both the treated and the untreated group , the researcher be more certain that any change in the treated group be a result of the specific manipulation .
experimental study provide the strong evidence for the etiology of disease , but - pron - must also be design carefully to eliminate subtle effect of bias .
typically , experimental study with human be conduct as doubleblind study , mean neither the subject nor the researcher know who be a treatment case and who be not .
this design remove a well - know cause of bias in research call the placebo effect , in which knowledge of the treatment by either the subject or the researcher can influence the outcome .
