understand how infectious pathogen spread be critical to prevent infectious disease .
many pathogen require a live host to survive , while other may be able to persist in a dormant state outside of a live host .
but have infect one host , all pathogen must also have a mechanism of transfer from one host to another or - pron - will die when - pron - host die .
pathogen often have elaborate adaptation to exploit host biology , behavior , and ecology to live in and move between host .
host have evolve defense against pathogen , but because - pron - rate of evolution be typically slow than - pron - pathogen ( because - pron - generation time be long ) , host be usually at an evolutionary disadvantage .
this section will explore where pathogen survive - both inside and outside host - and some of the many way - pron - move from one host to another .
reservoirs and carriers for pathogen to persist over long period of time - pron - require reservoir where - pron - normally reside .
reservoir can be live organism or nonlive site .
nonlive reservoir can include soil and water in the environment .
these may naturally harbor the organism because - pron - may grow in that environment .
these environment may also become contaminate with pathogen in human fece , pathogen shed by intermediate host , or pathogen contain in the remain of intermediate host .
pathogen may have mechanism of dormancy or resilience that allow - pron - to survive ( but typically not to reproduce ) for vary period of time in nonlive environment .
for example , clostridium tetani survive in the soil and in the presence of oxygen as a resistant endospore .
although many virus be soon destroy once in contact with air , water , or other non - physiological condition , certain type be capable of persist outside of a live cell for vary amount of time .
for example , a study that look at the ability of influenza virus to infect a cell culture after vary amount of time on a banknote show survival time from four  eight hour to one  seven day , depend on how - pron - be deposit on the banknote . [ eight ]
on the other hand , cold - cause rhinovirus be somewhat fragile , typically survive less than a day outside of physiological fluid .
a human act as a reservoir of a pathogen may or may not be capable of transmit the pathogen , depend on the stage of infection and the pathogen .
to help prevent the spread of disease among school child , the cdc have develop guideline base on the risk of transmission during the course of the disease .
for example , child with chickenpox be consider contagious for five day from the start of the rash , whereas child with most gastrointestinal illness should be keep home for two  four hour after the symptom disappear .

this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five an individual capable of transmit a pathogen without display symptom be refer to as a carrier .
a passive carrier be contaminate with the pathogen and can mechanically transmit - pron - to another host  however , a passive carrier be not infect .
for example , a health - care professional who fail to wash - pron - hand after see a patient harbor an infectious agent could become a passive carrier , transmit the pathogen to another patient who become infected .
by contrast , an active carrier be an infected individual who can transmit the disease to other .
an active carrier may or may not exhibit sign or symptom of infection .
for example , active carrier may transmit the disease during the incubation period ( before - pron - show sign and symptom ) or the period of convalescence ( after symptom have subside ) .
active carrier who do not present sign or symptom of disease despite infection be call asymptomatic carrier .
pathogen such as hepatitis b virus , herpe simplex virus , and hiv be frequently transmit by asymptomatic carrier .
mary mallon , better know as typhoid mary , be a famous historical example of an asymptomatic carrier .
an irish immigrant , mallon work as a cook for household in and around new york city between one  nine  zero  zero and one  nine  one  five .
in each household , the resident develop typhoid fever ( cause by salmonella typhi ) a few week after mallon start work .
later investigation determine that mallon be responsible for at least one  two  two case of typhoid fever , five of which be fatal . [ nine ] see eye on ethics  typhoid mary for more about the mallon case .
a pathogen may have more than one live reservoir .
in zoonotic disease , animal act as reservoir of human disease and transmit the infectious agent to human through direct or indirect contact .
in some case , the disease also affect the animal , but in other case the animal be asymptomatic .
in parasitic infection , the parasite 's preferred host be call the definitive host .
in parasite with complex life cycle , the definitive host be the host in which the parasite reach sexual maturity .
some parasite may also infect one or more intermediate host in which the parasite go through several immature life cycle stage or reproduce asexually .

transmission regardless of the reservoir , transmission must occur for an infection to spread .
first , transmission from the reservoir to the individual must occur .
then , the individual must transmit the infectious agent to other susceptible individual , either directly or indirectly .
pathogenic microorganism employ diverse transmission mechanism .

chapter one  six
 disease and epidemiology seven  one  seven contact transmission contact transmission include direct contact or indirect contact .
person - to - person transmission be a form of direct contact transmission .
here the agent be transmit by physical contact between two individual ( figure one  six  .  nine ) through action such as touching , kiss , sexual intercourse , or droplet spray .
direct contact can be categorize as vertical , horizontal , or droplet transmission .
vertical direct contact transmission occur when pathogen be transmit from mother to child during pregnancy , birth , or breastfeed .
other kind of direct contact transmission be call horizontal direct contact transmission .
often , contact between mucous membrane be require for entry of the pathogen into the new host , although skin - to - skin contact can lead to mucous membrane contact if the new host subsequently touch a mucous membrane .
contact transmission may also be site - specific  for example , some disease can be transmit by sexual contact but not by other form of contact .
when an individual cough or sneeze , small droplet of mucus that may contain pathogen be eject .
this lead to direct droplet transmission , which refer to droplet transmission of a pathogen to a new host over distance of one meter or less .
a wide variety of disease be transmit by droplet , include influenza and many form of pneumonia .
transmission over distance great than one meter be call airborne transmission .
indirect contact transmission involve inanimate object call fomite that become contaminate by pathogen from an infected individual or reservoir ( figure one  six  .  one  zero ) .
for example , an individual with the common cold may sneeze , cause droplet to land on a fomite such as a tablecloth or carpet , or the individual may wipe - pron - nose and then transfer mucus to a fomite such as a doorknob or towel .
transmission occur indirectly when a new susceptible host later touch the fomite and transfer the contaminated material to a susceptible portal of entry .
fomite can also include object use in clinical setting that be not properly sterilize , such as syrinx , needle , catheter , and surgical equipment .
pathogens transmit indirectly via such fomite be a major cause of healthcare - associate infection ( see control microbial growth ) .
figure one  six  .  nine direct contact transmission of pathogen can occur through physical contact .
many pathogen require contact with a mucous membrane to enter the body , but the host may transfer the pathogen from another point of contact ( e . g . , hand ) to a mucous membrane ( e . g . , mouth or eye ) .

contaminated doorknob , towel , and syrinx be all common example of fomite .

the term vehicle transmission refer to the transmission of pathogen through vehicle such as water , food , and air .
water contamination through poor sanitation method lead to waterborne transmission of disease .
waterborne disease remain a serious problem in many region throughout the world .
the world health organization ( who ) estimate that contaminate drinking water be responsible for more than five  zero  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero death each year . [ one  zero ]
similarly , food contaminate through poor handling or storage can lead to foodborne transmission of disease ( figure one  six  .  one  one ) .
dust and fine particle know as aerosol , which can float in the air , can carry pathogen and facilitate the airborne transmission of disease .
for example , dust particle be the dominant mode of transmission of hantavirus to human .
hantavirus be find in mouse fece , urine , and saliva , but when these substance dry , - pron - can disintegrate into fine particle that can become airborne when disturbed  inhalation of these particle can lead to a serious and sometimes fatal respiratory infection .
although droplet transmission over short distance be consider contact transmission as discuss above , long distance transmission of droplet through the air be consider vehicle transmission .
unlike large particle that drop quickly out of the air column , fine mucus droplet produce by cough or sneeze can remain suspend for long period of time , travel considerable distance .
in certain condition , droplet desiccate quickly to produce a droplet nucleus that be capable of transmit pathogen  air temperature and humidity can have an impact on effectiveness of airborne transmission .
tuberculosis be often transmit via airborne transmission when the causative agent , mycobacterium tuberculosis , be release in small particle with cough .
because tuberculosis require as few as one  zero microbe to initiate a new infection , patient with tuberculosis must be treat in room equip with special ventilation , and anyone enter the room should wear a mask .

vector transmission diseases can also be transmit by a mechanical or biological vector , an animal ( typically an arthropod ) that carry the disease from one host to another .
mechanical transmission be facilitate by a mechanical vector , an animal that carry a pathogen from one host to another without be infect - pron - .
for example , a fly may land on fecal matter and later transmit bacteria from the fece to food that - pron - land on  a human eat the food may then become infect by the bacteria , result in a case of diarrhea or dysentery ( figure one  six  .  one  two ) .
biological transmission occur when the pathogen reproduce within a biological vector that transmit the pathogen from one host to another ( figure one  six  .  one  two ) .
arthropod be the main vector responsible for biological transmission ( figure one  six  .  one  three ) .
most arthropod vector transmit the pathogen by bite the host , create a wound that serve as a portal of entry .
the pathogen may go through part of - pron - reproductive cycle in the gut or salivary gland of the arthropod to facilitate - pron - transmission through the bite .
for example , hemipteran ( call " kiss bug " or " assassin bug " ) transmit chagas disease to human by defecate when - pron - bite , after which the human scratch or rub the infect fece into a mucous membrane or break in the skin .
biological insect vector include mosquito , which transmit malaria and other disease , and lice , which transmit typhus .
other arthropod vector can include arachnid , primarily tick , which transmit lyme disease and other disease , and mite , which transmit scrub typhus and rickettsial pox .
biological transmission , because - pron - involve survival and reproduction within a parasitized vector , complicate the biology of the pathogen and - pron - transmission .
there be also important non - arthropod vector of disease , include mammal and bird .
various specie of mammal can transmit rabie to human , usually by mean of a bite that transmit the rabie virus .
chicken and other domestic poultry can transmit avian influenza to human through direct or indirect contact with avian influenza virus a shed in the bird ' saliva , mucous , and fece .

use gmo to stop the spread of zika
in two  zero  one  six , an epidemic of the zika virus be link to a high incidence of birth defect in south america and central america .
as winter turn to spring in the northern hemisphere , health official correctly predict the virus would spread to north america , coincide with the breeding season of - pron - major vector , the aedes aegypti mosquito .
the range of the a . aegypti mosquito extend well into the southern united states ( figure one  six  .  one  four ) .
because these same mosquito serve as vector for other problematic disease ( dengue fever , yellow fever , and other ) , various method of mosquito control have be propose as solution .
chemical pesticide have be use effectively in the past , and be likely to be use again  but because chemical pesticide can have negative impact on the environment , some scientist have propose an alternative that involve genetically engineer a . aegypti so that - pron - can not reproduce .
this method , however , have be the subject of some controversy .
one method that have work in the past to control pest , with little apparent downside , have be sterile male introduction .
this method control the screw - worm fly pest in the southwest united states and fruit fly pest of fruit crop .
in this method , male of the target specie be rear in the lab , sterilize with radiation , and release into the environment where - pron - mate with wild female , who subsequently bear no live offspring .
repeat release shrink the p population .
a similar method , take advantage of recombinant dna technology , [ one  one ] introduce a dominant lethal allele into male mosquito that be suppress in the presence of tetracycline ( an antibiotic ) during laboratory rear .
the male be release into the environment and mate with female mosquito .
unlike the sterile male method , these mating produce offspring , but - pron - die as larvae from the lethal gene in the absence of tetracycline in the environment .
as of two  zero  one  six , this method have yet to be implement in the united states , but a uk company test the method in piracicaba , brazil , and find an eight  two % reduction in wild a . aegypti larvae and a nine  one % reduction in dengue case in the treat area . [ one  two ]
in august two  zero  one  six , amid news of zika infection in several florida community , the fda give the uk company permission to test this same mosquito control method in key west , florida , pende compliance with local and state regulation and a referendum in the affect community .
the use of genetically modify organism ( gmos ) to control a disease vector have - pron - advocate as well as - pron - opponent .
in theory , the system could be use to drive the a . aegypti mosquito extinct - a noble goal accord to some , give the damage - pron - do to human populations . [ one  three ]
but opponent of the idea be concerned that the gene could escape the specie boundary of a . aegypti and cause problem in other specie , lead to unforeseen ecological consequence .
opponent be also wary of the program because - pron - be be administer by a for - profit corporation , create the potential for conflict of interest that would have to be tightly regulate  and - pron - be not clear how any unintended consequence of the program could be reverse .
there be other epidemiological consideration as well .
aedes aegypti be apparently not the only vector for the zika virus .
aedes albopictus , the asian tiger mosquito , be also a vector for the zika virus . [ one  four ] a . albopictus be now widespread around the planet include much of the united states ( figure one  six  .  one  four ) .
many other mosquito eye on ethics chapter one  six
 disease and epidemiology seven  two  three have be find to harbor zika virus , though - pron - capacity to act as vector be unknown . [ one  five ] genetically modify strain of a . aegypti will not control the other specie of vector .
finally , the zika virus can apparently be transmit sexually between human host , from mother to child , and possibly through blood transfusion .
all of these factor must be consider in any approach to control the spread of the virus .
clearly there be risk and unknown involve in conduct an open - environment experiment of an as - yet poorly understand technology .
but allow the zika virus to spread unchecked be also risky .
do the threat of a zika epidemic justify the ecological risk of genetically engineering mosquito ?
be current method of mosquito control sufficiently ineffective or harmful that - pron - need to try untested alternative ?
these be the question be put to public health official now .

hospital and other health - care facility generally set up special ward to isolate patient with particularly hazardous disease such as tuberculosis or ebola
( figure one  six  .  one  five ) .
depend on the setting , these ward may be equip with special air - handle method , and personnel may implement special protocol to limit the risk of transmission , such as personal protective equipment or the use of chemical disinfectant spray upon entry and exit of medical personnel .
the duration of the quarantine depend on factor such as the incubation period of the disease and the evidence suggestive of an infection .
the patient may be release if sign and symptom fail to materialize when expect or if preventive treatment can be administer in order to limit the risk of transmission .
if the infection be confirm , the patient may be compel to remain in isolation until the disease be no longer consider contagious .
in the united states , public health authority may only quarantine patient for certain disease , such as cholera , diphtheria , infectious tuberculosis , and strain of influenza capable of cause a pandemic .
individual enter the united states or move between state may be quarantine by the cdc if - pron - be suspect of have be expose to one of these disease .
although the cdc routinely monitor entry point to the united states for crew or passenger display illness , quarantine be rarely implement .

an isolation ward for ebola patient in lagos , nigeria .

healthcare - associated ( nosocomial ) infections hospitals , retirement home , and prison attract the attention of epidemiologist because these setting be associate with increase incidence of certain disease .
high rate of transmission may be cause by characteristic of the environment - pron - , characteristic of the population , or both .
consequently , special effort must be take to limit the risk of infection in these setting .
infection acquire in health - care facility , include hospital , be call nosocomial infection or healthcareassociate infection ( hai ) .

both who and some national public health agency such as the cdc monitor and prepare for emerge infectious disease .
an emerge infectious disease be either new to the human population or have show an increase in prevalence in the previous twenty year .
whether the disease be new or condition have change to cause an increase in frequency , - pron - status as emerge imply the need to apply resource to understand and control - pron - grow impact .
emerge disease may change - pron - frequency gradually over time , or - pron - may experience sudden epidemic growth .
the importance of vigilance be make clear during the ebola hemorrhagic fever epidemic in western africa through two  zero  one  four – two  zero  one  five .
although health expert have be aware of the ebola virus since the one  nine  seven  zero , an outbreak on such a large scale have never happen before ( figure one  six  .  one  six ) .
previous human epidemic have be small , isolated , and contain .
indeed , the gorilla and chimpanzee population of western africa have suffer far bad from ebola than the human population .
the pattern of small isolate human epidemic change in two  zero  one  four .
- pron - high transmission rate , couple with cultural practice for treatment of the dead and perhaps - pron - emergence in an urban setting , cause the disease to spread rapidly , and thousand of people die .
the international public health community respond with a large emergency effort to treat patient and contain the epidemic .
emerge disease be find in all country , both develop and develop ( table one  six  .  two ) .
some nation be better equip to deal with - pron - .
national and international public health agency watch for epidemic like the ebola outbreak in develop country because those country rarely have the health - care infrastructure and expertise to deal with large outbreak effectively .
even with the support of international agency , the system in western africa struggle to identify and care for the sick and control spread .
in addition to the altruistic goal of save life and assist nation lack in resource , the global nature of transportation mean that an outbreak anywhere can spread quickly to every corner of the planet .
manage an epidemic in one location - - pron - source - be far easy than fight - pron - on many front .
ebola be not the only disease that need to be monitor in the global environment .
in two  zero  one  five , who set priority on several emerge disease that have a high probability of cause epidemic and that be poorly understand ( and thus urgently require research and development effort ) .
a reemerge infectious disease be a disease that be increase in frequency after a previous period of decline .
- pron - reemergence may be a result of change condition or old prevention regime that be no longer work .
example of such disease be drug - resistant form of tuberculosis , bacterial pneumonia , and malaria .
drug - resistant strain of the bacteria cause gonorrhea and syphilis be also become more widespread , raise concern of untreatable infection .

sars outbreak and identification
on november one  six , two  zero  zero  two , the first case of a sars outbreak be report in guangdong province , china .
the patient exhibit influenza - like symptom such as fever , cough , myalgia , sore throat , and shortness of breath .
as the number of case grow , the chinese government be reluctant to openly communicate information about the epidemic with the world health organization ( who ) and the international community .
the slow reaction of chinese public health official to this new disease contribute to the spread of the epidemic within and later outside china .
in april two  zero  zero  three , the chinese government finally respond with a huge public health effort involve quarantine , medical checkpoint , and massive cleaning project .
over one  eight  ,  zero  zero  zero people be quarantine in beijing alone .
large funding initiative be create to improve health - care facility , and dedicated outbreak team be create to coordinate the response .
by august one  six , two  zero  zero  three , the last sars patient be release from a hospital in beijing nine month after the first case be report in china .
in the meantime , sars spread to other country on - pron - way to become a global pandemic .
though the infectious agent have yet to be identify , - pron - be think to be an influenza virus .
the disease be name sars , an acronym for severe acute respiratory syndrome , until the etiologic agent could be identify .
travel restriction to southeast asia be enforce by many country .
by the end of the outbreak , there be eight  ,  zero  nine  eight case and seven  seven  four death worldwide .
china and hong kong be hit hardest by the epidemic , but taiwan , singapore , and toronto , canada , also see significant number of case .
fortunately , timely public health response in many country effectively suppress the outbreak and lead to - pron - eventual containment .
for example , the disease be introduce to canada in february two  zero  zero  three by an infected traveler from hong kong , who die shortly after be hospitalize .
by the end of march , hospital isolation and home quarantine procedure be in place in the toronto area , stringent anti - infection protocol be introduce in hospital , and the medium be actively report on the disease .
public health official track down contact of infect individual and quarantine - pron - .
a total of two  five  ,  zero  zero  zero individual be quarantine in the city .
thank to the vigorous response of the canadian public health community , sars be bring under control in toronto by june , a mere four month after - pron - be introduce .
in two  zero  zero  three , who establish a collaborative effort to identify the causative agent of sars , which have now be identify as a coronavirus that be associate with horseshoe bat .
the genome of the sars virus be sequence and publish by researcher at the cdc and in canada in may two  zero  zero  three , and in the same month researcher in the netherlands confirm the etiology of the disease by fulfil koch 's postulate for the sars coronavirus .
the last know case of sars worldwide be report in two  zero  zero  four .

summary one  six  .  one
the language of epidemiologists  epidemiology be the science underlie public health .

morbidity mean be in a state of illness , whereas mortality refer to death  both morbidity rate and mortality rate be of interest to epidemiologist .

incidence be the number of new case ( morbidity or mortality ) , usually express as a proportion , during a specified time period  prevalence be the total number affect in the population , again usually express as a proportion .
 sporadic disease only occur rarely and largely without a geographic focus .
endemic disease occur at a constant ( and often low ) level within a population .
epidemic disease and pandemic disease occur when an outbreak occur on a significantly large than expect level , either locally or globally , respectively .

koch 's postulate specify the procedure for confirm a particular pathogen as the etiologic agent of a particular disease .
koch 's postulate have limitation in application if the microbe can not be isolate and culture or if there be no animal host for the microbe .
in this case , molecular koch 's postulate would be utilize .

in the united states , the centers for disease control and prevention monitor notifiable disease and publish weekly update in the morbidity and mortality weekly report .
one  six  .  two
track infectious diseases

early pioneer of epidemiology such as john snow , florence nightingale , and joseph lister , study disease at the population level and use datum to disrupt disease transmission .

descriptive epidemiology study rely on case analysis and patient history to gain information about outbreak , frequently while - pron - be still occur .

retrospective epidemiology study use historical datum to identify association with the disease state of present case .
prospective epidemiology study gather datum and follow case to find association with future disease state .
 analytical epidemiology study be observational study that be carefully design to compare group and uncover association between environmental or genetic factor and disease .
 experimental epidemiology study generate strong evidence of causation in disease or treatment by manipulate subject and compare - pron - with control subject .
one  six  .  three modes of disease transmission 
reservoir of human disease can include the human and animal population , soil , water , and inanimate object or material .

contact transmission can be direct or indirect through physical contact with either an infected host ( direct ) or contact with a fomite that an infected host have make contact with previously ( indirect ) .

vector transmission occur when a live organism carry an infectious agent on - pron - body ( mechanical ) or as an infection host - pron - ( biological ) , to a new host .

vehicle transmission occur when a substance , such as soil , water , or air , carry an infectious agent to a new host .
 healthcare - associate infection ( hai ) , or nosocomial infection , be acquire in a clinical setting .
transmission be facilitate by medical intervention and the high concentration of susceptible , immunocompromised individual in clinical setting .
one  six  .  four global public health

the world health organization ( who ) be an agency of the united nations that collect and analyze datum on disease occurrence from member nation .
who also coordinate public health program and response to international health emergency .

emerge disease be those that be new to human population or that have be increase in the past two decade .
reemerge disease be those that be make a resurgence in susceptible population after previously have be control in some geographic area .

physical barriers physical barrier play an important role in prevent microbe from reach tissue that be susceptible to infection .
at the cellular level , barrier consist of cell that be tightly join to prevent invader from cross through to deep tissue .
for example , the endothelial cell that line blood vessel have very tight cell - to - cell junction , block microbe from gain access to the bloodstream .
cell junction be generally compose of cell membrane protein that may connect with the extracellular matrix or with complementary protein from neighboring cell .

desmosome have intermediate fiber that act like shoelace , tie two cell together , allow small material to pass through the result space .
gap junction be channel between two cell that permit - pron - communication via signal .

the keratin make the skin 's surface mechanically tough and resistant to degradation by bacterial enzyme .

infection can occur when the skin barrier be compromise or break .

mucous membranes
the mucous membrane line the nose , mouth , lung , and urinary and digestive tract provide another nonspecific barrier against potential pathogen .
mucous membrane consist of a layer of epithelial cell bind by tight junction .
the epithelial cell secrete a moist , sticky substance call mucus , which cover and protect the more fragile cell layer beneath - pron - and trap debris and particulate matter , include microbe .
mucus secretion also contain antimicrobial peptide .
in many region of the body , mechanical action serve to flush mucus ( along with trapped or dead microbe ) out of the body or away from potential site of infection .
for example , in the respiratory system , inhalation can bring microbe , dust , mold spore , and other small airborne debris into the body .
this debris become trap in the mucus line the respiratory tract , a layer know as the mucociliary blanket .
the epithelial cell line the upper part of the respiratory tract be call ciliate epithelial cell because - pron - have hair - like appendage know as cilia .
movement of the cilia propel debris - laden mucus out and away from the lung .
the expel mucus be then swallow and destroy in the stomach , or cough up , or sneeze out ( figure one  seven  .  five ) .
this system of removal be often call the mucociliary escalator .

the mucociliary escalator push mucus away from the lung , along with any debris or microorganism that may be trap in the sticky mucus , and the mucus move up to the esophagus where - pron - can be remove by swallow .
the mucociliary escalator be such an effective barrier to microbe that the lung , the lowermost ( and most sensitive ) portion of the respiratory tract , be long consider to be a sterile environment in healthy individual .
only recently have research suggest that healthy lung may have a small normal microbiota .
disruption of the mucociliary escalator by the damaging effect of smoking or disease such as cystic fibrosis can lead to increase colonization of bacteria in the low respiratory tract and frequent infection , which highlight the importance of this physical barrier to host defense .
like the respiratory tract , the digestive tract be a portal of entry through which microbe enter the body , and the mucous membrane line the digestive tract provide a nonspecific physical barrier against ingested microbe .
the intestinal tract be line with epithelial cell , intersperse with mucus - secrete goblet cell ( figure one  seven  .  six ) .
this mucus mix with material receive from the stomach , trap foodborne microbe and debris .
the mechanical action of peristalsis , a series of muscular contraction in the digestive tract , move the slough mucus and other material through the intestine , rectum , and anus , excrete the material in fece .

endothelia
the epithelial cell line the urogenital tract , blood vessel , lymphatic vessel , and certain other tissue be know as endothelia .
these tightly packed cell provide a particularly effective frontline barrier against invader .
the endothelia of the blood - brain barrier , for example , protect the central nervous system ( cns ) , which consist of the brain and the spinal cord .
the cns be one of the most sensitive and important area of the body , as microbial infection of the cns can quickly lead to serious and often fatal inflammation .
the cell junction in the blood vessel travel through the cns be some of the tight and tough in the body , prevent any transient microbe in the bloodstream from enter the cns .
this keep the cerebrospinal fluid that surround and bathe the brain and spinal cord sterile under normal condition .

mechanical defenses
in addition to physical barrier that keep microbe out , the body have a number of mechanical defense that physically remove pathogen from the body , prevent - pron - from take up residence .
- pron - have already discuss several example of mechanical defense , include the shedding of skin cell , the expulsion of mucus via the mucociliary escalator , and the excretion of fece through intestinal peristalsis .
other important example of mechanical defense include the flush action of urine and tear , which both serve to carry microbe away from the body .
the flush action of urine be largely responsible for the normally sterile environment of the urinary tract , which include the chapter one  seven
 innate nonspecific host defense seven  four  one kidney , ureter , and urinary bladder .
urine pass out of the body wash out transient microorganism , prevent - pron - from take up residence .
the eye also have physical barrier and mechanical mechanism for prevent infection .
the eyelash and eyelid prevent dust and airborne microorganism from reach the surface of the eye .
any microbe or debris that make - pron - past these physical barrier may be flush out by the mechanical action of blink , which bathe the eye in tear , wash debris away ( figure one  seven  .  seven ) .

microbiome
in various region of the body , resident microbiota serve as an important first - line defense against invade pathogen .
through - pron - occupation of cellular bind site and competition for available nutrient , the resident microbiota prevent the critical early step of pathogen attachment and proliferation require for the establishment of an infection .
for example , in the vagina , member of the resident microbiota compete with opportunistic pathogen like the yeast candida .
this competition prevent infection by limit the availability of nutrient , thus inhibit the growth of candida , keep - pron - population in check .
similar competition occur between the microbiota and potential pathogen on the skin , in the upper respiratory tract , and in the gastrointestinal tract .
as will be discuss later in this chapter , the resident microbiota also contribute to the chemical defense of the innate nonspecific host defense .

the importance of the normal microbiota in host defense be highlight by the increase susceptibility to infectious disease when the microbiota be disrupt or eliminate .
treatment with antibiotic can significantly deplete the normal microbiota of the gastrointestinal tract , provide an advantage for pathogenic bacteria to colonize and cause diarrheal infection .
in the case of diarrhea cause by clostridium difficile , the infection can be severe and potentially lethal .
one strategy for treat c . difficile infection be fecal transplantation , which involve the transfer of fecal material from a donor ( screen for potential pathogen ) into the intestine of the recipient patient as a method of restore the normal microbiota and combat c . difficile infection .

one  seven  .  two chemical defenses learning objectives

describe how enzyme in body fluid provide protection against infection or disease  list and describe the function of antimicrobial peptide , complement component , cytokine , and acute - phase protein  describe similarity and difference among classic , alternate , and lectin complement pathway
in addition to physical defense , the innate nonspecific immune system use a number of chemical mediator that inhibit microbial invader .
the term “ chemical mediator " encompass a wide array of substance find in various body fluid and tissue throughout the body .
chemical mediator may work alone or in conjunction with each other to inhibit microbial colonization and infection .
some chemical mediator be endogenously produce , mean - pron - be produce by human body cell  other be produce exogenously , mean that - pron - be produce by certain microbe that be part of the microbiome .

the antimicrobial peptide ( amp ) be a special class of nonspecific cell - derive mediator with broad - spectrum antimicrobial property .
some amp be produce routinely by the body , whereas other be primarily produce ( or produce in great quantity ) in response to the presence of an invade pathogen .
research have begin explore how amp can be use in the diagnosis and treatment of disease .
amp may induce cell damage in microorganism in a variety of way , include by inflict damage to membrane , destroy dna and rna , or interfere with cell - wall synthesis .
depend on the specific antimicrobial mechanism , a particular amp may inhibit only certain group of microbe ( e . g . , gram - positive or gram - negative bacteria ) or - pron - may be more broadly effective against bacteria , fungus , protozoa , and virus .
many amp be find on the skin , but - pron - can also be find in other region of the body .
a family of amp call defensin can be produce by epithelial cell throughout the body as well as by cellular defense such as macrophage and neutrophil ( see cellular defenses ) .
defensin may be secrete or act inside host cell  - pron - combat microorganism by damage - pron - plasma membrane .
amp call bacteriocin be produce exogenously by certain member of the resident microbiota within the gastrointestinal tract .
the gene code for these type of amp be often carry on plasmid and can be pass between different specie within the resident microbiota through lateral or horizontal gene transfer .
there be numerous other amp throughout the body .

plasma protein mediators
many nonspecific innate immune factor be find in plasma , the fluid portion of blood .
plasma contain electrolyte , sugar , lipid , and protein , each of which help to maintain homeostasis ( i . e . , stable internal body function ) , and contain the protein involve in the clotting of blood .
additional protein find in blood plasma , such as acute - phase protein , complement protein , and cytokine , be involve in the nonspecific innate immune response .
plasma versus serum
there be two term for the fluid portion of blood  plasma and serum .
how do - pron - differ if - pron - be both fluid and lack cell ?
the fluid portion of blood leave over after coagulation ( blood cell clotting ) have take place be serum .
although molecule such as many vitamin , electrolyte , certain sugar , complement protein , and antibody be still present in serum , clotting factor be largely deplete .
plasma , conversely , still contain all the clotting element .
to obtain plasma from blood , an anticoagulant must be use to prevent clotting .
example of anticoagulant include heparin and ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid ( edta ) .
because clotting be inhibit , once obtain , the sample must be gently spin down in a centrifuge .
the heavy , denser blood cell form a pellet at the bottom of a centrifuge tube , while the fluid plasma portion , which be light and less dense , remain above the cell pellet .
acute - phase proteins
the acute - phase protein be another class of antimicrobial mediator .
acute - phase protein be primarily produce in the liver and secrete into the blood in response to inflammatory molecule from the immune system .
example of acute - phase protein include c - reactive protein , serum amyloid a , ferritin , transferrin , fibrinogen , and mannosebinding lectin .
each of these protein have a different chemical structure and inhibit or destroy microbe in some way ( table one  seven  .  four ) .

the complement system
the complement system be a group of plasma protein mediator that can act as an innate nonspecific defense while also serve to connect innate and adaptive immunity ( discuss in the next chapter ) .
the complement system be compose of more than three  zero protein ( include c one through c nine ) that normally circulate as precursor protein in blood .
these precursor protein become activate when stimulate or trigger by a variety of factor , include the presence of microorganism .
complement protein be consider part of innate nonspecific immunity because - pron - be always present in the blood and tissue fluid , allow - pron - to be activate quickly .
also , when activate through the alternative pathway ( describe later in this section ) , complement protein target pathogen in a nonspecific manner .
the process by which circulate complement precursor become functional be call complement activation .
this process be a cascade that can be trigger by one of three different mechanism , know as the alternative , classical , and lectin pathway .
the alternative pathway be initiate by the spontaneous activation of the complement protein c three .
the hydrolysis of c three produce two product , c three a and c three b .
when no invader microbe be present , c three b be very quickly degrade in a hydrolysis reaction use the water in the blood .
however , if invade microbe be present , c three b attach to the surface of these microbe .
once attach , c three b will recruit other complement protein in a cascade ( figure one  seven  .  nine ) .
the classical pathway provide a more efficient mechanism of activate the complement cascade , but - pron - depend upon the production of antibody by the specific adaptive immune defense .
to initiate the classical pathway , a specific antibody must first bind to the pathogen to form an antibody - antigen complex .
this activate the first protein in the complement cascade , the c one complex .
the c one complex be a multipart protein complex , and each component participate in the full activation of the overall complex .
follow recruitment and activation of the c one complex , the remain classical pathway complement protein be recruit and activate in a cascading sequence ( figure one  seven  .  nine ) .
the lectin activation pathway be similar to the classical pathway , but - pron - be trigger by the binding of mannose - binding lectin , an acute - phase protein , to carbohydrate on the microbial surface .
like other acute - phase protein , lectin be produce by liver cell and be commonly upregulate in response to inflammatory signal receive by the body during an infection ( figure one  seven  .  nine ) .

the three complement activation pathway have different trigger , as show here , but all three result in the activation of the complement protein c three , which produce c three a and c three b .
the latter bind to the surface of the target cell and then work with other complement protein to cleave c five into c five a and c five b .
c five b also bind to the cell surface and then recruit c six through c nine  these molecule form a ring structure call the membrane attack complex ( mac ) , which punch through the cell membrane of the invade pathogen , cause - pron - to swell and burst .
although each complement activation pathway be initiate in a different way , - pron - all provide the same protective outcome  opsonization , inflammation , chemotaxis , and cytolysis .
the term opsonization refer to the coating of a pathogen by a chemical substance ( call an opsonin ) that allow phagocytic cell to recognize , engulf , and destroy - pron - more easily .
opsonin from the complement cascade include c one q , c three b , and c four b .
additional important opsonin include mannose - bind protein and antibody .

c five a be well - characterize anaphylatoxin with potent proinflammatory function .
anaphylatoxin activate mast cell , cause degranulation and the release of inflammatory chemical signal , include mediator that cause vasodilation and increase vascular permeability .
c five a be also one of the most potent chemoattractant for neutrophil and other white blood cell , cellular defense that will be discuss in the next section .
the complement protein c six , c seven , c eight , and c nine assemble into a membrane attack complex ( mac ) , which allow c nine to polymerize into pore in the membrane of gram - negative bacteria .
these pore allow water , ion , and other molecule to move freely in and out of the targeted cell , eventually lead to cell lysis and death of the pathogen ( figure one  seven  .  nine ) .
however , the mac be only effective against gram - negative bacteria  - pron - can not penetrate the thick layer of peptidoglycan associate with cell wall of gram - positive bacteria .
since the mac do not pose a lethal threat to gram - positive bacterial pathogen , complement - mediate opsonization be more important for - pron - clearance .
cytokines cytokines be soluble protein that act as communication signal between cell .
in a nonspecific innate immune response , various cytokine may be release to stimulate production of chemical mediator or other cell function , such as cell proliferation , cell differentiation , inhibition of cell division , apoptosis , and chemotaxis .
when a cytokine bind to - pron - target receptor , the effect can vary widely depend on the type of cytokine and the type of cell or receptor to which - pron - have bind .
the function of a particular cytokine can be describe as autocrine , paracrine , or endocrine ( figure one  seven  .  one  zero ) .
in autocrine function , the same cell that release the cytokine be the recipient of the signal  in other word , autocrine function be a form of self - stimulation by a cell .
in contrast , paracrine function involve the release of cytokine from one cell to other nearby cell , stimulate some response from the recipient cell .
last , endocrine function occur when cell release cytokine into the bloodstream to be carry to target cell much farther away .

inflammation - elicit mediator
many of the chemical mediator discuss in this section contribute in some way to inflammation and fever , which be nonspecific immune response discuss in more detail in inflammation and fever .
cytokine stimulate the production of acute - phase protein such as c - reactive protein and mannose - binding lectin in the liver .
these acutephase protein act as opsonin , activate complement cascade through the lectin pathway .
some cytokine also bind mast cell and basophil , induce - pron - to release histamine , a proinflammatory compound .
histamine receptor be find on a variety of cell and mediate proinflammatory event , such as bronchoconstriction ( tightening of the airway ) and smooth muscle contraction .
in addition to histamine , mast cell may release other chemical mediator , such as leukotriene .
leukotriene be lipid - base proinflammatory mediator that be produce from the metabolism of arachidonic acid in the cell membrane of leukocyte and tissue cell .
compare with the proinflammatory effect of histamine , those of leukotriene be more potent and longer last .
together , these chemical mediator can induce cough , vomiting , and diarrhea , which serve to expel pathogen from the body .
certain cytokine also stimulate the production of prostaglandin , chemical mediator that promote the inflammatory effect of kinin and histamine .
prostaglandin can also help to set the body temperature higher , lead to fever , which promote the activity of white blood cell and slightly inhibit the growth of pathogenic microbe ( see inflammation and fever ) .
another inflammatory mediator , bradykinin , contribute to edema , which occur when fluid and leukocyte leak out of the bloodstream and into tissue .
- pron - bind to receptor on cell in the capillary wall , cause the capillary to dilate and become more permeable to fluid .

neutrophils ( pmn )
neutrophils ( pmn ) be frequently involve in the elimination and destruction of extracellular bacteria .
- pron - be capable of migrate through the wall of blood vessel to area of bacterial infection and tissue damage , where - pron - seek out and kill infectious bacteria .
pmn granule contain a variety of defensin and hydrolytic enzyme that help - pron - destroy bacteria through phagocytosis ( describe in more detail in pathogen recognition and phagocytosis )
in addition , when many neutrophil be bring into an infected area , - pron - can be stimulate to release toxic molecule into the surround tissue to better clear infectious agent .
this be call degranulation .
another mechanism use by neutrophil be neutrophil extracellular trap ( nets ) , which be extrude mesh of chromatin that be closely associate with antimicrobial granule protein and component .
chromatin be dna with associate protein ( usually histone protein , around which dna wrap for organization and pack within a cell ) .
by create and release a mesh or lattice - like structure of chromatin that be couple with antimicrobial protein , the neutrophil can mount a highly concentrated and efficient attack against nearby pathogen .
protein frequently associate with net include lactoferrin , gelatinase , cathepsin g , and myeloperoxidase .
each have a different mean of promote antimicrobial activity , help neutrophil eliminate pathogen .
the toxic protein in net may kill some of the body 's own cell along with invade pathogen .
however , this collateral damage can be repair after the danger of the infection have be eliminate .
as neutrophil fight an infection , a visible accumulation of leukocyte , cellular debris , and bacteria at the site of infection can be observe .
this buildup be what - pron - call pus ( also know as purulent or suppurative discharge or drainage ) .
the presence of pus be a sign that the immune defense have be activate against an infection  chapter one  seven  innate nonspecific host defense seven  five  five historically , some physician believe that induce pus formation could actually promote the healing of wound .
the practice of promote " laudable pu " ( by , for instance , wrap a wound in greasy wool soak in wine ) date back to the ancient physician galen in the two nd century ad , and be practice in variant form until the one  seven th century ( though - pron - be not universally accept ) .
today , this method be no longer practice because - pron - now know that - pron - be not effective .
although a small amount of pus formation can indicate a strong immune response , artificially induce pus formation do not promote recovery .

 innate nonspecific host defense seven  five  seven natural killer cells
most lymphocyte be primarily involve in the specific adaptive immune response , and thus will be discuss in the follow chapter .
an exception be the natural killer cell ( nk cell )  these mononuclear lymphocyte use nonspecific mechanism to recognize and destroy cell that be abnormal in some way .
cancer cell and cell infect with virus be two example of cellular abnormality that be target by nk cell .
recognition of such cell involve a complex process of identify inhibitory and activate molecular marker on the surface of the target cell .
molecular marker that make up the major histocompatibility complex ( mhc ) be express by healthy cell as an indication of " self .
"
this will be cover in more detail in next chapter .
nk cell be able to recognize normal mhc marker on the surface of healthy cell , and these mhc marker serve as an inhibitory signal prevent nk cell activation .
however , cancer cell and virus - infect cell actively diminish or eliminate expression of mhc marker on - pron - surface .
when these mhc marker be diminished or absent , the nk cell interpret this as an abnormality and a cell in distress .
this be one part of the nk cell activation process ( figure one  seven  .  one  six ) .
nk cell be also activate by bind to activate molecular molecule on the target cell .
these activate molecular molecule include “ altered self " or
" nonself " molecule .
when a nk cell recognize a decrease in inhibitory normal mhc molecule and an increase in activate molecule on the surface of a cell , the nk cell will be activate to eliminate the cell in distress .
figure one  seven  .  one  six natural killer ( nk ) cell be inhibit by the presence of the major histocompatibility cell ( mhc ) receptor on healthy cell .
cancer cell and virus - infect cell have reduce expression of mhc and increase expression of activate molecule .

extravasation ( diapedesis ) of leukocyte
some phagocyte be leukocyte ( wbcs ) that normally circulate in the bloodstream .
to reach pathogen locate in infect tissue , leukocyte must pass through the wall of small capillary blood vessel within tissue .
this process , call extravasation , or diapedesis , be initiate by complement factor c five a , as well as cytokine release into the immediate vicinity by resident macrophage and tissue cell respond to the presence of the infectious agent ( figure one  seven  .  one  nine ) .
similar to c five a , many of these cytokine be proinflammatory and chemotactic , and - pron - bind to cell of small capillary blood vessel , initiate a response in the endothelial cell line the inside of the blood vessel wall .
this response involve the upregulation and expression of various cellular adhesion molecule and receptor .
leukocyte pass through will stick slightly to the adhesion molecule , slow down and roll along the blood vessel wall near the infected area .
when - pron - reach a cellular junction , - pron - will bind to even more of these adhesion molecule , flatten out and squeeze through the cellular junction in a process know as transendothelial migration .
this mechanism of “ rolling adhesion " allow leukocyte to exit the bloodstream and enter the infect area , where - pron - can begin phagocytose the invade pathogen .
note that extravasation do not occur in artery or vein .
these blood vessel be surround by thick , multilayer protective wall , in contrast to the thin single - cell - layer wall of capillary .
furthermore , the blood flow in artery be too turbulent to allow for roll adhesion .
also , some leukocyte tend to respond to an infection more quickly than other .
the first to arrive typically be neutrophil , often within hour of a bacterial infection .
by contract , monocyte may take several day to leave the bloodstream and differentiate into macrophage .

pathogen recognition
as describe in the previous section , opsonization of pathogen by antibody  complement factor c one q , c three b , and c four b  and lectin can assist phagocytic cell in recognition of pathogen and attachment to initiate phagocytosis .
however , not all pathogen recognition be opsonin dependent .
phagocyte can also recognize molecular structure that be common to many group of pathogenic microbe .
such structure be call pathogen - associate molecular pattern ( pamps ) .
common pamp include the follow   peptidoglycan , find in bacterial cell wall   flagellin , a protein find in bacterial flagella   lipopolysaccharide ( lps ) from the outer membrane of gram - negative bacteria   lipopeptide , molecule express by most bacteria  and  nucleic acid such as viral dna or rna .
like numerous other pamp , these substance be integral to the structure of broad class of microbe .
the structure that allow phagocytic cell to detect pamp be call pattern recognition receptor ( prr ) .
one group of prr be the toll - like receptor ( tlr ) , which bind to various pamp and communicate with the nucleus of the phagocyte to elicit a response .
many tlr ( and other prr ) be locate on the surface of a phagocyte , but some can also be find embed in the membrane of interior compartment and organelle ( figure one  seven  .  two  zero ) .
these interior prr can be useful for the binding and recognition of intracellular pathogen that may have gain access to the inside of the cell before phagocytosis could take place .
viral nucleic acid , for example , may encounter an interior prr , trigger production of the antiviral cytokine interferon .
in addition to provide the first step of pathogen recognition , the interaction between pamp and prr on macrophage provide an intracellular signal that activate the phagocyte , cause - pron - to transition from a dormant state of readiness and slow proliferation to a state of hyperactivity , proliferation , production / secretion of cytokine , and enhance intracellular killing .
prr on macrophage also respond to chemical distress signal from damaged or stress cell .
this allow macrophage to extend - pron - response beyond protection from infectious disease to a broad role in the inflammatory response initiate from injury or other disease .

pathogen degradation
once pathogen recognition and attachment occur , the pathogen be engulf in a vesicle and bring into the internal compartment of the phagocyte in a process call phagocytosis ( figure one  seven  .  two  one ) .

to engulf the pathogen , the phagocyte form a pseudopod that wrap around the pathogen and then pinch - pron - off into a membrane vesicle call a phagosome .

the phagosome contain the pathogen fuse with one or more lysosome , form a phagolysosome .
formation of the phagolysosome enhance the acidification , which be essential for activation of ph - dependent digestive lysosomal enzyme and production of hydrogen peroxide and toxic reactive oxygen specie .
lysosomal enzyme such as lysozyme , phospholipase , and protease digest the pathogen .
other enzyme be involve a respiratory burst .
during the respiratory burst , phagocyte will increase - pron - uptake and consumption of oxygen , but not for energy production .
the increase oxygen consumption be focus on the production of superoxide anion , hydrogen peroxide , hydroxyl radical , and other reactive oxygen specie that be antibacterial .

explain the advantage and risk pose by inflammatory response the inflammatory response , or inflammation , be trigger by a cascade of chemical mediator and cellular response that may occur when cell be damage and stress or when pathogen successfully breach the physical barrier of the innate immune system .
although inflammation be typically associate with negative consequence of injury or disease , - pron - be a necessary process insofar as - pron - allow for recruitment of the cellular defense need to eliminate pathogen , remove damaged and dead cell , and initiate repair mechanism .
excessive inflammation , however , can result in local tissue damage and , in severe case , may even become deadly .
acute inflammation
an early , if not immediate , response to tissue injury be acute inflammation .
immediately follow an injury , vasoconstriction of blood vessel will occur to minimize blood loss .
the amount of vasoconstriction be relate to the amount of vascular injury , but - pron - be usually brief .
vasoconstriction be follow by vasodilation and increase vascular permeability , as a direct result of the release of histamine from resident mast cell .
increase blood flow and vascular permeability can dilute toxin and bacterial product at the site of injury or infection .
- pron - also contribute to the five observable sign associate with the inflammatory response  erythema ( redness ) , edema ( swell ) , heat , pain , and altered function .
vasodilation and increase vascular permeability be also associate with an influx of phagocyte at the site of injury and / or infection .
this can enhance the inflammatory response because phagocyte may release proinflammatory chemical when - pron - be activate by cellular distress signal release from damaged cell , by pamp , or by opsonin on the surface of pathogen .
activation of the complement system can further enhance the inflammatory response through the production of the anaphylatoxin
c five a .

eventually , tissue repair can begin in the wounded area .
chronic inflammation
when acute inflammation be unable to clear an infectious pathogen , chronic inflammation may occur .
this often result in an ongoing ( and sometimes futile ) low - level battle between the host organism and the pathogen .
the wounded area may heal at a superficial level , but pathogen may still be present in deep tissue , stimulate ongoing inflammation .
additionally , chronic inflammation may be involve in the progression of degenerative neurological disease such as alzheimer 's and parkinson 's , heart disease , and metastatic cancer .
chronic inflammation may lead to the formation of granuloma , pocket of infected tissue wall off and surround by wbc .
macrophage and other phagocyte wage an unsuccessful battle to eliminate the pathogen and dead cellular material within a granuloma .
one example of a disease that produce chronic inflammation be tuberculosis , which result in the formation of granuloma in lung tissue .
a tubercular granuloma be call a tubercle ( figure one  seven  .  two  four ) .
tuberculosis will be cover in more detail in bacterial infections of the respiratory tract .
chronic inflammation be not just associate with bacterial infection .
chronic inflammation can be an important cause of tissue damage from viral infection .
the extensive scar observe with hepatitis c infection and liver cirrhosis be the result of chronic inflammation .

fever a fever be an inflammatory response that extend beyond the site of infection and affect the entire body , result in an overall increase in body temperature .
body temperature be normally regulate and maintain by the hypothalamus , an anatomical section of the brain that function to maintain homeostasis in the body .
however , certain bacterial or viral infection can result in the production of pyrogen , chemical that effectively alter the “ thermostat setting " of the hypothalamus to elevate body temperature and cause fever .
pyrogens may be exogenous or endogenous .
for example , the endotoxin lipopolysaccharide ( lps ) , produce by gram - negative bacteria , be an exogenous pyrogen that may induce the leukocyte to release endogenous pyrogen such as interleukin -  one ( il -  one ) , il -  six , interferon - γ ( ifn - γ ) , and tumor necrosis factor ( tnf ) .
in a cascade effect , these molecule can then lead to the release of prostaglandin e two ( pge two ) from other cell , reset the hypothalamus to initiate fever ( figure one  seven  .  two  six ) .

the role of the hypothalamus in the inflammatory response .
macrophage recognize pathogen in an area and release cytokine that trigger inflammation .
the cytokine also send a signal up the vagus nerve to the hypothalamus .
like other form of inflammation , a fever enhance the innate immune defense by stimulate leukocyte to kill pathogen .
the rise in body temperature also may inhibit the growth of many pathogen since human pathogen be mesophile with optimum growth occur around three  five ° c ( nine  five ° f ) .
in addition , some study suggest that fever may also stimulate release of iron - sequester compound from the liver , thereby starve out microbe that rely on iron for growth . [ three ]
during fever , the skin may appear pale due to vasoconstriction of the blood vessel in the skin , which be mediate by the hypothalamus to divert blood flow away from extremity , minimize the loss of heat and raise the core temperature .
the hypothalamus will also stimulate shivering of muscle , another effective mechanism of generate heat and raise the core temperature .
the crisis phase occur when the fever break .
the hypothalamus stimulate vasodilation , result in a return of blood flow to the skin and a subsequent release of heat from the body .
the hypothalamus also stimulate sweat , which cool the skin as the sweat evaporate .
although a low - level fever may help an individual overcome an illness , in some instance , this immune response can be too strong , cause tissue and organ damage and , in severe case , even death .
the inflammatory response to bacterial superantigen be one scenario in which a life - threaten fever may develop .
superantigen be bacterial or viral protein that can cause an excessive activation of t cell from the specific adaptive immune defense , as well as an excessive release of cytokine that overstimulate the inflammatory response .
for example , staphylococcus aureus and streptococcus pyogene be capable of produce superantigen that cause toxic shock syndrome and scarlet fever , respectively .
both of these condition can be associate with very high , life - threaten fever in excess of four  two ° c ( one  zero  eight ° f ) .

summary one  seven  .  one physical defenses

nonspecific innate immunity provide a first line of defense against infection by nonspecifically block entry of microbe and target - pron - for destruction or removal from the body .

the physical defense of innate immunity include physical barrier , mechanical action that remove microbe and debris , and the microbiome , which compete with and inhibit the growth of pathogen .

the skin , mucous membrane , and endothelium throughout the body serve as physical barrier that prevent microbe from reach potential site of infection .
tight cell junction in these tissue prevent microbe from pass through .

microbes trap in dead skin cell or mucus be remove from the body by mechanical action such as shedding of skin cell , mucociliary sweeping , coughing , peristalsis , and flush of bodily fluid ( e . g . , urination , tear ) 
the resident microbiota provide a physical defense by occupy available cellular bind site and compete with pathogen for available nutrient .
one  seven  .  two chemical defenses

numerous chemical mediator produce endogenously and exogenously exhibit nonspecific antimicrobial function .

many chemical mediator be find in body fluid such as sebum , saliva , mucus , gastric and intestinal fluid , urine , tear , ceruman , and vaginal secretion .

antimicrobial peptide ( amp ) find on the skin and in other area of the body be largely produce in response to the presence of pathogen .
these include dermcidin , cathelicidin , defensin , histatin , and clinical focus chapter one  seven
 innate nonspecific host defenses seven  seven  one bacteriocin .

plasma contain various protein that serve as chemical mediator , include acute - phase protein , complement protein , and cytokine .

the complement system involve numerous precursor protein that circulate in plasma .
these protein become activated in a cascading sequence in the presence of microbe , result in the opsonization of pathogen , chemoattraction of leukocyte , induction of inflammation , and cytolysis through the formation of a membrane attack complex ( mac ) .

cytokine be protein that facilitate various nonspecific response by innate immune cell , include production of other chemical mediator , cell proliferation , cell death , and differentiation .

cytokines play a key role in the inflammatory response , trigger production of inflammation - elicit mediator such as acute - phase protein , histamine , leukotriene , prostaglandin , and bradykinin .
one  seven  .  three cellular defenses

the form element of the blood include red blood cell ( erythrocyte ) , white blood cell ( leukocyte ) , and platelet ( thrombocyte ) .
of these , leukocyte be primarily involve in the immune response .

all form element originate in the bone marrow as stem cell ( hsc ) that differentiate through hematopoiesis .

granulocyte be leukocyte characterize by a lob nucleus and granule in the cytoplasm .
these include neutrophil ( pmns ) , eosinophil , and basophil .

neutrophils be the leukocyte find in the large number in the bloodstream and - pron - primarily fight bacterial infection .

eosinophils target parasitic infection .
eosinophil and basophil be involve in allergic reaction .
both release histamine and other proinflammatory compound from - pron - granule upon stimulation .

mast cell function similarly to basophil but can be find in tissue outside the bloodstream .
 natural killer ( nk ) cell be lymphocyte that recognize and kill abnormal or infected cell by release protein that trigger apoptosis .

monocytes be large , mononuclear leukocyte that circulate in the bloodstream .
- pron - may leave the bloodstream and take up residence in body tissue , where - pron - differentiate and become tissue - specific macrophage and dendritic cell .
one  seven  .  four pathogen recognition and phagocytosis

phagocytes be cell that recognize pathogen and destroy - pron - through phagocytosis .

recognition often take place by the use of phagocyte receptor that bind molecule commonly find on pathogen , know as pathogen - associate molecular pattern ( pamps ) .

the receptor that bind pamp be call pattern recognition receptor , or prr .
toll - like receptor ( tlr ) be one type of prr find on phagocyte .

extravasation of white blood cell from the bloodstream into infected tissue occur through the process of transendothelial migration .

phagocytes degrade pathogen through phagocytosis , which involve engulf the pathogen , kill and digest - pron - within a phagolysosome , and then excrete undigested matter .
one  seven  .  five inflammation and fever  inflammation result from the collective response of chemical mediator and cellular defense to an injury or infection .

acute inflammation be short live and localize to the site of injury or infection .
chronic inflammation occur when the inflammatory response be unsuccessful , and may result in the formation of granuloma ( e . g . , with tuberculosis ) and scar ( e . g . , with hepatitis c viral infection and liver cirrhosis ) .

the five cardinal sign of inflammation be erythema , edema , heat , pain , and altered function .
these largely result from innate response that draw increase blood flow to the injure or infect tissue .

high animal , such as human , also possess an adaptive immune defense , which be highly specific for individual microbial pathogen .
this specific adaptive immunity be acquire through active infection or vaccination and serve as an important defense against pathogen that evade the defense of innate immunity .

adaptive immunity be define by two important characteristic  specificity and memory .
specificity refer to the adaptive immune system 's ability to target specific pathogen , and memory refer to - pron - ability to quickly respond to pathogen to which - pron - have previously be expose .
for example , when an individual recover from chickenpox , the body develop a memory of the infection that will specifically protect - pron - from the causative agent , the varicella - zoster virus , if - pron - be expose to the virus again later .
specificity and memory be achieve by essentially program certain cell involve in the immune response to respond rapidly to subsequent exposure of the pathogen .
this programming occur as a result of the first exposure to a pathogen or vaccine , which trigger a primary response .
subsequent exposure result in a secondary response that be fast and strong as a result of the body 's memory of the first exposure ( figure one  eight  .  two ) .
this secondary response , however , be specific to the pathogen in question .
for example , exposure to one virus ( e . g . , varicella - zoster virus ) will not provide protection against other viral disease ( e . g . , measle , mump , or polio ) .
adaptive specific immunity involve the action of two distinct cell type  b lymphocyte ( b cell ) and t lymphocyte ( t cell ) .
although b cell and t cell arise from a common hematopoietic stem cell differentiation pathway ( see figure one  seven  .  one  two ) , - pron - site of maturation and - pron - role in adaptive immunity be very different .
b cell mature in the bone marrow and be responsible for the production of glycoprotein call antibody , or immunoglobulin .
antibody be involve in the body 's defense against pathogen and toxin in the extracellular environment .
mechanism of adaptive specific immunity that involve b cell and antibody production be refer to as humoral immunity .
the maturation of t cell occur in the thymus .
t cell function as the central orchestrator of both innate and adaptive immune response .
- pron - be also responsible for destruction of cell infect with intracellular pathogen .
the targeting and destruction of intracellular pathogen by t cell be call cell - mediate immunity , or cellular immunity .

antigens activation of the adaptive immune defense be trigger by pathogen - specific molecular structure call antigen .
antigen be similar to the pathogen - associate molecular pattern ( pamps ) discuss in pathogen recognition and phagocytosis  however , whereas pamp be molecular structure find on numerous pathogen , antigen be unique to a specific pathogen .
the antigen that stimulate adaptive immunity to chickenpox , for example , be unique to the varicella - zoster virus but significantly different from the antigen associate with other viral pathogen .
the term antigen be initially use to describe molecule that stimulate the production of antibody  in fact , the term come from a combination of the word antibody and generator , and a molecule that stimulate antibody production be say to be antigenic .
however , the role of antigen be not limit to humoral immunity and the production of antibody  antigen also play an essential role in stimulate cellular immunity , and for this reason antigen be sometimes more accurately refer to as immunogen .
in this text , however , - pron - will typically refer to - pron - as antigen .
pathogen possess a variety of structure that may contain antigen .
for example , antigen from bacterial cell may be associate with - pron - capsule , cell wall , fimbriae , flagella , or pili .
bacterial antigen may also be associate with extracellular toxin and enzyme that - pron - secrete .
virus possess a variety of antigen associate with - pron - capsid , envelope , and the spike structure - pron - use for attachment to cell .
antigen may belong to any number of molecular class , include carbohydrate , lipid , nucleic acid , protein , and combination of these molecule .
antigen of different class vary in - pron - ability to stimulate adaptive immune defense as well as in the type of response - pron - stimulate ( humoral or cellular ) .
the structural complexity of an antigenic molecule be an important factor in - pron - antigenic potential .
in general , more complex molecule be more effective as antigen .
for example , the three - dimensional complex structure of protein make - pron - the most effective and potent antigen , capable of stimulate both humoral and cellular immunity .
in comparison , carbohydrate be chapter one  eight  adaptive specific host defense seven  seven  nine less complex in structure and therefore less effective as antigen  - pron - can only stimulate humoral immune defense .
lipid and nucleic acid be the least antigenic molecule , and in some case may only become antigenic when combine with protein or carbohydrate to form glycolipid , lipoprotein , or nucleoprotein .
one reason the three - dimensional complexity of antigen be so important be that antibody and t cell do not recognize and interact with an entire antigen but with small expose region on the surface of antigen call epitope .
a single antigen may possess several different epitope ( figure one  eight  .  three ) , and different antibody may bind to different epitope on the same antigen ( figure one  eight  .  four ) .
for example , the bacterial flagellum be a large , complex protein structure that can possess hundred or even thousand of epitope with unique three - dimensional structure .
moreover , flagella from different bacterial specie ( or even strain of the same specie ) contain unique epitope that can only be bind by specific antibody .
an antigen 's size be another important factor in - pron - antigenic potential .
whereas large antigenic structure like flagella possess multiple epitope , some molecule be too small to be antigenic by - pron - .
such molecule , call hapten , be essentially free epitope that be not part of the complex three - dimensional structure of a large antigen .
for a hapten to become antigenic , - pron - must first attach to a large carrier molecule ( usually a protein ) to produce a conjugate antigen .
the hapten - specific antibody produce in response to the conjugate antigen be then able to interact with unconjugated free hapten molecule .
hapten be not know to be associate with any specific pathogen , but - pron - be responsible for some allergic response .
for example , the hapten urushiol , a molecule find in the oil of plant that cause poison ivy , cause an immune response that can result in a severe rash ( call contact dermatitis ) .
similarly , the hapten penicillin can cause allergic reaction to drug in the penicillin class .

antibodies antibodies ( also call immunoglobulin ) be glycoprotein that be present in both the blood and tissue fluid .
the basic structure of an antibody monomer consist of four protein chain hold together by disulfide bond ( figure one  eight  .  five ) .
a disulfide bond be a covalent bond between the sulfhydryl r group find on two cysteine amino acid .
the two large chain be identical to each other and be call the heavy chain .
the two small chain be also identical to each other and be call the light chain .
join together , the heavy and light chain form a basic yshaped structure .
the two ‘ arm ' of the y - shape antibody molecule be know as the fab region , for “ fragment of antigen binding .
"
the far end of the fab region be the variable region , which serve as the site of antigen binding .
the amino acid sequence in the variable region dictate the three - dimensional structure , and thus the specific three - dimensional epitope to which the fab region be capable of bind .
although the epitope specificity of the fab region be identical for each arm of a single antibody molecule , this region display a high degree of variability between antibody with different epitope specificity .
