antibody class
the constant region of an antibody molecule determine - pron - class , or isotype .
the five class of antibody be igg , igm , iga , igd , and ige .
each class possess unique heavy chain designate by greek letter γ , μ , α , δ , and ε , respectively .
antibody class also exhibit important difference in abundance in serum , arrangement , body site of action , functional role , and size ( figure one  eight  .  six ) .
igg be a monomer that be by far the most abundant antibody in human blood , account for about eight  zero % of total serum antibody .
igg penetrate efficiently into tissue space , and be the only antibody class with the ability to cross the placental barrier , provide passive immunity to the develop fetus during pregnancy .
igg be also the most versatile antibody class in term of - pron - role in the body 's defense against pathogen .
igm be initially produce in a monomeric membrane - bind form that serve as an antigen - bind receptor on b cell .
the secrete form of igm assemble into a pentamer with five monomer of igm bind together by a protein structure call the j chain .
although the location of the j chain relative to the fc region of the five monomer prevent igm from perform some of the function of igg , the ten available fab site associate with a pentameric igm make - pron - an important antibody in the body 's arsenal of defense .
igm be the first antibody produce and secrete by b cell during the primary and secondary immune response , make pathogen - specific igm a valuable diagnostic marker during active or recent infection .
iga account for about one  three % of total serum antibody , and secretory iga be the most common and abundant antibody class find in the mucus secretion that protect the mucous membrane .
iga can also be find in other secretion such as breast milk , tear , and saliva .
secretory iga be assemble into a dimeric form with two monomer join by a protein structure call the secretory component .
one of the important function of secretory iga be to trap pathogen seven  eight  two chapter one  eight  adaptive specific host defense

as discuss in cellular defenses , major histocompatibility complex ( mhc ) molecule be express on the surface of healthy cell , identify - pron - as normal and " self " to natural killer ( nk ) cell .
mhc molecule also play an important role in the presentation of foreign antigen , which be a critical step in the activation of t cell and thus an important mechanism of the adaptive immune system .
major histocompatibility complex molecules
the major histocompatibility complex ( mhc ) be a collection of gene code for mhc molecule find on the surface of all nucleated cell of the body .
in human , the mhc gene be also refer to as human leukocyte antigen ( hla ) gene .
mature red blood cell , which lack a nucleus , be the only cell that do not express mhc molecule on - pron - surface .

mhc i molecule be find on all nucleated cell  - pron - present normal self - antigen as well as abnormal or nonself pathogen to the effector t cell involve in cellular immunity .
in contrast , mhc ii molecule be only find on macrophage , dendritic cell , and b cell  - pron - present abnormal or nonself pathogen antigen for the initial activation of t cell .
both type of mhc molecule be transmembrane glycoprotein that assemble as dimer in the cytoplasmic membrane of cell , but - pron - structure be quite different .
mhc i molecule be compose of a long α protein chain couple with a small β two microglobulin protein , and only the α chain span the cytoplasmic membrane .
the α chain of the mhc i molecule fold into three separate domain  α one , α two and α three .

both chain of the mhc ii molecule possess portion that span the plasma membrane , and each chain fold into two separate domain  α one and α two , and β one , and β two .
in order to present abnormal or non - self - antigen to t cell , mhc molecule have a cleft that serve as the antigen - bind site near the " top " ( or outermost ) portion of the mhc - i or mhc - ii dimer .
for mhc i , the antigenbinding cleft be form by the α one and α two domain , whereas for mhc ii , the cleft be form by the α one and β one domain ( figure one  eight  .  one  one ) .

antigen - presenting cell ( apcs )
all nucleate cell in the body have mechanism for processing and present antigen in association with mhc molecule .
this signal the immune system , indicate whether the cell be normal and healthy or infect with an intracellular pathogen .
however , only macrophage , dendritic cell , and b cell have the ability to present antigen specifically for the purpose of activate t cell  for this reason , these type of cell be sometimes refer to as antigen - present cell ( apcs ) .
while all apc play a similar role in adaptive immunity , there be some important difference to consider .
macrophage and dendritic cell be phagocyte that ingest and kill pathogen that penetrate the first - line barrier ( i . e . , skin and mucous membrane ) .
b cell , on the other hand , do not function as phagocyte but play a primary role in chapter one  eight  adaptive specific host defenses seven  eight  seven the production and secretion of antibody .
in addition , whereas macrophage and dendritic cell recognize pathogen through nonspecific receptor interaction ( e . g . , pamp , toll - like receptor , and receptor for opsonize complement or antibody ) , b cell interact with foreign pathogen or - pron - free antigen use antigen - specific immunoglobulin as receptor ( monomeric igd and igm ) .
when the immunoglobulin receptor bind to an antigen , the b cell internalize the antigen by endocytosis before processing and presentte the antigen to t cell .
antigen presentation with mhc ii molecules mhc ii molecule be only find on the surface of apc .
macrophage and dendritic cell use similar mechanism for processing and presentation of antigen and - pron - epitope in association with mhc ii  b cell use somewhat different mechanism that will be describe further in b lymphocytes and humoral immunity .
for now , - pron - will focus on the step of the process as - pron - pertain to dendritic cell .
after a dendritic cell recognize and attach to a pathogen cell , the pathogen be internalize by phagocytosis and be initially contain within a phagosome .
lysosome contain antimicrobial enzyme and chemical fuse with the phagosome to create a phagolysosome , where degradation of the pathogen for antigen processing begin .
protease ( protein - degrading ) be especially important in antigen processing because only protein antigen epitope be present to t cell by mhc ii ( figure one  eight  .  one  two ) .
apc do not present all possible epitope to t cell  only a selection of the most antigenic or immunodominant epitope be present .
the mechanism by which epitope be select for processing and presentation by an apc be complicated and not well understand  however , once the most antigenic , immunodominant epitope have be process , - pron - associate within the antigen - binding cleft of mhc ii molecule and be translocate to the cell surface of the dendritic cell for presentation to t cell .

mhc i molecules
mhc i molecule ,
find on all normal , healthy , nucleated cell , signal to the immune system that the cell be a normal " self " cell .

the exact mechanism by which cross - presentation occur be not yet well understand , but - pron - appear that cross - presentation be primarily a function of dendritic cell and not macrophage or b cell .

t cell production and maturation t cell , like all other white blood cell involve in innate and adaptive immunity , be form from multipotent hematopoietic stem cell ( hsc ) in the bone marrow ( see figure one  seven  .  one  two ) .
however , unlike the white blood cell of innate immunity , eventual t cell differentiate first into lymphoid stem cell that then become small , immature lymphocyte , sometimes call lymphoblast .
the first step of differentiation occur in the red marrow of bone ( figure one  eight  .  one  four ) , after which immature t lymphocyte enter the bloodstream and travel to the thymus for the final step of maturation ( figure one  eight  .  one  five ) .
once in the thymus , the immature t lymphocyte be refer to as thymocyte .
the maturation of thymocyte within the thymus can be divide into tree critical step of positive and negative selection , collectively refer to as thymic selection .
the first step of thymic selection occur in the cortex of the thymus and involve the development of a functional t - cell receptor ( tcr ) that be require for activation by apc .
thymocyte with defective tcr be remove by negative selection through the induction of apoptosis ( program control cell death ) .
the second step of thymic selection also occur in the cortex and involve the positive selection of thymocyte that will interact appropriately with mhc molecule .
thymocyte that can interact appropriately with mhc molecule receive a positive stimulation that move - pron - further through the process of maturation , whereas thymocyte that do not interact appropriately be not stimulate and be eliminate by apoptosis .
the third and final step of thymic selection occur in both the cortex and medulla and involve negative selection to remove selfreacte thymocyte , those that react to self - antigen , by apoptosis .
this final step be sometimes refer to as central tolerance because - pron - prevent self - react t cell from reach the bloodstream and potentially cause autoimmune disease , which occur when the immune system attack healthy " self " cell .
despite central tolerance , some self - reactive t cell generally escape the thymus and enter the peripheral bloodstream .
therefore , a second line of defense call peripheral tolerance be need to protect against autoimmune disease .
peripheral tolerance involve mechanism of anergy and inhibition of self - reactive t cell by regulatory t cell .
anergy refer to a state of nonresponsiveness to antigen stimulation .
in the case of self - reactive t cell that escape the thymus , lack of an essential co - stimulatory signal require for activation cause anergy and prevent autoimmune activation .
regulatory t cell participate in peripheral tolerance by inhibit the activation and function of selfreactive t cell and by secrete anti - inflammatory cytokine .
- pron - be not completely understand what event specifically direct maturation of thymocyte into regulatory t cell .
current theory suggest the critical event may occur during the third step of thymic selection , when most self - seven  nine  zero chapter one  eight  adaptive specific host defense
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five reactive t cell be eliminate .
regulatory t cell may receive a unique signal that be below the threshold require to target - pron - for negative selection and apoptosis .

class of t cells t cell can be categorize into three distinct class  helper t cell , regulatory t cell , and cytotoxic t cell .
these class be differentiate base on - pron - expression of certain surface molecule , - pron - mode of activation , and - pron - functional role in adaptive immunity ( table one  eight  .  one ) .
all t cell produce cluster of differentiation ( cd ) molecule , cell surface glycoprotein that can be use to identify and distinguish between the various type of white blood cell .
although t cell can produce a variety of cd molecule , cd four and cd eight be the two most important use for differentiation of the class .
helper t cell and regulatory t cell be characterize by the expression of cd four on - pron - surface , whereas cytotoxic t cell be characterize by the expression of cd eight .
class of t cell can also be distinguish by the specific mhc molecule and apc with which - pron - interact for activation .
helper t cell and regulatory t cell can only be activate by apc present antigen associate with mhc ii .
in contrast , cytotoxic t cell recognize antigen present in association with mhc i , either by apc or by nucleated cell infect with an intracellular pathogen .
the different class of t cell also play different functional role in the immune system .
helper t cell serve as the central orchestrator that help activate and direct function of humoral and cellular immunity .
in addition , helper t cell enhance the pathogen - kill function of macrophage and nk cell of innate immunity .
in contrast , the primary role of regulatory t cell be to prevent undesirable and potentially damaging immune response .
- pron - role in peripheral tolerance , for example , protect against autoimmune disorder , as discuss earlier .
finally , cytotoxic t cell be the primary effector cell for cellular immunity .
- pron - recognize and target cell that have be infect by intracellular pathogen , destroy infected cell along with the pathogen inside .

t - cell receptors
for both helper t cell and cytotoxic t cell , activation be a complex process that require the interaction of multiple molecule and exposure to cytokine .
the t - cell receptor ( tcr ) be involve in the first step of pathogen epitope recognition during the activation process .
the tcr come from the same receptor family as the antibody igd and igm , the antigen receptor on the b cell membrane surface , and thus share common structural element .
similar to antibody , the tcr have a variable region and a constant region , and the variable region provide the antigen - bind site ( figure one  eight  .  one  six ) .
however , the structure of tcr be small and less complex than the immunoglobulin molecule ( figure one  eight  .  five ) .
whereas immunoglobulin have four peptide chain and y - shape structure , the tcr consist of just two peptide chain ( α and β chain ) , both of which span the cytoplasmic membrane of the t cell .
tcr be epitope - specific , and - pron - have be estimate that two  five million t cell with unique epitope - bind tcr be require to protect an individual against a wide range of microbial pathogen .
because the human genome only contain about two  five  ,  zero  zero  zero gene , - pron - know that each specific tcr can not be encode by - pron - own set of gene .
this raise the question of how such a vast population of t cell with million of specific tcr can be achieve .
the answer be a process call genetic rearrangement , which occur in the thymus during the first step of thymic selection .
the gene that code for the variable region of the tcr be divide into distinct gene segment call variable ( v ) , diversity ( d ) , and join ( j ) segment .
the gene segment associate with the α chain of the tcr consist seven  zero or more different vα segment and six  one different jα segment .
the gene segment associate with the β chain of the tcr consist of five  two different vβ segment , two different dβ segment , and one  three different jβ segment .
during the development of the functional tcr in the thymus , genetic rearrangement in a t cell bring together one vα segment and one jα segment to code for the variable region of the α chain .
similarly , genetic rearrangement bring one of the vβ segment together with one of the dβ segment and one of thetjβ segment to code for the variable region of the β chain .
all the possible combination of rearrangement between different segment of v , d , and j provide the genetic diversity require to produce million of tcr with unique epitope - specific variable region .

superantigen and unregulated activation of t cell
when t cell activation be control and regulate , the result be a protective response that be effective in combat infection .
however , if t cell activation be unregulated and excessive , the result can be a life - threaten .
certain bacterial and viral pathogen produce toxin know as superantigen ( see virulence factors of bacterial and viral pathogens ) that can trigger such an unregulated response .
know bacterial superantigen include toxic shock syndrome toxin ( tsst ) , staphylococcal enterotoxin , streptococcal pyrogenic toxin , streptococcal superantigen , and the streptococcal mitogenic exotoxin .
virus know to produce superantigen include epstein - barr virus ( human herpesvirus four ) , cytomegalovirus ( human herpesvirus five ) , and other .

the mechanism of t cell activation by superantigen involve - pron - simultaneous bind to mhc ii molecule of apc and the variable region of the tcr β chain .
this bind occur outside of the antigen - binding cleft of mhc ii , so the superantigen will bridge together and activate mhc ii and tcr without specific foreign epitope recognition ( figure one  eight  .  one  nine ) .
the result be an excessive , uncontrolled release of cytokine , often call a cytokine storm , which stimulate an excessive inflammatory response .
this can lead to a dangerous decrease in blood pressure , shock , multiorgan failure , and potentially , death .

the primary and secondary antibody response humoral immunity refer to mechanism of the adaptive immune defense that be mediate by antibody secrete by b lymphocyte , or b cell .
this section will focus on b cell and discuss - pron - production and maturation , receptor , and mechanism of activation .
b cell production and maturation like t cell , b cell be form from multipotent hematopoietic stem cell ( hsc ) in the bone marrow and follow a pathway through lymphoid stem cell and lymphoblast ( see figure one  seven  .  one  two ) .
unlike t cell , however , lymphoblast clinical focus chapter one  eight  adaptive specific host defense seven  nine  nine destine to become b cell do not leave the bone marrow and travel to the thymus for maturation .
rather , eventual b cell continue to mature in the bone marrow .
the first step of b cell maturation be an assessment of the functionality of - pron - antigen - binding receptor .
this occur through positive selection for b cell with normal functional receptor .
a mechanism of negative selection be then use to eliminate self - react b cell and minimize the risk of autoimmunity .
negative selection of self - react b cell can involve elimination by apoptosis , editing or modification of the receptor so - pron - be no longer self - reactive , or induction of anergy in the b cell .
immature b cell that pass the selection in the bone marrow then travel to the spleen for - pron - final stage of maturation .
there - pron - become naïve mature b cell , i . e . , mature b cell that have not yet be activate .

compare the maturation of b cell with the maturation of t cell .
b - cell receptors like t cell
, b cell possess antigen - specific receptor with diverse specificity .
although - pron - rely on t cell for optimum function , b cell can be activate without help from t cell .
b - cell receptor ( bcr ) for naïve mature b cell be membrane - bind monomeric form of igd and igm .
- pron - have two identical heavy chain and two identical light chain connect by disulfide bond into a basic “ y " shape ( figure one  eight  .  two  zero ) .
the trunk of the y - shape molecule , the constant region of the two heavy chain , span the b cell membrane .
the two antigen - bind site expose to the exterior of the b cell be involve in the binding of specific pathogen epitope to initiate the activation process .
- pron - be estimate that each naïve mature b cell have upward of one  zero  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero bcr on - pron - membrane , and each of these bcr have an identical epitope - bind specificity .
in order to be prepared to react to a wide range of microbial epitope , b cell , like t cell , use genetic rearrangement of hundred of gene segment to provide the necessary diversity of receptor specificity .
the variable region of the bcr heavy chain be make up of v , d , and j segment , similar to the β chain of the tcr .
the variable region of the bcr light chain be make up of v and j segment , similar to the α chain of the tcr .
genetic rearrangement of all possible combination of v - j - d ( heavy chain ) and v - j ( light chain ) provide for million of unique antigen - bind site for the bcr and for the antibody secrete after activation .
one important difference between bcr and tcr be the way - pron - can interact with antigenic epitope .
whereas tcr can only interact with antigenic epitope that be present within the antigen - binding cleft of mhc i or mhc ii , bcr do not require antigen presentation with mhc  - pron - can interact with epitope on free antigen or with epitope display on the surface of intact pathogen .
another important difference be that tcr only recognize protein epitope , whereas bcr can recognize epitope associate with different molecular class ( e . g . , protein , polysaccharide , lipopolysaccharide ) .
activation of b cell occur through different mechanism depend on the molecular class of the antigen .
activation of a b cell by a protein antigen require the b cell to function as an apc , present the protein epitope with mhc ii to helper t cell .
because of - pron - dependence on t cell for activation of b cell , protein antigen be classify as tdependent antigen .
in contrast , polysaccharide , lipopolysaccharide , and other nonprotein antigen be consider t - independent antigen because - pron - can activate b cell without antigen processing and presentation to t cell .

t cell - dependent activation of b cell t cell - dependent activation of b cell be more complex than t cell - independent activation , but the result immune response be strong and develop memory .
t cell - dependent activation can occur either in response to free protein antigen or to protein antigen associate with an intact pathogen .
interaction between the bcr on a naïve mature b cell and a free protein antigen stimulate internalization of the antigen , whereas interaction with antigen associate with an intact pathogen initiate the extraction of the antigen from the pathogen before internalization .
once internalize inside the b cell , the protein antigen be process and present with mhc ii .
the presented antigen be then recognize by helper t cell specific to the same antigen .
the tcr of the helper t cell recognize the foreign antigen , and the t cell 's cd four molecule interact with mhc ii on the b cell .
the coordination between b cell and helper t cell that be specific to the same antigen be refer to as link recognition .
once activate by linked recognition , th two cell produce and secrete cytokine that activate the b cell and cause proliferation into clonal daughter cell .
after several round of proliferation , additional cytokine provide by the th two cell stimulate the differentiation of activated b cell clone into memory b cell , which will quickly respond to subsequent exposure to the same protein epitope , and plasma cell that lose - pron - membrane bcr and initially secrete pentameric igm ( figure one  eight  .  two  two ) .
after initial secretion of igm , cytokine secrete by th two cell stimulate the plasma cell to switch from igm production to production of igg , iga , or ige .
this process , call class switching or isotype switching , allow plasma cell clone from the same activate b cell to produce a variety of antibody class with the same epitope specificity .
class switching be accomplish by genetic rearrangement of gene segment encode the constant region , which determine an antibody 's class .
the variable region be not change , so the new class of antibody retain the original epitope specificity .

primary and secondary responses t cell - dependent activation of b cell play an important role in both the primary and secondary response associate with adaptive immunity .
with the first exposure to a protein antigen , a t cell - dependent primary antibody response occur .
the initial stage of the primary response be a lag period , or latent period , of approximately one  zero day , during which no antibody can be detect in serum .
this lag period be the time require for all of the step of the primary chapter one  eight  adaptive specific host defenses eight  zero  three response , include naïve mature b cell bind of antigen with bcr , antigen processing and presentation , helper t cell activation , b cell activation , and clonal proliferation .
the end of the lag period be characterize by a rise in igm level in the serum , as th two cell stimulate b cell differentiation into plasma cell .
igm level reach - pron - peak around one  four day after primary antigen exposure  at about this same time , th two stimulate antibody class switching , and igm level in serum begin to decline .
meanwhile , level of igg increase until - pron - reach a peak about three week into the primary response ( figure one  eight  .  two  three ) .
during the primary response , some of the clone b cell be differentiate into memory b cell program to respond to subsequent exposure .
this secondary response occur more quickly and forcefully than the primary response .
the lag period be decrease to only a few day and the production of igg be significantly high than observe for the primary response ( figure one  eight  .  two  three ) .
in addition , the antibody produce during the secondary response be more effective and bind with high affinity to the targeted epitope .
plasma cell produce during secondary response live longer than those produce during the primary response , so level of specific antibody remain elevated for a long period of time .

vaccination be a form of artificial immunity .
by artificially stimulate the adaptive immune defense , a vaccine trigger memory cell production similar to that which would occur during a primary response .
in so do , the patient be able to mount a strong secondary response upon exposure to the pathogen - but without have to first suffer through an initial infection .
in this section , - pron - will explore several different kind of artificial immunity along with various type of vaccine and the mechanism by which - pron - induce artificial immunity .
classification of adaptive immunity
all form of adaptive immunity can be describe as either active or passive .
active immunity refer to the activation of an individual 's own adaptive immune defense , whereas passive immunity refer to the transfer of adaptive immune defense from another individual or animal .
active and passive immunity can be further subdivide base on whether the protection be acquire naturally or artificially .
natural active immunity be adaptive immunity that develop after natural exposure to a pathogen ( figure one  eight  .  two  four ) .
example would include the lifelong immunity that develop after recovery from a chickenpox or measle infection ( although an acute infection be not always necessary to activate adaptive immunity ) .
the length of time that an individual be protect can vary substantially depend upon the pathogen and antigen involve .
for example , activation of adaptive immunity by protein spike structure during an intracellular viral infection can activate lifelong immunity , whereas activation by carbohydrate capsule antigen during an extracellular bacterial infection may activate short - term immunity .
natural passive immunity involve the natural passage of antibody from a mother to - pron - child before and after birth .
igg be the only antibody class that can cross the placenta from mother 's blood to the fetal blood supply .
placental transfer of igg be an important passive immune defense for the infant , last up to six month after birth .
secretory iga can also be transfer from mother to infant through breast milk .
artificial passive immunity refer to the transfer of antibody produce by a donor ( human or animal ) to another individual .
this transfer of antibody may be do as a prophylactic measure ( i . e . , to prevent disease after exposure to a pathogen ) or as a strategy for treat an active infection .
for example , artificial passive immunity be commonly use for post - exposure prophylaxis against rabie , hepatitis a , hepatitis b , and chickenpox ( in high risk individual ) .
active infection treat by artificial passive immunity include cytomegalovirus infection in immunocompromised patient and ebola virus infection .
in one  nine  nine  five , eight patient in the democratic republic of the congo with active ebola infection be treat with blood transfusion from patient who be recover from ebola .
only one of the eight patient die ( a one  two  .  five % mortality rate ) , which be much low than the expect eight  zero % mortality rate for ebola in untreated patients . [ two ]

what kind of immunity be confer by a vaccine ?
herd immunity
the four kind of immunity just describe result from an individual 's adaptive immune system .
for any give disease , an individual may be consider immune or susceptible depend on - pron - or - pron - ability to mount an effective immune response upon exposure .
thus , any give population be likely to have some individual who be immune and other individual who be susceptible .
if a population have very few susceptible individual , even those susceptible individual will be protect by a phenomenon call herd immunity .
herd immunity have nothing to do with an individual 's ability to mount an effective immune response  rather , - pron - occur because there be too few susceptible individual in a population for the disease to spread effectively .
vaccination program create herd immunity by greatly reduce the number of susceptible individual in a population .
even if some individual in the population be not vaccinate , as long as a certain percentage be immune ( either naturally or artificially ) , the few susceptible individual be unlikely to be expose to the pathogen .
however , because new individual be constantly enter population ( for example , through birth or relocation ) , vaccination program be necessary to maintain herd immunity .

other object to vaccine on religious or moral ground ( e . g . , the argument that gardasil vaccination against hpv may promote sexual promiscuity ) , on personal ethical ground ( e . g . , a conscientious objection to any medical intervention ) , or on political ground ( e . g . , the notion that mandatory vaccination be a violation of individual liberties ) . do such parent have a right to withhold vaccination from - pron - child ?
should - pron - be allow to put - pron - child - and society at large - at risk ?

variolation and vaccination thousands of year ago , - pron - be first recognize that individual who survive a smallpox infection be immune to subsequent infection .

variolation refer to the deliberate inoculation of individual with infectious material from scab or pustule of smallpox victim .
infectious material be either inject into the skin or introduce through the nasal route .
the infection that develop be usually mild than naturally acquire smallpox , and recovery from the milder infection provide protection against the more serious disease .
although the majority of individual treat by variolation develop only mild infection , the practice be not without risk .
more serious and sometimes fatal infection do occur , and because smallpox be contagious , eye on ethics three .

this japanese relief depict a patient receive a smallpox variolation from the physician ogata shunsaku ( one  seven  four  eight – one  eight  one  zero ) .
although variolation have be practice for century , the english physician edward jenner ( one  seven  four  nine – one  eight  two  three ) be generally credit with develop the modern process of vaccination .
jenner observe that milkmaid who develop cowpox , a disease similar to smallpox but milder , be immune to the more serious smallpox .
this lead jenner to hypothesize that exposure to a less virulent pathogen could provide immune protection against a more virulent pathogen , provide a safe alternative to variolation .
in one  seven  nine  six , jenner test - pron - hypothesis by obtain infectious sample from a milkmaid 's active cowpox lesion and inject the material into a young boy ( figure one  eight  .  two  six ) .
the boy develop a mild infection that include a low - grade fever , discomfort in - pron - axillae ( armpit ) and loss of appetite .
when the boy be later infect with infectious sample from smallpox lesion , - pron - do not contract smallpox . [ four ]
this new approach be term vaccination , a name derive from the use of cowpox ( latin vacca mean “ cow " ) to protect against smallpox .
today , - pron - know that jenner 's vaccine work because the cowpox virus be genetically and antigenically relate to the variola virus that cause smallpox .
exposure to cowpox antigen result in a primary response and the production of memory cell that identical or related epitope of variola virus upon a later exposure to smallpox .
the success of jenner 's smallpox vaccination lead other scientist to develop vaccine for other disease .
perhaps the most notable be louis pasteur , who develop vaccine for rabie , cholera , and anthrax .
during the two  zero th and two  one st century , effective vaccine be develop to prevent a wide range of disease cause by virus ( e . g . , chickenpox and shingle , hepatitis , measle , mump , polio , and yellow fever ) and bacteria ( e . g . , diphtheria , pneumococcal pneumonia , tetanus , and whooping cough , ) .

what be the difference between variolation and vaccination for smallpox ?

explain why vaccination be less risky than variolation .
class of vaccines for a vaccine to provide protection against a disease , - pron - must expose an individual to pathogen - specific antigen that will stimulate a protective adaptive immune response .
by - pron - very nature , this entail some risk .
as with any pharmaceutical drug , vaccine have the potential to cause adverse effect .
however , the ideal vaccine cause no severe adverse effect and pose no risk of contract the disease that - pron - be intend to prevent .
various type of vaccine have be develop with these goal in mind .
these different class of vaccine be describe in the next section and summarize in table one  eight  .  three .
live attenuated vaccines live attenuate vaccine expose an individual to a weakened strain of a pathogen with the goal of establish a subclinical infection that will activate the adaptive immune defense .
pathogen be attenuate to decrease - pron - virulence use method such as genetic manipulation ( to eliminate key virulence factor ) or long - term culturing in an unnatural host or environment ( to promote mutation and decrease virulence ) .
by establish an active infection , live attenuated vaccine stimulate a more comprehensive immune response than some other type of vaccine .
live attenuated vaccine activate both cellular and humoral immunity and stimulate the development of memory for long - last immunity .
in some case , vaccination of one individual with a live attenuated pathogen can even lead to natural transmission of the attenuated pathogen to other individual .
this can cause the other individual to also develop an active , subclinical infection that activate - pron - adaptive immune defense .
disadvantage associate with live attenuated vaccine include the challenge associate with long - term storage and transport as well as the potential for a patient to develop sign and symptom of disease during the active infection ( particularly in immunocompromised patient ) .
there be also a risk of the attenuated pathogen revert back to full virulence .

inactivated vaccines inactivate vaccine contain whole pathogen that have be kill or inactivate with heat , chemical , or radiation .
for inactivate vaccine to be effective , the inactivation process must not affect the structure of key antigen on the pathogen .
because the pathogen be kill or inactive , inactivate vaccine do not produce an active infection , and the result immune response be weak and less comprehensive than that provoke by a live attenuate vaccine .
typically the response involve only humoral immunity , and the pathogen can not be transmit to other individual .
in addition , inactivate vaccine usually require high dos and multiple booster , possibly cause inflammatory reaction at the site of injection .
despite these disadvantage , inactivated vaccine do have the advantage of long - term storage stability and ease of transport .
also , there be no risk of cause severe active infection .
however , inactivated vaccine be not without - pron - side effect .
table one  eight  .  three list example of inactivate vaccine .
subunit vaccines whereas live attenuated and inactive vaccine expose an individual to a weakened or dead pathogen , subunit vaccine only expose the patient to the key antigen of a pathogen - not whole cell or virus .
subunit vaccine can be produce either by chemically degrade a pathogen and isolate - pron - key antigen or by produce the antigen through genetic engineering .
because these vaccine contain only the essential antigen of a pathogen , the risk of side effect be relatively low .
table one  eight  .  three list example of subunit vaccine .
toxoid vaccines like subunit vaccine , toxoid vaccine do not introduce a whole pathogen to the patient  - pron - contain inactivate bacterial toxin , call toxoid .
toxoid vaccine be use to prevent disease in which bacterial toxin play an important role in pathogenesis .
these vaccine activate humoral immunity that neutralize the toxin .
table one  eight  .  three list example of toxoid vaccine .
conjugate vaccines a conjugate vaccine be a type of subunit vaccine that consist of a protein conjugate to a capsule polysaccharide .
conjugate vaccine have be develop to enhance the efficacy of subunit vaccine against pathogen that have protective polysaccharide capsule that help - pron - evade phagocytosis , cause invasive infection that can lead to meningitis and other serious condition .
the subunit vaccine against these pathogen introduce t - independent capsular polysaccharide antigen that result in the production of antibody that can opsonize the capsule and thus combat the infection  however , child under the age of two year do not respond effectively to these vaccine .
child do respond effectively when vaccinate with the conjugate vaccine , in which a protein with t - dependent antigen be conjugate to the capsule polysaccharide .
the conjugate protein - polysaccharide antigen stimulate production of antibody against both the protein and the capsule polysaccharide .
table one  eight  .  three list example of conjugate vaccine .

dna vaccines dna vaccine represent a relatively new and promising approach to vaccination .

summary one  eight  .  one overview of specific adaptive immunity  adaptive immunity be an acquire defense against foreign pathogen that be characterize by specificity and memory .
the first exposure to an antigen stimulate a primary response , and subsequent exposure stimulate a fast and strong secondary response .
 adaptive immunity be a dual system involve humoral immunity ( antibody produce by b cell ) and cellular immunity ( t cell direct against intracellular pathogen ) .

antigens , also call immunogen , be molecule that activate adaptive immunity .
a single antigen possess small epitope , each capable of induce a specific adaptive immune response .

an antigen 's ability to stimulate an immune response depend on several factor , include - pron - molecular class , molecular complexity , and size .

antibodies ( immunoglobulin ) be y - shape glycoprotein with two fab site for bind antigen and an fc portion involve in complement activation and opsonization .

the five class of antibody be igm , igg , iga , ige , and igd , each differ in size , arrangement , location within the body , and function .
the five primary function of antibody be neutralization , opsonization , agglutination , complement activation , and antibody - dependent cell - mediate cytotoxicity ( adcc ) .
one  eight  .  two major histocompatibility complexes and antigen - presenting cells

major histocompatibility complex ( mhc ) be a collection of gene code for glycoprotein molecule express on the surface of all nucleate cell .

mhc i molecule be express on all nucleated cell and be essential for presentation of normal " self " antigen .
cell that become infect by intracellular pathogen can present foreign antigen on mhc i as well , mark the infect cell for destruction .
 mhc ii molecule be express only on the surface of antigen - present cell ( macrophage , dendritic cell , and b cell ) .
antigen presentation with mhc ii be essential for the activation of t cell .

antigen - present cell ( apcs ) primarily ingest pathogen by phagocytosis , destroy - pron - in the phagolysosome , process the protein antigen , and select the most antigenic / immunodominant epitope with mhc ii for presentation to t cell .

cross - presentation be a mechanism of antigen presentation and t - cell activation use by dendritic cell not directly infect by the pathogen  - pron - involve phagocytosis of the pathogen but presentation on mhc i rather than mhc ii .
one  eight  .  three t lymphocytes and cellular immunity

immature t lymphocyte be produce in the red bone marrow and travel to the thymus for maturation .

thymic selection be a three - step process of negative and positive selection that determine which t cell will mature and exit the thymus into the peripheral bloodstream .
 central tolerance involve negative selection of self - reactive t cell in the thymus , and peripheral tolerance link to learning chapter one  eight
 adaptive specific host defenses eight  one  three involve anergy and regulatory t cell that prevent self - reactive immune response and autoimmunity .

the tcr be similar in structure to immunoglobulin , but less complex .
million of unique epitope - bind tcr be encode through a process of genetic rearrangement of v , d , and j gene segment .

t cell can be divide into three class - helper t cell , cytotoxic t cell , and regulatory t cell - base on - pron - expression of cd four or cd eight , the mhc molecule with which - pron - interact for activation , and - pron - respective function .
 activate helper t cell differentiate into th one , th two , th one  seven , or memory t cell subtype .
differentiation be direct by the specific cytokine to which - pron - be expose .
th one , th two , and th one  seven perform different function relate to stimulation of adaptive and innate immune defense .
memory t cell be long - live cell that can respond quickly to secondary exposure .

once activate , cytotoxic t cell target and kill cell infect with intracellular pathogen .
killing require recognition of specific pathogen epitope present on the cell surface use mhc i molecule .
killing be mediate by perforin and granzyme that induce apoptosis .

superantigen be bacterial or viral protein that cause a nonspecific activation of helper t cell , lead to an excessive release of cytokine ( cytokine storm ) and a systemic , potentially fatal inflammatory response .
one  eight  .  four b lymphocytes and humoral immunity  b lymphocyte or b cell produce antibody involve in humoral immunity .
b cell be produce in the bone marrow , where the initial stage of maturation occur , and travel to the spleen for final step of maturation into naïve mature b cell .
 b - cell receptor ( bcr ) be membrane - bind monomeric form of igd and igm that bind specific antigen epitope with - pron - fab antigen - bind region .
diversity of antigen bind specificity be create by genetic rearrangement of v , d , and j segment similar to the mechanism use for tcr diversity .

protein antigen be call t - dependent antigen because - pron - can only activate b cell with the cooperation of helper t cell .
other molecule class do not require t cell cooperation and be call t - independent antigen .

t cell - independent activation of b cell involve cross - linkage of bcr by repetitive nonprotein antigen epitope .
- pron - be characterize by the production of igm by plasma cell and do not produce memory b cell .

t cell - dependent activation of b cell involve processing and presentation of protein antigen to helper t cell , activation of the b cell by cytokine secrete from activate th two cell , and plasma cell that produce different class of antibody as a result of class switching .
memory b cell be also produce .

secondary exposure to t - dependent antigen result in a secondary antibody response initiate by memory b cell .
the secondary response develop more quickly and produce high and more sustained level of antibody with high affinity for the specific antigen .
one  eight  .  five vaccines 
adaptive immunity can be divide into four distinct classification  natural active immunity , natural passive immunity , artificial passive immunity , and artificial active immunity .

artificial active immunity be the foundation for vaccination and vaccine development .
vaccination program not only confer artificial immunity on individual , but also foster herd immunity in population .

variolation against smallpox originate in the one  zero th century in china , but the procedure be risky because - pron - could cause the disease - pron - be intend to prevent .
modern vaccination be develop by edward jenner , who develop the practice of inoculate patient with infectious material from cowpox lesion to prevent smallpox .
 live attenuate vaccine and inactivate vaccine contain whole pathogen that be weak , kill , or inactivate .
subunit vaccine , toxoid vaccine , and conjugate vaccine contain acellular component with antigen that stimulate an immune response .

immunotherapy introduction
an allergic reaction be an immune response to a type of antigen call an allergen .
allergen can be find in many different item , from peanut and insect sting to latex and some drug .
unlike other kind of antigen , allergen be not necessarily associate with pathogenic microbe , and many allergen provoke no immune response at all in most people .
allergic response vary in severity .
some be mild and localized , like hay fever or hive , but other can result in systemic , life - threaten reaction .
anaphylaxis , for example , be a rapidly develop allergic reaction that can cause a dangerous drop in blood pressure and severe swelling of the throat that may close off the airway .
allergy be just one example of how the immune system - the system normally responsible for prevent disease - can actually cause or mediate disease symptom .
in this chapter , - pron - will further explore allergy and other disorder of the immune system , include hypersensitivity reaction , autoimmune disease , transplant rejection , and disease associate with immunodeficiency .
chapter one  nine  diseases of the immune system eight  one  nine one  nine  .  one hypersensitivities learning objectives
 identify and compare the distinguish characteristic , mechanism , and major example of type i , ii , iii , and iv hypersensitivity
in adaptive specific host defenses , - pron - discuss the mechanism by which adaptive immune defense , both humoral and cellular , protect - pron - from infectious disease .
however , these same protective immune defense can also be responsible for undesirable reaction call hypersensitivity reaction .
hypersensitivity reaction be classify by - pron - immune mechanism .

type i hypersensitivity reaction involve immunoglobulin e ( ige ) antibody against soluble antigen , trigger mast cell degranulation .

type ii hypersensitivity reaction involve igg and igm antibody direct against cellular antigen , lead to cell damage mediate by other immune system effector .

type iii hypersensitivity reaction involve the interaction of igg , igm , and , occasionally , iga[ one ] antibodie with antigen to form immune complex .
accumulation of immune complex in tissue lead to tissue damage mediate by other immune system effector .
 type iv hypersensitivity reaction be t - cell – mediate reaction that can involve tissue damage mediate by activated macrophage and cytotoxic t cell .
type i hypersensitivitie
when a presensitized individual be expose to an allergen , - pron - can lead to a rapid immune response that occur almost immediately .
such a response be call an allergy and be classify as a type i hypersensitivity .
allergen may be seemingly harmless substance such as animal dander , mold , or pollen .
allergen may also be substance consider innately more hazardous , such as insect venom or therapeutic drug .
food intolerance can also yield allergic reaction as individual become sensitize to food such as peanut or shellfish ( figure one  nine  .  two ) .
regardless of the allergen , the first exposure activate a primary ige antibody response that sensitize an individual to type i hypersensitivity reaction upon subsequent exposure .

for susceptible individual , a first exposure to an allergen activate a strong th two cell response ( figure one  nine  .  three ) .
cytokine interleukin ( il ) -  four and il -  one  three from the th two cell

- pron - be estimate that each mast cell can bind up to five  zero  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero ige molecule , with each ige molecule have two allergen - specific fragment antigen - binding ( fab ) site available for bind allergen on subsequent exposure .
by the time this occur , the allergen be often no longer present and there be no allergic reaction , but the mast cell be prime for a subsequent exposure and the individual be sensitize to the allergen .
on subsequent exposure , allergen bind to multiple ige molecule on mast cell , cross - link the ige molecule .
within minute , this cross - linking of ige activate the mast cell and trigger degranulation , a reaction in which the content of the granule in the mast cell be release into the extracellular environment .
preformed component that be release from granule include histamine , serotonin , and bradykinin ( table one  nine  .  one ) .
the activated mast cell also release newly form lipid mediator ( leukotriene and prostaglandin from membrane arachadonic acid metabolism ) and cytokine such as tumor necrosis factor ( table one  nine  .  two ) .
the chemical mediator release by mast cell collectively cause the inflammation and sign and symptom associate with type i hypersensitivity reaction .
histamine stimulate mucus secretion in nasal passage and tear formation from lacrimal gland , promote the runny nose and watery eye of allergy .
interaction of histamine with nerve ending cause itch and sneezing .
the vasodilation cause by several of the mediator can result in hive , headache , angioedema ( swell that often affect the lip , throat , and tongue ) , and hypotension ( low blood pressure ) .
bronchiole constriction cause by some of the chemical mediator lead to wheeze , dyspnea ( difficulty breathing ) , cough , and , in more severe case , cyanosis ( bluish color to the skin or mucous membrane ) .
vomiting can result from stimulation of the vomit center in the cerebellum by histamine and serotonin .
histamine can also cause relaxation of intestinal smooth muscle and diarrhea .

the hygiene hypothesis
in most modern society , good hygiene be associate with regular bathing , and good health with cleanliness .
but some recent study suggest that the association between health and clean living may be a faulty one .
some go so far as to suggest that child should be encourage to play in the dirt - or even eat dirt[ three ]-for micro connections two .

chapter one  nine  diseases of the immune system eight  two  three the benefit of - pron - health .
this recommendation be base on the so - call hygiene hypothesis , which propose that childhood exposure to antigen from a diverse range of microbe lead to a better - function immune system later in life .
the hygiene hypothesis be first suggest in one  nine  eight  nine by david strachan[ four ] , who observe an inverse relationship between the number of old child in a family and the incidence of hay fever .
although hay fever in child have increase dramatically during the mid -  two  zero th century , incidence be significantly low in family with more child .
strachan propose that the low incidence of allergy in large family could be link to infection acquire from old sibling , suggest that these infection make child less susceptible to allergy .
strachan also argue that trend toward small family and a great emphasis on cleanliness in the two  zero th century have decrease exposure to pathogen and thus lead to high overall rate of allergy , asthma , and other immune disorder .
other researcher have observe an inverse relationship between the incidence of immune disorder and infectious disease that be now rare in industrialized country but still common in less industrialized countries . [ five ]
in developed nation , child under the age of five year be not expose to many of the microbe , molecule , and antigen - pron - almost certainly would have encounter a century ago .
the lack of early challenge to the immune system by organism with which human and - pron - ancestor evolve may result in failure in immune system function later in life .
type ii ( cytotoxic ) hypersensitivities immune reaction categorize as type ii hypersensitivity , or cytotoxic hypersensitivity , be mediate by igg and igm antibody bind to cell - surface antigen or matrix - associate antigen on basement membrane .
these antibody can either activate complement , result in an inflammatory response and lysis of the targeted cell , or - pron - can be involve in antibody - dependent cell - mediate cytotoxicity ( adcc ) with cytotoxic t cell .
in some case , the antigen may be a self - antigen , in which case the reaction would also be describe as an autoimmune disease .
( autoimmune disease be describe in autoimmune disorders ) .
in other case , antibody may bind to naturally occur , but exogenous , cell - surface molecule such as antigen associate with blood typing find on red blood cell ( rbc ) .
this lead to the coating of the rbc by antibody , activation of the complement cascade , and complement - mediate lysis of rbc , as well as opsonization of rbc for phagocytosis .
two example of type ii hypersensitivity reaction involve rbc be hemolytic transfusion reaction ( htr ) and hemolytic disease of the newborn ( hdn ) .
these type ii hypersensitivity reaction , which will be discuss in great detail , be summarize in table one  nine  .  four .
immunohematology be the study of blood and blood - form tissue in relation to the immune response .
antibodyinitiate response against blood cell be type ii hypersensitivity , thus fall into the field of immunohematology .
for student first learn about immunohematology , understand the immunological mechanism involve be make even more challenging by the complex nomenclature system use to identify different blood - group antigen , often call blood type .
the first blood - group antigen either use alphabetical name or be name for the first person know to produce antibody to the red blood cell antigen ( e . g . , kell , duffy , or diego ) .
however , in one  nine  eight  zero , the international society of blood transfusion ( isbt )
working party on terminology create a standard for blood - group terminology in an attempt to more consistently identify newly discover blood group antigen .
new antigen be now give a number and assign to a blood - group system , collection , or series .
however , even with this effort , blood - group nomenclature be still inconsistent .

one  nine  .  four abo blood group incompatibility
the recognition that individual have different blood type be first describe by karl landsteiner ( one  eight  six  eight – one  nine  four  three ) in the early one  nine  zero  zero s , base on - pron - observation that serum from one person could cause a clumping of rbc from another .
these study lead landsteiner to the identification of four distinct blood type .
subsequent research by other scientist determine that the four blood type be base on the presence or absence of surface carbohydrate "
a " and “ b , " and
this provide the foundation for the abo blood group system that be still in use today ( figure one  nine  .  four ) .
the function of these antigen be unknown , but some have be associate with normal biochemical function of the cell .
furthermore , abo blood type be inherit as allele ( one from each parent ) , and - pron - display pattern of dominant and codominant inheritance .
the allele for a and b blood type be codominant to each other , and both be dominant over blood type o . therefore , individual with genotype of aa or ao have type a blood and express the a carbohydrate antigen on the surface of - pron - rbc .
people with genotype of bb or bo have type b blood and express the b carbohydrate antigen on the surface of - pron - rbc .
those with a genotype of ab have type ab blood and express both a and b carbohydrate antigen on the surface of - pron - rbc .
finally , individual with a genotype of oo have type o blood and lack a and b
carbohydrate on the surface of - pron - rbc .
- pron - be important to note that the rbc of all four abo blood type share a common protein receptor molecule , and - pron - be the addition of specific carbohydrate to the protein receptor that determine a , b , and ab blood type .
the gene that be inherit for the a , b , and ab blood type encode enzyme that add the carbohydrate component to the protein receptor .
individual with o blood type still have the protein receptor but lack the enzyme that would add carbohydrate that would make - pron - red blood cell type a , b , or ab .
igm antibody in plasma that cross - react with blood group antigen not present on an individual 's own rbc be call isohemagglutinin ( figure one  nine  .  four ) .
isohemagglutinin be produce within the first few week after birth and persist throughout life .
these antibody be produce in response to exposure to environmental antigen from food and microorganism .
a person with type
a blood have a antigen on the surface of - pron - rbc and will produce anti - b antibody to environmental antigen that resemble the carbohydrate component of b antigen .
a person with type b blood have b antigen on the surface of - pron - rbc and will produce anti - a antibody to environmental antigen that be similar to the carbohydrate component of a antigen .
people with blood type
o lack both a and b antigen on - pron - rbc and , therefore , produce both anti - a and anti - b antibody .
conversely , people with ab blood type have both a and b antigen on - pron - rbc and , therefore , lack anti - a and anti - b antibody .

a patient may require a blood transfusion because - pron - lack sufficient rbc ( anemia ) or because - pron - have experience significant loss of blood volume through trauma or disease .
although the blood transfusion be give to help the patient , - pron - be essential that the patient receive a transfusion with match abo blood type .
a transfusion with an incompatible abo blood type may lead to a strong , potentially lethal type ii hypersensitivity cytotoxic response call hemolytic transfusion reaction ( htr ) ( figure one  nine  .  five ) .
for instance , if a person with type b blood receive a transfusion of type a blood , - pron - anti - a antibody will bind to and agglutinate the transfuse rbc .
in addition , activation of the classical complement cascade will lead to a strong inflammatory response , and the complement membrane attack complex ( mac ) will mediate massive hemolysis of the transfuse rbc .
the debris from damage and destroy rbc can occlude blood vessel in the alveoli of the lung and the glomeruli of the kidney .
within one to two  four hour of an incompatible transfusion , the patient experience fever , chill , pruritus ( itching ) , urticaria ( hive ) , dyspnea , hemoglobinuria ( hemoglobin in the urine ) , and hypotension ( low blood pressure ) .
in the most serious reaction , dangerously low blood pressure can lead to shock , multi - organ failure , and death of the patient .
hospital , medical center , and associate clinical laboratory typically use hemovigilance system to minimize the risk of htr due to clerical error .
hemovigilance system be procedure that track transfusion information from the donor source and blood product obtain to the follow - up of recipient patient .
hemovigilance system use in many country identify htr and - pron - outcome through mandatory reporting ( e . g . , to the food and drug administration in the united states ) , and this information be valuable to help prevent such occurrence in the future .
for example , if an htr be find to be the result of laboratory or clerical error , additional blood product collect from the donor at that time can be locate and label correctly to avoid additional htr .
as a result of these measure , htrassociate death in the united states occur in about one per two million transfuse units . [ six ] six .

rh factor
many different type of erythrocyte antigen have be discover since the description of the abo red cell antigen .
the second most frequently describe rbc antigen be rh factor , name after the rhesus macaque ( macaca mulatta ) factor identify by karl landsteiner and alexander weiner in one  nine  four  zero .
the rh system of rbc antigen be the most complex and immunogenic blood group system , with more than five  zero specificity identify to date .
of all the rh antigen , the one designate rho ( weiner ) or d ( fisher - race ) be the most immunogenic .
cell be classify as rh positive ( rh+ ) if the rho / d antigen be present or as rh negative ( rh− ) if the rho / d antigen be absent .
in contrast to the carbohydrate molecule that distinguish the abo blood group and be the target of igm isohemagglutinin in htr , the rh factor antigen be protein .
as discuss in b lymphocytes and humoral immunity , protein antigen activate b cell and antibody production through a t - cell – dependent mechanism , and the th two cell stimulate class switch from igm to other antibody class .
in the case of rh factor antigen , th two cell stimulate class switching to igg , and this have important implication for the mechanism of hdn .
like abo incompatibility , blood transfusion from a donor with the wrong rh factor antigen can cause a type ii hypersensitivity htr .
however , in contrast to the igm isohemagglutinin produce early in life through exposure to environmental antigen , production of anti - rh factor antibody require the exposure of an individual with rh− blood to rh+ positive rbc and activation of a primary antibody response .
although this primary antibody response can cause an htr in the transfusion patient , the hemolytic reaction would be delay up to two week during the extended lag period of a primary antibody response ( b lymphocytes and humoral immunity ) .
however , if the patient receive a subsequent transfusion with rh+ rbc , a more rapid htr would occur with anti - rh factor antibody already present in the blood .
furthermore , the rapid secondary antibody response would provide even more anti - rh factor antibody for the htr .
rh factor incompatibility between mother and fetus can also cause a type ii hypersensitivity hemolytic reaction , refer to as hemolytic disease of the newborn ( hdn )
( figure one  nine  .  six ) .
if an rh− woman carry an rh+ baby to term , the mother 's immune system can be expose to rh+ fetal red blood cell .
this exposure will usually occur during the last trimester of pregnancy and during the delivery process .
if this exposure occur , the rh+ fetal rbc will activate a primary adaptive immune response in the mother , and anti - rh factor igg antibody will be produce .
igg antibody be the only class of antibody that can cross the placenta from mother to fetus  however , in most case , the first rh+ baby be unaffected by these antibody because the first exposure typically occur late enough in the chapter one  nine  diseases of the immune system eight  two  seven pregnancy that the mother do not have time to mount a sufficient primary antibody response before the baby be bear .
if a subsequent pregnancy with an rh+ fetus occur , however , the mother 's second exposure to the rh factor antigen cause a strong secondary antibody response that produce large quantity of anti - rh factor igg . these antibody can cross the placenta from mother to fetus and cause hdn , a potentially lethal condition for the baby ( figure one  nine  .  six ) .
prior to the development of technique for diagnosis and prevention , rh factor incompatibility be the most common cause of hdn , result in thousand of infant death each year worldwide . [ seven ]
for this reason , the rh factor of prospective parent be regularly screen , and treatment have be develop to prevent hdn cause by rh incompatibility .
to prevent rh factor - mediate hdn , human rho ( d ) immune globulin ( e . g . , rhogam ) be inject intravenously or intramuscularly into the mother during the two  eight th week of pregnancy and within seven  two hour after delivery .
additional dos may be administer after event that may result in transplacental hemorrhage ( e . g . , umbilical blood sampling , chorionic villus sampling , abdominal trauma , amniocentesis ) .
this treatment be initiate during the first pregnancy with an rh+ fetus .
the anti - rh antibody in rho ( d ) immune globulin will bind to the rh factor of any fetal rbc that gain access to the mother 's bloodstream , prevent these rh+ cell from activate the mother 's primary antibody response .
without a primary anti - rh factor antibody response , the next pregnancy with an rh+ will have minimal risk of hdn .
however , the mother will need to be retreat with rho ( d ) immune globulin during that pregnancy to prevent a primary anti - rh antibody response that could threaten subsequent pregnancy .

type iii hypersensitivity type iii hypersensitivity be immune - complex reaction that be first characterize by nicolas maurice arthus ( one  eight  six  two – one  nine  four  five ) in one  nine  zero  three .
to produce antibody for experimental procedure , arthus immunize rabbit by inject - pron - with serum from horse .
however , while immunize rabbit repeatedly with horse serum , arthus notice a previously unreported and unexpected localized subcutaneous hemorrhage with edema at the site of injection .
this reaction develop within three to one  zero hour after injection .
this localized reaction to non - self serum protein be call an arthus reaction .
an arthus reaction occur when soluble antigen bind with igg in a ratio that result in the accumulation of antigen - antibody aggregate call immune complex .
a unique characteristic of type iii hypersensitivity be antibody excess ( primarily igg ) , couple with a relatively low concentration of antigen , result in the formation of small immune complex that deposit on the surface of the epithelial cell line the inner luman of small blood vessel or on the surface of tissue ( figure one  nine  .  seven ) .
this immune complex accumulation lead to a cascade of inflammatory event that include the follow  one . igg bind to antibody receptor on localize mast cell , result in mast - cell degranulation two .
complement activation with production of pro - inflammatory c three a and
c five a ( see chemical defenses )
three .

"
although phagocytosis do not occur , neutrophil degranulation result in the release of lysosomal enzyme that cause extracellular destruction of the immune complex , damaging localize cell in the process .
activation of coagulation pathway also occur , result in thrombi ( blood clot ) that occlude blood vessel and cause ischemia that can lead to vascular necrosis and localized hemorrhage .
systemic type iii hypersensitivity ( serum sickness ) occur when immune complex deposit in various body site , result in a more generalize systemic inflammatory response .
these immune complex involve non - self protein such as antibody produce in animal for artificial passive immunity ( see vaccines ) , certain drug , or microbial antigen that be continuously release over time during chronic infection ( e . g . , subacute bacterial endocarditis , chronic viral hepatitis ) .
the mechanism of serum sickness be similar to those describe in localized type iii hypersensitivity but involve widespread activation of mast cell , complement , neutrophil , and macrophage , which cause tissue destruction in area such as the kidney , joint , and blood vessel .
as a result of tissue destruction , symptom of serum sickness include chill , fever , rash , vasculitis , and arthritis .
development of glomerulonephritis or hepatitis be also possible .
autoimmune disease such as systemic lupus erythematosus ( sle ) and rheumatoid arthritis can also involve damage type iii hypersensitivity reaction when auto - antibody form immune complex with self antigen .
these condition be discuss in autoimmune disorders .

type iv hypersensitivity type iv hypersensitivity be not mediate by antibody like the other three type of hypersensitivity .
rather , type iv hypersensitivity be regulate by t cell and involve the action of effector cell .

( credit  modification of work by the centers for disease control and prevention ) hypersensitivity pneumonitis
some disease cause by hypersensitivity be not cause exclusively by one type .
for example , hypersensitivity pneumonitis ( hp ) , which be often an occupational or environmental disease , occur when the lung become inflamed due to an allergic reaction to inhale dust , endospore , bird feather , bird dropping , mold , or chemical .
hp go by many different name associate with various form of exposure ( figure one  nine  .  one  zero ) .
hp associate with bird dropping be sometimes call pigeon fancier 's lung or poultry worker 's lung - both common in bird breeder and handler .
cheese handler 's disease , farmer 's lung , sauna taker ' disease , and hot - tub lung be other name for hp associate with exposure to mold in various environment .
pathology associate with hp can be due to both type iii ( mediate by immune complex ) and type iv ( mediate by th one cell and macrophage ) hypersensitivity .
repeat exposure to allergen can cause alveolitis due to the formation of immune complex in the alveolar wall of the lung accompany by fluid accumulation , and the formation of granuloma and other lesion in the lung as a result of th one  - mediated macrophage activation .
alveolitis with fluid and granuloma formation result in poor oxygen perfusion in the alveoli , which , in turn , can cause symptom such as cough , dyspnea , chill , fever , sweating , myalgia , headache , and nausea .
symptom may occur as quickly as two hour after exposure and can persist for week if leave untreated .

diagnosis of hypersensitivities diagnosis of type i hypersensitivitie be a complex process require several diagnostic test in addition to a welldocumented patient history .
serum ige level can be measure , but elevate ige alone do not confirm allergic disease .
as part of the process to identify the antigen responsible for a type i reaction allergy , test through a prick puncture skin test ( ppst ) or an intradermal test can be perform .
ppst be carry out with the introduction of allergen in a series of superficial skin prick on the patient 's back or arm ( figure one  nine  .  one  two ) .
ppst be consider to be the most convenient and least expensive way to diagnose allergy , accord to the us joint council of allergy and the european academy of allergy and immunology .
the second type of testing , the intradermal test , require injection into the dermis with a small needle .
this needle , also know as a tuberculin needle , be attach to a syringe contain a small amount of allergen .
both the ppst and the intradermal test be observe for one  five – two  zero minute for a wheal - flare reaction to the allergen .
measurement of any wheal ( a raise , itchy bump ) and flare ( redness ) within minute indicate a type i hypersensitivity , and the large the wheal - flare reaction , the great the patient 's sensitivity to the allergen .
type iii hypersensitivity can often be misdiagnose because of - pron - nonspecific inflammatory nature .
the symptom be easily visible , but - pron - may be associate with any of a number of other disease .
a strong , comprehensive patient history be crucial to proper and accurate diagnosis .
test use to establish the diagnosis of hypersensitivity pneumonitis ( result from type iii hypersensitivity ) include bronchoalveolar lavage ( bal ) , pulmonary function test , and high - resolution compute tomography ( hrct ) .

treatment of hypersensitivities allergic reaction can be treat in various way .
prevention of allergic reaction can be achieve by desensitization ( hyposensitization ) therapy , which can be use to reduce the hypersensitivity reaction through repeat injection of allergen .
extremely dilute concentration of know allergen ( determine from the allergen test ) be inject into the patient at prescribed interval ( e . g . , weekly ) .
the quantity of allergen deliver by the shot be slowly increase over a buildup period until an effective dose be determine and that dose be maintain for the duration of treatment , which can last year .
patient be usually encourage to remain in the doctor 's office for three  zero minute after receive the injection in case the allergen administer cause a severe systemic reaction .
doctor ' office that administer desensitization therapy must be prepared to provide resuscitation and drug treatment in the case of such an event .
desensitization therapy be use for insect sting allergy and environmental allergy .
the allergy shot elicit the production of different interleukin and igg antibody response instead of ige .
when excess allergen - specific igg antibody be produce and bind to the allergen , - pron - can act as block antibody to neutralize the allergen before - pron - can bind ige on mast cell .

there be also therapy design to treat severe allergic reaction .
emergency systemic anaphylaxis be treat initially with an epinephrine injection , which can counteract the drop in blood pressure .
individual with know severe allergy often carry a self - administer auto - injector that can be use in case of exposure to the allergen ( e . g . , an insect sting or accidental ingestion of a food that cause a severe reaction ) .

treatment of type iv hypersensitivity include antihistamine , anti - inflammatory drug , analgesic , and , if possible , eliminate further exposure to the antigen .

in one  nine  seven  zero , artist walt kelly develop a poster promote earth day , feature a character from pogo , - pron - daily newspaper comic strip .

- pron - have meet the enemy and - pron - be - pron - .
