pogo be not talk about the human immune system , but - pron - very well could have be .
although the immune system protect the body by attack invade “ enemy " ( pathogen ) , in some case , the immune system can mistakenly identify the body 's own cell as the enemy , result in autoimmune disease .
autoimmune disease be those in which the body be attack by - pron - own specific adaptive immune response .
in normal , healthy state , the immune system induce tolerance , which be a lack of an anti - self immune response .
however , with autoimmunity , there be a loss of immune tolerance , and the mechanism responsible for autoimmune disease include type ii , iii , and iv hypersensitivity reaction .
autoimmune disease can have a variety of mixed symptom that flare up and disappear , make diagnosis difficult .
the cause of autoimmune disease be a combination of the individual ' s genetic makeup and the effect of environmental influence , such as sunlight , infection , medication , and environmental chemical .
however , the eight  three  eight chapter one  nine  diseases of the immune system
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five vagueness of this list reflect - pron - poor understanding of the etiology of these disease .
except in a very few specific disease , the initiation event ( s ) of most autoimmune state have not be fully characterize .
there be several possible cause for the origin of autoimmune disease and autoimmunity be likely due to several factor .
evidence now suggest that regulatory t and b cell play an essential role in the maintenance of tolerance and prevention of autoimmune response .
the regulatory t cell be especially important for inhibit autoreactive t cell that be not eliminate during thymic selection and escape the thymus ( see t lymphocytes and cellular immunity ) .
in addition , antigen mimicry between pathogen antigen and - pron - own self antigen can lead to crossreactivity and autoimmunity .
hide self - antigen may become expose because of trauma , drug interaction , or disease state , and trigger an autoimmune response .
all of these factor could contribute to autoimmunity .
ultimately , damage to tissue and organ in the autoimmune disease state come as a result of inflammatory response that be inappropriate  therefore , treatment often include immunosuppressive drug and corticosteroid .
organ - specific autoimmune diseases
some autoimmune disease be consider organ specific , mean that the immune system target specific organ or tissue .
example of organ - specific autoimmune disease include celiac disease , grave disease , hashimoto thyroiditis , type i diabetes mellitus , and addison disease .
celiac disease celiac disease be largely a disease of the small intestine , although other organ may be affect .
people in - pron - three  zero and four  zero , and child be most commonly affect , but celiac disease can begin at any age .
- pron - result from a reaction to protein , commonly call gluten , find mainly in wheat , barley , rye , and some other grain .
the disease have several genetic cause ( predisposition ) and poorly understand environmental influence .
on exposure to gluten , the body produce various autoantibody and an inflammatory response .
the inflammatory response in the small intestine lead to a reduction in the depth of the microvilli of the mucosa , which hinder absorption and can lead to weight loss and anemia .
the disease be also characterize by diarrhea and abdominal pain , symptom that be often misdiagnose as irritable bowel syndrome .
diagnosis of celiac disease be accomplish from serological test for the presence of primarily iga antibody to component of gluten , the transglutinaminase enzyme , and autoantibody to endomysium , a connective tissue surround muscle fiber .
serological test be typically follow up with endoscopy and biopsy of the duodenal mucosa .
serological screen survey have find about one % of individual in the united kingdom be positive even though - pron - do not all display symptoms . [ one  three ]
this early recognition allow for more careful monitoring and prevention of severe disease .
celiac disease be treat with complete removal of gluten - contain food from the diet , which result in improved symptom and reduced risk of complication .
other theoretical approach include breed grain that do not contain the immunologically reactive component or develop dietary supplement that contain enzyme that break down the protein component that cause
the immune response . [ one  four ] disorder of the thyroid graves disease be the most common cause of hyperthyroidism in the united states .
symptom of graves disease result from the production of thyroid - stimulating immunoglobulin ( tsi ) also call tsh - receptor antibody .
tsi target and bind to the receptor for thyroid stimulate hormone ( tsh ) , which be naturally produce by the pituitary gland .
tsi may cause conflicting symptom because - pron - may stimulate the thyroid to make too much thyroid hormone or block thyroid hormone production entirely , make diagnosis more difficult .
sign and symptom of grave disease include heat intolerance , rapid and irregular heartbeat , weight loss , goiter ( a swollen thyroid gland , protrude under the skin of the throat [ figure one  nine  .  one  three ] ) and exophthalmia ( bulge eye ) often refer to as grave one  three .

the most common cause of hypothyroidism in the united states be hashimoto thyroiditis , also call chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis .
patient with hashimoto thyroiditis often develop a spectrum of different disease because - pron - be more likely to develop additional autoimmune disease such as addison disease ( discuss later in this section ) , type one diabetes , rheumatoid arthritis , and celiac disease .

type one diabetes juvenile diabete , or type one diabetes mellitus , be usually diagnose in child and young adult .
- pron - be a t - celldependent autoimmune disease characterize by the selective destruction of the β cell of the islet of langerhans in the pancrea by cd four th one  - mediated cd eight t cell , anti - β - cell antibody , and macrophage activity .
there be also evidence that viral infection can have either a potentiating or inhibitory role in the development of type one diabetes ( t one d ) mellitus .
the destruction of the β cell cause a lack of insulin production by the pancrea .
in t one d , β - cell destruction may take place over several year , but symptom of hyperglycemia , extreme increase in thirst and urination , weight loss , and extreme fatigue usually have a sudden onset , and diagnosis usually do not occur until most β cell have already be destroy .

example of systemic autoimmune disease include multiple sclerosis , myasthenia gravi , psoriasis , rheumatoid arthritis , and systemic lupus erythematosus .
multiple sclerosis multiple sclerosis ( ms ) be an autoimmune central nervous system disease that affect the brain and spinal cord .
lesion in multiple location within the central nervous system be a hallmark of multiple sclerosis and be cause by infiltration of immune cell across the blood - brain barrier .
the immune cell include t cell that promote inflammation , demyelination , and neuron degeneration , all of which disrupt neuronal signaling .
symptom of ms include visual disturbance  muscle weakness  difficulty with coordination and balance  sensation such as numbness , prickling , or " pin and needle "  and cognitive and memory problem .
myasthenia gravis autoantibodies direct against acetylcholine receptor ( achrs ) in the synaptic cleft of neuromuscular junction lead to myasthenia gravi ( figure one  nine  .  one  six ) .
anti - achr antibody be high - affinity iggs and - pron - synthesis require activated cd four t cell to interact with and stimulate b cell .
once produce , the anti - achr antibody affect neuromuscular transmission by at least three mechanism 

complement binding and activation at the neuromuscular junction

accelerated achr endocytosis of molecule cross - link by antibody 
functional achr blocking , which prevent normal acetylcholine attachment to , and activation of , achr
regardless of the mechanism , the effect of anti - achr be extreme muscle weakness and potentially death through respiratory arrest in severe case .

psoriasis psoriasis be a skin disease that cause itchy or sore patch of thick , red skin with silvery scale on elbow , knee , scalp , back , face , palm , foot , and sometimes other area .
some individual with psoriasis also get a form of arthritis call psoriatic arthritis , in which the joint can become inflamed .
psoriasis result from the complex interplay between keratinocyte , dendritic cell , and t cell , and the cytokine produce by these various cell .
in a process call cell turnover , skin cell that grow deep in the skin rise to the surface .
normally , this process take a month .
in psoriasis , as a result of cytokine activation , cell turnover happen in just a few day .
the thick inflamed patch of skin that be characteristic of psoriasis develop because the skin cell rise too fast .
rheumatoid arthritis
the most common chronic inflammatory joint disease be rheumatoid arthritis ( ra ) ( figure one  nine  .  one  seven ) and - pron - be still a major medical challenge because of unsolved question relate to the environmental and genetic cause of the disease .
ra involve type iii hypersensitivity reaction and the activation of cd four t cell , result in chronic release of the inflammatory cytokine il -  one , il -  six , and tumor necrosis factor - α ( tnf - α ) .
the activated cd four t cell also stimulate the production of rheumatoid factor ( rf ) antibody and anticyclic citrullinate peptide antibody ( anti - ccp ) that form immune complex .
increase level of acute - phase protein , such as c - reactive protein ( crp ) , be also produce as part of the inflammatory process and participate in complement fixation with the antibody on the immune complex .
the formation of immune complex and reaction to the immune factor cause an inflammatory process in joint , particularly in the hand , foot , and leg .
diagnosis of ra be base on elevated level of rf , anti - ccp , quantitative crp , and the erythrocyte sedimentation rate ( esr ) ( modifiedwestergren ) .
in addition , radiograph , ultrasound , or magnetic resonance imaging scan can identify joint damage , such as erosion , a loss of bone within chapter one  nine  diseases of the immune system eight  four  three the joint , and narrowing of joint space .

systemic lupus erythematosus
the damage and pathology of systemic lupus erythematosus ( sle ) be cause by type iii hypersensitivity reaction .
autoantibody produce in sle be direct against nuclear and cytoplasmic protein .
anti - nuclear antibody ( ana ) be present in more than nine  five % of patient with sle , [ one  six ] with additional autoantibody include antidouble– stranded dna ( ds - dna ) and anti - sm antibody ( antibody to small nuclear ribonucleoprotein ) .
anti - ds - dna and anti - sm antibody be unique to patient with sle  thus , - pron - presence be include in the classification criterion of sle .
cellular interaction with autoantibody lead to nuclear and cellular destruction , with component release after cell death lead to the formation of immune complex .
because autoantibody in sle can target a wide variety of cell , symptom of sle can occur in many body location .
however , the most common symptom include fatigue , fever with no other cause , hair loss , and a sunlight - sensitive " butterfly " or wolf - mask
( lupus ) rash that be find in about five  zero % of people with sle ( figure one  nine  .  one  eight ) .
the rash be most often see over the cheek and bridge of the nose , but can be widespread .
other symptom may appear depend on affect area .
the joint may be affect , lead to arthritis of the finger , hand , wrist , and knee .
effect on the brain and nervous system can lead to headache , numbness , tingling , seizure , vision problem , and personality change .
there may also be abdominal pain , nausea , vomiting , arrhythmias , shortness of breath , and blood in the sputum .
effect on the skin can lead to additional area of skin lesion , and vasoconstriction can cause color change in the finger when - pron - be cold ( raynaud phenomenon ) .
effect on the kidney can lead to edema in the leg and weight gain .
a diagnosis of sle depend on identification of four of one  one of the most common symptom and confirm production of an array of autoantibody unique to sle .
a positive test for ana alone be not diagnostic .

transplant rejection
the different type of graft describe above have vary risk for rejection ( table one  nine  .  seven ) .

the major histocompatibility complex marker

a form of rejection call graft - versus - host disease ( gvhd ) primarily occur in recipient of bone marrow transplant and peripheral blood stem cell .
ghvd present a unique situation because the transplanted tissue be capable of produce immune cell  apc in the donate bone marrow may recognize the host cell as non - self , lead to activation of the donor cytotoxic t cell .
once activate , the donor 's t cell attack the recipient cell , cause acute gvhd .
acute gvhd typically develop within week after a bone marrow transplant , cause tissue damage affect the skin , gastrointestinal tract , liver , and eye .
in addition , acute gvhd may also lead to a cytokine storm , an unregulated secretion of cytokine that may be fatal .
in addition to acute gvhd , there be also the risk for chronic gvhd develop month after the bone marrow transplant .
the mechanism responsible for chronic gvhd be not well understand .
to minimize the risk of gvhd , - pron - be critically important to match the hla of the host and donor as closely as possible in bone marrow transplant .
in addition , the donate bone marrow be process before graft to remove as many donor apc and t cell as possible , leave mostly hematopoietic stem cell .

learning objectives
 compare the cause of primary and secondary immunodeficiency  describe treatment for primary and secondary immunodeficiency immunodeficiencies be inherit ( primary ) or acquire ( secondary ) disorder in which element of host immune defense be either absent or functionally defective .
in develop country , most immunodeficiency be inherit , and - pron - be usually first see in the clinic as recurrent or overwhelming infection in infant .
however , on a global scale , malnutrition be the most common cause of immunodeficiency and would be categorize as an acquired immunodeficiency .
acquired immunodeficiency be more likely to develop later in life , and the pathogenic mechanism of many remain obscure .
primary immunodeficiency primary immunodeficiency , which number more than two  five  zero , be cause by inherit defect of either nonspecific innate or specific adaptive immune defense .
in general , patient bear with primary immunodeficiency ( pi ) commonly have an increase susceptibility to infection .
this susceptibility can become apparent shortly after birth or in early childhood for some individual , whereas other patient develop symptom later in life .
some primary immunodeficiency be due to a defect of a single cellular or humoral component of the immune system  other may result from defect of more than one component .
example of primary immunodeficiency include chronic granulomatous disease , x - link agammaglobulinemia , selective iga deficiency , and severe combine immunodeficiency disease .
chronic granulomatous disease
the cause of chronic granulomatous disease ( cgd ) be defect in the nadph oxidase system of phagocytic cell , include neutrophil and macrophage , that prevent the production of superoxide radical in phagolysosome .
the inability to produce superoxide radical impair the antibacterial activity of phagocyte .
as a result , infection in clinical focus chapter one  nine  diseases of the immune system
eight  four  nine patient with cgd persist longer , lead to a chronic local inflammation call a granuloma .
microorganism that be the most common cause of infection in patient with cgd include aspergillus spp .
, staphylococcus aureus , chromobacterium violaceum , serratia marcescen , and salmonella typhimurium .
x - link agammaglobulinemia deficiencies in b cell due to defective differentiation lead to a lack of specific antibody production know as x - link agammaglobulinemia .
in one  nine  five  two , ogden c . bruton ( one  nine  zero  eight – two  zero  zero  three ) describe the first immunodeficiency in a boy whose immune system fail to produce antibody .
this defect be inherit on the x chromosome and be characterize by the absence of immunoglobulin in the serum  - pron - be call bruton x - link agammaglobulinemia ( xla ) .
the defective gene , btk , in xla be now know to encode a tyrosine kinase call bruton tyrosine kinase ( btk ) .
in patient whose b cell be unable to produce sufficient amount of btk , the b - cell maturation and differentiation halt at the pre - b - cell stage of growth .
b - cell maturation and differentiation beyond the pre - bcell stage of growth be require for immunoglobulin production .
patient who lack antibody production suffer from recurrent infection almost exclusively due to extracellular pathogen that cause pyogenic infection 
haemophilus influenzae , streptococcus pneumoniae , s . pyogene , and s . aureus .
because cell - mediate immunity be not impair , these patient be not particularly vulnerable to infection cause by virus or intracellular pathogen .
selective iga deficiency
the most common inherit form of immunoglobulin deficiency be selective iga deficiency , affect about one in eight  zero  zero people .
individual with selective iga deficiency produce normal level of igg and igm , but be not able to produce secretory iga . iga deficiency predispose these individual to lung and gastrointestinal infection for which secretory iga be normally an important defense mechanism .
infection in the lung and gastrointestinal tract can involve a variety of pathogen , include h . influenzae , s . pneumoniae , moraxella catarrhalis , s . aureus , giardia lamblia , or pathogenic strain of escherichia coli .
severe combined immunodeficiency patients who suffer from severe combine immunodeficiency ( scid ) have b - cell and t - cell defect that impair t - cell dependent antibody response as well as cell - mediate immune response .
patient with scid also can not develop immunological memory , so vaccine provide - pron - no protection , and live attenuated vaccine ( e . g . , for varicella - zoster , measle virus , rotavirus , poliovirus ) can actually cause the infection - pron - be intend to prevent .
the most common form be x - link scid , which account for nearly five  zero % of all case and occur primarily in male .
patient with scid be typically diagnose within the first few month of life after develop severe , often lifethreatene , opportunistic infection by candida spp .
, pneumocystis jirovecii , or pathogenic strain of e . coli .
without treatment , baby with scid do not typically survive infancy .
in some case , a bone marrow transplant may successfully correct the defect in lymphocyte development that lead to the scid phenotype , by replace the defective component .
however , this treatment approach be not without risk , as demonstrate by the famous case of david vetter ( one  nine  seven  one – one  nine  eight  four ) , better know as
" bubble boy

secondary immunodeficiency
a secondary immunodeficiency occur as a result an acquire impairment of function of b cell , t cell , or both .
secondary immunodeficiency can be cause by 
 systemic disorder such as diabetes mellitus , malnutrition , hepatitis , or hiv infection  immunosuppressive treatment such as cytotoxic chemotherapy , bone marrow ablation before transplantation , or radiation therapy 
prolonged critical illness due to infection , surgery , or trauma in the very young , elderly , or hospitalize patient unlike primary immunodeficiency , which have a genetic basis , secondary immunodeficiency be often reversible if the underlie cause be resolve .
patient with secondary immunodeficiency develop an increased susceptibility to an otherwise benign infection by opportunistic pathogen such as candida spp .
, p . jirovecii , and cryptosporidium .
hiv infection and the associate acquire immunodeficiency syndrome ( aids ) be the best - know secondary immunodeficiency .
aids be characterize by profound cd four t - cell lymphopenia ( decrease in lymphocyte ) .
the decrease in cd four t cell be the result of various mechanism , include hiv - induce pyroptosis ( a type of apoptosis that stimulate an inflammatory response ) , viral cytopathic effect , and cytotoxicity to hiv - infect cell .
the most common cause of secondary immunodeficiency worldwide be severe malnutrition , which affect both innate and adaptive immunity .
more research and information be need for the more common cause of secondary immunodeficiency  however , the number of new discovery in aids research far exceed that of any other single chapter one  nine  diseases of the immune system eight  five  one cause of secondary immunodeficiency .
aids research have pay off extremely well in term of discovery and treatment  increase research into the most common cause of immunodeficiency , malnutrition , would likely be as beneficial .

learning objectives
 explain how the adaptive specific immune response respond to tumor  discuss the risk and benefit of tumor vaccine
cancer involve a loss of the ability of cell to control - pron - cell cycle , the stage each eukaryotic cell go through as - pron - grow and then divide .
when this control be lose , the affect cell rapidly divide and often lose the ability to differentiate into the cell type appropriate for - pron - location in the body .
in addition , - pron - lose contact inhibition and can start to grow on top of each other .
this can result in formation of a tumor .
- pron - be important to make a distinction here  the term " cancer " be use to describe the disease result from loss of cell - cycle regulation and subsequent cell proliferation .
but the term " tumor " be more general .
a “ tumor " be an abnormal mass of cell , and a tumor can be benign ( not cancerous ) or malignant ( cancerous ) .
traditional cancer treatment use radiation and / or chemotherapy to destroy cancer cell  however , these treatment can have unwanted side effect because - pron - harm normal cell as well as cancer cell .
newer , promise therapy attempt to enlist the patient 's immune system to target cancer cell specifically .
- pron - be know that the immune system can recognize and destroy cancerous cell , and some researcher and immunologist also believe , base on the result of - pron - experiment , that many cancer be eliminate by the body 's own defense before - pron - can become a health problem .
this idea be not universally accept by researcher , however , and need further investigation for verification .
cell - mediated response to tumors cell - mediate immune response can be direct against cancer cell , many of which do not have the normal complement of self - protein , make - pron - a target for elimination .
abnormal cancer cell may also present tumor antigen .
these tumor antigen be not a part of the screening process use to eliminate lymphocyte during development  thus , even though - pron - be self - antigen , - pron - can stimulate and drive adaptive immune response against abnormal cell .
chapter one  nine  diseases of the immune system
eight  five  three presentation of tumor antigen can stimulate naïve helper t cell to become activate by cytokine such as il -  one  two and differentiate into th one cell .
th one cell release cytokine that can activate natural killer ( nk ) cell and enhance the killing of activate cytotoxic t cell .
both nk cell and cytotoxic t cell can recognize and target cancer cell , and induce apoptosis through the action of perforin and granzyme .
in addition , activate cytotoxic t cell can bind to cell - surface protein on abnormal cell and induce apoptosis by a second kill mechanism call the cd nine  five ( fas ) cytotoxic pathway .
despite these mechanism for remove cancerous cell from the body , cancer remain a common cause of death .
unfortunately , malignant tumor tend to actively suppress the immune response in various way .
in some cancer , the immune cell - pron - be cancerous .
in leukemia , lymphocyte that would normally facilitate the immune response become abnormal .
in other cancer , the cancerous cell can become resistant to induction of apoptosis .
this may occur through the expression of membrane protein that shut off cytotoxic t cell or that induce regulatory t cell that can shut down immune response .
the mechanism by which cancer cell alter immune response be still not yet fully understand , and this be a very active area of research .
as scientist ' understanding of adaptive immunity improve , cancer therapy that harness the body
's immune defense may someday be more successful in treat and eliminate cancer .

cancer vaccines
there be two type of cancer vaccine  preventive and therapeutic .
preventive vaccine be use to prevent cancer from occur , whereas therapeutic vaccine be use to treat patient with cancer .
most preventive cancer vaccine target viral infection that be know to lead to cancer .
these include vaccine against human papillomavirus ( hpv ) and hepatitis b , which help prevent cervical and liver cancer , respectively .
most therapeutic cancer vaccine be in the experimental stage .
- pron - exploit tumor - specific antigen to stimulate the immune system to selectively attack cancer cell .
specifically , - pron - aim to enhance th one function and interaction with cytotoxic t cell , which , in turn , result in more effective attack on abnormal tumor cell .
in some case , researcher have use genetic engineering to develop antitumor vaccine in an approach similar to that use for dna vaccine ( see micro connections  dna vaccine ) .
the vaccine contain a recombinant plasmid with gene for tumor antigen  theoretically , the tumor gene would not induce new cancer because - pron - be not functional , but - pron - could trick the immune system into target the tumor gene product as a foreign invader .
the first fda - approve therapeutic cancer vaccine be sipuleucel - t ( provenge ) , approve in two  zero  one  zero to treat certain case of prostate cancer . [ one  seven ]
this unconventional vaccine be custom design use the patient 's own cell .
apc be remove from the patient and culture with a tumor - specific molecule  the cell be then return to the patient .
this approach appear to enhance the patient 's immune response against the cancer cell .
another therapeutic cancer vaccine ( talimogene laherparepvec , also call t - vec or imlygic ) be approve by the fda in two  zero  one  five for treatment of melanoma , a form of skin cancer .
this vaccine contain a virus that be inject into tumor , where - pron - infect and lyse the tumor cell .
the virus also induce a response in lesion or tumor besides those into which the vaccine be inject , indicate that - pron - be stimulate a more general ( as oppose to local ) antitumor immune response in the patient .

summary one  nine  .  one hypersensitivities

an allergy be an adaptive immune response , sometimes life - threaten , to an allergen .

type i hypersensitivity require sensitization of mast cell with ige , involve an initial ige antibody response and ige attachment to mast cell .
on second exposure to an allergen , cross - linking of ige molecule on mast cell trigger degranulation and release of preformed and newly form chemical mediator of inflammation .
type i hypersensitivity may be localize and relatively minor ( hive and hay fever ) or systemwide and dangerous ( systemic anaphylaxis ) .
 type ii hypersensitivity result from antibody bind to antigen on cell and initiate cytotoxic response .
example include hemolytic transfusion reaction and hemolytic disease of the newborn .

type iii hypersensitivity result from formation and accumulation of immune complex in tissue , stimulate damage inflammatory response .
 type iv hypersensitivity be not mediate by antibody , but by helper t - cell activation of macrophage , eosinophil , and cytotoxic t cell .
one  nine  .  two autoimmune disorders
 autoimmune disease result from a breakdown in immunological tolerance .
the actual induction event ( s ) for autoimmune state be largely unknown .

some autoimmune disease attack specific organ , whereas other be more systemic .
 organ - specific autoimmune disease include celiac disease , grave disease , hashimoto thyroiditis , type i diabetes mellitus , and addison disease .
 systemic autoimmune disease include multiple sclerosis , myasthenia gravi , psoriasis , rheumatoid arthritis , and systemic lupus erythematosus .

treatment for autoimmune disease generally involve anti - inflammatory and immunosuppressive drug .
one  nine  .  three organ transplantation and rejection 
grafts and transplant can be classify as autograft , isograft , allograft , or xenograft base on the micro connections chapter one  nine  diseases of the immune system eight  five  five genetic difference between the donor 's and recipient 's tissue .
 genetic difference , especially among the mhc ( hla ) gene , will dictate the likelihood that rejection of the transplanted tissue will occur .

transplant recipient usually require immunosuppressive therapy to avoid rejection , even with good genetic matching .
this can create additional problem when immune response be need to fight off infectious agent and prevent cancer .

graft - versus - host disease can occur in bone marrow transplant , as the mature t cell in the transplant - pron - recognize the recipient 's tissue as foreign .

transplantation method and technology have improve greatly in recent decade and may move into new area with the use of stem cell technology to avoid the need for genetic matching of mhc molecule .
one  nine  .  four
immunodeficiency 
primary immunodeficiency be cause by genetic abnormality  secondary immunodeficiency be acquire through disease , diet , or environmental exposure 
primary immunodeficiency may result from flaw in phagocyte killing of innate immunity , or impairment of t cell and b cell .
 primary immunodeficiency include chronic granulomatous disease , x - link agammaglobulinemia , selective iga deficiency , and severe combine immunodeficiency disease .

secondary immunodeficiency result from environmentally induce defect in b cell and / or t cell .

causes for secondary immunodeficiency include malnutrition , viral infection , diabetes , prolonged infection , and chemical or radiation exposure .
one  nine  .  five cancer immunobiology and immunotherapy

cancer result from a loss of control of the cell cycle , result in uncontrolled cell proliferation and a loss of the ability to differentiate .

adaptive and innate immune response be engage by tumor antigen , self - molecule only find on abnormal cell .
these adaptive response stimulate helper t cell to activate cytotoxic t cell and nk cell of innate immunity that will seek and destroy cancer cell .

new anticancer therapy be in development that will exploit natural adaptive immunity anticancer response .
these include external stimulation of cytotoxic t cell and therapeutic vaccine that assist or enhance the immune response .

chapter two  zero
 laboratory analysis of the immune response eight  five  nine two  zero  .  one polyclonal and monoclonal antibody production learning objectives
 compare the method of development , use , and characteristic of monoclonal and polyclonal antibody 
explain the nature of antibody cross - reactivity and why this be less of a problem with monoclonal antibody
in addition to be crucial for - pron - normal immune response , antibody provide powerful tool for research and diagnostic purpose .
the high specificity of antibody make - pron - an excellent tool for detect and quantify a broad array of target , from drug to serum protein to microorganism .
with in vitro assay , antibody can be use to precipitate soluble antigen , agglutinate ( clump ) cell , opsonize and kill bacteria with the assistance of complement , and neutralize drug , toxin , and virus .
an antibody 's specificity result from the antigen - bind site form within the variable region - region of the antibody that have unique pattern of amino acid that can only bind to target antigen with a molecular sequence that provide complementary charge and noncovalent bond .
there be limitation to antibody specificity , however .
some antigen be so chemically similar that cross - reactivity occur  in other word , antibody raise against one antigen bind to a chemically similar but different antigen .
consider an antigen that consist of a single protein with multiple epitope ( figure two  zero  .  two ) .
this single protein may stimulate the production of many different antibody , some of which may bind to chemically identical epitope on other protein .
cross - reactivity be more likely to occur between antibody and antigen that have low affinity or avidity .
affinity , which can be determine experimentally , be a measure of the bind strength between an antibody ' s bind site and an epitope , whereas avidity be the total strength of all the interaction in an antibody - antigen complex ( which may have more than one bonding site ) .
avidity be influence by affinity as well as the structural arrangement of the epitope and the variable region of the antibody .
if an antibody have a high affinity / avidity for a specific antigen , - pron - be less likely to cross - react with an antigen for which - pron - have a low affinity / avidity .

what property make antibody useful for research and clinical diagnosis ?

what be cross - reactivity and why do - pron - occur ?
produce polyclonal antibodies antibodies use for research and diagnostic purpose be often obtain by inject a lab animal such as a rabbit or a goat with a specific antigen .
within a few week , the animal 's immune system will produce high level of antibody specific for the antigen .
these antibody can be harvest in an antiserum , which be whole serum collect from an animal follow exposure to an antigen .
because most antigen be complex structure with multiple epitope , - pron - result in the production of multiple antibody in the lab animal .
this so - call polyclonal antibody response be also typical of the response to infection by the human immune system .
antiserum draw from an animal will thus contain antibody from multiple clone of b cell , with each b cell respond to a specific epitope on the antigen ( figure two  zero  .  three ) .
lab animal be usually inject at least twice with antigen when be use to produce antiserum .
the second injection will activate memory cell that make class igg antibody against the antigen .
the memory cell also undergo affinity maturation , result in a pool of antibody with high average affinity .
affinity maturation occur because of mutation in the immunoglobulin gene variable region , result in b cell with slightly alter antigenbinde site .
on re - exposure to the antigen , those b cell capable of produce antibody with high affinity antigenbinde site will be stimulate to proliferate and produce more antibody than - pron - low - affinity peer .
an adjuvant , which be a chemical that provoke a generalize activation of the immune system that stimulate great antibody production , be often mix with the antigen prior to injection .
antiserum obtain from animal will not only contain antibody against the antigen artificially introduce in the laboratory , but - pron - will also contain antibody to any other antigen to which the animal have be expose during - pron - lifetime .
for this reason , antisera must first be " purify " to remove other antibody before use the antibody for research or diagnostic assay .

clinical uses of polyclonal antisera polyclonal antisera be use in many clinical test that be design to determine whether a patient be produce antibody in response to a particular pathogen .
while these test be certainly powerful diagnostic tool , - pron - have - pron - limitation , because - pron - be an indirect mean of determine whether a particular pathogen be present .
test base on a polyclonal response can sometimes lead to a false - positive result - in other word , a test that confirm the presence of an antigen that be , in fact , not present .
antibody - base test can also result in a false - negative result , which occur when the test fail to detect an antibody that be , in fact , present .
the accuracy of antibody test can be describe in term of test sensitivity and test specificity .
test sensitivity be the probability of get a positive test result when the patient be indeed infect .
if a test have high sensitivity , the probability of a false negative be low .
test specificity , on the other hand , be the probability of get a negative test result when the patient be not infect .
if a test have high specificity , the probability of a false positive be low .
false positive often occur due to cross - reactivity , which can occur when epitope from a different pathogen be similar to those find on the pathogen be test for .
for this reason , antibody - base test be often use only as screening test  if the result be positive , other confirmatory test be use to make sure that the result be not a false positive .
for example , a blood sample from a patient suspect of have hepatitis c can be screen for the virus use antibody that bind to antigen on hepatitis c virus .
if the patient be indeed infect with hepatitis c virus , the antibody will bind to the antigen , yield a positive test result .
if the patient be not infect with hepatitic c virus , the antibody will generally not bind to anything and the test should be negative  however , a false positive may occur if the patient have be previously infect by any of a variety of pathogen that elicit antibody that crossreact with the hepatitis c virus antigen .
antibody test for hepatitis c have high sensitivity ( a low probability of a false negative ) but low specificity ( a high probability of a false positive ) .
thus , patient who test positive must have a second , confirmatory test to rule out the possibility of a false positive .
the confirmatory test be a more expensive and time - consume test that directly test for the presence of hepatitis c viral rna in the blood .
only after the confirmatory test come back positive can the patient be definitively diagnose with a hepatitis c infection .
antibody - base test can result in a false negative if , for any reason , the patient 's immune system have not produce eight  six  two chapter two  zero  laboratory analysis of the immune response
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five detectable level of antibody .
for some disease , - pron - may take several week follow infection before the immune system produce enough antibody to cross the detection threshold of the assay .
in immunocompromised patient , the immune system may not be capable of produce a detectable level of antibody .
another limitation of use antibody production as an indicator of disease be that antibody in the blood will persist long after the infection have be clear .
depend on the type of infection , antibody will be present for many month  sometimes , - pron - may be present for the remainder of the patient 's life .
thus , a positive antibody - base test only mean that the patient be infect at some point in time  - pron - do not prove that the infection be active .
in addition to - pron - role in diagnosis , polyclonal antisera can activate complement , detect the presence of bacteria in clinical and food industry setting , and perform a wide array of precipitation reaction that can detect and quantify serum protein , virus , or other antigen .
however , with the many specificity of antibody present in a polyclonal antiserum , there be a significant likelihood that the antiserum will cross - react with antigen to which the individual be never expose .
therefore , - pron - must always account for the possibility of false - positive result when work with a polyclonal antiserum .

produce monoclonal antibodies
some type of assay require well antibody specificity and affinity than can be obtain use a polyclonal antiserum .
to attain this high specificity , all of the antibody must bind with high affinity to a single epitope .
this high specificity can be provide by monoclonal antibody ( mab ) .
table two  zero  .  one compare some of the important characteristic of monoclonal and polyclonal antibody .
unlike polyclonal antibody , which be produce in live animal , monoclonal antibody be produce in vitro use tissue - culture technique .
mab be produce by immunize an animal , often a mouse , multiple time with a specific antigen .
b cell from the spleen of the immunized animal be then remove .
since normal b cell be unable to proliferate forever , - pron - be fuse with immortal , cancerous b cell call myeloma cell , to yield hybridoma cell .
all of the cell be then place in a selective medium that allow only the hybridoma to grow  unfused myeloma cell can not grow , and any unfused b cell die off .
the hybridomas , which be capable of grow continuously in culture while produce antibody , be then screen for the desire mab .
those produce the desire mab be grow in tissue culture  the culture medium be harvest periodically and mab be purify from the medium .
this be a very expensive and time - consume process .
- pron - may take week of culturing and many liter of medium to provide enough mabs for an experiment or to treat a single patient .
mab be expensive ( figure two  zero  .  four ) .

mouse antibody can not be inject repeatedly into human , because the immune system will recognize - pron - as be foreign and will respond to - pron - with neutralize antibody .
this problem can be minimize by genetically engineer the antibody in the mouse b cell .
the variable region of the mouse light and heavy chain gene be ligate to human constant region , and the chimeric gene be then transfer into a host cell .
this allow production of a mab that be mostly " human " with only the antigen - bind site being of mouse origin .
humanized mab have be successfully use to treat cancer with minimal side effect .
for example , the humanized monoclonal antibody drug herceptin have be helpful for the treatment of some type of breast cancer .
there have also be a few preliminary trial of humanized mab for the treatment of infectious disease , but none of these treatment be currently in use .

use a cocktail of multiple mabs that target different strain of the pathogen can address this problem .

one promise technology for inexpensive mabs be the use of genetically engineer plant to produce antibody ( or plantibodie ) .

in some case , - pron - may even be possible to deliver these antibody by have patient eat the plant rather than by extract and inject the antibody .

detecting antigen - antibody complexes learning objectives
 describe various type of assay use to find antigen - antibody complex
 describe the circumstance under which antigen - antibody complex precipitate out of solution
 explain how antibody in patient serum can be use to diagnose disease laboratory test to detect antibody and antigen outside of the body ( e . g . , in a test tube ) be call in vitro assay .
when both antibody and - pron - correspond antigen be present in a solution , - pron - can often observe a precipitation reaction in which large complex ( lattice ) form and settle out of solution .
in the next several section , - pron - will discuss several common in vitro assays .
precipitin reactions
a visible antigen - antibody complex be call a precipitin , and in vitro assay that produce a precipitin be call precipitin reaction .
a precipitin reaction typically involve add soluble antigen to a test tube contain a solution of antibody .
each antibody have two arm , each of which can bind to an epitope .
when an antibody bind to two antigen , the two antigen become bind together by the antibody .
a lattice can form as antibody bind more and more antigen together , result in a precipitin ( figure two  zero  .  five ) .
most precipitin test use a polyclonal antiserum rather than monoclonal antibody because polyclonal antibody can bind to multiple epitope , make lattice formation more likely .
although mabs may bind some antigen , the binding will occur less often , make - pron - much less likely that a visible precipitin will form .
figure two  zero  .  five polyclonal antiserum bind to multiple epitope on an antigen , lead to lattice formation that result in a visible precipitin .
monoclonal antibody can only bind to a single epitope  therefore , less binding occur and lattice formation generally do not occur .
the amount of precipitation also depend on several other factor .
for example , precipitation be enhance when the antibody have a high affinity for the antigen .
while most antibody bind antigen with high affinity , even highaffinity bind use relatively weak noncovalent bond , so that individual interaction will often break and new interaction will occur .
in addition , for precipitin formation to be visible , there must be an optimal ratio of antibody to antigen .
the optimal five .

some antigen may have only one or two epitope recognize by the antiserum , whereas other antigen may have many different epitope and / or multiple instance of the same epitope on a single antigen molecule .
figure two  zero  .  six illustrate how the ratio of antigen and antibody affect the amount of precipitation .
to achieve the optimal ratio , antigen be slowly add to a solution contain antibody , and the amount of precipitin be determine qualitatively .
initially , there be not enough antigen to produce visible lattice formation  this be call the zone of antibody excess .
as more antigen be add , the reaction enter the equivalence zone ( or zone of equivalence ) , where both the optimal antigen - antibody interaction and maximal precipitation occur .
if even more antigen be add , the amount of antigen would become excessive and actually cause the amount of precipitation to decline .
figure two  zero  .  six
as antigen be slowly add to a solution contain a constant amount antibody , the amount of precipitin increase as the antibody - to - antigen ratio approach the equivalence zone and decrease once the proportion of antigen exceed the optimal ratio .

precipitin
ring test
a variety of technique allow - pron - to use precipitin formation to quantify either antigen concentration or the amount of antibody present in an antiserum .
one such technique be the precipitin ring test ( figure two  zero  .  seven ) , which be use to determine the relative amount of antigen - specific antibody in a sample of serum .
to perform this test , a set of test tube be prepare by add an antigen solution to the bottom of each tube .
each tube receive the same volume of solution , and the concentration of antigen be constant ( e . g . , one mg / ml ) .
next , glycerol be add to the antigen solution in each test tube , follow by a serial dilution of the antiserum .
the glycerol prevent mix of the antiserum with the antigen solution , allow antigen - antibody bind to take place only at the interface of the two solution .
the result be a visible ring of precipitin in the tube that have an antigen - antibody ratio within the equivalence zone .
this chapter two  zero  laboratory analysis of the immune response eight  six  seven high dilution with a visible ring be use to determine the titer of the antibody .
the titer be the reciprocal of the high dilution show a positive result , express as a whole number .
in figure two  zero  .  seven , the titer be one  six .
while a measurement of titer do not tell - pron - in absolute term how much antibody be present , - pron - do give a measure of biological activity , which be often more important than absolute amount .
in this example , - pron - would not be useful to know what mass of igg be present in the antiserum , because there be many different specificity of antibody present  but - pron - be important for - pron - to know how much of the antibody activity in a patient 's serum be direct against the antigen of interest ( e . g . , a particular pathogen or allergen ) .
figure two  zero  .  seven
a precipitin ring test be perform use a standard antigen solution in the bottom of the tube and a serial dilution of antiserum in the top of the tube .
glycerol prevent the two solution from mix so that precipitation only occur at the interface .
a visible ring of precipitation be see in the one  /  four , one  /  eight , and one  /  one  six dilution , indicate that these concentration be within the equivalence zone .
since one  /  one  six be the high dilution in which a precipitin be observe , the titer be the reciprocal , or one  six .
ouchterlony assay
while the precipitin ring test provide insight into antibody - antigen interaction , - pron - also have some drawback .
- pron - require the use of large amount of serum , and great care must be take to avoid mix the solution and disrupt the ring .
perform a similar test in an agar gel matrix can minimize these problem .
this type of assay be variously call double immunodiffusion or the ouchterlony assay for orjan ouchterlony , [ six ] who first describe the technique in one  nine  four  eight .
when agar be highly purified , - pron - produce a clear , colorless gel .
hole be punch in the gel to form well , and antigen and antisera be add to neighbor well .
protein be able to diffuse through the gel , and precipitin arcs form between the well at the zone of equivalence .
because the precipitin lattice be too large to diffuse through the gel , the arc be firmly lock in place and easy to see ( figure two  zero  .  eight ) .
although there be now more sensitive and quantitative method of detect antibody - antigen interaction , the ouchterlony test provide a rapid and qualitative way of determine whether an antiserum have antibody against a particular antigen .
the ouchterlony test be particularly useful when look for cross - reactivity .
- pron - can check an antiserum against a group of closely related antigen and see which combination form precipitin arc .

radial immunodiffusion
assay
the radial immunodiffusion ( rid ) assay be similar to the ouchterlony assay but be use to precisely quantify antigen concentration rather than to compare different antigen .
in this assay , the antiserum be add to temper agar ( liquid agar at slightly above four  five ° c ) , which be pour into a small petri dish or onto a glass slide and allow to cool .
wells be cut in the cool agar , and antigen be then add to the well and allow to diffuse .
as the antigen and antibody interact , - pron - form a zone of precipitation .
the square of the diameter of the zone of precipitation be directly proportional to the concentration of antigen .
by measure the zone of precipitation produce by sample of know concentration ( see the outer ring of sample in figure two  zero  .  nine ) , - pron - can prepare a standard curve for determine the concentration of an unknown solution .
the rid assay be a also useful test for determine the concentration of many serum protein such as the c three and c four complement protein , among other .

flocculation assays
a flocculation assay be similar to a precipitin reaction except that - pron - involve insoluble antigen such as lipid .
a flocculant be similar to a precipitin in that there be a visible lattice of antigen and antibody , but because lipid be insoluble in aqueous solution , - pron - can not precipitate .
instead of precipitation , flocculation ( foaming ) be observe in the test tube fluid .
use flocculation to test for syphilis syphilis be a sexually transmit infection that can cause severe , chronic disease in adult .
in addition , - pron - be readily pass from infected mother to - pron - newborn during pregnancy and childbirth , often result in stillbirth or serious long - term health problem for the infant .
unfortunately , syphilis can also be difficult to diagnose in expectant mother , because - pron - be often asymptomatic , especially in woman .
in addition , the causative agent , the bacterium treponema pallidum , be both difficult to grow on conventional lab medium and too small to see use routine microcopy .
for these reason , presumptive diagnosis of syphili be generally confirm indirectly in the laboratory use test that detect antibody to treponemal antigen .
in one  nine  zero  six , german scientist august von wassermann ( one  eight  six  six – one  nine  two  five ) introduce the first test for syphilis that rely

the antibody detect in the wassermann test be antiphospholipid antibody that be nonspecific to t . pallidum .
- pron - presence can assist in the diagnosis of syphilis , but because - pron - be nonspecific , - pron - can also lead to false - positive result in patient with other disease and autoimmune condition .
the original wasserman test have be modify over the year to minimize false - positive and be now know as the venereal disease research lab test , better know by - pron - acronym , the vdrl test .
to perform the vdrl test , patient serum or cerebral spinal fluid be place on a slide with a mixture of cardiolipin ( an antigenic phospholipid find in the mitochondrial membrane of various pathogen ) , lecithin , and cholesterol .
the lecithin and cholesterol stabilize the reaction and diminish false positive .
anti - treponemal antibody from an infected patient 's serum will bind cardiolipin and form a flocculant .
although the vdrl test be more specific than the original wassermann assay , false positive may still occur in patient with autoimmune disease that cause extensive cell damage ( e . g . , systemic lupus erythematosus ) .
neutralization assay
to cause infection , virus must bind to receptor on host cell .
antiviral antibody can neutralize viral infection by coat the virion , block the bind ( figure one  eight  .  seven ) .
this activity neutralize virion and can result in the formation of large antibody - virus complex ( which be readily remove by phagocytosis ) or by antibody bind to the virus and block - pron - bind to host cell receptor .
this neutralization activity be the basis of neutralization assay , sensitive assay use for diagnosis of viral infection .
when virus infect cell , - pron - often cause damage ( cytopathic effect ) that may include lysis of the host cell .
cytopathic effect can be visualize by grow host cell in a petri dish , cover the cell with a thin layer of agar , and then add virus ( see isolation , culture , and identification of viruses ) .
the virus will diffuse very slowly through the agar .
a virus will enter a host cell , proliferate ( cause cell damage ) , be release from the dead host cell , and then move to neighboring cell .
as more and more cell die , plaque of dead cell will form ( figure two  zero  .  one  zero ) .
during the course of a viral infection , the patient will mount an antibody response to the virus , and - pron - can quantify those antibody use a plaque reduction assay .
to perform the assay , a serial dilution be carry out on a serum sample .
each dilution be then mix with a standardized amount of the suspect virus .
any virus - specific antibody in the serum will neutralize some of the virus .
the suspension be then add to host cell in culture to allow any nonneutralized virus to infect the cell and form plaque after several day .
the titer be define as the reciprocal of the high dilution show a five  zero % reduction in plaque .
titer be always express as a whole number .
for example , if a one  /  six  four dilution be the high dilution to show five  zero % plaque reduction , then the titer be six  four .
the presence of antibody in the patient 's serum do not tell - pron - whether the patient be currently infect or be infect in the past .
current infection can be identify by wait two week and test another serum sample .
a four - fold increase in neutralize titer in this second sample indicate a new infection .

immunoelectrophoresis
when a patient have elevate protein level in the blood or be lose protein in the urine , a clinician will often order a polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis ( page ) assay ( see visualizing and characterizing dna , rna , and protein ) .
this assay compare the relative abundance of the various type of serum protein .
abnormal protein electrophoresis pattern can be further study use immunoelectrophoresis ( iep ) .
the iep begin by run a page .
antisera against select serum protein be add to trough run parallel to the electrophoresis track , form precipitin arc similar to those see in an ouchterlony assay ( figure two  zero  .  one  one ) .
this allow the identification of abnormal immunoglobulin protein in the sample .
iep be particularly useful in the diagnosis of multiple myeloma , a cancer of antibody - secrete cell .
patient with multiple myeloma can not produce healthy antibody  instead - pron - produce abnormal antibody that be monoclonal protein ( m protein ) .
thus , patient with multiple myeloma will present with elevated serum protein level that show a distinct band in the gamma globulin region of a protein electrophoresis gel and a sharp spike ( in m protein ) on the densitometer scan rather than the normal broad smear ( figure two  zero  .  one  two ) .
when antibody against the various type of antibody heavy and light chain be use to form precipitin arc , the m protein will cause distinctly skew arc against one class of heavy chain and one class of light chain as see in figure two  zero  .  one  one .

protein electrophoresis and the characterization of immunoglobulin structure
the advent of electrophoresis ultimately lead to research and understand the structure of antibody .
when swedish biochemist arne tiselius ( one  nine  zero  two – one  nine  seven  one ) publish the first protein electrophoresis result in one  nine  three  seven  , [ seven ] - pron - could identify the protein albumin ( the small and most abundant serum protein ) by the sharp band - pron - produce in the gel .
the other serum protein could not be resolve in a simple protein electrophoresis , so - pron - name the three broad band , with many protein in each band , alpha , beta , and gamma globulin .
two year later , american immunologist elvin kabat ( one  nine  one  four – two  zero  zero  zero ) travel to sweden to work with tiselius use this new technique and show that antibody migrate as gamma globulins . [ eight ]
with this new understanding in hand , researcher soon learn that multiple myeloma , because - pron - be a cancer of antibody - secrete cell , could be tentatively diagnose by the presence of a large m spike in the gamma - globulin region by protein electrophoresis .
prior to this discovery , study on immunoglobulin structure have be minimal , because of the difficulty of obtain pure sample to study .
sera from multiple myeloma patient prove to be an excellent source of highly enrich monoclonal immunoglobulin , provide the raw material for study over the next two  zero  - plus year that result in the elucidation of the structure of immunoglobulin .

in general , what do an immunoelectrophoresis assay accomplish ?
immunoblot assay  the western blot
after perform protein gel electrophoresis , specific protein can be identify in the gel use antibody .
this technique be know as the western blot .
follow separation of protein by page , the protein antigen in the gel be transfer to and immobilize on a nitrocellulose membrane .
this membrane can then be expose to a primary antibody produce to specifically bind to the protein of interest .
a second antibody equip with a molecular beacon will then bind to the first .
these secondary antibody be couple to another molecule such as an enzyme or a fluorophore ( a molecule that fluoresce when excite by light ) .
when use antibody couple to enzyme , a chromogenic substrate for the enzyme be add .
this substrate be usually colorless but will develop color in the presence of the antibody .
the fluorescence or substrate coloring identifie the location of the specific protein in the membrane to which the antibody be bind ( figure two  zero  .  one  three ) .
typically , polyclonal antibody be use for western blot assay .
- pron - be more sensitive than mab because of - pron - ability to bind to various epitope of the primary antigen , and the signal from polyclonal antibody be typically strong than that from mabs .
monoclonal antibody can also be use  however , - pron - be much more expensive to produce and be less sensitive , since - pron - be only able to recognize one specific epitope .
several variation of the western blot be useful in research .
in a southwestern blot , protein be separate by sds - page , blot onto a nitrocellulose membrane , allow to renature , and then probe with a fluorescently or radioactively label dna probe  the purpose of the southwestern be to identify specific dna - protein interaction .
far - western blot be carry out to determine protein - protein interaction between immobilized protein ( separate by sds - page , blot onto a nitrocellulose membrane , and allow to renature ) and non - antibody protein probe .
the bound non - antibody protein that interact with the immobilized protein in a far - western blot may be detect by radiolabeling , fluorescence , or the use of an antibody with an enzymatic molecular beacon .

what be the function of the enzyme in the immunoblot assay ?
complement - mediated immunoassay
one of the key function of antibody be the activation ( fixation ) of complement .
when antibody bind to bacteria , for example , certain complement protein recognize the bind antibody and activate the complement cascade .
in response , other complement protein bind to the bacteria where some serve as opsonin to increase the efficiency of phagocytosis and other create hole in gram - negative bacterial cell membrane , cause lysis .
this lytic activity can be use to detect the presence of antibody against specific antigen in the serum .
red blood cell be good indicator cell to use when evaluate complement - mediate cytolysis .
hemolysis of red blood cell release hemoglobin , which be a brightly color pigment , and hemolysis of even a small number of red cell will cause the solution to become noticeably pink ( figure two  zero  .  one  four ) .
this characteristic play a role in the complement fixation test , which allow the detection of antibody against specific pathogen .
the complement fixation test can be use to check for antibody against pathogen that be difficult to culture in the lab such as fungi , virus , or the bacteria chlamydia .
to perform the complement fixation test , antigen from a pathogen be add to patient serum .
if antibody to the antigen be present , the antibody will bind the antigen and fix all the available complement .
when red blood cell and antibody against red blood cell be subsequently add to the mix , there will be no complement leave to lyse the red cell .
thus , if the solution remain clear , the test be positive .
if there be no antipathogen antibody in the patient 's serum , the add antibody will activate the complement to lyse the red cell , yield a negative test ( figure two  zero  .  one  four ) .

if the sample do not contain antibody to the antigen , hemolysis of the sheep blood cell will be observe .

the use of agglutination test to identify streptococcal bacteria be develop in the one  nine  two  zero s by rebecca lancefield work with - pron - colleague a . r . dochez and oswald avery . [ nine ]
- pron - use antibody to identify m protein , a virulence factor on streptococci that be necessary for the bacteria 's ability to cause strep throat .

to identify antibody in a patient 's serum , the antigen of interest be attach to latex bead .

this technique be most often use when look for igm antibody , because - pron - structure provide maximum cross - linking .

in the reverse test , soluble antigen can be detect in a patient 's serum by attach specific antibody ( commonly mab ) to the latex bead and mix this complex with the serum ( figure two  zero  .  one  seven ) .
agglutination test be widely use in underdeveloped country that may lack appropriate facility for culturing bacteria .
for example , the widal test , use for the diagnosis of typhoid fever , look for agglutination of salmonella enterica subspecie typhi in patient sera .
the widal test be rapid , inexpensive , and useful for monitor the extent of an outbreak  however , - pron - be not as accurate as test that involve culture of the bacteria .
the widal test frequently produce false positive in patient with previous infection with other subspecie of salmonella , as well as false negative in patient with hyperproteinemia or immune deficiency .
in addition , agglutination test be limit by the fact that patient generally do not produce detectable level of antibody during the first week ( or longer ) of an infection .
a patient be say to have undergone seroconversion when antibody level reach the threshold for detection .
typically , seroconversion coincide with the onset of sign and symptom of disease .
however , in an hiv infection , for example , - pron - generally take three week for seroconversion to take place , and in some instance , - pron - may take much longer .
similar to technique for the precipitin ring test and plaque assay , - pron - be routine to prepare serial two - fold dilution of the patient 's serum and determine the titer of agglutinate antibody present .
since antibody level change over time in both primary and secondary immune response , by check sample over time , change in antibody titer can be detect .
for example , a comparison of the titer during the acute phase of an infection versus the titer from the convalescent phase will distinguish whether an infection be current or have occur in the past .

hemagglutination agglutination of red blood cell be call hemagglutination .
one common assay that use hemagglutination be the direct coombs ' test , also call the direct antihuman globulin test ( dat ) , which generally look for nonagglutinate antibody .
the test can also detect complement attach to red blood cell .
the coombs ' test be often employ when a newborn have jaundice , yellow of the skin cause by high blood concentration of bilirubin , a product of the breakdown of hemoglobin in the blood .
the coombs ' test be use to link to learning chapter two  zero  laboratory analysis of the immune response eight  eight  one determine whether the child 's red blood cell have be bind by the mother 's antibody .
these antibody would activate complement , lead to red blood cell lysis and the subsequent jaundice .
other condition that can cause positive direct coombs ' test include hemolytic transfusion reaction , autoimmune hemolytic anemia , infectious mononucleosis ( cause by epstein - barr virus ) , syphilis , and mycoplasma pneumonia .
a positive direct coombs ' test may also be see in some cancer and as an allergic reaction to some drug ( e . g . , penicillin ) .
the antibody bind to red blood cell in these condition be most often igg , and because of the orientation of the antigen - bind site on igg and the comparatively large size of a red blood cell , - pron - be unlikely that any visible agglutination will occur .
however , the presence of igg bind to red blood cell can be detect by add coombs ' reagent , an antiserum contain antihuman igg antibody ( that may be combine with anti - complement )
( figure two  zero  .  one  eight ) .
the coombs ' reagent link the igg attach to neighbor red blood cell and thus promote agglutination .
there be also an indirect coombs ' test know as the indirect antiglobulin test ( iat ) .
this screen an individual for antibody against red blood cell antigen ( other than the a and b antigen ) that be unbound in a patient 's serum ( figure two  zero  .  one  eight ) .
iat can be use to screen pregnant woman for antibody that may cause hemolytic disease of the newborn .
- pron - can also be use prior to give blood transfusion .

antibody that bind to red blood cell be not the only cause of hemagglutination .
some virus also bind to red blood cell , and this binding can cause agglutination when the virus cross - link the red blood cell .
for example , influenza virus have two different type of viral spike call neuraminidase ( n ) and hemagglutinin ( h ) , the latter name for - pron - ability to agglutinate red blood cell ( see viruses ) .
thus , - pron - can use red blood cell to detect the presence of influenza virus by direct hemagglutination assay ( ha ) , in which the virus cause visible agglutination of red blood cell .
the mump and rubella virus can also be detect use ha .

most frequently , a serial dilution viral agglutination assay be use to measure the titer or estimate the amount of virus produce in cell culture or for vaccine production .
a viral titer can be determine use a direct ha by make a serial dilution of the sample contain the virus , start with a high concentration of sample that be then dilute in a series of well .
the high dilution produce visible agglutination be the titer .
the assay be carry out in a microtiter plate with v - or round - bottom well .
in the presence of agglutinate virus , the red blood cell and virus clump together and produce a diffuse mat over the bottom of the well .
in the absence of virus , the red blood cell roll or sediment to the bottom of the well and form a dense pellet , which be why flat - bottom well can not be use ( figure two  zero  .  one  nine ) .
a modification of the ha assay can be use to determine the titer of antiviral antibody .
the presence of these antibody in a patient 's serum or in a lab - produce antiserum will neutralize the virus and block - pron - from agglutinate the red cell , make this a viral hemagglutination inhibition assay ( hia ) .
in this assay , patient serum be mixed with a standardized amount of virus .
after a short incubation , a standardized amount of red blood cell be add and hemagglutination be observe .
the titer of the patient 's serum be the high dilution that block agglutination ( figure two  zero  .  two  zero ) .

no agglutination of red blood cell be visible when the virus be absent , and the cell form a compact pellet at the bottom of the well .
in the presence of virus , a diffuse pink precipitate form in the well .

animal in the laboratory much of what - pron - know today about the human immune system have be learn through research conduct use animal - primarily , mammal - as model .
besides research , mammal be also use for the production of most of the antibody and other immune system component need for immunodiagnostic .
vaccine , diagnostic , therapy , and translational medicine in general have all be develop through research with animal model .
eye on ethics chapter two  zero  laboratory analysis of the immune response eight  eight  five consider some of the common use of laboratory animal for produce immune system component .
guinea pig be use as a source of complement , and mouse be the primary source of cell for make mabs .
these mab can be use in research and for therapeutic purpose .
antisera be raise in a variety of specie , include horse , sheep , goat , and rabbit .
when produce an antiserum , the animal will usually be inject at least twice , and adjuvant may be use to boost the antibody response .
the large animal use for make antisera will have blood harvest repeatedly over long period of time , with little harm to the animal , but that be not usually the case for rabbit .
although - pron - can obtain a few milliliter of blood from the ear vein of rabbit , - pron - usually need large volume , which result in the death of the animal .
- pron - also use animal for the study of disease .
the only way to grow treponema pallidum for the study of syphilis be in living animal .
many virus can be grow in cell culture , but growth in cell culture tell - pron - very little about how the immune system will respond to the virus .
when work on a newly discover disease , - pron - still employ koch 's postulate , which require cause disease in lab animal use pathogen from pure culture as a crucial step in prove that a particular microorganism be the cause of a disease .
study the proliferation of bacteria and virus in animal host , and how the host immune system respond , have be central to microbiological research for well over one  zero  zero year .
while the practice of use laboratory animal be essential to scientific research and medical diagnostic , many people strongly object to the exploitation of animal for human benefit .
this ethical argument be not a new one - indeed , one of charles darwin ' s daughter be an active antivivisectionist ( vivisection be the practice of cut or dissect a live animal to study - pron - ) .
most scientist acknowledge that there should be limit on the extent to which animal can be exploit for research purpose .
ethical consideration have lead the national institutes of health ( nih ) to develop strict regulation on the type of research that may be perform .
these regulation also include guideline for the humane treatment of lab animal , set standard for - pron - housing , care , and euthanization .
the nih document “ guide for the care and use of laboratory animals
" make - pron - clear that the use of animal in research be a privilege grant by society to researcher .
the nih guideline be base on the principle of the three r 's  replace , refine , and reduce .
researcher should strive to replace animal model with nonlive model , replace vertebrate with invertebrate whenever possible , or use computer - model when applicable .
- pron - should refine husbandry and experimental procedure to reduce pain and suffering , and use experimental design and procedure that reduce the number of animal need to obtain the desire information .
to obtain funding , researcher must satisfy nih reviewer that the research justify the use of animal and that - pron - use be in accordance with the guideline .
at the local level , any facility that use animal and receive federal funding must have an institutional animal care and use committee ( iacuc ) that ensure that the nih guideline be be follow .
the iacuc must include researcher , administrator , a veterinarian , and at least one person with no tie to the institution , that is , a concerned citizen .
this committee also perform inspection of laboratory and protocol .
for research involve human subject , an institutional review board ( irb ) ensure that proper guideline be follow .
visit this site ( https / / openstax . org / l /  two  two nihcareuseani ) to view the nih guide for the care and use of laboratory animals .
blood typing and cross - matching
in addition to antibody against bacteria and virus to which - pron - have previously be expose , most individual also carry antibody against blood type other than - pron - own .

the most important and perhaps best know be the abo and rh blood group ( see figure one  nine  .  four ) .
when unit of blood be be consider for transfusion , pretransfusion blood testing must be perform .
for the blood unit , commercially prepared antibody against the a , b , and rh antigen be mix with red blood cell from the unit to initially confirm that the blood type on the unit be accurate .
once a unit of blood have be request for transfusion , - pron - be vitally important to make sure the donor ( unit of blood ) and recipient ( patient ) be compatible for these crucial antigen .
in addition to confirm the blood type of the unit , the patient 's blood type be also confirm use the same commercially prepared antibody to a , b , and rh .
for example , as show in figure two  zero  .  two  one , if the donor blood be a - positive , - pron - will agglutinate with the anti - a antiserum and with the anti - rh antiserum .
if no agglutination be observe with any of the sera , then the blood type would be o - negative .
follow determination of the blood type , immediately prior to release the blood for transfusion , a cross - match be perform in which a small aliquot of the donor red blood cell be mix with serum from the patient awaiting transfusion .
if the patient do have antibody against the donor red blood cell , hemagglutination will occur .
to confirm any negative test result and check for sensitized red blood cell , coombs ' reagent may be add to the mix to facilitate visualization of the antibody - red blood cell interaction .
under some circumstance , a minor cross - match may be perform as well .
in this assay , a small aliquot of donor serum be mixed with patient red blood cell .
this allow the detection of agglutinize antibody in the donor serum .
this test be rarely necessary because transfusion generally use pack red blood cell with most of the plasma remove by centrifugation .
red blood cell have many other antigen in addition to abo and rh .
while most people be unlikely to have antibody against these antigen , woman who have have multiple pregnancy or patient who have have multiple transfusion may have - pron - because of repeat exposure .
for this reason , an antibody screen test be use to determine if such antibody be present .
patient serum be check against commercially prepare , pooled , type o red blood cell that express these antigen .
if agglutination occur , the antigen to which the patient be respond must be identify and determine not to be present in the donor unit .

 describe the different purpose of direct and indirect elisa similar to the western blot , enzyme immunoassay ( eia ) use antibody to detect the presence of antigen .
however , eia differ from western blot in that the assay be conduct in microtiter plate or in vivo rather than on an absorbent membrane .
there be many different type of eia , but - pron - all involve an antibody molecule whose constant region bind an enzyme , leave the variable region free to bind - pron - specific antigen .
the addition of a substrate for the enzyme allow the antigen to be visualize or quantify ( figure two  zero  .  two  two ) .

fluorescence can be detect by either a fluorescence microscope or a spectrophotometer .
