the mmr titer
the mmr vaccine be a combination vaccine that provide protection against measle , mump , and rubella ( german measle ) .
most people receive the mmr vaccine as child and thus have antibody against these disease .
however , for various reason , even vaccinate individual may become susceptible to these disease again later in life .
for example , some child may receive only one round of the mmr vaccine instead of the recommend two .
in addition , the titer of protective antibody in an individual 's body may begin to decline with age or as the result of some medical condition .
to determine whether the titer of antibody in an individual 's bloodstream be sufficient to provide protection , an mmr titer test can be perform .
the test be a simple immunoassay that can be do quickly with a blood sample .
the result of the test will indicate whether the individual still have immunity or need another dose of the mmr vaccine .
submit to an mmr titer be often a pre - employment requirement for healthcare worker , especially those who will frequently be in contact with young child or immunocompromise patient .
be a healthcare worker to become infected with measle , mump , or rubella , the individual could easily pass these disease on to susceptible patient , lead to an outbreak .
depend on the result of the mmr titer , healthcare worker may need to be revaccinate prior to begin work .
immunostaine one powerful use of eia be immunostaine , in which antibody - enzyme conjugate enhance microscopy .
immunohistochemistry ( ihc ) be use for examine whole tissue .
as see in figure two  zero  .  two  three , a section of tissue can be stain to visualize the various cell type .
in this example , a mab against cd eight be use to stain cd eight cell in a section of tonsil tissue .
- pron - be now possible to count the number of cd eight cell , determine - pron - relative number versus the other cell type present , and determine the location of these cell within this tissue .
such datum would be useful for study disease such as aids , in which the normal function of cd eight cell be crucial for slow disease progression .
immunocytochemistry ( icc ) be another valuable form of immunostaining .
while similar to ihc , in icc , extracellular matrix material be strip away , and the cell membrane be etch with alcohol to make - pron - permeable micro connections chapter two  zero  laboratory analysis of the immune response eight  eight  nine to antibody .
this allow antibody to pass through the cell membrane and bind to specific target inside the cell .
organelle , cytoskeletal component , and other intracellular structure can be visualize in this way .
while some icc technique use eia , the enzyme can be replace with a fluorescent molecule , make - pron - a fluorescent immunoassay .

enzyme - link immunosorbent assays ( elisas )
the enzyme - link immunosorbent assay ( elisas ) be widely use eia .
in the direct elisa , antigen be immobilize in the well of a microtiter plate .
an antibody that be specific for a particular antigen and be conjugate to an enzyme be add to each well .
if the antigen be present , then the antibody will bind .
after wash to remove any unbound antibody , a colorless substrate ( chromogen ) be add .
the presence of the enzyme convert the substrate into a colored end product ( figure two  zero  .  two  two ) .
while this technique be fast because - pron - only require the use of one antibody , - pron - have the disadvantage that the signal from a direct elisa be low ( low sensitivity ) .
in a sandwich elisa , the goal be to use antibody to precisely quantify specific antigen present in a solution , such as antigen from a pathogen , a serum protein , or a hormone from the blood or urine to list just a few example .
the first step of a sandwich elisa be to add the primary antibody to all the well of a microtiter plate ( figure two  zero  .  two  four ) .
the antibody stick to the plastic by hydrophobic interaction .
after an appropriate incubation time , any unbound antibody be wash away .
comparable wash be use between each of the subsequent step to ensure that only specifically bind molecule remain attached to the plate .
a block protein be then add ( e . g . , albumin or the milk protein casein ) to bind the remain nonspecific protein - bind site in the well .
some of the well will receive known amount of antigen to allow the construction of a standard curve , and unknown antigen solution be add to the other well .
the primary antibody capture the antigen and , follow a wash , the secondary antibody be add , which be a polyclonal antibody that be conjugate to an enzyme .
after a final wash , a colorless substrate ( chromogen ) eight  nine  zero chapter two  zero  laboratory analysis of the immune response
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five be add , and the enzyme convert - pron - into a colored end product .
the color intensity of the sample cause by the end product be measure with a spectrophotometer .
the amount of color produce ( measure as absorbance ) be directly proportional to the amount of enzyme , which in turn be directly proportional to the capture antigen .
elisa be extremely sensitive , allow antigen to be quantify in the nanogram ( one  zero – nine g ) per ml range .
in an indirect elisa , - pron - quantify antigen - specific antibody rather than antigen .
- pron - can use indirect elisa to detect antibody against many type of pathogen , include borrelia burgdorferi ( lyme disease ) and hiv .
there be three important difference between indirect and direct elisa as show in figure two  zero  .  two  five .
rather than use antibody to capture antigen , the indirect elisa start with attach know antigen ( e . g . , peptide from hiv ) to the bottom of the microtiter plate well .
after block the unbound site on the plate , patient serum be add  if antibody be present ( primary antibody ) , - pron - will bind the antigen .
after wash away any unbound protein , the secondary antibody with - pron - conjugate enzyme be direct against the primary antibody ( e . g . , antihuman immunoglobulin ) .
the secondary antibody allow - pron - to quantify how much antigen - specific antibody be present in the patient 's serum by the intensity of the color produce from the conjugate enzyme - chromogen reaction .
as with several other test for antibody discuss in this chapter , there be always concern about cross - reactivity with antibody direct against some other antigen , which can lead to false - positive result .
thus , - pron - can not definitively diagnose an hiv infection ( or any other type of infection ) base on a single indirect elisa assay .
- pron - must confirm any suspect positive test , which be most often do use either an immunoblot that actually identify the presence of specific peptide from the pathogen or a test to identify the nucleic acid associate with the pathogen , such as reverse transcriptase pcr ( rt - pcr ) or a nucleic acid antigen test .

immunofiltration and immunochromatographic assays
for some situation , - pron - may be necessary to detect or quantify antigen or antibody that be present at very low concentration in solution .
immunofiltration technique have be develop to make this possible .
in immunofiltration , a large volume of fluid be pass through a porous membrane into an absorbent pad .
an antigen attach to the porous membrane will capture antibody as - pron - pass  alternatively , - pron - can also attach an antibody to the membrane to capture antigen .
the method of immunofiltration have be adapt in the development of immunochromatographic assay , commonly know as lateral flow test or strip test .
these test be quick and easy to perform , make - pron - popular for point - of - care use ( i . e . , in the doctor 's office ) or in - home use .
one example be the torch test that allow doctor to screen pregnant woman or newborn for infection by an array of virus and other pathogen ( toxoplasma , other virus , rubella , cytomegalovirus , herpe simplex ) .
in - home pregnancy test be another widely use example of a lateral flow test ( figure two  zero  .  two  six ) .
immunofiltration test be also popular in develop country , because - pron - be inexpensive and do not require constant refrigeration of the dry reagent .
however , the technology be also build into some sophisticated laboratory equipment .
in lateral flow test ( figure two  zero  .  two  seven ) , fluid such as urine be apply to an absorbent pad on the test strip .
the fluid flow by capillary action and move through a stripe of bead with antibody attach to - pron - surface .
the fluid in the sample actually hydrate the reagent , which be present in a dry state in the stripe .
antibody - coat bead make of latex or tiny gold particle will bind antigen in the test fluid .
the antibody - antigen complex then flow over a second stripe that have immobilize antibody against the antigen  this stripe will retain the bead that have bind antigen .
a third control stripe bind any bead .
a red color ( from gold particle ) or blue ( from latex bead ) develop at the test line indicate a positive test .
if the color only develop at the control line , the test be negative .
like elisa technique , lateral flow test take advantage of antibody sandwich , provide sensitivity and specificity .
while not as quantitative as elisa , these test have the advantage of be fast , inexpensive , and not dependent on special equipment .
thus , - pron - can be perform anywhere by anyone .

although the indirect elisa for hiv be a sensitive assay , there be several complicating consideration .
first , if an infected person be test too soon after become infect , the test can yield false - negative result .
the seroconversion window be generally about three week , but in some case , - pron - can be more than two month .
in addition to false negative , false positive can also occur , usually due to previous infection with other virus that induce cross - react antibody .
the false - positive rate depend on the particular brand of test use , but zero  .  five % be not unusual . [ one  zero ] because of the possibility of a false positive , all positive test be follow up with a confirmatory test .
this confirmatory test be often an immunoblot ( western blot ) in which hiv peptide from the patient 's blood be identify use an hiv - specific mab - enzyme conjugate .
a positive western blot would confirm an hiv infection and a negative blot would confirm the absence of hiv despite the positive elisa .
unfortunately , western blot for hiv antigen often yield indeterminant result , in which case , - pron - neither confirm nor invalidate the result of the indirect elisa .
in fact , the rate of indeterminant can be one  zero – four  nine % ( which be why , combine with - pron - cost , western blot be not use for screening ) .

rapid visualization of bacteria from a clinical sample such as a throat swab or sputum can be achieve through fluorescent antibody ( fa ) technique that attach a fluorescent marker ( fluorogen ) to the constant region of an antibody , result in a reporter molecule that be quick to use , easy to see or measure , and able to bind to target marker with high specificity .
- pron - can also label cell , allow - pron - to precisely quantify particular subset of cell or even purify these subset for further research .
as with the enzyme assay , fa method may be direct , in which a label mab bind an antigen , or indirect , in which secondary polyclonal antibody bind patient antibody that react to a prepared antigen .
application of these two method be demonstrate in figure two  .  one  nine .
fa method be also use in automate cell counting and sort system to enumerate or segregate label subpopulation of cell in a sample .
direct fluorescent antibody techniques direct fluorescent antibody ( dfa )
test use a fluorescently label mab to bind and illuminate a target antigen .
dfa test be particularly useful for the rapid diagnosis of bacterial disease .
for example , fluorescence - label antibody against streptococcus pyogene ( group a strep ) can be use to obtain a diagnosis of strep throat from a throat swab .
the diagnosis be ready in a matter of minute , and the patient can be start on antibiotic before even leave the clinic .
dfa technique may also be use to diagnose pneumonia cause by mycoplasma pneumoniae or legionella pneumophila from sputum sample ( figure two  zero  .  two  eight ) .
the fluorescent antibody bind to the bacteria on a microscope slide , allow ready detection of the bacteria use a fluorescence microscope .
thus , the dfa technique be valuable for visualize certain bacteria that be difficult to isolate or culture from patient sample .

flow cytometry fluorescently label antibody can be use to quantify cell of a specific type in a complex mixture use flow cytometry ( figure two  zero  .  three  one ) , an automate , cell - count system that detect fluoresce cell as - pron - pass through a narrow tube one cell at a time .
for example , in hiv infection , - pron - be important to know the level of cd four t cell in the patient 's blood  if the number fall below five  zero  zero per μl of blood , the patient become more likely to acquire opportunistic infection  below two  zero  zero per μl , the patient can no longer mount a useful adaptive immune response at all .
the analysis begin by incubate a mixed - cell population ( e . g . , white blood cell from a donor ) with a fluorescently label mab specific for a subpopulation of cell ( e . g . , anti - cd four ) .
some experiment look at two cell marker simultaneously by add a different fluorogen to the appropriate mab .
the cell be then introduce to the flow cytometer through a narrow capillary that force the cell to pass in single file .
a laser be use to activate the fluorogen .
the fluorescent light radiate out in all direction , so the fluorescence detector can be position at an angle from the incident laser light .
figure two  zero  .  three  one show the obscuration bar in front of the forward - scatter detector that prevent laser light from hit the detector .
as a cell pass through the laser bar , the forward - scatter detector detect light scatter around the obscuration bar .
the scatter light be transform into a voltage pulse , and the cytometer count a cell .
the fluorescence from a label cell be detect by the side - scatter detector .
the light pass through various dichroic mirror such that the light emit from the fluorophore be receive by the correct detector .

in flow cytometry , a mixture of fluorescently label and unlabeled cell pass through a narrow capillary .
a laser excite the fluorogen , and the fluorescence intensity of each cell be measure by a detector .
( credit  modification of work by “ kierano” / wikimedia commons )
data be collect from both the forward - and side - scatter detector .
one way these datum can be present be in the form of a histogram .
the forward scatter be place on the y - axis ( to represent the number of cell ) , and the side scatter be place on the x - axis ( to represent the fluoresence of each cell ) .
the scaling for the x - axis be logarithmic , so fluorescence intensity increase by a factor of one  zero with each unit increase along the axis .
figure two  zero  .  three  two depict an example in which a culture of cell be combine with an antibody attach to a fluorophore to detect cd eight cell and then analyze by flow cytometry .
the histogram have two peak .
the peak on the left have low fluorescence reading , represent the subset of the cell population ( approximately three  zero cell ) that do not fluoresce  hence , - pron - be not bind by antibody and therefore do not express cd eight .
the peak on the right have high fluorescence reading , represent the subset of the cell population ( approximately one  zero  zero cell ) that show fluorescence  hence , - pron - be bind by the antibody and therefore do express cd eight .

the flow cytometer and immunofluorescence can also be modify to sort cell from a single sample into purified subpopulation of cell for research purpose .
this modification of the flow cytometer be call a fluorescenceactivate cell sorter ( facs ) .
in a facs , fluorescence by a cell induce the device to put a charge on a droplet of the transport fluid contain that cell .
the charge be specific to the wavelength of the fluorescent light , which allow for differential sorting by those different charge .
the sorting be accomplish by an electrostatic deflector that move the charge droplet contain the cell into one collect vessel or another .
the process result in highly purified subpopulation of cell .
one limitation of a facs be that - pron - only work on isolated cell .
thus , the method would work in sort white blood cell , since - pron - exist as isolated cell .
but for cell in a tissue , flow cytometry can only be apply if - pron - can excise the tissue and separate - pron - into single cell ( use protease to cleave cell - cell adhesion molecule ) without disrupt cell integrity .
this method may be use on tumor , but more often , immunohistochemistry and immunocytochemistry be use to study cell in tissue .

table two  zero  .  five summary two  zero  .  one polyclonal and monoclonal antibody production  antibodies bind with high specificity to antigen use to challenge the immune system , but - pron - may also show cross - reactivity by bind to other antigen that share chemical property with the original antigen .

injection of an antigen into an animal will result in a polyclonal antibody response in which different antibody be produce that react with the various epitope on the antigen .
 polyclonal antisera be useful for some type of laboratory assay , but other assay require more specificity .
diagnostic test that use polyclonal antisera be typically only use for screening because of the possibility of false - positive and false - negative result .
 monoclonal antibody provide high specificity than polyclonal antisera because - pron - bind to a single epitope and usually have high affinity .

monoclonal antibody be typically produce by culture antibody - secrete hybridoma derive from mouse .
mab be currently use to treat cancer , but - pron - exorbitant cost have prevent - pron - from be use more widely to treat infectious disease .
still , - pron - potential for laboratory and clinical use be drive the development of new , cost - effective solution such as plantibodie .

detecting antigen - antibody complexes

when present in the correct ratio , antibody and antigen will form a precipitin , or lattice that precipitate out of solution .

a precipitin ring test can be use to visualize lattice formation in solution .
the ouchterlony assay demonstrate lattice formation in a gel .
the radial immunodiffusion assay be use to quantify antigen by measure the size of a precipitation zone in a gel infuse with antibody .

insoluble antigen in suspension will form flocculant when bind by antibody .
this be the basis of the vdrl test for syphilis in which anti - treponemal antibody bind to cardiolipin in suspension .
 viral infection can be detect by quantify virus - neutralize antibody in a patient 's serum .

different antibody class in plasma or serum be identify by use immunoelectrophoresis .

the presence of specific antigen ( e . g . , bacterial or viral protein ) in serum can be demonstrate by western blot assay , in which the protein be transfer to a nitrocellulose membrane and identify use label antibody .

in the complement fixation test , complement be use to detect antibody against various pathogen .
two  zero  .  three agglutination assays  antibodies can agglutinate cell or large particle into a visible matrix .
agglutination test be often do on card or in microtiter plate that allow multiple reaction to take place side by side use small volume of reagent .

use antisera against certain protein allow identification of serovar within specie of bacteria .

detecting antibody against a pathogen can be a powerful tool for diagnose disease , but there be a period of time before patient go through seroconversion and the level of antibody become detectable .

some virus and bacteria will bind and agglutinate red blood cell  this interaction be the basis of the direct hemagglutination assay , most often use to determine the titer of virus in solution .

neutralization assay quantify the level of virus - specific antibody by measure the decrease in hemagglutination observe after mix patient serum with a standardized amount of virus .

hemagglutination assay be also use to screen and cross - match donor and recipient blood to ensure that the transfusion recipient do not have antibody to antigen in the donate blood .
two  zero  .  four eia and elisas 
enzyme immunoassay
( eia ) be use to visualize and quantify antigen .
- pron - use an antibody conjugate to an enzyme to bind the antigen , and the enzyme convert a substrate into an observable end product .
the substrate may be either a chromogen or a fluorogen .

immunostaining be an eia technique for visualize cell in a tissue ( immunohistochemistry ) or examine intracellular structure ( immunocytochemistry ) .

direct elisa be use to quantify an antigen in solution .
the primary antibody capture the antigen , and the secondary antibody deliver an enzyme .
production of end product from the chromogenic substrate be directly proportional to the amount of capture antigen .

indirect elisa be use to detect antibody in patient serum by attach antigen to the well of a microtiter plate , allow the patient ( primary ) antibody to bind the antigen and an enzyme - conjugate secondary antibody to detect the primary antibody .

immunofiltration and immunochromatographic assay be use in lateral flow test , which can be use to diagnose pregnancy and various disease by detect color - label antigen - antibody complex in urine or other fluid sample two  zero  .  five fluorescent antibody techniques

immunofluorescence assay use antibody - fluorogen conjugate to illuminate antigen for easy , rapid detection .
 direct immunofluorescence can be use to detect the presence of bacteria in clinical sample such as sputum .

indirect immunofluorescence detect the presence of antigen - specific antibody in patient sera .
the fluorescent antibody bind to the antigen - specific antibody rather than the antigen .

the use of indirect immunofluorescence assay to detect antinuclear antibody be an important tool in the diagnosis of several autoimmune disease .
 flow cytometry use fluorescent mabs against cell - membrane protein to quantify specific subset of cell in complex mixture .

fluorescence - activate cell sorter be an extension of flow cytometry in which fluorescence intensity be use to physically separate cell into high and low fluorescence population .

the human body be cover in skin , and like most covering , skin be design to protect what be underneath .
one of - pron - primary purpose be to prevent microbe in the surround environment from invade underlie tissue and organ .
but in spite of - pron - role as a protective covering , skin be not - pron - immune from infection .
certain pathogen and toxin can cause severe infection or reaction when - pron - come in contact with the skin .
other pathogen be opportunistic , breach the skin 's natural defense through cut , wound , or a disruption of normal microbiota result in an infection in the surround skin and tissue .
still other pathogen enter the body via different route - through the respiratory or digestive system , for example - but cause reaction that manifest as skin rash or lesion .
nearly all human experience skin infection to some degree .
many of these condition be , as the name suggest , “ skin deep , " with symptom that be local and non - life - threaten .
at some point , almost everyone must endure condition like acne , athlete 's foot , and minor infection of cut and abrasion , all of which result from infection of the skin .
but not all skin infection be quite so innocuous .
some can become invasive , lead to systemic infection or spread over large area of skin , potentially become life - threaten .

not only be - pron - a physical barrier to penetration of deep tissue by potential pathogen , but - pron - also provide an inhospitable environment for the growth of many pathogen .
in this section , - pron - will provide a brief overview of the anatomy and normal microbiota of the skin and eye , along with general symptom associate with skin and eye infection .
layer of the skin human skin be make up of several layer and sublayer .
the two main layer be the epidermis and the dermis .
these layer cover a third layer of tissue call the hypodermis , which consist of fibrous and adipose connective tissue ( figure two  one  .  two ) .
the epidermis be the outermost layer of the skin , and - pron - be relatively thin .
the exterior surface of the epidermis , call the stratum corneum , primarily consist of dead skin cell .
this layer of dead cell limit direct contact between the outside world and live cell .
the stratum corneum be rich in keratin , a tough , fibrous protein that be also find in hair and nail .
keratin help make the outer surface of the skin relatively tough and waterproof .
- pron - also help to keep the surface of the skin dry , which reduce microbial growth .
however , some microbe be still able to live on the surface of the skin , and some of these can be shed with dead skin cell in the process of desquamation , which be the shedding and peeling of skin that occur as a normal process but that may be accelerate when infection be present .
beneath the epidermis lie a thick skin layer call the dermis .
the dermis contain connective tissue and embed structure such as blood vessel , nerve , and muscle .
structure call hair follicle ( from which hair grow ) be locate within the dermis , even though much of - pron - structure consist of epidermal tissue .
the dermis also contain the two major type of gland find in human skin  sweat gland ( tubular gland that produce sweat ) and sebaceous gland ( which be associate with hair follicle and produce sebum , a lipid - rich substance contain protein and mineral ) .
perspiration ( sweat ) provide some moisture to the epidermis , which can increase the potential for microbial growth .
for this reason , more microbe be find on the region of the skin that produce the most sweat , such as the skin part one sam , a college freshman with a bad habit of oversleep , nick - pron - shave in a rush to get to class on time .
at the time , - pron - do not think twice about - pron - .
but two day later , - pron - notice the cut be surround by a reddish area of skin that be warm to the touch .
when the wound start ooze pus , - pron - decide - pron - have well stop by the university 's clinic .
the doctor take a sample from the lesion and then clean the area .

normal microbiota of the skin
the skin be home to a wide variety of normal microbiota , consist of commensal organism that derive nutrition from skin cell and secretion such as sweat and sebum .
the normal microbiota of skin tend to inhibit transientmicrobe colonization by produce antimicrobial substance and outcompete other microbe that land on the surface of the skin .
this help to protect the skin from pathogenic infection .
the skin 's property differ from one region of the body to another , as do the composition of the skin 's microbiota .
the availability of nutrient and moisture partly dictate which microorganism will thrive in a particular region of the skin .
relatively moist skin , such as that of the naris ( nostril ) and underarm , have a much different microbiota than the dryer skin on the arm , leg , hand , and top of the foot .
some area of the skin have high density of sebaceous gland .
these sebum - rich area , which include the back , the fold at the side of the nose , and the back of the neck , harbor distinct microbial community that be less diverse than those find on other part of the body .
different type of bacteria dominate the dry , moist , and sebum - rich region of the skin .
the most abundant microbe typically find in the dry and sebaceous region be betaproteobacteria and propionibacteria , respectively .
in the chapter two  one  skin and eye infections nine  one  five moist region , corynebacterium and staphylococcus be most commonly find ( figure two  one  .  three ) .
virus and fungus be also find on the skin , with malassezia be the most common type of fungus find as part of the normal microbiota .
the role and population of virus in the microbiota , know as virome , be still not well understand , and there be limitation to the technique use to identify - pron - .
however , circoviridae , papillomaviridae , and polyomaviridae appear to be the most common resident in the healthy skin virome . [ one ][ two ][ three ] figure two  one  .  three
the normal microbiota vary on different region of the skin , especially in dry versus moist area .

note that there be significant variation among individual .

anatomy and microbiota of the eye
although the eye and skin have distinct anatomy , - pron - be both in direct contact with the external environment .
an important component of the eye be the nasolacrimal drainage system , which serve as a conduit for the fluid of the eye , call tear .
tear flow from the external eye to the nasal cavity by the lacrimal apparatus , which be compose of nine  one  eight chapter two  one  skin and eye infections
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five the structure involve in tear production ( figure two  one  .  six ) .
the lacrimal gland , above the eye , secrete tear to keep the eye moist .
there be two small opening , one on the inside edge of the upper eyelid and one on the inside edge of the lower eyelid , near the nose .
each of these opening be call a lacrimal punctum .
together , these lacrimal puncta collect tear from the eye that be then convey through lacrimal duct to a reservoir for tear call the lacrimal sac , also know as the dacrocyst or tear sac .
from the sac , tear fluid flow via a nasolacrimal duct to the inner nose .
each nasolacrimal duct be locate underneath the skin and pass through the bone of the face into the nose .
chemical in tear , such as defensin , lactoferrin , and lysozyme , help to prevent colonization by pathogen .
in addition , mucin facilitate removal of microbe from the surface of the eye .

the surface of the eyeball and inner eyelid be mucous membrane call conjunctiva .
the normal conjunctival microbiota have not be well characterize , but do exist .

the watery material inside of the eyeball be call the vitreous humor .
unlike the conjunctiva , - pron - be protect from contact with the environment and be almost always sterile , with no normal microbiota ( figure two  one  .  seven ) .

chapter two  one  skin and eye infections nine  two  one staphylococcal infections of the skin staphylococcus specie be commonly find on the skin , with s . epidermidis and s . homini be prevalent in the normal microbiota .
s . aureus be also commonly find in the nasal passage and on healthy skin , but pathogenic strain be often the cause of a broad range of infection of the skin and other body system .
s . aureus be quite contagious .
- pron - be spread easily through skin - to - skin contact , and because many people be chronic nasal carrier ( asymptomatic individual who carry s . aureus in - pron - naris ) , the bacteria can easily be transfer from the nose to the hand and then to fomite or other individual .
because - pron - be so contagious , s . aureus be prevalent in most community setting .
this prevalence be particularly problematic in hospital , where antibioticresistant strain of the bacteria may be present , and where immunocompromised patient may be more susceptible to infection .
resistant strain include methicillin - resistant s . aureus ( mrsa ) , which can be acquire through healthcare setting ( hospital - acquire mrsa , or ha - mrsa ) or in the community ( community - acquire mrsa , or camrsa ) .
hospital patient often arrive at health - care facility already colonize with antibiotic - resistant strain of s . aureus that can be transfer to health - care provider and other patient .
some hospital have attempt to detect these individual in order to institute prophylactic measure , but - pron - have have mix success ( see eye on ethic 
screen patient for mrsa ) .
when a staphylococcal infection develop , choice of medication be important .
as discuss above , many staphylococci ( such as mrsa ) be resistant to some or many antibiotic .
thus , antibiotic sensitivity be measure to identify the most suitable antibiotic .
however , even before receive the result of sensitivity analysis , suspect s . aureus infection be often initially treat with drug know to be effective against mrsa , such as trimethoprimsulfamethoxazole ( tmp / smz ) , clindamycin , a tetracycline ( doxycycline or minocycline ) , or linezolid .
the pathogenicity of staphylococcal infection be often enhance by characteristic chemical secrete by some strain .
staphylococcal virulence factor include hemolysin call staphylolysin , which be cytotoxic for many type of cell , include skin cell and white blood cell .
virulent strain of s . aureus be also coagulase - positive , mean - pron - produce coagulase , a plasma - clot protein that be involve in abscess formation .
- pron - may also produce leukocidin , which kill white blood cell and can contribute to the production of pus and protein a , which inhibit phagocytosis by bind to the constant region of antibody .
some virulent strain of s . aureus also produce other toxin , such as toxic shock syndrome toxin -  one
( see virulence factors of bacterial and viral pathogens ) .
to confirm the causative agent of a suspect staphylococcal skin infection , sample from the wound be cultured .
under the microscope , gram - positive staphylococcus specie have cellular arrangement that form grapelike cluster  when grow on blood agar , colony have a unique pigmentation range from opaque white to cream .
a catalase test be use to distinguish staphylococcus from streptococcus , which be also a genus of gram - positive cocci and a common cause of skin infection .
staphylococcus specie be catalase - positive while streptococcus specie be catalase - negative .
other test be perform on sample from the wound in order to distinguish coagulase - positive specie of staphylococcus ( cops ) such as s . aureus from common coagulase - negative specie ( cons ) such as s . epidermidis .
although cons be less likely than cops to cause human disease , - pron - can cause infection when - pron - enter the body , as can sometimes occur via catheter , indwell medical device , and wound .
passive agglutination testing can be use to distinguish cops from cons .
if the sample be coagulase - positive , the sample be generally presume to contain s . aureus .
additional genetic testing would be necessary to identify the particular strain of s . aureus .
another way to distinguish cops from cons be by culture the sample on mannitol salt agar ( msa ) .
staphylococcus specie readily grow on this medium because - pron - be tolerant of the high concentration of sodium chloride ( seven  .  five % nacl ) .
however , cops such as s . aureus ferment mannitol ( which will be evident on a msa plate ) , whereas cons such as s . epidermidis do not ferment mannitol but can be distinguish by the fermentation of other sugar such as lactose , malonate , and raffinose ( figure two  one  .  nine ) .

screen patient for mrsa
accord to the cdc , eight  six % of invasive mrsa infection be associate in some way with healthcare , as oppose to be community - acquire .
in hospital and clinic , asymptomatic patient who harbor mrsa may spread the bacteria to individual who be more susceptible to serious illness .
in an attempt to control the spread of mrsa , hospital have try screen patient for mrsa .
if patient test positive follow a nasal swab test , - pron - can undergo decolonization use chlorhexidine wash or intranasal mupirocin .
some study have report substantial reduction in mrsa disease follow implementation of these protocol , while other have not .
this be partly because there be no standard protocol for these procedure .
several different mrsa identification test may be use , some involve slow culture technique and other rapid testing .
other factor , such as the effectiveness of general hand - washing protocol , may also play a role in help to prevent mrsa transmission .
there be still other question that need to be address  how frequently should patient be screen ?
which individual should be test ?
from where on the body should sample be collect ?
will increase resistance develop from the decolonization procedure ?
even if identification and decolonization procedure be perfect , ethical question will remain .
should patient have the right to decline testing ?
should a patient who test positive for mrsa have the right to decline the decolonization procedure , and if so , should hospital have the right to refuse treatment to the patient ?
how do - pron - balance the individual
's right to receive care with the right of other patient who could be expose to disease as a result ?
superficial staphylococcal infections s . aureus be often associate with pyoderma , skin infection that be purulent .
pus formation occur because many eye on ethics chapter two  one  skin and eye infections nine  two  three strain of s . aureus produce leukocidin , which kill white blood cell .
these purulent skin infection may initially manifest as folliculitis , but can lead to furuncle or deep abscess call carbuncle .
folliculitis generally present as bump and pimple that may be itchy , red , and / or pus - fill .
in some case , folliculitis be self - limit , but if - pron - continue for more than a few day , worsen , or return repeatedly , - pron - may require medical treatment .
sweat , skin injury , ingrown hair , tight clothing , irritation from shave , and skin condition can all contribute to folliculitis .
avoidance of tight clothing and skin irritation can help to prevent infection , but topical antibiotic ( and sometimes other treatment ) may also help .
folliculitis can be identify by skin inspection  treatment be generally start without first culture and identify the causative agent .
in contrast , furuncle ( boil ) be deep infection ( figure two  one  .  one  zero ) .
- pron - be most common in those individual ( especially young adult and teenager ) who play contact sport , share athletic equipment , have poor nutrition , live in close quarter , or have weaken immune system .
good hygiene and skin care can often help to prevent furuncle from become more infective , and - pron - generally resolve on - pron - own .
however , if furuncle spread , increase in number or size , or lead to systemic symptom such as fever and chill , then medical care be need .
- pron - may sometimes need to be drain ( at which time the pathogen can be culture ) and treat with antibiotic .
when multiple boil develop into a deep lesion , - pron - be call a carbuncle ( figure two  one  .  one  zero ) .
because carbuncle be deep , - pron - be more commonly associate with systemic symptom and a general feeling of illness .
large , recurrent , or worsen carbuncle require medical treatment , as do those associate with sign of illness such as fever .
carbuncles generally need to be drain and treat with antibiotic .
while carbuncle be relatively easy to identify visually , culturing and laboratory analysis of the wound may be recommend for some infection because antibiotic resistance be relatively common .
proper hygiene be important to prevent these type of skin infection or to prevent the progression of exist infection .

staphylococcal scald skin syndrome ( ssss ) be another superficial infection cause by s . aureus that be most commonly see in young child , especially infant .
bacterial exotoxin first produce erythema ( redness of the skin ) and then severe peeling of the skin , as may occur after scald ( figure two  one  .  one  one ) .
ssss be diagnose by examine characteristic of the skin ( which may rub off easily ) , use blood test to check for elevated white blood cell count , culturing , and other method .
intravenous antibiotic and fluid therapy be use as treatment .

impetigo
the skin infection impetigo cause the formation of vesicle , pustule , and possibly bullae , often around the nose and mouth .
bullae be large , fluid - fill blister that measure at least five mm in diameter .
impetigo can be diagnose as either nonbullous or bullous .
in nonbullous impetigo , vesicle and pustule rupture and become encrusted sore .
typically the crust be yellowish , often with exudate drain from the base of the lesion .
in bullous impetigo , the bullae fill and rupture , result in large , drain , encrust lesion ( figure two  one  .  one  two ) .
especially common in child , impetigo be particularly concern because - pron - be highly contagious .
impetigo can be cause by s . aureus alone , by streptococcus pyogene alone , or by coinfection of s . aureus and s . pyogene .
impetigo be often diagnose through observation of - pron - characteristic appearance , although culture and susceptibility testing may also be use .
topical or oral antibiotic treatment be typically effective in treat most case of impetigo .
however , case cause by s . pyogene can lead to serious sequelae ( pathological condition result from infection , disease , injury , therapy , or other trauma ) such as acute glomerulonephritis ( agn ) , which be severe inflammation in the kidney .

nosocomial s . epidermidis infections
though not as virulent as s . aureus , the staphylococcus s . epidermidis can cause serious opportunistic infection .
such infection usually occur only in hospital setting .
s . epidermidis be usually a harmless resident of the normal chapter two  one  skin and eye infections
nine  two  five skin microbiota .
however , health - care worker can inadvertently transfer s . epidermidis to medical device that be insert into the body , such as catheter , prosthesis , and indwell medical device .
once - pron - have bypass the skin barrier , s . epidermidis can cause infection inside the body that can be difficult to treat .
like s . aureus , s . epidermidis be resistant to many antibiotic , and localized infection can become systemic if not treat quickly .
to reduce the risk of nosocomial ( hospital - acquire ) s . epidermidis , health - care worker must follow strict procedure for handle and sterilize medical device before and during surgical procedure .

why be staphylococcus aureus infection often purulent ?
streptococcal infections of the skin streptococcus be gram - positive cocci with a microscopic morphology that resemble chain of bacteria .
colony be typically small ( one – two mm in diameter ) , translucent , entire edge , with a slightly raise elevation that can be either nonhemolytic , alpha - hemolytic , or beta - hemolytic when grow on blood agar ( figure two  one  .  one  three ) .
additionally , - pron - be facultative anaerobe that be catalase - negative .
figure two  one  .  one  three streptococcus pyogene form chain of cocci .
( credit  modification of work by centers for disease control and prevention )
the genus streptococcus include important pathogen that be categorize in serological lancefield group base on the distinguish characteristic of - pron - surface carbohydrate .
the most clinically important streptococcal specie in human be s . pyogene , also know as group a streptococcus ( gas ) .
s . pyogene produce a variety of extracellular enzyme , include streptolysin o and s , hyaluronidase , and streptokinase .
these enzyme can aid in transmission and contribute to the inflammatory response . [ six ] s . pyogene also produce a capsule and m protein , a streptococcal cell wall protein .
these virulence factor help the bacteria to avoid phagocytosis while provoke a substantial immune response that contribute to symptom associate with streptococcal infection .
s . pyogene cause a wide variety of disease not only in the skin , but in other organ system as well .
example of disease elsewhere in the body include pharyngitis and scarlet fever , which will be cover in later chapter .

an infection that develop in the dermis or hypodermis can cause cellulitis , which present as a reddened area of the skin that be warm to the touch and painful .
the causative agent be often s . pyogene , which may breach the epidermis through a cut or abrasion , although cellulitis may also be cause by staphylococci .
s . pyogene can also cause erysipela , a condition that present as a large , intensely inflamed patch of skin involve the dermis ( often on the leg or face ) .
these infection can be suppurative , which result in a bullous form of erysipela .
streptococcal and other pathogen may also cause a condition call erythema nodosum , characterize by inflammation in the subcutaneous fat cell of the hypodermis .
- pron - sometimes result from a streptococcal infection , though other pathogen can also cause the condition .
- pron - be not suppurative , but lead to red nodule on the skin , most frequently on the shin ( figure two  one  .  one  four ) .
in general , streptococcal infection be best treat through identification of the specific pathogen follow by treatment base upon that particular pathogen 's susceptibility to different antibiotic .
many immunological test , include agglutination reaction and elisa , can be use to detect streptococci .
penicillin be commonly prescribe for treatment of cellulitis and erysipela because resistance be not widespread in streptococci at this time .
in most patient , erythema nodosum be self - limit and be not treat with antimicrobial drug .
recommend treatment may include nonsteroidal anti - inflammatory drug ( nsaids ) , cool wet compress , elevation , and bed rest .

necrotizing fasciitis streptococcal infection that start in the skin can sometimes spread elsewhere , result in a rare but potentially life - threaten condition call necrotize fasciitis , sometimes refer to as flesh - eat bacterial syndrome .
s . pyogene be one of several specie that can cause this rare but potentially - fatal condition  other include klebsiella , clostridium , escherichia coli , s . aureus , and aeromonas hydrophila .
necrotize fasciitis occur when the fascia , a thin layer of connective tissue between the skin and muscle , become infect .
severe invasive necrotizing fasciitis due to streptococcus pyogene occur when virulence factor that be responsible for adhesion and invasion overcome host defense .
s . pyogene invasin allow bacterial cell to adhere to tissue and establish infection .
bacterial protease unique to s . pyogene aggressively infiltrate and destroy host tissue , inactivate complement , and prevent neutrophil migration to the site of infection .
the infection and result tissue death can spread very rapidly , as large area of skin become detached and die .
treatment generally require debridement ( surgical removal of dead or infected tissue ) or amputation of infect limb to stop the spread of the infection  surgical treatment be supplement with intravenous antibiotic and other therapy ( figure two  one  .  one  five ) .
necrotize fasciitis do not always originate from a skin infection  in some case there be no known portal of entry .
some study have suggest that experience a blunt force trauma can increase the risk of develop streptococcal necrotizing fasciitis . [ seven ] chapter two  one

name at least two type of skin infection commonly cause by pseudomonas spp .
acne one of the most ubiquitous skin condition be acne .
acne afflict nearly eight  zero % of teenager and young adult , but - pron - can be find in individual of all age .
high incidence among adolescent be due to hormonal change that can result in overproduction of sebum .
acne occur when hair follicle become clog by shed skin cell and sebum , cause non - inflammatory lesion call comedo .
comedo ( singular " comedo " ) can take the form of whitehead and blackhead pimple .
whitehead be cover by skin , whereas blackhead pimple be not  the black color occur when lipid in the clog follicle become expose to the air and oxidize ( figure two  one  .  one  eight ) .
figure two  one  .  one  eight
( a )
acne be characterize by whitehead and blackhead comedo that result from clog hair follicle .
( b ) blackhead , visible as black spot on the skin , have a dark appearance due to the oxidation of lipid in sebum via exposure to the air .

often comedone lead to infection by propionibacterium acne , a gram - positive , non - spore - form , aerotolerant anaerobic bacillus find on skin that consume component of sebum .
p . acne secrete enzyme that damage the hair follicle , cause inflammatory lesion that may include papule , pustule , nodule , or pseudocyst , depend on - pron - size and severity .
treatment of acne depend on the severity of the case .
there be multiple way to grade acne severity , but three level be usually consider base on the number of comedo , the number of inflammatory lesion , and the type of lesion .
mild acne be treat with topical agent that may include salicylic acid ( which help to remove old skin cell ) or retinoid ( which have multiple mechanism , include the reduction of inflammation ) .
moderate acne may be treat with antibiotic ( erythromycin , clindamycin ) , acne cream ( e . g . , benzoyl peroxide ) , and hormone .
severe acne may require treatment use strong medication such as isotretinoin ( a retinoid that reduce oil buildup , among other effect , but that also have serious side effect such as photosensitivity ) .
other treatment , such as phototherapy and las therapy to kill bacteria and possibly reduce oil production , be also sometimes use .

anthrax
the zoonotic disease anthrax be cause by bacillus anthracis , a gram - positive , endospore - form , facultative anaerobe .
anthrax mainly affect animal such as sheep , goat , cattle , and deer , but can be find in human as well .
sometimes call wool sorter 's disease , - pron - be often transmit to human through contact with infected animal or animal product , such as wool or hide .
however , exposure to b . anthracis can occur by other mean , as the endospore be widespread in soil and can survive for long period of time , sometimes for hundred of year .
the vast majority of anthrax case ( nine  five – nine  nine % ) occur when anthrax endospore enter the body through abrasion of the skin . [ eight ]
this form of the disease be call cutaneous anthrax .
- pron - be characterize by the formation of a nodule on the skin  the cell within the nodule die , form a black eschar , a mass of dead skin tissue ( figure two  one  .  one  nine ) .
the localized infection can eventually lead to bacteremia and septicemia .
if untreated , cutaneous anthrax can cause death in two  zero % of patients . [ nine ]
once in the skin tissue , b . anthracis endospore germinate and produce a capsule , which prevent the bacteria from be phagocytize , and two binary exotoxin that cause edema and tissue damage .
the first of the two exotoxin consist of a combination of protective antigen ( pa ) and an enzymatic lethal factor ( lf ) , form lethal toxin ( letx ) .
the second consist of protective antigen ( pa ) and an edema factor ( ef ) , form edema toxin ( edtx ) .

less commonly , anthrax infection can be initiate through other portal of entry such as the digestive tract ( gastrointestinal anthrax ) or respiratory tract ( pulmonary anthrax or inhalation anthrax ) .
typically , case of noncutaneous anthrax be more difficult to treat than the cutaneous form .
the mortality rate for gastrointestinal anthrax can be up to four  zero % , even with treatment .
inhalation anthrax , which occur when anthrax spore be inhale , initially cause influenza - like symptom , but mortality rate be approximately four  five % in treated individual and eight  five % in those not treat .
a relatively new form of the disease , injection anthrax , have be report in europe in intravenous drug user  - pron - occur when drug be contaminate with b . anthracis .
patient with injection anthrax show sign and symptom of severe soft tissue infection that differ clinically from cutaneous anthrax .
this often delay diagnosis and treatment , and lead to a high mortality rate . [ one  zero ] b . anthracis colony on blood agar have a rough texture and serrate edge that eventually form an undulating band ( figure two  one  .  one  nine ) .
broad spectrum antibiotic such as penicillin , erythromycin , and tetracycline be often effective treatment .
unfortunately , b . anthracis have be use as a biological weapon and remain on the united nations ' list of potential agent of bioterrorism . [ one  one ]
over a period of several month in two  zero  zero  one , a number of letter be mail to member of the news medium and the united states congress .
as a result , one  one individual develop cutaneous anthrax and another one  one developed inhalation anthrax .
those infect include recipient of the letter , postal worker , and two other individual .
five of those infect with pulmonary anthrax die .
the anthrax spore have be carefully prepared to aerosolize , show that the perpetrator have a high level of expertise in microbiology . [ one  two ]
a vaccine be available to protect individual from anthrax .
however , unlike most routine vaccine , the current anthrax vaccine be unique in both - pron - formulation and the protocol
dictate who receive it . [ one  three ]
the vaccine be administer through five intramuscular injection over a period of one  eight month , follow by annual booster .
the us food and drug administration ( fda ) have only approve administration of the vaccine prior to exposure for at - risk adult , such as individual who work with anthrax in a laboratory , some individual who handle animal or animal product ( e . g . , some veterinarian ) , and some member of the united states military .

bacterial conjunctivitis ( pinkeye ) be a condition characterize by inflammation of the conjunctiva , often accompany by a discharge of sticky fluid ( describe as acute purulent conjunctivitis )
( figure two  one  .  two  one ) .
conjunctivitis can affect one eye or both , and - pron - usually do not affect vision permanently .
bacterial conjunctivitis be most commonly cause by haemophilus influenzae , but can also be cause by other specie such as moraxella catarrhalis , s . pneumoniae , and s . aureus .
the causative agent may be identify use bacterial culture , gram stain , and diagnostic biochemical , antigenic , or nucleic acid profile test of the isolate pathogen .
bacterial conjunctivitis be very contagious , be transmit via secretion from infect individual , but - pron - be also self - limit .

neonatal conjunctivitis newborns whose mother have certain sexually transmit infection be at risk of contract ophthalmia neonatorum or inclusion conjunctivitis , which be two form of neonatal conjunctivitis contract through exposure to pathogen during passage through the birth canal .
gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum be cause by neisseria gonorrhoeae , the bacterium that cause the std gonorrhea ( figure two  one  .  two  two ) .
inclusion ( chlamydial ) conjunctivitis be cause by chlamydia trachomatis , the anaerobic , obligate , intracellular parasite that cause the std chlamydia .
to prevent gonoccocal ophthalmia neonatorum , silver nitrate ointment be once routinely apply to all infant ' eye shortly after birth  however , - pron - be now more common to apply antibacterial cream or drop , such as erythromycin .
most hospital be require by law to provide this preventative treatment to all infant , because conjunctivitis cause by n . gonorrhoeae , c . trachomatis , or other bacteria acquire during a vaginal delivery can have serious complication .
if untreated , the infection can spread to the cornea , result in ulceration or perforation that can cause vision loss or even permanent blindness .
as such , neonatal conjunctivitis be treat aggressively with oral or intravenous antibiotic to stop the spread of the infection .
causative agent of inclusion conjunctivitis may be identify use bacterial culture , gram stain , and diagnostic biochemical , antigenic , or nucleic acid profile test .

chapter two  one  skin and eye infections nine  three  five trachoma trachoma , or granular conjunctivitis , be a common cause of preventable blindness that be rare in the united states but widespread in develop country , especially in africa and asia .
the condition be cause by the same specie that cause neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis in infant , chlamydia trachomatis .
c . trachomatis can be transmit easily through fomite such as contaminate towel , bed linen , and clothing and also by direct contact with infected individual .
c . trachomatis can also be spread by fly that transfer infect mucous contain c . trachomatis from one human to another .
infection by c . trachomatis cause chronic conjunctivitis , which lead to the formation of necrotic follicle and scar in the upper eyelid .
the scar turn the eyelash inward ( a condition know as trichiasis ) and mechanical abrasion of the cornea lead to blindness ( figure two  one  .  two  three ) .
antibiotic such as azithromycin be effective in treat trachoma , and outcome be good when the disease be treat promptly .
in area where this disease be common , large public health effort be focus on reduce transmission by teach people how to avoid the risk of the infection .
figure two  one  .  two  three ( a )
if trachoma be not treat early with antibiotic , scar on the eyelid can lead to trichiasis , a condition in which the eyelash turn inward .
( b )
trichiasis lead to blindness if not correct by surgery , as show here .

why be trachoma rare in the united states ?
safe eradication of trachoma
though uncommon in the united states and other develop nation , trachoma be the lead cause of preventable blindness worldwide , with more than four million people at immediate risk of blindness from trichiasis .
the vast majority of those affect by trachoma live in africa and the middle east in isolate rural or desert community with limited access to clean water and sanitation .
these condition provide an environment micro connections nine  three  six chapter two  one  skin and eye infections
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five conducive to the growth and spread of chlamydia trachomatis , the bacterium that cause trachoma , via wastewater and eye - seek fly .
in response to this crisis , recent year have see major public health effort aim at treat and prevent trachoma .
the alliance for global elimination of trachoma by two  zero  two  zero ( get two  zero  two  zero ) , coordinate by the world health organization ( who ) , promote an initiative dub “ safe , " which stand for “ surgery , antibiotics , facial cleanliness , and environmental improvement .
"
the carter center , a charitable , nongovernment organization lead by former us president jimmy carter , have partner with the who to promote the safe initiative in six of the most critically impact nation in africa .
through - pron - trachoma control program , the carter center train and equip local surgeon to correct trichiasis and distribute antibiotic to treat trachoma .
the program also promote well personal hygiene through health education and improve sanitation by fund the construction of household latrine .
this reduce the prevalence of open sewage , which provide breeding ground for the fly that spread trachoma .
bacterial keratitis keratitis can have many cause , but bacterial keratitis be most frequently cause by staphylococcus epidermidis and / or pseudomonas aeruginosa .
contact lens user be particularly at risk for such an infection because s . epidermidis and p . aeruginosa both adhere well to the surface of the lense .
risk of infection can be greatly reduce by proper care of contact lense and avoid wear lense overnight .
because the infection can quickly lead to blindness , prompt and aggressive treatment with antibiotic be important .
the causative agent may be identify use bacterial culture , gram stain , and diagnostic biochemical , antigenic , or nucleic acid profile test of the isolated pathogen .

biofilms and infections of the skin and eye
when treat bacterial infection of the skin and eye , - pron - be important to consider that few such infection can be attribute to a single pathogen .
while biofilm may develop in other part of the body , - pron - be especially relevant to skin infection ( such as those cause by s . aureus or p . aeruginosa ) because of - pron - prevalence in chronic skin wound .
biofilm develop when bacteria ( and sometimes fungi ) attach to a surface and produce extracellular polymeric substance ( eps ) in which cell of multiple organism may be embed .
when a biofilm develop on a wound , - pron - may interfere with the natural healing process as well as diagnosis and treatment .
because biofilm vary in composition and be difficult to replicate in the lab , - pron - be still not thoroughly understand .
the extracellular matrix of a biofilm consist of polymer such as polysaccharide , extracellular dna , protein , and lipid , but the exact makeup varie .
the organism live within the extracellular matrix may include familiar pathogen as well as other bacteria that do not grow well in culture ( such as numerous obligate anaerobe ) .
this present challenge when culture sample from infection that involve a biofilm .
because only some specie grow in vitro , the culture may contain only a subset of the bacterial specie involve in the infection .
biofilm confer many advantage to the resident bacteria .
for example , biofilm can facilitate attachment to surface on or in the host organism ( such as wound ) , inhibit phagocytosis , prevent the invasion of neutrophil , and sequester host antibody .
additionally , biofilm can provide a level of antibiotic resistance not find in the isolated cell and colony that be typical of laboratory culture .
the extracellular matrix provide a physical barrier to antibiotic , shield the target cell from exposure .
moreover , cell within a biofilm may differentiate to create subpopulation of dormant cell call persister cell .
nutrient limitation deep within a biofilm add another level of resistance , as stress response can slow metabolism and increase drug resistance .

prevention require limit exposure to contagious pathogen .
when infection do occur , prompt treatment with antibiotic can often limit or prevent permanent damage .

papillomas papillomas ( wart ) be the expression of common skin infection by human papillomavirus ( hpv ) and be transmit by direct contact .

roseola and fifth disease
the viral disease roseola and fifth disease be somewhat similar in term of - pron - presentation , but - pron - be cause by different virus .
roseola , sometimes call roseola infantum or exanthem subitum ( " sudden rash " ) , be a mild viral infection usually cause by human herpesvirus -  six ( hhv -  six ) and occasionally by hhv -  seven .
- pron - be spread via direct contact with the saliva or respiratory secretion of an infected individual , often through droplet aerosol .
roseola be very common in child , with symptom include a runny nose , a sore throat , and a cough , along with ( or follow by ) a high fever ( three  nine  .  four ºc ) .
about three to five day after the fever subside , a rash may begin to appear on the chest and abdomen .
the rash , which do not cause discomfort , initially form characteristic macule that be flat or papule that be firm and slightly raise  some macule or papule may be surround by a white ring .
the rash may eventually spread to the neck and arm , and sometimes continue to spread to the face and leg .
the diagnosis be generally make base upon observation of the symptom .
however , - pron - be possible to perform serological test to confirm the diagnosis .
while treatment may be recommend to control the fever , the disease usually resolve without treatment within a week after the fever develop .
for individual at particular risk , such as those who be immunocompromise , the antiviral medication ganciclovir may be use .
fifth disease ( also know as erythema infectiosum ) be another common , highly contagious illness that cause a distinct rash that be critical to diagnosis .
fifth disease be cause by parvovirus b one  nine , and be transmit by contact et al .

dermatophyte be commonly find in the environment and in soil and be frequently transfer to the skin via contact with other human and animal .
fungal spore can also spread on hair .
many dermatophyte grow well in moist , dark environment .
for example , tinea pedis ( athlete 's foot ) commonly spread in public shower , and the causative fungi grow well in the dark , moist confine of sweaty shoe and sock .
likewise , tinea cruris ( jock itch ) often spread in communal living environment and thrive in warm , moist undergarment .
tinea on the body ( tinea corporis ) often produce lesion that grow radially and heal towards the center .
this cause the formation of a red ring , lead to the misleading name of ringworm recall the clinical focus case in the eukaryotes of microbiology .
several approach may be use to diagnose tinea .
a wood 's lamp ( also call a black lamp ) with a wavelength of three  six  five nm be often use .
when direct on a tinea , the ultraviolet light emit from the wood 's lamp cause the fungal element ( spore and hypha ) to fluoresce .
direct microscopic evaluation of specimen from skin scraping , hair , or nail can also be use to detect fungi .
generally , these specimen be prepare in a wet mount use a potassium hydroxide solution ( one  zero %– two  zero % aqueous koh ) , which dissolve the keratin in hair , nail , and skin cell to nine  four  four chapter two  one  skin and eye infections

cutaneous aspergillosis
another cause of cutaneous mycose be aspergillus , a genus consisting of mold of many different specie , some of which cause a condition call aspergillosis .
primary cutaneous aspergillosis , in which the infection begin in the skin , be rare but do occur .
more common be secondary cutaneous aspergillosis , in which the infection begin in the respiratory system and disseminate systemically .
both primary and secondary cutaneous aspergillosis result in distinctive eschar that form at the site or site of infection ( figure two  one  .  three  one ) .
pulmonary aspergillosis will be discuss more thoroughly in respiratory mycoses ) .

primary cutaneous aspergillosis usually occur at the site of an injury and be most often cause by aspergillus fumigatus or aspergillus flavus .
- pron - be usually report in patient who have have an injury while work in an agricultural or outdoor environment .
however , opportunistic infection can also occur in health - care setting , often at the site of intravenous catheter , venipuncture wound , or in association with burn , surgical wound , or occlusive dressing .
after candidiasis , aspergillosis be the second most common hospital - acquire fungal infection and often occur in immunocompromised patient , who be more vulnerable to opportunistic infection .
cutaneous aspergillosis be diagnose use patient history , culturing , histopathology use a skin biopsy .
treatment involve the use of antifungal medication such as voriconazole ( prefer for invasive aspergillosis ) , itraconazole , and amphotericin b if itraconazole be not effective .
for immunosuppressed individual or burn patient , medication may be use and surgical or immunotherapy treatment may be need .

sporotrichosis
whereas cutaneous mycose be superficial , subcutaneous mycose can spread from the skin to deep tissue .
in temperate region , the most common subcutaneous mycosis be a condition call sporotrichosis , cause by the fungus sporothrix schenkii and commonly know as rise gardener 's disease or rise thorn disease ( recall case in point 
every rose have - pron - thorn ) .
sporotrichosis be often contract after work with soil , plant , or timber , as the fungus can gain entry through a small wound such as a thorn - prick or splinter .
sporotrichosis can generally be avoid by wear glove and protective clothing while garden and promptly clean and disinfect any wound sustain during outdoor activity .
sporothrix infection initially present as small ulcer in the skin , but the fungus can spread to the lymphatic system and sometimes beyond .
when the infection spread , nodule appear , become necrotic , and may ulcerate .
as more lymph node become affect , abscess and ulceration may develop over a large area ( often on one arm or hand ) .
in severe case , the infection may spread more widely throughout the body , although this be relatively uncommon .
sporothrix infection can be diagnose base upon histologic examination of the affected tissue .

identify the major characteristic of specific parasitic disease affect the skin and eye many parasitic protozoan and helminth use the skin or eye as a portal of entry .
some may physically burrow into the skin or the mucosa of the eye  other breach the skin barrier by mean of an insect bite .
still other take advantage of a wound to bypass the skin barrier and enter the body , much like other opportunistic pathogen .
although many parasite enter the body through the skin , in this chapter - pron - will limit - pron - discussion to those for which the skin or eye be the primary site of infection .
parasite that enter through the skin but travel to a different site of infection will be cover in other chapter .
in addition , - pron - will limit - pron - discussion to microscopic parasitic infection of the skin and eye .
macroscopic parasite such as lice , scabie , mite , and tick be beyond the scope of this text .
acanthamoeba infections acanthamoeba be a genus of free - live protozoan amoebae that be common in soil and unchlorinated body of fresh water .
( this be one reason why some swimming pool be treat with chlorine . )
the genus contain a few parasitic specie , some of which can cause infection of the eye , skin , and nervous system .
such infection can sometimes travel and affect other body system .
skin infection may manifest as abscess , ulcer , and nodule .
when acanthamoebae infect the eye , cause inflammation of the cornea , the condition be call acanthamoeba keratitis .
figure two  one  .  three  four illustrate the acanthamoeba life cycle and various mode of infection .
while acanthamoeba keratitis be initially mild , - pron - can lead to severe corneal damage , vision impairment , or even blindness if leave untreated .
similar to eye infection involve p . aeruginosa , acanthamoeba pose a much great risk to wearer of contact lense because the amoeba can thrive in the space between contact lense and the cornea .
prevention through proper contact lens care be important .
lense should always be properly disinfect prior to use , and should never be wear while swim or use a hot tub .
acanthamoeba can also enter the body through other pathway , include skin wound and the respiratory tract .
- pron - usually do not cause disease except in immunocompromised individual  however , in rare case , the infection can spread to the nervous system , result in a usually fatal condition call granulomatous amoebic encephalitis ( gae ) ( see fungal and parasitic diseases of the nervous system ) .
disseminate infection , lesion , and acanthamoeba keratitis can be diagnose by observe symptom and examine patient sample under the microscope to view the parasite .
skin biopsy may be use .
acanthamoeba keratitis be difficult to treat , and prompt treatment be necessary to prevent the condition from progress .
the condition generally require three to four week of intensive treatment to resolve .
common treatment include topical antiseptic ( e . g . , polyhexamethylene biguanide , chlorhexidine , or both ) , sometimes with painkiller or corticosteroid ( although the latter be controversial because - pron - suppress the immune system , which can worsen the infection ) .
azole be sometimes prescribe as well .
advanced case of keratitis may require a corneal transplant to prevent blindness .

even in area in which loa loa worm be common , the disease be generally find in less than three  zero % of the population . [ one  seven ]
- pron - have be suggest that traveler who spend time in the region may be somewhat more susceptible to develop symptom than the native population , and the presentation of infection may differ . [ one  eight ]
the parasite be spread by deerflie ( genus chrysops ) , which can ingest the larvae from an infect human via a blood meal ( figure two  one  .  three  six ) .
when the deerfly bite other human , - pron - deposit the larvae into - pron - bloodstream .
after about five month in the human body , some larvae develop into adult worm , which can grow to several centimeter in length and live for year in the subcutaneous tissue of the host .
the name “ eye worm " allude to the visible migration of worm across the conjunctiva of the eye .
adult worm live in the subcutaneous tissue and can travel at about one cm per hour .
- pron - can often be observe when migrate through the eye , and sometimes under the skin  in fact , this be generally how the disease be diagnose .
- pron - be also possible to test for antibody , but the presence of antibody do not necessarily indicate a current infection  - pron - only mean that the individual be expose at some time .
some patient be asymptomatic , but in other the migrate worm can cause fever and area of allergic inflammation know as calabar swelling .
worm migrate through the conjunctiva can cause temporary eye pain and itching , but generally there be no lasting damage to the eye .
some patient experience a range of other symptom , such as widespread itching , hive , and joint and muscle pain .
worm can be surgically remove from the eye or the skin , but this treatment only relieve discomfort  - pron - do not cure the infection , which involve many worm .
the preferred treatment be diethylcarbamazine , but this medication produce severe side effect in some individual , such as brain inflammation and possible death in patient with heavy infection .
albendazole be also sometimes use if diethylcarbamazine be not appropriate or not successful .
if leave untreated for many year , loiasis can damage the kidney , heart , and lung , though these symptom be rare .

two  one  .  two bacterial infections of the skin and eyes

staphylococcus and streptococcus cause many different type of skin infection , many of which occur when bacteria breach the skin barrier through a cut or wound .
 s . aureus be frequently associate with purulent skin infection that manifest as folliculitis , furuncle , or carbuncle .
s . aureus be also a lead cause of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome ( ssss ) .
 s . aureus be generally drug resistant and current mrsa strain be resistant to a wide range of antibiotic .

community - acquire and hospital - acquire staphyloccocal infection be an ongoing problem because many people be asymptomatic carrier .

group a streptococci ( gas ) , s . pyogene , be often responsible for case of cellulitis , erysipela , and erythema nosodum .
gas be also one of many possible cause of necrotize fasciitis .
 p . aeruginosa be often responsible for infection of the skin and eye , include wound and burn infection , hot tub rash , otitis externa , and bacterial keratitis .

acne be a common skin condition that can become more inflammatory when propionibacterium acne infect hair follicle and pore clog with dead skin cell and sebum .

cutaneous anthrax occur when bacillus anthracis breach the skin barrier .
the infection result in a localize black eschar on skin .
anthrax can be fatal if b . anthracis spread to the bloodstream .

common bacterial conjunctivitis be often cause by haemophilus influenzae and usually resolve on - pron - own in a few day .
more serious form of conjunctiviti include gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum , inclusion conjunctivitis ( chlamydial ) , and trachoma , all of which can lead to blindness if untreated .

keratitis be frequently cause by staphylococcus epidermidis and / or pseudomonas aeruginosa , especially among contact lens user , and can lead to blindness .

biofilms complicate the treatment of wound and eye infection because pathogen live in biofilm can be difficult to treat and eliminate .
two  one  .  three viral infections of the skin and eyes
 papillomas ( wart ) be cause by human papillomaviruse .

herpes simplex virus ( especially hsv -  one ) mainly cause oral herpe , but lesion can appear on other area of the skin and mucous membrane .

roseola and fifth disease be common viral illness that cause skin rash  roseola be cause by hhv -  six and hhv -  seven while fifth disease be cause by parvovirus one  nine .
 viral conjunctivitis be often cause by adenovirus and may be associate with the common cold .
herpe keratitis be cause by herpesviruse that spread to the eye .
two  one  .  four mycose of the skin 
mycoses can be cutaneous , subcutaneous , or systemic .

common cutaneous mycose include tinea cause by dermatophyte of the genera trichophyton , epidermophyton , and microsporum .
tinea corporis be call ringworm .
tinea on other part of the body have name associate with the affect body part .

aspergillosis be a fungal disease cause by mold of the genus aspergillus .
primary cutaneous aspergillosis enter through a break in the skin , such as the site of an injury or a surgical wound  - pron - be a common hospitalacquire infection .
in secondary cutaneous aspergillosis , the fungus enter via the respiratory system and disseminate systemically , manifest in lesion on the skin .

the most common subcutaneous mycosis be sporotrichosis ( rise gardener 's disease ) , cause by sporothrix schenkii .

suspend within this volume of air be million of microbe of terrestrial , animal , and human origin - include many potential pathogen .
a few of these pathogen will cause relatively mild infection like sore throat and cold .
other , however , be less benign .
accord to the world health organization , respiratory tract infection such as tuberculosis , influenza , and pneumonia be responsible for more than four million death worldwide in two  zero  one  two  . [ one ]
at one time , - pron - be think that antimicrobial drug and preventive vaccine may hold respiratory infection in check in the develop world , but recent development suggest otherwise .
the rise of multiple - antibiotic resistance in organism like mycobacterium tuberculosis have render many of - pron - modern drug ineffective .
in addition , there have be a recent resurgence in disease like whooping cough and measle , once - common childhood illness make rare by effective vaccine .
despite advance in medicine and public health program , - pron - be likely that respiratory pathogen will remain formidable adversary for the foreseeable future .
