general causes and modes of transmission of urogenital infections hormonal change , particularly shift in estrogen in woman due to pregnancy or menopause , can increase susceptibility to urogenital infection .
as discuss earlier , estrogen play an important role in regulate the availability of glycogen and subsequent production of lactic acid by lactobacillus specie .
low level of estrogen be associate with an increased vaginal ph and an increase risk of bacterial vaginosis and yeast infection .
estrogen also play a role in maintain the elasticity , strength , and thickness of the vaginal wall , and keep the vaginal wall lubricate , reduce dryness .
low level of estrogen be associate with thinning of the vaginal wall .
this thinning increase the risk of tear and abrasion , which compromise the protective barrier and increase susceptibility to pathogen .
another common cause of urogenital infection in female be fecal contamination that occur because of the close proximity of the anus and the urethra .
escherichia coli , an important member of the digestive tract microbiota , be the most common cause of urinary tract infection ( urethritis and cystitis ) in woman  - pron - generally cause infection when - pron - be introduce to the urethra in fecal matter .
good hygiene can reduce the risk of urinary tract infection by this route .
in man , urinary tract infection be more commonly associate with other condition , such as an enlarged prostate , kidney stone , or placement of a urinary catheter .
all of these condition impair the normal emptying of the bladder , which serve to flush out microbe capable of cause infection .
infection that be transmit between individual through sexual contact be call sexually transmit infection ( sti ) or sexually transmit disease ( std ) .
( the cdc prefer the term std , but who prefer sti , [ one ] which encompass infection that result in disease as well as those that be subclinical or asymptomatic . )
sti often affect the external genitalia and skin , where microbe be easily transfer through physical contact .
lymph node in the genital region may also become swollen as a result of infection .
however , many sti have systemic effect as well , cause symptom that range from mild ( e . g . , general malaise ) to severe ( e . g . , liver damage or serious immunosuppression ) .

cystitis cystitis be most often cause by a bacterial infection of the bladder , but - pron - can also occur as a reaction to certain treatment or irritant such as radiation treatment , hygiene spray , or spermicide .
common symptom of cystitis include dysuria ( urination accompany by burn , discomfort , or pain ) , pyuria ( pu in the urine ) , hematuria ( blood in the urine ) , and bladder pain .
in woman , bladder infection be more common because the urethra be short and locate in close proximity to the anus , which can result in infection of the urinary tract by fecal bacteria .
bladder infection be also more common in the elderly because the bladder may not empty fully , cause urine to pool  the elderly may also have weak immune system that make - pron - more vulnerable to infection .
condition such as prostatitis in man or kidney stone in both man and woman can impact proper drainage of urine and increase risk of bladder infection .
catheterization can also increase the risk of bladder infection ( see case in point 
cystitis in the elderly ) .
gram - negative bacteria such as escherichia coli ( most commonly ) , proteus vulgaris , pseudomonas aeruginosa , and klebsiella pneumoniae cause most bladder infection .
gram - positive pathogen associate with cystitis include the coagulase - negative staphylococcus saprophyticus , enterococcus faecalis , and streptococcus agalactiae .
routine manual urinalysis use a urine dipstick or test strip can be use for rapid screening of infection .
these test strip ( figure two  three  .  five ) be either hold in a urine stream or dip in a sample of urine to test for the presence of nitrite , leukocyte esterase , protein , or blood that can indicate an active bacterial infection .
the presence of nitrite may indicate the presence of e . coli or k . pneumonia  these bacteria produce nitrate reductase , which convert nitrate to nitrite .
the leukocyte esterase ( le ) test detect the presence of neutrophil as an indication of active infection .
low specificity , sensitivity , or both , associate with these rapid screening test require that care be take in interpretation of result and in - pron - use in diagnosis of urinary tract infection .
therefore , positive le or nitrite result be follow by a urine culture to confirm a bladder infection .
urine culture be generally accomplish use blood agar and macconkey agar , and - pron - be important to culture a clean catch of urine to minimize contamination with normal microbiota of the penis and vagina .
a clean catch of urine be accomplish by first wash the labia and urethral opening of female patient or the penis of male patient .
the patient then release a small amount of urine into the toilet bowl before stop the flow of urine .
finally , the patient resume urination , this time fill the container use to collect the specimen .
bacterial cystitis be commonly treat with fluoroquinolone , nitrofurantoin , cephalosporin , or a combination of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole .
pain medication may provide relief for patient with dysuria .
treatment be more difficult in elderly patient , who experience a high rate of complication such as sepsis and kidney infection .

this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five kidney infections ( pyelonephritis and glomerulonephritis ) pyelonephritis , an inflammation of the kidney , can be cause by bacteria that have spread from other part of the urinary tract ( such as the bladder ) .
in addition , pyelonephritis can develop from bacteria that travel through the bloodstream to the kidney .
when the infection spread from the low urinary tract , the causative agent be typically fecal bacteria such as e . coli .
common sign and symptom include back pain ( due to the location of the kidney ) , fever , and nausea or vomiting .
gross hematuria ( visible blood in the urine ) occur in three  zero – four  zero % of woman but be rare in men . [ two ]
the infection can become serious , potentially lead to bacteremia and systemic effect that can become life - threaten .
scar of the kidney can occur and persist after the infection have clear , which may lead to dysfunction .
diagnosis of pyelonephritis be make use microscopic examination of urine , culture of urine , test for leukocyte esterase and nitrite level , and examination of the urine for blood or protein .
- pron - be also important to use blood culture to evaluate the spread of the pathogen into the bloodstream .
image of the kidney may be perform in highrisk patient with diabetes or immunosuppression , the elderly , patient with previous renal damage , or to rule out an obstruction in the kidney .
pyelonephritis can be treat with either oral or intravenous antibiotic , include penicillin , cephalosporin , vancomycin , fluoroquinolone , carbapenem , and aminoglycosides .
glomerulonephritis occur when the glomeruli of the nephron be damage from inflammation .
whereas pyelonephritis be usually acute , glomerulonephritis may be acute or chronic .
the most well - characterize mechanism of glomerulonephritis be the post - streptococcal sequelae associate with streptococcus pyogene throat and skin infection .
although s . pyogene do not directly infect the glomeruli of the kidney , immune complex that form in blood between s . pyogene antigen and antibody lodge in the capillary endothelial cell junction of the glomeruli and trigger a damaging inflammatory response .
glomerulonephritis can also occur in patient with bacterial endocarditis ( infection and inflammation of heart tissue )  however , - pron - be currently unknown whether glomerulonephritis associate with endocarditis be also immune - mediate .
leptospirosis leptospira be generally harmless spirochete that be commonly find in the soil .
however , some pathogenic specie can cause an infection call leptospirosis in the kidney and other organ ( figure two  three  .  six ) .
leptospirosis can produce fever , headache , chill , vomiting , diarrhea , and rash with severe muscular pain .
if the disease continue to progress , infection of the kidney , meninge , or liver may occur and may lead to organ failure or meningitis .
when the kidney and liver become seriously infected , - pron - be call weil 's disease .
pulmonary hemorrhagic syndrome can also develop in the lung , and jaundice may occur .
leptospira spp .
be find widely in animal such as dog , horse , cattle , pig , and rodent , and be excrete in - pron - urine .
human generally become infect by come in contact with contaminated soil or water , often while swim or during flooding  infection can also occur through contact with body fluid contain the bacteria .
the bacteria may enter the body through mucous membrane , skin injury , or by ingestion .
the mechanism of pathogenicity be not well understand .
leptospirosis be extremely rare in the united states , although - pron - be endemic in hawaii  five  zero % of all case in the united states come from hawaii . [ three ]
- pron - be more common in tropical than in temperate climate , and individual who work with animal or animal product be most at risk .
the bacteria can also be cultivate in specialized medium , with growth observe in broth in a few day to four week  however , diagnosis of leptospirosis be generally make use fast method , such as detection of antibody to leptospira spp .
in patient sample use serologic testing .
polymerase chain reaction ( pcr ) , enzyme - link immunosorbent assay ( elisa ) , slide agglutination , and indirect immunofluorescence test may all be use for diagnosis .
treatment for leptospirosis involve broad - spectrum antibiotic such as penicillin and doxycycline .
for more serious case of leptospirosis , antibiotic may be give intravenously .

nongonococcal urethritis ( ngu )
there be two main category of bacterial urethritis  gonorrheal and nongonococcal .
gonorrheal urethritis be cause by neisseria gonorrhoeae and be associate with gonorrhea , a common sti .
this cause of urethritis will be discuss in bacterial infections of the reproductive system .
the term nongonococcal urethritis ( ngu ) refer to inflammation of the urethra that be unrelated to n . gonorrhoeae .
in woman , ngu be often asymptomatic .
in man , ngu be typically a mild disease , but can lead to purulent discharge and dysuria .
because the symptom be often mild or nonexistent , most infected individual do not know that - pron - be infect , yet - pron - be carrier of the disease .
asymptomatic patient also have no reason to seek treatment , and although not common , untreated ngu can spread to the reproductive organ , cause pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis in woman and epididymitis and prostatitis in man .
important bacterial pathogen that cause nongonococcal urethritis include chlamydia trachomatis , mycoplasma genitalium , ureaplasma urealyticum , and mycoplasma homini .
c . trachomatis be a difficult - to - stain , gram - negative bacterium with an ovoid shape .
an intracellular pathogen , c . trachomatis cause the most frequently report sti in the united states , chlamydia .
although most person infect with c . trachomatis be asymptomatic , some patient can present with ngu .
c . trachomatis can also cause nonurogenital infection such as the ocular disease trachoma ( see bacterial infections of the skin and eyes ) .

bacterial vaginitis and vaginosis inflammation of the vagina be call vaginitis , often cause by a bacterial infection .
- pron - be also possible to have an imbalance in the normal vaginal microbiota without inflammation call bacterial vaginosis ( bv ) .
vaginosis may be asymptomatic or may cause mild symptom such as a thin , white - to - yellow , homogeneous vaginal discharge , burning , odor , and itch .
the major causative agent be gardnerella vaginalis , a gram - variable to gram - negative pleomorphic bacterium .
other causative agent include anaerobic specie such as member of the genera bacteroides and fusobacterium .
additionally , ureaplasma and mycoplasma may be involve .
the disease be usually self - limit , although antibiotic treatment be recommend if symptom develop .
g . vaginalis appear to be more virulent than other vaginal bacterial specie potentially associate with bv .
like lactobacillus spp .
, g . vaginalis be part of the normal vaginal microbiota , but when the population of lactobacillus spp . decrease and the vaginal ph increase , g . vaginalis flourish , cause vaginosis by attach to vaginal epithelial cell and form a thick protective biofilm .
g . vaginalis also produce a cytotoxin call vaginolysin that lyse vaginal epithelial cell and red blood cell .
since g . vaginalis can also be isolate from healthy woman , the “ gold standard " for the diagnosis of bv be direct examination of vaginal secretion and not the culture of g . vaginalis .
diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis from vaginal secretion can be accurately make in three way .
the first be to use a dna probe .
the second method be to assay for sialidase activity ( sialidase be an enzyme produce by g . vaginalis and other bacteria associate with vaginosis , include bacteroides spp .
, prevotella spp . , and mobiluncus spp . ) .
the third method be to assess gram - stain vaginal smear for microscopic morphology and relative number and type of bacteria , squamous epithelial cell , and leukocyte .
by examine slide prepare from vaginal swab , - pron - be possible to distinguish lactobacilli ( long , grampositive rod ) from other gram - negative specie responsible for bv .
a shift in predominance from gram - positive bacilli to gram - negative coccobacilli can indicate bv .
additionally , the slide may contain so - call clue cell , which be epithelial cell that appear to have a granular or stippled appearance due to bacterial cell attach to - pron - surface ( figure two  three  .  nine ) .
presumptive diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis can involve an assessment of clinical symptom and evaluation of vaginal fluid use amsel 's diagnostic criterion which include three out of four of the follow characteristic  one . white to yellow discharge  two .
a fishy odor , most noticeable when one  zero % koh be add  three .

the presence of clue cell .
treatment be often unnecessary because the infection often clear on - pron - own .
however , in some case , antibiotic such as topical or oral clindamycin or metronidazole may be prescribe .
alternative treatment include oral tinidazole or clindamycin ovule ( vaginal suppository ) .

gonorrhea also know as the clap , gonorrhea be a common sexually transmit disease of the reproductive system that be especially prevalent in individual between the age of one  five and two  four .
- pron - be cause by neisseria gonorrhoeae , often call gonococcus or gc , which have fimbriae that allow the cell to attach to epithelial cell .
- pron - also have a type of lipopolysaccharide endotoxin call lipooligosaccharide as part of the outer membrane structure that enhance - pron - pathogenicity .
in addition to cause urethritis , n . gonorrhoeae can infect other body tissue such as the skin , meninge , pharynx , and conjunctiva .
many infect individual ( both man and woman ) be asymptomatic carrier of gonorrhea .
when symptom do occur , - pron - manifest differently in male and female .
male may develop pain and burn during urination and discharge from the penis that may be yellow , green , or white ( figure two  three  .  one  zero ) .
less commonly , the testicle may become swollen or tender .
over time , these symptom can increase and spread .
in some case , chronic infection develop .
the disease can also develop in the rectum , cause symptom such as discharge , soreness , bleeding , itching , and pain ( especially in association with bowel movement ) .

when a gonorrhea infection disseminate throughout the body , serious complication can develop .
the infection may spread through the blood ( bacteremia ) and affect organ throughout the body , include the heart ( gonorrheal endocarditis ) , joint ( gonorrheal arthritis ) , and meninge encase the brain ( meningitis ) .

antibiotic resistance in neisseria antibiotic resistance in many pathogen be steadily increase , cause serious concern throughout the public health community .
increase resistance have be especially notable in some specie , such as neisseria gonorrhoeae .
the cdc monitor the spread of antibiotic resistance in n . gonorrhoeae , which - pron - classify as an urgent threat , and make recommendation for treatment .
so far , n . gonorrhoeae have show resistance to cefixime ( a cephalosporin ) , ceftriaxone ( another cephalosporin ) , azithromycin , and tetracycline .
resistance to tetracycline be the most common , and be see in one  eight  eight  ,  six  zero  zero case of gonorrhea in two  zero  one  one ( out of a total eight  two  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero case ) .

these resistance gene be spread by plasmid , and a single bacterium may be resistant to multiple antibiotic .
the cdc currently recommend treatment with two medication , ceftriaxone and azithromycin , to attempt to slow the spread of resistance .
if resistance to cephalosporin increase , - pron - will be extremely difficult to control the spread of n . gonorrhoeae .
chlamydia chlamydia trachomatis be the causative agent of the sti chlamydia ( figure two  three  .  one  one ) .
while many chlamydia infection be asymptomatic , chlamydia be a major cause of nongonococcal urethritis ( ngu ) and may also cause epididymitis and orchitis in man .
in woman , chlamydia infection can cause urethritis , salpingitis , and pid .
in addition , chlamydial infection may be associate with an increase risk of cervical cancer .
because chlamydia be widespread , often asymptomatic , and have the potential to cause substantial complication , routine screening be recommend for sexually active woman who be under age two  five , at high risk ( i . e . , not in a monogamous relationship ) , or begin prenatal care .

syphilis syphilis be spread through direct physical ( generally sexual ) contact , and be cause by the gram - negative spirochete treponema pallidum .
t . pallidum have a relatively simple genome and lack lipopolysaccharide endotoxin characteristic of gram - negative bacteria .
however , - pron - do contain lipoprotein that trigger an immune response in the host , cause tissue damage that may enhance the pathogen 's ability to disseminate while evade the host immune system .
after enter the body , t . pallidum move rapidly into the bloodstream and other tissue .
if not treat effectively , syphilis progress through three distinct stage  primary , secondary , and tertiary .
primary syphilis appear as a single lesion on the cervix , penis , or anus within one  zero to nine  zero day of transmission .
such lesion contain many t . pallidum cell and be highly infectious .
the lesion , call a hard chancre , be initially hard and painless , but - pron - soon develop into an ulcerated sore ( figure two  three  .  one  two ) .
localize lymph node swell may occur as well .
in some case , these symptom may be relatively mild , and the lesion may heal on - pron - own within two to six week .
because the lesion be painless and often occur in hide location ( e . g . , the cervix or anus ) , infected individual sometimes do not notice - pron - .
the secondary stage generally develop once the primary chancre have heal or begin to heal .
secondary syphilis be characterize by a rash that affect the skin and mucous membrane of the mouth , vagina , or anus .
the rash often begin on the palm or the sol of the foot and spread to the trunk and the limb ( figure two  three  .  one  two ) .
the rash may take many form , such as macular or papular .
on mucous membrane , - pron - may manifest as mucus patch or white , wartlike lesion call condylomata lata .
the rash may be accompany by malaise , fever , and swelling of
lymph chapter two  three  urogenital system infections one  zero  two  seven node .
individual be highly contagious in the secondary stage , which last two to six week and be recurrent in about two  five % of case .
after the secondary phase , syphilis can enter a latent phase , in which there be no symptom but microbial level remain high .
blood test can still detect the disease during latency .
the latent phase can persist for year .
tertiary syphilis , which may occur one  zero to two  zero year after infection , produce the most severe symptom and can be fatal .
granulomatous lesion call gumma may develop in a variety of location , include mucous membrane , bone , and internal organ ( figure two  three  .  one  two ) .
gummas can be large and destructive , potentially cause massive tissue damage .
the most deadly lesion be those of the cardiovascular system ( cardiovascular syphilis ) and the central nervous system ( neurosyphilis ) .
cardiovascular syphilis can result in a fatal aortic aneurysm ( rupture of the aorta ) or coronary stenosis ( a blockage of the coronary artery ) .
damage to the central nervous system can cause dementia , personality change , seizure , general paralysis , speech impairment , loss of vision and hearing , and loss of bowel and bladder control .

the recommend method for diagnose early syphili be darkfield or brightfield ( silver stain ) microscopy of tissue or exudate from lesion to detect t . pallidum ( figure two  three  .  one  three ) .
if these method be not available , two type of serologic test ( treponemal and nontreponemal ) can be use for a presumptive diagnosis once the spirochete have spread in the body .
nontreponemal serologic test include the venereal disease research laboratory ( vdrl ) and rapid plasma reagin ( rpr ) test .
these be similar screening test that detect nonspecific antibody ( those for lipid antigen produce during infection ) rather than those produce against the spirochete .
treponemal serologic test measure antibody direct against t . pallidum antigen use particle agglutination ( t . pallidum passive particle agglutination or tp - pa ) , immunofluorescence ( the fluorescent t . pallidum antibody absorption or fta - abs ) , various enzyme reaction ( enzyme immunoassay or eia ) and chemiluminescence immunoassay ( cia ) .
confirmatory testing , rather than screening , must be do use treponemal rather than nontreponemal test because only the former test for antibody to spirochete antigen .
both treponemal and nontreponemal test should be use ( as oppose to just one ) since both test have limitation than can result in false positive or false negative .
neurosyphilis can not be diagnose use a single test .
with or without clinical sign , - pron - be generally necessary to assess a variety of factor , include reactive serologic test result , cerebrospinal fluid cell count abnormality , cerebrospinal fluid protein abnormality , or reactive vdrl - csf ( the vdrl test of cerebrospinal fluid ) .
the vdrlcsf be highly specific , but not sufficiently sensitive for conclusive diagnosis .
the recommend treatment for syphilis be parenteral penicillin g ( especially long - act benzathine penicillin , although the exact choice depend on the stage of disease ) .
other option include tetracycline and doxycycline .

genital herpes genital herpe be a common condition cause by the herpe simplex virus ( figure two  three  .  one  six ) , an envelop , doublestranded dna virus that be classify into two distinct type .

this occur more commonly with hsv -  two than with hsv -  one  . [ one  one ]
the virus move down peripheral nerve , typically sensory neuron , to ganglia in the spine ( either the trigeminal ganglion or the lumbar - sacral ganglia ) and become latent .
reactivation can later occur , cause the formation of new vesicle .
hsv -  two most effectively reactivate from the lumbar - sacral ganglia .
not everyone infect with hsv -  two experience reactivation , which be typically associate with stressful condition , and the frequency of reactivation vary throughout life and among individual .
between outbreak or when there be no obvious vesicle , the virus can still be transmit .
virologic and serologic technique be use for diagnosis .
the virus may be culture from lesion .
the immunostaining method that be use to detect virus from culture generally require less expertise than method base on cytopathic effect ( cpe ) , as well as be a less expensive option .
however , pcr or other dna amplification method may be prefer because - pron - provide the most rapid result without wait for culture amplification .
pcr be also good for detect systemic infection .
serologic technique be also useful in some circumstance , such as when symptom persist but pcr testing be negative .
while there be no cure or vaccine for hsv -  two infection , antiviral medication be available that manage the infection by keep the virus in - pron - dormant or latent phase , reduce sign and symptom .
if the medication be discontinue , then the condition return to - pron - original severity .
the recommend medication , which may be take at the start of an outbreak or daily as a method of prophylaxis , be acyclovir , famciclovir , and valacyclovir .
neonatal herpes herpes infection in newborn , refer to as neonatal herpe , be generally transmit from the mother to the neonate during childbirth , when the child be expose to pathogen in the birth canal .
infection can occur regardless of whether lesion be present in the birth canal .
in most case , the infection of the newborn be limit to skin , mucous membrane , and eye , and outcome be good .
however , sometimes the virus become disseminate and spread to the central nervous system , result in motor function deficit or death .
in some case , infection can occur before birth when the virus cross the placenta .
this can cause serious complication in fetal development and may result in spontaneous abortion or severe disability if the fetus survive .
the condition be most serious when the mother be infect with hsv for the first time during pregnancy .

human papillomas warts of all type be cause by a variety of strain of human papillomavirus ( hpv ) ( see viral infections of the skin and eyes ) .
condylomata acuminata , more commonly call genital wart or venereal wart ( figure two  three  .  one  eight ) , be an extremely prevalent sti cause by certain strain of hpv .
condylomata be irregular , soft , pink growth that be find on external genitalia or the anus .
hpv be a small , non - enveloped virus with a circular double - strand dna genome .
researcher have identify over two  zero  zero different strain ( call type ) of hpv , with approximately four  zero causing sti .
while some type of hpv cause genital wart , hpv infection be often asymptomatic and self - limit .
however , genital hpv infection often co - occur with other sti like syphilis or gonorrhea .
additionally , some form of hpv ( not the same one associate with genital wart ) be associate with cervical cancer .
at least one  four oncogenic ( cancer - cause )
hpv type be know to have a causal association with cervical cancer .
example of oncogenic hpv be type one  six and one  eight , which be associate with seven  zero % of cervical cancers . [ one  two ]
oncogenic hpv type can also cause oropharyngeal cancer , anal cancer , vaginal cancer , vulvar cancer , and penile cancer .
most of these cancer be cause by hpv type one  six .
hpv virulence factor include protein ( e six and e seven ) that be capable of inactivate tumor suppressor protein , lead to uncontrolled cell division and the development of cancer .
hpv can not be culture , so molecular test be the primary method use to detect hpv .
while routine hpv screening be not recommend for man , - pron - be include in guideline for woman .
an initial screening for hpv at age three  zero , conduct at the same time as a pap test , be recommend .
if the test be negative , then further hpv testing be recommend every five year .
more frequent testing may be need in some case .
the protocol use to collect , transport , and store sample vary base on both the type of hpv testing and the purpose of the testing .
this should be determine in individual case in consultation with the laboratory that will perform the testing .
because hpv testing be often conduct concurrently with pap testing , the most common approach use a single sample collection within one vial for both .
this approach use liquid - base cytology ( lbc ) .
the sample be then use for pap smear cytology as well as hpv testing and genotyping .
hpv can be recognize in pap smear by the presence of cell call koilocyte ( call koilocytosis or koilocytotic atypia ) .
koilocyte have a hyperchromatic atypical nucleus that stain darkly and a high ratio of nuclear material to cytoplasm .
there be a distinct clear appearance around the nucleus call a perinuclear halo ( figure two  three  .  one  nine ) .

 summarize the important characteristic of vaginal candidiasis only one major fungal pathogen affect the urogenital system .
candida be a genus of fungi capable of exist in a yeast form or as a multicellular fungus .
candida spp . be commonly find in the normal , healthy microbiota of the skin , gastrointestinal tract , respiratory system , and female urogenital tract ( figure two  three  .  two  one ) .
- pron - can be pathogenic due to - pron - ability to adhere to and invade host cell , form biofilm , secrete hydrolase ( e . g . , protease , phospholipase , and lipase ) that assist in - pron - spread through tissue , and change - pron - phenotype to protect - pron - from the immune system .
however , - pron - typically only cause disease in the female reproductive tract under condition that compromise the host 's defense .
while there be at least two  zero candida specie of clinical importance , c . albican be the specie most commonly responsible for fungal vaginitis .

as discuss earlier , lactobacilli in the vagina inhibit the growth of other organism , include bacteria and candida , but disruption can allow candida to increase in number .
typical disruption include antibiotic therapy , illness ( especially diabetes ) , pregnancy , and the presence of transient microbe .
immunosuppression can also play a role , and the severe immunosuppression associate with hiv infection often allow candida to thrive .
this can cause genital or vaginal candidiasis , a condition characterize by vaginitis and commonly know as a yeast infection .
when a yeast infection develop , inflammation occur along with symptom of pruritus ( itching ) , a thick white or yellow discharge , and odor .
other form of candidiasis include cutaneous candidiasis ( see mycose of the skin ) and oral thrush ( see microbial diseases of the mouth and oral cavity ) .
although candida spp . be find in the normal microbiota , candida spp .
may also be transmit between individual .
sexual contact be a common mode of transmission , although candidiasis be not consider an sti .
diagnosis of vaginal candidiasis can be make use microscopic evaluation of vaginal secretion to determine whether there be an excess of candida .
culturing approach be less useful because candida be part of the normal microbiota and will regularly appear .
- pron - be also easy to contaminate sample with candida because - pron - be so common , so care must be take to handle clinical material appropriately .
sample can be refrigerate if there be a delay in handling .
candida be a dimorphic fungus , so - pron - do not only exist in a yeast form  cultivation can be use to identify chlamydospore and pseudohyphae , which develop from germ tube ( figure two  three  .  two  two ) .
the presence of the germ tube can be use in a diagnostic test in which culture yeast cell be combine with rabbit serum and observe after a few hour for the presence of germ tube .
molecular test be also available if need .
the affirm vpii microbial identification test , for instance , test simultaneously for the vaginal microbe c . albican , g . vaginalis ( see bacterial infections of the urinary system ) , and trichomonas vaginalis ( see protozoan infections of the urogenital system ) .
topical antifungal medication for vaginal candidiasis include butoconazole , miconazole , clotrimazole , tioconazole , and nystatin .
oral treatment with fluconazole can be use .
there be often no clear precipitating factor for infection , so prevention be difficult .

 identify the most common protozoan pathogen that cause infection of the reproductive system  summarize the important characteristic of trichomoniasis only one major protozoan specie cause infection in the urogenital system .
trichomoniasis , or “ trich
, " be the most common nonviral sti and be cause by a flagellate protozoan trichomonas vaginalis .
t . vaginalis have an undulating membrane and , generally , an amoeboid shape when attach to cell in the vagina .
in culture , - pron - have an oval shape .
t . vaginalis be commonly find in the normal microbiota of the vagina .
as with other vaginal pathogen , - pron - can cause vaginitis when there be disruption to the normal microbiota .
- pron - be find only as a trophozoite and do not form cyst .
t . vaginalis can adhere to cell use adhesin such as lipoglycan  - pron - also have other cell - surface virulence factor , include tetraspanin that be involve in cell adhesion , motility , and tissue invasion .
in addition , t . vaginalis be capable of phagocytose other microbe of the normal microbiota , contribute to the development of an imbalance that be favorable to infection .
both man and woman can develop trichomoniasis .
man be generally asymptomatic , and although woman be more likely to develop symptom , - pron - be often asymptomatic as well .
when symptom do occur , - pron - be characteristic of urethritis .
man experience itching , irritation , discharge from the penis , and burn after urination or ejaculation .
woman experience dysuria  itch , burning , redness , and soreness of the genitalia  and vaginal discharge .
the infection may also spread to the cervix .
infection increase the risk of transmit or acquire hiv and be associate with pregnancy complication such as preterm birth .
microscopic evaluation of wet mount be an inexpensive and convenient method of diagnosis , but the sensitivity of this method be low ( figure two  three  .  two  four ) .
nucleic acid amplification testing ( naat ) be prefer due to - pron - high sensitivity .
use wet mount and then naat for those who initially test negative be one option to improve sensitivity .

summary two  three  .  one anatomy and normal microbiota of the urogenital tract

the urinary system be responsible for filter the blood , excrete waste , and help to regulate electrolyte and water balance .

the urinary system include the kidney , ureter , urinary bladder , and urethra  the bladder and urethra be the most common site of infection .

common site of infection in the male reproductive system include the urethra , as well as the testis , prostate and epididymis .

the most common site of infection in the female reproductive system be the vulva , vagina , cervix , and link to learn chapter two  three

urogenital system infections one  zero  four  three fallopian tube .

infections of the urogenital tract can occur through colonization from the external environment , alteration in microbiota due to hormonal or other physiological and environmental change , fecal contamination , and sexual transmission ( sti ) .
two  three  .  two bacterial infections of the urinary system 
bacterial cystitis be commonly cause by fecal bacteria such as e . coli .

pyelonephritis be a serious kidney infection that be often cause by bacteria that travel from infection elsewhere in the urinary tract and may cause systemic complication .

leptospirosis be a bacterial infection of the kidney that can be transmit by exposure to infect animal urine , especially in contaminated water .
- pron - be more common in tropical than in temperate climate .

nongonococcal urethritis ( ngu ) be commonly cause by c . trachomatis , m . genitalium , ureaplasma urealyticum , and m . homini .

diagnosis and treatment for bacterial urinary tract infection varie .
urinalysis ( e . g . , for leukocyte esterase level , nitrite level , microscopic evaluation , and culture of urine ) be an important component in most case .
broad - spectrum antibiotic be typically use .
two  three  .  three bacterial infections of the reproductive system

bacterial vaginosis be cause by an imbalance in the vaginal microbiota , with a decrease in lactobacilli and an increase in vaginal ph . g . vaginalis be the most common cause of bacterial vaginosis , which be associate with vaginal discharge , odor , burning , and itch .

gonorrhea be cause by n . gonorrhoeae , which can cause infection of the reproductive and urinary tract and be associate with symptom of urethritis .
if leave untreated , - pron - can progress to epididymitis , salpingitis , and pelvic inflammatory disease and enter the bloodstream to infect other site in the body .

chlamydia be the most commonly report sti and be cause by c . trachomatis .
most infection be asymptomatic , and infection that be not treat can spread to involve the epididymis of man and cause salpingitis and pelvic inflammatory disease in woman .

syphilis be cause by t . pallidum and have three stage , primary , secondary , and tertiary .
primary syphilis be associate with a painless hard chancre lesion on genitalia .
secondary syphilis be associate with skin and mucous membrane lesion .
tertiary syphilis be the most serious and life - threaten , and can involve serious nervous system damage .

chancroid be an infection of the reproductive tract cause by h . ducreyi that result in the development of characteristic soft chancre .
two  three  .  four viral infections of the reproductive system
 genital herpe be usually cause by hsv -  two ( although hsv -  one can also be responsible ) and may cause the development of infectious , potentially recurrent vesicle  neonatal herpe can occur in baby bear to infect mother and can cause symptom that range from relatively mild ( more common ) to severe .

human papillomaviruse be the most common sexually transmit virus and include strain that cause genital wart as well as strain that cause cervical cancer .
two  three  .  five fungal infections of the reproductive system 
candida spp . be typically present in the normal microbiota in the body , include the skin , respiratory tract , gastrointestinal tract , and female urogenital system .

disruption in the normal vaginal microbiota can lead to an overgrowth of candida , cause vaginal candidiasis .
 vaginal candidiasis can be treat with topical or oral fungicide .
prevention be difficult .

two  four  .  six helminthic infections of the gastrointestinal tract introduction gastrointestinal ( gi ) disease be so common that , unfortunately , most people have have first - hand experience with the unpleasant symptom , such as diarrhea , vomiting , and abdominal discomfort .
the cause of gastrointestinal illness can vary widely , but such disease can be group into two category  those cause by infection ( the growth of a pathogen in the gi tract ) or intoxication ( the presence of a microbial toxin in the gi tract ) .
foodborne pathogen like escherichia coli o one  five  seven  h seven be among the most common source of gastrointestinal disease .
contaminate food and water have always pose a health risk for human , but in today 's global economy , outbreak can occur on a much large scale .
e . coli o one  five  seven  h seven be a potentially deadly strain of e . coli with a history of contaminate meat and produce that be not properly process .
the source of an e . coli o one  five  seven  h seven outbreak can be difficult to trace , especially if the contaminate food be process in a foreign country .
once the source be identify , authority may issue recall of the contaminate food product , but by then there be typically numerous case of food poisoning , some of - pron - fatal .

two  four  .  one anatomy and normal microbiota of
the digestive system learning objectives
 describe the major anatomical feature of the human digestive system

explain how microorganism overcome the defense of the digestive tract to cause infection or intoxication 
describe general sign and symptom associate with infection of the digestive system the human digestive system , or the gastrointestinal ( gi ) tract , begin with the mouth and end with the anus .
the part of the mouth include the tooth , the gum , the tongue , the oral vestibule ( the space between the gum , lip , and tooth ) , and the oral cavity proper ( the space behind the tooth and gum ) .
other part of the gi tract be the pharynx , esophagus , stomach , small intestine , large intestine , rectum , and anus ( figure two  four  .  two ) .
accessory digestive organ include the salivary gland , liver , gallbladder , spleen , and pancrea .
the digestive system contain normal microbiota , include archaea , bacteria , fungus , protist , and even virus .

anatomy and normal microbiota of the gi tract
as food leave the oral cavity , - pron - travel through the pharynx , or the back of the throat , and move into the esophagus , which carry the food from the pharynx to the stomach without add any additional digestive enzyme .
the stomach produce mucus to protect - pron - lining , as well as digestive enzyme and acid to break down food .
partially digested food then leave the stomach through the pyloric sphincter , reach the first part of the small intestine call the duodenum .
pancreatic juice , which include enzyme and bicarbonate ion , be release into the small intestine to neutralize the acidic material from the stomach and to assist in digestion .
bile , produce by the liver but store in the gallbladder , be also release into the small intestine to emulsify fat so that - pron - can travel in the watery environment of the small intestine .
digestion continue in the small intestine , where the majority of nutrient contain in the food be absorb .
simple columnar epithelial cell call enterocyte line the lumen surface of the small intestinal fold call villi .
each enterocyte have small microvilli ( cytoplasmic membrane extension ) on the cellular apical surface that increase the surface area to allow more absorption of nutrient to occur ( figure two  four  .  five ) .

digest food leave the small intestine and move into the large intestine , or colon , where there be a more diverse microbiota .
near this junction , there be a small pouch in the large intestine call the cecum , which attach to the appendix .
further digestion occur throughout the colon and water be reabsorb , then waste be excrete through the rectum , the last section of the colon , and out of the body through the anus ( figure two  four  .  two ) .
the environment of most of the gi tract be harsh , which serve two purpose  digestion and immunity .
the stomach be an extremely acidic environment ( ph one  .  five – three  .  five ) due to the gastric juice that break down food and kill many ingested microbe  this help prevent infection from pathogen .
the environment in the small intestine be less harsh and be able to support microbial community .
microorganism present in the small intestine can include lactobacilli , diptherioid and the fungus candida .
on the other hand , the large intestine ( colon ) contain a diverse and abundant microbiota that be important for normal function .
these microbe include bacteriodetes ( especially the genera bacteroides and prevotella ) and firmicutes ( especially member of the genus clostridium ) .
methanogenic archaea and some fungi be also present , among many other specie of bacteria .
these microbe all aid in digestion and contribute to the production of fece , the waste excrete from the digestive tract , and flatus , the gas produce from microbial fermentation of undigested food .
- pron - can also produce valuable nutrient .
for example , lactic acid bacteria such as one  zero  five  four chapter two  four  digestive system infections
this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five bifidobacteria can synthesize vitamin , such as vitamin b one  two , folate , and riboflavin , that human can not synthesize - pron - .
e . coli find in the intestine can also break down food and help the body produce vitamin k , which be important for blood coagulation .
the gi tract have several other method of reduce the risk of infection by pathogen .
small aggregate of underlying lymphoid tissue in the ileum , call peyer 's patch ( figure two  four  .  five ) , detect pathogen in the intestine via microfold ( m ) cell , which transfer antigen from the luman of the intestine to the lymphocyte on peyer 's patch to induce an immune response .
the peyer 's patch then secrete iga and other pathogen - specific antibody into the intestinal luman to help keep intestinal microbe at safe level .
goblet cell , which be modify simple columnar epithelial cell , also line the gi tract ( figure two  four  .  six ) .
goblet cell secrete a gel - form mucin , which be the major component of mucus .
the production of a protective layer of mucus help reduce the risk of pathogen reach deep tissue .
the constant movement of material through the gastrointestinal tract also help to move transient pathogen out of the body .
in fact , fece be compose of approximately two  five % microbe , two  five % slough epithelial cell , two  five % mucus , and two  five % digested or undigested food .
finally , the normal microbiota provide an additional barrier to infection via a variety of mechanism .
for example , these organism outcompete potential pathogen for space and nutrient within the intestine .
this be know as competitive exclusion .
member of the microbiota may also secrete protein toxin know as bacteriocin that be able to bind to specific receptor on the surface of susceptible bacteria .

in the mouth , fermentation by anaerobic microbe produce acid that damage the tooth and gum .

additionally , some pathogen can cause infection of the mucosa , gland , and other structure in the mouth , result in inflammation , sore , canker , and other lesion .
an open sore in the mouth or gi tract be typically call an ulcer .
infection and intoxication of the low gi tract often produce symptom such as nausea , vomiting , diarrhea , ache , and fever .
in some case , vomiting and diarrhea may cause severe dehydration and other complication that can become serious or fatal .
various clinical term be use to describe gastrointestinal symptom .
for example , gastritis be an inflammation of the stomach line that result in swelling and enteritis refer to inflammation of the intestinal mucosa .

inflammation of the liver be call hepatitis .

because an inflamed colon do not reabsorb water as effectively as - pron - normally do , stool become watery , cause diarrhea .
damage to the epithelial cell of the colon can also cause bleed and excess mucus to appear in watery stool , a condition call dysentery .

explain the role of microbial activity in disease of the mouth and oral cavity  compare the major characteristic of specific oral disease and infection despite the presence of saliva and the mechanical force of chew and eating , some microbe thrive in the mouth .
these microbe can cause damage to the tooth and can cause infection that have the potential to spread beyond the mouth and sometimes throughout the body .
dental caries cavity of the tooth , know clinically as dental carie , be microbial lesion that cause damage to the tooth .
over time , the lesion can grow through the outer enamel layer to infect the underlie dentin or even the innermost pulp .
if dental carie be not treat , the infection can become an abscess that spread to the deep tissue of the tooth , near the root , or to the bloodstream .
tooth decay result from the metabolic activity of microbe that live on the tooth .
a layer of protein and carbohydrate form when clean tooth come into contact with saliva .
microbe be attract to this food source and form a biofilm call plaque .
the most important cariogenic specie in these biofilm be streptococcus mutan .
when sucrose , a disaccharide sugar from food , be break down by bacteria in the mouth , glucose and fructose be produce .
the glucose be use to make dextran , which be part of the extracellular matrix of the biofilm .
fructose be ferment , produce organic acid such as lactic acid .
these acid dissolve the mineral of the tooth , include enamel , even though - pron - be the hard material in the body .
the acid work even more quickly on expose dentin ( figure two  four  .  seven ) .
over time , the plaque biofilm can become thick and eventually calcify .
when a heavy plaque deposit become harden in this way , - pron - be call tartar or dental calculus
( figure two  four  .  eight ) .
these substantial plaque biofilm can include a variety of bacterial specie , include streptococcus and actinomyces specie .

periodontal disease
in addition to damage to the tooth - pron - , the surround structure can be affect by microbe .
periodontal disease be the result of infection that lead to inflammation and tissue damage in the structure surround the tooth .
the progression from mild to severe periodontal disease be generally reversible and preventable with good oral hygiene .
inflammation of the gum that can lead to irritation and bleeding be call gingivitis .
when plaque accumulate on the tooth , bacteria colonize the gingival space .
as this space become increasingly block , the environment become anaerobic .
this allow a wide variety of microbe to colonize , include porphyromonas , streptococcus , and actinomyces .
the bacterial product , which include lipopolysaccharide ( lps ) , protease , lipoteichoic acid , and other , cause inflammation and gum damage ( figure two  four  .  nine ) .

over time , chronic gingivitis can develop into the more serious condition of periodontitis ( figure two  four  .  one  zero ) .
when this happen , the gums recede and expose part of the tooth below the crown .
this newly expose area be relatively unprotected , so bacteria can grow on - pron - and spread underneath the enamel of the crown and cause cavity .
bacteria in the gingival space can also erode the cementum , which help to hold the tooth in place .
if not treat , erosion of cementum can lead to the movement or loss of tooth .
the bone of the jaw can even erode if the infection spread .
this condition can be associate with bleeding and halitosis ( bad breath ) .
cleaning and appropriate dental hygiene may be sufficient to treat periodontitis .
however , in case of severe periodontitis , an antibiotic may be give .
antibiotic may be give in pill form or apply directly to the gum ( local treatment ) .
antibiotic give can include tetracycline , doxycycline , macrolide or β - lactam .
because periodontitis can be cause by a mix of microbe , a combination of antibiotic may be give .

trench mouth

this be severe periodontitis characterize by erosion of the gum , ulcer , substantial pain with chewing , and halitosis ( figure two  four  .  one  one ) that can be diagnose by visual examination and x - ray .

how do gingivitis progress to periodontitis ?
healthy mouth , healthy body good oral health promote good overall health , and the reverse be also true .
poor oral health can lead to difficulty eat , which can cause malnutrition .
painful or loose tooth can also cause a person to avoid certain food or eat less .
malnutrition due to dental problem be of great concern for the elderly , for whom - pron - can worsen other health condition and contribute to mortality .
individual who have serious illness , especially aids , be also at increase risk of malnutrition from dental problem .
additionally , poor oral health can contribute to the development of disease .
increase bacterial growth in the mouth can cause inflammation and infection in other part of the body .
for example , streptococcus in the mouth , the main contributor to biofilm on tooth , tartar , and dental carie , can spread throughout the body when there be damage to the tissue inside the mouth , as can happen during dental work .
s . mutan produce a surface adhesin know as p one , which bind to salivary agglutinin on the surface of the tooth .
p one can also bind to extracellular matrix protein include fibronectin and collagen .
when streptococcus enter the bloodstream as a result of tooth brushing or dental cleaning , - pron - cause inflammation that can lead to the accumulation of plaque in the artery and contribute to the development of atherosclerosis , a condition associate with cardiovascular disease , heart attack , and stroke .
in some case , bacteria that spread through the blood vessel can lodge in the heart and cause endocarditis ( an example of a focal infection ) .

as note earlier , normal oral microbiota can cause dental and periodontal infection .
however , there be number of other infection that can manifest in the oral cavity when other microbe be present .
herpetic gingivostomatitis
as describe in viral infections of the skin and eyes , infection by herpe simplex virus type one ( hsv -  one ) frequently manifest as oral herpe , also call acute herpe labialis and characterize by cold sore on the lip , mouth , or gum .
hsv -  one can also cause acute herpetic gingivostomatitis , a condition that result in ulcer of the mucous membrane inside the mouth ( figure two  four  .  one  two ) .
herpetic gingivostomatitis be normally self - limit except in immunocompromised patient .
like oral herpe , the infection be generally diagnose through clinical examination , but culture or biopsy may be obtain if other sign or symptom suggest the possibility of a different causative agent .
if treatment be need , mouthwash or antiviral medication such as acyclovir , famciclovir , or valacyclovir may be use .

oral thrush
the yeast candida be part of the normal human microbiota , but overgrowth , especially of candida albican , can lead to infection in several part of the body .
when candida infection develop in the oral cavity , - pron - be call oral thrush .
oral thrush be most common in infant because - pron - do not yet have well develop immune system and have not acquire the robust normal microbiota that keep candida in check in adult .
oral thrush be also common in immunodeficient patient and be a common infection in patient with aids .
oral thrush be characterize by the appearance of white patch and pseudomembrane in the mouth ( figure two  four  .  one  three ) and can be associate with bleed .
the infection may be treat topically with nystatin or clotrimazole oral suspension , although systemic treatment be sometimes need .
in serious case , systemic azole such as fluconazole or itraconazole ( for strain resistant to fluconazole ) , may be use .
amphotericin b can also be use if the infection be severe or if the candida specie be azole - resistant .

mump
the viral disease mump be an infection of the parotid gland , the large of the three pair of salivary gland ( figure two  four  .  three ) .
the causative agent be mump virus ( muv ) , a paramyxovirus with an envelope that have hemagglutinin and neuraminidase spike .
a fusion protein locate on the surface of the envelope help to fuse the viral envelope to the host cell plasma membrane .
mump virus be transmit through respiratory droplet or through contact with contaminate saliva , make - pron - quite contagious so that - pron - can lead easily to epidemic .
- pron - cause fever , muscle pain , headache , pain with chew , loss of appetite , fatigue , and weakness .
there be swell of the salivary gland and associate pain ( figure two  four  .  one  four ) .
the virus can enter the bloodstream ( viremia ) , allow - pron - to spread to the organ and the central nervous system .
the infection range from subclinical case to case with serious complication , such as encephalitis , meningitis , and deafness .
inflammation of the pancrea , testis , ovary , and breast may also occur and cause permanent damage to those organ  despite these complication , a mump infection rarely cause sterility .
mump can be recognize base on clinical sign and symptom , and a diagnosis can be confirm with laboratory testing .
the virus can be identify use culture or molecular technique such as rt - pcr .
serologic test be also available , especially enzyme immunoassay that detect antibody .
there be no specific treatment for mump , so supportive therapy be use .
the most effective way to avoid infection be through vaccination .
although mump use to be a common childhood disease , - pron - be now rare in the united states due to vaccination with the measle , mump , and rubella ( mmr ) vaccine .

 identify the most common bacteria that can cause infection of the gi tract

compare the major characteristic of specific bacterial disease affect the gi
tract
a wide range of gastrointestinal disease be cause by bacterial contamination of food .
recall that foodborne disease can arise from either infection or intoxication .
in both case , bacterial toxin be typically responsible for produce disease sign and symptom .
the distinction lie in where the toxin be produce .
in an infection , the microbial agent be ingest , colonize the gut , and then produce toxin that damage host cell .
in an intoxication , bacteria produce toxin in the food before - pron - be ingest .
in either case , the toxin cause damage to the cell line the gastrointestinal tract , typically the colon .
this lead to the common sign and symptom of diarrhea or watery stool and abdominal cramp , or the more severe dysentery .
symptom of foodborne disease also often include nausea and vomiting , which be mechanism the body use to expel the toxic material .
most bacterial gastrointestinal illness be short - lived and self - limit  however , loss of fluid due to severe diarrheal illness can lead to dehydration that can , in some case , be fatal without proper treatment .
oral rehydration therapy with electrolyte solution be an essential aspect of treatment for most patient with gi disease , especially in child and infant .
staphylococcal food poisoning staphylococcal food poisoning be one form of food intoxication .
when staphylococcus aureus grow in food , - pron - may produce enterotoxin that , when ingest , can cause symptom such as nausea , diarrhea , cramping , and vomit within one to six hour .
in some severe case , - pron - may cause headache , dehydration , and change in blood pressure and heart rate .
sign and symptom resolve within two  four to four  eight hour .
s . aureus be often associate with a variety of raw or undercooked and cooked food include meat ( e . g . , canned meat , ham , and sausage ) and dairy product ( e . g . , cheese , milk , and butter ) .
- pron - be also commonly find on hand and can be transmit to prepare food through poor hygiene , include poor handwashing and the use of contaminate food preparation surface , such as cut board .
the great risk be for food leave at a temperature below six  zero ° c ( one  four  zero ° f ) , which allow the bacteria to grow .
cooked food should generally be reheat to at least six  zero ° c ( one  four  zero ° f ) for safety and most raw meat should be cook to even high internal temperature ( figure two  four  .  one  six ) .

e . coli infections
the gram - negative rod escherichia coli be a common member of the normal microbiota of the colon .
although the vast majority of e . coli strain be helpful commensal bacteria , some can be pathogenic and may cause dangerous diarrheal disease .
the pathogenic strain have additional virulence factor such as type one fimbriae that promote colonization of the colon or may produce toxin ( see virulence factors of bacterial and viral pathogens ) .
these virulence factor be acquire through horizontal gene transfer .
extraintestinal disease can result if the bacteria spread from the gastrointestinal tract .
although these bacteria can be spread from person to person , - pron - be often acquire through contaminate food or water .
there be six recognize pathogenic group of e . coli , but - pron - will focus here on the four that be most commonly transmit through food and water .
enterotoxigenic e . coli ( etec ) , also know as traveler 's diarrhea , cause diarrheal illness and be common in less developed country .
in mexico , etec infection be call montezuma 's revenge .
follow ingestion of contaminate food or water , infect individual develop a watery diarrhea , abdominal cramp , malaise ( a feeling of be unwell ) , and a low fever .
etec produce a heat - stable enterotoxin similar to cholera toxin , and adhesin call colonization factor that help the bacteria to attach to the intestinal wall .
some strain of etec also produce heat - labile toxin .
the disease be usually relatively mild and self - limit .
diagnosis involve culture and pcr .
if need , antibiotic treatment with fluoroquinolone , doxycycline , rifaximin , and trimethoprim - sulfamethoxazole ( tmp / smz ) may shorten infection duration .
however , antibiotic resistance be a problem .
enteroinvasive e . coli ( eiec ) be very similar to shigellosis , include - pron - pathogenesis of intracellular invasion into intestinal epithelial tissue .
this bacterium carry a large plasmid that be involve in epithelial cell penetration .
the illness be usually self - limit , with symptom include watery diarrhea , chill , cramp , malaise , fever , and dysentery .
culturing and pcr testing can be use for diagnosis .
antibiotic treatment be not recommend , so supportive therapy be use if need .
enteropathogenic e . coli ( epec ) can cause a potentially fatal diarrhea , especially in infant and those in less developed country .
fever , vomiting , and diarrhea can lead to severe dehydration .
these e . coli inject a protein ( tir ) that attach to the surface of the intestinal epithelial cell and trigger rearrangement of host cell actin from microvilli to pedestal .
tir also happen to be the receptor for intimin , a surface protein produce by epec , thereby allow e . coli to " sit " on the pedestal .
the gene necessary for this pedestal formation be encode on the locus for enterocyte effacement ( lee ) pathogenicity island .
as with etec , diagnosis involve culturing and pcr .
treatment be similar to that for etec .
the most dangerous strain be enterohemorrhagic e . coli ( ehec ) , which be the strain capable of cause epidemic .
in particular , the strain o one  five  seven  h seven have be responsible for several recent outbreak .
recall that the o and h refer to surface antigen that contribute to pathogenicity and trigger a host immune response
( “ o " refer to the o - side chain of the lipopolysaccharide and the “ h " refer to the flagella ) .
similar to epec , ehec also form pedestal .
ehec also produce a shiga - like toxin .
because the genome of this bacterium have be sequence , - pron - be know that the shiga toxin gene be most likely acquire through transduction ( horizontal gene transfer ) .
the shiga toxin gene originate from shigella dysenteriae .
prophage from a bacteriophage that previously infect shigella integrate into the chromosome of e . coli .
the shiga - like toxin be often call verotoxin .

the gastrointestinal disease cholera be a serious infection often associate with poor sanitation , especially follow natural disaster , because - pron - be spread through contaminated water and food that have not be heat to temperature high enough to kill the bacteria .
- pron - be cause by vibrio cholerae serotype o one , a gram - negative , flagellated bacterium in the shape of a curved rod ( vibrio ) .
accord to the cdc , cholera cause an estimate three to five million case and one  zero  zero  ,  zero  zero  zero death each year . [ seven ]
because v . cholerae be kill by stomach acid , relatively large dos be need for a few microbial cell to survive to reach the intestine and cause infection .
the motile cell travel through the mucous layer of the intestine , where - pron - attach to epithelial cell and release cholera enterotoxin .
the toxin be an a - b toxin with activity through adenylate cyclase ( see virulence factors of bacterial and viral pathogens ) .
within the intestinal cell , cyclic amp ( camp ) level increase , which activate a chloride channel and result in the release of ion into the intestinal luman .
this increase in osmotic pressure in the lumen lead to water also enter the luman .
as the water and electrolyte leave the body , - pron - cause rapid dehydration and electrolyte imbalance .
diarrhea be so profuse that - pron - be often call " rice water stool ,
" and patient be place on cot with a hole in - pron - to monitor the fluid loss ( figure two  four  .  one  nine ) .
cholera be diagnose by take a stool sample and culture for vibrio .
the bacteria be oxidase positive and show non - lactose fermentation on macconkey agar .
gram - negative lactose fermenter will produce red colony while non - fermenter will produce white / colorless colony .
gram - positive bacteria will not grow on macconkey .
lactose fermentation be commonly use for pathogen identification because the normal microbiota generally ferment lactose while pathogen do not .
v . cholerae may also be culture on thiosulfate citrate bile salt sucrose ( tcbs ) agar , a selective and differential medium for vibrio spp .
, which produce a distinct yellow colony .
cholera may be self - limit and treatment involve rehydration and electrolyte replenishment .
although antibiotic be not typically need , - pron - can be use for severe or disseminated disease .
tetracycline be recommend , but doxycycline , erythromycin , orfloxacin , ciprofloxacin , and tmp / smz may be use .
recent evidence suggest that azithromycin be also a good first - line antibiotic .
good sanitation - include appropriate sewage treatment , clean supply for cooking , and purified drinking water - be important to prevent infection

peptic ulcers
the gram - negative bacterium helicobacter pylorus be able to tolerate the acidic environment of the human stomach and have be show to be a major cause of peptic ulcer , which be ulcer of the stomach or duodenum .
the bacterium be also associate with increase risk of stomach cancer ( figure two  four  .  two  zero ) .
accord to the cdc , approximately twothird of the population be infect with h . pylorus , but less than two  zero % have a risk of develop ulcer or stomach chapter two  four  digestive system infections one  zero  seven  three cancer .
h . pylorus be find in approximately eight  zero % of stomach ulcer and in over nine  zero % of duodenal ulcers . [ eight ] h . pylorus colonize epithelial cell in the stomach use pili for adhesion .
these bacteria produce urease , which stimulate an immune response and create ammonia that neutralize stomach acid to provide a more hospitable microenvironment .
the infection damage the cell of the stomach lining , include those that normally produce the protective mucus that serve as a barrier between the tissue and stomach acid .
as a result , inflammation ( gastritis ) occur and ulcer may slowly develop .
ulcer formation can also be cause by toxin activity .
- pron - have be report that five  zero % of clinical isolate of h . pylorus have detectable level of exotoxin activity in vitro . [ nine ]
this toxin , vaca , induce vacuole formation in host cell .
vaca have no primary sequence homology with other bacterial toxin , and in a mouse model , there be a correlation between the presence of the toxin gene , the activity of the toxin , and gastric epithelial tissue damage .
sign and symptom include nausea , lack of appetite , bloating , burping , and weight loss .
bleed ulcer may produce dark stool .
if no treatment be provide , the ulcer can become deep , more tissue can be involve , and stomach perforation can occur .
because perforation allow digestive enzyme and acid to leak into the body , - pron - be a very serious condition .

to diagnose h . pylorus infection , multiple method be available .

clostridium perfringen gastroenteritis clostridium perfringen gastroenteritis be a generally mild foodborne disease that be associate with undercooked meat and other food .
c . perfringen be a gram - positive , rod - shape , endospore - form anaerobic bacterium that be tolerant of high and low temperature .
at high temperature , the bacteria can form endospore that will germinate rapidly in food or within the intestine .
food poisoning by type
a strain be common .
this strain always produce an enterotoxin , sometimes also present in other strain , that cause the clinical symptom of cramp and diarrhea .
a more severe form of the illness , call pig - bel or enteritis necrotican , cause hemorrhaging , pain , vomiting , and bloating .
gangrene of the intestine may result .
this form have a high mortality rate but be rare in the united states .
diagnosis involve detect the c . perfringen toxin in stool sample use either molecular biology technique ( pcr detection of the toxin gene ) or immunology technique ( elisa ) .
the bacteria - pron - may also be detect in food or in fecal sample .
treatment include rehydration therapy , electrolyte replacement , and intravenous fluid .
antibiotic be not recommend because - pron - can damage the balance of the microbiota in the gut , and there be concern about antibiotic resistance .
the illness can be prevent through proper handling and cooking of food , include prompt refrigeration at sufficiently low temperature and cook food to a sufficiently high temperature .
clostridium difficile clostridium difficile be a gram - positive rod that can be a commensal bacterium as part of the normal microbiota of healthy individual .
when the normal microbiota be disrupt by long - term antibiotic use , - pron - can allow the overgrowth of this bacterium , result in antibiotic - associate diarrhea cause by c . difficile .
antibiotic - associate diarrhea can also be consider a nosocomial disease .
patient at the great risk of c . difficile infection be those who be immunocompromise , have be in health - care setting for extended period , be old , have recently take antibiotic , have have gastrointestinal procedure do , or use proton pump inhibitor , which reduce stomach acidity and allow proliferation of c . difficile .
because this specie can form endospore , - pron - can survive for extended period of time in the environment under harsh condition and be a considerable concern in health - care setting .
this bacterium produce two toxin , clostridium difficile toxin a ( tcda ) and clostridium difficile toxin b ( tcdb ) .
these toxin inactivate small gtp - bind protein , result in actin condensation and cell rounding , follow by cell death .
infection begin with focal necrosis , then ulceration with exudate , and can progress to pseudomembranous colitis , which involve inflammation of the colon and the development of a pseudomembrane of fibrin contain dead epithelial cell and leukocyte ( figure two  four  .  two  one ) .
watery diarrhea , dehydration , fever , loss of appetite , and abdominal pain can result .
perforation of the colon can occur , lead to septicemia , shock , and death .
c . difficile be also associate with necrotize enterocolitis in premature baby and neutropenic enterocolitis associate with cancer therapy .

hepatitis hepatitis be a general term mean inflammation of the liver , which can have a variety of cause .

there be five main hepatitis virus that be clinically significant  hepatitisviruse a ( hav ) , b ( hbv ) , c ( hcv ) , d , ( hdv ) and e ( hev )
( figure two  four  .  two  six ) .
note that other virus , such as epstein - barr virus ( ebv ) , yellow fever , and cytomegalovirus ( cmv ) can also cause hepatitis and be discuss in viral infections of the circulatory and lymphatic systems .

five main type of virus cause hepatitis .
hav be a non - envelop ssrna ( + ) virus and be a member of the picornavirus family ( baltimore group iv ) .
hbv be a dsdna envelop virus , replicate use reverse transcriptase , and be a member of the hepadnavirus family ( baltimore group vii ) .
hcv be an envelop ssrna ( + ) virus and be a member of the flavivirus family ( baltimore group iv ) .
hdv be an envelop ssrna ( – ) that be circular ( baltimore group v ) .
this virus can only propagate in the presence of hbv .
hev be a non - envelop ssrna ( + ) virus and a member of the hepeviridae family ( baltimore group iv ) .
although the five hepatitis virus differ , - pron - can cause some similar sign and symptom because - pron - all have an affinity for hepatocyte ( liver cell ) .
hav and hev can be contract through ingestion while hbv , hcv , and hdv be transmit by parenteral contact .
- pron - be possible for individual to become long term or chronic carrier of hepatitis virus .

the hbv vaccine be also protective against hdv .

prevent hbv transmission in health - care settings hepatitis b be once a lead on - the - job hazard for health - care worker .
many health - care worker over the year have become infect , some develop cirrhosis and liver cancer .
in one  nine  eight  two , the cdc recommend that health - care worker be vaccinate against hbv , and rate of infection have decline since then .

therefore , there be still a small risk for infection , especially for health - care worker work with individual who have chronic infection , such as drug addict , and for those with high risk of needle stick , such as phlebotomist .
dentist be also at risk .
health - care worker need to take appropriate precaution to prevent infection by hbv and other illness .
blood be the great risk , but other body fluid can also transmit infection .
damaged skin , as occur with eczema or psoriasis , can also allow transmission .
avoid contact with body fluid , especially blood , by wear glove and face protection and use disposable syrinx and needle reduce the risk of infection .
washing expose skin with soap and water be recommend .
antiseptic may also be use , but may not help .
post - exposure treatment , include treatment with hepatitis b immunoglobulin ( hbig ) and vaccination , may be use in the event of exposure to the virus from an infected patient .
detailed protocol be available for manage these situation .
the virus can remain infective for up to seven day when on surface , even if no blood or other fluid be visible , so - pron - be important to consider the good choice for disinfect and sterilize equipment that could potentially transmit the virus .
the cdc recommend a solution of one  zero % bleach to disinfect surfaces . [ one  eight ]
finally , testing blood product be important to reduce the risk of transmission during transfusion and similar procedure .

giardiasis also call backpacker 's diarrhea or beaver fever , giardiasis be a common disease in the united states cause by the flagellate protist giardia lamblia , also know as giardia intestinali or giardia duodenalis ( figure one  .  one  six ) .
to establish infection , g . lamblia use a large adhesive disk to attach to the intestinal mucosa .
the disk be comprise of microtubule .
during adhesion , the flagella of g . lamblia move in a manner that draw fluid out from under the disk , result in an area of low pressure that promote - pron - adhesion to the intestinal epithelial cell .
due to - pron - attachment , giardia also block absorption of nutrient , include fat .
transmission occur through contaminate food or water or directly from person to person .
child in day - care center be at risk due to - pron - tendency to put item into - pron - mouth that may be contaminate .
large outbreak may occur if a public water supply become contaminate .
giardia have a resistant cyst stage in - pron - life cycle that be able to survive cold temperature and the chlorination treatment typically use for drinking water in municipal reservoir .
as a result , municipal water must be filter to trap and remove these cyst .
once consume by the host , giardia develop into the active tropozoite .
infect individual may be asymptomatic or have gastrointestinal sign and symptom , sometimes accompany by weight loss .
common symptom , which appear one to three week after exposure , include diarrhea , nausea , stomach cramp , gas , greasy stool ( because fat absorption be be block ) , and possible dehydration .
the parasite remain in the colon and do not cause systemic infection .
sign and symptom generally clear within two to six week .
chronic infection may develop and be often resistant to treatment .
these be associate with weight loss , episodic diarrhea , and malabsorption syndrome due to the block nutrient absorption .
diagnosis may be make use observation under the microscope .

amoebiasis ( amebiasis )
the protozoan parasite entamoeba histolytica cause amoebiasis , which be know as amoebic dysentery in severe case .

disease can be cause by as few as one  zero cyst be transmit .
