hantavirus
the genus hantavirus consist of at least four serogroup with nine virus cause two major clinical ( sometimes overlapping ) syndrome 
hantavirus pulmonary syndrome ( hps ) in north america and hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome ( hfrs ) in other continent .
hantaviruse be find throughout the world in wild rodent that shed the virus in - pron - urine and fece .
transmission occur between rodent and to human through inhalation of aerosol of the rodent urine and fece .
hantaviruse associate with outbreak in the us and canada be transmit by the deer mouse , white - footed mouse , or cotton rat .
hps begin as a nonspecific flu - like illness with headache , fever , myalgia , nausea , vomiting , diarrhea , and abdominal pain .
patient rapidly develop pulmonary edema and hypotension result in pneumonia , shock , and death , with a mortality rate of up to five  zero % . [ three  eight ]
this virus can also cause hfrs , which have not be report in the us .
the initial symptom of this condition include high fever , headache , chill , nausea , inflammation or redness of the eye , or a rash .
later symptom be hemorrhage , hypotension , kidney failure , shock , and death .
the mortality rate of hfrs can be as high as one  five % . [ three  nine ] elisa , western blot , rapid immunoblot strip assay ( riba ) , and rt - pcr detect host antibody or viral protein produce during infection .
immunohistological staining may also be use to detect the presence of viral antigen .
there be no clinical treatment other than general supportive care available for hps infection .
patient with hfrs can be treat with ribavirin . [ four  zero ]

hiv be spread through direct contact with body fluid .
casual contact and insect vector be not sufficient for disease transmission  common mode of transmission include sexual contact and sharing of needle by intravenous ( iv ) drug user .
- pron - generally take many year before the effect of an hiv infection be detect .
hiv infection be not dormant during this period  virion be continually produce , and the immune system continually attempt to clear the viral infection , while the virus persistently infect additional cd four t cell .
over time , the cd four t - cell population be devastate , ultimately lead to aids .
when people be infect with hiv , - pron - disease progress through three stage base on cd four t - cell count and the presence of clinical symptom ( figure two  five  .  two  five ) .

stage one  acute hiv infection .
two to four week after infection with hiv , patient may experience a flulike illness , which can last for a few week .
patient with acute hiv infection have more than five  zero  zero cell / μl cd four t cell and a large amount of virus in - pron - blood .
patient be very contagious during this stage .
to confirm acute infection , either a fourth - generation antibody - antigen test or a nucleic acid test ( nat ) must be perform .

stage two  clinical latency .
during this period , hiv enter a period of dormancy .
patient have between two  zero  zero and four  nine  nine cell / μl cd four t cell  hiv be still active but reproduce at low level , and patient may not experience any symptom of illness .
for patient who be not take medicine to treat hiv , this period can last a decade or long .
for patient receive antiretroviral therapy , the stage may last for several decade , and those with low level of the virus in - pron - blood be much less likely to transmit hiv than those who be not virally suppress .
near the end of the latent stage , the patient 's viral load start to increase and the cd four t - cell count begin to decrease , lead to the development of symptom and increase susceptibility to opportunistic infection .

stage three  acquire immunodeficiency syndrome ( aids ) .
patient be diagnose with aids when - pron - cd four t - cell count drop below two  zero  zero cell / μl or when - pron - develop certain opportunistic illness .
during this stage , the immune system become severely damage by hiv .
common symptom of aids include chill , fever , sweat , swollen lymph gland , weakness , and weight loss  in addition , patient often develop rare cancer such as kaposi 's sarcoma and opportunistic infection such as pneumocystis pneumonia , tuberculosis , cryptosporidiosis , and toxoplasmosis .
this be a fatal progression that , in the terminal stage , include waste one  one  four  eight chapter two  five  circulatory and lymphatic system infections

the initial diagnosis of hiv be perform use a serological test for antibody production against the pathogen .
positive test result be confirm by western blot or pcr test .
- pron - can take week or month for the body to produce antibody in response to an infection .
there be fourth - generation test that detect hiv antibody and hiv antigen that be present even before the body begin produce antibody .
nucleic acid test ( nats ) be a third type of test that be relatively expensive and uncommon  nat can detect hiv in blood and determine the viral load .
as a consequence of provirus formation , - pron - be currently not possible to eliminate hiv from an infected patient 's body .
elimination by specific antibody be ineffective because the virus mutate rapidly
-
a result of the error - prone reverse transcriptase and the inability to correct error .
antiviral treatment , however , can greatly extend life expectancy .
to combat the problem of drug resistance , combination of antiretroviral drug call antiretroviral therapy ( art ) , sometimes call highly active art or combine art , be use .
there be several different target for antiviral drug action ( and a grow list of drug for each of these target ) .
one class of drug inhibit hiv entry  other class inhibit reverse transcriptase by block viral rna - dependent and dna - dependent dna polymerase activity  and still other inhibit one of the three hiv enzyme need to replicate inside human cell .

infections one  one  four  nine hiv , aids , and education
when the first outbreak of aids in the us occur in the early one  nine  eight  zero s , very little be know about the disease or - pron - origin .
erroneously , the disease quickly become stigmatize as one associate with what become identify as at - risk behavior such as sexual promiscuity , homosexuality , and iv drug use , even though mount evidence indicate the disease be also contract through transfusion of blood and blood product or by fetus of infect mother .
in the mid -  one  nine  eight  zero , scientist elucidate the identity of the virus , - pron - mode of transmission , and mechanism of pathogenesis .
campaign be undertake to educate the public about how hiv spread to stem infection rate and encourage behavioral change that reduce the risk for infection .
approach to this campaign , however , emphasize very different strategy .
some group favor educational program that emphasize sexual abstinence , monogamy , heterosexuality , and “ just say no to drug .
"
other group place an emphasis on " safe sex " in sex education program and advocate social service program that pass out free condom to anyone , include sexually active minor , and provide needle exchange program for iv drug user .
these be clear example of the intersection between disease and cultural value .
as a future health professional , what be - pron - responsibility in term of educate patient about behavior that put - pron - at risk for hiv or other disease while possibly set - pron - own personal opinion aside ?
- pron - will no doubt encounter patient whose cultural and moral value differ from - pron - own .
be - pron - ethical for - pron - to promote - pron - own moral agenda to - pron - patient ?
how can - pron - advocate for practical disease prevention while still respect the personal view of - pron - patient ?

malaria
despite more than a century of intense research and clinical advancement , malaria remain one of the most important infectious disease in the world today .
- pron - widespread distribution place more than half of the world 's population in jeopardy .
in two  zero  one  five , the who estimate there be about two  one  four million case of malaria worldwide , result in about four  three  eight  ,  zero  zero  zero death  about eight  eight % of case and nine  one % of death occur in africa . [ four  three ]
although malaria be not currently a major threat in the us , the possibility of - pron - reintroduction be a concern .
malaria be cause by several protozoan parasite in the genus plasmodium  p . falciparum , p . knowlesi , p . malariae , p . ovale , and p . vivax .
plasmodium primarily infect red blood cell and be transmit through the bite of anopheles mosquito .
currently , p . falciparum be the most common and most lethal cause of malaria , often call falciparum malaria .
falciparum malaria be widespread in highly populated region of africa and asia , put many people at risk for the most severe form of the disease .
the classic sign and symptom of malaria be cycle of extreme fever and chill .
the sudden , violent symptom of malaria start with malaise , abrupt chill , and fever ( three  nine – four  one ° c [ one  zero  two  .  two – one  zero  five  .  eight ° f ] ) , rapid and faint pulse , polyuria , headache , myalgia , nausea , and vomiting .
after two to six hour of these symptom , the fever fall , and profuse sweat occur for two to three hour , follow by extreme fatigue .
these symptom be a result of plasmodium emerge from red blood cell synchronously , lead to simultaneous rupture of a large number of red blood cell , result in damage to the spleen , liver , lymph node , and bone marrow .
the organ damage result from hemolysis cause patient to develop sludge blood ( i . e . , blood in which the red blood cell agglutinate into clump ) that can lead to lack of oxygen , necrosis of blood vessel , organ failure , and death .
in established infection , malarial cycle of fever and chill typically occur every two day in the disease describe as tertian malaria , which be cause by p . vivax and p . ovale .
the cycle occur every three day in the disease describe as quartan malaria , which be cause by p . malariae .
these interval may vary among case .
plasmodium have a complex life cycle that include several developmental stage alternately produce in mosquito and human ( figure two  five  .  two  seven ) .
when an infected mosquito take a blood meal , sporozoite in the mosquito salivary gland be inject into the host 's blood .
these parasite circulate to the liver , where - pron - develop into schizont .
the schizont then undergo schizogony , result in the release of many merozoite at once .
the merozoite move to the bloodstream and infect red blood cell .
inside red blood cell , merozoite develop into trophozoite that produce more merozoite .
the synchronous release of merozoite from red blood cell in the evening lead to the symptom of malaria .
in addition , some trophozoite alternatively develop into male and female gametocyte .
the gametocyte be take up when the mosquito take a blood meal from an infect individual .
sexual sporogony occur in the gut of the mosquito .
the gametocyte fuse to form zygote in the insect gut .
the zygote become motile and elongate into an ookinete .
this form penetrate the midgut wall and develop into an oocyst .
finally , the oocyst release new four  three .

drug such as chloroquine , atovaquone , artemether , and lumefantrine may be prescribe for both acute and prophylactic therapy , although some plasmodium spp . have show resistance to antimalarial drug .
use of insecticide and insecticide - treat bed net can limit the spread of malaria .
despite effort to develop a vaccine for malaria , none be currently available .

toxoplasmosis
the disease toxoplasmosis be cause by the protozoan toxoplasma gondii .
t . gondii be find in a wide variety of bird and mammals , [ four  four ] and human infection be common .
the centers for disease control and prevention ( cdc ) estimate that two  two  .  five % of the population one  two year and old have be infect with t . gondii  but immunocompetent individual be typically asymptomatic , however . [ four  five ] domestic cat be the only know definitive host for the sexual stage of t . gondii and , thus , be the main reservoir of infection .

t . gondii have a complex life cycle that involve multiple host .
the t . gondii life cycle begin when unsporulated oocyst be shed in the cat 's fece .
these oocyst take one – five day to sporulate in the environment and become infective .
intermediate host in nature include bird and rodent , which become infected after ingest soil , water , or plant material contaminate with the infective oocyst .
once ingest , the oocyst transform into tachyzoite that localize in the bird or rodent neural and muscle tissue , where - pron - develop into tissue cyst .
cat may become infected after consume bird and rodent harbor tissue cyst .
cat and other animal may also become infect directly by ingestion of sporulate oocyst in the environment .
interestingly , toxoplasma infection appear to be able to modify the host 's behavior .
mouse infect by toxoplasma lose - pron - fear of cat pheromone .
as a result , - pron - become easy prey for cat , facilitate the transmission of the parasite to the cat definitive host[ four  six ]
( figure two  five  .  two  nine ) .
toxoplasma infection in human be extremely common , but most infected people be asymptomatic or have subclinical symptom .
some study suggest that the parasite may be able to influence the personality and psychomotor performance of infect human , similar to the way - pron - modify behavior in other mammals . [ four  seven ]
when symptom do occur , - pron - tend to be mild and similar to those of mononucleosis .
however , asymptomatic toxoplasmosis can become problematic in certain situation .
cyst can lodge in a variety of human tissue and lie dormant for year .
reactivation of these quiescent infection can occur in immunocompromised patient follow transplantation , cancer therapy , or the development of an immune disorder such as aids .
in patient with aids who have toxoplasmosis , the immune system can not combat the growth of t . gondii in body tissue  as a result , these cyst can cause encephalitis , retinitis , pneumonitis , cognitive disorder , and seizure that can eventually be fatal .
toxoplasmosis can also pose a risk during pregnancy because tachyzoite can cross the placenta and cause serious infection in the develop fetus .
the extent of fetal damage result from toxoplasmosis depend on the severity of maternal disease , the damage to the placenta , the gestational age of the fetus when infect , and the virulence of the organism .
congenital toxoplasmosis often lead to fetal loss or premature birth and can result in damage to the central nervous system , manifest as mental retardation , deafness , or blindness .
consequently , pregnant woman be advise by the cdc to take particular care in prepare meat , gardening , and care for pet cats . [ four  eight ]
diagnosis of toxoplasmosis infection during pregnancy be usually achieve by serology include torch testing ( the “ t " in torch stand for toxoplasmosis ) .
diagnosis of congenital infection can also be achieve by detect t . gondii dna in amniotic fluid , use molecular method such as pcr .
in adult , diagnosis of toxoplasmosis can include observation of tissue cyst in tissue specimen .
tissue cyst may be observe in giemsa - orwright - stain biopsy specimen , and ct , magnetic resonance imaging , and lumbar puncture can also be use to confirm infection ( figure two  five  .  three  zero ) .
prevent infection be the good first - line defense against toxoplasmosis .
preventive measure include wash hand thoroughly after handle raw meat , soil , or cat litter , and avoid consumption of vegetable possibly contaminate with cat fece .
all meat should be cook to an internal temperature of seven  three  .  nine – seven  six  .  seven ° c ( one  six  five – one  seven  zero ° f ) .
most immunocompetent patient do not require clinical intervention for toxoplasma infection .
however , neonate , pregnant woman , and immunocompromise patient can be treat with pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine - except during the first trimester of pregnancy , because these drug can cause birth defect .
spiramycin have be use safely to reduce transmission in pregnant woman with primary infection during the first trimester because - pron - do not cross the placenta .

babesiosis babesiosis be a rare zoonotic infectious disease cause by babesia spp .
these parasitic protozoan infect various wild and domestic animal and can be transmit to human by black - legged ixode tick .
in human , babesia infect red blood cell and replicate inside the cell until - pron - rupture .
the babesia release from the rupture red blood cell continue the growth cycle by invade other red blood cell .
patient may be asymptomatic , but those who do have symptom often initially experience malaise , fatigue , chill , fever , headache , myalgia , and arthralgia .
in rare case , particularly in asplenic ( absence of the spleen ) patient , the elderly , and patient with aids , babesiosis may resemble falciparum malaria , with high fever , hemolytic anemia , hemoglobinuria ( hemoglobin or blood in urine ) , jaundice , and renal failure , and the infection can be fatal .
previously acquire asymptomatic babesia infection may become symptomatic if a splenectomy be perform .
diagnosis be base mainly on the microscopic observation of parasite in blood smear ( figure two  five  .  three  one ) .
serologic and antibody detection by ifa can also be perform and pcr - base test be available .
many people do not require clinical intervention for babesia infection , however , serious infection can be clear with a combination of atovaquone and azithromycin or a combination of clindamycin and quinine .

chagas disease also call american trypanosomiasis , chagas disease be a zoonosis classify as a neglect tropical disease ( ntd ) .
- pron - be cause by the flagellate protozoan trypanosoma cruzi and be most commonly transmit to animal and people through the fece of triatomine bug .
the triatomine bug be nickname the kissing bug because - pron - frequently bite human on the face or around the eye  the insect often defecate near the bite and the infect fecal matter may be rub into the bite wind by the bite individual ( figure two  five  .  three  two ) .
the bite - pron - be painless and , initially , many people show no sign of the disease .
alternative mode of transmission include contaminate blood transfusion , organ transplant from infected donor , and congenital transmission from mother to fetus .
chagas disease be endemic throughout much of mexico , central america , and south america , where , accord to who , an estimate six million to seven million people be infected . [ four  nine ]
currently , chagas disease be not endemic in the us , even though triatomine bug be find in the southern half of the country .
triatomine bug typically be active at night , when - pron - take blood meal by bite the face and lip of people or animal as - pron - sleep and often defecate near the site of the bite .
infection occur when the host rub the fece into - pron - eye , mouth , the bite wound , or another break in the skin .
the protozoan then enter the blood and invade tissue of the heart and central nervous system , as well as macrophage and monocyte .
nonhuman reservoir of t . cruzi parasite include wild animal and domesticate animal such as dog and cat , which also act as reservoir of the pathogen . [ five  zero ]
there be three phase of chagas disease  acute , intermediate , and chronic .
these phase can be either asymptomatic or life - threaten depending on the immunocompetence status of the patient .
in acute phase disease , symptom include fever , headache , myalgia , rash , vomiting , diarrhea , and enlarge spleen , liver , and lymph node .
in addition , a localize nodule call a chagoma may form at the portal of entry , and swelling of the eyelid or the side of the face , call romaña ' s sign , may occur near the bite wound .
symptom of the acute phase may resolve spontaneously , but if untreated , the infection can persist in tissue , cause irreversible damage to the heart or brain .
in rare case , young child may die of myocarditis or meningoencephalitis during the acute phase four  nine .

leishmaniasis
although - pron - be classify as an ntd , leishmaniasis be relatively widespread in tropical and subtropical region , affect people in more than nine  zero country .
- pron - be cause by approximately two  zero different specie of leishmania , protozoan parasite that be transmit by sand fly vector such as phlebotomus spp .
and lutzomyia spp .
dog , cat , sheep , horse , cattle rodent , and human can all serve as reservoir .
the leishmania protozoan be phagocytose by macrophage but use virulence factor to avoid destruction within the phagolysosome .
the virulence factor inhibit the phagolysosome enzyme that would otherwise destroy the parasite .
the parasite reproduce within the macrophage , lyse - pron - , and the progeny infect new macrophage ( see chapter two  five  circulatory and lymphatic system infections one  one  five  nine micro connections  when phagocytosis fails ) .
the three major clinical form of leishmaniasis be cutaneous ( oriental sore , delhi boil , aleppo boil ) , visceral ( kalaazar , dumdum fever ) , and mucosal ( espundia ) .
the most common form of disease be cutaneous leishmaniasis , which be characterize by the formation of sore at the site of the insect bite that may start out as papule or nodule before become large ulcer ( figure two  five  .  three  three ) .
- pron - may take visceral leishmaniasis month and sometimes year to develop , lead to enlargement of the lymph node , liver , spleen , and bone marrow .
the damage to these body site trigger fever , weight loss , and swell of the spleen and liver .
- pron - also cause a decrease in the number of red blood cell ( anemia ) , white blood cell ( leukopenia ) , and platelet ( thrombocytopenia ) , cause the patient to become immunocompromised and more susceptible to fatal infection of the lung and gastrointestinal tract .
the mucosal form of leishmaniasis be one of the less common form of the disease .
- pron - cause a lesion similar to the cutaneous form but mucosal leishmaniasis be associate with mucous membrane of the mouth , naris , or pharynx , and can be destructive and disfiguring .
mucosal leishmaniasis occur less frequently when the original cutaneous ( skin ) infection be promptly treat .
definitive diagnosis of leishmaniasis be make by visualize organism in giemsa - stain smear , by isolate leishmania protozoan in culture , or by pcr - base assay of aspirate from infected tissue .
specific dna probe or analysis of culture parasite can help to distinguish leishmania specie that be cause simple cutaneous leishmaniasis from those capable of cause mucosal leishmaniasis .
cutaneous leishmaniasis be usually not treat .
the lesion will resolve after week ( or several month ) , but may result in scar .
recurrence rate be low for this disease .
more serious infection can be treat with stibogluconate ( antimony gluconate ) , amphotericin b , and miltefosine .

schistosomiasis schistosomiasis ( bilharzia ) be an ntd cause by blood fluke in the genus schistosoma that be native to the caribbean , south america , middle east , asia , and africa .
most human schistosomiasis case be cause by schistosoma mansoni , s . haematobium , or s . japonicum .
schistosoma be the only trematode that invade through the skin  all other trematode infect by ingestion .
who estimate that at least two  five  eight million people require preventive treatment for schistosomiasis in two  zero  one  four  . [ five  one ]
infect human host shed schistosoma egg in urine and fece , which can contaminate freshwater habitat of snail that serve as intermediate host .
the egg hatch in the water , release miracidia , an intermediate growth stage of the schistosoma that infect the snail .
the miracidia mature and multiply inside the snail , transform into cercariae that leave the snail and enter the water , where - pron - can penetrate the skin of swimmer and bather .
the cercariae migrate through human tissue and enter the bloodstream , where - pron - mature into adult male and female worm that mate and release fertilize egg .
the egg travel through the bloodstream and penetrate various body site , include the bladder or intestine , from which - pron - be excrete in urine or stool to start the life cycle over again ( figure five  .  two  two ) .
a few day after infection , patient may develop a rash or itchy skin associate with the site of cercariae penetration .
within one – two month of infection , symptom may develop , include fever , chill , cough , and myalgia , as egg that be not excrete circulate through the body .
after year of infection , the egg become lodged in tissue and trigger inflammation and scarring that can damage the liver , central nervous system , intestine , spleen , lung , and bladder .
this may cause abdominal pain , enlargement of the liver , blood in the urine or stool , and problem pass urine .
increase risk for bladder cancer be also associate with chronic schistosoma infection .
in addition , child who be repeatedly infect can develop malnutrition , anemia , and learn difficulty .
diagnosis of schistosomiasis be make by the microscopic observation of egg in fece or urine , intestine or bladder tissue specimen , or serologic test .
the drug praziquantel be effective for the treatment of all schistosome infection .
improve wastewater management and educate at - risk population to limit exposure to contaminate water can help control the spread of the disease .
cercarial dermatitis
the cercaria of some specie of schistosoma can only transform into adult worm and complete - pron - life cycle in animal host such as migratory bird and mammal .
the cercaria of these worm be still capable of penetrate human skin , but - pron - be unable to establish a productive infection in human tissue .
still , the presence of the cercaria in small blood vessel trigger an immune response , result in itchy raise bump call cercarial dermatitis ( also know as swimmer 's itch or clam digger ' s itch ) .
although - pron - be uncomfortable , cercarial dermatitis be typically self - limit and rarely serious .
antihistamine and antipruritic can be use to limit inflammation and itching , respectively .

summary two  five  .  one anatomy of the circulatory and lymphatic systems

the circulatory system move blood throughout the body and have no normal microbiota .

the lymphatic system move fluid from the interstitial space of tissue toward the circulatory system and filter the lymph .
- pron - also have no normal microbiota .

the circulatory and lymphatic system be home to many component of the host immune defense .

infections of the circulatory system may occur after a break in the skin barrier or - pron - may enter the bloodstream at the site of a localize infection .
pathogen or toxin in the bloodstream can spread rapidly throughout the body and can provoke systemic and sometimes fatal inflammatory response such as sirs , sepsis , and endocarditis .

infections of the lymphatic system can cause lymphangitis and lymphadenitis .
two  five  .  two bacterial infections of the circulatory and lymphatic systems

bacterial infection of the circulatory system be almost universally serious .
leave untreated , most have high mortality rate .

bacterial pathogen usually require a breach in the immune defense to colonize the circulatory system .
most often , this involve a wound or the bite of an arthropod vector , but - pron - can also occur in hospital setting and result in nosocomial infection .

sepsis from both gram - negative and gram - positive bacteria , puerperal fever , rheumatic fever , endocarditis , gas gangrene , osteomyelitis , and toxic shock syndrome be typically a result of injury or introduction of bacteria by medical or surgical intervention .

tularemia , brucellosis , cat - scratch fever , rat - bite fever , and bubonic plague be zoonotic disease transmit by biological vector 
ehrlichiosis , anaplasmosis , endemic and murine typhus , rocky mountain spot fever , lyme disease , relapse fever , and trench fever be transmit by arthropod vector .

because - pron - symptom be so similar to those of other disease , many bacterial infection of the circulatory system be difficult to diagnose .

standard antibiotic therapy be effective for the treatment of most bacterial infection of the circulatory system , unless the bacterium be resistant , in which case synergistic treatment may be require .

the systemic immune response to a bacteremia , which involve the release of excessive amount of cytokine , can sometimes be more damaging to the host than the infection - pron - .
two  five  .  three viral infections of the circulatory and lymphatic systems

human herpesviruse such epstein - barr virus ( hhv -  four ) and cytomegalovirus ( hhv -  five ) be widely distribute .
the former be associate with infectious mononucleosis and burkitt lymphoma , and the latter can cause serious congenital infection as well as serious disease in immunocompromised adult .

arboviral disease such as yellow fever , dengue fever , and chikungunya fever be characterize by high fever and vascular damage that can often be fatal .
ebola virus disease be a highly contagious and often fatal infection spread through contact with bodily fluid .

although there be a vaccine available for yellow fever , treatment for patient with yellow fever , dengue , chikungunya fever , and ebola virus disease be limit to supportive therapy .

patients infect with human immunodeficiency virus ( hiv ) progress through three stage of disease , culminate in aids .
antiretroviral therapy ( art ) use various combination of drug to suppress viral load , extend the period of latency and reduce the likelihood of transmission .
 vector control and animal reservoir control remain the good defense against most virus that cause disease of the circulatory system .
two  five  .  four parasitic infections of the circulatory and lymphatic systems

malaria be a protozoan parasite that remain an important cause of death primarily in the tropic .
several specie in the genus plasmodium be responsible for malaria and all be transmit by anopheles mosquito .
plasmodium infect and destroy human red blood cell , lead to organ damage , anemia , blood vessel necrosis , and death .
malaria can be treat with various antimalarial drug and prevent through vector control .

toxoplasmosis be a widespread protozoal infection that can cause serious infection in the immunocompromised and in develop fetus .
domestic cat be the definitive host .

babesiosis be a generally asymptomatic infection of red blood cell that can cause malaria - like symptom in elderly , immunocompromised , or asplenic patient .
 chagas disease be a tropical disease transmit by triatomine bug .
the trypanosome infect heart , neural tissue , monocyte , and phagocyte , often remain latent for many year before cause serious and sometimes fatal damage to the digestive system and heart .

leishmaniasis be cause by the protozoan leishmania and be transmit by sand fly .
symptom be generally mild , but serious case may cause organ damage , anemia , and loss of immune competence .

schistosomiasis be cause by a fluke transmit by snail .
the fluke move throughout the body in the blood stream and chronically infect various tissue , lead to organ damage .

the name be derive from the latin word for " madness " or " fury , " most likely because animal infect with rabie may behave with uncharacteristic rage and aggression .
and while the thought of be attack by a rabid animal be terrify enough , the disease - pron - be even more frightful .
once symptom appear , the disease be almost always fatal , even when treat .
rabie be an example of a neurological disease cause by an acellular pathogen .
the rabie virus enter nervous tissue shortly after transmission and make - pron - way to the central nervous system , where - pron - presence lead to change in behavior and motor function .
well - know symptom associate with rabid animal include foam at the mouth , hydrophobia ( fear of water ) , and unusually aggressive behavior .
rabie claim ten of thousand of human life worldwide , mainly in africa and asia .
most human case result from dog bite , although many mammal specie can become infected and transmit the disease .
human infection rate be low in the united states and many other country as a result of control measure in animal population .
however , rabie be not the only disease with serious or fatal neurological effect .
in this chapter , - pron - examine the important microbial disease of the nervous system .

nervous system infections one  one  six  nine
two  six  .  one anatomy of the nervous system
learning objectives
 describe the major anatomical feature of the nervous system 
explain why there be no normal microbiota of the nervous system

explain how microorganism overcome defense of the nervous system to cause infection  identify and describe general symptom associate with various infection of the nervous system
the human nervous system can be divide into two interact subsystem  the peripheral nervous system ( pns ) and the central nervous system ( cns ) .
the cns consist of the brain and spinal cord .
the peripheral nervous system be an extensive network of nerve connect the cns to the muscle and sensory structure .
the relationship of these system be illustrate in figure two  six  .  two .
the central nervous system
the brain be the most complex and sensitive organ in the body .
- pron - be responsible for all function of the body , include serve as the coordinate center for all sensation , mobility , emotion , and intellect .
protection for the brain be provide by the bone of the skull , which in turn be cover by the scalp , as show in figure two  six  .  three .
the scalp be compose of an outer layer of skin , which be loosely attach to the aponeurosis , a flat , broad tendon layer that anchor the superficial layer of the skin .
the periosteum , below the aponeurosis , firmly encase the bone of the skull and provide protection , nutrition to the bone , and the capacity for bone repair .
below the boney layer of the skull be three layer of membrane call meninge that surround the brain .
the relative position of these meninge be show in figure two  six  .  three .
the meningeal layer close to the bone of the skull be call the dura mater ( literally mean tough mother ) .
below the dura mater lie the arachnoid mater ( literally spider - like mother ) .
the innermost meningeal layer be a delicate membrane call the pia mater ( literally tender mother ) .
unlike the other meningeal layer , the pia mater firmly adhere to the convolute surface of the brain .
between the arachnoid mater and pia mater be the subarachnoid space .
the subarachnoid space within this region be fill with cerebrospinal fluid ( csf ) .
this watery fluid be produce by cell of the choroid plexus - area in each ventricle of the brain that consist of cuboidal epithelial cell surround dense capillary bed .
the csf serve to deliver nutrient and remove waste from neural tissue .

- pron - physician order a chest x - ray , which reveal consolidation of the right lung .

nervous system infections one  one  seven  one
the blood - brain barrier
the tissue of the cns have extra protection in that - pron - be not expose to blood or the immune system in the same way as other tissue .
the blood vessel that supply the brain with nutrient and other chemical substance lie on top of the pia mater .
the capillary associate with these blood vessel in the brain be less permeable than those in other location in the body .
the capillary endothelial cell form tight junction that control the transfer of blood component to the brain .
in addition , cranial capillary have far few fenestra ( pore - like structure that be seal by a membrane ) and pinocytotic vesicle than other capillary .
as a result , material in the circulatory system have a very limited ability to interact with the cns directly .
this phenomenon be refer to as the blood - brain barrier .
the blood - brain barrier protect the cerebrospinal fluid from contamination , and can be quite effective at exclude potential microbial pathogen .
as a consequence of these defense , there be no normal microbiota in the cerebrospinal fluid .
the blood - brain barrier also inhibit the movement of many drug into the brain , particularly compound that be not lipid soluble .
this have profound ramification for treatment involve infection of the cns , because - pron - be difficult for drug to cross the blood - brain barrier to interact with pathogen that cause infection .
the spinal cord also have protective structure similar to those surround the brain .
within the bone of the vertebrae be meninge of dura mater ( sometimes call the dural sheath ) , arachnoid mater , pia mater , and a blood - spinal cord barrier that control the transfer of blood component from blood vessel associate with the spinal cord .
to cause an infection in the cns , pathogen must successfully breach the blood - brain barrier or blood - spinal cord barrier .
various pathogen employ different virulence factor and mechanism to achieve this , but - pron - can generally be group into four category  intercellular ( also call paracellular ) , transcellular , leukocyte facilitated , and nonhematogenous .
intercellular entry involve the use of microbial virulence factor , toxin , or inflammationmediate process to pass between the cell of the blood - brain barrier .
in transcellular entry , the pathogen pass through the cell of the blood - brain barrier use virulence factor that allow - pron - to adhere to and trigger uptake by vacuole - or receptor - mediate mechanism .
leukocyte - facilitate entry be a trojan - horse mechanism that occur when a pathogen infect peripheral blood leukocyte to directly enter the cns .
nonhematogenous entry allow pathogen to enter the brain without encounter the blood - brain barrier  - pron - occur when pathogen travel along either the olfactory or trigeminal cranial nerve that lead directly into the cns .

the peripheral nervous system
the pns be form of the nerve that connect organ , limb , and other anatomic structure of the body to the brain and spinal cord .
unlike the brain and spinal cord , the pns be not protect by bone , meninge , or a blood barrier , and , as a consequence , the nerve of the pns be much more susceptible to injury and infection .
microbial damage to peripheral nerve can lead to tingling or numbness know as neuropathy .
these symptom can also be produce by trauma and noninfectious cause such as drug or chronic disease like diabete .

the cells of the nervous system tissues of the pns and cns be form of cell call glial cell ( neuroglial cell ) and neuron ( nerve cell ) .
glial cell assist in the organization of neuron , provide a scaffold for some aspect of neuronal function , and aid in recovery from neural injury .
neuron be specialized cell find throughout the nervous system that transmit signal through the nervous system use electrochemical process .
the basic structure of a neuron be show in figure two  six  .  four .
the cell body ( or soma ) be the metabolic center of the neuron and contain the nucleus and most of the cell 's organelle .
the many finely branched extension from the soma be call dendrite .
the soma also produce an elongate extension , call the axon , which be responsible for the transmission of electrochemical signal through elaborate ion transport process .
axon of some type of neuron can extend up to one meter in length in the human body .
to facilitate electrochemical signal transmission , some neuron have a myelin sheath surround the axon .
myelin , form from the cell membrane of glial cell like the schwann cell in the pns and oligodendrocyte in the cns , surround and insulate the axon , significantly increase the speed of electrochemical signal transmission along the axon .
the end of an axon form numerous branch that end in bulb call synaptic terminal .
neuron form junction with other cell , such as another neuron , with which - pron - exchange signal .
the junction , which be actually gap between neuron , be refer to as synapsis .
at each synapse , there be a presynaptic neuron and a postsynaptic neuron ( or other cell ) .
the synaptic terminal of the axon of the presynaptic terminal form the synapse with the dendrite , soma , or sometimes the axon of the postsynaptic neuron , or a part of another type of cell such as a muscle cell .
the synaptic terminal contain vesicle fill with chemical call neurotransmitter .
when the electrochemical signal move down the axon reach the synapse , the vesicle fuse with the membrane , and neurotransmitter be release , which diffuse across the synapse and bind to receptor on the membrane of the postsynaptic cell , potentially initiate a response in that cell .
that response in the postsynaptic cell may include further propagation of an electrochemical signal to transmit information or contraction of a muscle fiber .
figure two  six  .  four ( a )
a myelinate neuron be associate with oligodendrocyte .
oligodendrocyte be a type of glial cell that form the myelin sheath in the cns that insulate the axon so that electrochemical nerve impulse be transfer more efficiently .
( b )
a synapse consist of the axonal end of the presynaptic neuron ( top ) that release neurotransmitter that cross the synaptic space ( or cleft ) and bind to receptor on dendrite of the postsynaptic neuron ( bottom ) .

meningitis and encephalitis
although the skull provide the brain with an excellent defense , - pron - can also become problematic during infection .
any swelling of the brain or meninge that result from inflammation can cause intracranial pressure , lead to severe damage of the brain tissue , which have limit space to expand within the inflexible bone of the skull .
the term meningitis be use to describe an inflammation of the meninge .
typical symptom can include severe headache , fever , photophobia ( increase sensitivity to light ) , stiff neck , convulsion , and confusion .
an inflammation of brain tissue be call encephalitis , and patient exhibit sign and symptom similar to those of meningitis in addition to lethargy , seizure , and personality change .
when inflammation affect both the meninge and the brain tissue , the condition be call meningoencephaliti .
all three form of inflammation be serious and can lead to blindness , deafness , coma , and death .
meningitis and encephalitis can be cause by many different type of microbial pathogen .
however , these condition can also arise from noninfectious cause such as head trauma , some cancer , and certain drug that trigger inflammation .
to determine whether the inflammation be cause by a pathogen , a lumbar puncture be perform to obtain a sample of csf .
if the csf contain increased level of white blood cell and abnormal glucose and protein level , this indicate that the inflammation be a response to an infectioninflinin .

what be the two type of inflammation that can impact the cns ?

why do both form of inflammation have such serious consequence ?
guillain - barré syndrome guillain - barré syndrome ( gbs ) be a rare condition that can be precede by a viral or bacterial infection that result in an autoimmune reaction against myelinate nerve cell .
the destruction of the myelin sheath around these neuron result in a loss of sensation and function .
the first symptom of this condition be tingle and weakness in the affect tissue .
the symptom intensify over a period of several week and can culminate in complete paralysis .
severe case can be life - threaten .
infection by several different microbial pathogen , include campylobacter jejuni ( the most common risk factor ) , cytomegalovirus , epstein - barr virus , varicellazoster virus , mycoplasma pneumoniae , [ one ] and zika virus[ two ] have be identify as trigger for gbs .
anti - myelin antibody from patient with gbs have be demonstrate to also recognize c . jejuni .
- pron - be possible that crossreactive antibody , antibody that react with similar antigenic site on different protein , may be form during an infection and may lead to this autoimmune response .
gbs be solely identify by the appearance of clinical symptom .
there be no other diagnostic test available .
fortunately , most case spontaneously resolve within a few month with few permanent effect , as there be no available vaccine .
gbs can be treat by plasmapheresis .
in this procedure , the patient 's plasma be filter from - pron - blood , remove autoantibody .

learning objectives
 identify the most common bacteria that can cause infection of the nervous system  compare the major characteristic of specific bacterial disease affect the nervous system
bacterial infection that affect the nervous system be serious and can be life - threaten .
fortunately , there be only a few bacterial specie commonly associate with neurological infection .
bacterial meningitis bacterial meningitis be one of the most serious form of meningitis .
bacteria that cause meningitis often gain access to the cns through the bloodstream after trauma or as a result of the action of bacterial toxin .
bacteria may also spread from structure in the upper respiratory tract , such as the oropharynx , nasopharynx , sinus , and middle ear .
patient with head wound or cochlear implant ( an electronic device place in the inner ear ) be also at risk for develop meningitis .
many of the bacteria that can cause meningitis be commonly find in healthy people .
the most common cause of non - neonatal bacterial meningitis be neisseria meningitidis , streptococcus pneumoniae , and haemophilus influenzae .
all three of these bacterial pathogen be spread from person to person by respiratory secretion .
each can colonize and cross through the mucous membrane of the oropharynx and nasopharynx , and enter the blood .
once in the blood , these pathogen can disseminate throughout the body and be capable of both establish an infection and trigger inflammation in any body site , include the meninge ( figure two  six  .  five ) .
without appropriate systemic antibacterial therapy , the case - fatality rate can be as high as seven  zero % , and two  zero % of those survivor may be leave with irreversible nerve damage or tissue destruction , result in hearing loss , neurologic disability , or loss of a limb .
mortality rate be much low ( as low as one  five % ) in population where appropriate therapeutic drug and preventive vaccine be available . [ three ] figure two  six  .  five

nervous system infections one  one  seven  five meningitis .
these bacteria cause infection of the arachnoid mater and csf after spread through the circulation in blood or by spread from an infection of the sinus or nasopharynx .
streptococcus agalactiae , commonly find in the microbiota of the vagina and gastrointestinal tract , can also cause bacterial meningitis in newborn after transmission from the mother either before or during birth .
the profound inflammation cause by these microbe can result in early symptom that include severe headache , fever , confusion , nausea , vomiting , photophobia , and stiff neck .
systemic inflammatory response associate with some type of bacterial meningitis can lead to hemorrhaging and purpuric lesion on skin , follow by even more severe condition that include shock , convulsion , coma , and death - in some case , in the span of just a few hour .
diagnosis of bacterial meningitis be best confirm by analysis of csf obtain by a lumbar puncture .
abnormal level of polymorphonuclear neutrophil ( pmn )
( > one  zero pmn / mm three ) , glucose ( < four  five mg / dl ) , and protein ( > four  five mg / dl ) in the csf be suggestive of bacterial meningitis . [ four ]
characteristics of specific form of bacterial meningitis be detail in the subsection that follow .
meningococcal meningitis meningococcal meningitis be a serious infection cause by the gram - negative coccus n . meningitidis .
in some case , death can occur within a few hour of the onset of symptom .
nonfatal case can result in irreversible nerve damage , result in hear loss and brain damage , or amputation of extremity because of tissue necrosis .
meningococcal meningitis can infect people of any age , but - pron - prevalence be high among infant , adolescent , and young adults . [ five ]
meningococcal meningitis be once the most common cause of meningitis epidemic in human population .
this be still the case in a swath of sub - saharan africa know as the meningitis belt , but meningococcal meningitis epidemic have become rare in most other region , thank to meningococcal vaccine .
however , outbreak can still occur in community , school , college , prison , and other population where people be in close direct contact .
n . meningitidis have a high affinity for mucosal membrane in the oropharynx and nasopharynx .
contact with respiratory secretion contain n . meningitidis be an effective mode of transmission .
the pathogenicity of n . meningitidis be enhance by virulence factor that contribute to the rapid progression of the disease .
these include lipooligosaccharide ( los ) endotoxin , type iv pili for attachment to host tissue , and polysaccharide capsule that help the cell avoid phagocytosis and complement - mediate killing .
additional virulence factor include iga protease ( which break down iga antibody ) , the invasion factor opa , opc , and porin ( which facilitate transcellular entry through the blood - brain barrier ) , iron - uptake factor ( which strip heme unit from hemoglobin in host cell and use - pron - for growth ) , and stress protein that protect bacteria from reactive oxygen molecule .
a unique sign of meningococcal meningitis be the formation of a petechial rash on the skin or mucous membrane , characterize by tiny , red , flat , hemorrhagic lesion .
this rash , which appear soon after disease onset , be a response to los endotoxin and adherence virulence factor that disrupt the endothelial cell of capillary and small vein in the skin .
the blood vessel disruption trigger the formation of tiny blood clot , cause blood to leak into the surround tissue .
as the infection progress , the level of virulence factor increase , and the hemorrhagic lesion can increase in size as blood continue to leak into tissue .
lesion large than one  .  zero cm usually occur in patient develop shock , as virulence factor cause increase hemorrhage and clot formation .
sepsis , as a result of systemic damage from meningococcal virulence factor , can lead to rapid multiple organ failure , shock , disseminate intravascular coagulation , and death .
because meningococcoal meningitis progress so rapidly , a great variety of clinical specimen be require for the timely detection of n . meningitidis .
require specimen can include blood , csf , naso - and oropharyngeal swab , urethral and endocervical swab , petechial aspirate , and biopsy .
safety protocol for handling and transport of specimen suspect of contain n . meningitidis should always be follow , since case of fatal meningococcal four .

pneumococcal meningitis
pneumococcal meningitis be cause by the encapsulate gram - positive bacterium s . pneumoniae ( pneumococcus , also call strep pneumo ) .
this organism be commonly find in the microbiota of the pharynx of three  zero – seven  zero % of young child , depend on the sampling method , while s . pneumoniae can be find in few than five % of healthy adult .
although - pron - be often present without disease symptom , this microbe can cross the blood - brain barrier in susceptible individual .
in some case , - pron - may also result in septicemia .
since the introduction of the hib vaccine , s . pneumoniae have become the lead cause of meningitis in human age two month through adulthood .
s . pneumoniae can be identify in csf sample use gram - stain specimen , latex agglutination , and immunochromatographic rdt specific for s . pneumoniae .
in gram - stain sample , s . pneumoniae appear as grampositive , lancet - shape diplococci ( figure two  six  .  eight ) .
identification of s . pneumoniae can also be achieve use culture of csf and blood , and at least nine  three distinct serotype can be identify base on the quellung reaction to unique capsular polysaccharide .
pcr and rt - pcr assay be also available to confirm identification .
major virulence factor produce by s . pneumoniae include pi -  one pilin for adherence to host cell ( pneumococcal adherence ) and virulence factor b ( pavb ) for attachment to cell of the respiratory tract  choline - bind protein ( cbpa ) that bind to epithelial cell and interfere with immune factor iga and c three  and the cytoplasmic bacterial toxin pneumolysin that trigger an inflammatory response .
with the emergence of drug - resistant strain of s . pneumoniae , pneumococcal meningitis be typically treat with broad - spectrum antibiotic , such as levofloxacin , cefotaxime , penicillin , or other β - lactam antibiotic .
the two available pneumococcal vaccine be describe in bacterial infections of the respiratory tract .

haemophilus influenzae type b meningitis due to h . influenzae serotype b ( hib ) , an encapsulate pleomorphic gram - negative coccobacilli , be now uncommon in most country , because of the use of the effective hib vaccine .
without the use of the hib vaccine , h . influenzae can be the primary cause of meningitis in child two month thru five year of age .
h . influenzae can be find in the throat of healthy individual , include infant and young child .
by five year of age , most child have develop immunity to this microbe .
infant old than two month of age , however , do not produce a sufficient protective antibody response and be susceptible to serious disease .
the intracranial pressure cause by this infection lead to a five % mortality rate and two  zero % incidence of deafness or brain damage in survivors . [ eight ] h . influenzae produce at least one  six different virulence factor , include los , which trigger inflammation , and haemophilus adhesion and penetration factor ( hap ) , which aid in attachment and invasion into respiratory epithelial cell .

 nervous system infections one  one  seven  nine neonatal meningitis s . agalactiae , group b streptococcus ( gbs ) , be an encapsulated gram - positive bacterium that be the most common cause of neonatal meningitis , a term that refer to meningitis occur in baby up to three month of age . [ one  zero ] s . agalactiae can also cause meningitis in people of all age and can be find in the urogenital and gastrointestinal microbiota of about one  zero – three  zero % of human .
neonatal infection occur as either early onset or late - onset disease .
early onset disease be define as occur in infant up to seven day old .
the infant initially become infect by s . agalactiae during childbirth , when the bacteria may be transfer from the mother 's vagina .
incidence of early onset neonatal meningitis can be greatly reduce by give intravenous antibiotic to the mother during labor .
late - onset neonatal meningitis occur in infant between one week and three month of age .
infant bear to mother with s . agalactiae in the urogenital tract have a high risk of late - onset menigitis , but late - onset infection can be transmit from source other than the mother  often , the source of infection be unknown .
infant who be bear prematurely ( before three  seven week of pregnancy ) or to mother who develop a fever also have a great risk of contract late - onset neonatal meningitis .
sign and symptom of early onset disease include temperature instability , apnea ( cessation of breathing ) , bradycardia ( slow heart rate ) , hypotension , difficulty feeding , irritability , and limpness .
when asleep , the baby may be difficult to wake up .
symptom of late - onset disease be more likely to include seizure , bulging fontanel ( soft spot ) , stiff neck , hemiparesis ( weakness on one side of the body ) , and opisthotono ( rigid body with arched back and head throw backward ) .
s . agalactiae produce at least one  two virulence factor that include fbsa
that attach to host cell surface protein , pi -  one pili that promote the invasion of human endothelial cell , a polysaccharide capsule that prevent the activation of the alternative complement pathway and inhibit phagocytosis , and the toxin camp factor , which form pore in host cell membrane and bind to igg and igm antibody .
diagnosis of neonatal meningitis be often , but not uniformly , confirm by positive result from culture of csf or blood .
test include routine culture , antigen detection by enzyme immunoassay , serotyping of different capsule type , pcr , and rt - pcr .
- pron - be typically treat with β - lactam antibiotic such as intravenous penicillin or ampicillin plus gentamicin .
even with treatment , roughly one  zero % mortality be see in infect neonates . [ one  one ]

this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five neurotoxin ( tent ) .
these two toxin have lethal dos of zero  .  two – one  zero ng per kg body weight .
bont can be produce by unique strain of c . butyricum , and c . baratii  however , - pron - be primarily associate with c . botulinum and the condition of botulism .
tent , which cause tetanus , be only produce by c . tetani .
these powerful neural exotoxin be the primary virulence factor for these pathogen .
the mode of action for these toxin be describe in virulence factors of bacterial and viral pathogens and illustrate in figure one  five  .  one  six .
diagnosis of tetanus or botulism typically involve bioassay that detect the presence of bont and tent in fecal specimen , blood ( serum ) , or suspect food .
in addition , both c . botulinum and c . tetani can be isolate and culture use commercially available medium for anaerobe .
elisa and rt - pcr test be also available .
tetanus tetanus be a noncommunicable disease characterize by uncontrollable muscle spasm ( contraction ) cause by the action of tent .
- pron - generally occur when c . tetani infect a wound and produce tent , which rapidly bind to neural tissue , result in an intoxication ( poisoning ) of neuron .
depend on the site and extent of infection , case of tetanus can be describe as localized , cephalic , or generalize .
generalize tetanus that occur in a newborn be call neonatal tetanus .
localized tetanus occur when tent only affect the muscle group close to the injury site .
there be no cns involvement , and the symptom be usually mild , with localized muscle spasm cause by a dysfunction in the surround neuron .
individual with partial immunity - especially previously vaccinate individual who neglect to get the recommend booster shot - be most likely to develop localized tetanus as a result of c . tetani infect a puncture wound .
cephalic tetanus be a rare , localized form of tetanus generally associate with wound on the head or face .
in rare case , - pron - have occur in case of otitis medium ( middle ear infection ) .
cephalic tetanus often result in patient see double image , because of the spasm affect the muscle that control eye movement .
both localized and cephalic tetanus may progress to generalize tetanus - a much more serious condition - if tent be able to spread further into body tissue .
in generalize tetanus , tent enter neuron of the pns .
from there , tent travel from the site of the wound , usually on an extremity of the body , retrograde ( back up ) to inhibitory neuron in the cns .
there , - pron - prevent the release of gamma aminobutyric acid ( gaba ) , the neurotransmitter responsible for muscle relaxation .
the result muscle spasm often first occur in the jaw muscle , lead to the characteristic symptom of lockjaw ( inability to open the mouth ) .
as the toxin progressively continue to block neurotransmitter release , other muscle become involved , result in uncontrollable , sudden muscle spasm that be powerful enough to cause tendon to rupture and bone to fracture .
spasm in the muscle in the neck , back , and leg may cause the body to form a rigid , stiff arch , a posture call opisthotono ( figure two  six  .  nine ) .
spasm in the larynx , diaphragm , and muscle of the chest restrict the patient 's ability to swallow and breathe , eventually lead to death by asphyxiation ( insufficient supply of oxygen ) .
neonatal tetanus typically occur when the stump of the umbilical cord be contaminate with spore of c . tetani after delivery .
although this condition be rare in the united states , neonatal tetanus be a major cause of infant mortality in country that lack maternal immunization for tetanus and where birth often occur in unsanitary condition .
at the end of the first week of life , infected infant become irritable , feed poorly , and develop rigidity with spasm .
neonatal tetanus have a very poor prognosis with a mortality rate of seven  zero %– one  zero  zero % . [ one  two ] treatment for patient with tetanus include assist breathing through the use of a ventilator , wound debridement , fluid balance , and antibiotic therapy with metronidazole or penicillin to halt the growth of c . tetani .
in addition , patient be treat with tent antitoxin , preferably in the form of human immunoglobulin to neutralize nonfixed toxin and benzodiazepine to enhance the effect of gaba for muscle relaxation and anxiety .
a tetanus toxoid ( tt ) vaccine be available for protection and prevention of tetanus .
- pron - be the t component of vaccine such as dtap , tdap , and td .
the cdc recommend child receive dos of the dtap vaccine at two , four , six , and one  five – one  eight one  two .

botulism botulism be a rare but frequently fatal illness cause by intoxication by bont .
- pron - can occur either as the result of an infection by c . botulinum , in which case the bacteria produce bont in vivo , or as the result of a direct introduction of bont into tissue .
infection and production of bont in vivo can result in wound botulism , infant botulism , and adult intestinal toxemia .
wound botulism typically occur when c . botulinum be introduce directly into a wound after a traumatic injury , deep puncture wound , or injection site .
infant botulism , which occur in infant young than one year of age , and adult intestinal toxemia , which occur in immunocompromised adult , result from ingest c . botulinum endospore in food .
the endospore germinate in the body , result in the production of bont in the intestinal tract .
intoxication occur when bont be produce outside the body and then introduce directly into the body through food ( foodborne botulism ) , air ( inhalation botulism ) , or a clinical procedure ( iatrogenic botulism ) .
foodborne botulism , the most common of these form , occur when bont be produce in contaminate food and then ingest along with the food ( recall case in point 
a streak of bad potluck ) .
inhalation botulism be rare because bont be unstable as an aerosol and do not occur in nature  however , - pron - can be produce in the laboratory and be use ( unsuccessfully ) as a bioweapon by terrorist in japan in the one  nine  nine  zero .
a few case of accidental inhalation botulism have also occur .
iatrogenic botulism be also rare  - pron - be associate with injection of bont use for cosmetic purpose ( see micro connections 
medicinal use of botulinum toxin ) .
when bont enter the bloodstream in the gastrointestinal tract , wound , or lung , - pron - be transfer to the neuromuscular junction of motor neuron where - pron - bind irreversibly to presynaptic membrane and prevent the release of acetylcholine from the presynaptic terminal of motor neuron into the neuromuscular junction .
the consequence of prevent acetylcholine release be the loss of muscle activity , lead to muscle relaxation and eventually paralysis .
if bont be absorb through the gastrointestinal tract , early symptom of botulism include blur vision , droop eyelid , difficulty swallowing , abdominal cramp , nausea , vomiting , constipation , or possibly diarrhea .
this be follow by progressive flaccid paralysis , a gradual weakening and loss of control over the muscle .
a patient 's experience can be particularly terrify , because hearing remain normal , consciousness be not lose , and - pron - or - pron - be one  three .

in infant , notable sign of botulism include weak cry , decrease ability to suckle , and hypotonia ( limpness of head or body ) .
eventually , botulism end in death from respiratory failure cause by the progressive paralysis of the muscle of the upper airway , diaphragm , and chest .
botulism be treat with an antitoxin specific for bont .
if administer in time , the antitoxin stop the progression of paralysis but do not reverse - pron - .
once the antitoxin have be administer , the patient will slowly regain neurological function , but this may take several week or month , depend on the severity of the case .
during recovery , patient generally must remain hospitalized and receive breathing assistance through a ventilator .

medicinal use of botulinum toxin
although - pron - be the most toxic biological material know to man , botulinum toxin be often intentionally inject into people to treat other condition .
type a botulinum toxin be use cosmetically to reduce wrinkle .
the injection of minute quantity of this toxin into the face cause the relaxation of facial muscle , thereby give the skin a smooth appearance .
eyelid twitch and cross eye can also be treat with botulinum toxin injection .
other use of this toxin include the treatment of hyperhidrosis ( excessive sweating ) .
in fact , botulinum toxin can be use to moderate the effect of several other apparently nonmicrobial disease involve inappropriate nerve function .
such disease include cerebral palsy , multiple sclerosis , and parkinson 's disease .
each of these disease be characterize by a loss of control over muscle contraction  treatment with botulinum toxin serve to relax contract muscle .
listeriosis listeria monocytogene be a nonencapsulated , nonsporulate , gram - positive rod and a foodborne pathogen that cause listeriosis .
at - risk group include pregnant woman , neonate , the elderly , and the immunocompromised ( recall the clinical focus case study in microbial growth and microbial mechanisms of pathogenicity ) .
listeriosis lead to meningitis in about two  zero % of case , particularly neonate and patient over the age of six  zero .
the cdc identifie listeriosis as the third lead cause of death due to foodborne illness , with overall mortality rate reach one  six % . [ one  four ]
in pregnant woman , listeriosis can cause also cause spontaneous abortion in pregnant woman because of the pathogen 's unique ability to cross the placenta .
l . monocytogene be generally introduce into food item by contamination with soil or animal manure use as fertilizer .
food commonly associate with listeriosis include fresh fruit and vegetable , frozen vegetable , process meat , soft cheese , and raw milk . [ one  five ]
unlike most other foodborne pathogen , listeria be able to grow at temperature between zero ° c and five  zero ° c , and can therefore continue to grow , even in refrigerated food .

hansen 's disease ( leprosy ) hansen 's disease ( also know as leprosy ) be cause by a long , thin , filamentous rod - shape bacterium mycobacterium leprae , an obligate intracellular pathogen .
m . leprae be classify as gram - positive bacteria , but - pron - be best visualize microscopically with an acid - fast stain and be generally refer to as an acid - fast bacterium .
hansen 's disease affect the pns , lead to permanent damage and loss of appendage or other body part .
one  one  eight  four chapter two  six

this openstax book be available for free at http / / cnx . org / content / col one  two  zero  eight  seven  /  one  .  five hansen 's disease be communicable but not highly contagious  approximately nine  five % of the human population can not be easily infect because - pron - have a natural immunity to m . leprae .
person - to - person transmission occur by inhalation into nasal mucosa or prolong and repeat contact with infected skin .
armadillos , one of only five mammal susceptible to hansen 's disease , have also be implicate in transmission of some cases . [ one  six ]
in the human body , m . leprae grow good at the cooler temperature find in peripheral tissue like the nose , toe , finger , and ear .
some of the virulence factor that contribute to m . leprae 's pathogenicity be locate on the capsule and cell wall of the bacterium .
these virulence factor enable - pron - to bind to and invade schwann cell , result in progressive demyelination that gradually destroy neuron of the pns .
the loss of neuronal function lead to hypoesthesia ( numbness ) in infected lesion .
m . leprae be readily phagocytize by macrophage but be able to survive within macrophage in part by neutralize reactive oxygen specie produce in the oxidative burst of the phagolysosome .
like l . monocytogene , m . leprae also can move directly between macrophage to avoid clearance by immune factor .
the extent of the disease be relate to the immune response of the patient .
initial symptom may not appear for as long as two to five year after infection .
these often begin with small , blanched , numb area of the skin .
in most individual , these will resolve spontaneously , but some case may progress to a more serious form of the disease .
tuberculoid ( paucibacillary )
hansen 's disease be mark by the presence of relatively few ( three or less ) flat , blanched skin lesion with small nodule at the edge and few bacteria present in the lesion .
although these lesion can persist for year or decade , the bacteria be hold in check by an effective immune response include cell - mediate cytotoxicity .
individual who be unable to contain the infection may later develop lepromatous ( multibacillary ) hansen 's disease .
this be a progressive form of the disease characterize by nodule fill with acid - fast bacilli and macrophage .
impaired function of infected schwann cell lead to peripheral nerve damage , result in sensory loss that lead to ulcer , deformity , and fracture .
damage to the ulnar nerve ( in the wrist ) by m . leprae be one of the most common cause of crippling of the hand .
in some case , chronic tissue damage can ultimately lead to loss of finger or toe .
when mucosal tissue be also involve , disfigure lesion of the nose and face can also occur ( figure two  six  .  one  one ) .
hansen 's disease be diagnose on the basis of clinical sign and symptom of the disease , and confirm by the presence of acid - fast bacilli on skin smear or in skin biopsy specimen ( figure two  six  .  one  one ) .
m . leprae do not grow in vitro on any know laboratory medium , but - pron - can be identify by culture in vivo in the footpad of laboratory mouse or armadillo .
where need , pcr and genotyping of m . leprae dna in infect human tissue may be perform for diagnosis and epidemiology .
hansen 's disease respond well to treatment and , if diagnose and treat early , do not cause disability .
in the united states , most patient with hansen 's disease be treat in ambulatory care clinic in major city by the national hansen 's disease program , the only institution in the united states exclusively devoted to hansen 's disease .
since one  nine  nine  five , who have make multidrug therapy for hansen 's disease available free of charge to all patient worldwide .
as a result , global prevalence of hansen 's disease have decline from about five  .  two million case in one  nine  eight  five to roughly one  seven  six  ,  zero  zero  zero in two  zero  one  four  . [ one  seven ]
multidrug therapy consist of dapsone and rifampicin for all patient and a third drug , clofazimin , for patient with multibacillary disease .
currently , there be no universally accept vaccine for hansen 's disease .
india and brazil use a tuberculosis vaccine against hansen 's disease because both disease be cause by specie of mycobacterium .
the effectiveness of this method be questionable , however , since - pron - appear that the vaccine work in some population but not in other .

leper colonies disfiguring , deadly disease like leprosy have historically be stigmatize in many culture .
before leprosy be understand , victim be often isolate in leper colony , a practice mention frequently in ancient text , include the bible .
but leper colony be not just an artifact of the ancient world .
in hawaii , a leper colony establish in the late nineteenth century persist until the mid - twentieth century , - pron - resident force to live in deplorable conditions . [ one  eight ]
although leprosy be a communicable disease , - pron - be not consider contagious ( easily communicable ) , and - pron - certainly do not pose enough of a threat to justify the permanent isolation of - pron - victim .
today , - pron - reserve the practice of isolation and quarantine to patient with more dangerous disease , such as ebola or multiple - drug - resistant bacteria like mycobacterium tuberculosis and staphylococcus aureus .
the ethical argument for this practice be that isolate infect patient be necessary to prevent the transmission and spread of highly contagious disease - even when - pron - go against the wish of the patient .
of course , - pron - be much easy to justify the practice of temporary , clinical quarantining than permanent social segregation , as occur in leper colony .
in the one  nine  eight  zero , there be call by some group to establish camp for people infect with aids .
although this idea be never actually implement , - pron - beg the question - where do - pron - draw the line ?
be permanent isolation camp or colony ever medically or socially justifiable ?
suppose there be an outbreak of a fatal , contagious disease for which there be no treatment .
would - pron - be justifiable to impose social isolation on those afflict with the disease ?
how would - pron - balance the right of the infect with the risk - pron - pose to other ?
to what extent should society expect individual to put - pron - own health at risk for the sake of treat other humanely ?

learning objectives
 identify the most common acellular pathogen that can cause infection of the nervous system  compare the major characteristic of specific viral disease affect the nervous system
a number of different virus and subviral particle can cause disease that affect the nervous system .
viral disease tend to be more common than bacterial infection of the nervous system today .
fortunately , viral infection be generally mild than - pron - bacterial counterpart and often spontaneously resolve .
some of the more important acellular pathogen of the nervous system be describe in this section .
viral meningitis
although - pron - be much more common than bacterial meningitis , viral meningitis be typically less severe .
many different virus can lead to meningitis as a sequela of the primary infection , include those that cause herpe , influenza , measle , and mump .
most case of viral meningitis spontaneously resolve , but severe case do occur .
arboviral encephalitis several type of insect - bear virus can cause encephalitis .
collectively , these virus be refer to as arbovirus ( because - pron - be arthropod - borne ) , and the disease - pron - cause be describe as arboviral encephalitis .
most arbovirus be endemic to specific geographical region .
arborviral encephalitis disease find in the united states include eastern equine encephalitis ( eee ) , western equine encephalitis ( wee ) , st . louis encephalitis , and west nile encephalitis ( wne ) .
expansion of arbovirus beyond - pron - endemic region sometimes occur , generally as a result of environmental change that be favorable to the virus or - pron - vector .
increase travel of infected human , animal , or vector have also allow arbovirus to spread into new region .
in most case , arboviral infection be asymptomatic or lead to a mild disease .
however , when symptom do occur , - pron - include high fever , chill , headache , vomiting , diarrhea , and restlessness .
in elderly patient , severe arboviral encephalitis can rapidly lead to convulsion , coma , and death .
mosquito be the most common biological vector for arbovirus , which tend to be envelop ssrna virus .
thus , prevention of arboviral infection be best achieve by avoid mosquito - use insect repellent , wear long pant and sleeve , sleep in well - screen room , use bed net , etc .
diagnosis of arboviral encephalitis be base on clinical symptom and serologic testing of serum or csf .
there be no antiviral drug to treat any of these arboviral disease , so treatment consist of supportive care and management of symptom .
eastern equine encephalitis ( eee ) be cause by eastern equine encephalitis virus ( eeev ) , which can cause severe disease in horse and human .
bird be reservoir for eeev with accidental transmission to horse and human by aedes , coquillettidia , and culex specie of mosquito .
neither horse nor human serve as reservoir .
eee be most common in us gulf coast and atlantic state .
eee be one of the more severe mosquito - transmit disease in the united states , but fortunately , - pron - be a very rare disease in the united states ( figure two  six  .  one  three  ) . [ one  nine ][ two  zero ] western equine encephalitis ( wee ) be cause by western equine encephalitis virus ( weev ) .
weev be usually transmit to horse and human by the culex tarsalis mosquito and , in the past decade , have cause very few case of encephalitis in human in the united states .
in human , wee symptom be less severe than eee and include one  nine .

zika virus infection zika virus infection be an emerge arboviral disease associate with human illness in africa , southeast asia , and south and central america  however , - pron - range be expand as a result of the widespread range of - pron - mosquito vector .

rabies rabies be a deadly zoonotic disease that have be know since antiquity .
the disease be cause by rabie virus ( rv ) , a member of the family rhabdoviridae , and be primarily transmit through the bite of an infected mammal .
rhabdoviridae be envelop rna virus that have a distinctive bullet shape ( figure two  six  .  one  five )  - pron - be first study two  five .
